When she (Kitty) had got round the turn, she (Kitty) gave herself a push off with one foot, and skated straight up to Shtcherbatsky.

A boy in Russian dress, desperately waving his (boy) arms and bowed down to the ground, overtook her (Kitty). Clutching at his (boy) arm, she (Kitty) nodded smiling to Levin.

When he (Levin) thought of her (Kitty), he (Levin) could call up a vivid picture of her (Kitty) to himself, especially the charm of that little fair head, so freely set on the shapely girlish shoulders, and so full of childish brightness and good humor.

The childishness of her (Kitty) expression, together with the delicate beauty of her (Kitty) figure, made up her (Kitty) special charm, and that he (Levin) fully realized.

But what always struck him (Levin) in her (Kitty) as something unlooked for, was the expression of her (Kitty) eyes, soft, serene, and truthful, and above all, her (Kitty) smile, which always transported Levin to an enchanted world, where he (Levin) felt himself softened and tender, as he (Levin) remembered himself in some days of his (Levin) early childhood.

She (Kitty) was more splendid than he (Levin) had imagined her (Kitty). '' Have you been here long? '' she (Kitty) said, giving him (Levin) her (Kitty) hand.

'' Thank you,'' she (Kitty) added, as he (Levin) picked up the handkerchief that had fallen out of her (Kitty) muff. '' I? I've not long...yesterday...

I was meaning to come and see you,'' he (Levin) said; and then, recollecting with what intention he (Levin) was trying to see her (Kitty), he (Levin) was promptly overcome with confusion and blushed.

I mean today... I arrived,'' answered Levin, in his (Levin) emotion not at once understanding her (Kitty) question. '' '' I didn't know you could skate, and skate so well.

'' She (Kitty) looked at him (Levin) earnestly, as though wishing to make out the cause of his (Levin) confusion. '' Your praise is worth having.

The tradition is kept up here that you are the best of skaters,'' she (Kitty) said, with her (Kitty) little black-gloved hand brushing a grain of hoarfrost off her (Kitty) muff.

'' Yes, I used once to skate with passion; I wanted to reach perfection.''

``You do everything with passion, I think,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said smiling.

'' I should so like to see how you skate. Put on skates, and let us skate together. ''

``Skate together!

Can that be possible?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

thought Levin, gazing at her (Kitty). '' I'll put them on directly,'' he (Levin) said. And he (Levin) went off to get skates.

It's a long while since we've seen you here, sir,'' said the attendant, supporting his (attendant) foot, and screwing on the heel of the skate.

'' '' Except you, there's none of the gentlemen first-rate skaters. Will that be all right? '' said he (attendant), tightening the strap.

'' Oh, yes, yes; make haste, please,'' answered Levin, with difficulty restraining the smile of rapture which would overspread his (Levin) face.

'' Yes,'' he (Levin) thought,

``this now is life, this is happiness! Together, she (attendant) said; let us skate together! Speak to her (attendant) now?

But that's just why I'm afraid to speak--because I'm happy now, happy in hope, anyway .... And then?.... But I must!

Levin rose to his (Levin) feet, took off his (Levin) overcoat, and scurrying over the rough ice round the hut, came out on the smooth ice and skated without effort, as it were, by simple exercise of will, increasing and slackening speed and turning his (Levin) course.

She (attendant) gave him (Levin) her (attendant) hand, and they set off side by side, going faster and faster, and the more rapidly they moved the more tightly she (attendant) grasped his (Levin) hand.

I must! I must! Away with weakness! '' (he)

He (Levin) approached with timidity, but again her (attendant) smile reassured him (Levin). '' With you I should soon learn; I somehow feel confidence in you,'' she (attendant) said to him (Levin).

And I have confidence in myself when you are leaning on me,'' he (Levin) said, but was at once panic-stricken at what he (Levin) had said, and blushed.

And indeed, no sooner had he (Levin) uttered these words, when all at once, like the sun going behind a cloud, her (attendant) face lost all its friendliness, and Levin detected the familiar change in her (attendant) expression that denoted the working of thought; a crease showed on her (attendant) smooth brow.

'' '' Is there anything troubling you?--though I've no right to ask such a question,'' he (Levin) added hurriedly. '' Oh, why so?

.... No, I have nothing to trouble me,'' she (attendant) responded coldly; and she (attendant) added immediately:

``You haven't seen Mlle. Linon, have you?'' (she)

``Not yet. '' (unknown)
``Go and speak to her (attendant), she (attendant) likes you so much.'' (unknown)
'' What's wrong? I have offended her (attendant). Lord help me!

'' thought Levin, and he (Levin) flew towards the old Frenchwoman with the gray ringlets, who was sitting on a bench. Smiling and showing her (Frenchwoman) false teeth, she (Frenchwoman) greeted him (Levin) as an old friend.

Tiny bear has grown big now!'' pursued the Frenchwoman, laughing, and she (Frenchwoman) reminded him (Levin) of his (Levin) joke about the three young ladies whom he (Levin) had compared to the three bears in the English nursery tale.

'' Yes, you see we're growing up,'' she (Frenchwoman) said to him (Levin), glancing towards Kitty,

``and growing old. '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Do you remember that's what you used to call them?''

He (Levin) remembered absolutely nothing, but she (Kitty) had been laughing at the joke for ten years now, and was fond of it.

When Levin darted up to Kitty her (Kitty) face was no longer stern; her (Kitty) eyes looked at him (Levin) with the same sincerity and friendliness, but Levin fancied that in her (Kitty) friendliness there was a certain note of deliberate composure.

'' Now, go and skate, go and skate. Our Kitty has learned to skate nicely, hasn't she (Kitty)? '' And he (Levin) felt depressed.

After talking a little of her (Kitty) old governess and her (Kitty) peculiarities, she (Kitty) questioned him (Levin) about his (Levin) life. '' Surely you must be dull in the country in the winter, aren't you?

No, I'm not dull, I am very busy,'' he (Levin) said, feeling that she (Kitty) was holding him (Levin) in check by her (Kitty) composed tone, which he (Levin) would not have the force to break through, just as it had been at the beginning of the winter.

'' she (Kitty) said. '' '' Are you going to stay in town long?'' Kitty questioned him (Levin). '' I don't know,'' he (Levin) answered, not thinking of what he (Levin) was saying.

The thought that if he (Levin) were held in check by her (Kitty) tone of quiet friendliness he (Levin) would end by going back again without deciding anything came into his (Levin) mind, and he (Levin) resolved to make a struggle against it.

'' How is it you don't know?''

``I don't know. It depends upon you,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, and was immediately horror-stricken at his (Levin) own words.

Whether it was that she (Kitty) had heard his (Levin) words, or that she (Kitty) did not want to hear them, she (Kitty) made a sort of stumble, twice struck out, and hurriedly skated away from him (Levin).

She (Kitty) skated up to Mlle. Linon, said something to her (Kitty), and went towards the pavilion where the ladies took off their skates.

Merciful God! help me, guide me,'' said Levin, praying inwardly, and at the same time, feeling a need of violent exercise, he (Levin) skated about describing inner and outer circles.

At that moment one of the young men, the best of the skaters of the day, came out of the coffee-house in his (Levin) skates, with a cigarette in his (Levin) mouth.

'' My God! what have I done! Taking a run, he (God) dashed down the steps in his (God) skates, crashing and bounding up and down.

He (God) flew down, and without even changing the position of his (God) hands, skated away over the ice. '' Ah, that's a new trick!'' said Levin, and he (Levin) promptly ran up to the top to do this new trick.

Levin went to the steps, took a run from above as best he (Levin) could, and dashed down, preserving his (Levin) balance in this unwonted movement with his (Levin) hands.

On the last step he (Levin) stumbled, but barely touching the ice with his (Levin) hand, with a violent effort recovered himself, and skated off, laughing.

'' Don't break your neck! it needs practice!'' Nikolay Shtcherbatsky shouted after him (Levin). '' How splendid, how nice he (Levin) is!'' Kitty was thinking at that time, as she (Kitty) came out of the pavilion with Mlle.

Linon, and looked towards him (Levin) with a smile of quiet affection, as though he (Levin) were a favorite brother. '' And can it be my fault, can I have done anything wrong?

They talk of flirtation. I know it's not he (Levin) that I love; but still I am happy with him (Levin), and he (Levin)'s so jolly.

Catching sight of Kitty going away, and her (Kitty) mother meeting her (Kitty) at the steps, Levin, flushed from his (Levin) rapid exercise, stood still and pondered a minute.

Only, why did he (Levin) say that?... '' she (Kitty) mused. He (Levin) took off his (Levin) skates, and overtook the mother and daughter at the entrance of the gardens.

'' Delighted to see you,'' said Princess Shtcherbatskaya. '' On Thursdays we are home, as always. '' '' Today, then?''

``We shall be pleased to see you,'' (the princess)
the princess said stiffly.

This stiffness hurt Kitty, and she (Kitty) could not resist the desire to smooth over her (Kitty) mother's coldness. She (Kitty) turned her (Kitty) head, and with a smile said:

``Good-bye till this evening.

At that moment Stepan Arkadyevitch, his (Levin) hat cocked on one side, with beaming face and eyes, strode into the garden like a conquering hero.

'' (She)

But as he (hero) approached his (hero) mother-in-law, he (hero) responded in a mournful and crestfallen tone to her (mother-in-law) inquiries about Dolly's health.

After a little subdued and dejected conversation with his (hero) mother-in-law, he (hero) threw out his (hero) chest again, and put his (hero) arm in Levin's.

I've been thinking about you all this time, and I'm very, very glad you've come,'' he (hero) said, looking him (hero) in the face with a significant air.

Yes, come along,'' answered Levin in ecstasy, hearing unceasingly the sound of that voice saying,

``Good-bye till this evening,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
and seeing the smile with which it was said.

'' Well, shall we set off? '' he (Levin) asked. '' '' '' To the England or the Hermitage? ''

``I don't mind which.

All right, then, the England,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, selecting that restaurant because he (Levin) owed more there than at the Hermitage, and consequently considered it mean to avoid it.

'' '' '' Have you got a sledge? That's first-rate, for I sent my carriage home. '' The friends hardly spoke all the way.

Levin was wondering what that change in Kitty's expression had meant, and alternately assuring himself that there was hope, and falling into despair, seeing clearly that his (Levin) hopes were insane, and yet all the while he (Levin) felt himself quite another man, utterly unlike what he (Levin) had been before her (Kitty) smile and those words,

``Good-bye till this evening.

'' (he)

Stepan Arkadyevitch was absorbed during the drive in composing the menu of the dinner. '' You like turbot, don't you?

'' he (Levin) said to Levin as they were arriving. '' Eh?'' responded Levin. '' Turbot? Yes, I'm awfully fond of turbot.

When Levin went into the restaurant with Oblonsky, he (Levin) could not help noticing a certain peculiarity of expression, as it were, a restrained radiance, about the face and whole figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Oblonsky took off his (Levin) overcoat, and with his (Levin) hat over one ear walked into the dining room, giving directions to the Tatar waiters, who were clustered about him (Levin) in evening coats, bearing napkins.

Bowing to right and left to the people he (Levin) met, and here as everywhere joyously greeting acquaintances, he (Levin) went up to the sideboard for a preliminary appetizer of fish and vodka, and said to the painted Frenchwoman decked in ribbons, lace, and ringlets, behind the counter, something so amusing that even that Frenchwoman was moved to genuine laughter.

Levin for his (Levin) part refrained from taking any vodka simply because he (Levin) felt such a loathing of that Frenchwoman, all made up, it seemed, of false hair, poudre de riz, and vinaigre de toilette .

His (Levin) whole soul was filled with memories of Kitty, and there was a smile of triumph and happiness shining in his (Levin) eyes.

'' Chapter 10 He (Levin) made haste to move away from her (Kitty), as from a dirty place. '' This way, your excellency, please.

Your excellency won't be disturbed here,'' said a particularly pertinacious, white-headed old Tatar with immense hips and coat-tails gaping widely behind.

``Walk in, your excellency,'' (he)
he (Tatar) said to Levin; by way of showing his (Levin) respect to Stepan Arkadyevitch, being attentive to his (Levin) guest as well.

Instantly flinging a fresh cloth over the round table under the bronze chandelier, though it already had a table cloth on it, he (Levin) pushed up velvet chairs, and came to a standstill before Stepan Arkadyevitch with a napkin and a bill of fare in his (Levin) hands, awaiting his (Levin) commands.

'' If you prefer it, your excellency, a private room will be free directly; Prince Golistin with a lady. Fresh oysters have come in.''

``Ah! oysters. '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
Stepan Arkadyevitch became thoughtful. '' How if we were to change our program, Levin? '' he (Levin) said, keeping his (Levin) finger on the bill of fare.

And his (Levin) face expressed serious hesitation. '' Are the oysters good? Mind now. '' '' They're Flensburg, your excellency. We've no Ostend.''

``Flensburg will do, but are they fresh?'' (unknown)
``Only arrived yesterday.'' (unknown)
'' Well, then, how if we were to begin with oysters, and so change the whole program?

Eh?'' '' It's all the same to me. I should like cabbage soup and porridge better than anything; but of course there's nothing like that here.''

'' Porridge √† la Russe, your honor would like?'' said the Tatar, bending down to Levin, like a nurse speaking to a child.

``that I shan't appreciate your choice.

I am fond of good things. '' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' Well, then, my friend, you give us two--or better say three--dozen oysters, clear soup with vegetables...''

With vegetables in it, you know. Then turbot with thick sauce, then...roast beef; and mind it's good. Yes, and capons, perhaps, and then sweets.

Oh, yes, Parmesan. Or would you like another?'' '' No, it's all the same to me,'' said Levin, unable to suppress a smile.

And the Tatar ran off with flying coat-tails, and in five minutes darted in with a dish of opened oysters on mother-of-pearl shells, and a bottle between his (Tatar) fingers.

Stepan Arkadyevitch crushed the starchy napkin, tucked it into his (Tatar) waistcoat, and settling his (Tatar) arms comfortably, started on the oysters. ''

Not bad,'' he (Tatar) said, stripping the oysters from the pearly shell with a silver fork, and swallowing them one after another.

'' Not bad,'' he (Tatar) repeated, turning his (Tatar) dewy, brilliant eyes from Levin to the Tatar. Levin ate the oysters indeed, though white bread and cheese would have pleased him (Levin) better.

Even the Tatar, uncorking the bottle and pouring the sparkling wine into the delicate glasses, glanced at Stepan Arkadyevitch, and settled his (Tatar) white cravat with a perceptible smile of satisfaction.

But he (Tatar) was admiring Oblonsky. '' You don't care much for oysters, do you?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, emptying his (Tatar) wine glass,

``or you're worried about something.

Eh? '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

He (Tatar) wanted Levin to be in good spirits. But it was not that Levin was not in good spirits; he (Levin) was ill at ease.

With what he (Levin) had in his (Levin) soul, he (Levin) felt sore and uncomfortable in the restaurant, in the midst of private rooms where men were dining with ladies, in all this fuss and bustle; the surroundings of bronzes, looking glasses, gas, and waiters--all of it was offensive to him (Levin).

He (Levin) was afraid of sullying what his (Levin) soul was brimful of. '' I? Yes, I am; but besides, all this bothers me,'' he (Levin) said.

You can't conceive how queer it all seems to a country person like me, as queer as that gentleman's nails I saw at your place...

'' ''

``Yes, I saw how much interested you were in poor Grinevitch's nails,'' (I)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing. '' It's too much for me,'' responded Levin.

We in the country try to bring our hands into such a state as will be most convenient for working with.

'' Do try, now, and put yourself in my place, take the point of view of a country person. So we cut our nails; sometimes we turn up our sleeves.

And here people purposely let their nails grow as long as they will, and link on small saucers by way of studs, so that they can do nothing with their hands.

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled gaily. '' Oh, yes, that's just a sign that he (our) has no need to do coarse work.

But still it's queer to me, just as at this moment it seems queer to me that we country folks try to get our meals over as soon as we can, so as to be ready for our work, while here are we trying to drag out our meal as long as possible, and with that object eating oysters...''

His (our) work is with the mind... '' ``Maybe.

``Why, of course,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
objected Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' But that's just the aim of civilization--to make everything a source of enjoyment.''

'' Well, if that's its aim, I'd rather be a savage.'' '' And so you are a savage. All you Levins are savages.

He (Levins) remembered his (Levins) brother Nikolay, and felt ashamed and sore, and he (Levins) scowled; but Oblonsky began speaking of a subject which at once drew his (Levins) attention.

'' Levin sighed. '' Oh, I say, are you going tonight to our people, the Shtcherbatskys', I mean? '' he (Levin) said, his (Levin) eyes sparkling significantly as he (Levin) pushed away the empty rough shells, and drew the cheese towards him (Levin).

'' Yes, I shall certainly go,'' replied Levin;

``though I fancied the princess was not very warm in her (princess) invitation.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
``What nonsense!

That's her (princess) manner.... Come, boy, the soup! .... That's her (princess) manner-- grande dame, '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' I'm coming, too, but I have to go to the Countess Bonina's rehearsal.

Come, isn't it true that you're a savage? How do you explain the sudden way in which you vanished from Moscow?

The Shtcherbatskys were continually asking me about you, as though I ought to know. The only thing I know is that you always do what no one else does.''

'' Yes,'' said Levin, slowly and with emotion,

``you're right. I am a savage. Only, my savageness is not in having gone away, but in coming now.

Now I have come...'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' Oh, what a lucky fellow you are! '' broke in Stepan Arkadyevitch, looking into Levin's eyes.

``I know a gallant steed by tokens sure, And by his (Levin) eyes I know a youth in love,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
declaimed Stepan Arkadyevitch.

No; not over exactly, but the future is yours, and the present is mine, and the present--well, it's not all that it might be.

'' Everything is before you.''
``Why, is it over for you already?'' (unknown)
'' ''

'' Oh, things go wrong.

But I don't want to talk of myself, and besides I can't explain it all,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Well, why have you come to Moscow, then?

.... Hi! take away! '' he (I) called to the Tatar. '' You guess? '' responded Levin, his (Levin) eyes like deep wells of light fixed on Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' I guess, but I can't be the first to talk about it. You can see by that whether I guess right or wrong,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, gazing at Levin with a subtle smile.

'' Well, and what have you to say to me? '' said Levin in a quivering voice, feeling that all the muscles of his (Levin) face were quivering too.

'' How do you look at the question?'' Stepan Arkadyevitch slowly emptied his (Levin) glass of Chablis, never taking his (Levin) eyes off Levin.

``I?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
``there's nothing I desire so much as that--nothing! It would be the best thing that could be.'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

'' But you're not making a mistake? You know what we're speaking of?'' said Levin, piercing him (Levin) with his (Levin) eyes. ''

You think it's possible?''

``I think it's possible. Why not possible?'' (unknown)
'' No! do you really think it's possible? No, tell me all you think!

Oh, but if...if refusal's in store for me!... Indeed I feel sure... ''

``Why should you think that?'' (I)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling at his (Levin) excitement.

'' It seems so to me sometimes. That will be awful for me, and for her (you) too. '' '' Oh, well, anyway there's nothing awful in it for a girl.

He (Levin) so well knew that feeling of Levin's, that for him (Levin) all the girls in the world were divided into two classes: one class--all the girls in the world except her (girl), and those girls with all sorts of human weaknesses, and very ordinary girls: the other class--she (girl) alone, having no weaknesses of any sort and higher than all humanity.

Every girl's proud of an offer. '' '' Yes, every girl, but not she (girl). '' Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled. '' Stay, take some sauce,'' he (Levin) said, holding back Levin's hand as it pushed away the sauce.

Levin obediently helped himself to sauce, but would not let Stepan Arkadyevitch go on with his (Levin) dinner. '' No, stop a minute, stop a minute,'' he (Levin) said.

'' You must understand that it's a question of life and death for me. I have never spoken to any one of this.

You know we're utterly unlike each other, different tastes and views and everything; but I know you're fond of me and understand me, and that's why I like you awfully.

And there's no one I could speak of it to, except you. But for God's sake, be quite straightforward with me.

''

``I tell you what I think,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling. '' But I'll say more: my wife is a wonderful woman...

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed, remembering his (God) position with his (God) wife, and, after a moment's silence, resumed--

``She (wife) has a gift of foreseeing things.

She (wife) sees right through people; but that's not all; she (wife) knows what will come to pass, especially in the way of marriages.

She (wife) foretold, for instance, that Princess Shahovskaya would marry Brenteln. No one would believe it, but it came to pass. And she (Princess)'s on your side.

'' (wife)

``How do you mean?'' (she)
'' It's not only that she (Princess) likes you--she (Princess) says that Kitty is certain to be your wife.

'' At these words Levin's face suddenly lighted up with a smile, a smile not far from tears of emotion. ''

She (Kitty) says that!'' cried Levin. '' I always said she (Kitty) was exquisite, your wife. There, that's enough, enough said about it,'' he (Levin) said, getting up from his (Levin) seat.

He (Levin) walked with his (Levin) firm tread twice up and down the little cage of a room, blinked his (Levin) eyelids that his (Levin) tears might not fall, and only then sat down to the table.

'' All right, but do sit down. '' But Levin could not sit down. '' You must understand,'' said he (Levin),

``it's not love.

I've been in love, but it's not that. It's not my feeling, but a sort of force outside me has taken possession of me.

I went away, you see, because I made up my mind that it could never be, you understand, as a happiness that does not come on earth; but I've struggled with myself, I see there's no living without it.

And it must be settled. '' (he)

'' What did you go away for?'' ``Ah, stop a minute! Ah, the thoughts that come crowding on one!

The questions one must ask oneself! Listen. You can't imagine what you've done for me by what you said. I'm so happy that I've become positively hateful; I've forgotten everything.

I heard today that my brother Nikolay...you know, he (Nikolay)'s here... I had even forgotten him (Nikolay). It seems to me that he (Nikolay)'s happy too.

It's a sort of madness. But one thing's awful.... Here, you've been married, you know the feeling... it's awful that we--old--with a past... not of love, but of sins...

are brought all at once so near to a creature pure and innocent; it's loathsome, and that's why one can't help feeling oneself unworthy.

``Alas! all the same,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin,
``when with loathing I go over my life, I shudder and curse and bitterly regret it...

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' Oh, well, you've not many sins on your conscience.'' Yes.''
``What would you have? The world's made so,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

The one comfort is like that prayer, which I always liked: `Forgive me not according to my unworthiness, but according to Thy lovingkindness.'

'' That's the only way she (I) can forgive me. '' Chapter 11 Levin emptied his (Levin) glass, and they were silent for a while.

'' There's one other thing I ought to tell you. Do you know Vronsky? '' Stepan Arkadyevitch asked Levin. '' No, I don't.

``Give us another bottle,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
Stepan Arkadyevitch directed the Tatar, who was filling up their glasses and fidgeting round them just when he (Tatar) was not wanted.

Who's Vronsky?'' said Levin, and his (Levin) face was suddenly transformed from the look of childlike ecstasy which Oblonsky had just been admiring to an angry and unpleasant expression.

Vronsky is one of the sons of Count Kirill Ivanovitch Vronsky, and one of the finest specimens of the gilded youth of Petersburg.

I made his (Levin) acquaintance in Tver when I was there on official business, and he (Levin) came there for the levy of recruits.

Why do you ask?'' '' Why you ought to know Vronsky is that he (Levin)'s one of your rivals.'' '' '' Fearfully rich, handsome, great connections, an aide-de-camp, and with all that a very nice, good-natured fellow.

But he (fellow)'s more than simply a good-natured fellow, as I've found out here--he (fellow)'s a cultivated man, too, and very intelligent; he (fellow)'s a man who'll make his (fellow) mark.

Well, he (fellow) turned up here soon after you'd gone, and as I can see, he (fellow)'s over head and ears in love with Kitty, and you know that her (Kitty) mother...''

'' Levin scowled and was dumb. ''

``Excuse me, but I know nothing,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, frowning gloomily. And immediately he (Levin) recollected his (Levin) brother Nikolay and how hateful he (Levin) was to have been able to forget him (Levin).

I've told you what I know, and I repeat that in this delicate and tender matter, as far as one can conjecture, I believe the chances are in your favor.

'' You wait a bit, wait a bit,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling and touching his (Levin) hand. '' '' Levin dropped back in his (Levin) chair; his (Levin) face was pale.

'' But I would advise you to settle the thing as soon as may be,'' pursued Oblonsky, filling up his (Levin) glass.

'' No, thanks, I can't drink any more,'' said Levin, pushing away his (Levin) glass. '' I shall be drunk.... Come, tell me how are you getting on?

'' he (Levin) went on, obviously anxious to change the conversation. '' One word more: in any case I advise you to settle the question soon.

Tonight I don't advise you to speak,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Go round tomorrow morning, make an offer in due form, and God bless you...''

'' Oh, do you still think of coming to me for some shooting? Come next spring, do,'' said Levin. Now his (Levin) whole soul was full of remorse that he (Levin) had begun this conversation with Stepan Arkadyevitch.

A feeling such as his (Levin) was profaned by talk of the rivalry of some Petersburg officer, of the suppositions and the counsels of Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled. He (Levin) knew what was passing in Levin's soul. '' I'll come some day,'' he (Levin) said. '' But women, my boy, they're the pivot everything turns upon.

Tell me frankly now,'' he (boy) pursued, picking up a cigar and keeping one hand on his (boy) glass;

``give me your advice.'' (he)

Things are in a bad way with me, very bad. And it's all through women.

``Why, what is it?'' (I)
``I'll tell you.

``Excuse me, but I'm absolutely unable to comprehend how...just as I can't comprehend how I could now, after my dinner, go straight to a baker's shop and steal a roll.

Suppose you're married, you love your wife, but you're fascinated by another woman...'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes sparkled more than usual.

'' Why not? A roll will sometimes smell so good one can't resist it.''

``Himmlisch ist's, wenn ich bezwungen Meine irdische Begier; Aber doch wenn's nich gelungen Hatt' ich auch recht huebsch Plaisir!'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Yes, but joking apart,'' resumed Stepan Arkadyevitch,

``you must understand that the woman is a sweet, gentle loving creature, poor and lonely, and has sacrificed everything.

As he (Arkadyevitch) said this, Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled subtly. Levin, too, could not help smiling. '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Now, when the thing's done, don't you see, can one possibly cast her (woman) off?

Even supposing one parts from her (woman), so as not to break up one's family life, still, can one help feeling for her (woman), setting her (woman) on her (woman) feet, softening her (woman) lot?''

You know to me all women are divided into two classes...at least no...truer to say: there are women and there are...

I've never seen exquisite fallen beings, and I never shall see them, but such creatures as that painted Frenchwoman at the counter with the ringlets are vermin to my mind, and all fallen women are the same.

'' Well, you must excuse me there. ''

``But the Magdalen?'' (unknown)
``Ah, drop that! Christ would never have said those words if He (Christ) had known how they would be abused.

Of all the Gospel those words are the only ones remembered. However, I'm not saying so much what I think, as what I feel.

I have a loathing for fallen women. You're afraid of spiders, and I of these vermin. Most likely you've not made a study of spiders and don't know their character; and so it is with me.'' (unknown)

It's very well for you to talk like that; it's very much like that gentleman in Dickens who used to fling all difficult questions over his (Dickens) right shoulder.

'' But to deny the facts is no answer. What's to be done--you tell me that, what's to be done? Your wife gets older, while you're full of life.

Before you've time to look round, you feel that you can't love your wife with love, however much you may esteem her (wife).

And then all at once love turns up, and you're done for, done for,'' Stepan Arkadyevitch said with weary despair. Levin half smiled.

'' Yes, you're done for,'' resumed Oblonsky. '' But what's to be done?''

``Don't steal rolls. '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
Stepan Arkadyevitch laughed outright.

But you must understand, there are two women; one insists only on her (wife) rights, and those rights are your love, which you can't give her (wife); and the other sacrifices everything for you and asks for nothing.

'' Oh, moralist! What are you to do? How are you to act? There's a fearful tragedy in it. '' ''

If you care for my profession of faith as regards that, I'll tell you that I don't believe there was any tragedy about it.

To my mind, love...both the sorts of love, which you remember Plato defines in his (Plato) Banquet, served as the test of men.

And this is why. Some men only understand one sort, and some only the other. And those who only know the non-platonic love have no need to talk of tragedy.

In such love there can be no sort of tragedy. ' I'm much obliged for the gratification, my humble respects'--that's all the tragedy.

And in platonic love there can be no tragedy, because in that love all is clear and pure, because... '' At that instant Levin recollected his (Levin) own sins and the inner conflict he (Levin) had lived through.

And he (Levin) added unexpectedly:

``But perhaps you are right. Very likely... I don't know, I don't know. '' (he)
'' It's this, don't you see,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
``you're very much all of a piece.

You have a character that's all of a piece, and you want the whole of life to be of a piece too--but that's not how it is.

You despise public official work because you want the reality to be invariably corresponding all the while with the aim--and that's not how it is.

You want a man's work, too, always to have a defined aim, and love and family life always to be undivided--and that's not how it is.

That's your strong point and your failing. All the variety, all the charm, all the beauty of life is made up of light and shadow.

And suddenly both of them felt that though they were friends, though they had been dining and drinking together, which should have drawn them closer, yet each was thinking only of his (man) own affairs, and they had nothing to do with one another.

Oblonsky had more than once experienced this extreme sense of aloofness, instead of intimacy, coming on after dinner, and he (man) knew what to do in such cases.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Levin sighed and made no reply. He (Levin) was thinking of his (Levin) own affairs, and did not hear Oblonsky. '' Bill!''

he (Levin) called, and he (Levin) went into the next room where he (Levin) promptly came across an aide-de-camp of his (Levin) acquaintance and dropped into conversation with him (Levin) about an actress and her (actress) protector.

And at once in the conversation with the aide-de-camp Oblonsky had a sense of relaxation and relief after the conversation with Levin, which always put him (Levin) to too great a mental and spiritual strain.

When the Tatar appeared with a bill for twenty-six roubles and odd kopecks, besides a tip for himself, Levin, who would another time have been horrified, like any one from the country, at his (Levin) share of fourteen roubles, did not notice it, paid, and set off homewards to dress and go to the Shtcherbatskys' there to decide his (Levin) fate.

Chapter 12 The young Princess Kitty Shtcherbatskaya was eighteen. It was the first winter that she (Shtcherbatskaya) had been out in the world.

Her (Shtcherbatskaya) success in society had been greater than that of either of her (Shtcherbatskaya) elder sisters, and greater even than her (Shtcherbatskaya) mother had anticipated.

To say nothing of the young men who danced at the Moscow balls being almost all in love with Kitty, two serious suitors had already this first winter made their appearance: Levin, and immediately after his (Levin) departure, Count Vronsky.

Levin's appearance at the beginning of the winter, his (Levin) frequent visits, and evident love for Kitty, had led to the first serious conversations between Kitty's parents as to her (Kitty) future, and to disputes between them.

The princess for her (princess) part, going round the question in the manner peculiar to women, maintained that Kitty was too young, that Levin had done nothing to prove that he (Levin) had serious intentions, that Kitty felt no great attraction to him (Levin), and other side issues; but she (Kitty) did not state the principal point, which was that she (Kitty) looked for a better match for her (Kitty) daughter, and that Levin was not to her (Kitty) liking, and she (Kitty) did not understand him (Levin).

The prince was on Levin's side; he (Levin) said he (Levin) wished for nothing better for Kitty. When Levin had abruptly departed, the princess was delighted, and said to her (princess) husband triumphantly:

``You see I was right.

When Vronsky appeared on the scene, she (princess) was still more delighted, confirmed in her (princess) opinion that Kitty was to make not simply a good, but a brilliant match.

She (Kitty) disliked in Levin his (Levin) strange and uncompromising opinions and his (Levin) shyness in society, founded, as she (Kitty) supposed, on his (Levin) pride and his (Levin) queer sort of life, as she (Kitty) considered it, absorbed in cattle and peasants.

She (Kitty) did not very much like it that he (Levin), who was in love with her (Kitty) daughter, had kept coming to the house for six weeks, as though he (Levin) were waiting for something, inspecting, as though he (Levin) were afraid he (Levin) might be doing them too great an honor by making an offer, and did not realize that a man, who continually visits at a house where there is a young unmarried girl, is bound to make his (man) intentions clear.

'' (husband)

In the mother's eyes there could be no comparison between Vronsky and Levin. And suddenly, without doing so, he (Levin) disappeared.

'' It's as well he (Levin)'s not attractive enough for Kitty to have fallen in love with him (Levin),'' thought the mother. Vronsky satisfied all the mother's desires.

Very wealthy, clever, of aristocratic family, on the highroad to a brilliant career in the army and at court, and a fascinating man.

Vronsky openly flirted with Kitty at balls, danced with her (Kitty), and came continually to the house, consequently there could be no doubt of the seriousness of his (man) intentions.

But, in spite of that, the mother had spent the whole of that winter in a state of terrible anxiety and agitation.

Her (mother) husband, about whom everything was well known before hand, had come, looked at his (husband) future bride, and been looked at.

Nothing better could be wished for. Princess Shtcherbatskaya had herself been married thirty years ago, her (Shtcherbatskaya) aunt arranging the match. The match-making aunt had ascertained and communicated their mutual impression.

That impression had been favorable. Afterwards, on a day fixed beforehand, the expected offer was made to her (aunt) parents, and accepted.

But over her (aunt) own daughters she (aunt) had felt how far from simple and easy is the business, apparently so commonplace, of marrying off one's daughters.

The panics that had been lived through, the thoughts that had been brooded over, the money that had been wasted, and the disputes with her (aunt) husband over marrying the two elder girls, Darya and Natalia!

Now, since the youngest had come out, she (Natalia) was going through the same terrors, the same doubts, and still more violent quarrels with her (Natalia) husband than she (Natalia) had over the elder girls.

The old prince, like all fathers indeed, was exceedingly punctilious on the score of the honor and reputation of his (prince) daughters.

All had passed very simply and easily. So it seemed, at least, to the princess. He (prince) was irrationally jealous over his (prince) daughters, especially over Kitty, who was his (prince) favorite.

The princess had grown accustomed to this already with her (princess) other daughters, but now she (princess) felt that there was more ground for the prince's touchiness.

She (princess) saw that of late years much was changed in the manners of society, that a mother's duties had become still more difficult.

She (mother) saw that girls of Kitty's age formed some sort of clubs, went to some sort of lectures, mixed freely in men's society; drove about the streets alone, many of them did not curtsey, and, what was the most important thing, all the girls were firmly convinced that to choose their husbands was their own affair, and not their parents'.

Marriages aren't made nowadays as they used to be,'' was thought and said by all these young girls, and even by their elders.

At every turn he (girls) had scenes with the princess for compromising her (princess) daughter. '' But how marriages were made now, the princess could not learn from any one.

The French fashion--of the parents arranging their children's future--was not accepted; it was condemned. The English fashion of the complete independence of girls was also not accepted, and not possible in Russian society.

The Russian fashion of match-making by the offices of intermediate persons was for some reason considered unseemly; it was ridiculed by every one, and by the princess herself.

Everyone with whom the princess had chanced to discuss the matter said the same thing:

``Mercy on us, it's high time in our day to cast off all that old-fashioned business.

It's the young people have to marry; and not their parents; and so we ought to leave the young people to arrange it as they choose.

It was very easy for anyone to say that who had no daughters, but the princess realized that in the process of getting to know each other, her (princess) daughter might fall in love, and fall in love with someone who did not care to marry her (princess) or who was quite unfit to be her (princess) husband.

And, however much it was instilled into the princess that in our times young people ought to arrange their lives for themselves, she (princess) was unable to believe it, just as she (princess) would have been unable to believe that, at any time whatever, the most suitable playthings for children five years old ought to be loaded pistols.

But how girls were to be married, and how parents were to marry them, no one knew. '' (the princess)

And so the princess was more uneasy over Kitty than she (princess) had been over her (princess) elder sisters.

She (princess) saw that her (princess) daughter was in love with him (princess), but tried to comfort herself with the thought that he (princess) was an honorable man, and would not do this.

But at the same time she (princess) knew how easy it is, with the freedom of manners of today, to turn a girl's head, and how lightly men generally regard such a crime.

Now she (girl) was afraid that Vronsky might confine himself to simply flirting with her (girl) daughter. The week before, Kitty had told her (Kitty) mother of a conversation she (Kitty) had with Vronsky during a mazurka.

Vronsky had told Kitty that both he (Vronsky) and his (Vronsky) brother were so used to obeying their mother that they never made up their minds to any important undertaking without consulting her (mother).

This conversation had partly reassured the princess; but perfectly at ease she (princess) could not be. '' And just now, I am impatiently awaiting my mother's arrival from Petersburg, as peculiarly fortunate,'' he (Vronsky) told her (mother).

She (mother) knew that the old lady was expected from day to day, that she (lady) would be pleased at her (lady) son's choice, and she (lady) felt it strange that he (son) should not make his (son) offer through fear of vexing his (son) mother.

However, she (mother) was so anxious for the marriage itself, and still more for relief from her (mother) fears, that she (mother) believed it was so.

Bitter as it was for the princess to see the unhappiness of her (princess) eldest daughter, Dolly, on the point of leaving her (princess) husband, her (princess) anxiety over the decision of her (princess) youngest daughter's fate engrossed all her (princess) feelings.

Kitty had repeated this without attaching any significance to the words. But her (princess) mother saw them in a different light. Today, with Levin's reappearance, a fresh source of anxiety arose.

She (princess) was afraid that her (princess) daughter, who had at one time, as she (princess) fancied, a feeling for Levin, might, from extreme sense of honor, refuse Vronsky, and that Levin's arrival might generally complicate and delay the affair so near being concluded.

'' Why, has he (Levin) been here long? '' the princess asked about Levin, as they returned home. '' He (Levin) came today, mamma.''

There's one thing I want to say...'' began the princess, and from her (princess) serious and alert face, Kitty guessed what it would be.

'' '' Mamma,'' she (Kitty) said, flushing hotly and turning quickly to her (Kitty),

``please, please don't say anything about that. I know, I know all about it.

'' (her)

She (Kitty) wished for what her (Kitty) mother wished for, but the motives of her (Kitty) mother's wishes wounded her (Kitty). '' I only want to say that to raise hopes...

``I won't,'' (I)
said her (Kitty) mother, seeing the tears in her (mother) daughter's eyes;
``but one thing, my love; you promised me you would have no secrets from me.

Never, mamma, none,'' (daughter)

answered Kitty, flushing a little, and looking her (Kitty) mother straight in the face,
``but there's no use in my telling you anything, and I...

'' (mother)

``Mamma, darling, for goodness' sake, don't talk about it. It's so horrible to talk about it.'' (unknown)
You won't?'' '' I

...if I wanted to, I don't know what to say or how... I don't know...'' '' No, she (Kitty) could not tell an untruth with those eyes,'' thought the mother, smiling at her (mother) agitation and happiness.

The princess smiled that what was taking place just now in her (princess) soul seemed to the poor child so immense and so important.

Chapter 13 After dinner, and till the beginning of the evening, Kitty was feeling a sensation akin to the sensation of a young man before a battle.

She (Kitty) felt that this evening, when they would both meet for the first time, would be a turning point in her (Kitty) life.

Her (Kitty) heart throbbed violently, and her (Kitty) thoughts would not rest on anything. And she (Kitty) was continually picturing them to herself, at one moment each separately, and then both together.

The memories of childhood and of Levin's friendship with her (Kitty) dead brother gave a special poetic charm to her (Kitty) relations with him (Levin).

His (Levin) love for her (Kitty), of which she (Kitty) felt certain, was flattering and delightful to her (Kitty); and it was pleasant for her (Kitty) to think of Levin.

In her (Kitty) memories of Vronsky there always entered a certain element of awkwardness, though he (Levin) was in the highest degree well-bred and at ease, as though there were some false note--not in Vronsky, he (Levin) was very simple and nice, but in herself, while with Levin she (Kitty) felt perfectly simple and clear.

But, on the other hand, directly she (Kitty) thought of the future with Vronsky, there arose before her (Kitty) a perspective of brilliant happiness; with Levin the future seemed misty.

When she (Kitty) went upstairs to dress, and looked into the looking-glass, she (Kitty) noticed with joy that it was one of her (Kitty) good days, and that she (Kitty) was in complete possession of all her (Kitty) forces,--she (Kitty)

When she (Kitty) mused on the past, she (Kitty) dwelt with pleasure, with tenderness, on the memories of her (Kitty) relations with Levin. needed this

so for what lay before her (Kitty): she (Kitty) was conscious of external composure and free grace in her (Kitty) movements. At half-past seven she (Kitty) had only just gone down into the drawing room, when the footman announced,

``Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin.

'' (the footman)

The princess was still in her (princess) room, and the prince had not come in. '' So it is to be,'' thought Kitty, and all the blood seemed to rush to her (Kitty) heart.

At that moment she (Kitty) knew beyond doubt that he (Levin) had come early on purpose to find her (Kitty) alone and to make her (Kitty) an offer.

And only then for the first time the whole thing presented itself in a new, different aspect; only then she (Kitty) realized that the question did not affect her (Kitty) only-- with whom she (Kitty) would be happy, and whom she (Kitty) loved--but that she (Kitty) would have that moment to wound a man whom she (Kitty) liked.

She (Kitty) was horrified at her (Kitty) paleness, as she (Kitty) glanced into the looking-glass. And to wound him (man) cruelly. What for? Because he (man), dear fellow, loved her (Kitty), was in love with her (Kitty).

But there was no help for it, so it must be, so it would have to be. '' My God! shall I myself really have to say it to him (God)?

'' she (Kitty) thought. '' Can I tell him (God) I don't love him (God)? That will be a lie. What am I to say to him (God)?

That I love someone else? No, that's impossible. I'm going away, I'm going away. '' She (Kitty) had reached the door, when she (Kitty) heard his (God) step.

'' No! it's not honest. What have I to be afraid of? I have done nothing wrong. What is to be, will be!

I'll tell the truth. And with him (God) one can't be ill at ease. Here he (God) is,'' she (Kitty) said to herself, seeing his (God) powerful, shy figure, with his (God) shining eyes fixed on her (Kitty).

She (Kitty) looked straight into his (God) face, as though imploring him (God) to spare her (Kitty), and gave her (Kitty) hand. '' It's not time yet; I think I'm too early,'' he (God) said glancing round the empty drawing room.

When he (God) saw that his (God) expectations were realized, that there was nothing to prevent him (God) from speaking, his (God) face became gloomy.

But this was just what I wanted, to find you alone,'' he (God) began, not sitting down, and not looking at her (Kitty), so as not to lose courage.

'' Oh, no,'' said Kitty, and sat down at the table. '' '' Mamma will be down directly. She (Kitty) was very much tired....

Yesterday... '' She (Kitty) talked on, not knowing what her (Kitty) lips were uttering, and not taking her (Kitty) supplicating and caressing eyes off him (God).

He (God) glanced at her (Kitty); she (Kitty) blushed, and ceased speaking. '' I told you I did not know whether I should be here long...that it depended on you...

'' She (Kitty) dropped her (Kitty) head lower and lower, not knowing herself what answer she (Kitty) should make to what was coming. ''

That it depended on you,'' he (God) repeated. '' I meant to say... I meant to say... I came for this...to be my wife!

'' he (God) brought out, not knowing what he (God) was saying; but feeling that the most terrible thing was said, he (God) stopped short and looked at her (wife)...

She (wife) was breathing heavily, not looking at him (God). She (wife) was feeling ecstasy. Her (wife) soul was flooded with happiness. She (wife) had never anticipated that the utterance of love would produce such a powerful effect on her (wife).

But it lasted only an instant. She (wife) remembered Vronsky. She (wife) lifted her (wife) clear, truthful eyes, and seeing his (God) desperate face, she (wife) answered hastily:

``That cannot be...forgive me.

'' (she)

A moment ago, and how close she (wife) had been to him (God), of what importance in his (God) life! And how aloof and remote from him (God) she (wife) had become now!

'' It was bound to be so,'' he (God) said, not looking at her (wife). He (God) bowed, and was meaning to retreat. Chapter 14

But at that very moment the princess came in. There was a look of horror on her (princess) face when she (princess) saw them alone, and their disturbed faces.

Thank God, she (princess) has refused him (God),'' thought the mother, and her (mother) face lighted up with the habitual smile with which she (mother) greeted her (mother) guests on Thursdays.

Levin bowed to her (mother), and said nothing. Kitty did not speak nor lift her (Kitty) eyes. '' She (Kitty) sat down and began questioning Levin about his (Levin) life in the country.

He (Levin) sat down again, waiting for other visitors to arrive, in order to retreat unnoticed. Five minutes later there came in a friend of Kitty's, married the preceding winter, Countess Nordston.

She (Nordston) was fond of Kitty, and her (Kitty) affection for her (Kitty) showed itself, as the affection of married women for girls always does, in the desire to make a match for Kitty after her (Kitty) own ideal of married happiness; she (Kitty) wanted her (Kitty) to marry Vronsky.

She (Kitty) was a thin, sallow, sickly, and nervous woman, with brilliant black eyes. Levin she (Kitty) had often met at the Shtcherbatskys' early in the winter, and she (Kitty) had always disliked him (Levin).

I do like it when he (Levin) looks down at me from the height of his (Levin) grandeur, or breaks off his (Levin) learned conversation with me because I'm a fool, or is condescending to me.

Her (Kitty) invariable and favorite pursuit, when they met, consisted in making fun of him (Levin). '' I like that so; to see him (Levin) condescending!

She (Kitty) was right, for Levin actually could not bear her (Kitty), and despised her (Kitty) for what she (Kitty) was proud of and regarded as a fine characteristic--her (Kitty) nervousness, her (Kitty) delicate contempt and indifference for everything coarse and earthly.

The Countess Nordston and Levin got into that relation with one another not seldom seen in society, when two persons, who remain externally on friendly terms, despise each other to such a degree that they cannot even take each other seriously, and cannot even be offended by each other.

I am so glad he (Levin) can't bear me,'' she (Countess) used to say of him (Levin). The Countess Nordston pounced upon Levin at once.

So you've come back to our corrupt Babylon,'' she (Countess) said, giving him (Levin) her (Countess) tiny, yellow hand, and recalling what he (Levin) had chanced to say early in the winter, that Moscow was a Babylon.

'' Ah, Konstantin Dmitrievitch! '' Come, is Babylon reformed, or have you degenerated? '' she (Countess) added, glancing with a simper at Kitty.

It's very flattering for me, countess, that you remember my words so well,'' responded Levin, who had succeeded in recovering his (Levin) composure, and at once from habit dropped into his (Levin) tone of joking hostility to the Countess Nordston.

'' '' They must certainly make a great impression on you.'' '' Oh, I should think so! I always note them all down.

Awkward as it was for Levin to withdraw now, it would still have been easier for him (Levin) to perpetrate this awkwardness than to remain all the evening and see Kitty, who glanced at him (Levin) now and then and avoided his (Levin) eyes.

Well, Kitty, have you been skating again?... '' And she (Kitty) began talking to Kitty. He (Levin) was on the point of getting up, when the princess, noticing that he (Levin) was silent, addressed him (Levin).

'' Shall you be long in Moscow? You're busy with the district council, though, aren't you, and can't be away for long?''

``No, princess, I'm no longer a member of the council,'' (he)
he (member) said. '' I have come up for a few days.

'' '' There's something the matter with him (member),'' thought Countess Nordston, glancing at his (member) stern, serious face. '' He (member) isn't in his (member) old argumentative mood.

But I'll draw him (member) out. I do love making a fool of him (fool) before Kitty, and I'll do it.''

``Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said to him (Dmitrievitch),
``do explain to me, please, what's the meaning of it.

At home in our village of Kaluga all the peasants and all the women have drunk up all they possessed, and now they can't pay us any rent.

You know all about such things. What's the meaning of that? You always praise the peasants so. '' (him)

At that instant another lady came into the room, and Levin got up.

Excuse me, countess, but I really know nothing about it, and can't tell you anything,'' he (Levin) said, and looked round at the officer who came in behind the lady.

'' '' That must be Vronsky,'' thought Levin, and, to be sure of it, glanced at Kitty. She (Kitty) had already had time to look at Vronsky, and looked round at Levin.

And simply from the look in her (Kitty) eyes, that grew unconsciously brighter, Levin knew that she (Kitty) loved that man, knew it as surely as if she (Kitty) had told him (Levin) so in words.

Now, whether for good or for ill, Levin could not choose but remain; he (Levin) must find out what the man was like whom she (Kitty) loved.

There are people who, on meeting a successful rival, no matter in what, are at once disposed to turn their backs on everything good in him (Levin), and to see only what is bad.

There are people, on the other hand, who desire above all to find in that lucky rival the qualities by which he (Levin) has outstripped them, and seek with a throbbing ache at heart only what is good.

But what sort of a man was he (man)? Levin belonged to the second class. But he (Levin) had no difficulty in finding what was good and attractive in Vronsky.

It was apparent at the first glance. Vronsky was a squarely built, dark man, not very tall, with a good-humored, handsome, and exceedingly calm and resolute face.

Everything about his (man) face and figure, from his (man) short-cropped black hair and freshly shaven chin down to his (man) loosely fitting, brand-new uniform, was simple and at the same time elegant.

As he (man) approached her (man), his (man) beautiful eyes shone with a specially tender light, and with a faint, happy, and modestly triumphant smile -LRB-so it seemed to Levin-RRB-, bowing carefully and respectfully over her (man), he (Levin) held out his (Levin) small broad hand to her (man).

Greeting and saying a few words to everyone, he (Levin) sat down without once glancing at Levin, who had never taken his (Levin) eyes off him (Levin).

Making way for the lady who had come in, Vronsky went up to the princess and then to Kitty. '' Let me introduce you,'' said the princess, indicating Levin.

'' Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, Count Alexey Kirillovitch Vronsky. '' Vronsky got up and, looking cordially at Levin, shook hands with him (Levin).

'' I believe I was to have dined with you this winter,'' he (Levin) said, smiling his (Levin) simple and open smile;

``but you had unexpectedly left for the country.'' (he)

My words must make a deep impression on you, since you remember them so well,'' said Levin, and, suddenly conscious that he (Levin) had said just the same thing before, he (Levin) reddened.

``Konstantin Dmitrievitch despises and hates town and us townspeople,'' (Countess Nordston)
said Countess Nordston. '' Vronsky looked at Levin and Countess Nordston, and smiled.

'' Are you always in the country? '' he (Levin) inquired. '' I should think it must be dull in the winter.''

'' It's not dull if one has work to do; besides, one's not dull by oneself,'' Levin replied abruptly. '' I am fond of the country,'' said Vronsky, noticing, and affecting not to notice, Levin's tone.

'' But I hope, count, you would not consent to live in the country always,'' said Countess Nordston. '' I don't know; I have never tried for long.

I never longed so for the country, Russian country, with bast shoes and peasants, as when I was spending a winter with my mother in Nice.

I experienced a queer feeling once,'' he (Levin) went on. '' Nice itself is dull enough, you know. And indeed, Naples and Sorrento are only pleasant for a short time.

He (Levin) talked on, addressing both Kitty and Levin, turning his (Levin) serene, friendly eyes from one to the other, and saying obviously just what came into his (Levin) head.

Noticing that Countess Nordston wanted to say something, he (Levin) stopped short without finishing what he (Levin) had begun, and listened attentively to her (Nordston).

The conversation did not flag for an instant, so that the princess, who always kept in reserve, in case a subject should be lacking, two heavy guns--the relative advantages of classical and of modern education, and universal military service--had not to move out either of them, while Countess Nordston had not a chance of chaffing Levin.

Levin wanted to, and could not, take part in the general conversation; saying to himself every instant,

``Now go,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
he (Levin) still did not go, as though waiting for something.

The conversation fell upon table-turning and spirits, and Countess Nordston, who believed in spiritualism, began to describe the marvels she (Nordston) had seen.

And it's just there that Russia comes back to me most vividly, and especially the country. It's as though...'' '' Ah, countess, you really must take me, for pity's sake do take me to see them!

I have never seen anything extraordinary, though I am always on the lookout for it everywhere,'' said Vronsky, smiling. '' Very well, next Saturday,'' answered Countess Nordston.

'' But you, Konstantin Dmitrievitch, do you believe in it? '' she (Countess) asked Levin. '' Why do you ask me? You know what I shall say.''

'' But I want to hear your opinion.'' '' My opinion,'' answered Levin,

``is only that this table-turning simply proves that educated society--so called--is no higher than the peasants.

They believe in the evil eye, and in witchcraft and omens, while we... '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' Oh, then you don't believe in it?''

``I can't believe in it, countess.'' (I)
'' But if I've seen it myself?'' '' The peasant women too tell us they have seen goblins.''

Oh, no, Masha, Konstantin Dmitrievitch said he (Dmitrievitch) could not believe in it,'' said Kitty, blushing for Levin, and Levin saw this, and, still more exasperated, would have answered, but Vronsky with his (Vronsky) bright frank smile rushed to the support of the conversation, which was threatening to become disagreeable.

``Then you think I tell a lie? '' (she)
And she (Kitty) laughed a mirthless laugh. '' '' You do not admit the conceivability at all?

'' he (Vronsky) queried. '' But why not? We admit the existence of electricity, of which we know nothing. Why should there not be some new force, still unknown to us, which...

''

``When electricity was discovered,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin interrupted hurriedly,
``it was only the phenomenon that was discovered, and it was unknown from what it proceeded and what were its effects, and ages passed before its applications were conceived.

But the spiritualists have begun with tables writing for them, and spirits appearing to them, and have only later started saying that it is an unknown force.

Yes, but the spiritualists say we don't know at present what this force is, but there is a force, and these are the conditions in which it acts.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Vronsky listened attentively to Levin, as he (Levin) always did listen, obviously interested in his (Levin) words. '' Let the scientific men find out what the force consists in.

''

``Why, because with electricity,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin interrupted again,
``every time you rub tar against wool, a recognized phenomenon is manifested, but in this case it does not happen every time, and so it follows it is not a natural phenomenon.

Feeling probably that the conversation was taking a tone too serious for a drawing room, Vronsky made no rejoinder, but by way of trying to change the conversation, he (Levin) smiled brightly, and turned to the ladies.

No, I don't see why there should not be a new force, if it... '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' Do let us try at once, countess,'' he (Levin) said; but Levin would finish saying what he (Levin) thought.

I think,'' he (Levin) went on,

``that this attempt of the spiritualists to explain their marvels as some sort of new natural force is most futile.

'' (he)

They boldly talk of spiritual force, and then try to subject it to material experiment. '' Every one was waiting for him (Levin) to finish, and he (Levin) felt it.

'' And I think you would be a first-rate medium,'' said Countess Nordston;

``there's something enthusiastic in you. '' (Countess Nordston)
Levin opened his (Levin) mouth, was about to say something, reddened, and said nothing.

'' Do let us try table-turning at once, please,'' said Vronsky. '' Princess, will you allow it? '' And Vronsky stood up, looking for a little table.

She (Princess) felt for him (Levin) with her (Princess) whole heart, the more because she (Princess) was pitying him (Levin) for suffering of which she (Princess) was herself

Kitty got up to fetch a table, and as she (Kitty) passed, her (Kitty) eyes met Levin's. the cause. '' If you can forgive me, forgive me,'' said her (Kitty) eyes,

``I am so happy.

'' (me)

``I hate them all, and you, and myself,'' (he)
his (Levin) eyes responded, and he (Levin) took up his (Levin) hat. But he (Levin) was not destined to escape.

Just as they were arranging themselves round the table, and Levin was on the point of retiring, the old prince came in, and after greeting the ladies, addressed Levin.

``Ah!'' (he)
he (Levin) began joyously.
``Been here long, my boy? I didn't even know you were in town. Very glad to see you.

The old prince embraced Levin, and talking to him (Levin) did not observe Vronsky, who had risen, and was serenely waiting till the prince should turn to him (prince).

She (boy) saw, too, how coldly her (boy) father responded at last to Vronsky's bow, and how Vronsky looked with amiable perplexity at her (boy) father, as though trying and failing to understand how and why anyone could be hostilely disposed towards him (father), and she (boy) flushed.

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

Kitty felt how distasteful her (Kitty) father's warmth was to Levin after what had happened. '' Prince, let us have Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' said Countess Nordston;
``we want to try an experiment.

Well, you must excuse me, ladies and gentlemen, but to my mind it is better fun to play the ring game,'' (Countess Nordston)

said the old prince, looking at Vronsky, and guessing that it had been his (prince) suggestion.

Vronsky looked wonderingly at the prince with his (prince) resolute eyes, and, with a faint smile, began immediately talking to Countess Nordston of the great ball that was to come off next week.

''

``What experiment? Table-turning? '' (unknown)
There's some sense in that, anyway. '' '' I hope you will be there? '' he (prince) said to Kitty.

As soon as the old prince turned away from him (prince), Levin went out unnoticed, and the last impression he (Levin) carried away with him (Levin) of that evening was the smiling, happy face of Kitty answering Vronsky's inquiry about the ball.

At the end of the evening Kitty told her (Kitty) mother of her (Kitty) conversation with Levin, and in spite of all the pity she (Kitty) felt for Levin, she (Kitty) was glad at the thought that she (Kitty) had received an offer .

Chapter 15 She (Kitty) had no doubt that she (Kitty) had acted rightly. But after she (Kitty) had gone to bed, for a long while she (Kitty) could not sleep.

It was Levin's face, with his (Levin) scowling brows, and his (Levin) kind eyes looking out in dark dejection below them, as he (Levin) stood listening to her (Kitty) father, and glancing at her (Kitty) and at Vronsky.

One impression pursued her (Kitty) relentlessly. And she (Kitty) felt so sorry for him (Levin) that tears came into her (Kitty) eyes. But immediately she (Kitty) thought of the man for whom she (Kitty) had given him (man) up.

She (Kitty) remembered the love for her (Kitty) of the man she (Kitty) loved, and once more all was gladness in her (Kitty) soul, and she (Kitty) lay on the pillow, smiling with happiness.

She (Kitty) vividly recalled his (man) manly, resolute face, his (man) noble self-possession, and the good nature conspicuous in everything towards everyone. '' I'm sorry

, I'm sorry; but what could I do? It's not my fault,'' she (Kitty) said to herself; but an inner voice told her (Kitty) something else.

Whether she (Kitty) felt remorse at having won Levin's love, or at having refused him (Levin), she (Kitty) did not know. But her (Kitty) happiness was poisoned by doubts.

'' Lord, have pity on us; Lord, have pity on us; Lord, have pity on us! '' she (Kitty) repeated to herself, till she (Kitty) fell asleep.

Meanwhile there took place below, in the prince's little library, one of the scenes so often repeated between the parents on account of their favorite daughter.

'' What? I'll tell you what! '' shouted the prince, waving his (prince) arms, and at once wrapping his (prince) squirrel-lined dressing-gown round him (prince) again.

'' That you've no pride, no dignity; that you're disgracing, ruining your daughter by this vulgar, stupid match-making!'' '' But, really, for mercy's sake, prince, what have I done?'' said the princess, almost crying.

She (princess), pleased and happy after her (princess) conversation with her (princess) daughter, had gone to the prince to say good-night as usual, and though she (princess) had no intention of telling him (prince) of Levin's offer and Kitty's refusal, still she (Kitty) hinted to her (Kitty) husband that she (Kitty) fancied things were practically settled with Vronsky, and that he (husband) would declare himself so soon as his (husband) mother arrived.

And thereupon, at those words, the prince had all at once flown into a passion, and began to use unseemly language.

First of all, you're trying to catch an eligible gentleman, and all Moscow will be talking of it, and with good reason.

'' What have you done? I'll tell you what. If you have evening parties, invite everyone, don't pick out the possible suitors.

Invite all the young bucks. Engage a piano player, and let them dance, and not as you do things nowadays, hunting up good matches.

It makes me sick, sick to see it, and you've gone on till you've turned the poor wench's head. Levin's a thousand times the better man.

As for this little Petersburg swell, they're turned out by machinery, all on one pattern, and all precious rubbish. But if he (Levin) were a prince of the blood, my daughter need not run after anyone.''

'' But what have I done?''

``Why, you've... '' (The prince)
The prince was crying wrathfully. '' I know if one were to listen to you,'' interrupted the princess,
``we should never marry our daughter.

If it's to be so, we'd better go into the country. '' (the princess)

'' Well, and we had better.'' '' But do wait a minute.

Do I try and catch them? I don't try to catch them in the least. A young man, and a very nice one, has fallen in love with her (daughter), and she (daughter), I fancy...''

'' Oh, yes, you fancy! And how if she (daughter) really is in love, and he (man)'s no more thinking of marriage than I am!

... Oh, that I should live to see it! Ah! spiritualism! Ah! Nice! Ah! the ball!'' And the prince, imagining that he (prince) was mimicking his (prince) wife, made a mincing curtsey at each word.

'' And this is how we're preparing wretchedness for Kitty; and she (Kitty)'s really got the notion into her (Kitty) head...'' '' But what makes you suppose so?''

I see a man who has serious intentions, that's Levin: and I see a peacock, like this feather-head, who's only amusing himself.''

``I don't suppose; I know. We have eyes for such things, though women-folk haven't. '' (unknown)
Oh, well, when once you get an idea into your head!...

'' '' Well, you'll remember my words, but too late, just as with Dolly.'' '' Well, well, we won't talk of it,'' the princess stopped him (Levin), recollecting her (princess) unlucky Dolly.

And signing each other with the cross, the husband and wife parted with a kiss, feeling that they each remained of their own opinion.

The princess had at first been quite certain that that evening had settled Kitty's future, and that there could be no doubt of Vronsky's intentions, but her (Kitty) husband's words had disturbed her (Kitty).

And returning to her (Kitty) own room, in terror before the unknown future, she (Kitty), too, like Kitty, repeated several times in her (Kitty) heart,

``Lord, have pity; Lord, have pity; Lord, have pity.

His (Lord) mother had been in her (mother) youth a brilliant society woman, who had had during her (mother) married life, and still more afterwards, many love affairs notorious in the whole fashionable world.

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

By all means, and good night! '' '' Chapter 16 Vronsky had never had a real home life. His (Lord) father he (Lord) scarcely remembered, and he (Lord) had been educated in the Corps of Pages.

Leaving the school very young as a brilliant officer, he (officer) had at once got into the circle of wealthy Petersburg army men.

In Moscow he (officer) had for the first time felt, after his (officer) luxurious and coarse life at Petersburg, all the charm of intimacy with a sweet and innocent girl of his (officer) own rank, who cared for him (officer).

Although he (officer) did go more or less into Petersburg society, his (officer) love affairs had always hitherto been outside it. It never even entered his (officer) head that there could be any harm in his (officer) relations with Kitty.

He (officer) talked to her (Kitty) as people commonly do talk in society--all sorts of nonsense, but nonsense to which he (officer) could not help attaching a special meaning in her (Kitty) case.

Although he (officer) said nothing to her (Kitty) that he (officer) could not have said before everybody, he (officer) felt that she (Kitty) was becoming more and more dependent upon him (officer), and the more he (officer) felt this, the better he (officer) liked it, and the tenderer was his (officer) feeling for her (Kitty).

He (officer) did not know that his (officer) mode of behavior in relation to Kitty had a definite character, that it is courting young girls with no intention of marriage, and that such courting is one of the evil actions common among brilliant young men such as he (officer) was.

At balls he (officer) danced principally with her (Kitty). He (officer) was a constant visitor at their house. It seemed to him (officer) that he (officer) was the first who had discovered this pleasure, and he (officer) was enjoying his (officer) discovery.

If he (officer) could have heard what her (Kitty) parents were saying that evening, if he (officer) could have put himself at the point of view of the family and have heard that Kitty would be unhappy if he (officer) did not marry her (Kitty), he (officer) would have been greatly astonished, and would not have believed it.

He (officer) could not believe that what gave such great and delicate pleasure to him (officer), and above all to her (Kitty), could be wrong.

Still less could he (officer) have believed that he (officer) ought to marry. Marriage had never presented itself to him (officer) as a possibility.

He (officer) not only disliked family life, but a family, and especially a husband was, in accordance with the views general in the bachelor world in which he (bachelor) lived, conceived as something alien, repellant, and, above all, ridiculous.

But though Vronsky had not the least suspicion what the parents were saying, he (bachelor) felt on coming away from the Shtcherbatskys' that the secret spiritual bond which existed between him (bachelor) and Kitty had grown so much stronger that evening that some step must be taken.

What is so exquisite,'' he (bachelor) thought, as he (bachelor) returned from the Shtcherbatskys', carrying away with him (bachelor), as he (bachelor) always did, a delicious feeling of purity and freshness, arising partly from the fact that he (bachelor) had not been smoking for a whole evening, and with it a new feeling of tenderness at her (Kitty) love for

is that not a word has been said by me or by her (Kitty), but we understand each other so well in this unseen language of looks and tones, that this evening more clearly than ever she (Kitty) told me she (Kitty) loves me.

But what step could and ought to be taken he (bachelor) could not imagine. '' him (bachelor)--

``what is so exquisite And how secretly, simply, and most of all, how trustfully!

I feel myself better, purer. I feel that I have a heart, and that there is a great deal of good in me.

Those sweet, loving eyes! When she (Kitty) said: Indeed I do...' '' (him)

Well, what then? Oh, nothing. It's good for me, and good for her (Kitty).

'' And he (bachelor) began wondering where to finish the evening. He (bachelor) passed in review of the places he (bachelor) might go to.

'' Club? a game of bezique, champagne with Ignatov? No, I'm not going. Ch√¢teau des Fleurs ; there I shall find Oblonsky, songs, the cancan.

He (bachelor) went straight to his (bachelor) room at Dussot's Hotel, ordered supper, and then undressed, and as soon as his (bachelor) head touched the pillow, fell into a sound sleep.

No, I'm sick of it. That's why I like the Shtcherbatskys', that I'm growing better. I'll go home. '' Chapter 17

Next day at eleven o'clock in the morning Vronsky drove to the station of the Petersburg railway to meet his (bachelor) mother, and the first person he (bachelor) came across on the great flight of steps was Oblonsky, who was expecting his (bachelor) sister by the same train.

'' Ah! your excellency! '' cried Oblonsky,

``whom are you meeting?'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)
'' My mother,'' Vronsky responded, smiling, as everyone did who met Oblonsky.

He (Vronsky) shook hands with him (Vronsky), and together they ascended the steps. '' She (mother) is to be here from Petersburg today.''

``I was looking out for you till two o'clock last night.

Where did you go after the Shtcherbatskys'?'' (unknown)

``Home,'' (Home Vronsky)
answered Vronsky. '' I must own I felt so well content yesterday after the Shtcherbatskys' that I didn't care to go anywhere.''

``I know a gallant steed by tokens sure, And by his (Vronsky) eyes I know a youth in love,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
declaimed Stepan Arkadyevitch, just as he (Vronsky) had done before to Levin.

Vronsky smiled with a look that seemed to say that he (Vronsky) did not deny it, but he (Vronsky) promptly changed the subject.

You don't say so!'' '' Honi soit qui mal y pense! My sister Anna. ''

``Ah! that's Madame Karenina,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky.

I really am not sure,'' Vronsky answered heedlessly, with a vague recollection of something stiff and tedious evoked by the name Karenina. ''

'' You know her (Anna), no doubt?'' '' I think I do. Or perhaps not... But Alexey Alexandrovitch, my celebrated brother-in-law, you surely must know.

All the world knows him (Alexandrovitch). ''

But you know that's not... not in my line, '' (Vronsky)

said Vronsky in English. '' Yes, he (Alexandrovitch)'s a very remarkable man; rather a conservative, but a splendid man,'' observed Stepan Arkadyevitch,
``a splendid man.'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

'' (mother)

``I don't know why it is,'' (Vronsky)
