'' (he)

He (Levin)'s a capital fellow,'' pursued Oblonsky.
``Isn't he (Levin)?'' (unknown)
They are all on the defensive, lose their tempers, as though they all want to make one feel something...''

``Yes, that's true, it is so,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing good-humoredly. '' Will the train soon be in? '' Vronsky asked a railway official.

The approach of the train was more and more evident by the preparatory bustle in the station, the rush of porters, the movement of policemen and attendants, and people meeting the train.

Through the frosty vapor could be seen workmen in short sheepskins and soft felt boots crossing the rails of the curving line.

'' The train's signaled,'' answered the man. The hiss of the boiler could be heard on the distant rails, and the rumble of something heavy.

'' No,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, who felt a great inclination to tell Vronsky of Levin's intentions in regard to Kitty. ''

No, you've not got a true impression of Levin. He (Levin)'s a very nervous man, and is sometimes out of humor, it's true, but then he (Levin) is often very nice.

But yesterday there were special reasons,'' pursued Stepan Arkadyevitch, with a meaning smile, totally oblivious of the genuine sympathy he (Levin) had felt the day before for his (Levin) friend, and feeling the same sympathy now, only for Vronsky.

He (Levin)'s such a true, honest nature, and a heart of gold. '' Yes, there were reasons why he (Levin) could not help being either particularly happy or particularly unhappy.

'' Vronsky stood still and asked directly:

``How so? Do you mean he (Levin) made your belle-soeur an offer yesterday?'' (Vronsky)
'' Maybe,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' I fancied something of the sort yesterday. Yes, if he (Levin) went away early, and was out of humor too, it must mean it....

I should imagine, though, she (Levin) might reckon on a better match,'' said Vronsky, drawing himself up and walking about again,

``though I don't know him (Vronsky), of course,'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
he (Vronsky) added.

He (Vronsky)'s been so long in love, and I'm very sorry for him (Vronsky).'' '' So that's it! '' Yes, that is a hateful position!

If you don't succeed with them it only proves that you've not enough cash, but in this case one's dignity's at stake.

That's why most fellows prefer to have to do with Klaras. But here's the train. '' The engine had already whistled in the distance.

A few instants later the platform was quivering, and with puffs of steam hanging low in the air from the frost, the engine rolled up, with the lever of the middle wheel rhythmically moving up and down, and the stooping figure of the engine-driver covered with frost.

Behind the tender, setting the platform more and more slowly swaying, came the luggage van with a dog whining in it.

At last the passenger carriages rolled in, oscillating before coming to a standstill. A smart guard jumped out, giving a whistle, and after him (guard) one by one

the impatient passengers began to get down: an officer of the guards, holding himself erect, and looking severely about him (guard); a nimble little merchant with a satchel, smiling gaily; a peasant with a sack over his (peasant) shoulder.

Vronsky, standing beside Oblonsky, watched the carriages and the passengers, totally oblivious of his (peasant) mother. What he (peasant) had just heard about Kitty excited and delighted him (peasant).

Unconsciously he (peasant) arched his (peasant) chest, and his (peasant) eyes flashed. He (peasant) felt himself a conqueror. '' Countess Vronskaya is in that compartment,'' said the smart guard, going up to Vronsky.

He (guard) did not in his (guard) heart respect his (guard) mother, and without acknowledging it to himself, he (guard) did not love her (mother), though in accordance with the ideas of the set in which he (guard) lived, and with his (guard) own education, he (guard) could not have conceived of any behavior to his (guard) mother not in the highest degree respectful and obedient, and the more externally obedient and respectful his (guard) behavior, the less in his (guard) heart he (guard) respected and loved her (mother).

Chapter 18 Vronsky followed the guard to the carriage, and at the door of the compartment he (guard) stopped short to make room for a lady who was getting out.

With the insight of a man of the world, from one glance at this lady's appearance Vronsky classified her (lady) as belonging to the best society.

He (man) begged pardon, and was getting into the carriage, but felt he (man) must glance at her (lady) once more; not that she (lady) was very beautiful, not on account of the elegance and modest grace which were apparent in her (lady) whole figure, but because in the expression of her (lady) charming face, as she (lady) passed close by him (man), there was something peculiarly caressing and soft.

The guard's words roused him (guard), and forced him (guard) to think of his (guard) mother and his (guard) approaching meeting with her (mother). As he (guard) looked round, she (mother) too turned her (mother) head.

Her (mother) shining gray eyes, that looked dark from the thick lashes, rested with friendly attention on his (guard) face, as though she (mother) were recognizing him (guard), and then promptly turned away to the passing crowd, as though seeking someone.

In that brief look Vronsky had time to notice the suppressed eagerness which played over her (mother) face, and flitted between the brilliant eyes and the faint smile that curved her (mother) red lips.

It was as though her (mother) nature were so brimming over with something that against her (mother) will it showed itself now in the flash of her (mother) eyes, and now in her (mother) smile.

Deliberately she (mother) shrouded the light in her (mother) eyes, but it shone against her (mother) will in the faintly perceptible smile. Vronsky stepped into the carriage.

His (Vronsky) mother, a dried-up old lady with black eyes and ringlets, screwed up her (mother) eyes, scanning her (mother) son, and smiled slightly with her (mother) thin lips.

Getting up from the seat and handing her (mother) maid a bag, she (mother) gave her (mother) little wrinkled hand to her (mother) son to kiss, and lifting his (son) head from her (mother) hand, kissed him (son) on the cheek.

``You had a good journey?'' (son)
said her (mother) son, sitting down beside her (mother), and involuntarily listening to a woman's voice outside the door.

'' You got my telegram? Quite well? Thank God.'' He (God) knew it was the voice of the lady he (God) had met at the door.

'' All the same I don't agree with you,'' said the lady's voice. '' It's the Petersburg view, madame.''

``Not Petersburg, but simply feminine,'' (she)
she (lady) responded.

'' Well, well, allow me to kiss your hand. ''

``Good-bye, Ivan Petrovitch. And could you see if my brother is here, and send him (brother) to me?

'' (the lady)

said the lady in the doorway, and stepped back again into the compartment. '' Well, have you found your brother?'' said Countess Vronskaya, addressing the lady.

Excuse me, I did not know you, and, indeed, our acquaintance was so slight,'' said Vronsky, bowing,

``that no doubt you do not remember me.

Oh, no,'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)

said she (lady),

Vronsky understood now that this was Madame Karenina. '' (she)

Your brother is here,'' he (brother) said, standing up. '' '' '' but you all the way.

'' As she (mother) spoke she (mother) let the eagerness that would insist on coming out show itself in her (mother) smile. '' And still no sign of my brother.''

Madame Karenina, however, did not wait for her (mother) brother, but catching sight of him (brother) she (mother) stepped out with her (mother) light, resolute step.

And as soon as her (mother) brother had reached her (mother), with a gesture that struck Vronsky by its decision and its grace, she (mother) flung her (mother) left arm around his (brother) neck, drew him (brother) rapidly to her (mother), and kissed him (brother) warmly.

``Do call him (brother), Alexey,'' (the countess)
said the old countess. Vronsky stepped out onto the platform and shouted:
``Oblonsky! Here!'' (Vronsky)
Vronsky gazed, never taking his (Alexey) eyes from her (countess), and smiled, he (Alexey) could not have said why.

But recollecting that his (Alexey) mother was waiting for him (Alexey), he (Alexey) went back again into the carriage. '' She (mother)'s very sweet, isn't she (mother)?'' said the countess of Madame Karenina.

'' Her (mother) husband put her (mother) with me, and I was delighted to have her (mother). We've been talking all the way. And so you, I hear...

vous filez le parfait amour. Tant mieux, mon cher, tant mieux. ''

``I don't know what you are referring to, maman,'' (he)
he (husband) answered coldly.

``Come, maman, let us go. '' (Madame)
Madame Karenina entered the carriage again to say good-bye to the countess. '' Well, countess, you have met your son, and I my brother,'' she (countess) said.

'' And all my gossip is exhausted. I should have nothing more to tell you.'' '' Oh, no,'' said the countess, taking her (countess) hand.

'' I could go all around the world with you and never be dull. You are one of those delightful women in whose company it's sweet to be silent as well as to talk.

Now please don't fret over your son; you can't expect never to be parted. '' Madame Karenina stood quite still, holding herself very erect, and her (countess) eyes were smiling.

Anna Arkadyevna,'' the countess said in explanation to her (countess) son,

``has a little son eight years old, I believe, and she (countess) has never been parted from him (son) before, and she (countess) keeps fretting over leaving him (son).'' (son)

Yes, the countess and I have been talking all the time, I of my son and she (countess) of hers,'' said Madame Karenina, and again a smile lighted up her (countess) face, a caressing smile intended for him (son).

I am afraid that you must have been dreadfully bored,'' he (son) said, promptly catching the ball of coquetry she (countess) had flung him (son).

'' '' '' But apparently she (countess) did not care to pursue the conversation in that strain, and she (countess) turned to the old countess.

'' Thank you so much. The time has passed so quickly. Good-bye, countess.''

``Good-bye, my love,'' (the countess)
answered the countess. '' Let me have a kiss of your pretty face.

I speak plainly, at my age, and I tell you simply that I've lost my heart to you.'' Stereotyped as the phrase was, Madame Karenina obviously believed it and was delighted by it.

She (countess) flushed, bent down slightly, and put her (countess) cheek to the countess's lips, drew herself up again, and with the same smile fluttering between her (countess) lips and her (countess) eyes, she (countess) gave her (countess) hand to Vronsky.

He (my) pressed the little hand she (countess) gave him (my), and was delighted, as though at something special, by the energetic squeeze with which she (countess) freely and vigorously shook his (my) hand.

She (countess) went out with the rapid step which bore her (countess) rather fully-developed figure with such strange lightness. '' Very charming,'' said the countess.

That was just what her (countess) son was thinking. His (son) eyes followed her (countess) till her (countess) graceful figure was out of sight, and then the smile remained on his (son) face.

He (son) saw out of the window how she (countess) went up to her (countess) brother, put her (countess) arm in his (brother), and began telling him (brother) something eagerly, obviously something that had nothing to do with him (brother), Vronsky, and at that he (brother) felt annoyed.

'' Well, maman, are you perfectly well? '' he (brother) repeated, turning to his (brother) mother. '' Everything has been delightful. Alexander has been very good, and Marie has grown very pretty.

And she (Marie) began telling him (Alexander) again of what interested her (Marie) most--the christening of her (Marie) grandson, for which she (Marie) had been staying in Petersburg, and the special favor shown her (Marie) elder son by the Tsar.

She (Marie)'s very interesting. '' '' Here's Lavrenty,'' said Vronsky, looking out of the window;

``now we can go, if you like.

The old butler who had traveled with the countess, came to the carriage to announce that everything was ready, and the countess got up to go.

'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)

'' Come; there's not such a crowd now,'' said Vronsky. The maid took a handbag and the lap dog, the butler and a porter the other baggage.

Vronsky gave his (Vronsky) mother his (Vronsky) arm; but just as they were getting out of the carriage several men ran suddenly by with panic-stricken faces.

The station-master, too, ran by in his (Vronsky) extraordinary colored cap. Obviously something unusual had happened. The crowd who had left the train were running back again.

'' What?... What? ... Where? ... Flung himself!... Crushed!... '' was heard among the crowd. Stepan Arkadyevitch, with his (Vronsky) sister on his (Vronsky) arm, turned back.

They too looked scared, and stopped at the carriage door to avoid the crowd. The ladies got in, while Vronsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch followed the crowd to find out details of the disaster.

A guard, either drunk or too much muffled up in the bitter frost, had not heard the train moving back, and had been crushed.

Before Vronsky and Oblonsky came back the ladies heard the facts from the butler. Oblonsky and Vronsky had both seen the mutilated corpse.

Oblonsky was evidently upset. He (Vronsky) frowned and seemed ready to cry. '' Ah, how awful! Ah, Anna, if you had seen it!

Ah, how awful! '' he (Vronsky) said. Vronsky did not speak; his (Vronsky) handsome face was serious, but perfectly composed. '' Oh, if you had seen it, countess,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' And his (Vronsky) wife was there.... It was awful to see her (wife)!.... She (wife) flung herself on the body. They say he (Vronsky) was the only support of an immense family.

How awful!''

``Couldn't one do anything for her (wife)?'' (Madame Karenina/Karenina)
said Madame Karenina in an agitated whisper. Vronsky glanced at her (wife), and immediately got out of the carriage.

When he (Vronsky) came back a few minutes later, Stepan Arkadyevitch was already in conversation with the countess about the new singer, while the countess was impatiently looking towards the door, waiting for her (countess) son.

'' I'll be back directly, maman,'' he (son) remarked, turning round in the doorway. '' Now let us be off,'' said Vronsky, coming in.

They went out together. Vronsky was in front with his (Vronsky) mother. Behind walked Madame Karenina with her (mother) brother. Just as they were going out of the station the station-master overtook Vronsky.

'' You gave my assistant two hundred roubles. Would you kindly explain for whose benefit you intend them?''

``For the widow,'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
said Vronsky, shrugging his (Vronsky) shoulders.

'' I should have thought there was no need to ask. ''

``You gave that? '' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)
cried Oblonsky, behind, and, pressing his (Vronsky) sister's hand, he (Vronsky) added:
``Very nice, very nice!

Isn't he (Vronsky) a splendid fellow? Good-bye, countess. '' (he)

And he (Vronsky) and his (Vronsky) sister stood still, looking for her (sister) maid. When they went out the Vronsky's carriage had already driven away.

People coming in were still talking of what happened. '' What a horrible death!'' said a gentleman, passing by. '' They say he (gentleman) was cut in two pieces.''

``On the contrary, I think it's the easiest--instantaneous,'' (unknown)
observed another. '' How is it they don't take proper precautions? '' said a third.

Madame Karenina seated herself in the carriage, and Stepan Arkadyevitch saw with surprise that her (sister) lips were quivering, and she (sister) was with difficulty restraining her (sister) tears.

'' What is it, Anna? '' he (gentleman) asked, when they had driven a few hundred yards. '' It's an omen of evil,'' she (Anna) said.

'' What nonsense!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' You've come, that's the chief thing. You can't conceive how I'm resting my hopes on you.''

``Have you known Vronsky long? '' (she)
she (Anna) asked. '' Yes. You know we're hoping he (gentleman) will marry Kitty. ''
``Yes?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna softly.

``Come now, let us talk of you,'' (she)
she (Anna) added, tossing her (Anna) head, as though she (Anna) would physically shake off something superfluous oppressing her (Anna).

``Let us talk of your affairs. I got your letter, and here I am. '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
'' Yes, all my hopes are in you,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' Well, tell me all about it. '' And Stepan Arkadyevitch began to tell his (gentleman) story. On reaching home Oblonsky helped his (gentleman) sister out, sighed, pressed her (sister) hand, and set off to his (gentleman) office.

Chapter 19 When Anna went into the room, Dolly was sitting in the little drawing-room with a white-headed fat little boy, already like his (boy) father, giving him (boy) a lesson in French reading.

His (boy) mother had several times taken his (boy) hand from it, but the fat little hand went back to the button again.

As the boy read, he (boy) kept twisting and trying to tear off a button that was nearly off his (boy) jacket. His (boy) mother pulled the button off and put it in her (mother) pocket.

'' Keep your hands still, Grisha,'' she (mother) said, and she (mother) took up her (mother) work, a coverlet she (mother) had long been making.

She (mother) always set to work on it at depressed moments, and now she (mother) knitted at it nervously, twitching her (mother) fingers and counting the stitches.

Though she (mother) had sent word the day before to her (mother) husband that it was nothing to her (mother) whether his (husband) sister came or not, she (mother) had made everything ready for her (mother) arrival, and was expecting her (mother) sister-in-law with emotion.

Still she (mother) did not forget that Anna, her (Anna) sister-in-law, was the wife of one of the most important personages in Petersburg, and was a Petersburg grande dame .

And, thanks to this circumstance, she (Anna) did not carry out her (Anna) threat to her (Anna) husband--that is to say, she (Anna) remembered that her (Anna) sister-in-law was coming.

Dolly was crushed by her (Dolly) sorrow, utterly swallowed up by it. '' And, after all, Anna is in no wise to blame,'' thought Dolly.

I know nothing of her (Dolly) except the very best, and I have seen nothing but kindness and affection from her (Dolly) towards myself.

It was true that as far as she (Dolly) could recall her (Dolly) impressions at Petersburg at the Karenins', she (Dolly) did not like their household itself; there was something artificial in the whole framework of their family life.

'' '' '' But why should I not receive her (Dolly)? If only she (Dolly) doesn't take it into her (Dolly) head to console me!'' thought Dolly.

All consolation and counsel and Christian forgiveness, all that I have thought over a thousand times, and it's all no use.

She (Dolly) did not want to talk of her (Dolly) sorrow, but with that sorrow in her (Dolly) heart she (Dolly) could not talk of outside matters.

She (Dolly) knew that in one way or another she (Dolly) would tell Anna everything, and she (Anna) was alternately glad at the thought of speaking freely, and angry at the necessity of speaking of her (Anna) humiliation with her (Anna), his (counsel) sister, and of hearing her (Anna) ready-made phrases of good advice and comfort.

She (Anna) had been on the lookout for her (Anna), glancing at her (Anna) watch every minute, and, as so often happens, let slip just that minute when her (Anna) visitor arrived, so that she (Anna) did not hear the bell.

Catching a sound of skirts and light steps at the door, she (Anna) looked round, and her (Anna) care-worn face unconsciously expressed not gladness, but wonder.

'' '' All these days Dolly had been alone with her (Dolly) children. She (Dolly) got up and embraced her (Dolly) sister-in-law. '' What, here already!''

``I am glad, too,'' (Dolly)

Heavens, how he (I)'s grown!'' said Anna; and kissing him (I), never taking her (Anna) eyes off Dolly, she (Dolly) stood still and flushed a little.

She (Anna) mentioned them, not only remembering the names, but the years, months, characters, illnesses of all the children, and Dolly could not but appreciate that.

She (Dolly) took her (Dolly) in her (Dolly) arms and kissed her (Dolly). '' Delightful child, delightful! Show me them all. '' '' Very well, we will go to them,'' she (Dolly) said.

Dolly looked coldly at Anna; she (Anna) was waiting now for phrases of conventional sympathy, but Anna said nothing of the sort.

Dolly, dear,'' she (Anna) said,

Dolly,'' she (Dolly) said,
``he (Dolly) has told me.'' (she)
'' But, darling, I'm simply sorry, sorry from my heart for you!''

Under the thick lashes of her (Dolly) shining eyes tears suddenly glittered. She (Dolly) moved nearer to her (Dolly) sister-in-law and took her (Dolly) hand in her (Dolly) vigorous little hand.

Dolly did not shrink away, but her (Dolly) face did not lose its frigid expression. She (Dolly) said: ``To comfort me's impossible. Everything's lost after what has happened, everything's over!

Anna lifted the wasted, thin hand of Dolly, kissed it and said:

``But, Dolly, what's to be done, what's to be done?

'' (Dolly)

And directly she (Dolly) had said this, her (Dolly) face suddenly softened. How is it best to act in this awful position--that's what you must think of.''

And the worst of all is, you see, that I can't cast him (Dolly) off: there are the children, I am tied.

'' All's over, and there's nothing more,'' said Dolly. '' And I can't live with him (Dolly)! it's a torture to me to see him (Dolly).''

``Dolly, darling, he (Dolly) has spoken to me, but I want to hear it from you: tell me about it. '' (Dolly)
Dolly looked at her (Dolly) inquiringly.

Sympathy and love unfeigned were visible on Anna's face. '' Very well,'' she (Anna) said all at once. '' But I will tell you it from the beginning.

You know how I was married. With the education mamma gave us I was more than innocent, I was stupid. I knew nothing.

I know they say men tell their wives of their former lives, but Stiva''--she (Anna) corrected herself--

``Stepan Arkadyevitch told me nothing. You'll hardly believe it, but till now I imagined that I was the only woman he (you) had known.

You must understand that I was so far from suspecting infidelity, I regarded it as impossible, and then-- try to imagine it--with such ideas, to find out suddenly all the horror, all the loathsomeness....

So I lived eight years. You must try and understand me. To be fully convinced of one's happiness, and all at once...

'' (she)

continued Dolly, holding back her (Dolly) sobs,
``to get a letter...his (you) letter to his (you) mistress, my governess. No, it's too awful!'' (Dolly)

I can understand being carried away by feeling,'' she (Dolly) went on after a brief silence,

``but deliberately, slyly deceiving me...and with whom?...

She (Dolly) hastily pulled out her (Dolly) handkerchief and hid her (Dolly) face in it. '' (she)

To go on being my husband together with her (Dolly)...it's awful!

You can't understand...'' '' Oh, yes, I understand! I understand! Dolly, dearest, I do understand,'' said Anna, pressing her (Anna) hand. ''

And do you imagine he (husband) realizes all the awfulness of my position?'' Dolly resumed. '' Not the slightest! He (husband)'s happy and contented.''

'' Oh, no!'' Anna interposed quickly. '' He (husband)'s to be pitied, he (husband)'s weighed down by remorse... ''

``Is he (husband) capable of remorse?'' (he)

Dolly interrupted, gazing intently into her (Dolly) sister-in-law's face. '' Yes. I know him (husband). I could not look at him (husband) without feeling sorry for him (husband).

'' -LRB-and here Anna guessed what would touch Dolly most-RRB-

Yes, I can see that his (husband) position is awful; it's worse for the guilty than the innocent,'' (Dolly)

she (Dolly) said,

'' (she)

Dolly looked dreamily away beyond her (Dolly) sister-in-law as she (Dolly) listened to her (Dolly) words. '' But how am I to forgive him (husband), how am I to be his (husband) wife again after her (wife)?

For me to live with him (husband) now would be torture, just because I love my past love for him (husband)... '' And sobs cut short her (wife) words.

But as though of set design, each time she (wife) was softened she (wife) began to speak again of what exasperated her (wife). ''

She (wife)'s young, you see, she (wife)'s pretty,'' she (wife) went on. '' Do you know, Anna, my youth and my beauty are gone, taken by whom?

I have worked for him (husband), and all I had has gone in his (husband) service, and now of course any fresh, vulgar creature has more charm for him (husband).

By him (husband) and his (husband) children. No doubt they talked of me together, or, worse still, they were silent. Do you understand?

'' Again her (Anna) eyes glowed with hatred. '' And after that he (husband) will tell me.... What! can I believe him (husband)? Never!

Would you believe it, I was teaching Grisha just now: once this was a joy to me, now it is a torture.

No, everything is over, everything that once made my comfort, the reward of my work, and my sufferings.... What have I to strive and toil for?

What's so awful is that all at once my heart's turned, and instead of love and tenderness, I have nothing but hatred for him (husband); yes, hatred.

Why are the children here? I could kill him (husband).''

``Darling Dolly, I understand, but don't torture yourself. You are so distressed, so overwrought, that you look at many things mistakenly.

'' (Dolly)

Dolly grew calmer, and for two minutes both were silent. '' What's to be done? Think for me, Anna, help me.

Anna could think of nothing, but her (Anna) heart responded instantly to each word, to each change of expression of her (Anna) sister-in-law.

I have thought over everything, and I see nothing. '' '' One thing I would say,'' began Anna. '' I am his (Anna) sister, I know his (Anna) character, that faculty of forgetting everything, everything

'' -LRB-she (Anna) waved her (Anna) hand before her (Anna) forehead-RRB-,

``that faculty for being completely carried away, but for completely repenting too. He (Anna) cannot believe it, he (Anna) cannot comprehend now how he (Anna) can have acted as he (Anna) did.'' (she)

'' No; he (Anna) understands, he (Anna) understood!'' Dolly broke in. '' But I...you are forgetting me...does it make it easier for me?''

``Wait a minute. When he (Anna) told me, I will own I did not realize all the awfulness of your position. I saw nothing but him (Anna), and that the family was broken up.

I felt sorry for him (Anna), but after talking to you, I see it, as a woman, quite differently. I see your agony, and I can't tell you how sorry I am for you!

But, Dolly, darling, I fully realize your sufferings, only there is one thing I don't know; I don't know... I don't know how much love there is still in your heart for him (Anna).

That you know--whether there is enough for you to be able to forgive him (Anna). If there is, forgive him (Anna)!'' (Dolly)

'' No,'' Dolly was beginning, but Anna cut her (Anna) short, kissing her (Anna) hand once more.

'' I know more of the world than you do,'' she (Anna) said. '' I know how men like Stiva look at it.

You speak of his (Anna) talking of you with her (Anna). That never happened. Such men are unfaithful, but their home and wife are sacred to them.

Somehow or other these women are still looked on with contempt by them, and do not touch on their feeling for their family.

They draw a sort of line that can't be crossed between them and their families. I don't understand it, but it is so.''

I remember the time when he (Anna) came to me and cried, talking of you, and all the poetry and loftiness of his (Anna) feeling for you, and I know that the longer he (Anna) has lived with you the loftier you have been in his (Anna) eyes.

'' My dear, how glad I am you came. It has made things better, ever so much better. '' Chapter 20

The whole of that day Anna spent at home, that's to say at the Oblonskys', and received no one, though some of her (Anna) acquaintances had already heard of her (Anna) arrival, and came to call; the same day.

She (Anna) merely sent a brief note to her (Anna) brother to tell him (brother) that he (brother) must not fail to dine at home.

Anna spent the whole morning with Dolly and the children. '' Come, God is merciful,'' she (Dolly) wrote. Oblonsky did dine at home

: the conversation was general, and his (God) wife, speaking to him (God), addressed him (God) as

``Stiva,'' (him)
as she (wife) had not done before.

In the relations of the husband and wife the same estrangement still remained, but there was no talk now of separation, and Stepan Arkadyevitch saw the possibility of explanation and reconciliation.

She (wife) knew Anna Arkadyevna, but only very slightly, and she (wife) came now to her (wife) sister's with some trepidation, at the prospect of meeting this fashionable Petersburg lady, whom everyone spoke so highly of.

Immediately after dinner Kitty came in. But she (Kitty) made a favorable impression on Anna Arkadyevna--she (Arkadyevna) saw that at once. Anna was unmistakably admiring her (Anna) loveliness and her (Anna) youth: before Kitty knew where she (Kitty) was

she (Kitty) found herself not merely under Anna's sway, but in love with her (Anna), as young girls do fall in love with older and married women.

In the elasticity of her (Anna) movements, the freshness and the unflagging eagerness which persisted in her (Anna) face, and broke out in her (Anna) smile and her (Anna) glance, she (Anna) would rather have passed for a girl of twenty, had it not been for a serious and at times mournful look in her (Anna) eyes, which struck and attracted Kitty.

Kitty felt that Anna was perfectly simple and was concealing nothing, but that she (Anna) had another higher world of interests inaccessible to her (Anna), complex and poetic.

After dinner, when Dolly went away to her (Dolly) own room, Anna rose quickly and went up to her (Anna) brother, who was just lighting a cigar.

Anna was not like a fashionable lady, nor the mother of a boy of eight years old.

``Stiva,'' (she)
she (Anna) said to him (boy), winking gaily, crossing him (boy) and glancing towards the door,
``go, and God help you.

'' (him)

He (God) threw down the cigar, understanding her (Anna), and departed through the doorway. When Stepan Arkadyevitch had disappeared, she (Anna) went back to the sofa where she (Anna) had been sitting, surrounded by the children.

Either because the children saw that their mother was fond of this aunt, or that they felt a special charm in her (mother) themselves, the two elder ones, and the younger following their lead, as children so often do, had clung about their new aunt since before dinner, and would not leave her (aunt) side.

And it had become a sort of game among them to sit a close as possible to their aunt, to touch her (aunt), hold her (aunt) little hand, kiss it, play with her (aunt) ring, or even touch the flounce of her (aunt) skirt.

And again Grisha poked his (it) little face under her (aunt) arm, and nestled with his (it) head on her (aunt) gown, beaming with pride and happiness.

``Come, come, as we were sitting before,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna Arkadyevna, sitting down in her (Arkadyevna) place. '' And when is your next ball?

'' she (Arkadyevna) asked Kitty. '' Next week, and a splendid ball. One of those balls where one always enjoys oneself.''

``Why, are there balls where one always enjoys oneself?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

Anna said, with tender irony. '' It's strange, but there are. At the Bobrishtchevs' one always enjoys oneself, and at the Nikitins' too, while at the Mezhkovs' it's always dull.

No, my dear, for me there are no balls now where one enjoys oneself,'' said Anna, and Kitty detected in her (Anna) eyes that mysterious world which was not open to her (Anna).

Haven't you noticed it?'' '' '' For me there are some less dull and tiresome. ''

``How can you be dull at a ball?'' (unknown)

``Why should not I be dull at a ball? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
inquired Anna. Kitty perceived that Anna knew what answer would follow.

She (Anna) blushed a little, and said:

``In the first place it's never so; and secondly, if it were, what difference would it make to me?'' (She)

'' Because you always look nicer than anyone. '' Anna had the faculty of blushing.

``Are you coming to this ball?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
asked Kitty.

'' I imagine it won't be possible to avoid going. Here, take it,'' she (Kitty) said to Tanya, who was pulling the loosely-fitting ring off her (Kitty) white, slender-tipped finger.

'' I shall be so glad if you go. I should so like to see you at a ball.''

``Anyway, if I do go, I shall comfort myself with the thought that it's a pleasure to you...

Grisha, don't pull my hair. It's untidy enough without that,'' (she)

she (Kitty) said, putting up a straying lock, which Grisha had been playing with.

'' I imagine you at the ball in lilac.'' '' And why in lilac precisely?'' asked Anna, smiling. '' Now, children, run along, run along.

Miss Hoole is calling you to tea,'' she (Hoole) said, tearing the children from her (Hoole), and sending them off to the dining room.

Do you hear? '' I know why you press me to come to the ball. You expect a great deal of this ball, and you want everyone to be there to take part in it.

''

``How do you know? Yes.'' (unknown)
'' Oh! what a happy time you are at,'' pursued Anna. '' I remember, and I know that blue haze like the mist on the mountains in Switzerland.

That mist which covers everything in that blissful time when childhood is just ending, and out of that vast circle, happy and gay, there is a path growing narrower and narrower, and it is delightful and alarming to enter the ballroom, bright and splendid as it is....

Who has not been through it?'' Kitty smiled without speaking. '' But how did she (Kitty) go through it? How I should like to know all her (Kitty) love story!

'' thought Kitty, recalling the unromantic appearance of Alexey Alexandrovitch, her (Kitty) husband. '' I know something. Stiva told me, and I congratulate you.

I liked him (Alexandrovitch) so much,'' Anna continued. '' I met Vronsky at the railway station. ''

``Oh, was he (Alexandrovitch) there? '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
asked Kitty, blushing.

I traveled yesterday with Vronsky's mother,'' she (Kitty) went on;

``and his (Vronsky) mother talked without a pause of him (Vronsky), he (Vronsky)'s her (mother) favorite.

'' (she)

What was it Stiva told you?''
``Stiva gossiped about it all. And I should be so glad... I know mothers are partial, but...'' (unknown)

``What did his (Vronsky) mother tell you?'' (unknown)
'' Oh, a great deal! And I know that he (Vronsky)'s her (mother) favorite; still one can see how chivalrous he (Vronsky) is....

Well, for instance, she (mother) told me that he (Vronsky) had wanted to give up all his (Vronsky) property to his (Vronsky) brother, that he (Vronsky) had done something extraordinary when he (Vronsky) was quite a child, saved a woman out of the water.

He (Vronsky)'s a hero, in fact,'' said Anna, smiling and recollecting the two hundred roubles he (Vronsky) had given at the station. But she (Anna) did not tell Kitty about the two hundred roubles.

She (Kitty) felt that there was something that had to do with her (Kitty) in it, and something that ought not to have been.

She (Kitty) pressed me very much to go and see her (Kitty),'' Anna went on;

``and I shall be glad to go to see her (Anna) tomorrow.

Stiva is staying a long while in Dolly's room, thank God,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

Anna added, changing the subject, and getting up, Kitty fancied, displeased with something.

For some reason it was disagreeable to her (Kitty) to think of it. '' '' No, I'm first! No, I!'' screamed the children, who had finished tea, running up to their Aunt Anna.

All together,'' said Anna, and she (Anna) ran laughing to meet them, and embraced and swung round all the throng of swarming children, shrieking with delight.

'' Chapter 21 Dolly came out of her (Dolly) room to the tea of the grown-up people. Stepan Arkadyevitch did not come out.

I am afraid you'll be cold upstairs,'' observed Dolly, addressing Anna; ``I want to move you downstairs, and we shall be nearer.

``Oh, please, don't trouble about me,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
answered Anna, looking intently into Dolly's face, trying to make out whether there had been a reconciliation or not.

He (we) must have left his (we) wife's room by the other door. '' '' '' It will be lighter for you here,'' answered her (wife) sister-in-law.

'' I assure you that I sleep everywhere, and always like a marmot.'' '' What's the question? '' inquired Stepan Arkadyevitch, coming out of his (we) room and addressing his (we) wife.

From his (we) tone both Kitty and Anna knew that a reconciliation had taken place. '' I want to move Anna downstairs, but we must hang up blinds.

No one knows how to do it; I must see to it myself,'' answered Dolly addressing him (we). '' God knows whether they are fully reconciled,'' thought Anna, hearing her (Anna) tone, cold and composed.

'' Oh, nonsense, Dolly, always making difficulties,'' answered her (Dolly) husband. '' Come, I'll do it all, if you like...''

``Yes, they must be reconciled,'' (I)
thought Anna.

You tell Matvey to do what can't be done, and go away yourself, leaving him (husband) to make a muddle of everything,'' and her (Anna) habitual, mocking smile curved the corners of Dolly's lips as she (Dolly) spoke.

Full, full reconciliation, full,'' thought Anna;

``thank God!'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
and rejoicing that she (Anna) was the cause of it, she (Anna) went up to Dolly and kissed her (Dolly).

'' I know how you do everything,'' answered Dolly. '' '' '' Not at all. Why do you always look down on me and Matvey?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling hardly perceptibly, and addressing his (God) wife.

The whole evening Dolly was, as always, a little mocking in her (Dolly) tone to her (Dolly) husband, while Stepan Arkadyevitch was happy and cheerful, but not so as to seem as though, having been forgiven, he (husband) had forgotten his (husband) offense.

At half-past nine o'clock a particularly joyful and pleasant family conversation over the tea-table at the Oblonskys' was broken up by an apparently simple incident.

But this simple incident for some reason struck everyone as strange. Talking about common acquaintances in Petersburg, Anna got up quickly.

'' She (Anna) is in my album,'' she (Anna) said;

``and , by the way, I'll show you my Seryozha,'' (she)
she (Anna) added, with a mother's smile of pride.

Towards ten o'clock, when she (Anna) usually said good-night to her (Anna) son, and often before going to a ball put him (son) to bed herself, she (Anna) felt depressed at being so far from him (son); and whatever she (Anna) was talking about, she (Anna) kept coming back in thought to her (Anna) curly-headed Seryozha.

She (Anna) longed to look at his (son) photograph and talk of him (son). Seizing the first pretext, she (Anna) got up, and with her (Anna) light, resolute step went for her (Anna) album.

The stairs up to her (Anna) room came out on the landing of the great warm main staircase. Just as she (Anna) was leaving the drawing room, a ring was heard in the hall.

'' Who can that be?'' said Dolly. '' It's early for me to be fetched, and for anyone else it's late,'' observed Kitty.

When Anna was passing the top of the staircase, a servant was running up to announce the visitor, while the visitor himself was standing under a lamp.

Anna glancing down at once recognized Vronsky, and a strange feeling of pleasure and at the same time of dread of something stirred in her (Anna) heart.

'' Sure to be someone with papers for me,'' put in Stepan Arkadyevitch. He (visitor) was standing still, not taking off his (visitor) coat, pulling something out of his (visitor) pocket.

At the instant when she (Anna) was just facing the stairs, he (visitor) raised his (visitor) eyes, caught sight of her (Anna), and into the expression of his (visitor) face there passed a shade of embarrassment and dismay.

With a slight inclination of her (Anna) head she (Anna) passed, hearing behind her (Anna) Stepan Arkadyevitch's loud voice calling him (visitor) to come up, and the quiet, soft, and composed voice of Vronsky refusing.

When Anna returned with the album, he (visitor) was already gone, and Stepan Arkadyevitch was telling them that he (visitor) had called to inquire about the dinner they were giving next day to a celebrity who had just arrived.

She (Anna) thought that she (Anna) was the only person who knew why he (visitor) had come, and why he (visitor) would not come up.

'' And nothing would induce him (visitor) to come up. What a queer fellow he (visitor) is!'' added Stepan Arkadyevitch. Kitty blushed. ''

He (visitor) has been at home,'' she (Kitty) thought,

``and didn't find me, and thought I should be here, but he (visitor) did not come up because he (visitor) thought it late, and Anna's here.

There was nothing either exceptional or strange in a man's calling at half-past nine on a friend to inquire details of a proposed dinner party and not coming in, but it seemed strange to all of them.

'' (she)

All of them looked at each other, saying nothing, and began to look at Anna's album. Above all, it seemed strange and not right to Anna.

The ball was only just beginning as Kitty and her (Kitty) mother walked up the great staircase, flooded with light, and lined with flowers and footmen in powder and red coats.

From the rooms came a constant, steady hum, as from a hive, and the rustle of movement; and while on the landing between trees they gave last touches to their hair and dresses before the mirror, they heard from the ballroom the careful, distinct notes of the fiddles of the orchestra beginning the first waltz.

A little old man in civilian dress, arranging his (man) gray curls before another mirror, and diffusing an odor of scent, stumbled against them on the stairs, and stood aside, evidently admiring Kitty, whom he (man) did not know.

A beardless youth, one of those society youths whom the old Prince Shtcherbatsky called

``young bucks,'' (Shtcherbatsky/Prince Shtcherbatsky/Prince)
in an exceedingly open waistcoat, straightening his (Shtcherbatsky) white tie as he (Shtcherbatsky) went, bowed to them, and after running by, came back to ask Kitty for a quadrille.

Chapter 22 As the first quadrille had already been given to Vronsky, she (Kitty) had to promise this youth the second. An officer, buttoning his (officer) glove, stood aside in the doorway, and stroking his (officer) mustache, admired rosy Kitty.

Although her (Kitty) dress, her (Kitty) coiffure, and all the preparations for the ball had cost Kitty great trouble and consideration, at this moment she (Kitty) walked into the ballroom in her (Kitty) elaborate tulle dress over a pink slip as easily and simply as though all the rosettes and lace, all the minute details of her (Kitty) attire, had not cost her (Kitty) or her (Kitty) family a moment's attention, as though she (Kitty) had been born in that tulle and lace, with her (Kitty) hair done up high on her (Kitty) head, and a rose and two leaves on the top of it.

When, just before entering the ballroom, the princess, her (princess) mother, tried to turn right side out of the ribbon of her (princess) sash, Kitty had drawn back a little.

She (Kitty) felt that everything must be right of itself, and graceful, and nothing could need setting straight. It was one of Kitty's best days.

Her (Kitty) dress was not uncomfortable anywhere; her (Kitty) lace berthe did not droop anywhere; her (Kitty) rosettes were not crushed nor torn off; her (Kitty) pink slippers with high, hollowed-out heels did not pinch, but gladdened her (Kitty) feet; and the thick rolls of fair chignon kept up on her (Kitty) head as if they were her (Kitty) own hair.

All the three buttons buttoned up without tearing on the long glove that covered her (Kitty) hand without concealing its lines. The black velvet of her (Kitty) locket nestled with special softness round her (Kitty) neck.

That velvet was delicious; at home, looking at her (Kitty) neck in the looking glass, Kitty had felt that that velvet was speaking.

About all the rest there might be a doubt, but the velvet was delicious. Kitty smiled here too, at the ball, when she (Kitty) glanced at it in the glass.

Her (Kitty) bare shoulders and arms gave Kitty a sense of chill marble, a feeling she (Kitty) particularly liked. Her (Kitty) eyes sparkled, and her (Kitty) rosy lips could not keep from smiling from the consciousness of her (Kitty) own attractiveness.

She (Kitty) had scarcely entered the ballroom and reached the throng of ladies, all tulle, ribbons, lace, and flowers, waiting to be asked to dance--Kitty was never one of that throng--when she (Kitty) was asked for a waltz, and asked by the best partner, the first star in the hierarchy of the ballroom, a renowned director of dances, a married man, handsome and well-built, Yegorushka Korsunsky.

He (man) had only just left the Countess Bonina, with whom he (man) had danced the first half of the waltz, and, scanning his (man) kingdom--that is to say, a few couples who had started dancing--he (man) caught sight of Kitty, entering, and flew up to her (Kitty) with that peculiar, easy amble which is confined to directors of balls.

Without even asking her (Kitty) if she (Kitty) cared to dance, he (man) put out his (man) arm to encircle her (Kitty) slender waist. She (Kitty) looked round for someone to give her (Kitty) fan to, and their hostess, smiling to her (Kitty), took it.

How nice you've come in good time,'' he (man) said to her (Kitty), embracing her (Kitty) waist;

``such a bad habit to be late.

Bending her (Kitty) left hand, she (Kitty) laid it on his (man) shoulder, and her (Kitty) little feet in their pink slippers began swiftly, lightly, and rhythmically moving over the slippery floor in time to the music.

It's a rest to waltz with you,'' (her)

he (man) said to her (Kitty), as they fell into the first slow steps of the waltz.

'' '' '' '' It's exquisite--such lightness, precision. '' He (man) said to her (Kitty) the same thing he (man) said to almost all his (man) partners whom he (man) knew well.

She (Kitty) was not like a girl at her (Kitty) first ball, for whom all faces in the ballroom melt into one vision of fairyland.

And she (Kitty) was not a girl who had gone the stale round of balls till every face in the ballroom was familiar and tiresome.

But she (Kitty) was in the middle stage between these two; she (Kitty) was excited, and at the same time she (Kitty) had sufficient self-possession to be able to observe.

She (Kitty) smiled at his (man) praise, and continued to look about the room over his (man) shoulder. In the left corner of the ballroom she (Kitty) saw the cream of society gathered together.

There--incredibly naked--was the beauty Lidi, Korsunsky's wife; there was the lady of the house; there shone the bald head of Krivin, always to be found where the best people were.

There, too, she (lady) descried Stiva, and there she (lady) saw the exquisite figure and head of Anna in a black velvet gown.

In that direction gazed the young men, not venturing to approach. And he (man) was there. Kitty had not seen him (man) since the evening she (Kitty) refused Levin.

With her (Kitty) long-sighted eyes, she (Kitty) knew him (Levin) at once, and was even aware that he (Levin) was looking at her (Kitty). '' Another turn, eh?

You're not tired?'' said Korsunsky, a little out of breath. '' No, thank you!''

``Where shall I take you?'' (unknown)
``Madame Karenina's here, I think...take me to her (Kitty).'' (Korsunsky)

And Korsunsky began waltzing with measured steps straight towards the group in the left corner, continually saying,

``Pardon, mesdames, pardon, pardon, mesdames'' (Korsunsky)
; and steering his (Levin) course through the sea of lace, tulle, and ribbon, and not disarranging a feather, he (Levin) turned his (Levin) partner sharply round, so that her (Kitty) slim ankles, in light transparent stockings, were exposed to view, and her (Kitty) train floated out in fan shape and covered Krivin's knees.

'' Wherever you command. '' Korsunsky bowed, set straight his (fan) open shirt front, and gave her (Kitty) his (fan) arm to conduct her (Kitty) to Anna Arkadyevna.

Anna was not in lilac, as Kitty had so urgently wished, but in a black, low-cut, velvet gown, showing her (Kitty) full throat and shoulders, that looked as though carved in old ivory, and her (Kitty) rounded arms, with tiny, slender wrists.

Kitty, flushed, took her (Kitty) train from Krivin's knees, and, a little giddy, looked round, seeking Anna. The whole gown was trimmed with Venetian guipure.

On her (Anna) head, among her (Anna) black hair--her (Anna) own, with no false additions--was a little wreath of pansies, and a bouquet of the same in the black ribbon of her (Anna) sash among white lace.

All that was noticeable was the little wilful tendrils of her (Anna) curly hair that would always break free about her (Anna) neck and temples.

Her (Anna) coiffure was not striking. Round her (Anna) well-cut, strong neck was a thread of pearls. Kitty had been seeing Anna every day; she (Anna) adored her (Anna), and had pictured her (Anna) invariably in lilac.

But now seeing her (Anna) in black, she (Anna) felt that she (Anna) had not fully seen her (Anna) charm. She (Anna) saw her (Anna) now as someone quite new and surprising to her (Anna).

Now she (Anna) understood that Anna could not have been in lilac, and that her (Anna) charm was just that she (Anna) always stood out against her (Anna) attire, that her (Anna) dress could never be noticeable on her (Anna).

And her (Anna) black dress, with its sumptuous lace, was not noticeable on her (Anna); it was only the frame, and all that was seen was she (Anna)--simple, natural, elegant, and at the same time gay and eager.

She (Anna) was standing holding herself, as always, very erect, and when Kitty drew near the group she (Kitty) was speaking to the master of the house, her (Kitty) head slightly turned towards him (master).

No, I don't throw stones,'' she (Kitty) was saying, in answer to something,

``though I can't understand it,'' (she)
she (Kitty) went on, shrugging her (Kitty) shoulders, and she (Kitty) turned at once with a soft smile of protection towards Kitty.

With a flying, feminine glance she (Kitty) scanned her (Kitty) attire, and made a movement of her (Kitty) head, hardly perceptible, but understood by Kitty, signifying approval of her (Kitty) dress and her (Kitty) looks.

'' '' You came into the room dancing,'' she (Kitty) added. '' This is one of my most faithful supporters,'' said Korsunsky, bowing to Anna Arkadyevna, whom he (Kitty) had not yet seen.

'' The princess helps to make balls happy and successful. Anna Arkadyevna, a waltz? '' he (Kitty) said, bending down to her (Arkadyevna).

'' Why, have you met?'' inquired their host. '' Is there anyone we have not met? My wife and I are like white wolves--everyone knows us,'' answered Korsunsky.

'' A waltz, Anna Arkadyevna?''

``I don't dance when it's possible not to dance,'' (she)
she (Arkadyevna) said. '' But tonight it's impossible,'' answered Korsunsky.

Well, since it's impossible tonight, let us start,'' she (Arkadyevna) said, not noticing Vronsky's bow, and she (Arkadyevna) hastily put her (Arkadyevna) hand on Korsunsky's shoulder.

At that instant Vronsky came up. '' '' What is she (Arkadyevna) vexed with him (Vronsky) about?'' thought Kitty, discerning that Anna had intentionally not responded to Vronsky's bow.

Vronsky went up to Kitty reminding her (Kitty) of the first quadrille, and expressing his (Vronsky) regret that he (Vronsky) had not seen her (Kitty) all this time.

Kitty gazed in admiration at Anna waltzing, and listened to him (Vronsky). She (Anna) expected him (Vronsky) to ask her (Anna) for a waltz, but he (Vronsky) did not, and she (Anna) glanced wonderingly at him (Vronsky).

He (Vronsky) flushed slightly, and hurriedly asked her (Anna) to waltz, but he (Vronsky) had only just put his (Vronsky) arm round her (Anna) waist and taken the first step when the music suddenly stopped.

Kitty looked into his (Vronsky) face, which was so close to her (Kitty) own, and long afterwards--for several years after--that look, full of love, to which he (Vronsky) made no response, cut her (Kitty) to the heart with an agony of shame.

'' shouted Korsunsky from the other side of the room, and seizing the first young lady he (Vronsky) came across he (Vronsky) began dancing himself.

After the first waltz Kitty went to her (Kitty) mother, and she (Kitty) had hardly time to say a few words to Countess Nordston when Vronsky came up again for the first quadrille.

During the quadrille nothing of any significance was said: there was disjointed talk between them of the Korsunskys, husband and wife, whom he (husband) described very amusingly, as delightful children at forty, and of the future town theater; and only once the conversation touched her (wife) to the quick, when he (husband) asked her (wife) about Levin, whether he (husband) was here, and added that he (husband) liked him (husband) so much.

'' Pardon! pardon! Waltz! waltz! Chapter 23 Vronsky and Kitty waltzed several times round the room. But Kitty did not expect much from the quadrille.

She (Kitty) looked forward with a thrill at her (Kitty) heart to the mazurka. She (Kitty) fancied that in the mazurka everything must be decided.

She (Kitty) felt sure she (Kitty) would dance the mazurka with him (husband) as she (Kitty) had done at former balls, and refused five young men, saying she (Kitty) was engaged for the mazurka.

The fact that he (husband) did not during the quadrille ask her (Kitty) for the mazurka did not trouble her (Kitty). The whole ball up to the last quadrille was for Kitty an enchanted vision of delightful colors, sounds, and motions.

But as she (Kitty) was dancing the last quadrille with one of the tiresome young men whom she (Kitty) could not refuse, she (Kitty) chanced to be vis-a-vis with Vronsky and Anna.

She (Anna) had not been near Anna again since the beginning of the evening, and now again she (Anna) saw her (Anna) suddenly quite new and surprising.

She (Anna) saw in her (Anna) the signs of that excitement of success she (Anna) knew so well in herself; she (Anna) saw that she (Anna) was intoxicated with the delighted admiration she (Anna) was exciting.

She (Anna) knew that feeling and knew its signs, and saw them in Anna; saw the quivering, flashing light in her (Anna) eyes, and the smile of happiness and excitement unconsciously playing on her (Anna) lips, and the deliberate grace, precision, and lightness of her (Anna) movements.

She (Anna) only sat down when she (Anna) felt too tired and begged for a rest. '' Who? '' she (Anna) asked herself. ''

'' And not assisting the harassed young man she (Anna) was dancing with in the conversation, the thread of which he (man) had lost and could not pick up again, she (Anna) obeyed with external liveliness the peremptory shouts of Korsunsky starting them all into the grand rond , and then into the ch√¢ine , and at the same time she (Anna) kept watch with a growing pang at her (Anna) heart.

All or one? '' No, it's not the admiration of the crowd has intoxicated her (Anna), but the adoration of one. And that one?

Every time he (man) spoke to Anna the joyous light flashed into her (Anna) eyes, and the smile of happiness curved her (Anna) red lips.

she (Anna) seemed to make an effort to control herself, to try not to show these signs of delight, but they came out on her (Anna) face of themselves.

can it be he (man)? '' '' But what of him (man)? '' Kitty looked at him (man) and was filled with terror. What was pictured so clearly to Kitty in the mirror of Anna's face she (Anna) saw in him (man).

Now every time he (man) turned to her (Anna), he (man) bent his (man) head, as though he (man) would have fallen at her (Anna) feet, and in his (man) eyes there was nothing but humble submission and dread.

I would not offend you,'' his (man) eyes seemed every time to be saying,

``but I want to save myself, and I don't know how.

What had become of his (man) always self-possessed resolute manner, and the carelessly serene expression of his (man) face? '' (I)

'' On his (man) face was a look such as Kitty had never seen before.

They were speaking of common acquaintances, keeping up the most trivial conversation, but to Kitty it seemed that every word they said was determining their fate and hers.

And strange it was that they were actually talking of how absurd Ivan Ivanovitch was with his (Ivan) French, and how the Eletsky girl might have made a better match, yet these words had all the while consequence for them, and they were feeling just as Kitty did.

Nothing but the stern discipline of her (Kitty) bringing-up supported her (Kitty) and forced her (Kitty) to do what was expected of her (Kitty), that is, to dance, to answer questions, to talk, even to smile.

But before the mazurka, when they were beginning to rearrange the chairs and a few couples moved out of the smaller rooms into the big room, a moment of despair and horror came for Kitty.

The whole ball, the whole world, everything seemed lost in fog in Kitty's soul. She (Kitty) had refused five partners, and now she (Kitty) was not dancing the mazurka.

She (Kitty) had not even a hope of being asked for it, because she (Kitty) was so successful in society that the idea would never occur to anyone that she (Kitty) had remained disengaged till now.

She (Kitty) would have to tell her (Kitty) mother she (Kitty) felt ill and go home, but she (Kitty) had not the strength to do this.

She (Kitty) felt crushed. She (Kitty) went to the furthest end of the little drawing room and sank into a low chair. Her (Kitty) light, transparent skirts rose like a cloud about her (Kitty) slender waist;

one bare, thin, soft, girlish arm, hanging listlessly, was lost in the folds of her (Kitty) pink tunic; in the other she (Kitty) held her (Kitty) fan, and with rapid, short strokes fanned her (Kitty) burning face.

But while she (Kitty) looked like a butterfly, clinging to a blade of grass, and just about to open its rainbow wings for fresh flight, her (Kitty) heart ached with a horrible despair.

'' But perhaps I am wrong, perhaps it was not so? '' And again she (Kitty) recalled all she (Kitty) had seen. ''

Kitty, what is it?'' said Countess Nordston, stepping noiselessly over the carpet towards her (Nordston). '' I don't understand it. '' Kitty's lower lip began to quiver; she (Kitty) got up quickly.

'' Kitty, you're not dancing the mazurka?''

``No, no,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
said Kitty in a voice shaking with tears. '' He (lip) asked her (Kitty) for the mazurka before me,'' said Countess Nordston, knowing Kitty would understand who were
``he (lip)'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
and
``her (Kitty).

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

'' She (Kitty) said: `Why, aren't you going to dance it with Princess Shtcherbatskaya?''' '' Oh, I don't care!'' answered Kitty.

but she (Kitty) herself understood her (Kitty) position; no one knew that she (Kitty) had just refused the man whom perhaps she (Kitty) loved, and refused him (man) because she (Kitty) had put her (Kitty) faith in another.

No one Countess Nordston found Korsunsky, with whom she (Kitty) was to dance the mazurka, and told him (man) to ask Kitty. Kitty danced in the first couple, and luckily for her (Kitty)

she (Kitty) had not to talk, because Korsunsky was all the time running about directing the figure. Vronsky and Anna sat almost opposite her (Anna).

She (Anna) saw them with her (Anna) long-sighted eyes, and saw them, too, close by, when they met in the figures, and the more she (Anna) saw of them the more convinced was she (Anna) that her (Anna) unhappiness was complete.

And on Vronsky's face, always so firm and independent, she (Anna) saw that look that had struck her (Anna), of bewilderment and humble submissiveness, like the expression of an intelligent dog when it has done wrong.

She (Anna) saw that they felt themselves alone in that crowded room. Anna smiled, and her (Anna) smile was reflected by him (Vronsky). She (Anna) grew thoughtful, and he (Vronsky) became serious.

She (Anna) was fascinating in her (Anna) simple black dress, fascinating were her (Anna) round arms with their bracelets, fascinating was her (Anna) firm neck with its thread of pearls, fascinating the straying curls of her (Anna) loose hair, fascinating the graceful, light movements of her (Anna) little feet and hands, fascinating was that lovely face in its eagerness, but there was something terrible and cruel in her (Anna) fascination.

Some supernatural force drew Kitty's eyes to Anna's face. Kitty admired her (Kitty) more than ever, and more and more acute was her (Kitty) suffering.

When Vronsky saw her (Kitty), coming across her (Kitty) in the mazurka, he (Vronsky) did not at once recognize her (Kitty), she (Kitty) was so changed.

Kitty felt overwhelmed, and her (Kitty) face showed it. '' Delightful ball! '' he (Vronsky) said to her (Kitty), for the sake of saying something.

In the middle of the mazurka, repeating a complicated figure, newly invented by Korsunsky, Anna came forward into the center of the circle, chose two gentlemen, and summoned a lady and Kitty.

'' Yes,'' she (Kitty) answered. Kitty gazed at her (Kitty) in dismay as she (Kitty) went up. Anna looked at her (Anna) with drooping eyelids, and smiled, pressing her (Anna) hand.

But, noticing that Kitty only responded to her (Kitty) smile by a look of despair and amazement, she (Kitty) turned away from her (Kitty), and began gaily talking to the other lady.

Anna did not mean to stay to supper, but the master of the house began to press her (Anna) to do so.

Nonsense, Anna Arkadyevna,'' said Korsunsky, drawing her (Arkadyevna) bare arm under the sleeve of his (master) dress coat,

``I've such an idea for a cotillion!

'' (Korsunsky)

Yes, there is something uncanny, devilish and fascinating in her (Arkadyevna),'' Kitty said to herself. '' Un bijou! '' And he (master) moved gradually on, trying to draw her (Kitty) along with him (master).

No, I am not going to stay,'' answered Anna, smiling, but in spite of her (Anna) smile, both Korsunsky and the master of the house saw from her (Anna) resolute tone that she (Anna) would not stay.

No; why, as it is, I have danced more at your ball in Moscow than I have all the winter in Petersburg,'' said Anna, looking round at Vronsky, who stood near her (Anna).

Their host smiled approvingly. '' '' '' I must rest a little before my journey.''

``Are you certainly going tomorrow then?'' (Vronsky)
asked Vronsky.

Yes, I suppose so,'' answered Anna, as it were wondering at the boldness of his (Anna) question; but the irrepressible, quivering brilliance of her (Anna) eyes and her (Anna) smile set him (Anna) on fire as she (Anna) said it.

``Yes, there is something in me hateful, repulsive,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
thought Levin, as he (Levin) came away from the Shtcherbatskys', and walked in the direction of his (Levin) brother's lodgings.

'' Anna Arkadyevna did not stay to supper, but went home. Chapter 24 '' And I don't get on with other people.

Pride, they say. No, I have no pride. If I had any pride, I should not have put myself in such a position.

And he (Levin) pictured to himself Vronsky, happy, good-natured, clever, and self-possessed, certainly never placed in the awful position in which he (Levin) had been that evening.

'' '' Yes, she (Arkadyevna) was bound to choose him (Levin). So it had to be, and I cannot complain of anyone or anything.

I am myself to blame. What right had I to imagine she (Arkadyevna) would care to join her (Arkadyevna) life to mine? Who am I and what am I?

A nobody, not wanted by any one, nor of use to anybody. '' And he (Levin) recalled his (Levin) brother Nikolay, and dwelt with pleasure on the thought of him (Levin).

'' Isn't he (Levin) right that everything in the world is base and loathsome? And are we fair in our judgment of brother Nikolay?

Of course, from the point of view of Prokofy, seeing him (Nikolay) in a torn cloak and tipsy, he (Nikolay)'s a despicable person.

But I know him (Nikolay) differently. I know his (Nikolay) soul, and know that we are like him (Nikolay). And I, instead of going to seek him (Nikolay) out, went out to dinner, and came here.

All the long way to his (Nikolay) brother's, Levin vividly recalled all the facts familiar to him (Nikolay) of his (Nikolay) brother Nikolay's life.

He (Nikolay) remembered how his (Nikolay) brother, while at the university, and for a year afterwards, had, in spite of the jeers of his (Nikolay) companions, lived like a monk, strictly observing all religious rites, services, and fasts, and avoiding every sort of pleasure, especially women.

And afterwards, how he (Nikolay) had all at once broken out: he (Nikolay) had associated with the most horrible people, and rushed into the most senseless debauchery.

He (Nikolay) remembered later the scandal over a boy, whom he (Nikolay) had taken from the country to bring up, and, in a fit of rage, had so violently beaten that proceedings were brought against him (Nikolay) for unlawfully wounding.

Then he (Nikolay) recalled the scandal with a sharper, to whom he (Nikolay) had lost money, and given a promissory note, and against whom he (Nikolay) had himself lodged a complaint, asserting that he (Nikolay) had cheated him (Nikolay).

'' Levin walked up to a lamppost, read his (Levin) brother's address, which was in his (Levin) pocketbook, and called a sledge. -LRB-This was the money Sergey Ivanovitch had paid.-RRB-

He (Ivanovitch) remembered the shameful proceedings he (Ivanovitch) had tried to get up against his (Ivanovitch) brother Sergey Ivanovitch, accusing him (Ivanovitch) of not having paid him (Ivanovitch) his (Ivanovitch) share of his (Ivanovitch) mother's fortune, and the last scandal, when he (Ivanovitch) had gone to a western province in an official capacity, and there had got into trouble for assaulting a village elder....

It was all horribly disgusting, yet to Levin it appeared not at all in the same disgusting light as it inevitably would to those who did not know Nikolay, did not know all his (Nikolay) story, did not know his (Nikolay) heart.

Levin remembered that when Nikolay had been in the devout stage, the period of fasts and monks and church services, when he (Nikolay) was seeking in religion a support and a curb for his (Nikolay) passionate temperament, everyone, far from encouraging him (Nikolay), had jeered at him (Nikolay), and he (Nikolay), too, with the others.

They had teased him (Nikolay), called him (Nikolay) Noah and Monk; and, when he (Nikolay) had broken out, no one had helped him (Nikolay), but everyone had turned away from him (Nikolay) with horror and disgust.

Levin felt that, in spite of all the ugliness of his (Levin) life, his (Levin) brother Nikolay, in his (Levin) soul, in the very depths of his (Levin) soul, was no more in the wrong than the people who despised him (Levin).

Then he (Levin) remembered how he (Levin) had spent a night in the lockup for disorderly conduct in the street. He (Levin) was not to blame for having been born with his (Levin) unbridled temperament and his (Levin) somehow limited intelligence.

I will tell him (Levin) everything, without reserve, and I will make him (Levin) speak without reserve, too, and I'll show him (Levin) that I love him (Levin), and so understand him (Levin),'' Levin resolved to himself, as, towards eleven o'clock, he (Levin) reached the hotel of which he (Levin) had the address.

But he (Levin) had always wanted to be good. '' '' At the top, 12 and 13,'' the porter answered Levin's inquiry. ''

The door of No. 12 was half open, and there came out into the streak of light thick fumes of cheap, poor tobacco, and the sound of a voice, unknown to Levin; but he (Levin) knew at once that his (Levin) brother was there; he (Levin) heard his (Levin) cough.

As he (Levin) went in the door, the unknown voice was saying:

``It all depends with how much judgment and knowledge the thing's done.'' (he)

Konstantin Levin looked in at the door, and saw that the speaker was a young man with an immense shock of hair, wearing a Russian jerkin, and that a pockmarked woman in a woolen gown, without collar or cuffs, was sitting on the sofa.

Konstantin felt a sharp pang at his (Konstantin) heart at the thought of the strange company in which his (Konstantin) brother spent his (Konstantin) life.

No one had heard him (Konstantin), and Konstantin, taking off his (Konstantin) galoshes, listened to what the gentleman in the jerkin was saying.

At home?''

``Sure to be at home. '' (brother)
His (Konstantin) brother was not to be seen. He (Konstantin) was speaking of some enterprise.

'' Well, the devil flay them, the privileged classes,'' his (devil) brother's voice responded, with a cough. '' Masha! get us some supper and some wine if there's any left; or else go and get some.

'' The woman rose, came out from behind the screen, and saw Konstantin. '' There's some gentleman, Nikolay Dmitrievitch,'' she (woman) said.

'' Whom do you want?'' said the voice of Nikolay Levin, angrily. '' It's I,'' answered Konstantin Levin, coming forward into the light.

He (Levin) could be heard getting up hurriedly, stumbling against something, and Levin saw, facing him (Levin) in the doorway, the big, scared eyes, and the huge, thin, stooping figure of his (Levin) brother, so familiar, and yet astonishing in its weirdness and sickliness.

'' Who's I ? '' Nikolay's voice said again, still more angrily. He (Nikolay) was even thinner than three years before, when Konstantin Levin had seen him (Levin) last.

His (Levin) hair had grown thinner, the same straight mustaches hid his (Levin) lips, the same eyes gazed strangely and naively at his (Levin) visitor.

He (Levin) was wearing a short coat, and his (Levin) hands and big bones seemed huger than ever. '' Ah, Kostya!'' he (Kostya) exclaimed suddenly, recognizing his (Kostya) brother, and his (Kostya) eyes lit up with joy.

But the same second he (Kostya) looked round at the young man, and gave the nervous jerk of his (Kostya) head and neck that Konstantin knew so well, as if his (Konstantin) neckband hurt him (Konstantin); and a quite different expression, wild, suffering, and cruel, rested on his (Konstantin) emaciated face.

'' I wrote to you and Sergey Ivanovitch both that I don't know you and don't want to know you. What is it you want?

The worst and most tiresome part of his (Ivanovitch) character, what made all relations with him (Ivanovitch) so difficult, had been forgotten by Konstantin Levin when he (Levin) thought of him (Levin), and now, when he (Levin) saw his (Levin) face, and especially that nervous twitching of his (Levin) head, he (Levin) remembered it all.

'' He (Levin) was not at all the same as Konstantin had been fancying him (Konstantin). '' I didn't want to see you for anything,'' he (Konstantin) answered timidly.

'' I've simply come to see you. '' His (Konstantin) brother's timidity obviously softened Nikolay. His (Nikolay) lips twitched. '' Oh, so that's it?

'' he (Nikolay) said. '' Well, come in; sit down. Like some supper? Masha, bring supper for three. No, stop a minute.

he (Nikolay) said, addressing his (Nikolay) brother, and indicating the gentleman in the jerkin:

``This is Mr. Kritsky, my friend from Kiev, a very remarkable man.

Do you know who this is? '' (the gentleman)

He (man)'s persecuted by the police, of course, because he (man)'s not a scoundrel. '' And he (man) looked round in the way he (man) always did at everyone in the room.

Seeing that the woman standing in the doorway was moving to go, he (man) shouted to her (woman),

``Wait a minute, I said.

And with the inability to express himself, the incoherence that Konstantin knew so well, he (Konstantin) began, with another look round at everyone, to tell his (Konstantin) brother Kritsky's story: how he (Konstantin) had been expelled from the university for starting a benefit society for the poor students and Sunday schools; and how he (Konstantin) had afterwards been a teacher in a peasant school, and how he (Konstantin) had been driven out of that too, and had afterwards been condemned for something.

'' (her)

'' You're of the Kiev university?'' said Konstantin Levin to Kritsky, to break the awkward silence that followed. '' Yes, I was of Kiev,'' Kritsky replied angrily, his (Levin) face darkening.

``And this woman,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Nikolay Levin interrupted him (Levin), pointing to her (woman),
``is the partner of my life, Marya Nikolaevna. I took her (Nikolaevna) out of a bad house,'' (her)
and he (Levin) jerked his (Levin) neck saying this;

``but I love her (Nikolaevna) and respect her (Nikolaevna), and any one who wants to know me,'' (he)
he (Levin) added, raising his (Levin) voice and knitting his (Levin) brows,
``I beg to love her (Nikolaevna) and respect her (Nikolaevna).

She (Nikolaevna)'s just the same as my wife, just the same. So now you know whom you've to do with. And if you think you're lowering yourself, well, here's the floor, there's the door.

'' (he)

And again his (Levin) eyes traveled inquiringly over all of them. '' Why I should be lowering myself, I don't understand.

''

``Then, Masha, tell them to bring supper; three portions, spirits and wine.... No, wait a minute.... No, it doesn't matter....

Go along. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Chapter 25 '' So you see,'' pursued Nikolay Levin, painfully wrinkling his (Levin) forehead and twitching. It was obviously difficult for him (Levin) to think of what to say and do.

'' Here, do you see?''... He (Levin) pointed to some sort of iron bars, fastened together with strings, lying in a corner of the room.

'' Do you see that? That's the beginning of a new thing we're going into. It's a productive association...'' Konstantin scarcely heard him (Konstantin).

He (Konstantin) looked into his (Konstantin) sickly, consumptive face, and he (Konstantin) was more and more sorry for him (Konstantin), and he (Konstantin) could not force himself to listen to what his (Konstantin) brother was telling him (Konstantin) about the association.

He (Konstantin) saw that this association was a mere anchor to save him (Konstantin) from self-contempt. Nikolay Levin went on talking:

``You know that capital oppresses the laborer.

The laborers with us, the peasants, bear all the burden of labor, and are so placed that however much they work they can't escape from their position of beasts of burden.

All the profits of labor, on which they might improve their position, and gain leisure for themselves, and after that education, all the surplus values are taken from them by the capitalists.

And society's so constituted that the harder they work, the greater the profit of the merchants and landowners, while they stay beasts of burden to the end.

Yes, of course,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

said Konstantin, looking at the patch of red that had come out on his (Konstantin) brother's projecting cheek bones.

And so we're founding a locksmiths' association, where all the production and profit and the chief instruments of production will be in common.

And that state of things must be changed,'' he (chief) finished up, and he (chief) looked questioningly at his (chief) brother. '' '' ''

``Where is the association to be?'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
asked Konstantin Levin. '' In the village of Vozdrem, Kazan government.'' '' But why in a village?

In the villages, I think, there is plenty of work as it is. Why a locksmiths' association in a village? ''

``Why?

Because the peasants are just as much slaves as they ever were, and that's why you and Sergey Ivanovitch don't like people to try and get them out of their slavery,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

said Nikolay Levin, exasperated by the objection.

Konstantin Levin sighed, looking meanwhile about the cheerless and dirty room. This sigh seemed to exasperate Nikolay still more. '' I know your and Sergey Ivanovitch's aristocratic views.

I know that he (Ivanovitch) applies all the power of his (Ivanovitch) intellect to justify existing evils.'' '' No; and what do you talk of Sergey Ivanovitch for?'' said Levin, smiling.

'' Sergey Ivanovitch? I'll tell you what for!'' Nikolay Levin shrieked suddenly at the name of Sergey Ivanovitch. '' I'll tell you what for....

But what's the use of talking? There's only one thing.... What did you come to me for? You look down on this, and you're welcome to,--and go away, in God's name go away!

'' he (God) shrieked, getting up from his (God) chair. '' And go away, and go away!''

``I don't look down on it at all,'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
said Konstantin Levin timidly.

'' I don't even dispute it. '' At that instant Marya Nikolaevna came back. Nikolay Levin looked round angrily at her (Nikolaevna).

; I've grown irritable,'' said Nikolay Levin, getting calmer and breathing painfully;
