She (Nikolaevna) went quickly to him (Ivanovitch), and whispered something. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

I'm not well It's such rubbish, such lying, such self-deception. What can a man write of justice who knows nothing of it?

he (man) asked Kritsky, sitting down again at the table, and moving back off half of it the scattered cigarettes, so as to clear a space.

Have you read his (man) article? '' '' I've not read it,'' Kritsky responded gloomily, obviously not desiring to enter into the conversation.

'' Why not?'' said Nikolay Levin, now turning with exasperation upon Kritsky. '' Because I didn't see the use of wasting my time over it.

'' '' Oh, but excuse me, how did you know it would be wasting your time? That article's too deep for many people

--that's to say it's over their heads. But with me, it's another thing; I see through his (Levin) ideas, and I know where its weakness lies.

'' Everyone was mute. Kritsky got up deliberately and reached his (Levin) cap. '' Won't you have supper? All right, good-bye! Come round tomorrow with the locksmith.

'' Kritsky had hardly gone out when Nikolay Levin smiled and winked. '' He (Levin)'s no good either,'' he (Levin) said. '' I see, of course...''

But at that instant Kritsky, at the door, called him (Levin)... '' What do you want now? '' he (Levin) said, and went out to him (Levin) in the passage.

Left alone with Marya Nikolaevna, Levin turned to her (Nikolaevna). '' Have you been long with my brother? '' he (Levin) said to her (Nikolaevna).

'' Yes, more than a year. Nikolay Dmitrievitch's health has become very poor. Nikolay Dmitrievitch drinks a great deal,'' she (Nikolaevna) said.

'' That is...how does he (Levin) drink?''

``Drinks vodka, and it's bad for him (Levin).'' (unknown)
``And a great deal? '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
whispered Levin. ''

Yes,'' she (Nikolaevna) said, looking timidly towards the doorway, where Nikolay Levin had reappeared. '' What were you talking about? '' he (Levin) said, knitting his (Levin) brows, and turning his (Levin) scared eyes from one to the other.

'' What was it?'' '' Oh, nothing,'' Konstantin answered in confusion. '' Oh, if you don't want to say, don't. Only it's no good your talking to her (Nikolaevna).

You understand everything, I see, and have taken stock of everything, and look with commiseration on my shortcomings,'' he (Konstantin) began again, raising his (Konstantin) voice.

She (Nikolaevna)'s a wench, and you're a gentleman,'' he (Konstantin) said with a jerk of the neck. '' '' Nikolay Dmitrievitch, Nikolay Dmitrievitch,'' whispered Marya Nikolaevna, again going up to him (Konstantin).

'' Oh, very well, very well! ... But where's the supper? Ah, here it is,'' he (Konstantin) said, seeing a waiter with a tray.

Here, set it here,'' he (Konstantin) added angrily, and promptly seizing the vodka, he (Konstantin) poured out a glassful and drank it greedily.

'' '' Like a drink?'' he (Konstantin) turned to his (Konstantin) brother, and at once became better humored. '' Well, enough of Sergey Ivanovitch.

I'm glad to see you, anyway. After all's said and done, we're not strangers. Come, have a drink. Tell me what you're doing,'' he (Ivanovitch) went on, greedily munching a piece of bread, and pouring out another glassful.

I'm busy looking after the land,'' answered Konstantin, watching with horror the greediness with which his (Konstantin) brother ate and drank, and trying to conceal that he (Konstantin) noticed it.

'' How are you living?''

``I live alone in the country, as I used to. '' (unknown)
Why don't you get married?''

``It hasn't happened so,'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
Konstantin answered, reddening a little.
``Why not? For me now...everything's at an end! I've made a mess of my life.

But this I've said, and I say still, that if my share had been given me when I needed it, my whole life would have been different.

'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)

Konstantin made haste to change the conversation. '' Do you know your little Vanya's with me, a clerk in the countinghouse at Pokrovskoe.

'' Nikolay jerked his (Nikolay) neck, and sank into thought. '' Yes, tell me what's going on at Pokrovskoe. Is the house standing still, and the birch trees, and our schoolroom?

Now mind and don't alter anything in the house, but make haste and get married, and make everything as it used to be again.

And Philip the gardener, is he (gardener) living? How I remember the arbor and the seat! Then I'll come and see you, if your wife is nice.''

'' But come to me now,'' said Levin. '' How nicely we would arrange it!''

``I'd come and see you if I were sure I should not find Sergey Ivanovitch.

Yes, but say what you like, you will have to choose between me and him (Ivanovitch),'' (he)

he (Ivanovitch) said, looking timidly into his (Ivanovitch) brother's face.

If you want to hear my confession of faith on the subject, I tell you that in your quarrel with Sergey Ivanovitch I take neither side.

''

``You wouldn't find him (Ivanovitch) there. I live quite independently of him (Ivanovitch).'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
'' This timidity touched Konstantin. '' You're both wrong.

You're more wrong externally, and he (Konstantin) inwardly. '' '' Ah, ah! You see that, you see that!'' Nikolay shouted joyfully. ''

But I personally value friendly relations with you more because... ''

``Why, why? '' (I)
Konstantin could not say that he (Konstantin) valued it more because Nikolay was unhappy, and needed affection.

But Nikolay knew that this was just what he (Nikolay) meant to say, and scowling he (Nikolay) took up the vodka again. ''

Enough, Nikolay Dmitrievitch!'' said Marya Nikolaevna, stretching out her (Nikolaevna) plump, bare arm towards the decanter.

``Let it be! Don't insist! I'll beat you!

Marya Nikolaevna smiled a sweet and good-humored smile, which was at once reflected on Nikolay's face, and she (Nikolaevna) took the bottle.

'' (he)

he (Nikolay) shouted. '' And do you suppose she (Nikolaevna) understands nothing?'' said Nikolay. '' She (Nikolaevna) understands it all better than any of us.

Isn't it true there's something good and sweet in her (Nikolaevna)?''

``Were you never before in Moscow?'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
Konstantin said to her (Nikolaevna), for the sake of saying something.

No one ever spoke to her (Nikolaevna) so but the justices of the peace who tried her (Nikolaevna) for trying to get out of a house of ill-fame.

'' Only you mustn't be polite and stiff with her (Nikolaevna). It frightens her (Nikolaevna). Mercy on us, the senselessness in the world!

'' he (Konstantin) cried suddenly. '' These new institutions, these justices of the peace, rural councils, what hideousness it all is!'' And he (Konstantin) began to enlarge on his (Konstantin) encounters with the new institutions.

Konstantin Levin heard him (Levin), and the disbelief in the sense of all public institutions, which he (Levin) shared with him (Levin), and often expressed, was distasteful to him (Levin) now from his (Levin) brother's lips.

'' In another world we shall understand it all,'' he (Levin) said lightly. '' In another world! Ah, I don't like that other world!

Here one would think that to get out of all the baseness and the mess, one's own and other people's, would be a good thing, and yet I'm afraid of death, awfully afraid of death.

I don't like it,'' he (Levin) said, letting his (Levin) scared eyes rest on his (Levin) brother's eyes. '' '' He (Levin) shuddered. '' But do drink something.

Would you like some champagne? Or shall we go somewhere? Let's go to the Gypsies! Do you know I have got so fond of the Gypsies and Russian songs.

'' His (Russian) speech had begun to falter, and he (Russian) passed abruptly from one subject to another. Konstantin with the help of Masha persuaded him (Konstantin) not to go out anywhere, and got him (Konstantin) to bed hopelessly drunk.

Masha promised to write to Konstantin in case of need, and to persuade Nikolay Levin to go and stay with his (Levin) brother.

On the journey in the train he (Levin) talked to his (Levin) neighbors about politics and the new railways, and, just as in Moscow, he (Levin) was overcome by a sense of confusion of ideas, dissatisfaction with himself, shame of something or other.

But when he (Levin) got out at his (Levin) own station, when he (Levin) saw his (Levin) one-eyed coachman, Ignat, with the collar of his (Levin) coat turned up; when, in the dim light reflected by the station fires, he (Levin) saw his (Levin) own sledge, his (Levin) own horses with their tails tied up, in their harness trimmed with rings and tassels; when the coachman Ignat, as he (Levin) put in his (Levin) luggage, told him (Levin) the village news, that the contractor had arrived, and that Pava had calved,--he (contractor) felt that little by little the confusion was clearing up, and the shame and self-dissatisfaction were passing away.

He (contractor) felt this at the mere sight of Ignat and the horses; but when he (contractor) had put on the sheepskin brought for him (contractor), had sat down wrapped up in the sledge, and had driven off pondering on the work that lay before him (contractor) in the village, and staring at the side-horse, that had been his (contractor) saddle-horse, past his (contractor) prime now, but a spirited beast from the Don, he (Don) began to see what had happened to him (Don) in quite a different light.

Chapter 26 In the morning Konstantin Levin left Moscow, and towards evening he (Levin) reached home. He (Levin) felt himself, and did not want to be any one else.

In the first place he (Levin) resolved that from that day he (Levin) would give up hoping for any extraordinary happiness, such as marriage must have given him (Levin), and consequently he (Levin) would not so disdain what he (Levin) really had.

Secondly, he (Levin) would never again let himself give way to low passion, the memory of which had so tortured him (Levin) when he (Levin) had been making up his (Levin) mind to make an offer.

Then remembering his (Levin) brother Nikolay, he (Levin) resolved to himself that he (Levin) would never allow himself to forget him (Levin), that he (Levin) would follow him (Levin) up, and not lose sight of him (Levin), so as to be ready to help when things should go ill with him (Levin).

All he (Levin) wanted now was to be better than before. And that would be soon, he (Levin) felt. Then, too, his (Levin) brother's talk of communism, which he (Levin) had treated so lightly at the time, now made him (Levin) think.

But he (Levin) always felt the injustice of his (Levin) own abundance in comparison with the poverty of the peasants, and now he (Levin) determined that so as to feel quite in the right, though he (Levin) had worked hard and lived by no means luxuriously before, he (Levin) would now work still harder, and would allow himself even less luxury.

And all this seemed to him (Levin) so easy a conquest over himself that he (Levin) spent the whole drive in the pleasantest daydreams.

He (Levin) considered a revolution in economic conditions nonsense. With a resolute feeling of hope in a new, better life, he (Levin) reached home before nine o'clock at night.

The snow of the little quadrangle before the house was lit up by a light in the bedroom windows of his (Levin) old nurse, Agafea Mihalovna, who performed the duties of housekeeper in his (Levin) house.

A setter bitch, Laska, ran out too, almost upsetting Kouzma, and whining, turned round about Levin's knees, jumping up and longing, but not daring, to put her (bitch) forepaws on his (Levin) chest.

She (bitch) was not yet asleep. Kouzma, waked up by her (bitch), came sidling sleepily out onto the steps. '' You're soon back again, sir,'' said Agafea Mihalovna.

'' I got tired of it, Agafea Mihalovna. With friends, one is well; but at home, one is better,'' he (Levin) answered, and went into his (Levin) study.

The familiar details came out: the stag's horns, the bookshelves, the looking-glass, the stove with its ventilator, which had long wanted mending, his (Levin) father's sofa, a large table, on the table an open book, a broken ash tray, a manuscript book with his (Levin) handwriting.

As he (Levin) saw all this, there came over him (Levin) for an instant a doubt of the possibility of arranging the new life, of which he (Levin) had been dreaming on the road.

All these traces of his (Levin) life seemed to clutch him (Levin), and to say to him (Levin):

``No, you're not going to get away from us, and you're not going to be different, but you're going to be the same as you've always been; with doubts, everlasting dissatisfaction with yourself, vain efforts to amend, and falls, and everlasting expectation, of a happiness which you won't get, and which isn't possible for you.

This the things said to him (Levin), but another voice in his (Levin) heart was telling him (Levin) that he (Levin) must not fall under the sway of the past, and that one can do anything with oneself.

And hearing that voice, he (Levin) went into the corner where stood his (Levin) two heavy dumbbells, and began brandishing them like a gymnast, trying to restore his (Levin) confident temper.

The study was slowly lit up as the candle was brought in. '' (him)

There was a creak of steps at the door.

The bailiff came in, and said everything, thank God, was doing well; but informed him (God) that the buckwheat in the new drying machine had been a little scorched.

He (God) hastily put down the dumbbells. This piece of news irritated Levin. The new drying machine had been constructed and partly invented by Levin.

The bailiff had always been against the drying machine, and now it was with suppressed triumph that he (bailiff) announced that the buckwheat had been scorched.

Levin was firmly convinced that if the buckwheat had been scorched, it was only because the precautions had not been taken, for which he (Levin) had hundreds of times given orders.

But there had been an important and joyful event: Pava, his (Levin) best cow, an expensive beast, bought at a show, had calved.

He (Levin) was annoyed, and reprimanded the bailiff. '' Kouzma, give me my sheepskin. And you tell them to take a lantern.

I'll come and look at her (Levin),'' he (Levin) said to the bailiff. The cowhouse for the more valuable cows was just behind the house.

There was the warm, steamy smell of dung when the frozen door was opened, and the cows, astonished at the unfamiliar light of the lantern, stirred on the fresh straw.

Walking across the yard, passing a snowdrift by the lilac tree, he (Levin) went into the cowhouse. He (Levin) caught a glimpse of the broad, smooth, black and piebald back of Hollandka.

Berkoot, the bull, was lying down with his (Levin) ring in his (Levin) lip, and seemed about to get up, but thought better of it, and only gave two snorts as they passed by him (Levin).

Pava, a perfect beauty, huge as a hippopotamus, with her (lip) back turned to them, prevented their seeing the calf, as she (lip) sniffed her (lip) all over.

Pava, uneasy, began lowing, but when Levin put the calf close to her (lip) she (lip) was soothed, and, sighing heavily, began licking her (lip) with her (lip) rough tongue.

Levin went into the pen, looked Pava over, and lifted the red and spotted calf onto her (lip) long, tottering legs. The calf, fumbling, poked her (lip) nose under her (lip) mother's udder, and stiffened her (lip) tail out straight.

'' Here, bring the light, Fyodor, this way,'' said Levin, examining the calf. '' Like the mother! though the color takes after the father; but that's nothing.

Very good. Long and broad in the haunch. Vassily Fedorovitch, isn't she (mother) splendid? '' he (Long) said to the bailiff, quite forgiving him (Long) for the buckwheat under the influence of his (Long) delight in the calf.

'' How could she (mother) fail to be? Oh, Semyon the contractor came the day after you left. You must settle with him (contractor), Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' said the bailiff.

This question was enough to take Levin back to all the details of his (Levin) work on the estate, which was on a large scale, and complicated.

He (Levin) went straight from the cowhouse to the counting house, and after a little conversation with the bailiff and Semyon the contractor, he (bailiff) went back to the house and straight upstairs to the drawing room.

'' I did inform you about the machine. '' Chapter 27 The house was big and old-fashioned, and Levin, though he (Levin) lived alone, had the whole house heated and used.

He (Levin) knew that this was stupid, he (Levin) knew that it was positively not right, and contrary to his (Levin) present new plans, but this house was a whole world to Levin.

They had lived just the life that to Levin seemed the ideal of perfection, and that he (Levin) had dreamed of beginning with his (Levin) wife, his (Levin) family.

His (Levin) conception of her (wife) was for him (Levin) a sacred memory, and his (Levin) future wife was bound to be in his (Levin) imagination a repetition of that exquisite, holy ideal of a woman that his (Levin) mother had been.

He (Levin) was so far from conceiving of love for woman apart from marriage that he (Levin) positively pictured to himself first the family, and only secondarily the woman who would give him (Levin) a family.

His (Levin) ideas of marriage were, consequently, quite unlike those of the great majority of his (Levin) acquaintances, for whom getting married was one of the numerous facts of social life.

It was the world in which his (Levin) father and mother had lived and died. Levin scarcely remembered his (Levin) mother. For Levin it was the chief affair of life, on which its whole happiness turned.

When he (Levin) had gone into the little drawing room, where he (Levin) always had tea, and had settled himself in his (Levin) armchair with a book, and Agafea Mihalovna had brought him (Levin) tea, and with her (mother) usual,

``Well, I'll stay a while, sir,'' (him)
had taken a chair in the window, he (Levin) felt that, however strange it might be, he (Levin) had not parted from his (Levin) daydreams, and that he (Levin) could not live without them.

He (Levin) was reading a book, and thinking of what he (Levin) was reading, and stopping to listen to Agafea Mihalovna, who gossiped away without flagging, and yet with all that, all sorts of pictures of family life and work in the future rose disconnectedly before his (Levin) imagination.

He (Levin) felt that in the depth of his (Levin) soul something had been put in its place, settled down, and laid to rest.

He (Levin) heard Agafea Mihalovna talking of how Prohor had forgotten his (Levin) duty to God, and with the money Levin had given him (Levin) to buy a horse, had been drinking without stopping, and had beaten his (Levin) wife till he (Levin)'d half killed her (wife).

And now he (Levin) had to give up that. Whether with her (wife), or with another, still it would be. He (Levin) listened, and read his (Levin) book, and recalled the whole train of ideas suggested by his (Levin) reading.

He (Levin) recalled his (Levin) own criticisms of Tyndall of his (Levin) complacent satisfaction in the cleverness of his (Levin) experiments, and for his (Levin) lack of philosophic insight.

It was Tyndall's Treatise on Heat . And suddenly there floated into his (Tyndall) mind the joyful thought:

``In two years' time I shall have two Dutch cows

; Pava herself will perhaps still be alive, a dozen young daughters of Berkoot and the three others--how lovely!'' (He)

He (Tyndall) took up his (Tyndall) book again.

Very good, electricity and heat are the same thing; but is it possible to substitute the one quantity for the other in the equation for the solution of any problem?

It's particulary nice if Pava's daughter should be a red-spotted cow, and all the herd will take after her (daughter), and the other three, too!

'' No. Well, then what of it? The connection between all the forces of nature is felt instinctively.... Splendid! To go out with my wife and visitors to meet the herd....

My wife says, Kostya and I looked after that calf like a child.' `How can it interest you so much?' says a visitor. '

Everything that interests him (visitor), interests me.' But who will she (wife) be? '' And he (visitor) remembered what had happened at Moscow... ''

Well, there's nothing to be done.... It's not my fault. But now everything shall go on in a new way. It's nonsense to pretend that life won't let one, that the past won't let one.

Old Laska, who had not yet fully digested her (wife) delight at his (Laska) return, and had run out into the yard to bark, came back wagging her (wife) tail, and crept up to him (Laska), bringing in the scent of fresh air, put her (wife) head under his (Laska) hand, and whined plaintively, asking to be stroked.

One must struggle to live better, much better.''... He (Laska) raised his (Laska) head, and fell to dreaming. '' There, who'd have thought it?'' said Agafea Mihalovna.

'' The dog now...why, she (wife) understands that her (wife) master's come home, and that he (master)'s low-spirited.''

``Why low-spirited?'' (unknown)
``Do you suppose I don't see it, sir?

It's high time I should know the gentry. Why, I've grown up from a little thing with them. It's nothing, sir, so long as there's health and a clear conscience.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Levin looked intently at her (wife), surprised at how well she (wife) knew his (Levin) thought. '' Shall I fetch you another cup?'' said she (wife), and taking his (Levin) cup she (wife) went out.

Laska kept poking her (wife) head under his (Laska) hand. He (Laska) stroked her (wife), and she (wife) promptly curled up at his (Laska) feet, laying her (wife) head on a hindpaw.

And in token of all now being well and satisfactory, she (wife) opened her (wife) mouth a little, smacked her (wife) lips, and settling her (wife) sticky lips more comfortably about her (wife) old teeth, she (wife) sank into blissful repose.

Levin watched all her (wife) movements attentively. '' That's what I'll do,'' he (Levin) said to himself;

``that's what I'll do! Nothing's amiss....

After the ball, early next morning, Anna Arkadyevna sent her (Arkadyevna) husband a telegram that she (Arkadyevna) was leaving Moscow the same day.

No, I must go, I must go'' (he)

Stepan Arkadyevitch was not dining at home, but he (husband) promised to come and see his (husband) sister off at seven o'clock.

Kitty, too, did not come, sending a note that she (Kitty) had a headache. Dolly and Anna dined alone with the children and the English governess.

Whether it was that the children were fickle, or that they had acute senses, and felt that Anna was quite different that day from what she (Anna) had been when they had taken such a fancy to her (Anna), that she (Anna) was not now interested in

they had abruptly dropped their play with their aunt, and their love for her (aunt), and were quite indifferent that she (aunt) was going away.

them,--but Anna was absorbed the whole morning in preparations for her (Anna) departure. She (Anna) wrote notes to her (Anna) Moscow acquaintances, put down her (Anna) accounts, and packed.

Altogether Dolly fancied she (Anna) was not in a placid state of mind, but in that worried mood, which Dolly knew well with herself, and which does not come without cause, and for the most part covers dissatisfaction with self.

After dinner, Anna went up to her (Anna) room to dress, and Dolly followed her (Dolly). '' How queer you are today!'' Dolly said to her (Dolly).

'' I? Do you think so? I'm not queer, but I'm nasty. I am like that sometimes. I keep feeling as if I could cry.

It's very stupid, but it'll pass off,'' said Anna quickly, and she (Anna) bent her (Anna) flushed face over a tiny bag in which she (Anna) was packing a nightcap and some cambric handkerchiefs.

Her (Anna) eyes were particularly bright, and were continually swimming with tears. '' In the same way I didn't want to leave Petersburg, and now I don't want to go away from here.''

``You came here and did a good deed,'' (Dolly)
said Dolly, looking intently at her (Dolly). Anna looked at her (Anna) with eyes wet with tears.

'' Don't say that, Dolly. I've done nothing, and could do nothing. I often wonder why people are all in league to spoil me.

What have I done, and what could I do? In your heart there was found love enough to forgive... '' ''

If it had not been for you, God knows what would have happened! How happy you are, Anna!'' said Dolly. ''

Everything is clear and good in your heart.'' '' Every heart has its own skeletons , as the English say. ''

'' You have no sort of skeleton , have you? Everything is so clear in you.''

``I have!'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna suddenly, and, unexpectedly after her (Anna) tears, a sly, ironical smile curved her (Anna) lips.

'' Come, he (God)'s amusing, anyway, your skeleton , and not depressing,'' said Dolly, smiling. '' No, he (God)'s depressing. Do you know why I'm going today instead of tomorrow?

It's a confession that weighs on me; I want to make it to you,'' said Anna, letting herself drop definitely into an armchair, and looking straight into Dolly's face.

And to her (Dolly) surprise Dolly saw that Anna was blushing up to her (Anna) ears, up to the curly black ringlets on her (Dolly) neck.

'' Yes,'' Anna went on. '' Do you know why Kitty didn't come to dinner? She (Anna)'s jealous of me. I have spoiled...

But truly, truly, it's not my fault, or only my fault a little bit,'' she (Anna) said, daintily drawling the words

``a little bit.'' (she)

I've been the cause of that ball being a torture to her (Anna) instead of a pleasure. '' Oh, how like Stiva you said that!'' said Dolly, laughing.

Anna was hurt. '' Oh no, oh no! I'm not Stiva,'' she (Anna) said, knitting her (Anna) brows. '' That's why I'm telling you, just because I could never let myself doubt myself for an instant,'' said Anna.

She (Anna) was not merely doubting herself, she (Anna) felt emotion at the thought of Vronsky, and was going away sooner than she (Anna) had meant, simply to avoid meeting him (Anna).

But at the very moment she (Anna) was uttering the words, she (Anna) felt that they were not true. '' Yes, Stiva told me you danced the mazurka with him (Anna), and that he (Anna)...

''

``You can't imagine how absurdly it all came about. I only meant to be matchmaking, and all at once it turned out quite differently.

She (Anna) crimsoned and stopped. '' Oh, they feel it directly?'' said Dolly. '' But I should be in despair if there were anything serious in it on his (Anna) side,'' Anna interrupted her (Anna).

'' And I am certain it will all be forgotten, and Kitty will leave off hating me.''

``All the same, Anna, to tell you the truth, I'm not very anxious for this marriage for Kitty.

But you'll make it right, Dolly? Eh? '' Dolly could scarcely suppress a smile. She (Dolly) loved Anna, but she (Anna) enjoyed seeing that she (Anna) too had her (Anna) weaknesses.

Anna's emotionalism infected Dolly, and when she (Dolly) embraced her (Dolly) sister-in-law for the last time, she (Dolly) whispered:

``Remember, Anna, what you've done for me--I shall never forget.

said Anna, kissing her (Anna) and hiding her (Anna) tears. '' You understood me, and you understand. Good-bye, my darling!''

'' was the first thought that came to Anna Arkadyevna, when she (Arkadyevna) had said good-bye for the last time to her (Arkadyevna) brother, who had stood blocking up the entrance to the carriage till the third bell rang.

Chapter 29 ``Come, it's all over, and thank God! She (Arkadyevna) sat down on her (Arkadyevna) lounge beside Annushka, and looked about her (Arkadyevna) in the twilight of the sleeping-carriage.

tomorrow I shall see Seryozha and Alexey Alexandrovitch, and my life will go on in the old way, all nice and as usual.

Still in the same anxious frame of mind, as she (Arkadyevna) had been all that day, Anna took pleasure in arranging herself for the journey with great care.

With her (Anna) little deft hands she (Anna) opened and shut her (Anna) little red bag, took out a cushion, laid it on her (Anna) knees, and carefully wrapping up her (Anna) feet, settled herself comfortably.

Two other ladies began talking to Anna, and a stout elderly lady tucked up her (Anna) feet, and made observations about the heating of the train.

Anna answered a few words, but not foreseeing any entertainment from the conversation, she (Anna) asked Annushka to get a lamp, hooked it onto the arm of her (Anna) seat, and took from her (Anna) bag a paper knife and an English novel.

The fuss and bustle were disturbing; then when the train had started, she (Anna) could not help listening to the noises; then the snow beating on the left window and sticking to the pane, and the sight of the muffled guard passing by, covered with snow on one side, and the conversations about the terrible snowstorm raging outside, distracted her (Anna) attention.

Farther on, it was continually the same again and again: the same shaking and rattling, the same snow on the window, the same rapid transitions from steaming heat to cold, and back again to heat, the same passing glimpses of the same figures in the twilight, and the same voices, and Anna began to read and to understand what she (Anna) read.

Annushka was already dozing, the red bag on her (Anna) lap, clutched by her (Anna) broad hands, in gloves, of which one was torn.

Anna Arkadyevna read and understood, but it was distasteful to her (Arkadyevna) to read, that is, to follow the reflection of other people's lives.

``Thank God! '' (An lady)
An invalid lady had already lain down to sleep. At first her (lady) reading made no progress. She (lady) had too great a desire to live herself.

If she (lady) read that the heroine of the novel was nursing a sick man, she (lady) longed to move with noiseless steps about the room of a sick man; if she (lady) read of a member of Parliament making a speech, she (lady) longed to be delivering the speech; if she (lady) read of how Lady Mary had ridden after the hounds, and had provoked her (Mary) sister-in-law, and had surprised everyone by her (Mary) boldness, she (Mary) too wished to be doing the same.

But there was no chance of doing anything; and twisting the smooth paper knife in her (Mary) little hands, she (Mary) forced herself to read.

The hero of the novel was already almost reaching his (hero) English happiness, a baronetcy and an estate, and Anna was feeling a desire to go with him (hero) to the estate, when she (Anna) suddenly felt that he (hero) ought to feel ashamed, and that she (Anna) was ashamed of the same thing.

But what had he (hero) to be ashamed of? '' What have I to be ashamed of? '' she (Anna) asked herself in injured surprise.

She (Anna) laid down the book and sank against the back of the chair, tightly gripping the paper cutter in both hands.

She (Anna) remembered the ball, remembered Vronsky and his (hero) face of slavish adoration, remembered all her (Anna) conduct with him (hero): there was nothing shameful.

And for all that, at the same point in her (Anna) memories, the feeling of shame was intensified, as though some inner voice, just at the point when she (Anna) thought of Vronsky, were saying to her (Anna),

``Warm, very warm, hot.'' (her)

There was nothing. She (Anna) went over all her (Anna) Moscow recollections. All were good, pleasant. '' Well, what is it? '' she (Anna) said to herself resolutely, shifting her (Anna) seat in the lounge.

Can it be that between me and this officer boy there exist, or can exist, any other relations than such as are common with every acquaintance?

'' What does it mean? Am I afraid to look it straight in the face? Why, what is it? '' She (Anna) laughed contemptuously and took up her (Anna) book again; but now she (Anna) was definitely unable to follow what she (Anna) read.

She (Anna) passed the paper knife over the window pane, then laid its smooth, cool surface to her (Anna) cheek, and almost laughed aloud at the feeling of delight that all at once without cause came over her (Anna).

She (Anna) felt her (Anna) eyes opening wider and wider, her (Anna) fingers and toes twitching nervously, something within oppressing her (Anna) breathing, while all shapes and sounds seemed in the uncertain half-light to strike her (Anna) with unaccustomed vividness.

Moments of doubt were continually coming upon her (Anna), when she (Anna) was uncertain whether the train were going forwards or backwards, or were standing still altogether; whether it were Annushka at her (Anna) side or a stranger.

She (Anna) felt as though her (Anna) nerves were strings being strained tighter and tighter on some sort of screwing peg. '' What's that on the arm of the chair, a fur cloak or some beast?

And what am I myself? Myself or some other woman? '' She (woman) was afraid of giving way to this delirium. But something drew her (woman) towards it, and she (woman) could yield to it or resist it at will.

For a moment she (woman) regained her (woman) self-possession, and realized that the thin peasant who had come in wearing a long overcoat, with buttons missing from it, was the stoveheater, that he (peasant) was looking at the thermometer, that it was the wind and snow bursting in after him (peasant) at the door; but then everything grew blurred again....

That peasant with the long waist seemed to be gnawing something on the wall, the old lady began stretching her (lady) legs the whole length of the carriage, and filling it with a black cloud; then there was a fearful shrieking and banging, as though someone were being torn to pieces; then there was a blinding dazzle of red fire before her (lady) eyes and a wall seemed to rise up and hide everything.

She (lady) got up to rouse herself, and slipped off her (lady) plaid and the cape of her (lady) warm dress. Anna felt as though she (Anna) were sinking down.

But it was not terrible, but delightful. The voice of a man muffled up and covered with snow shouted something in her (Anna) ear.

She (Anna) got up and pulled herself together; she (Anna) realized that they had reached a station and that this was the guard.

She (Anna) asked Annushka to hand her (Anna) the cape she (Anna) had taken off and her (Anna) shawl, put them on and moved towards the door.

'' Do you wish to get out?'' asked Annushka. '' Yes, I want a little air. It's very hot in here.

'' And she (Anna) opened the door. The driving snow and the wind rushed to meet her (Anna) and struggled with her (Anna) over the door.

The wind seemed as though lying in wait for her (Anna); with gleeful whistle it tried to snatch her (Anna) up and bear her (Anna) off, but she (Anna) clung to the cold door post, and holding her (Anna) skirt got down onto the platform and under the shelter of the carriages.

The wind had been powerful on the steps, but on the platform, under the lee of the carriages, there was a lull.

With enjoyment she (Anna) drew deep breaths of the frozen, snowy air, and standing near the carriage looked about the platform and the lighted station.

The raging tempest rushed whistling between the wheels of the carriages, about the scaffolding, and round the corner of the station.

The carriages, posts, people, everything that was to be seen was covered with snow on one side, and was getting more and more thickly covered.

For a moment there would come a lull in the storm, but then it would swoop down again with such onslaughts that it seemed impossible to stand against it.

Meanwhile men ran to and fro, talking merrily together, their steps crackling on the platform as they continually opened and closed the big doors.

But she (it) enjoyed the struggle. She (it) opened the door and went out. Chapter 30 The bent shadow of a man glided by at her (it) feet, and she (it) heard sounds of a hammer upon iron.

'' Hand over that telegram!'' came an angry voice out of the stormy darkness on the other side. '' This way!

No. 28!'' several different voices shouted again, and muffled figures ran by covered with snow. Two gentlemen with lighted cigarettes passed by her (it).

She (it) drew one more deep breath of the fresh air, and had just put her (it) hand out of her (it) muff to take hold of the door post and get back into the carriage, when another man in a military overcoat, quite close beside her (it), stepped between her (it) and the flickering light of the lamp post.

She (it) looked round, and the same instant recognized Vronsky's face. Putting his (Vronsky) hand to the peak of his (Vronsky) cap, he (Vronsky) bowed to her (it) and asked,

She (it) gazed rather a long while at him (Vronsky) without answering, and, in spite of the shadow in which he (Vronsky) was standing, she (it) saw, or fancied she (it) saw, both the expression of his (Vronsky) face and his (Vronsky) eyes.

Was there anything she (it) wanted? Could he (Vronsky) be of any service to her (it)? It was again that expression of reverential ecstasy which had so worked upon her (it) the day before.

More than once she (it) had told herself during the past few days, and again only a few moments before, that Vronsky was for her (it) only one of the hundreds of young men, forever exactly the same, that are met everywhere, that she (it) would never allow herself to bestow a thought upon him (Vronsky).

But now at the first instant of meeting him (Vronsky), she (it) was seized by a feeling of joyful pride. She (it) had no need to ask why he (Vronsky) had come.

She (it) knew as certainly as if he (Vronsky) had told her (it) that he (Vronsky) was here to be where she (it) was. '' I didn't know you were going.

What are you coming for? '' she (it) said, letting fall the hand with which she (it) had grasped the door post. And irrepressible delight and eagerness shone in her (it) face.

'' What am I coming for? '' he (Vronsky) repeated, looking straight into her (it) eyes. '' You know that I have come to be where you are,'' he (Vronsky) said;

``I can't help it.

At that moment the wind, as it were, surmounting all obstacles, sent the snow flying from the carriage roofs, and clanked some sheet of iron it had torn off, while the hoarse whistle of the engine roared in front, plaintively and gloomily.

'' (he)

All the awfulness of the storm seemed to her (it) more splendid now. He (Vronsky) had said what her (it) soul longed to hear, though she (it) feared it with her (it) reason.

She (it) made no answer, and in her (it) face he (Vronsky) saw conflict. '' Forgive me, if you dislike what I said,'' he (Vronsky) said humbly.

He (Vronsky) had spoken courteously, deferentially, yet so firmly, so stubbornly, that for a long while she (it) could make no answer. ''

It's wrong, what you say, and I beg you, if you're a good man, to forget what you've said, as I forget it,'' she (it) said at last.

'' Not one word, not one gesture of yours shall I , could I, ever forget... ''

``Enough, enough!'' (I)
she (it) cried trying assiduously to give a stern expression to her (it) face, into which he (man) was gazing greedily.

And clutching at the cold door post, she (it) clambered up the steps and got rapidly into the corridor of the carriage.

Though she (it) could not recall her (it) own words or his (man), she (it) realized instinctively that the momentary conversation had brought them fearfully closer; and she (it) was panic-stricken and blissful at it.

But in the little corridor she (it) paused, going over in her (it) imagination what had happened. After standing still a few seconds, she (it) went into the carriage and sat down in her (it) place.

The overstrained condition which had tormented her (it) before did not only come back, but was intensified, and reached such a pitch that she (it) was afraid every minute that something would snap within her (it) from the excessive tension.

But in that nervous tension, and in the visions that filled her (it) imagination, there was nothing disagreeable or gloomy: on the contrary there was something blissful, glowing, and exhilarating.

She (it) did not sleep all night. Towards morning Anna sank into a doze, sitting in her (Anna) place, and when she (Anna) waked it was daylight and the train was near Petersburg.

At once thoughts of home, of husband and of son, and the details of that day and the following came upon her (Anna).

At Petersburg, as soon as the train stopped and she (Anna) got out, the first person that attracted her (Anna) attention was her (Anna) husband.

she (Anna) thought, looking at his (husband) frigid and imposing figure, and especially the ears that struck her (Anna) at the moment as propping up the brim of his (husband) round hat.

Catching sight of her (Anna), he (husband) came to meet her (Anna), his (husband) lips falling into their habitual sarcastic smile, and his (husband) big, tired eyes looking straight at her (Anna).

An unpleasant sensation gripped at her (Anna) heart when she (Anna) met his (husband) obstinate and weary glance, as though she (Anna) had expected to see him (husband) different.

'' Oh, mercy! why do his (husband) ears look like that? '' She (Anna) was especially struck by the feeling of dissatisfaction with herself that she (Anna) experienced on meeting him (husband).

That feeling was an intimate, familiar feeling, like a consciousness of hypocrisy, which she (Anna) experienced in her (Anna) relations with her (Anna) husband.

Yes, as you see, your tender spouse, as devoted as the first year after marriage, burned with impatience to see you,'' he (husband) said in his (husband) deliberate, high-pitched voice, and in that tone which he (husband) almost always took with her (Anna), a tone of jeering at anyone who should say in earnest what he (husband) said.

But hitherto she (Anna) had not taken note of the feeling, now she (Anna) was clearly and painfully aware of it. '' ''

Is Seryozha quite well? '' she (Anna) asked. '' And is this all the reward,'' said he (husband),

``for my ardor? He (husband)'s quite well...

'' (he)

Chapter 31 Vronsky had not even tried to sleep all that night. He (husband) sat in his (husband) armchair, looking straight before him (husband) or scanning the people who got in and out.

If he (husband) had indeed on previous occasions struck and impressed people who did not know him (husband) by his (husband) air of unhesitating composure, he (husband) seemed now more haughty and self-possessed than ever.

He (husband) looked at people as if they were things. A nervous young man, a clerk in a law court, sitting opposite him (man), hated him (man) for that look.

The young man asked him (man) for a light, and entered into conversation with him (man), and even pushed against him (man), to make him (man) feel that he (man) was not a thing, but a person.

But Vronsky gazed at him (man) exactly as he (man) did at the lamp, and the young man made a wry face, feeling that he (man) was losing his (man) self-possession under the oppression of this refusal to recognize him (man) as a person.

He (man) felt himself a king, not because he (man) believed that he (man) had made an impression on Anna--he (man) did not yet believe that,--but because the impression she (Anna) had made on him (man) gave him (man) happiness and pride.

Vronsky saw nothing and no one. What would come of it all he (man) did not know, he (man) did not even think.

He (man) felt that all his (man) forces, hitherto dissipated, wasted, were centered on one thing, and bent with fearful energy on one blissful goal.

He (man) knew only that he (man) had told her (Anna) the truth, that he (man) had come where she (Anna) was, that all the happiness of his (man) life, the only meaning in life for him (man), now lay in seeing and hearing her (Anna).

And when he (man) got out of the carriage at Bologova to get some seltzer water, and caught sight of Anna, involuntarily his (man) first word had told her (Anna) just what he (man) thought.

And he (man) was happy at it. And he (man) was glad he (man) had told her (Anna) it, that she (Anna) knew it now and was thinking of it.

When he (man) was back in the carriage, he (man) kept unceasingly going over every position in which he (man) had seen her (Anna), every word she (Anna) had uttered, and before his (man) fancy, making his (man) heart faint with emotion, floated pictures of a possible future.

When he (man) got out of the train at Petersburg, he (man) felt after his (man) sleepless night as keen and fresh as after a cold bath.

Once more,'' he (man) said to himself, smiling unconsciously,

``once more I shall see her (Anna) walk, her (Anna) face; she (Anna) will say something, turn her (Anna) head, glance, smile, maybe.

He (man) did not sleep all night. He (man) paused near his (man) compartment, waiting for her (Anna) to get out. '' (he)

'' But before he (man) caught sight of her (Anna), he (man) saw her (Anna) husband, whom the station-master was deferentially escorting through the crowd.

Only now for the first time did Vronsky realize clearly the fact that there was a person attached to her (Anna), a husband.

He (husband) knew that she (Anna) had a husband, but had hardly believed in his (husband) existence, and only now fully believed in him (husband), with his (husband) head and shoulders, and his (husband) legs clad in black trousers; especially when he (husband) saw this husband calmly take her (Anna) arm with a sense of property.

Seeing Alexey Alexandrovitch with his (Alexandrovitch) Petersburg face and severely self-confident figure, in his (Alexandrovitch) round hat, with his (Alexandrovitch) rather prominent spine, he (Alexandrovitch) believed in him (Alexandrovitch), and was aware of a disagreeable sensation, such as a man might feel tortured by thirst, who, on reaching a spring, should find a dog, a sheep, or a pig, who has drunk of it and muddied the water.

'' Ah, yes! The husband. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch's manner of walking, with a swing of the hips and flat feet, particularly annoyed Vronsky.

But she (Alexandrovitch) was still the same, and the sight of her (Alexandrovitch) affected him (Alexandrovitch) the same way, physically reviving him (Alexandrovitch), stirring him (Alexandrovitch), and filling his (Alexandrovitch) soul with rapture.

He (Alexandrovitch) told his (Alexandrovitch) German valet, who ran up to him (Alexandrovitch) from the second class, to take his (Alexandrovitch) things and go on, and he (Alexandrovitch) himself went up to her (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) saw the first meeting between the husband and wife, and noted with a lover's insight the signs of slight reserve with which she (wife) spoke to her (wife) husband.

He (husband) could recognize in no one but himself an indubitable right to love her (wife). '' No, she (wife) does not love him (husband) and cannot love him (husband),'' he (husband) decided to himself.

At the moment when he (husband) was approaching Anna Arkadyevna he (husband) noticed too with joy that she (Arkadyevna) was conscious of his (husband) being near, and looked round, and seeing him (husband), turned again to her (Arkadyevna) husband.

he (husband) asked, bowing to her (Arkadyevna) and her (Arkadyevna) husband together, and leaving it up to Alexey Alexandrovitch to accept the bow on his (Alexandrovitch) own account, and to recognize it or not, as he (Alexandrovitch) might see fit.

Her (Arkadyevna) face looked weary, and there was not that play of eagerness in it, peeping out in her (Arkadyevna) smile and her (Arkadyevna) eyes; but for a single instant, as she (Arkadyevna) glanced at him (Alexandrovitch), there was a flash of something in her (Arkadyevna) eyes, and although the flash died away at once, he (Alexandrovitch) was happy for that moment.

'' Have you passed a good night? '' '' Thank you, very good,'' she (Arkadyevna) answered. She (Arkadyevna) glanced at her (Arkadyevna) husband to find out whether he (husband) knew Vronsky.

Alexey Alexandrovitch looked at Vronsky with displeasure, vaguely recalling who this was. Vronsky's composure and self-confidence here struck, like a scythe against a stone, upon the cold self-confidence of Alexey Alexandrovitch.

You set off with the mother and you return with the son,'' he (son) said, articulating each syllable, as though each were a separate favor he (son) was bestowing.

'' Count Vronsky,'' said Anna. '' Ah! We are acquainted, I believe,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch indifferently, giving his (Alexandrovitch) hand. '' ''

You're back from leave, I suppose? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said, and without waiting for a reply, he (Alexandrovitch) turned to his (Alexandrovitch) wife in his (Alexandrovitch) jesting tone:

By addressing his (Alexandrovitch) wife like this he (Alexandrovitch) gave Vronsky to understand that he (Vronsky) wished to be left alone, and, turning slightly towards him (Vronsky), he (Vronsky) touched his (Vronsky) hat; but Vronsky turned to Anna Arkadyevna.

``Well, were a great many tears shed at Moscow at parting? '' (I)
'' I hope I may have the honor of calling on you,'' he (Vronsky) said.

Most fortunate,'' he (Vronsky) said to his (Vronsky) wife, dismissing Vronsky altogether,

``that I should just have half an hour to meet you, so that I can prove my devotion,'' (Vronsky)
he (Vronsky) went on in the same jesting tone.

Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced with his (Alexandrovitch) weary eyes at Vronsky. '' Delighted,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said coldly. '' On Mondays we're at home. ''

You lay too much stress on your devotion for me to value it much,'' she (wife) responded in the same jesting tone, involuntarily listening to the sound of Vronsky's steps behind them.

'' But what has it to do with me? '' she (wife) said to herself, and she (wife) began asking her (wife) husband how Seryozha had got on without her (wife).

'' Oh, capitally! Mariette says he (husband) has been very good, And...I must disappoint you...but he (husband) has not missed you as your husband has.

-LRB-He (husband) used to call the Countess Lidia Ivanovna, well known in society, a samovar, because she (Ivanovna) was always bubbling over with excitement.-RRB-

But once more merci, my dear, for giving me a day. Our dear Samovar will be delighted. '' '' She (Ivanovna) has been continually asking after you.

And, do you know, if I may venture to advise you, you should go and see her (Ivanovna) today. You know how she (Ivanovna) takes everything to heart.

The Countess Lidia Ivanovna was a friend of her (Ivanovna) husband's, and the center of that one of the coteries of the Petersburg world with which Anna was, through her (Anna) husband, in the closest relations.

I shall not be alone at dinner again,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
