The first person to meet Anna at home was her (Anna) son. He (son) dashed down the stairs to her (Anna), in spite of the governess's call, and with desperate joy shrieked:

``Mother! mother!

'' (the governess)

Running up to her (Mother), he (son) hung on her (Mother) neck. '' I told you it was mother! '' he (son) shouted to the governess.

'' I knew! '' And her (Mother) son, like her (Mother) husband, aroused in Anna a feeling akin to disappointment. She (Mother) had imagined him (husband) better than he (husband) was in reality.

But even as he (husband) was, he (husband) was charming, with his (husband) fair curls, his (husband) blue eyes, and his (husband) plump, graceful little legs in tightly pulled-up stockings.

Anna experienced almost physical pleasure in the sensation of his (husband) nearness, and his (husband) caresses, and moral soothing, when she (Anna) met his (husband) simple, confiding, and loving glance, and heard his (husband) na√Øve questions.

Anna took out the presents Dolly's children had sent him (husband), and told her (Anna) son what sort of little girl was Tanya at Moscow, and how Tanya could read, and even taught the other children.

She (Tanya) had to let herself drop down to the reality to enjoy him (son) as he (son) really was. '' Why, am I not so nice as she (Tanya)?

'' asked Seryozha. '' To me you're nicer than anyone in the world. ''

``I know that,'' (Seryozha)
said Seryozha, smiling. Anna had not had time to drink her (Anna) coffee when the Countess Lidia Ivanovna was announced.

The Countess Lidia Ivanovna was a tall, stout woman, with an unhealthily sallow face and splendid, pensive black eyes. Anna liked her (Anna), but today she (Anna) seemed to be seeing her (Anna) for the first time with all her (Anna) defects.

'' Well, my dear, so you took the olive branch? '' inquired Countess Lidia Ivanovna, as soon as she (Ivanovna) came into the room.

'' Yes, it's all over, but it was all much less serious than we had supposed,'' answered Anna. '' My belle-soeur is in general too hasty.

But Countess Lidia Ivanovna, though she (Ivanovna) was interested in everything that did not concern her (Ivanovna), had a habit of never listening to what interested her (Ivanovna); she (Ivanovna) interrupted Anna:

''

``Yes, there's plenty of sorrow and evil in the world. I am so worried today.'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
'' Oh, why? '' asked Anna, trying to suppress a smile.

The Society of the Little Sisters'' -LRB-this was a religiously-patriotic, philanthropic institution-RRB-

``was going splendidly, but with these gentlemen it's impossible to do anything,'' (the Sisters)
added Countess Lidia Ivanovna in a tone of ironical submission to destiny.

'' I'm beginning to be weary of fruitlessly championing the truth, and sometimes I'm quite unhinged by it. '' They pounce on the idea, and distort it, and then work it out so pettily and unworthily.

Two or three people, your husband among them, understand all the importance of the thing, but the others simply drag it down.

Yesterday Pravdin wrote to me...'' Pravdin was a well-known Panslavist abroad, and Countess Lidia Ivanovna described the purport of his (husband) letter.

Then the countess told her (countess) of more disagreements and intrigues against the work of the unification of the churches, and departed in haste, as she (countess) had that day to be at the meeting of some society and also at the Slavonic committee.

'' It was all the same before, of course; but why was it I didn't notice it before?'' Anna asked herself. ''

It's really ludicrous; her (Anna) object is doing good; she (Anna) a Christian, yet she (Anna)'s always angry; and she (Anna) always has enemies, and always enemies in the name of Christianity and doing good.

After Countess Lidia Ivanovna another friend came, the wife of a chief secretary, who told her (Ivanovna) all the news of the town.

Or has she (Ivanovna) been very much irritated today? '' At three o'clock she (Ivanovna) too went away, promising to come to dinner.

Anna, left alone, spent the time till dinner in assisting at her (Anna) son's dinner -LRB-he (son) dined apart from his (son) parents-RRB- and in putting her (Anna) things in order, and in reading and answering the notes and letters which had accumulated on her (Anna) table.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was at the ministry. The feeling of causeless shame, which she (Anna) had felt on the journey, and her (Anna) excitement, too, had completely vanished.

In the habitual conditions of her (Anna) life she (Anna) felt again resolute and irreproachable. She (Anna) recalled with wonder her (Anna) state of mind on the previous day.

Vronsky said something silly, which it was easy to put a stop to, and I answered as I ought to have done.

'' What was it? Nothing. To speak of it to my husband would be unnecessary and out of the question. To speak of it would be to attach importance to what has no importance.

She (Anna) remembered how she (Anna) had told her (Anna) husband of what was almost a declaration made her (Anna) at Petersburg by a young man, one of her (Anna) husband's subordinates, and how Alexey Alexandrovitch had answered that every woman living in the world was exposed to such incidents, but that he (Alexandrovitch) had the fullest confidence in her (woman) tact, and could never lower her (woman) and himself by jealousy.

'' '' So then there's no reason to speak of it? And indeed, thank God, there's nothing to speak of,'' she (woman) told herself.

Chapter 33 Alexey Alexandrovitch came back from the meeting of the ministers at four o'clock, but as often happened, he (Alexandrovitch) had not time to come in to her (woman).

He (Alexandrovitch) went into his (Alexandrovitch) study to see the people waiting for him (Alexandrovitch) with petitions, and to sign some papers brought him (Alexandrovitch) by his (Alexandrovitch) chief secretary.

At dinner time -LRB-there were always a few people dining with the Karenins-RRB- there arrived an old lady, a cousin of Alexey Alexandrovitch, the chief secretary of the department and his (Alexandrovitch) wife, and a young man who had been recommended to Alexey Alexandrovitch for the service.

Precisely at five o'clock, before the bronze Peter the First clock had struck the fifth stroke, Alexey Alexandrovitch came in, wearing a white tie and evening coat with two stars, as he (Alexandrovitch) had to go out directly after dinner.

Anna went into the drawing room to receive these guests. Every minute of Alexey Alexandrovitch's life was portioned out and occupied.

And to make time to get through all that lay before him (Alexandrovitch) every day, he (Alexandrovitch) adhered to the strictest punctuality. ''

Unhasting and unresting,'' was his (Alexandrovitch) motto. He (Alexandrovitch) came into the dining hall, greeted everyone, and hurriedly sat down, smiling to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

'' Yes, my solitude is over. You wouldn't believe how uncomfortable'' -LRB-he (Alexandrovitch) laid stress on the word uncomfortable -RRB-

``it is to dine alone.

At dinner he (Alexandrovitch) talked a little to his (Alexandrovitch) wife about Moscow matters, and, with a sarcastic smile, asked her (wife) after Stepan Arkadyevitch; but the conversation was for the most part general, dealing with Petersburg official and public news.

After dinner he (official) spent half an hour with his (official) guests, and again, with a smile, pressed his (official) wife's hand, withdrew, and drove off to the council.

Anna did not go out that evening either to the Princess Betsy Tverskaya, who, hearing of her (Tverskaya) return, had invited her (Tverskaya), nor to the theater, where she (Tverskaya) had a box for that evening.

'' (he)

She (Tverskaya) did not go out principally because the dress she (Tverskaya) had reckoned upon was not ready. Altogether, Anna, on turning, after the departure of her (Anna) guests, to the consideration of her (Anna) attire, was very much annoyed.

She (Anna) was generally a mistress of the art of dressing well without great expense, and before leaving Moscow she (Anna) had given her (Anna) dressmaker three dresses to transform.

The dresses had to be altered so that they could not be recognized, and they ought to have been ready three days before.

It appeared that two dresses had not been done at all, while the other one had not been altered as Anna had intended.

The dressmaker came to explain, declaring that it would be better as she (Anna) had done it, and Anna was so furious that she (Anna) felt ashamed when she (Anna) thought of it afterwards.

To regain her (Anna) serenity completely she (Anna) went into the nursery, and spent the whole evening with her (Anna) son, put him (son) to bed herself, signed him (son) with the cross, and tucked him (son) up.

She (Anna) felt so light-hearted and serene, she (Anna) saw so clearly that all that had seemed to her (Anna) so important on her (Anna) railway journey was only one of the common trivial incidents of fashionable life, and that she (Anna) had no reason to feel ashamed before anyone else or before herself.

She (Anna) was glad she (Anna) had not gone out anywhere, and had spent the evening so well. Anna sat down at the hearth with an English novel and waited for her (Anna) husband.

Exactly at half-past nine she (Anna) heard his (husband) ring, and he (husband) came into the room. '' Here you are at last! ''

she (Anna) observed, holding out her (Anna) hand to him (husband). He (husband) kissed her (Anna) hand and sat down beside her (Anna). '' Altogether then, I see your visit was a success,'' he (husband) said to her (Anna).

Oh, yes,'' she (Anna) said, and she (Anna) began telling him (husband) about everything from the beginning: her (Anna) journey with Countess Vronskaya, her (Anna) arrival, the accident at the station.

'' Then she (Anna) described the pity she (Anna) had felt, first for her (Anna) brother, and afterwards for Dolly. '' I imagine one cannot exonerate such a man from blame, though he (man) is your brother,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch severely.

She (Dolly) knew that he (Alexandrovitch) said that simply to show that family considerations could not prevent him (Alexandrovitch) from expressing his (Alexandrovitch) genuine opinion.

Anna smiled. She (Anna) knew that characteristic in her (Anna) husband, and liked it. '' I am glad it has all ended so satisfactorily, and that you are back again,'' he (husband) went on.

Anna had heard nothing of this act, And she (Anna) felt conscience-stricken at having been able so readily to forget what was to him (husband) of such importance.

'' Come, what do they say about the new act I have got passed in the council? '' '' Here, on the other hand, it has made a great sensation,'' he (husband) said, with a complacent smile.

She (Anna) saw that Alexey Alexandrovitch wanted to tell her (Anna) something pleasant to him (Alexandrovitch) about it, and she (Anna) brought him (Alexandrovitch) by questions to telling it.

With the same complacent smile he (Alexandrovitch) told her (Anna) of the ovations he (Alexandrovitch) had received in consequence of the act he (Alexandrovitch) had passed.

'' I was very, very glad. It shows that at last a reasonable and steady view of the matter is becoming prevalent among us.

Having drunk his (Alexandrovitch) second cup of tea with cream, and bread, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up, and was going towards his (Alexandrovitch) study.

'' '' And you've not been anywhere this evening? You've been dull, I expect? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said. '' Oh, no! '' she (Anna) answered, getting up after him (Alexandrovitch) and accompanying him (Alexandrovitch) across the room to his (Alexandrovitch) study.

'' What are you reading now? '' she (Anna) asked. '' Just now I'm reading Duc de Lille, Po√©sie des Enfers, '' he (Duc) answered.

Anna smiled, as people smile at the weaknesses of those they love, and, putting her (Anna) hand under his (Duc), she (Anna) escorted him (Duc) to the door of the study.

'' A very remarkable book. '' She (Anna) knew his (Duc) habit, that had grown into a necessity, of reading in the evening.

She (Anna) knew, too, that in spite of his (Duc) official duties, which swallowed up almost the whole of his (Duc) time, he (Duc) considered it his (Duc) duty to keep up with everything of note that appeared in the intellectual world.

She (Anna) knew, too, that he (Duc) was really interested in books dealing with politics, philosophy, and theology, that art was utterly foreign to his (Duc) nature; but, in spite of this, or rather, in consequence of it, Alexey Alexandrovitch never passed over anything in the world of art, but made it his (Alexandrovitch) duty to read everything.

She (Anna) knew that in politics, in philosophy, in theology, Alexey Alexandrovitch often had doubts, and made investigations; but on questions of art and poetry, and, above all, of music, of which he (Alexandrovitch) was totally devoid of understanding, he (Alexandrovitch) had the most distinct and decided opinions.

He (Alexandrovitch) was fond of talking about Shakespeare, Raphael, Beethoven, of the significance of new schools of poetry and music, all of which were classified by him (Beethoven) with very conspicuous consistency.

Well, God be with you,'' she (Anna) said at the door of the study, where a shaded candle and a decanter of water were already put by his (God) armchair.

'' '' And I'll write to Moscow. '' He (God) pressed her (Anna) hand, and again kissed it. '' All the same he (God)'s a good man

; truthful, good-hearted, and remarkable in his (God) own line,'' Anna said to herself going back to her (Anna) room, as though she (Anna) were defending him (God) to someone who had attacked him (God) and said that one could not love him (God).

Precisely at twelve o'clock, when Anna was still sitting at her (Anna) writing table, finishing a letter to Dolly, she (Dolly) heard the sound of measured steps in slippers, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, freshly washed and combed, with a book under his (Alexandrovitch) arm, came in to her (Dolly).

'' But why is it his (Alexandrovitch) ears stick out so strangely? Or has he (Alexandrovitch) had his (Alexandrovitch) hair cut? '' '' It's time, it's time,'' said he (Alexandrovitch), with a meaning smile, and he (Alexandrovitch) went into their bedroom.

'' And what right had he (Alexandrovitch) to look at him (Alexandrovitch) like that? '' thought Anna, recalling Vronsky's glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch.

Undressing, she (Anna) went into the bedroom; but her (Anna) face had none of the eagerness which, during her (Anna) stay in Moscow, had fairly flashed from her (Anna) eyes and her (Anna) smile; on the contrary, now the fire seemed quenched in her (Anna), hidden somewhere far away.

Chapter 34 When Vronsky went to Moscow from Petersburg, he (Alexandrovitch) had left his (Alexandrovitch) large set of rooms in Morskaia to his (Alexandrovitch) friend and favorite comrade Petritsky.

Towards evening he (Alexandrovitch) was always drunk, and he (Alexandrovitch) had often been locked up after all sorts of ludicrous and disgraceful scandals, but he (Alexandrovitch) was a favorite both of his (Alexandrovitch) comrades and his (Alexandrovitch) superior officers.

On arriving at twelve o'clock from the station at his (Alexandrovitch) flat, Vronsky saw, at the outer door, a hired carriage familiar to him (Alexandrovitch).

While still outside his (Alexandrovitch) own door, as he (Alexandrovitch) rang, he (Alexandrovitch) heard masculine laughter, the lisp of a feminine voice, and Petritsky's voice.

Petritsky was a young lieutenant, not particularly well-connected, and not merely not wealthy, but always hopelessly in debt. '' If that's one of the villains, don't let him (lieutenant) in!''

Baroness Shilton, a friend of Petritsky's, with a rosy little face and flaxen hair, resplendent in a lilac satin gown, and filling the whole room, like a canary, with her (Baroness) Parisian chatter, sat at the round table making coffee.

Petritsky, in his (friend) overcoat, and the cavalry captain Kamerovsky, in full uniform, probably just come from duty, were sitting each side of her (Baroness).

Vronsky told the servant not to announce him (Vronsky), and slipped quietly into the first room. '' Bravo! Vronsky! '' shouted Petritsky, jumping up, scraping his (Bravo) chair.

'' Our host himself! Baroness, some coffee for him (Bravo) out of the new coffee pot. Why, we didn't expect you! Hope you're satisfied with the ornament of your study,'' he (Bravo) said, indicating the baroness.

'' You know each other, of course?''

``I should think so,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, with a bright smile, pressing the baroness's little hand.

'' What next! I'm an old friend. '' '' You're home after a journey,'' said the baroness,

``so I'm flying. Oh, I'll be off this minute, if I'm in the way.

'' (the baroness)

``You're home, wherever you are, baroness,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky. '' How do you do, Kamerovsky? '' he (friend) added, coldly shaking hands with Kamerovsky.

'' There, you never know how to say such pretty things,'' said the baroness, turning to Petritsky. '' No; what's that for?

Well, then, I'll make you some coffee, so go and wash and get ready,'' said the baroness, sitting down again, and anxiously turning the screw in the new coffee pot.

Pierre, give me the coffee,'' she (baroness) said, addressing Petritsky, whom she (baroness) called Pierre as a contraction of his (Pierre) surname, making no secret of her (baroness) relations with him (Pierre).

After dinner I say things quite as good. ''

``After dinner there's no credit in them? '' (I)
'' I'll put it in.''

``You'll spoil it!'' (I)
'' No, I won't spoil it! Well, and your wife?'' said the baroness suddenly, interrupting Vronsky's conversation with his (Pierre) comrade.

'' We've been marrying you here. Have you brought your wife?''

``No, baroness. I was born a Bohemian, and a Bohemian I shall die.'' (the baroness)

And the baroness, detaining Vronsky, began telling him (Pierre), with many jokes, about her (baroness) last new plans of life, asking his (Pierre) advice.

``So much the better, so much the better. Shake hands on it. '' (He)
'' He (Pierre) persists in refusing to give me a divorce!

Well, what am I to do? '' -LRB- He (Pierre) was her (baroness) husband.-RRB- '' Now I want to begin a suit against him (Pierre).

What do you advise? Kamerovsky, look after the coffee; it's boiling over. You see, I'm engrossed with business! I want a lawsuit, because I must have my property.

Do you understand the folly of it, that on the pretext of my being unfaithful to him (Pierre),'' she (baroness) said contemptuously,

``he (Pierre) wants to get the benefit of my fortune.

Vronsky heard with pleasure this light-hearted prattle of a pretty woman, agreed with her (woman), gave her (woman) half-joking counsel, and altogether dropped at once into the tone habitual to him (counsel) in talking to such women.

One, the lower class, vulgar, stupid, and, above all, ridiculous people, who believe that one husband ought to live with the one wife whom he (husband) has lawfully married; that a girl should be innocent, a woman modest, and a man manly, self-controlled, and strong

'' (she)

In his (man) Petersburg world all people were divided into utterly opposed classes. ; that one ought to bring up one's children, earn one's bread, and pay one's debts; and various similar absurdities.

To this class they all belonged, and in it the great thing was to be elegant, generous, plucky, gay, to abandon oneself without a blush to every passion, and to laugh at everything else.

For the first moment only, Vronsky was startled after the impression of a quite different world that he (man) had brought with him (man) from Moscow.

But immediately as though slipping his (man) feet into old slippers, he (man) dropped back into the light-hearted, pleasant world he (man) had always lived in.

The coffee was never really made, but spluttered over every one, and boiled away, doing just what was required of it--that is, providing much cause for much noise and laughter, and spoiling a costly rug and the baroness's gown.

This was the class of old-fashioned and ridiculous people. But there was another class of people, the real people. '' Well now, good-bye, or you'll never get washed, and

I shall have on my conscience the worst sin a gentleman can commit. So you would advise a knife to his (gentleman) throat?

'' '' To be sure, and manage that your hand may not be far from his (gentleman) lips. He (gentleman)'ll kiss your hand, and all will end satisfactorily,'' answered Vronsky.

Kamerovsky got up too, and Vronsky, not waiting for him (gentleman) to go, shook hands and went off to his (gentleman) dressing room.

While he (gentleman) was washing, Petritsky described to him (gentleman) in brief outlines his (gentleman) position, as far as it had changed since Vronsky had left Petersburg.

'' So at the Francais! '' and, with a rustle of her (gentleman) skirts, she (gentleman) vanished. No money at all. His (Vronsky) father said he (Vronsky) wouldn't give him (Vronsky) any and pay his (Vronsky) debts.

His (Vronsky) tailor was trying to get him (Vronsky) locked up, and another fellow, too, was threatening to get him (Vronsky) locked up. The colonel of the regiment had announced that if these scandals did not cease he (Vronsky) would have to leave.

As for the baroness, he (Vronsky) was sick to death of her (baroness), especially since she (baroness)'d taken to offering continually to lend him (Vronsky) money.

But he (Vronsky) had found a girl--he (Vronsky)'d show her (girl) to Vronsky--a marvel, exquisite, in the strict Oriental style,

``genre of the slave Rebecca, don't you know.

He (slave)'d had a row, too, with Berkoshov, and was going to send seconds to him (slave), but of course it would come to nothing.

And, not letting his (slave) comrade enter into further details of his (slave) position, Petritsky proceeded to tell him (slave) all the interesting news.

As he (slave) listened to Petritsky's familiar stories in the familiar setting of the rooms he (slave) had spent the last three years in, Vronsky felt a delightful sense of coming back to the careless Petersburg life that he (Vronsky) was used to.

'' (Vronsky)

he (Vronsky) cried, letting down the pedal of the washing basin in which he (Vronsky) had been sousing his (Vronsky) healthy red neck.

'' Altogether everything was supremely amusing and jolly. ``Impossible!

``Impossible!'' (he)
he (Vronsky) cried, at the news that Laura had flung over Fertinghof and had made up to Mileev.

'' And is he (Vronsky) as stupid and pleased as ever? Well, and how's Buzulukov?'' '' Oh, there is a tale about Buzulukov--simply lovely!

'' cried Petritsky. '' You know his (Vronsky) weakness for balls, and he (Vronsky) never misses a single court ball. He (Vronsky) went to a big ball in a new helmet.

Have you seen the new helmets? Very nice, lighter. Well, so he (Vronsky)'s standing.... No, I say, do listen. ''

``I am listening,'' (Vronsky)
answered Vronsky, rubbing himself with a rough towel.

Up comes the Grand Duchess with some ambassador or other, and, as ill-luck would have it, she (Duchess) begins talking to him (ambassador) about the new helmets.

'' The Grand Duchess positively wanted to show the new helmet to the ambassador. They see our friend standing there. ''

-LRB-Petritsky mimicked how he (friend) was standing with the helmet.-RRB- '' The Grand Duchess asked him (friend) to give her (Duchess) the helmet; he (friend) doesn't give it to her (Duchess).

What do you think of that? Well, every one's winking at him (friend), nodding, frowning--give it to her (Duchess), do! He (friend) doesn't give it to her (Duchess).

He (friend)'s mute as a fish. Only picture it!... Well, the...what's his (friend) name, whatever he (friend) was...tries to take the helmet from him (friend)...

he (friend) won't give it up!... He (friend) pulls it from him (friend), and hands it to the Grand Duchess. ' Here, your Highness,' says he (Highness), `is the new helmet.'

She (Duchess) turned the helmet the other side up, And--just picture it!--plop went a pear and sweetmeats out of it, two pounds of sweetmeats!...

And long afterwards, when he (Highness) was talking of other things, he (Highness) broke out into his (Highness) healthy laugh, showing his (Highness) strong, close rows of teeth, when he (Highness) thought of the helmet.

Having heard all the news, Vronsky, with the assistance of his (Highness) valet, got into his (Highness) uniform, and went off to report himself.

He (Highness) intended, when he (Highness) had done that, to drive to his (Highness) brother's and to Betsy's and to pay several visits with a view to beginning to go into that society where he (Highness) might meet Madame Karenina.

He (Highness)'d been storing them up, the darling!'' Vronsky burst into roars of laughter. As he (Highness) always did in Petersburg, he (Highness) left home not meaning to return till late at night.

At the end of the winter, in the Shtcherbatskys' house, a consultation was being held, which was to pronounce on the state of Kitty's health and the measures to be taken to restore her (Kitty) failing strength.

The family doctor gave her (Kitty) cod liver oil, then iron, then nitrate of silver, but as the first and the second and the third were alike in doing no good, and as his (doctor) advice when spring came was to go abroad, a celebrated physician was called in.

PART TWO Chapter 1 She (Kitty) had been ill, and as spring came on she (Kitty) grew worse. The celebrated physician, a very handsome man, still youngish, asked to examine the patient.

He (patient) maintained, with peculiar satisfaction, it seemed, that maiden modesty is a mere relic of barbarism, and that nothing could be more natural than for a man still youngish to handle a young girl naked.

He (man) thought it natural because he (man) did it every day, and felt and thought, as it seemed to him (man), no harm as he (man) did it

and consequently he (man) considered modesty in the girl not merely as a relic of barbarism, but also as an insult to himself.

There was nothing for it but to submit, since, although all the doctors had studied in the same school, had read the same books, and learned the same science, and though some people said this celebrated doctor was a bad doctor, in the princess's household and circle it was for some reason accepted that this celebrated doctor alone had some special knowledge, and that he (doctor) alone could save Kitty.

After a careful examination and sounding of the bewildered patient, dazed with shame, the celebrated doctor, having scrupulously washed his (doctor) hands, was standing in the drawing room talking to the prince.

As a man who had seen something of life, and neither a fool nor an invalid, he (fool) had no faith in medicine, and in his (fool) heart was furious at the whole farce, specially as he (fool) was perhaps the only one who fully comprehended the cause of Kitty's illness.

The prince frowned and coughed, listening to the doctor. '' Conceited blockhead! '' he (doctor) thought, as he (doctor) listened to the celebrated doctor's chatter about his (doctor) daughter's symptoms.

The doctor was meantime with difficulty restraining the expression of his (doctor) contempt for this old gentleman, and with difficulty condescending to the level of his (doctor) intelligence.

He (doctor) perceived that it was no good talking to the old man, and that the principal person in the house was the mother.

Before her (mother) he (man) decided to scatter his (man) pearls. At that instant the princess came into the drawing room with the family doctor.

The prince withdrew, trying not to show how ridiculous he (prince) thought the whole performance. The princess was distracted, and did not know what to do.

She (princess) felt she (princess) had sinned against Kitty. '' Well, doctor, decide our fate,'' said the princess.

``Tell me everything.'' (unknown)
``Is there hope?

'' (she)

she (princess) meant to say, but her (princess) lips quivered, and she (princess) could not utter the question. '' Well, doctor? ''
``Immediately, princess.

I will talk it over with my colleague, and then I will have the honor of laying my opinion before you.'' (the doctors)

When the doctors were left alone, the family doctor began timidly explaining his (doctor) opinion, that there was a commencement of tuberculous trouble, but

'' So we had better leave you?'' '' As you please. '' The princess went out with a sigh. ...and so on.

The celebrated doctor listened to him (doctor), and in the middle of his (doctor) sentence looked at his (doctor) big gold watch. '' Yes,'' said he (doctor).

The commencement of the tuberculous process we are not, as you are aware, able to define; till there are cavities, there is nothing definite.

'' But...'' The family doctor respectfully ceased in the middle of his (doctor) observations. '' But we may suspect it. And there are indications; malnutrition, nervous excitability, and so on.

But, you know, there are always moral, spiritual causes at the back in these cases,'' the family doctor permitted himself to interpolate with a subtle smile.

The question stands thus: in presence of indications of tuberculous process, what is to be done to maintain nutrition?'' '' ''

Yes, that's an understood thing,'' responded the celebrated physician, again glancing at his (physician) watch. '' Beg pardon, is the Yausky bridge done yet, or shall I have to drive around?'' he (physician) asked.

'' Ah! it is. Oh, well, then I can do it in twenty minutes. So we were saying the problem may be put thus: to maintain nutrition and to give tone to the nerves.

The one is in close connection with the other, one must attack both sides at once.'' '' And how about a tour abroad?

And take note: if there is an early stage of tuberculous process, of which we cannot be certain, a foreign tour will be of no use.

'' asked the family doctor. '' I've no liking for foreign tours. What is wanted is means of improving nutrition, and not for lowering it.

And the celebrated doctor expounded his (doctor) plan of treatment with Soden waters, a remedy obviously prescribed primarily on the ground that they could do no harm.

'' The family doctor listened attentively and respectfully. '' But in favor of foreign travel I would urge the change of habits, the removal from conditions calling up reminiscences.

And then the mother wishes it,'' he (doctor) added. '' Ah! Well, in that case, to be sure, let them go. Only, those German quacks are mischievous....

They ought to be persuaded.... Well, let them go then. '' He (doctor) glanced once more at his (doctor) watch. '' Oh! time's up already,

The celebrated doctor announced to the princess -LRB-a feeling of what was due from him (doctor) dictated his (doctor) doing so-RRB- that he (doctor) ought to see the patient once more.

'' And he (doctor) went to the door. '' What! another examination!'' cried the mother, with horror. '' Oh, no, only a few details, princess.''

Wasted and flushed, with a peculiar glitter in her (princess) eyes, left there by the agony of shame she (princess) had been put through, Kitty stood in the middle of the room.

``Come this way. '' (the mother)
And the mother, accompanied by the doctor, went into the drawing room to Kitty. When the doctor came in she (Kitty) flushed crimson, and her (Kitty) eyes filled with tears.

All her (Kitty) illness and treatment struck her (Kitty) as a thing so stupid, ludicrous even! Doctoring her (Kitty) seemed to her (Kitty) as absurd as putting together the pieces of a broken vase.

Her (Kitty) heart was broken. Why would they try to cure her (Kitty) with pills and powders? But she (Kitty) could not grieve her (Kitty) mother, especially as her (Kitty) mother considered herself to blame.

'' May I trouble you to sit down, princess? '' the celebrated doctor said to her (princess). He (doctor) sat down with a smile, facing her (princess), felt her (princess) pulse, and again began asking her (princess) tiresome questions.

She (princess) answered him (doctor), and all at once got up, furious. '' Excuse me, doctor, but there is really no object in this.

This is the third time you've asked me the same thing. '' The celebrated doctor did not take offense. '' Nervous irritability,'' he (doctor) said to the princess, when Kitty had left the room.

And the doctor began scientifically explaining to the princess, as an exceptionally intelligent woman, the condition of the young princess, and concluded by insisting on the drinking of the waters, which were certainly harmless.

'' However, I had finished... '' At the question: Should they go abroad? the doctor plunged into deep meditation, as though resolving a weighty problem.

Finally his (doctor) decision was pronounced: they were to go abroad, but to put no faith in foreign quacks, and to apply to him (doctor) in any need.

It seemed as though some piece of good fortune had come to pass after the doctor had gone. The mother was much more cheerful when she (mother) went back to her (mother) daughter, and Kitty pretended to be more cheerful.

She (Kitty) had often, almost always, to be pretending now. '' Really, I'm quite well, mamma. But if you want to go abroad, let's go!

'' she (Kitty) said, and trying to appear interested in the proposed tour, she (Kitty) began talking of the preparations for the journey.

She (Kitty) knew that there was to be a consultation that day, and though she (Kitty) was only just up after her (Kitty) confinement -LRB-she (Kitty) had another baby, a little girl, born at the end of the winter-RRB-, though she (girl) had trouble and anxiety enough of her (girl) own, she (girl) had left her (girl) tiny baby and a sick child, to come and hear Kitty's fate, which was to be decided that day.

Chapter 2 Soon after the doctor, Dolly had arrived. '' Well, well? '' she (Dolly) said, coming into the drawing room, without taking off her (Dolly) hat.

They tried to tell her (Dolly) what the doctor had said, but it appeared that though the doctor had talked distinctly enough and at great length, it was utterly impossible to report what he (doctor) had said.

'' You're all in good spirits. Good news, then?'' The only point of interest was that it was settled they should go abroad.

Dolly could not help sighing. Her (Dolly) dearest friend, her (Dolly) sister, was going away. And her (Dolly) life was not a cheerful one.

The union Anna had cemented turned out to be of no solid character, and family harmony was breaking down again at the same point.

There had been nothing definite, but Stepan Arkadyevitch was hardly ever at home; money, too, was hardly ever forthcoming, and Dolly was continually tortured by suspicions of infidelity, which she (Dolly) tried to dismiss, dreading the agonies of jealousy she (Dolly) had been through already.

The first onslaught of jealousy, once lived through, could never come back again, and even the discovery of infidelities could never now affect her (Dolly) as it had the first time.

Such a discovery now would only mean breaking up family habits, and she (Dolly) let herself be deceived, despising him (Dolly) and still more herself, for the weakness.

Besides this, the care of her (Dolly) large family was a constant worry to her (Dolly): first, the nursing of her (Dolly) young baby did not go well

Her (Dolly) relations with Stepan Arkadyevitch after their reconciliation had become humiliating. , then the nurse had gone away, now one of the children had fallen ill.

'' Well, how are all of you?'' asked her (nurse) mother. '' Ah, mamma, we have plenty of troubles of our own.

I have come here now to hear about Kitty, and then I shall shut myself up entirely, if--God forbid--it should be scarlatina.

The old prince too had come in from his (prince) study after the doctor's departure, and after presenting his (prince) cheek to Dolly, and saying a few words to her (Dolly), he (prince) turned to his (prince) wife:

Lili is ill, and I'm afraid it's scarlatina. ''

``How have you settled it? you're going? Well, and what do you mean to do with me?'' (unknown)

``I suppose you had better stay here, Alexander,'' (wife)
said his (Alexander) wife. '' That's as you like.''
``Mamma, why shouldn't father come with us?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
said Kitty.

'' It would be nicer for him (father) and for us too. '' The old prince got up and stroked Kitty's hair.

It always seemed to her (Kitty) that he (prince) understood her (Kitty) better than anyone in the family, though he (prince) did not say much about her (Kitty).

She (Kitty) lifted her (Kitty) head and looked at him (prince) with a forced smile. Being the youngest, she (Kitty) was her (Kitty) father's favorite, and she (Kitty) fancied that his (father) love gave him (father) insight.

When now her (Kitty) glance met his (father) blue kindly eyes looking intently at her (Kitty), it seemed to her (Kitty) that he (father) saw right through her (Kitty), and understood all that was not good that was passing within her (Kitty).

Reddening, she (Kitty) stretched out towards him (father) expecting a kiss, but he (father) only patted her (Kitty) hair and said:

``These stupid chignons! There's no getting at the real daughter.

'' '' Oh, that's it!'' said the prince. '' And so am I to be getting ready for a journey too?

At your service,'' (daughter)
