Yes, he (criminal) sees it all, he (criminal) understands it all, and in these words he (criminal)'s telling me that though I'm ashamed, I must get over my shame.

'' '' She (Kitty) could not pluck up spirit to make any answer. She (Kitty) tried to begin, and all at once burst into tears, and rushed out of the room.

'' See what comes of your jokes! '' the princess pounced down on her (princess) husband. '' You're always... '' she (princess) began a string of reproaches.

The prince listened to the princess's scolding rather a long while without speaking, but his (prince) face was more and more frowning.

She (princess)'s so much to be pitied, poor child, so much to be pitied, and you don't feel how it hurts her (princess) to hear the slightest reference to the cause of it.

Ah! to be so mistaken in people!'' said the princess, and by the change in her (princess) tone both Dolly and the prince knew she (princess) was speaking of Vronsky.

``Ah, I can't bear to hear you!'' (the prince)
said the prince gloomily, getting up from his (prince) low chair, and seeming anxious to get away, yet stopping in the doorway.

There are laws, madam, and since you've challenged me to it, I'll tell you who's to blame for it all: you and you, you and nobody else.

'' '' I don't know why there aren't laws against such base, dishonorable people.'' '' Laws against such young gallants there have always been, and there still are!

Yes, if there has been nothing that ought not to have been, old as I am, I'd have called him (you) out to the barrier, the young dandy.

The prince apparently had plenty more to say, but as soon as the princess heard his (prince) tone she (princess) subsided at once, and became penitent, as she (princess) always did on serious occasions.

Yes, and now you physic her (princess) and call in these quacks. '' '' Alexander, Alexander,'' she (princess) whispered, moving to him (Alexander) and beginning to weep.

As soon as she (princess) began to cry the prince too calmed down. He (prince) went up to her (princess). '' There, that's enough, that's enough!

he (prince) said, not knowing what he (prince) was saying, as he (prince) responded to the tearful kiss of the princess that he (prince) felt on his (prince) hand.

You're wretched too, I know. It can't be helped. There's no great harm done. God is merciful... thanks... '' And the prince went out of the room.

Before this, as soon as Kitty went out of the room in tears, Dolly, with her (Dolly) motherly, family instincts, had promptly perceived that here a woman's work lay before her (Dolly), and she (Dolly) prepared to do it.

She (Dolly) took off her (Dolly) hat, and, morally speaking, tucked up her (Dolly) sleeves and prepared for action. While her (Dolly) mother was attacking her (Dolly) father, she (Dolly) tried to restrain her (Dolly) mother, so far as filial reverence would allow.

During the prince's outburst she (Dolly) was silent; she (Dolly) felt ashamed for her (Dolly) mother, and tender towards her (Dolly) father for so quickly being kind again.

But when her (Dolly) father left them she (Dolly) made ready for what was the chief thing needful--to go to Kitty and console her (Kitty).

I'd been meaning to tell you something for a long while, mamma: did you know that Levin meant to make Kitty an offer when he (Levin) was here the last time?

'' He (Levin) told Stiva so.'' '' Well, what then? I don't understand...''

``So did Kitty perhaps refuse him (Levin)?... She (Kitty) didn't tell you so?'' (I)

'' No, she (Kitty) has said nothing to me either of one or the other; she (Kitty)'s too proud. But I know it's all on account of the other.''

'' Yes, but suppose she (Kitty) has refused Levin, and she (Kitty) wouldn't have refused him (Levin) if it hadn't been for the other, I know.

It was too terrible for the princess to think how she (princess) had sinned against her (princess) daughter, and she (princess) broke out angrily.

And then, he (Levin) has deceived her (princess) so horribly. '' '' Oh, I really don't understand! Nowadays they will all go their own way, and mothers haven't a word to say in anything, and then...''

When she (princess) went into Kitty's little room, a pretty, pink little room, full of knick-knacks in vieux saxe, as fresh, and pink, and white, and gay as Kitty herself had been two months ago, Dolly remembered how they had decorated the room the year before together, with what love and gaiety.

Her (Dolly) heart turned cold when she (Dolly) saw Kitty sitting on a low chair near the door, her (Kitty) eyes fixed immovably on a corner of the rug.

``Mamma, I'll go up to her (Kitty).'' (unknown)
``Well, do. Did I tell you not to?'' (mother)
said her (Kitty) mother. Chapter 3 Kitty glanced at her (Kitty) sister, and the cold, rather ill-tempered expression of her (Kitty) face did not change.

I'm just going now, and I shall have to keep in and you won't be able to come to see me,'' said Dolly, sitting down beside her (Dolly).

'' '' I want to talk to you.''

``What about?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Kitty asked swiftly, lifting her (Kitty) head in dismay. '' What should it be, but your trouble?''

``I have no trouble.'' (unknown)
``Nonsense, Kitty. Do you suppose I could help knowing? I know all about it. And believe me, it's of so little consequence....

We've all been through it. '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

Kitty did not speak, and her (Kitty) face had a stern expression. '' He (Dolly)'s not worth your grieving over him (Dolly),'' pursued Darya Alexandrovna, coming straight to the point.

'' No, because he (Dolly) has treated me with contempt,'' said Kitty, in a breaking voice. '' Don't talk of it! Please, don't talk of it!''

'' But who can have told you so? No one has said that. I'm certain he (Dolly) was in love with you, and would still be in love with you, if it hadn't...

'' Oh, the most awful thing of all for me is this sympathizing! '' shrieked Kitty, suddenly flying into a passion.

She (Kitty) turned round on her (Kitty) chair, flushed crimson, and rapidly moving her (Kitty) fingers, pinched the clasp of her (Kitty) belt first with one hand

Dolly knew this trick her (Dolly) sister had of clenching her (Dolly) hands when she (Dolly) was much excited; she (Dolly) knew, too, that in moments of excitement

Kitty was capable of forgetting herself and saying a great deal too much, and Dolly would have soothed her (Dolly), but it was too late.

and then with the other. '' What, what is it you want to make me feel, eh?'' said Kitty quickly. ''

That I've been in love with a man who didn't care a straw for me, and that I'm dying of love for him (man)?

And this is said to me by my own sister, who imagines that... that... that she (sister)'s sympathizing with me!... I don't want these condolences and humbug!''

``Kitty, you're unjust. '' (unknown)
``Why are you tormenting me?'' (I.)
'' But I...quite the contrary... I see you're unhappy... '' But Kitty in her (Kitty) fury did not hear her (Kitty).

'' I've nothing to grieve over and be comforted about. I am too proud ever to allow myself to care for a man who does not love me.''

``Yes, I don't say so either.... Only one thing. Tell me the truth,'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna, taking her (Kitty) by the hand: ``tell me, did Levin speak to you?...

She (Kitty) leaped up from her (Kitty) chair, and flinging her (Kitty) clasp on the ground, she (Kitty) gesticulated rapidly with her (Kitty) hands and said:

``Why bring Levin in too?

'' (she)

The mention of Levin's name seemed to deprive Kitty of the last vestige of self-control. I can't understand what you want to torment me for.

I've told you, and I say it again, that I have some pride, and never, never would I do as you're doing--go back to a man who's deceived you, who has cared for another woman.

And saying these words she (woman) glanced at her (woman) sister, and seeing that Dolly sat silent, her (Dolly) head mournfully bowed, Kitty, instead of running out of the room as she (Kitty) had meant to do, sat down near the door, and hid her (Kitty) face in her (Kitty) handkerchief.

I can't understand it! You may, but I can't! '' The silence lasted for two minutes: Dolly was thinking of herself.

That humiliation of which she (Dolly) was always conscious came back to her (Dolly) with a peculiar bitterness when her (Dolly) sister reminded her (Dolly) of it.

But suddenly she (Dolly) heard the rustle of a skirt, and with it the sound of heart-rending, smothered sobbing, and felt arms about her (Dolly) neck.

She (Dolly) had not looked for such cruelty in her (Dolly) sister, and she (Dolly) was angry with her (Dolly). Kitty was on her (Kitty) knees before her (Kitty).

'' Dolinka, I am so, so wretched! '' she (Kitty) whispered penitently. And the sweet face covered with tears hid itself in Darya Alexandrovna's skirt.

As though tears were the indispensable oil, without which the machinery of mutual confidence could not run smoothly between the two sisters, the sisters after their tears talked, not of what was uppermost in their minds, but, though they talked of outside matters, they understood each other.

Kitty knew that the words she (Kitty) had uttered in anger about her (Kitty) husband's infidelity and her (Kitty) humiliating position had cut her (Kitty) poor sister to the heart, but that she (Kitty) had forgiven her (Kitty).

She (Kitty) felt certain that her (Kitty) surmises were correct; that Kitty's misery, her (Kitty) inconsolable misery, was due precisely to the fact that Levin had made her (Kitty) an offer

and she (Kitty) had refused him (Levin), and Vronsky had deceived her (Kitty), and that she (Kitty) was fully prepared to love Levin and to detest Vronsky.

Dolly for her (Dolly) part knew all she (Dolly) had wanted to find out. Kitty said not a word of that; she (Kitty) talked of nothing but her (Kitty) spiritual condition.

'' I have nothing to make me miserable,'' she (Kitty) said, getting calmer;

``but can you understand that everything has become hateful, loathsome, coarse to me, and

I myself most of all? You can't imagine what loathsome thoughts I have about everything. '' (she)

``Why, whatever loathsome thoughts can you have?

'' (Dolly)

asked Dolly, smiling. '' The most utterly loathsome and coarse: I can't tell you. It's not unhappiness, or low spirits, but much worse.

As though everything that was good in me was all hidden away, and nothing was left but the most loathsome. Come, how am I to tell you?

'' she (Dolly) went on, seeing the puzzled look in her (Dolly) sister's eyes. '' Father began saying something to me just now....

Mother takes me to a ball: it seems to me she (Mother) only takes me to get me married off as soon as may be, and be rid of me.

It seems to me he (Father) thinks all I want is to be married. I know it's not the truth, but I can't drive away such thoughts.

Eligible suitors, as they call them--I can't bear to see them. It seems to me they're taking stock of me and summing me up.

In old days to go anywhere in a ball dress was a simple joy to me, I admired myself; now I feel ashamed and awkward.

Kitty hesitated; she (Kitty) wanted to say further that ever since this change had taken place in her (Kitty), Stepan Arkadyevitch had become insufferably repulsive to her (Kitty), and that she (Kitty) could not see him (me) without the grossest and most hideous conceptions rising before her (Kitty) imagination.

And then! The doctor.... Then...'' '' Oh, well, everything presents itself to me, in the coarsest, most loathsome light,'' she (Kitty) went on.

'' That's my illness. Perhaps it will pass off.'' '' But you mustn't think about it.''

``I can't help it. I'm never happy except with the children at your house.

'' (unknown)

``What a pity you can't be with me!'' (I)
'' Oh, yes, I'm coming. I've had scarlatina, and I'll persuade mamma to let me.''

Kitty insisted on having her (Kitty) way, and went to stay at her (Kitty) sister's and nursed the children all through the scarlatina, for scarlatina

The two sisters brought all the six children successfully through it, but Kitty was no better in health, and in Lent the Shtcherbatskys went abroad.

it turned out to be. Chapter 4 The highest Petersburg society is essentially one: in it everyone knows everyone else, everyone even visits everyone else.

But this great set has its subdivisions. Anna Arkadyevna Karenina had friends and close ties in three different circles of this highest society.

One circle was her (Anna) husband's government official set, consisting of his (official) colleagues and subordinates, brought together in the most various and capricious manner, and belonging to different social strata.

Anna found it difficult now to recall the feeling of almost awe-stricken reverence which she (Anna) had at first entertained for these persons.

Now she (Anna) knew all of them as people know one another in a country town; she (Anna) knew their habits and weaknesses, and where the shoe pinched each one of them.

She (Anna) knew their relations with one another and with the head authorities, knew who was for whom, and how each one maintained his (official) position, and where they agreed and disagreed.

But the circle of political, masculine interests had never interested her (Anna), in spite of countess Lidia Ivanovna's influence, and she (Ivanovna) avoided it.

Another little set with which Anna was in close relations was the one by means of which Alexey Alexandrovitch had made his (Alexandrovitch) career.

The center of this circle was the Countess Lidia Ivanovna. It was a set made up of elderly, ugly, benevolent, and godly women, and clever, learned, and ambitious men.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had the highest esteem for this circle, and Anna with her (Anna) special gift for getting on with everyone, had in the early days of her (Anna) life in Petersburg made friends in this circle also.

One of the clever people belonging to the set had called it

``the conscience of Petersburg society. '' (the people)
Now, since her (Anna) return from Moscow, she (Anna) had come to feel this set insufferable.

It seemed to her (Anna) that both she (Anna) and all of them were insincere, and she (Anna) felt so bored and ill at ease in that world that she (Anna) went to see the Countess Lidia Ivanovna as little as possible.

The third circle with which Anna had ties was preeminently the fashionable world--the world of balls, of dinners, of sumptuous dresses, the world that hung on to the court with one hand, so as to avoid sinking to the level of the demi-monde.

For the demi-monde the members of that fashionable world believed that they despised, though their tastes were not merely similar, but in fact identical.

Her (Anna) connection with this circle was kept up through Princess Betsy Tverskaya, her (Tverskaya) cousin's wife, who had an income of a hundred and twenty thousand roubles, and who had taken a great fancy to Anna ever since she (Anna) first came out, showed her (Anna) much attention, and drew her (Anna) into her (Anna) set, making fun of Countess Lidia Ivanovna's coterie.

When I'm old and ugly I'll be the same,'' Betsy used to say;

``but for a pretty young woman like you it's early days for that house of charity.

Anna had at first avoided as far as she (Anna) could Princess Tverskaya's world, because it necessitated an expenditure beyond her (Anna) means, and besides in her (Anna) heart she (Anna) preferred the first circle.

'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)

'' But since her (Anna) visit to Moscow she (Anna) had done quite the contrary. She (Anna) avoided her (Anna) serious-minded friends, and went out into the fashionable world.

There she (Anna) met Vronsky, and experienced an agitating joy at those meetings. She (Anna) met Vronsky specially often at Betsy's for Betsy was a Vronsky by birth and his (Vronsky) cousin.

Vronsky was everywhere where he (Vronsky) had any chance of meeting Anna, and speaking to her (Anna), when he (Vronsky) could, of his (Vronsky) love.

She (Anna) gave him (Vronsky) no encouragement, but every time she (Anna) met him (Vronsky) there surged up in her (Anna) heart that same feeling of quickened life that had come upon her (Anna) that day in the railway carriage when she (Anna) saw him (Vronsky) for the first time.

She (Anna) was conscious herself that her (Anna) delight sparkled in her (Anna) eyes and curved her (Anna) lips into a smile, and she (Anna) could not quench the expression of this delight.

Soon after her (Anna) return from Moscow, on arriving at a soiree where she (Anna) had expected to meet him (Vronsky), and not finding him (Vronsky) there, she (Anna) realized distinctly from the rush of disappointment that she (Anna) had been deceiving herself, and that this pursuit was not merely not distasteful to her (Anna), but that it made the whole interest of her (Anna) life.

At first Anna sincerely believed that she (Anna) was displeased with him (Vronsky) for daring to pursue her (Anna). A celebrated singer was singing for the second time, and all the fashionable world was in the theater.

Vronsky, seeing his (singer) cousin from his (singer) stall in the front row, did not wait till the entr`acte, but went to her (Anna) box.

'' Why didn't you come to dinner? '' she (Anna) said to him (singer). '' I marvel at the second sight of lovers,'' she (Anna) added with a smile, so that no one

but he (singer) could hear; '' she (Anna) wasn't there . But come after the opera. '' Vronsky looked inquiringly at her (Anna). She (Anna) nodded.

But how I remember your jeers!'' continued Princess Betsy, who took a peculiar pleasure in following up this passion to a successful issue.

He (singer) thanked her (Betsy) by a smile, and sat down beside her (Betsy). '' '' What's become of all that? You're caught, my dear boy.''

'' That's my one desire, to be caught,'' answered Vronsky, with his (boy) serene, good-humored smile. '' If I complain of anything it's only that I'm not caught enough, to tell the truth.

I begin to lose hope. ''

``Why, whatever hope can you have?'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
said Betsy, offended on behalf of her (Betsy) friend. ''

But in her (Betsy) eyes there were gleams of light that betrayed that she (Betsy) understood perfectly and precisely as he (friend) did what hope he (friend) might have.

Excuse me,'' he (friend) added, taking an opera glass out of her (Betsy) hand, and proceeding to scrutinize, over her (Betsy) bare shoulder, the row of boxes facing them.

Enendons nous... '' '' None whatever,'' said Vronsky, laughing and showing his (Vronsky) even rows of teeth. '' '' I'm afraid I'm becoming ridiculous.

He (Vronsky) was very well aware that he (Vronsky) ran no risk of being ridiculous in the eyes of Betsy or any other fashionable people.

He (Vronsky) was very well aware that in their eyes the position of an unsuccessful lover of a girl, or of any woman free to marry, might be ridiculous.

But the position of a man pursuing a married woman, and, regardless of everything, staking his (man) life on drawing her (woman) into adultery, has something fine and grand about it, and can never be ridiculous; and so it was with a proud and gay smile under his (man) mustaches that he (man) lowered the opera glass and looked at his (man) cousin.

'' '' But why was it you didn't come to dinner? '' she (woman) said, admiring him (man). '' I must tell you about that.

I was busily employed, and doing what, do you suppose? I'll give you a hundred guesses, a thousand... you'd never guess.

I've been reconciling a husband with a man who'd insulted his (man) wife. Yes, really!'' '' Well, did you succeed?''

``Almost.'' (unknown)
``You really must tell me about it,'' (she)
she (wife) said, getting up.

``Come to me in the next entr`acte. '' (I)
'' I can't; I'm going to the French theater.''
``From Nilsson? '' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
Betsy queried in horror, though she (Betsy) could not herself have distinguished Nilsson's voice from any chorus girl's.

``Blessed are the peacemakers; theirs is the kingdom of heaven,''' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
said Betsy, vaguely recollecting she (Betsy) had heard some similar saying from someone.

'' Can't help it. I've an appointment there, all to do with my mission of peace. '' '' Very well, then, sit down, and tell me what it's all about.

'' And she (Betsy) sat down again. Chapter 5 '' This is rather indiscreet, but it's so good it's an awful temptation to tell the story,'' said Vronsky, looking at her (Betsy) with his (Vronsky) laughing eyes.

'' I'm not going to mention any names.'' '' But I shall guess, so much the better.''

``Well, listen: two festive young men were driving--

'' (unknown)

``Officers of your regiment, of course?'' (unknown)
``I didn't say they were officers,--two young men who had been lunching.'' (unknown)
``In other words, drinking.'' (a woman)

And they beheld a pretty woman in a hired sledge; she (woman) overtakes them, looks round at them, and, so they fancy anyway, nods to them and laughs.

``Possibly. They were driving on their way to dinner with a friend in the most festive state of mind. They, of course, follow her (woman).

They gallop at full speed. To their amazement, the fair one alights at the entrance of the very house to which they were going.

The fair one darts upstairs to the top story. They get a glimpse of red lips under a short veil, and exquisite little feet.'' (unknown)

``You describe it with such feeling that I fancy you must be one of the two.'' (unknown)
'' And after what you said, just now!

Well, the young men go in to their comrade's; he (comrade) was giving a farewell dinner. There they certainly did drink a little too much, as one always does at farewell dinners.

No one knows; only their host's valet, in answer to their inquiry whether any `young ladies' are living on the top floor, answered that there were a great many of them about there.

And at dinner they inquire who lives at the top in that house. After dinner the two young men go into their host's study, and write a letter to the unknown fair one.

They compose an ardent epistle, a declaration in fact, and they carry the letter upstairs themselves, so as to elucidate whatever might appear not perfectly intelligible in the letter.

A maidservant opens the door, they hand her (maidservant) the letter, and assure the maid that they're both so in love that they'll die on the spot at the door.

All at once a gentleman appears with whiskers like sausages, as red as a lobster, announces that there is no one living in the flat except his (gentleman) wife, and sends them both about their business.

''

``Why are you telling me these horrible stories? Well?'' (unknown)
``They ring. The maid, stupefied, carries in their messages. '' (unknown)
``How do you know he (gentleman) had whiskers like sausages, as you say?'' (unknown)

``Ah, you shall hear. I've just been to make peace between them.'' (unknown)
'' Well, and what then?'' '' That's the most interesting part of the story.

It appears that it's a happy couple, a government clerk and his (gentleman) lady. The government clerk lodges a complaint, and I became a mediator, and such a mediator!

... I assure you Talleyrand couldn't hold a candle to me.''

``Why, where was the difficulty?'' (unknown)
``Ah, you shall hear.... We apologize in due form: we are in despair, we entreat forgiveness for the unfortunate misunderstanding.

The government clerk with the sausages begins to melt, but he (mediator), too, desires to express his (mediator) sentiments, and as soon as ever he (mediator) begins to express them, he (mediator) begins to get hot and say nasty things, and again I'm obliged to trot out all my diplomatic talents.

I allowed that their conduct was bad, but I urged him (mediator) to take into consideration their heedlessness, their youth; then, too, the young men had only just been lunching together. '

You understand. They regret it deeply, and beg you to overlook their misbehavior.' The government clerk was softened once more. '

I consent, count, and am ready to overlook it; but you perceive that my wife--my wife's a respectable woman --has been exposed to the persecution, and insults, and effrontery of young upstarts, scoundrels...'

And you must understand, the young upstarts are present all the while, and I have to keep the peace between them.

Again I call out all my diplomacy, and again as soon as the thing was about at an end, our friend the government clerk gets hot and red, and his (friend) sausages stand on end with wrath, and once more I launch out into diplomatic wiles.'' (unknown)

``Ah, he (friend) must tell you this story!'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
said Betsy, laughing, to a lady who came into her (Betsy) box. '' He (friend) has been making me laugh so.''

she (Betsy) added, giving Vronsky one finger of the hand in which she (Betsy) held her (Betsy) fan, and with a shrug of her (Betsy) shoulders she (Betsy) twitched down the bodice of her (Betsy) gown that had worked up, so as to be duly naked as she (Betsy) moved forward towards the footlights into the light of the gas, and the sight of all eyes.

Vronsky drove to the French theater, where he (fan) really had to see the colonel of his (fan) regiment, who never missed a single performance there.

He (fan) wanted to see him (fan), to report on the result of his (fan) mediation, which had occupied and amused him (fan) for the last three days.

Petritsky, whom he (fan) liked, was implicated in the affair, and the other culprit was a capital fellow and first-rate comrade, who had lately joined the regiment, the young Prince Kedrov.

``Well, bonne chance ! '' (unknown)
And what was most important, the interests of the regiment were involved in it too. Both the young men were in Vronsky's company.

The colonel of the regiment was waited upon by the government clerk, Venden, with a complaint against his (colonel) officers, who had insulted his (colonel) wife.

His (colonel) young wife, so Venden told the story--he (colonel) had been married half a year--was at church with her (wife) mother, and suddenly overcome by indisposition, arising from her (wife) interesting condition, she (wife) could not remain standing, she (wife) drove home in the first sledge, a smart-looking one, she (wife) came across.

On the spot the officers set off in pursuit of her (wife); she (wife) was alarmed, and feeling still more unwell, ran up the staircase home.

Venden himself, on returning from his (colonel) office, heard a ring at their bell and voices, went out, and seeing the intoxicated officers with a letter, he (colonel) had turned them out.

He (colonel) asked for exemplary punishment. '' Yes, it's all very well,'' said the colonel to Vronsky, whom he (colonel) had invited to come and see him (colonel).

'' Petritsky's becoming impossible. Not a week goes by without some scandal. This government clerk won't let it drop, he (colonel)'ll go on with the thing.

Vronsky saw all the thanklessness of the business, and that there could be no question of a duel in it, that everything must be done to soften the government clerk, and hush the matter up.

The colonel had called in Vronsky just because he (colonel) knew him (colonel) to be an honorable and intelligent man, and, more than all, a man who cared for the honor of the regiment.

The colonel and Vronsky were both fully aware that Vronsky's name and rank would be sure to contribute greatly to the softening of the injured husband's feelings.

'' They talked it over, and decided that Petritsky and Kedrov must go with Vronsky to Venden's to apologize. And these two influences were not in fact without effect; though the result remained, as Vronsky had described, uncertain.

On reaching the French theater, Vronsky retired to the foyer with the colonel, and reported to him (Vronsky) his (Vronsky) success, or non-success.

The colonel, thinking it all over, made up his (colonel) mind not to pursue the matter further, but then for his (colonel) own satisfaction proceeded to cross-examine Vronsky about his (colonel) interview; and it was a long while before he (colonel) could restrain his (colonel) laughter, as Vronsky described how the government clerk, after subsiding for a while, would suddenly flare up again, as he (Vronsky) recalled the details, and how Vronsky, at the last half word of conciliation, skillfully maneuvered a retreat, shoving Petritsky out before him (Vronsky).

'' It's a disgraceful story, but killing. Kedrov really can't fight the gentleman! Was he (gentleman) so awfully hot? '' he (gentleman) commented, laughing.

'' But what do you say to Claire today? She (Claire)'s marvelous,'' he (gentleman) went on, speaking of a new French actress. ''

However often you see her (actress), every day she (actress)'s different. It's only the French who can do that. '' Chapter 6 Princess Betsy drove home from the theater, without waiting for the end of the last act.

She (Betsy) had only just time to go into her (Betsy) dressing room, sprinkle her (Betsy) long, pale face with powder, rub it, set her (Betsy) dress to rights, and order tea in the big drawing room, when one after another carriages drove up to her (Betsy) huge house in Bolshaia Morskaia.

Her (Betsy) guests stepped out at the wide entrance, and the stout porter, who used to read the newspapers in the mornings behind the glass door, to the edification of the passers-by, noiselessly opened the immense door, letting the visitors pass by him (porter) into the house.

Almost at the same instant the hostess, with freshly arranged coiffure and freshened face, walked in at one door and her (hostess) guests at the other door of the drawing room, a large room with dark walls, downy rugs, and a brightly lighted table, gleaming with the light of candles, white cloth, silver samovar, and transparent china tea things.

Chairs were set with the aid of footmen, moving almost imperceptibly about the room; the party settled itself, divided into two groups:

one round the samovar near the hostess, the other at the opposite end of the drawing room, round the handsome wife of an ambassador, in black velvet, with sharply defined black eyebrows.

In both groups conversation wavered, as it always does, for the first few minutes, broken up by meetings, greetings, offers of tea, and as it were, feeling about for something to rest upon.

She (wife)'s exceptionally good as an actress; one can see she (wife)'s studied Kaulbach,'' said a diplomatic attache in the group round the ambassador's wife.

The hostess sat down at the table and took off her (hostess) gloves. '' '' Did you notice how she (hostess) fell down?...''

No one can possibly say anything new about her (hostess),'' said a fat, red-faced, flaxen-headed lady, without eyebrows and chignon, wearing an old silk dress.

``Oh, please, don't let us talk about Nilsson! This was Princess Myakaya, noted for her (Princess) simplicity and the roughness of her (Princess) manners, and nicknamed enfant terrible .

Princess Myakaya, sitting in the middle between the two groups, and listening to both, took part in the conversation first of one and then of the other.

Three people have used that very phrase about Kaulbach to me today already, just as though they had made a compact about it.

'' (I)

And I can't see why they liked that remark so. '' The conversation was cut short by this observation, and a new subject had to be thought of again.

Do tell me something amusing but not spiteful,'' said the ambassador's wife, a great proficient in the art of that elegant conversation called by the English, small talk .

'' She (wife) addressed the attache, who was at a loss now what to begin upon. '' They say that that's a difficult task, that nothing's amusing that isn't spiteful,'' he (ambassador) began with a smile.

'' But I'll try. Get me a subject. It all lies in the subject. If a subject's given me, it's easy to spin something round it.

I often think that the celebrated talkers of the last century would have found it difficult to talk cleverly now. Everything clever is so stale...''

``That has been said long ago,'' (the ambassador)
the ambassador's wife interrupted him (ambassador), laughing. The conversation began amiably, but just because it was too amiable, it came to a stop again.

They had to have recourse to the sure, never-failing topic--gossip. '' Don't you think there's something Louis Quinze about Tushkevitch? ''

he (Louis) said, glancing towards a handsome, fair-haired young man, standing at the table. '' Oh, yes! He (Louis)'s in the same style as the drawing room and that's why it is he (Louis)'s so often here.

This conversation was maintained, since it rested on allusions to what could not be talked of in that room--that is to say, of the relations of Tushkevitch with their hostess.

Round the samovar and the hostess the conversation had been meanwhile vacillating in just the same way between three inevitable topics: the latest piece of public news, the theater, and scandal.

'' It, too, came finally to rest on the last topic, that is, ill-natured gossip. '' Have you heard the Maltishtcheva woman--the mother, not the daughter--has ordered a costume in diable rose color?

''

``Nonsense! No, that's too lovely!'' (unknown)
``I wonder that with her (daughter) sense--for she (daughter)'s not a fool, you know-- that she (daughter) doesn't see how funny she (daughter) is.

Everyone had something to say in censure or ridicule of the luckless Madame Maltishtcheva, and the conversation crackled merrily, like a burning faggot-stack.

The husband of Princess Betsy, a good-natured fat man, an ardent collector of engravings, hearing that his (collector) wife had visitors, came into the drawing room before going to his (collector) club.

'' (he)

Stepping noiselessly over the thick rugs, he (collector) went up to Princess Myakaya. '' How did you like Nilsson? '' he (Nilsson) asked.

'' Oh, how can you steal upon anyone like that! How you startled me! '' she (Princess) responded. '' Please don't talk to me about the opera; you know nothing about music.

I'd better meet you on your own ground, and talk about your majolica and engravings. Come now, what treasure have you been buying lately at the old curiosity shops?''

``Would you like me to show you? But you don't understand such things.'' (unknown)
``Oh, do show me! I've been learning about them at those--what's their names?...the bankers...

they've some splendid engravings. They showed them to us.'' (unknown)

``Why, have you been at the Sch√ºtzburgs? '' (the hostess)
asked the hostess from the samovar.

They asked my husband and me to dinner, and told us the sauce at that dinner cost a hundred pounds,'' Princess Myakaya said, speaking loudly, and conscious everyone was listening;

``and very nasty sauce it was, some green mess.

We had to ask them, and I made them sauce for eighteen pence, and everybody was very much pleased with it.

'' (everyone)

Yes, ma chere . I can't run to hundred-pound sauces. '' '' She (Princess)'s unique!'' said the lady of the house.

The sensation produced by Princess Myakaya's speeches was always unique, and the secret of the sensation she (Princess) produced lay in the fact that though she (Princess) spoke not always appropriately, as now, she (Princess) said simple things with some sense in them.

``Marvelous!'' (someone)
said someone. In the society in which she (Princess) lived such plain statements produced the effect of the wittiest epigram. Princess Myakaya could never see why it had that effect, but she (Princess) knew it had, and took advantage of it.

As everyone had been listening while Princess Myakaya spoke, and so the conversation around the ambassador's wife had dropped, Princess Betsy tried to bring the whole party together, and turned to the ambassador's wife.

No, we're very happy here,'' the ambassador's wife responded with a smile, and she (wife) went on with the conversation that had been begun.

'' Will you really not have tea? You should come over here by us.'' '' It was a very agreeable conversation.

They were criticizing the Karenins, husband and wife. '' Anna is quite changed since her (Anna) stay in Moscow. There's something strange about her (Anna),'' said her (Anna) friend.

'' The great change is that she (Anna) brought back with her (Anna) the shadow of Alexey Vronsky,'' said the ambassador's wife. ''

Well, what of it? There's a fable of Grimm's about a man without a shadow, a man who's lost his (man) shadow.

And that's his (man) punishment for something. I never could understand how it was a punishment. But a woman must dislike being without a shadow.''

'' Yes, but women with a shadow usually come to a bad end,'' said Anna's friend. '' Bad luck to your tongue!'' said Princess Myakaya suddenly.

'' Madame Karenina's a splendid woman. I don't like her (Princess) husband, but I like her (Princess) very much.''

``Why don't you like her (Princess) husband?

He (husband)'s such a remarkable man,'' (the ambassador)

said the ambassador's wife. '' My husband says there are few statesmen like him (husband) in Europe.''

'' And my husband tells me just the same, but I don't believe it,'' said Princess Myakaya. '' If our husbands didn't talk to us, we should see the facts as they are.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, to my thinking, is simply a fool. I say it in a whisper...but doesn't it really make everything clear?

Before, when I was told to consider him (fool) clever, I kept looking for his (fool) ability, and thought myself a fool for not seeing it; but directly I said, he (fool)'s a fool, though only in a whisper, everything's explained, isn't it?''

``How spiteful you are today!'' (unknown)
``Not a bit. I'd no other way out of it. One of the two had to be a fool.

And, well, you know one can't say that of oneself.'' (everyone)

''`No one is satisfied with his (fool) fortune, and everyone is satisfied with his (fool) wit.'

'' The attach√© repeated the French saying. '' That's just it, just it,'' Princess Myakaya turned to him (fool). '' But the point is that I won't abandon Anna to your mercies.

She (Anna)'s so nice, so charming. How can she (Anna) help it if they're all in love with her (Anna), and follow her (Anna) about like shadows?''

'' Oh, I had no idea of blaming her (Anna) for it,'' Anna's friend said in self-defense. '' If no one follows us about like a shadow, that's no proof that we've any right to blame her (Anna).

And having duly disposed of Anna's friend, the Princess Myakaya got up, and together with the ambassador's wife, joined the group at the table, where the conversation was dealing with the king of Prussia.

The princess gave us a sketch of Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' said the ambassador's wife with a smile, as she (wife) sat down at the table.

'' '' What wicked gossip were you talking over there?'' asked Betsy. '' About the Karenins. '' Pity we didn't hear it!'' said Princess Betsy, glancing towards the door.

Vronsky was not merely acquainted with all the persons whom he (Alexandrovitch) was meeting here; he (Alexandrovitch) saw them all every day; and so he (Alexandrovitch) came in with the quiet manner with which one enters a room full of people from whom one has only just parted.

'' Ah, here you are at last! '' she (Betsy) said, turning with a smile to Vronsky, as he (Alexandrovitch) came in. ''

Where do I come from? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said, in answer to a question from the ambassador's wife. '' Well, there's no help for it, I must confess.

From the opera bouff√© . I do believe I've seen it a hundred times, and always with fresh enjoyment. It's exquisite!

I know it's disgraceful, but I go to sleep at the opera, and I sit out the opera bouff√© to the last minute, and enjoy it.

He (Alexandrovitch) mentioned a French actress, and was going to tell something about her (actress); but the ambassador's wife, with playful horror, cut him (ambassador) short.

This evening... '' '' Please don't tell us about that horror.'' '' All right, I won't especially as everyone knows those horrors.''

And we should all go to see them if it were accepted as the correct thing, like the opera,'' chimed in Princess Myakaya.

'' Chapter 7 Steps were heard at the door, and Princess Betsy, knowing it was Madame Karenina, glanced at Vronsky. He (ambassador) was looking towards the door, and his (ambassador) face wore a strange new expression.

Joyfully, intently, and at the same time timidly, he (ambassador) gazed at the approaching figure, and slowly he (ambassador) rose to his (ambassador) feet.

Holding herself extremely erect, as always, looking straight before her (Betsy), and moving with her (Betsy) swift, resolute, and light step, that distinguished her (Betsy) from all other society women, she (Betsy) crossed the short space to her (Betsy) hostess, shook hands with her (Betsy), smiled, and with the same smile looked around at Vronsky.

Anna walked into the drawing room. Vronsky bowed low and pushed a chair up for her (Anna). She (Anna) acknowledged this only by a slight nod, flushed a little, and frowned.

But immediately, while rapidly greeting her (Anna) acquaintances, and shaking the hands proffered to her (Anna), she (Anna) addressed Princess Betsy:

``I have been at Countess Lidia's, and meant to have come here earlier, but I stayed on.

Sir John was there. He (John)'s very interesting.'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)

'' Oh, that's this missionary?'' '' Yes; he (John) told us about the life in India, most interesting things.

'' The conversation, interrupted by her (Betsy) coming in, flickered up again like the light of a lamp being blown out. ''

Sir John! Yes, Sir John; I've seen him (John). He (John) speaks well. The Vlassieva girl's quite in love with him (John). '' ''

And is it true the younger Vlassieva girl's to marry Topov?''

``Yes, they say it's quite a settled thing. '' (unknown)
``I wonder at the parents!

They say it's a marriage for love.'' (unknown)

``For love? What antediluvian notions you have! Can one talk of love in these days?'' (the ambassador)
said the ambassador's wife.

'' What's to be done? It's a foolish old fashion that's kept up still,'' said Vronsky. '' So much the worse for those who keep up the fashion.

Yes, but then how often the happiness of these prudent marriages flies away like dust just because that passion turns up that they have refused to recognize,'' said Vronsky.

The only happy marriages I know are marriages of prudence.'' '' '' But by marriages of prudence we mean those in which both parties have sown their wild oats already.

That's like scarlatina--one has to go through it and get it over.''

``Then they ought to find out how to vaccinate for love, like smallpox.

'' (unknown)

``I was in love in my young days with a deacon,'' (Princess)
said the Princess Myakaya. '' I don't know that it did me any good.''

'' No; I imagine, joking apart, that to know love, one must make mistakes and then correct them,'' said Princess Betsy.

'' Even after marriage?'' said the ambassador's wife playfully. '' `It's never too late to mend.' '' The attach√© repeated the English proverb.

she (wife) turned to Anna, who, with a faintly perceptible resolute smile on her (wife) lips, was listening in silence to the conversation.

I think,'' said Anna, playing with the glove she (Anna) had taken off,

``I think...of so many men, so many minds, certainly so many hearts, so many kinds of love.

'' (she)

Just so,'' Betsy agreed;
``one must make mistakes and correct them. What do you think about it? '' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
'' ''

Vronsky was gazing at Anna, and with a fainting heart waiting for what she (Anna) would say. He (it) sighed as after a danger escaped when she (Anna) uttered these words.

Anna suddenly turned to him (it). '' Oh, I have had a letter from Moscow. They write me that Kitty Shtcherbatskaya's very ill.''

``Really?'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
said Vronsky, knitting his (Vronsky) brows. Anna looked sternly at him (Vronsky). '' That doesn't interest you?''
``On the contrary, it does, very much.

What was it exactly they told you, if I may know? '' (he)

he (Vronsky) questioned. Anna got up and went to Betsy.

'' Give me a cup of tea,'' she (Anna) said, standing at her (Anna) table. While Betsy was pouring out the tea, Vronsky went up to Anna.

I often think men have no understanding of what's not honorable though they're always talking of it,'' said Anna, without answering him (Vronsky).

I've wanted to tell you so a long while,'' she (Anna) added, and moving a few steps away, she (Anna) sat down at a table in a corner covered with albums.

'' What is it they write to you? '' he (Vronsky) repeated. '' '' '' I don't quite understand the meaning of your words,'' he (Vronsky) said, handing her (Anna) the cup.

She (Anna) glanced towards the sofa beside her (Anna), and he (Vronsky) instantly sat down. '' Yes, I have been wanting to tell you,'' she (Anna) said, not looking at him (Vronsky).

'' You behaved wrongly, very wrongly.''

``Do you suppose I don't know that I've acted wrongly? But who was the cause of my doing so?

'' (me)

'' What do you say that to me for? '' she (Anna) said, glancing severely at him (Vronsky). '' You know what for,'' he (Vronsky) answered boldly and joyfully, meeting her (Anna) glance and not dropping his (Vronsky) eyes.

Not he (Vronsky), but she (Anna), was confused. '' That only shows you have no heart,'' she (Anna) said. But her (Anna) eyes said that she (Anna) knew he (Vronsky) had a heart, and that was why she (Anna) was afraid of him (Vronsky).

'' What you spoke of just now was a mistake, and not love.''

``Remember that I have forbidden you to utter that word, that hateful word,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, with a shudder.

But at once she (Anna) felt that by that very word

``forbidden'' (she)
she (Anna) had shown that she (Anna) acknowledged certain rights over him (Vronsky), and by that very fact was encouraging him (Vronsky) to speak of love.

I have long meant to tell you this,'' she (Anna) went on, looking resolutely into his (Vronsky) eyes, and hot all over from the burning flush on her (Anna) cheeks.

'' '' I've come on purpose this evening, knowing I should meet you. I have come to tell you that this must end.

I have never blushed before anyone, and you force me to feel to blame for something. '' He (Vronsky) looked at her (Anna) and was struck by a new spiritual beauty in her (Anna) face.

'' What do you wish of me? '' he (Vronsky) said simply and seriously. '' I want you to go to Moscow and ask for Kitty's forgiveness,'' she (Kitty) said.

'' You don't wish that?'' he (Vronsky) said. He (Vronsky) saw she (Kitty) was saying what she (Kitty) forced herself to say, not what she (Kitty) wanted to say.

'' If you love me, as you say,'' she (Kitty) whispered,

``do so that I may be at peace. '' (she)
His (Vronsky) face grew radiant.

'' Don't you know that you're all my life to me? But I know no peace, and I can't give it to you;

all myself--and love... yes. I can't think of you and myself apart. You and I are one to me. And I see no chance before us of peace for me or for you.

I see a chance of despair, of wretchedness...or I see a chance of bliss, what bliss!... Can it be there's no chance of it?

'' he (I) murmured with his (I) lips; but she (me) heard. She (me) strained every effort of her (me) mind to say what ought to be said.

But instead of that she (me) let her (me) eyes rest on him (I), full of love, and made no answer. '' It's come!

'' he (I) thought in ecstasy. '' When I was beginning to despair, and it seemed there would be no end--it's come!

``Then do this for me: never say such things to me, and let us be friends,'' (she)
she (me) said in words; but her (me) eyes spoke quite differently.

She (me) loves me! She (me) owns it!'' '' Friends we shall never be, you know that yourself. Whether we shall be the happiest or the wretchedest of people--that's in your hands.

'' She (me) would have said something, but he (I) interrupted her (me). '' I ask one thing only: I ask for the right to hope, to suffer as I do.

But if even that cannot be, command me to disappear, and I disappear. You shall not see me if my presence is distasteful to you.''

``I don't want to drive you away. '' (unknown)
``Only don't change anything, leave everything as it is,'' (he)
he (I) said in a shaky voice.

'' Here's your husband. '' At that instant Alexey Alexandrovitch did in fact walk into the room with his (Alexandrovitch) calm, awkward gait.

Glancing at his (Alexandrovitch) wife and Vronsky, he (Alexandrovitch) went up to the lady of the house, and sitting down for a cup of tea, began talking in his (Alexandrovitch) deliberate, always audible voice, in his (Alexandrovitch) habitual tone of banter, ridiculing someone.

'' Your Rambouillet is in full conclave,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, looking round at all the party;

``the graces and the muses. '' (the party)

But Princess Betsy could not endure that tone of his (Alexandrovitch)--

``sneering,'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
as she (Betsy) called it, using the English word, and like a skillful hostess she (hostess) at once brought him (Alexandrovitch) into a serious conversation on the subject of universal conscription.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was immediately interested in the subject, and began seriously defending the new imperial decree against Princess Betsy, who had attacked it.

Vronsky and Anna still sat at the little table. '' This is getting indecorous,'' whispered one lady, with an expressive glance at Madame Karenina, Vronsky, and her (lady) husband.

But not only those ladies, almost everyone in the room, even the Princess Myakaya and Betsy herself, looked several times in the direction of the two who had withdrawn from the general circle, as though that were a disturbing fact.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was the only person who did not once look in that direction, and was not diverted from the interesting discussion he (Alexandrovitch) had entered upon.

Noticing the disagreeable impression that was being made on everyone, Princess Betsy slipped someone else into her (Betsy) place to listen to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and went up to Anna.

'' What did I tell you?'' said Anna's friend. '' I'm always amazed at the clearness and precision of your husband's language,'' she (Anna) said.

'' The most transcendental ideas seem to be within my grasp when he (husband)'s speaking. '' '' Oh, yes! '' said Anna, radiant with a smile of happiness, and not understanding a word of what Betsy had said.

She (Betsy) crossed over to the big table and took part in the general conversation. Alexey Alexandrovitch, after staying half an hour, went up to his (Alexandrovitch) wife and suggested that they should go home together.

The fat old Tatar, Madame Karenina's coachman, was with difficulty holding one of her (wife) pair of grays, chilled with the cold and rearing at the entrance.

But she (wife) answered, not looking at him (Tatar), that she (wife) was staying to supper. Alexey Alexandrovitch made his (Alexandrovitch) bows and withdrew. A footman stood opening the carriage door.

Anna Arkadyevna, with her (Arkadyevna) quick little hand, was unfastening the lace of her (Arkadyevna) sleeve, caught in the hook of her (Arkadyevna) fur cloak, and with bent head listening to the words Vronsky murmured as he (Vronsky) escorted her (Arkadyevna) down.

You've said nothing, of course, and I ask nothing,'' he (Vronsky) was saying; ``but you know that friendship's not what I want: that there's only one happiness in life for me, that word that you dislike

``Love,'' (me)
she (Arkadyevna) repeated slowly, in an inner voice, and suddenly, at the very instant she (Arkadyevna) unhooked the lace, she (Arkadyevna) added,

and she (Arkadyevna) glanced into his (Vronsky) face.
