She (Arkadyevna) gave him (Vronsky) her (Arkadyevna) hand, and with her (Arkadyevna) rapid, springy step she (Arkadyevna) passed by the porter and vanished into the carriage.

He (porter) kissed the palm of his (porter) hand where she (Arkadyevna) had touched it, and went home, happy in the sense that he (porter) had got nearer to the attainment of his (porter) aims that evening than during the last two months.

Chapter 8 Alexey Alexandrovitch had seen nothing striking or improper in the fact that his (Alexandrovitch) wife was sitting with Vronsky at a table apart, in eager conversation with him (Alexandrovitch) about something.

But he (Alexandrovitch) noticed that to the rest of the party this appeared something striking and improper, and for that reason it seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) too to be improper.

Her (wife) glance, the touch of her (wife) hand, set him (Alexandrovitch) aflame. He (Alexandrovitch) made up his (Alexandrovitch) mind that he (Alexandrovitch) must speak of it to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

On reaching home Alexey Alexandrovitch went to his (Alexandrovitch) study, as he (Alexandrovitch) usually did, seated himself in his (Alexandrovitch) low chair, opened a book on the Papacy at the place where he (Alexandrovitch) had laid the paper-knife in it, and read till one o'clock, just as he (Alexandrovitch) usually did.

But from time to time he (Alexandrovitch) rubbed his (Alexandrovitch) high forehead and shook his (Alexandrovitch) head, as though to drive away something. At his (Alexandrovitch) usual time he (Alexandrovitch) got up and made his (Alexandrovitch) toilet for the night.

But this evening, instead of his (Alexandrovitch) usual thoughts and meditations upon official details, his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts were absorbed by his (Alexandrovitch) wife and something disagreeable connected with her (wife).

Contrary to his (Alexandrovitch) usual habit, he (Alexandrovitch) did not get into bed, but fell to walking up and down the rooms with his (Alexandrovitch) hands clasped behind his (Alexandrovitch) back.

He (Alexandrovitch) could not go to bed, feeling that it was absolutely needful for him (Alexandrovitch) first to think thoroughly over the position that had just arisen.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch had made up his (Alexandrovitch) mind that he (Alexandrovitch) must talk to his (Alexandrovitch) wife about it, it had seemed a very easy and simple matter.

But now, when he (Alexandrovitch) began to think over the question that had just presented itself, it seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) very complicated and difficult.

Anna Arkadyevna had not yet come in. With a book under his (Alexandrovitch) arm he (Alexandrovitch) went upstairs. Alexey Alexandrovitch was not jealous.

Why one ought to have confidence-- that is to say, complete conviction that his (Alexandrovitch) young wife would always love him (Alexandrovitch)--he (Alexandrovitch) did not ask himself.

But he (Alexandrovitch) had no experience of lack of confidence, because he (Alexandrovitch) had confidence in her (wife), and told himself that he (Alexandrovitch) ought to have it.

Now, though his (Alexandrovitch) conviction that jealousy was a shameful feeling and that one ought to feel confidence, had not broken down, he (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) was standing face to face with something illogical and irrational, and did not know what was to be done.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was standing face to face with life, with the possibility of his (Alexandrovitch) wife's loving someone other than himself, and this seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) very irrational and incomprehensible because it was life itself.

Jealousy according to his (Alexandrovitch) notions was an insult to one's wife, and one ought to have confidence in one's wife. All his (Alexandrovitch) life Alexey Alexandrovitch had lived and worked in official spheres, having to do with the reflection of life.

Now he (Alexandrovitch) experienced a feeling akin to that of a man who, while calmly crossing a precipice by a bridge, should suddenly discover that the bridge is broken, and that there is a chasm below.

And every time he (Alexandrovitch) had stumbled against life itself he (Alexandrovitch) had shrunk away from it. That chasm was life itself, the bridge that artificial life in which Alexey Alexandrovitch had lived.

For the first time the question presented itself to him (Alexandrovitch) of the possibility of his (Alexandrovitch) wife's loving someone else, and he (Alexandrovitch) was horrified at it.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not undress, but walked up and down with his (Alexandrovitch) regular tread over the resounding parquet of the dining room, where one lamp was burning, over the carpet of the dark drawing room, in which the light was reflected on the big new portrait of himself hanging over the sofa, and across her (wife) boudoir, where two candles burned, lighting up the portraits of her (wife) parents and woman friends, and the pretty knick-knacks of her (wife) writing table, that he (Alexandrovitch) knew so well.

At each turn in his (Alexandrovitch) walk, especially at the parquet of the lighted dining room, he (Alexandrovitch) halted and said to himself,

``Yes, this I must decide and put a stop to; I must express my view of it and my decision.

He (Alexandrovitch) walked across her (wife) boudoir to the bedroom door, and turned back again. '' (he)

And he (Alexandrovitch) turned back again. '' But express what--what decision?

'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself in the drawing room, and he (Alexandrovitch) found no reply. '' But after all,'' he (Alexandrovitch) asked himself before turning into the boudoir,

``what has occurred?

Nothing. She (wife) was talking a long while with him (Alexandrovitch). But what of that? Surely women in society can talk to whom they please.

And then, jealousy means lowering both myself and her (wife),'' (he)

he (Alexandrovitch) told himself as he (Alexandrovitch) went into her (wife) boudoir; but this dictum, which had always had such weight with him (Alexandrovitch) before, had now no weight and no meaning at all.

And from the bedroom door he (Alexandrovitch) turned back again; but as he (Alexandrovitch) entered the dark drawing room some inner voice told him (Alexandrovitch) that it was not so, and that if others noticed it that showed that there was something.

And he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself again in the dining room, ``Yes, I must decide and put a stop to it, and express my view of it...

And again he (Alexandrovitch) asked himself,

``What had occurred?'' (he)
and answered,
``Nothing,'' (he)
and recollected that jealousy was a feeling insulting to his (Alexandrovitch) wife; but again in the drawing room he (Alexandrovitch) was convinced that something had happened.

'' And again at the turn in the drawing room he (Alexandrovitch) asked himself,

``Decide how? '' (he)
His (Alexandrovitch) thoughts, like his (Alexandrovitch) body, went round a complete circle, without coming upon anything new.

There, looking at her (wife) table, with the malachite blotting case lying at the top and an unfinished letter, his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts suddenly changed.

He (Alexandrovitch) noticed this, rubbed his (Alexandrovitch) forehead, and sat down in her (wife) boudoir. He (Alexandrovitch) began to think of her (wife), of what she (wife) was thinking and feeling.

For the first time he (Alexandrovitch) pictured vividly to himself her (wife) personal life, her (wife) ideas, her (wife) desires, and the idea that she (wife) could and should have a separate life of her (wife) own seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) so alarming that he (Alexandrovitch) made haste to dispel it.

It was the chasm which he (Alexandrovitch) was afraid to peep into. To put himself in thought and feeling in another person's place was a spiritual exercise not natural to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

And the worst of it all,'' thought he (Alexandrovitch),

``is that just now, at the very moment when my great work is approaching completion'' (he)
-LRB-he (Alexandrovitch) was thinking of the project he (Alexandrovitch) was bringing forward at the time-RRB-,
``when I stand in need of all my mental peace and all my energies, just now this stupid worry should fall foul of me.

He (Alexandrovitch) looked on this spiritual exercise as a harmful and dangerous abuse of the fancy. '' (he)

But what's to be done?

I'm not one of those men who submit to uneasiness and worry without having the force of character to face them.

'' I must think it over, come to a decision, and put it out of my mind,'' he (character) said aloud. ''

The question of her (character) feelings, of what has passed and may be passing in her (character) soul, that's not my affair; that's the affair of her (character) conscience, and falls under the head of religion,'' he (character) said to himself, feeling consolation in the sense that he (character) had found to which division of regulating principles this new circumstance could be properly referred.

And so,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch said to himself,

``questions as to her (character) feelings, and so on, are questions for her (character) conscience, with which I can have nothing to do.

As the head of the family, I am a person bound in duty to guide her (character), and consequently, in part the person responsible; I am bound to point out the danger I perceive, to warn her (character), even to use my authority.

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

My duty is clearly defined. I ought to speak plainly to her (character). '' And everything that he (Alexandrovitch) would say tonight to his (Alexandrovitch) wife took clear shape in Alexey Alexandrovitch's head.

Thinking over what he (Alexandrovitch) would say, he (Alexandrovitch) somewhat regretted that he (Alexandrovitch) should have to use his (Alexandrovitch) time and mental powers for domestic consumption, with so little to show for it, but, in spite of that, the form and contents of the speech before him (Alexandrovitch) shaped itself as clearly and distinctly in his (Alexandrovitch) head as a ministerial report.

I must say and express fully the following points: first, exposition of the value to be attached to public opinion and to decorum; secondly, exposition of religious significance of marriage; thirdly, if need be, reference to the calamity possibly ensuing to our son; fourthly, reference to the unhappiness likely to result to herself.

This trick, a bad habit, the cracking of his (son) fingers, always soothed him (son), and gave precision to his (son) thoughts, so needful to him (son) at this juncture.

'' '' And, interlacing his (son) fingers, Alexey Alexandrovitch stretched them, and the joints of the fingers cracked. There was the sound of a carriage driving up to the front door.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, ready for his (Alexandrovitch) speech, stood compressing his (Alexandrovitch) crossed fingers, waiting to see if the crack would not come again.

Already, from the sound of light steps on the stairs, he (Alexandrovitch) was aware that she (Alexandrovitch) was close, and though he (Alexandrovitch) was satisfied with his (Alexandrovitch) speech, he (Alexandrovitch) felt frightened of the explanation confronting him (Alexandrovitch)...

Alexey Alexandrovitch halted in the middle of the room. A woman's step was heard mounting the stairs. One joint cracked. Chapter 9 Anna came in with hanging head, playing with the tassels of her (Anna) hood.

Her (Anna) face was brilliant and glowing; but this glow was not one of brightness; it suggested the fearful glow of a conflagration in the midst of a dark night.

On seeing her (Anna) husband, Anna raised her (Anna) head and smiled, as though she (Anna) had just waked up. '' You're not in bed?

What a wonder! '' she (Anna) said, letting fall her (Anna) hood, and without stopping, she (Anna) went on into the dressing room. ''

It's late, Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' she (Anna) said, when she (Anna) had gone through the doorway. '' Anna, it's necessary for me to have a talk with you.''

``With me? '' (she)
she (Anna) said, wonderingly. She (Anna) came out from behind the door of the dressing room, and looked at him (Alexandrovitch).

'' Why, what is it? What about? '' she (Anna) asked, sitting down. '' Well, let's talk, if it's so necessary. But it would be better to get to sleep.

'' Anna said what came to her (Anna) lips, and marveled, hearing herself, at her (Anna) own capacity for lying. How simple and natural were her (Anna) words, and how likely that she (Anna) was simply sleepy!

She (Anna) felt herself clad in an impenetrable armor of falsehood. She (Anna) felt that some unseen force had come to her (Anna) aid and was supporting her (Anna).

'' She (Anna) looked at him (Anna) so simply, so brightly, that anyone who did not know her (Anna) as her (Anna) husband knew her (Anna) could not have noticed anything unnatural, either in the sound or the sense of her (Anna) words.

But to him (husband), knowing her (Anna), knowing that whenever he (husband) went to bed five minutes later than usual, she (Anna) noticed it, and asked him (husband) the reason; to him (husband), knowing that every joy, every pleasure and pain that she (Anna) felt she (Anna) communicated to him (husband) at once; to him (husband), now to see that she (Anna) did not care to notice his (husband) state of mind, that she (Anna) did not care to say a word about herself, meant a great deal.

He (husband) saw that the inmost recesses of her (Anna) soul, that had always hitherto lain open before him (husband), were closed against him (husband).

More than that, he (husband) saw from her (Anna) tone that she (Anna) was not even perturbed at that, but as it were said straight out to him (husband):

``Yes, it's shut up, and so it must be, and will be in future.

'' (him)

Anna, I must warn you,'' he (husband) began. '' Warn me? '' she (Anna) said. '' Of what? '' Now he (husband) experienced a feeling such as a man might have, returning home and finding his (husband) own house locked up.

I want to warn you,'' he (husband) said in a low voice,

``that through thoughtlessness and lack of caution you may cause yourself to be talked about in society.

'' (he)

But perhaps the key may yet be found,'' thought Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' Your too animated conversation this evening with Count Vronsky'' -LRB-he (Alexandrovitch) enunciated the name firmly and with deliberate emphasis-RRB-
``attracted attention.

He (Alexandrovitch) talked and looked at her (husband) laughing eyes, which frightened him (Alexandrovitch) now with their impenetrable look, and, as he (Alexandrovitch) talked, he (Alexandrovitch) felt all the uselessness and idleness of his (Alexandrovitch) words.

You're always like that,'' (he)

she (husband) answered, as though completely misapprehending him (Alexandrovitch), and of all he (Alexandrovitch) had said only taking in the last phrase.

'' '' '' One time you don't like my being dull, and another time you don't like my being lively. I wasn't dull.

Does that offend you?'' Alexey Alexandrovitch shivered, and bent his (Alexandrovitch) hands to make the joints crack. '' Oh, please, don't do that

, I do so dislike it,'' she (husband) said. '' Anna, is this you?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, quietly making an effort over himself, and restraining the motion of his (Alexandrovitch) fingers.

'' But what is it all about? '' she (Anna) said, with such genuine and droll wonder. '' What do you want of me?

He (Alexandrovitch) saw that instead of doing as he (Alexandrovitch) had intended--that is to say, warning his (Alexandrovitch) wife against a mistake in the eyes of the world--he (Alexandrovitch) had unconsciously become agitated over what was the affair of her (wife) conscience, and was struggling against the barrier he (Alexandrovitch) fancied between them.

This is what I meant to say to you,'' he (Alexandrovitch) went on coldly and composedly,

``and I beg you to listen to it.

I consider jealousy, as you know, a humiliating and degrading feeling, and I shall never allow myself to be influenced by it; but there are certain rules of decorum which cannot be disregarded with impunity.

I observed it, but judging by the impression made on the company, everyone observed that your conduct and deportment were not altogether what could be desired.

'' (he)

Alexey Alexandrovitch paused, and rubbed his (Alexandrovitch) forehead and his (Alexandrovitch) eyes. '' This evening it was not ''
``I positively don't understand,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, shrugging her (Anna) shoulders--
``He (Alexandrovitch) doesn't care,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
she (Anna) thought.

But other people noticed it, and that's what upsets him (Alexandrovitch).''--

``You're not well, Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' (she)
she (Anna) added, and she (Anna) got up, and would have gone towards the door; but he (Alexandrovitch) moved forward as though he (Alexandrovitch) would stop her (Anna).

'' His (Alexandrovitch) face was ugly and forbidding, as Anna had never seen him (Alexandrovitch). She (Anna) stopped, and bending her (Anna) head back and on one side, began with her (Anna) rapid hand taking out her (Anna) hairpins.

Well, I'm listening to what's to come,'' she (Anna) said, calmly and ironically;

``and indeed I listen with interest, for I should like to understand what's the matter.

She (Anna) spoke, and marveled at the confident, calm, and natural tone in which she (Anna) was speaking, and the choice of the words she (Anna) used.

To enter into all the details of your feelings I have no right, and besides, I regard that as useless and even harmful,'' (she)

began Alexey Alexandrovitch.

Your feelings are an affair of your own conscience; but I am in duty bound to you, to myself, and to God, to point out to you your duties.

'' '' '' '' Ferreting in one's soul, one often ferrets out something that might have lain there unnoticed. Our life has been joined, not by man, but by God.

That union can only be severed by a crime, and a crime of that nature brings its own chastisement.''

``I don't understand a word.

And, oh dear! how sleepy I am, unluckily,'' (she)

she (I) said, rapidly passing her (I) hand through her (I) hair, feeling for the remaining hairpins. ''

Anna, for God's sake don't speak like that! '' he (God) said gently. '' Perhaps I am mistaken, but believe me, what I say, I say as much for myself as for you.

For an instant her (Anna) face fell, and the mocking gleam in her (Anna) eyes died away; but the word love threw her (Anna) into revolt again.

I am your husband, and I love you. '' She (Anna) thought:

``Love? Can he (husband) love? If he (husband) hadn't heard there was such a thing as love, he (husband) would never have used the word.

He (husband) doesn't even know what love is.'' (She)

``Alexey Alexandrovitch, really I don't understand,'' (she)
she (Anna) said. '' Define what it is you find...

''

``Pardon, let me say all I have to say. I love you. But I am not speaking of myself; the most important persons in this matter are our son and yourself.

It may very well be, I repeat, that my words seem to you utterly unnecessary and out of place; it may be that they are called forth by my mistaken impression.

But if you are conscious yourself of even the smallest foundation for them, then I beg you to think a little, and if your heart prompts you, to speak out to me...

In that case, I beg you to forgive me. '' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

Alexey Alexandrovitch was unconsciously saying something utterly unlike what he (Alexandrovitch) had prepared.

'' I have nothing to say. And besides,'' she (I) said hurriedly, with difficulty repressing a smile,

``it's really time to be in bed.

'' (she)

Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed, and, without saying more, went into the bedroom. When she (I) came into the bedroom, he (Alexandrovitch) was already in bed.

His (Alexandrovitch) lips were sternly compressed, and his (Alexandrovitch) eyes looked away from her (I). Anna got into her (Anna) bed, and lay expecting every minute that he (Alexandrovitch) would begin to speak to her (Anna) again.

She (Anna) both feared his (Alexandrovitch) speaking and wished for it. But he (Alexandrovitch) was silent. She (Anna) waited for a long while without moving, and had forgotten about him (Alexandrovitch).

She (Anna) thought of that other; she (Anna) pictured him (Alexandrovitch), and felt how her (Anna) heart was flooded with emotion and guilty delight at the thought of him (Alexandrovitch).

For the first instant Alexey Alexandrovitch seemed, as it were, appalled at his (Alexandrovitch) own snoring, and ceased; but after an interval of two breathings the snore sounded again, with a new tranquil rhythm.

A long while she (Anna) lay, not moving, with open eyes, whose brilliance she (Anna) almost fancied she (Anna) could herself see in the darkness.

Suddenly she (Anna) heard an even, tranquil snore. '' It's late, it's late,'' she (Anna) whispered with a smile. Chapter 10 From that time a new life began for Alexey Alexandrovitch and for his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

Nothing special happened. Anna went out into society, as she (Anna) had always done, was particularly often at Princess Betsy's, and met Vronsky everywhere.

All his (Alexandrovitch) efforts to draw her (Betsy) into open discussion she (Betsy) confronted with a barrier which he (Alexandrovitch) could not penetrate, made up of a sort of amused perplexity.

Alexey Alexandrovitch saw this, but could do nothing. Outwardly everything was the same, but their inner relations were completely changed. Alexey Alexandrovitch, a man of great power in the world of politics, felt himself helpless in this.

Every time he (Alexandrovitch) began to think about it, he (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) must try once more, that by kindness, tenderness, and persuasion there was still hope of saving her (Betsy), of bringing her (Betsy) back to herself, and every day he (Alexandrovitch) made ready to talk to her (Betsy).

But every time he (Alexandrovitch) began talking to her (Betsy), he (Alexandrovitch) felt that the spirit of evil and deceit, which had taken possession of her (Betsy), had possession of him (Alexandrovitch) too, and he (Alexandrovitch) talked to her (Betsy) in a tone quite unlike that in which he (Alexandrovitch) had meant to talk.

Like an ox with head bent, submissively he (Alexandrovitch) awaited the blow which he (Alexandrovitch) felt was lifted over him (Alexandrovitch). Involuntarily he (Alexandrovitch) talked to her (Betsy) in his (Alexandrovitch) habitual tone of jeering at anyone who should say what he (Alexandrovitch) was saying.

That which for Vronsky had been almost a whole year the one absorbing desire of his (Alexandrovitch) life, replacing all his (Alexandrovitch) old desires; that which for Anna had been an impossible, terrible, and even for that reason more entrancing dream of bliss, that desire had been fulfilled.

And in that tone it was impossible to say what needed to be said to her (Anna). Chapter 11 He (Alexandrovitch) stood before her (Anna), pale, his (Alexandrovitch) lower jaw quivering, and besought her (Anna) to be calm, not knowing how or why.

But the louder he (Alexandrovitch) spoke, the lower she (Anna) dropped her (Anna) once proud and gay, now shame-stricken head, and she (Anna) bowed down and sank from the sofa where she (Anna) was sitting, down on the floor, at his (Alexandrovitch) feet; she (Anna) would have fallen on the carpet if he (Alexandrovitch) had not held her (Anna).

'' Anna! Anna! '' he (Alexandrovitch) said with a choking voice,

``Anna, for pity's sake!... '' (he)
'' My God! Forgive me! ''

She (Anna) felt so sinful, so guilty, that nothing was left her (Anna) but to humiliate herself and beg forgiveness; and as now there was no one in her (Anna) life

she (Anna) said, sobbing, pressing his (God) hands to her (Anna) bosom. but him (God), to him (God) she (Anna) addressed her (Anna) prayer for forgiveness. Looking at him (God), she (Anna) had a physical sense of her (Anna) humiliation, and she (Anna) could say nothing more.

He (God) felt what a murderer must feel, when he (God) sees the body he (God) has robbed of life. That body, robbed by him (God) of life, was their love, the first stage of their love.

There was something awful and revolting in the memory of what had been bought at this fearful price of shame. Shame at their spiritual nakedness crushed her (Anna) and infected him (God).

But in spite of all the murderer's horror before the body of his (murderer) victim, he (murderer) must hack it to pieces, hide the body, must use what he (murderer) has gained by his (murderer) murder.

And with fury, as it were with passion, the murderer falls on the body, and drags it and hacks at it; so he (murderer) covered her (Anna) face and shoulders with kisses.

She (Anna) held his (murderer) hand, and did not stir. '' Yes, these kisses--that is what has been bought by this shame. Yes, and one hand, which will always be mine--the hand of my accomplice.

'' She (Anna) lifted up that hand and kissed it. He (accomplice) sank on his (accomplice) knees and tried to see her (Anna) face; but she (Anna) hid it, and said nothing.

At last, as though making an effort over herself, she (Anna) got up and pushed him (accomplice) away. Her (Anna) face was still as beautiful, but it was only the more pitiful for that.

'' All is over,'' she (Anna) said;

``I have nothing but you. Remember that.'' (she)
``I can never forget what is my whole life.

For one instant of this happiness...'' (she)

``Happiness!'' (she)
she (Anna) said with horror and loathing and her (Anna) horror unconsciously infected him (accomplice). '' For pity's sake, not a word, not a word more.

'' She (Anna) rose quickly and moved away from him (accomplice). '' Not a word more,'' she (Anna) repeated, and with a look of chill despair, incomprehensible to him (accomplice), she (Anna) parted from him (accomplice).

She (Anna) felt that at that moment she (Anna) could not put into words the sense of shame, of rapture, and of horror at this stepping into a new life, and she (Anna) did not want to speak of it, to vulgarize this feeling by inappropriate words.

But later too, and the next day and the third day, she (Anna) still found no words in which she (Anna) could express the complexity of her (Anna) feelings; indeed, she (Anna) could not even find thoughts in which she (Anna) could clearly think out all that was in her (Anna) soul.

But this calm for thought never came; every time the thought rose of what she (Anna) had done and what would happen to her (Anna), and what she (Anna) ought to do, a horror came over her (Anna) and she (Anna) drove those thoughts away.

She (Anna) said to herself:

``No, just now I can't think of it, later on, when I am calmer. '' (She)
'' Later, later,'' she (Anna) said--
``when I am calmer.

But in dreams, when she (Anna) had no control over her (Anna) thoughts, her (Anna) position presented itself to her (Anna) in all its hideous nakedness.

'' (she)

One dream haunted her (Anna) almost every night. She (Anna) dreamed that both were her (Anna) husbands at once, that both were lavishing caresses on her (Anna).

Alexey Alexandrovitch was weeping, kissing her (Anna) hands, and saying,

``How happy we are now! '' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
And Alexey Vronsky was there too, and he (Vronsky) too was her (Anna) husband.

And she (Anna) was marveling that it had once seemed impossible to her (Anna), was explaining to them, laughing, that this was ever so much simpler, and that now both of them were happy and contented.

In the early days after his (husband) return from Moscow, whenever Levin shuddered and grew red, remembering the disgrace of his (Levin) rejection, he (Levin) said to himself: ``This was just how I used to shudder and blush, thinking myself utterly lost, when I was plucked in physics and did not get my remove; and how I thought myself utterly ruined after I had mismanaged that affair of my sister's that was entrusted to me.

But this dream weighed on her (sister) like a nightmare, and she (sister) awoke from it in terror. Chapter 12 And yet, now that years have passed, I recall it and wonder that it could distress me so much.

It will be the same thing too with this trouble. Time will go by and I shall not mind about this either.

But three months had passed and he (I) had not left off minding about it; and it was as painful for him (I) to think of it as it had been those first days.

He (I) could not be at peace because after dreaming so long of family life, and feeling himself so ripe for it, he (I) was still not married, and was further than ever from marriage.

He (I) was painfully conscious himself, as were all about him (I), that at his (I) years it is not well for man to be alone.

He (I) remembered how before starting for Moscow he (I) had once said to his (I) cowman Nikolay, a simple-hearted peasant, whom he (I) liked talking to:

``Well, Nikolay!

I mean to get married,'' (he)

and how Nikolay had promptly answered, as of a matter on which there could be no possible doubt:
``And high time too, Konstantin Demitrievitch.

The place was taken, and whenever he (Demitrievitch) tried to imagine any of the girls he (Demitrievitch) knew in that place, he (Demitrievitch) felt that it was utterly impossible.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' But marriage had now become further off than ever. Moreover, the recollection of the rejection and the part he (Demitrievitch) had played in the affair tortured him (Demitrievitch) with shame.

However often he (Demitrievitch) told himself that he (Demitrievitch) was in no wise to blame in it, that recollection, like other humiliating reminiscences of a similar kind, made him (Demitrievitch) twinge and blush.

There had been in his (Demitrievitch) past, as in every man's, actions, recognized by him (Demitrievitch) as bad, for which his (Demitrievitch) conscience ought to have tormented him (Demitrievitch); but the memory of these evil actions was far from causing him (Demitrievitch) so much suffering as those trivial but humiliating reminiscences.

And with these memories was now ranged his (Demitrievitch) rejection and the pitiful position in which he (Demitrievitch) must have appeared to others that evening.

These wounds never healed. But time and work did their part. Bitter memories were more and more covered up by the incidents--paltry in his (Demitrievitch) eyes, but really important--of his (Demitrievitch) country life.

He (Demitrievitch) was impatiently looking forward to the news that she (Demitrievitch) was married, or just going to be married, hoping that such news would, like having a tooth out, completely cure him (Demitrievitch).

Meanwhile spring came on, beautiful and kindly, without the delays and treacheries of spring,--one of those rare springs in which plants, beasts, and man rejoice alike.

This lovely spring roused Levin still more, and strengthened him (Levin) in his (Levin) resolution of renouncing all his (Levin) past and building up his (Levin) lonely life firmly and independently.

Though many of the plans with which he (Levin) had returned to the country had not been carried out, still his (Levin) most important resolution--that of purity--had been kept by him (Levin).

He (Levin) was free from that shame, which had usually harassed him (Levin) after a fall; and he (Levin) could look everyone straight in the face.

In February he (Levin) had received a letter from Marya Nikolaevna telling him (Levin) that his (Levin) brother Nikolay's health was getting worse, but that he (Levin) would not take advice, and in consequence of this letter Levin went to Moscow to his (Levin) brother's and succeeded in persuading him (Levin) to see a doctor and to go to a watering-place abroad.

He (Levin) succeeded so well in persuading his (Levin) brother, and in lending him (Levin) money for the journey without irritating him (Levin), that he (Levin) was satisfied with himself in that matter.

In addition to his (Levin) farming, which called for special attention in spring, and in addition to reading, Levin had begun that winter a work on agriculture, the plan of which turned on taking into account the character of the laborer on the land as one of the unalterable data of the question, like the climate and the soil, and consequently deducing all the principles of scientific culture, not simply from the data of soil and climate, but from the data of soil, climate, and a certain unalterable character of the laborer.

Every week he (laborer) thought less often of Kitty. Thus, in spite of his (laborer) solitude, or in consequence of his (laborer) solitude, his (laborer) life was exceedingly full.

With her (Kitty) indeed he (laborer) not infrequently fell into discussion upon physics, the theory of agriculture, and especially philosophy; philosophy was Agafea Mihalovna's favorite subject.

Only rarely he (laborer) suffered from an unsatisfied desire to communicate his (laborer) stray ideas to someone besides Agafea Mihalovna. Spring was slow in unfolding.

For the last few weeks it had been steadily fine frosty weather. In the daytime it thawed in the sun, but at night there were even seven degrees of frost.

There was such a frozen surface on the snow that they drove the wagons anywhere off the roads. Easter came in the snow.

Then all of a sudden, on Easter Monday, a warm wind sprang up, storm clouds swooped down, and for three days and three nights the warm, driving rain fell in streams.

On Thursday the wind dropped, and a thick gray fog brooded over the land as though hiding the mysteries of the transformations that were being wrought in nature.

Behind the fog there was the flowing of water, the cracking and floating of ice, the swift rush of turbid, foaming torrents; and on the following Monday, in the evening, the fog parted, the storm clouds split up into little curling crests of cloud, the sky cleared, and the real spring had come.

In the morning the sun rose brilliant and quickly wore away the thin layer of ice that covered the water, and all the warm air was quivering with the steam that rose up from the quickened earth.

The old grass looked greener, and the young grass thrust up its tiny blades; the buds of the guelder-rose and of the currant and the sticky birch-buds were swollen with sap, and an exploring bee was humming about the golden blossoms that studded the willow.

Larks trilled unseen above the velvety green fields and the ice-covered stubble-land; peewits wailed over the low lands and marshes flooded by the pools; cranes and wild geese flew high across the sky uttering their spring calls.

The cattle, bald in patches where the new hair had not grown yet, lowed in the pastures; the bowlegged lambs frisked round their bleating mothers.

There was a merry chatter of peasant women over their linen at the pond, and the ring of axes in the yard, where the peasants were repairing ploughs and harrows.

Chapter 13 Levin put on his (Levin) big boots, and, for the first time, a cloth jacket, instead of his (Levin) fur cloak, and went out to look after his (Levin) farm, stepping over streams of water that flashed in the sunshine and dazzled his (Levin) eyes, and treading one minute on ice and the next into sticky mud.

Nimble children ran about the drying paths, covered with the prints of bare feet. The real spring had come. Spring is the time of plans and projects.

And, as he (Levin) came out into the farmyard, Levin, like a tree in spring that knows not what form will be taken by the young shoots and twigs imprisoned in its swelling buds, hardly knew what undertakings he (Levin) was going to begin upon now in the farm work that was so dear to him (Levin).

But he (Levin) felt that he (Levin) was full of the most splendid plans and projects. First of all he (Levin) went to the cattle.

The cows had been let out into their paddock, and their smooth sides were already shining with their new, sleek, spring coats; they basked in the sunshine and lowed to go to the meadow.

Levin gazed admiringly at the cows he (Levin) knew so intimately to the minutest detail of their condition, and gave orders for them to be driven out into the meadow, and the calves to be let into the paddock.

The cowherd girls, picking up their petticoats, ran splashing through the mud with bare legs, still white, not yet brown from the sun, waving brush wood in their hands, chasing the calves that frolicked in the mirth of spring.

After admiring the young ones of that year, who were particularly fine--the early calves were the size of a peasant's cow, and Pava's daughter, at three months old, was as big as a yearling-- Levin

The herdsman ran gaily to get ready for the meadow. gave orders for a trough to be brought out and for them to be fed in the paddock.

But it appeared that as the paddock had not been used during the winter, the hurdles made in the autumn for it were broken.

He (Levin) sent for the carpenter, who, according to his (Levin) orders, ought to have been at work at the thrashing machine. But it appeared that the carpenter was repairing the harrows, which ought to have been repaired before Lent.

It was annoying to come upon that everlasting slovenliness in the farm work against which he (carpenter) had been striving with all his (carpenter) might for so many years.

The hurdles, as he (carpenter) ascertained, being not wanted in winter, had been carried to the cart-horses' stable; and there broken, as they were of light construction, only meant for feeding calves.

Moreover, it was apparent also that the harrows and all the agricultural implements, which he (carpenter) had directed to be looked over and repaired in the winter, for which very purpose he (carpenter) had hired three carpenters, had not been put into repair, and the harrows were being repaired when they ought to have been harrowing the field.

The bailiff, beaming all over, like everyone that day, in a sheepskin bordered with astrachan, came out of the barn, twisting a bit of straw in his (bailiff) hands.

This was very annoying to Levin. Levin sent for his (Levin) bailiff, but immediately went off himself to look for him (Levin). ''

Why isn't the carpenter at the thrashing machine?'' '' Oh, I meant to tell you yesterday, the harrows want repairing. Here it's time they got to work in the fields.

'' '' But what were they doing in the winter, then?'' '' But what did you want the carpenter for?''

``Where are the hurdles for the calves' paddock?'' (unknown)

``I ordered them to be got ready. What would you have with those peasants!'' (the bailiff)
said the bailiff, with a wave of his (bailiff) hand.

'' It's not those peasants but this bailiff!'' said Levin, getting angry. '' Why, what do I keep you for? '' he (Levin) cried.

But, bethinking himself that this would not help matters, he (Levin) stopped short in the middle of a sentence, and merely sighed.

'' Well, what do you say? Can sowing begin? '' he (Levin) asked, after a pause. '' Behind Turkin tomorrow or the next day they might begin.''

'' And the clover?''

``I've sent Vassily and Mishka; they're sowing. Only I don't know if they'll manage to get through; it's so slushy.

That they were only sowing the clover on fifteen acres, not on all the forty-five, was still more annoying to him (Levin).

Clover, as he (Levin) knew, both from books and from his (Levin) own experience, never did well except when it was sown as early as possible, almost in the snow.

'' (unknown)

``How many acres? '' (unknown)
``About fifteen.'' (unknown)
``Why not sow all?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
cried Levin. And yet Levin could never get this done.

'' There's no one to send. What would you have with such a set of peasants? Three haven't turned up. And there's Semyon...''

'' Well, you should have taken some men from the thatching.'' '' And so I have, as it is. ''

``Where are the peasants, then?'' (unknown)

``four are shifting the oats for fear of a touch of mildew, Konstantin Dmitrievitch.
