meant that his (Levin) English seed oats were already ruined. Again they had not done as he (Levin) had ordered.

'' Why, but I told you during Lent to put in pipes,'' he (Levin) cried. '' Don't put yourself out; we shall get it all done in time.

'' Levin waved his (Levin) hand angrily, went into the granary to glance at the oats, and then to the stable. The oats were not yet spoiled.

But the peasants were carrying the oats in spades when they might simply let them slide down into the lower granary; and arranging for this to be done, and taking two workmen from there for sowing clover, Levin got over his (Levin) vexation with the bailiff.

Indeed, it was such a lovely day that one could not be angry. '' Ignat! '' he (Levin) called to the coachman, who, with his (Levin) sleeves tucked up, was washing the carriage wheels,

``saddle me...'' (the coachman)

While they were saddling his (Levin) horse, Levin again called up the bailiff, who was hanging about in sight, to make it up with him (Levin), and began talking to him (Levin) about the spring operations before them, and his (Levin) plans for the farm.

'' Which, sir?'' '' Well, let it be Kolpik. '' '' Yes, sir. '' The wagons were to begin carting manure earlier, so as to get all done before the early mowing.

And the ploughing of the further land to go on without a break so as to let it ripen lying fallow.

And the mowing to be all done by hired labor, not on half-profits. The bailiff listened attentively, and obviously made an effort to approve of his (bailiff) employer's projects.

But still he (bailiff) had that look Levin knew so well that always irritated him (Levin), a look of hopelessness and despondency. That look said:

``That's all very well, but as God wills.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Nothing mortified Levin so much as that tone. But it was the tone common to all the bailiffs he (Levin) had ever had.

They had all taken up that attitude to his (Levin) plans, and so now he (Levin) was not angered by it, but mortified, and felt all the more roused to struggle against this, as it seemed, elemental force continually ranged against him (Levin), for which he (Levin) could find no other expression than

``as God wills.

'' (he)

``If we can manage it, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' (the bailiff)
said the bailiff. '' Why ever shouldn't you manage it?''
``We positively must have another fifteen laborers.

And they don't turn up. There were some here today asking seventy roubles for the summer. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Levin was silent. Again he (Levin) was brought face to face with that opposing force.

He (Levin) knew that however much they tried, they could not hire more than forty--thirty-seven perhaps or thirty-eight-- laborers for a reasonable sum.

Some forty had been taken on, and there were no more. But still he (Levin) could not help struggling against it.

``Send to Sury, to Tchefirovka; if they don't come we must look for them.'' (I)

'' Oh, I'll send, to be sure,'' said Vassily Fedorovitch despondently. '' But there are the horses, too, they're not good for much.''

I know, of course,'' Levin added laughing, ``you always want to do with as little and as poor quality as possible; but this year I'm not going to let you have things your own way.

``We'll get some more. I'll see to everything myself.'' (unknown)
``Why, I don't think you take much rest as it is. It cheers us up to work under the master's eye...'' (I)

I'll go and have a look at them,'' he (master) said, getting on to the little bay cob, Kolpik, who was led up by the coachman.

'' So they're sowing clover behind the Birch Dale? '' You can't get across the streams, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' the coachman shouted.

And Levin rode through the slush of the farmyard to the gate and out into the open country, his (Levin) good little horse, after his (Levin) long inactivity, stepping out gallantly, snorting over the pools, and asking, as it were, for guidance.

'' All right, I'll go by the forest. '' If Levin had felt happy before in the cattle pens and farmyard, he (Levin) felt happier yet in the open country.

Swaying rhythmically with the ambling paces of his (Levin) good little cob, drinking in the warm yet fresh scent of the snow and the air, as he (Levin) rode through his (Levin) forest over the crumbling, wasted snow, still left in parts, and covered with dissolving tracks, he (Levin) rejoiced over every tree, with the moss reviving on its bark and the buds swelling on its shoots.

When he (Levin) came out of the forest, in the immense plain before him (Levin), his (Levin) grass fields stretched in an unbroken carpet of green, without one bare place or swamp, only spotted here and there in the hollows with patches of melting snow.

He (Levin) was not put out of temper even by the sight of the peasants' horses and colts trampling down his (Levin) young grass -LRB-he (Levin) told a peasant he (Levin) met to drive them out-RRB-, nor by the sarcastic and stupid reply of the peasant Ipat, whom he (peasant) met on the way, and asked,

``Well, Ipat, shall we soon be sowing?'' (he)

The further he (peasant) rode, the happier he (peasant) became, and plans for the land rose to his (peasant) mind each better than the last; to plant all his (peasant) fields with hedges along the southern borders, so that the snow should not lie under them; to divide them up into six fields of arable and three of pasture and hay; to build a cattle yard at the further end of the estate, and to dig a pond and to construct movable pens for the cattle as a means of manuring the land.

And then eight hundred acres of wheat, three hundred of potatoes, and four hundred of clover, and not one acre exhausted.

Absorbed in such dreams, carefully keeping his (peasant) horse by the hedges, so as not to trample his (peasant) young crops, he (peasant) rode up to the laborers who had been sent to sow clover.

A cart with the seed in it was standing, not at the edge, but in the middle of the crop, and the winter corn had been torn up by the wheels and trampled by the horse.

``We must get the ploughing done first, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' (unknown)
answered Ipat. Both the laborers were sitting in the hedge, probably smoking a pipe together.

The earth in the cart, with which the seed was mixed, was not crushed to powder, but crusted together or adhering in clods.

Seeing the master, the laborer, Vassily, went towards the cart, while Mishka set to work sowing. This was not as it should be, but with the laborers Levin seldom lost his (Levin) temper.

When Vassily came up, Levin told him (Levin) to lead the horse to the hedge. '' It's all right, sir, it'll spring up again,'' responded Vassily.

'' Please don't argue,'' said Levin,

``but do as you're told. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
'' Yes, sir,'' answered Vassily, and he (Levin) took the horse's head.

'' What a sowing, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' he (Dmitrievitch) said, hesitating;

``first rate. Only it's a work to get about! You drag a ton of earth on your shoes.'' (he)

``Why is it you have earth that's not sifted?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin. '' Well, we crumble it up,'' answered Vassily, taking up some seed and rolling the earth in his (Levin) palms.

Levin had more than once already tried a way he (Levin) knew for stifling his (Levin) anger, and turning all that seemed dark right again, and he (Levin) tried that way now.

He (Levin) watched how Mishka strode along, swinging the huge clods of earth that clung to each foot; and getting off his (Levin) horse, he (Levin) took the sieve from Vassily and started sowing himself.

Vassily was not to blame for their having filled up his (Levin) cart with unsifted earth, but still it was annoying. ''

Vassily pointed to the mark with his (Levin) foot, and Levin went forward as best he (Levin) could, scattering the seed on the land.

Walking was as difficult as on a bog, and by the time Levin had ended the row he (Levin) was in a great heat, and he (Levin) stopped and gave up the sieve to Vassily.

Where did you stop?'' '' Well, master, when summer's here, mind you don't scold me for these rows,'' said Vassily. ''

Eh?'' said Levin cheerily, already feeling the effect of his (Levin) method. '' Why, you'll see in the summer time. It'll look different.

Look you where I sowed last spring. How I did work at it! I do my best, Konstantin Dmitrievitch, d'ye see, as I would for my own father.

I don't like bad work myself, nor would I let another man do it. What's good for the master's good for us too.

To look out yonder now,'' said Vassily, pointing,

``it does one's heart good. '' (Vassily/Vassily Fedorovitch)
'' It's a lovely spring, Vassily.''
``Why, it's a spring such as the old men don't remember the like of.

I was up home; an old man up there has sown wheat too, about an acre of it. He (man) was saying you wouldn't know it from rye.'' (unknown)

``Have you been sowing wheat long?'' (unknown)
``Why, sir, it was you taught us the year before last. You gave me two measures.

We sold about eight bushels and sowed a rood.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' Well, mind you crumble up the clods,'' said Levin, going towards his (Levin) horse,
``and keep an eye on Mishka.

And if there's a good crop you shall have half a rouble for every acre. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``Humbly thankful. We are very well content, sir, as it is.

Levin got on his (Levin) horse and rode towards the field where was last year's clover, and the one which was ploughed ready for the spring corn.

'' (unknown)

The crop of clover coming up in the stubble was magnificent. It had survived everything, and stood up vividly green through the broken stalks of last year's wheat.

The horse sank in up to the pasterns, and he (Levin) drew each hoof with a sucking sound out of the half-thawed ground.

Over the ploughland riding was utterly impossible; the horse could only keep a foothold where there was ice, and in the thawing furrows he (Levin) sank deep in at each step.

The ploughland was in splendid condition; in a couple of days it would be fit for harrowing and sowing. Everything was capital, everything was cheering.

Levin rode back across the streams, hoping the water would have gone down. And he (Levin) did in fact get across, and startled two ducks.

There must be snipe too,'' he (Levin) thought, and just as he (Levin) reached the turning homewards he (Levin) met the forest keeper, who confirmed his (Levin) theory about the snipe.

Levin went home at a trot, so as to have time to eat his (Levin) dinner and get his (Levin) gun ready for the evening.

As he (Levin) rode up to the house in the happiest frame of mind, Levin heard the bell ring at the side of the principal entrance of the house.

'' Chapter 14 '' Yes, that's someone from the railway station,'' he (Levin) thought,

``just the time to be here from the Moscow train...

Who could it be? What if it's brother Nikolay? He (Nikolay) did say: `Maybe I'll go to the waters, or maybe I'll come down to you.'

He (Nikolay) felt dismayed and vexed for the first minute, that his (Nikolay) brother Nikolay's presence should come to disturb his (Nikolay) happy mood of spring.

But he (Nikolay) felt ashamed of the feeling, and at once he (Nikolay) opened, as it were, the arms of his (Nikolay) soul, and with a softened feeling of joy and expectation, now he (Nikolay) hoped with all his (Nikolay) heart that it was his (Nikolay) brother.

He (Nikolay) pricked up his (Nikolay) horse, and riding out from behind the acacias he (Nikolay) saw a hired three-horse sledge from the railway station, and a gentleman in a fur coat.

'' (he)

It was not his (gentleman) brother. '' Oh, if it were only some nice person one could talk to a little!'' he (gentleman) thought.

'' Ah,'' cried Levin joyfully, flinging up both his (Levin) hands. '' Here's a delightful visitor! Ah, how glad I am to see you!''

he (Levin) shouted, recognizing Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' I shall find out for certain whether she (Arkadyevitch)'s married, or when she (Arkadyevitch)'s going to be married,'' he (Levin) thought.

Well, you didn't expect me, eh?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting out of the sledge, splashed with mud on the bridge of his (Levin) nose, on his (Levin) cheek, and on his (Levin) eyebrows, but radiant with health and good spirits.

And on that delicious spring day he (Levin) felt that the thought of her (Arkadyevitch) did not hurt him (Levin) at all. '' ''

I've come to see you in the first place,'' he (Levin) said, embracing and kissing him (Levin),

``to have some stand-shooting second, and to sell the forest at Ergushovo third.'' (him)

``Delightful! What a spring we're having! How ever did you get along in a sledge?'' (unknown)
``In a cart it would have been worse still, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' (the driver)
answered the driver, who knew him (Dmitrievitch).

Levin led his (Levin) friend to the room set apart for visitors, where Stepan Arkadyevitch's things were carried also--a bag, a gun in a case, a satchel for cigars.

Leaving him (Levin) there to wash and change his (Levin) clothes, Levin went off to the counting house to speak about the ploughing and clover.

'' Well, I'm very, very glad to see you,'' said Levin, with a genuine smile of childlike delight. Agafea Mihalovna, always very anxious for the credit of the house, met him (Levin) in the hall with inquiries about dinner.

'' Do just as you like, only let it be as soon as possible,'' he (Levin) said, and went to the bailiff.

When he (Levin) came back, Stepan Arkadyevitch, washed and combed, came out of his (Levin) room with a beaming smile, and they went upstairs together.

'' Well, I am glad I managed to get away to you! Now I shall understand what the mysterious business is that you are always absorbed in here.

No, really, I envy you. What a house, how nice it all is! So bright, so cheerful!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgetting that it was not always spring and fine weather like that day.

A pretty maid in an apron might be even more agreeable, perhaps; but for your severe monastic style it does very well.

Stepan Arkadyevitch told him (it) many interesting pieces of news; especially interesting to Levin was the news that his (Levin) brother, Sergey Ivanovitch, was intending to pay him (Levin) a visit in the summer.

Not one word did Stepan Arkadyevitch say in reference to Kitty and the Shtcherbatskys; he (Levin) merely gave him (Levin) greetings from his (Levin) wife.

'' And your nurse is simply charming! '' Levin was grateful to him (Levin) for his (Levin) delicacy and was very glad of his (Levin) visitor.

As always happened with him (Levin) during his (Levin) solitude, a mass of ideas and feelings had been accumulating within him (Levin), which he (Levin) could not communicate to those about him (Levin).

And now he (Levin) poured out upon Stepan Arkadyevitch his (Levin) poetic joy in the spring, and his (Levin) failures and plans for the land, and his (Levin) thoughts and criticisms on the books he (Levin) had been reading, and the idea of his (Levin) own book, the basis of which really was, though he (Levin) was unaware of it himself, a criticism of all the old books on agriculture.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, always charming, understanding everything at the slightest reference, was particularly charming on this visit, and Levin noticed in him (Levin) a special tenderness, as it were, and a new tone of respect that flattered him (Levin).

The efforts of Agafea Mihalovna and the cook, that the dinner should be particularly good, only ended in the two famished friends attacking the preliminary course, eating a great deal of bread and butter, salt goose and salted mushrooms, and in Levin's finally ordering the soup to be served without the accompaniment of little pies, with which the cook had particularly meant to impress their visitor.

But though Stepan Arkadyevitch was accustomed to very different dinners, he (cook) thought everything excellent: the herb brandy, and the bread, and the butter, and above all the salt goose and the mushrooms, and the nettle soup, and the chicken in white sauce, and the white Crimean wine--

I feel as if, coming to you, I had landed on a peaceful shore after the noise and jolting of a steamer.

And so you maintain that the laborer himself is an element to be studied and to regulate the choice of methods in agriculture.

Of course, I'm an ignorant outsider; but I should fancy theory and its application will have its influence on the laborer too.

everything was superb and delicious. '' Splendid, splendid! '' he (laborer) said, lighting a fat cigar after the roast. '' '' ''

Yes, but wait a bit. I'm not talking of political economy, I'm talking of the science of agriculture. It ought to be like the natural sciences, and to observe given phenomena and the laborer in his (laborer) economic, ethnographical...''

At that instant Agafea Mihalovna came in with jam. '' Oh, Agafea Mihalovna,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, kissing the tips of his (laborer) plump fingers,

``what salt goose, what herb brandy!...

What do you think, isn't it time to start, Kostya? '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

he (Kostya) added. Levin looked out of the window at the sun sinking behind the bare tree-tops of the forest.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, going down, carefully took the canvas cover off his (Levin) varnished gun case with his (Levin) own hands, and opening it, began to get ready his (Levin) expensive new-fashioned gun.

Kouzma, who already scented a big tip, never left Stepan Arkadyevitch's side, and put on him (Levin) both his (Levin) stockings and boots, a task which Stepan Arkadyevitch readily left him (Levin).

Kostya, give orders that if the merchant Ryabinin comes...I told him (Kostya) to come today, he (Kostya)'s to be brought in and to wait for me...''

'' Yes, it's time,'' he (Kostya) said. '' Kouzma, get ready the trap,'' and he (Kostya) ran downstairs. ''

``Why, do you mean to say you're selling the forest to Ryabinin?'' (unknown)

'' Yes. Do you know him (Kostya)?'' '' To be sure I do. I have had to do business with him (Kostya), `positively and conclusively.'

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch laughed. '' Positively and conclusively'' were the merchant's favorite words. '' Yes, it's wonderfully funny the way he (merchant) talks.

She (Kostya) knows where her (Kostya) master's going! '' he (master) added, patting Laska, who hung about Levin, whining and licking his (Levin) hands, his (Levin) boots, and his (Levin) gun.

The trap was already at the steps when they went out. '' I told them to bring the trap round; or would you rather walk?''

'' No, we'd better drive,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting into the trap. He (Levin) sat down, tucked the tiger-skin rug round him (Levin), and lighted a cigar.

'' How is it you don't smoke? A cigar is a sort of thing, not exactly a pleasure, but the crown and outward sign of pleasure.

Come, this is life! How splendid it is! This is how I should like to live!''

``Why, who prevents you?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, smiling.

'' No, you're a lucky man! You've got everything you like. You like horses--and you have them ; dogs--you have them; shooting-- you have it; farming--you have it.''

``Perhaps because I rejoice in what I have, and don't fret for what I haven't,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, thinking of Kitty. Stepan Arkadyevitch comprehended, looked at him (Levin), but said nothing.

Levin was grateful to Oblonsky for noticing, with his (Levin) never-failing tact, that he (Levin) dreaded conversation about the Shtcherbatskys, and so saying nothing about them.

But now Levin was longing to find out what was tormenting him (Levin) so, yet he (Levin) had not the courage to begin.

``Come, tell me how things are going with you,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, bethinking himself that it was not nice of him (Levin) to think only of himself.

You don't admit, I know, that one can be fond of new rolls when one has had one's rations of bread--to your mind

Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes sparkled merrily. '' it's a crime; but I don't count life as life without love,'' he (Levin) said, taking Levin's question his (Levin) own way.

'' What am I to do? I'm made that way. And really, one does so little harm to anyone, and gives oneself so much pleasure...

''

``What! is there something new, then?'' (anyone)
queried Levin. '' Yes, my boy, there is! There, do you see, you know the type of Ossian's women....

Women, such as one sees in dreams.... Well, these women are sometimes to be met in reality...and these women are terrible.

Woman, don't you know, is such a subject that however much you study it, it's always perfectly new.'' '' Well, then, it would be better not to study it.''

Levin listened in silence, and in spite of all the efforts he (Levin) made, he (Levin) could not in the least enter into the feelings of his (Levin) friend and understand his (Levin) sentiments and the charm of studying such women.

'' No. Some mathematician has said that enjoyment lies in the search for truth, not in the finding it. '' Chapter 15

On reaching the copse, Levin got out of the trap and led Oblonsky to a corner of a mossy, swampy glade, already quite free from snow.

He (Levin) went back himself to a double birch tree on the other side, and leaning his (Levin) gun on the fork of a dead lower branch, he (Levin) took off his (Levin) full overcoat, fastened his (Levin) belt again, and worked his (Levin) arms to see if they were free.

The place fixed on for the stand-shooting was not far above a stream in a little aspen copse. Gray old Laska, who had followed them, sat down warily opposite him (Laska) and pricked up her (Gray) ears.

The sun was setting behind a thick forest, and in the glow of sunset the birch trees, dotted about in the aspen copse, stood out clearly with their hanging twigs, and their buds swollen almost to bursting.

From the thickest parts of the copse, where the snow still remained, came the faint sound of narrow winding threads of water running away.

In the pauses of complete stillness there came the rustle of last year's leaves, stirred by the thawing of the earth and the growth of the grass.

Tiny birds twittered, and now and then fluttered from tree to tree. '' Imagine! One can hear and see the grass growing!''

He (One) stood, listened, and gazed sometimes down at the wet mossy ground, sometimes at Laska listening all alert, sometimes at the sea of bare tree tops that stretched on the slope below him (Laska), sometimes at the darkening sky, covered with white streaks of cloud.

A hawk flew high over a forest far away with slow sweep of its wings; another flew with exactly the same motion in the same direction and vanished.

Levin said to himself, noticing a wet, slate-colored aspen leaf moving beside a blade of young grass. The birds twittered more and more loudly and busily in the thicket.

An owl hooted not far off, and Laska, starting, stepped cautiously a few steps forward, and putting her (its) head on one side, began to listen intently.

Beyond the stream was heard the cuckoo. Twice she (its) uttered her (its) usual cuckoo call, and then gave a hoarse, hurried call and broke down.

'' Imagine! the cuckoo already!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, coming out from behind a bush. '' Yes, I hear it,'' answered Levin, reluctantly breaking the stillness with his (Levin) voice, which sounded disagreeable to himself.

Stepan Arkadyevitch's figure again went behind the bush, and Levin saw nothing but the bright flash of a match, followed by the red glow and blue smoke of a cigarette.

'' Now it's coming!'' '' Tchk! tchk! '' came the snapping sound of Stepan Arkadyevitch cocking his (Levin) gun. '' What's that cry?

'' asked Oblonsky, drawing Levin's attention to a prolonged cry, as though a colt were whinnying in a high voice, in play.

'' Oh, don't you know it? That's the hare. But enough talking! Listen, it's flying! '' almost shrieked Levin, cocking his (Levin) gun.

They heard a shrill whistle in the distance, and in the exact time, so well known to the sportsman, two seconds later-- another, a third, and after the third whistle the hoarse, guttural cry could be heard.

Levin looked about him (Levin) to right and to left, and there, just facing him (Levin) against the dusky blue sky above the confused mass of tender shoots of the aspens, he (Levin) saw the flying bird.

It was flying straight towards him (Levin); the guttural cry, like the even tearing of some strong stuff, sounded close to his (Levin) ear; the long beak and neck of the bird could be seen, and at the very instant when Levin was taking aim, behind the bush where Oblonsky stood, there was a flash of red lightning: the bird dropped like an arrow, and darted upwards again.

Again came the red flash and the sound of a blow, and fluttering its wings as though trying to keep up in the air, the bird halted, stopped still an instant, and fell with a heavy splash on the slushy ground.

Here it is!'' said Levin, pointing to Laska, who with one ear raised, wagging the end of her (Levin) shaggy tail, came slowly back as though she (Levin) would prolong the pleasure, and as it were smiling, brought the dead bird to her (Levin) master.

Well, I'm glad you were successful,'' said Levin, who, at the same time, had a sense of envy that he (Levin) had not succeeded in shooting the snipe.

'' Can I have missed it?'' shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch, who could not see for the smoke. '' '' '' It was a bad shot from the right barrel,'' responded Stepan Arkadyevitch, loading his (Levin) gun.

Two snipe, playing and chasing one another, and only whistling, not crying, flew straight at the very heads of the sportsmen.

There was the report of four shots, and like swallows the snipe turned swift somersaults in the air and vanished from sight.

'' Sh...it's flying! '' The shrill whistles rapidly following one another were heard again. The stand-shooting was capital. Stepan Arkadyevitch shot two more birds and Levin two, of which one was not found.

Venus, bright and silvery, shone with her (Venus) soft light low down in the west behind the birch trees, and high up in the east twinkled the red lights of Arcturus.

It began to get dark. Over his (Levin) head Levin made out the stars of the Great Bear and lost them again.

The snipe had ceased flying; but Levin resolved to stay a little longer, till Venus, which he (Levin) saw below a branch of birch, should be above it, and the stars of the Great Bear should be perfectly plain.

Venus had risen above the branch, and the ear of the Great Bear with its shaft was now all plainly visible against the dark blue sky, yet still he (Great) waited.

'' Isn't it time to go home?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. It was quite still now in the copse, and not a bird was stirring.

``Let's stay a little while,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
answered Levin. '' As you like. '' They were standing now about fifteen paces from one another.

'' said Levin unexpectedly; ``how is it you don't tell me whether your sister-in-law's married yet, or when she (sister-in-law)'s going to be?

``Stiva! '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin felt so resolute and serene that no answer, he (Levin) fancied, could affect him (Levin). But he (Levin) had never dreamed of what Stepan Arkadyevitch replied.

She (sister-in-law)'s never thought of being married, and isn't thinking of it; but she (sister-in-law)'s very ill, and the doctors have sent her (sister-in-law) abroad.

'' They're positively afraid she (sister-in-law) may not live. ''

``What!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
cried Levin. '' Very ill? What is wrong with her (sister-in-law)? How has she (sister-in-law)...?

'' While they were saying this, Laska, with ears pricked up, was looking upwards at the sky, and reproachfully at them.

'' They have chosen a time to talk,'' she (sister-in-law) was thinking. '' It's on the wing.... Here it is, yes, it is.

But at that very instant both suddenly heard a shrill whistle which, as it were, smote on their ears, and both suddenly seized their guns and two flashes gleamed, and two gangs sounded at the very same instant.

They'll miss it,'' thought Laska. The snipe flying high above instantly folded its wings and fell into a thicket, bending down the delicate shoots.

'' Splendid! Together! '' cried Levin, and he (Levin) ran with Laska into the thicket to look for the snipe. '' Oh, yes, what was it that was unpleasant?

'' he (Levin) wondered. '' Yes, Kitty's ill.... Well, it can't be helped; I'm very sorry,'' he (Levin) thought. '' She (Kitty)'s found it!

Isn't she (Kitty) a clever thing? '' he (Levin) said, taking the warm bird from Laska's mouth and packing it into the almost full game bag.

On the way home Levin asked all details of Kitty's illness and the Shtcherbatskys' plans, and though he (Levin) would have been ashamed to admit it, he (Levin) was pleased at what he (Levin) heard.

He (Levin) was pleased that there was still hope, and still more pleased that she (Kitty) should be suffering who had made him (Levin) suffer so much.

But when Stepan Arkadyevitch began to speak of the causes of Kitty's illness, and mentioned Vronsky's name, Levin cut him (Levin) short.

'' I've got it, Stiva! '' he (Levin) shouted. Chapter 16 '' I have no right whatever to know family matters, and, to tell the truth, no interest in them either.

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled hardly perceptibly, catching the instantaneous change he (Levin) knew so well in Levin's face, which had become as gloomy as it had been bright a minute before.

'' '' Have you quite settled about the forest with Ryabinin? '' asked Levin. '' Yes, it's settled. The price is magnificent; thirty-eight thousand.

Eight straight away, and the rest in six years. I've been bothering about it for ever so long. No one would give more.''

How do you mean for nothing?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch with a good-humored smile, knowing that nothing would be right in Levin's eyes now.

'' Then you've as good as given away your forest for nothing,'' said Levin gloomily. '' '' Because the forest is worth at least a hundred and fifty roubles the acre,'' answered Levin.

'' Oh, these farmers!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch playfully. '' Your tone of contempt for us poor townsfolk!... But when it comes to business, we do it better than anyone.

I assure you I have reckoned it all out,'' he (Levin) said,

``and the forest is fetching a very good price--so much so that I'm afraid of this fellow's crying off, in fact.

You know it's not `timber,''' (he)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, hoping by this distinction to convince Levin completely of the unfairness of his (Levin) doubts.

And it won't run to more than twenty-five yards of fagots per acre, and he (Levin)'s giving me at the rate of seventy roubles the acre.

I know,'' he (Levin) thought,

``that fashion not only in him (Levin), but in all city people, who, after being twice in ten years in the country, pick up two or three phrases and use them in season and out of season, firmly persuaded that they know all about it. '

'' (he)

'' Levin smiled contemptuously. '' Timber, run to so many yards the acre. ' He (Levin) says those words without understanding them himself.''

``I wouldn't attempt to teach you what you write about in your office,'' (he)
said he (Levin),
``and if need arose, I should come to you to ask about it.

But you're so positive you know all the lore of the forest. It's difficult. Have you counted the trees?'' (he)

``How count the trees?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing, still trying to draw his (Levin) friend out of his (Levin) ill-temper.

'' Count the sands of the sea, number the stars. Some higher power might do it.'' '' Oh, well, the higher power of Ryabinin can.

Not a single merchant ever buys a forest without counting the trees, unless they get it given them for nothing, as you're doing now.

I go there every year shooting, and your forest's worth a hundred and fifty roubles an acre paid down, while he (merchant)'s giving you sixty by installments.

I know your forest. So that in fact you're making him (merchant) a present of thirty thousand.''

``Come, don't let your imagination run away with you,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch piteously.

'' Why was it none would give it, then?''

``Why, because he (merchant) has an understanding with the merchants; he (merchant)'s bought them off.

He (merchant) wouldn't look at a bargain that gave him (merchant) ten, fifteen per cent profit, but holds back to buy a rouble's worth for twenty kopecks.

I've had to do with all of them; I know them. They're not merchants, you know: they're speculators. '' (unknown)

'' Well, enough of it!

At the steps there stood a trap tightly covered with iron and leather, with a sleek horse tightly harnessed with broad collar-straps.

You're out of temper.''

``Not the least,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin gloomily, as they drove up to the house. In the trap sat the chubby, tightly belted clerk who served Ryabinin as coachman.

Ryabinin himself was already in the house, and met the friends in the hall. Ryabinin was a tall, thinnish, middle-aged man, with mustache and a projecting clean-shaven chin, and prominent muddy-looking eyes.

He (man) was dressed in a long-skirted blue coat, with buttons below the waist at the back, and wore high boots wrinkled over the ankles and straight over the calf, with big galoshes drawn over them.

He (man) rubbed his (man) face with his (man) handkerchief, and wrapping round him (man) his (man) coat, which sat extremely well as it was, he (man) greeted them with a smile, holding out his (man) hand to Stepan Arkadyevitch, as though he (man) wanted to catch something.

'' So here you are,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, giving him (man) his (man) hand. '' That's capital. ''

``I did not venture to disregard your excellency's commands, though the road was extremely bad.

I positively walked the whole way, but I am here at my time. Konstantin Dmitrievitch, my respects'' (he)

; he (Dmitrievitch) turned to Levin, trying to seize his (Dmitrievitch) hand too.

But Levin, scowling, made as though he (Levin) did not notice his (Levin) hand, and took out the snipe. '' Your honors have been diverting yourselves with the chase?

What kind of bird may it be, pray? '' added Ryabinin, looking contemptuously at the snipe:

``a great delicacy, I suppose.

'' (Ryabinin)

And he (Levin) shook his (Levin) head disapprovingly, as though he (Levin) had grave doubts whether this game were worth the candle. ''

Would you like to go into my study?'' Levin said in French to Stepan Arkadyevitch, scowling morosely.

``Go into my study; you can talk there.

'' (unknown)

``Quite so, where you please,'' (Ryabinin)
said Ryabinin with contemptuous dignity, as though wishing to make it felt that others might be in difficulties as to how to behave, but that he (Levin) could never be in any difficulty about anything.

On entering the study Ryabinin looked about, as his (Levin) habit was, as though seeking the holy picture, but when he (Levin) had found it, he (Levin) did not cross himself.

He (Levin) scanned the bookcases and bookshelves, and with the same dubious air with which he (Levin) had regarded the snipe, he (Levin) smiled contemptuously and shook his (Levin) head disapprovingly, as though by no means willing to allow that this game were worth the candle.

'' Well, have you brought the money? '' asked Oblonsky.

``Sit down.'' (unknown)
``Oh, don't trouble about the money. I've come to see you to talk it over.

``I don't mind if I do,'' (Ryabinin)
said Ryabinin, sitting down and leaning his (Levin) elbows on the back of his (Levin) chair in a position of the intensest discomfort to himself.

'' '' What is there to talk over? But do sit down. '' '' You must knock it down a bit, prince.

It would be too bad. The money is ready conclusively to the last farthing. As to paying the money down, there'll be no hitch there.

Levin, who had meanwhile been putting his (Levin) gun away in the cupboard, was just going out of the door, but catching the merchant's words, he (merchant) stopped.

'' '' Why, you've got the forest for nothing as it is,'' he (merchant) said. '' He (merchant) came to me too late, or I'd have fixed the price for him (merchant).

Very close about money is Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' he (Dmitrievitch) said with a smile, turning to Stepan Arkadyevitch;

``there's positively no dealing with him (Dmitrievitch).

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Ryabinin got up, and in silence, with a smile, he (Dmitrievitch) looked Levin down and up. '' I was bargaining for some wheat of him (Levin), and a pretty price I offered too.

''

``Why should I give you my goods for nothing? I didn't pick it up on the ground, nor steal it either.'' (unknown)

``Mercy on us! nowadays there's no chance at all of stealing. With the open courts and everything done in style, nowadays there's no question of stealing.

We are just talking things over like gentlemen. His (Levin) excellency's asking too much for the forest. I can't make both ends meet over it.

I must ask for a little concession.'' (unknown)

'' But is the thing settled between you or not? If it's settled, it's useless haggling; but if it's not,'' said Levin,
``I'll buy the forest.

With rapid, bony fingers he (Levin) unbuttoned his (Levin) coat, revealing a shirt, bronze waistcoat buttons, and a watch chain, and quickly pulled out a fat old pocketbook.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

The smile vanished at once from Ryabinin's face. A hawklike, greedy, cruel expression was left upon it. '' Here you are, the forest is mine,'' he (Levin) said, crossing himself quickly, and holding out his (Levin) hand.

'' Take the money; it's my forest. That's Ryabinin's way of doing business ; he (Levin) doesn't haggle over every half-penny,'' he (Levin) added, scowling and waving the pocketbook.

'' I wouldn't be in a hurry if I were you,'' said Levin.

``Come, really,'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)
said Oblonsky in surprise. '' I've given my word, you know.

'' Levin went out of the room, slamming the door. Ryabinin looked towards the door and shook his (Levin) head with a smile.

Why, I'm buying it, upon my honor, simply, believe me, for the glory of it, that Ryabinin, and no one else, should have bought the copse of Oblonsky.

'' It's all youthfulness--positively nothing but boyishness. And as to the profits, why, I must make what God gives. In God's name.

Within an hour the merchant, stroking his (merchant) big overcoat neatly down, and hooking up his (merchant) jacket, with the agreement in his (merchant) pocket, seated himself in his (merchant) tightly covered trap, and drove homewards.

If you would kindly sign the title-deed... '' '' Ugh, these gentlefolks! '' he (merchant) said to the clerk. '' They--they're a nice lot!''

'' That's so,'' responded the clerk, handing him (merchant) the reins and buttoning the leather apron. '' But I can congratulate you on the purchase, Mihail Ignatitch?''

Chapter 17 Stepan Arkadyevitch went upstairs with his (merchant) pocket bulging with notes, which the merchant had paid him (merchant) for three months in advance.

The business of the forest was over, the money in his (merchant) pocket; their shooting had been excellent, and Stepan Arkadyevitch was in the happiest frame of mind, and so he (merchant) felt specially anxious to dissipate the ill-humor that had come upon Levin.

Levin certainly was out of humor, and in spite of all his (Levin) desire to be affectionate and cordial to his (Levin) charming visitor, he (Levin) could not control his (Levin) mood.

'' Well, well... '' He (Levin) wanted to finish the day at supper as pleasantly as it had been begun. The intoxication of the news that Kitty was not married had gradually begun to work upon him (Levin).

Kitty was not married, but ill, and ill from love for a man who had slighted her (Kitty). This slight, as it were, rebounded upon him (man).

Vronsky had slighted her (Kitty), and she (Kitty) had slighted him (man), Levin. Consequently Vronsky had the right to despise Levin, and therefore he (Levin) was his (Levin) enemy.

He (Levin) vaguely felt that there was something in it insulting to him (Levin), and he (Levin) was not angry now at what had disturbed him (Levin), but he (Levin) fell foul of everything that presented itself.

But all this Levin did not think out. The stupid sale of the forest, the fraud practiced upon Oblonsky and concluded in his (Levin) house, exasperated him (Levin).

'' Well, finished? '' he (Levin) said, meeting Stepan Arkadyevitch upstairs. '' Would you like supper?'' '' Well, I wouldn't say no to it.

What an appetite I get in the country! Wonderful! Why didn't you offer Ryabinin something?'' '' Oh, damn him (Levin)!''

``Still, how you do treat him (Levin)!'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)
said Oblonsky.

'' You didn't even shake hands with him (Levin). Why not shake hands with him (Levin)? '' '' Because I don't shake hands with a waiter, and a waiter's a hundred times better than he (waiter) is.

'' '' What a reactionist you are, really! What about the amalgamation of classes?'' said Oblonsky. '' Anyone who likes amalgamating is welcome to it, but it sickens me.''

'' You're a regular reactionist, I see. ''

``Really, I have never considered what I am. I am Konstantin Levin, and nothing else.'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)

'' And Konstantin Levin very much out of temper,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling. '' Yes, I am out of temper, and do you know why?

Because--excuse me--of your stupid sale... '' Stepan Arkadyevitch frowned good-humoredly, like one who feels himself teased and attacked for no fault of his (Levin) own.

``Come, enough about it! '' (he)
he (Levin) said. '' When did anybody ever sell anything without being told immediately after the sale, `It was worth much more'?

But when one wants to sell, no one will give anything.... No, I see you've a grudge against that unlucky Ryabinin.''

You'll say again that I'm a reactionist, or some other terrible word; but all the same it does annoy and anger me to see on all sides the impoverishing of the nobility to which I belong, and, in spite of the amalgamation of classes, I'm glad to belong.

'' Maybe I have. And do you know why? And their impoverishment is not due to extravagance--that would be nothing; living in good style

--that's the proper thing for noblemen; it's only the nobles who know how to do it. Now the peasants about us buy land, and I don't mind that.

The gentleman does nothing, while the peasant works and supplants the idle man. That's as it ought to be. And I'm very glad for the peasant.

But I do mind seeing the process of impoverishment from a sort of --I don't know what to call it-- innocence.

And there a merchant will get three acres of land, worth ten roubles, as security for the loan of one rouble.

Here a Polish speculator bought for half its value a magnificent estate from a young lady who lives in Nice. Here, for no kind of reason, you've made that rascal a present of thirty thousand roubles.

'' '' Well, what should I have done? Counted every tree?''

``Of course, they must be counted. You didn't count them, but Ryabinin did.

Ryabinin's children will have means of livelihood and education, while yours maybe will not!'' (me)

'' Well, you must excuse me, but there's something mean in this counting.

We have our business and they have theirs, and they must make their profit. Anyway, the thing's done, and there's an end of it.

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch sat down at the table and began joking with Agafea Mihalovna, assuring her (their) that it was long since he (You) had tasted such a dinner and such a supper.

And here come some poached eggs, my favorite dish. And Agafea Mihalovna will give us that marvelous herb-brandy... '' Well, you do praise it, anyway,'' said Agafea Mihalovna,

``but Konstantin Dmitrievitch, give him (Dmitrievitch) what you will--a crust of bread--

He (Dmitrievitch) wanted to put one question to Stepan Arkadyevitch, but he (Dmitrievitch) could not bring himself to the point, and could not find the words or the moment in which to put it.

Stepan Arkadyevitch had gone down to his (Dmitrievitch) room, undressed, again washed, and attired in a nightshirt with goffered frills, he (Dmitrievitch) had got into bed, but Levin still lingered in his (Levin) room, talking of various trifling matters, and not daring to ask what he (Levin) wanted to know.

How wonderfully they make this soap,'' (Agafea Mihalovna)

he (Levin) said gazing at a piece of soap he (Levin) was handling, which Agafea Mihalovna had put ready for the visitor but Oblonsky had not used.

he (Levin)'ll eat it and walk away. '' Though Levin tried to control himself, he (Levin) was gloomy and silent. '' '' Only look; why, it's a work of art.''

``Yes, everything's brought to such a pitch of perfection nowadays,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, with a moist and blissful yawn. '' The theater, for instance, and the entertainments... a--a--a!

'' he (Levin) yawned. '' The electric light everywhere...a--a--a!'' '' Yes, the electric light,'' said Levin. '' Yes. Oh, and where's Vronsky now?

'' he (Levin) asked suddenly, laying down the soap.

``Vronsky? '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, checking his (Levin) yawn;
``he (Levin)'s in Petersburg. He (Levin) left soon after you did, and he (Levin)'s not once been in Moscow since.

And do you know, Kostya, I'll tell you the truth,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

he (Kostya) went on, leaning his (Kostya) elbow on the table, and propping on his (Kostya) hand his (Kostya) handsome ruddy face, in which his (Kostya) moist, good-natured, sleepy eyes shone like stars.

'' It's your own fault. You took fright at the sight of your rival. But, as I told you at the time, I couldn't say which had the better chance.

Why didn't you fight it out? I told you at the time that...'' He (Kostya) yawned inwardly, without opening his (Kostya) mouth. ''

Yes, there's something humbugging, diplomatic in his (Kostya) face,'' and feeling he (Kostya) was blushing, he (Kostya) looked Stepan Arkadyevitch straight in the face without speaking.

Does he (Kostya) know, or doesn't he (Kostya), that I did make an offer?'' Levin wondered, gazing at him (Levin). '' '' If there was anything on her (Kostya) side at the time, it was nothing but a superficial attraction,'' pursued Oblonsky.

His (Levin) being such a perfect aristocrat, don't you know, and his (Levin) future position in society, had an influence not with her (Kostya), but with her (Kostya) mother.

The humiliation of his (Levin) rejection stung him (Levin) to the heart, as though it were a fresh wound he (Levin) had only just received.

'' '' Levin scowled. But he (Levin) was at home, and the walls of home are a support. '' Stay, stay,'' he (Levin) began, interrupting Oblonsky.

But allow me to ask what it consists in, that aristocracy of Vronsky or of anybody else, beside which I can be looked down upon?

A man whose father crawled up from nothing at all by intrigue, and whose mother--God knows whom she (mother) wasn't mixed up with....

No, excuse me, but I consider myself aristocratic, and people like me, who can point back in the past to three or four honorable generations of their family, of the highest degree of breeding -LRB-talent and intellect, of course that's another matter-RRB-, and have never curried favor with anyone, never depended on anyone for anything, like my father and my grandfather.

'' You talk of his (grandfather) being an aristocrat. You consider Vronsky an aristocrat, but I don't. And I know many such.

You think it mean of me to count the trees in my forest, while you make Ryabinin a present of thirty thousand; but you get rents from your lands and I don't know what, while I don't

We are aristocrats, and not those who can only exist by favor of the powerful of this world, and who can be bought for twopence halfpenny.

and so I prize what's come to me from my ancestors or been won by hard work... '' '' Well, but whom are you attacking?

I agree with you,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, sincerely and genially; though he (your) was aware that in the class of those who could be bought for

twopence halfpenny Levin was reckoning him (Levin) too. Levin's warmth gave him (Levin) genuine pleasure. '' Whom are you attacking? Though a good deal is not true that you say about Vronsky, but I won't talk about that.

I tell you straight out, if I were you, I should go back with me to Moscow, and...'' '' No; I don't know whether you know it or not, but I don't care.

And I tell you--I did make an offer and was rejected, and Katerina Alexandrovna is nothing now to me but a painful and humiliating reminiscence.''

``What ever for? What nonsense!'' (unknown)
'' But we won't talk about it. Please forgive me, if I've been nasty,'' said Levin.

Now that he (Levin) had opened his (Levin) heart, he (Levin) became as he (Levin) had been in the morning. '' You're not angry with me, Stiva?

Please don't be angry,'' he (Levin) said, and smiling, he (Levin) took his (Levin) hand. '' Of course not; not a bit, and no reason to be.

I'm glad we've spoken openly. And do you know, stand-shooting in the morning is unusually good--why not go? I couldn't sleep the night anyway, but I might go straight from shooting to the station.

Although all Vronsky's inner life was absorbed in his (Levin) passion, his (Levin) external life unalterably and inevitably followed along the old accustomed lines of his (Levin) social and regimental ties and interests.

The interests of his (Levin) regiment took an important place in Vronsky's life, both because he (Vronsky) was fond of the regiment, and because the regiment was fond of him (Vronsky).

They were not only fond of Vronsky in his (Vronsky) regiment, they respected him (Vronsky) too, and were proud of him (Vronsky); proud that this man, with his (man) immense wealth, his (man) brilliant education and abilities, and the path open before him (man) to every kind of success, distinction, and ambition, had disregarded all that, and of all the interests of life had the interests of his (man) regiment and his (man) comrades nearest to his (man) heart.

Vronsky was aware of his (Vronsky) comrades' view of him (Vronsky), and in addition to his (Vronsky) liking for the life, he (Vronsky) felt bound to keep up that reputation.

It need not be said that he (Vronsky) did not speak of his (Vronsky) love to any of his (Vronsky) comrades, nor did he (Vronsky) betray his (Vronsky) secret even in the wildest drinking bouts -LRB-though indeed he (Vronsky) was never so drunk as to lose all control of himself-RRB-.

''

``Capital. '' (he)
Chapter 18 And he (Vronsky) shut up any of his (Vronsky) thoughtless comrades who attempted to allude to his (Vronsky) connection.

But in spite of that, his (Vronsky) love was known to all the town; everyone guessed with more or less confidence at his (Vronsky) relations with Madame Karenina.

The majority of the younger men envied him (Vronsky) for just what was the most irksome factor in his (Vronsky) love--the exalted position of Karenin, and the consequent publicity of their connection in society.

The greater number of the young women, who envied Anna and had long been weary of hearing her (Anna) called virtuous , rejoiced at the fulfillment of their predictions, and were only waiting for a decisive turn in public opinion to fall upon her (Anna) with all the weight of their scorn.

The greater number of the middle-aged people and certain great personages were displeased at the prospect of the impending scandal in society.

Vronsky's mother, on hearing of his (Karenin) connection, was at first pleased at it, because nothing to her (mother) mind gave such a finishing touch to a brilliant young man as a liaison in the highest society; she (mother) was pleased, too, that Madame Karenina, who had so taken her (mother) fancy, and had talked so much of her (mother) son, was, after all, just like all other

They were already making ready their handfuls of mud to fling at her (mother) when the right moment arrived. pretty and well-bred women,--at least according to the Countess Vronskaya's ideas.

But she (Countess) had heard of late that her (Countess) son had refused a position offered him (son) of great importance to his (son) career, simply in order to remain in the regiment, where he (son) could be constantly seeing Madame Karenina.

She (Countess) was vexed, too, that from all she (Countess) could learn of this connection it was not that brilliant, graceful, worldly liaison which she (Countess) would have welcomed, but a sort of Wertherish, desperate passion, so she (Countess) was told, which might well lead him (son) into imprudence.

She (Countess) had not seen him (son) since his (son) abrupt departure from Moscow, and she (Countess) sent her (Countess) elder son to bid him (son) come to see her (Countess).

She (Countess) learned that great personages were displeased with him (son) on this account, and she (Countess) changed her (Countess) opinion. This elder son, too, was displeased with his (son) younger brother.

He (son) did not distinguish what sort of love his (son) might be, big or little, passionate or passionless, lasting or passing -LRB-he (son) kept a ballet girl himself, though he (son) was the father of a family, so he (son) was lenient in these matters-RRB-, but he (son) knew that this love affair was viewed with displeasure by those whom it was necessary to please, and therefore he (son) did not approve of his (son) brother's conduct.

Besides the service and society, Vronsky had another great interest--horses; he (Vronsky) was passionately fond of horses. That year races and a steeplechase had been arranged for the officers.

Vronsky had put his (Vronsky) name down, bought a thoroughbred English mare, and in spite of his (Vronsky) love affair, he (Vronsky) was looking forward to the races with intense, though reserved, excitement...

On the contrary, he (Vronsky) needed occupation and distraction quite apart from his (Vronsky) love, so as to recruit and rest himself from the violent emotions that agitated him (Vronsky).

On the day of the races at Krasnoe Selo, Vronsky had come earlier than usual to eat beefsteak in the common messroom of the regiment.

He (Vronsky) had no need to be strict with himself, as he (Vronsky) had very quickly been brought down to the required light weight; but still he (Vronsky) had to avoid gaining flesh, and so he (Vronsky) eschewed farinaceous and sweet dishes.

He (Vronsky) sat with his (Vronsky) coat unbuttoned over a white waistcoat, resting both elbows on the table, and while waiting for the steak he (Vronsky) had ordered he (Vronsky) looked at a French novel that lay open on his (Vronsky) plate.

These two passions did not interfere with one another. Chapter 19 He (Vronsky) was only looking at the book to avoid conversation with the officers coming in and out; he (Vronsky) was thinking.

But he (Vronsky) had not seen her (Vronsky) for three days, and as her (Vronsky) husband had just returned from abroad, he (Vronsky) did not know whether she (Vronsky) would be able to meet him (Vronsky) today or not, and he (Vronsky) did not know how to find out.

He (Vronsky) was thinking of Anna's promise to see him (Vronsky) that day after the races. He (Vronsky) had had his (Vronsky) last interview with her (Anna) at his (Vronsky) cousin Betsy's summer villa.

He (Vronsky) visited the Karenins' summer villa as rarely as possible. Now he (Vronsky) wanted to go there, and he (Vronsky) pondered the question how to do it.

'' Of course I shall say Betsy has sent me to ask whether she (Betsy)'s coming to the races. Of course, I'll go,'' he (Vronsky) decided, lifting his (Vronsky) head from the book.

``Send to my house, and tell them to have out the carriage and three horses as quick as they can,'' (he)
he (Vronsky) said to the servant, who handed him (Vronsky) the steak on a hot silver dish, and moving the dish up he (Vronsky) began eating.

And as he (Vronsky) vividly pictured the happiness of seeing her (Betsy), his (Vronsky) face lighted up. From the billiard room next door came the sound of balls knocking, of talk and laughter.

Two officers appeared at the entrance-door: one, a young fellow, with a feeble, delicate face, who had lately joined the regiment from the Corps of Pages; the other, a plump, elderly officer, with a bracelet on his (officer) wrist, and little eyes, lost in fat.

Vronsky glanced at them, frowned, and looking down at his (officer) book as though he (officer) had not noticed them, he (officer) proceeded to eat and read at the same time.

'' What? Fortifying yourself for your work? '' said the plump officer, sitting down beside him (officer). '' As you see,'' responded Vronsky, knitting his (officer) brows, wiping his (officer) mouth, and not looking at the officer.

'' So you're not afraid of getting fat? '' said the latter, turning a chair round for the young officer.

``What?'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky angrily, making a wry face of disgust, and showing his (officer) even teeth.

'' You're not afraid of getting fat?''

``Waiter, sherry!'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, without replying, and moving the book to the other side of him (Waiter), he (Waiter) went on reading.

The plump officer took up the list of wines and turned to the young officer. '' You choose what we're to drink,'' he (officer) said, handing him (officer) the card, and looking at him (officer).

Rhine wine, please,'' said the young officer, stealing a timid glance at Vronsky, and trying to pull his (officer) scarcely visible mustache.

'' Seeing that Vronsky did not turn round, the young officer got up. '' Let's go into the billiard room,'' he (officer) said.

The plump officer rose submissively, and they moved towards the door. At that moment there walked into the room the tall and well-built Captain Yashvin.

Nodding with an air of lofty contempt to the two officers, he (Yashvin) went up to Vronsky. '' Ah! here he (Yashvin) is!

'' he (Yashvin) cried, bringing his (Yashvin) big hand down heavily on his (Yashvin) epaulet. Vronsky looked round angrily, but his (Yashvin) face lighted up immediately with his (Yashvin) characteristic expression of genial and manly serenity.

'' That's it, Alexey,'' said the captain, in his (Alexey) loud baritone. '' You must just eat a mouthful, now, and drink only one tiny glass.

'' '' Oh, I'm not hungry. '' '' There go the inseparables,'' Yashvin dropped, glancing sarcastically at the two officers who were at that instant leaving the room.

And he (Yashvin) bent his (Yashvin) long legs, swathed in tight riding breeches, and sat down in the chair, too low for him (Yashvin), so that his (Yashvin) knees were cramped up in a sharp angle.

'' Why didn't you turn up at the Red Theater yesterday? Numerova wasn't at all bad. Where were you?''

``I was late at the Tverskoys','' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky.

Yashvin, a gambler and a rake, a man not merely without moral principles, but of immoral principles, Yashvin was Vronsky's greatest friend in the regiment.

Vronsky liked him (Vronsky) both for his (Vronsky) exceptional physical strength, which he (Vronsky) showed for the most part by being able to drink like a fish, and do without sleep without being in the slightest degree affected by it; and for his (Vronsky) great strength of character, which he (Vronsky) showed in his (Vronsky) relations with his (Vronsky) comrades and superior officers, commanding both fear and respect, and also at cards, when he (Vronsky) would play for tens of thousands and however much he (Vronsky) might have drunk, always with such skill and decision that he (Vronsky) was reckoned the best player in the English Club.

Vronsky respected and liked Yashvin particularly because he (Yashvin) felt Yashvin liked him (Yashvin), not for his (Yashvin) name and his (Yashvin) money, but for himself.

'' Ah!'' responded Yashvin. And of all men he (Yashvin) was the only one with whom Vronsky would have liked to speak of his (Yashvin) love.

He (Yashvin) felt that Yashvin, in spite of his (Yashvin) apparent contempt for every sort of feeling, was the only man who could, so he (Yashvin) fancied, comprehend the intense passion which now filled his (Yashvin) whole life.

Moreover, he (Yashvin) felt certain that Yashvin, as it was, took no delight in gossip and scandal, and interpreted his (Yashvin) feeling rightly, that is to say, knew and believed that this passion was not a jest, not a pastime, but something more serious and important.

Vronsky had never spoken to him (Yashvin) of his (Yashvin) passion, but he (Yashvin) was aware that he (Yashvin) knew all about it, and that he (Yashvin) put the right interpretation on it, and he (Yashvin) was glad to see that in his (Yashvin) eyes.

yes,'' he (Yashvin) said, to the announcement that Vronsky had been at the Tverskoys'; and his (Yashvin) black eyes shining, he (Yashvin) plucked at his (Yashvin) left mustache, and began twisting it into his (Yashvin) mouth, a bad habit he (Yashvin) had.

'' Ah! '' Well, and what did you do yesterday? Win anything? '' asked Vronsky. '' Eight thousand. But three don't count; he (Yashvin) won't pay up.''

'' Oh, then you can afford to lose over me,'' said Vronsky, laughing. -LRB-Yashvin had bet heavily on Vronsky in the races.-RRB-

'' No chance of my losing. Mahotin's the only one that's risky. '' And the conversation passed to forecasts of the coming race, the only thing Vronsky could think of just now.

'' Come along, I've finished,'' said Vronsky, and getting up he (Vronsky) went to the door. Yashvin got up too, stretching his (Yashvin) long legs and his (Yashvin) long back.

'' he (Yashvin) shouted, in his (Yashvin) rich voice, that always rang out so loudly at drill, and set the windows shaking now.

'' It's too early for me to dine, but I must have a drink. I'll come along directly. Hi, wine! ''

No, all right,'' he (Yashvin) shouted again immediately after. '' You're going home, so I'll go with you. '' And he (Yashvin) walked out with Vronsky.

Chapter 20 Vronsky was staying in a roomy, clean, Finnish hut, divided into two by a partition. Petritsky lived with him (Yashvin) in camp too.

Get up, don't go on sleeping,'' said Yashvin, going behind the partition and giving Petritsky, who was lying with ruffled hair and with his (Yashvin) nose in the pillow, a prod on the shoulder.

Petritsky was asleep when Vronsky and Yashvin came into the hut. '' Petritsky jumped up suddenly onto his (Vronsky) knees and looked round.

'' Your brother's been here,'' he (Vronsky) said to Vronsky. '' He (Vronsky) waked me up, damn him (Vronsky), and said he (Vronsky)'d look in again.

'' And pulling up the rug he (Vronsky) flung himself back on the pillow. '' Oh, do shut up, Yashvin! '' he (Vronsky) said, getting furious with Yashvin, who was pulling the rug off him (Yashvin).

'' Shut up!'' He (Yashvin) turned over and opened his (Yashvin) eyes. '' You'd better tell me what to drink; such a nasty taste in my mouth, that...

'' '' Brandy's better than anything,'' boomed Yashvin. '' Tereshtchenko! brandy for your master and cucumbers,'' he (master) shouted, obviously taking pleasure in the sound of his (master) own voice.

'' Brandy, do you think? Eh? '' queried Petritsky, blinking and rubbing his (master) eyes. '' And you'll drink something? All right then, we'll have a drink together!

He (master) went to the door of the partition wall, raised his (master) hands, and hummed in French,

``There was a king in Thule.'' (French)

Vronsky, have a drink?'' said Petritsky, getting up and wrapping the tiger-skin rug round him (king).

``Vronsky, will you have a drink?'' (unknown)

``Go along,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, putting on the coat his (king) valet handed to him (king). '' Where are you off to?'' asked Yashvin.

'' Oh, here are your three horses,'' he (Yashvin) added, seeing the carriage drive up. '' To the stables, and I've got to see Bryansky, too, about the horses,'' said Vronsky.

Vronsky had as a fact promised to call at Bryansky's, some eight miles from Peterhof, and to bring him (Yashvin) some money owing for some horses; and he (Yashvin) hoped to have time to get that in too.

Petritsky, still humming, winked and made a pout with his (Yashvin) lips, as though he (Yashvin) would say:

``Oh, yes, we know your Bryansky.'' (he)

But his (Yashvin) comrades were at once aware that he (Yashvin) was not only going there. '' Mind you're not late! '' was Yashvin's only comment; and to change the conversation:

``How's my roan? is he (Yashvin) doing all right? '' (Yashvin/Prince Yashvin/Prince)
he (Yashvin) inquired, looking out of the window at the middle one of the three horses, which he (Yashvin) had sold Vronsky.

``Stop! '' (Petritsky)
