Wait a bit; where are they? '' Vronsky stopped. '' Well, where are they?''

``Where are they? That's just the question!'' (Petritsky)
said Petritsky solemnly, moving his (brother) forefinger upwards from his (brother) nose.

'' Come, tell me; this is silly!'' said Vronsky smiling. '' I have not lighted the fire. Here somewhere about. ''

``Come, enough fooling! Where is the letter?'' (I)
'' No, I've forgotten really. Or was it a dream? Wait a bit, wait a bit!

But what's the use of getting in a rage. If you'd drunk four bottles yesterday as I did you'd forget where you were lying.

Wait a bit, I'll remember! '' Petritsky went behind the partition and lay down on his (you) bed. '' Wait a bit!

This was how I was lying, and this was how he (you) was standing. Yes--yes--yes.... Here it is!''--and Petritsky pulled a letter out from under the mattress, where he (you) had hidden it.

It was the letter he (you) was expecting--from his (you) mother, reproaching him (you) for not having been to see her (mother)--and the note was from his (you) brother to say that he (you) must have a little talk with him (you).

Vronsky took the letter and his (Vronsky) brother's note. Vronsky knew that it was all about the same thing. '' What business is it of theirs!

'' thought Vronsky, and crumpling up the letters he (Vronsky) thrust them between the buttons of his (Vronsky) coat so as to read them carefully on the road.

In the porch of the hut he (Vronsky) was met by two officers; one of his (Vronsky) regiment and one of another. Vronsky's quarters were always a meeting place for all the officers.

'' Where are you off to?''

``I must go to Peterhof. '' (unknown)
``Has the mare come from Tsarskoe?'' (I)
'' Yes, but I've not seen her (mare) yet.

'' '' They say Mahotin's Gladiator's lame. ''

``Nonsense! But however are you going to race in this mud?'' (unknown)
said the other.

'' Here are my saviors!'' cried Petritsky, seeing them come in. Before him (Vronsky) stood the orderly with a tray of brandy and salted cucumbers.

Well, you did give it to us yesterday,'' said one of those who had come in;

``you didn't let us get a wink of sleep all night.

'' (me)

Here's Yashvin ordering me to drink a pick-me-up.'' '' '' '' Oh, didn't we make a pretty finish!'' said Petritsky.

'' Volkov climbed onto the roof and began telling us how sad he (Vronsky) was. I said: `Let's have music, the funeral march!'

``Drink it up; you positively must drink the brandy, and then seltzer water and a lot of lemon,'' (Yashvin/Prince Yashvin/Prince)
said Yashvin, standing over Petritsky like a mother making a child take medicine,
``and then a little champagne--just a small bottle.'' (a child)

He (Yashvin) fairly dropped asleep on the roof over the funeral march.''

``Come, there's some sense in that. Stop a bit, Vronsky.

We'll all have a drink.'' (unknown)

'' No; good-bye all of you. I'm not going to drink today. ''
``Why, are you gaining weight?

All right, then we must have it alone. Give us the seltzer water and lemon.'' (unknown)

``Vronsky!'' (someone)
shouted someone when he (Yashvin) was already outside.

'' Well?'' '' You'd better get your hair cut, it'll weigh you down, especially at the top. '' Vronsky was in fact beginning, prematurely, to get a little bald.

He (Yashvin) laughed gaily, showing his (Yashvin) even teeth, and pulling his (Yashvin) cap over the thin place, went out and got into his (Yashvin) carriage.

he (Yashvin) said, and was just pulling out the letters to read them through, but he (Yashvin) thought better of it, and put off reading them so as not to distract his (Yashvin) attention before looking at the mare.

The temporary stable, a wooden shed, had been put up close to the race course, and there his (Yashvin) mare was to have been taken the previous day.

During the last few days he (Yashvin) had not ridden her (mare) out for exercise himself, but had put her (mare) in the charge of the trainer, and so now he (trainer) positively did not know in what condition his (trainer) mare had arrived yesterday and was today.

He (trainer) had scarcely got out of his (trainer) carriage when his (trainer) groom, the so-called

``stable boy,'' (groom boy)
recognizing the carriage some way off, called the trainer.

A dry-looking Englishman, in high boots and a short jacket, clean-shaven, except for a tuft below his (Englishman) chin, came to meet him (Englishman), walking with the uncouth gait of jockey, turning his (jockey) elbows out and swaying from side to side.

'' To the stables! ''

``Later!'' (He)
Chapter 21 He (jockey) had not yet seen her (mare) there. '' Well, how's Frou-Frou? '' Vronsky asked in English.

'' All right, sir,'' the Englishman's voice responded somewhere in the inside of his (Englishman) throat. '' Better not go in,'' he (Englishman) added, touching his (Englishman) hat.

'' I've put a muzzle on her (mare), and the mare's fidgety. Better not go in, it'll excite the mare.'' '' No, I'm going in.

``Come along, then,'' (Englishman)
said the Englishman, frowning, and speaking with his (Englishman) mouth shut, and, with swinging elbows, he (Englishman) went on in front with his (Englishman) disjointed gait.

A stable boy, spruce and smart in his (Englishman) holiday attire, met them with a broom in his (Englishman) hand, and followed them.

In the shed there were five horses in their separate stalls, and Vronsky knew that his (Vronsky) chief rival, Gladiator, a very tall chestnut horse, had been brought there, and must be standing among them.

I want to look at her (Englishman).'' They went into the little yard in front of the shed. Even more than his (Vronsky) mare, Vronsky longed to see Gladiator, whom he (Vronsky) had never seen.

But he (Vronsky) knew that by the etiquette of the race course it was not merely impossible for him (Vronsky) to see the horse, but improper even to ask questions about him (Vronsky).

Just as he (Vronsky) was passing along the passage, the boy opened the door into the second horse-box on the left, and Vronsky caught a glimpse of a big chestnut horse with white legs.

He (boy) knew that this was Gladiator, but, with the feeling of a man turning away from the sight of another man's open letter, he (man) turned round and went into Frou-Frou's stall.

I never can say the name,'' said the Englishman, over his (Englishman) shoulder, pointing his (Englishman) big finger and dirty nail towards Gladiator's stall.

'' The horse is here belonging to Mak... Mak... '' Mahotin? Yes, he (Mak)'s my most serious rival,'' said Vronsky. '' If you were riding him (Mak),'' said the Englishman,

``I'd bet on you.

'' (the Englishman)

``Frou-Frou's more nervous; he (Englishman)'s stronger,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, smiling at the compliment to his (Englishman) riding. '' In a steeplechase it all depends on riding and on pluck,'' said the Englishman.

Of pluck--that is, energy and courage--Vronsky did not merely feel that he (Englishman) had enough; what was of far more importance, he (Englishman) was firmly convinced that no one in the world could have more of this

``pluck'' (he)
than he (Englishman) had.

The mare's fidgety,'' he (Englishman) added, nodding towards the horse-box, before which they were standing, and from which came the sound of restless stamping in the straw.

'' Don't you think I want more thinning down?'' '' Oh, no,'' answered the Englishman. '' Please, don't speak loud. He (Englishman) opened the door, and Vronsky went into the horse-box, dimly lighted by one little window.

Looking round him (Englishman) in the twilight of the horse-box, Vronsky unconsciously took in once more in a comprehensive glance all the points of his (Englishman) favorite mare.

In the horse-box stood a dark bay mare, with a muzzle on, picking at the fresh straw with her (mare) hoofs. Frou-Frou was a beast of medium size, not altogether free from reproach, from a breeder's point of view.

Her (mare) hind-quarters were a little drooping, and in her (mare) fore-legs, and still more in her (mare) hind-legs, there was a noticeable curvature.

The muscles of both hind- and fore-legs were not very thick; but across her (mare) shoulders the mare was exceptionally broad, a peculiarity specially striking now that she (mare) was lean from training.

The bones of her (mare) legs below the knees looked no thicker than a finger from in front, but were extraordinarily thick seen from the side.

She (mare) was small-boned all over; though her (mare) chest was extremely prominent in front, it was narrow. She (mare) looked altogether, except across the shoulders, as it were, pinched in at the sides and pressed out in depth.

But she (mare) had in the highest degree the quality that makes all defects forgotten: that quality was blood , the blood that tells , as the English expression has it.

The muscles stood up sharply under the network of sinews, covered with the delicate, mobile skin, soft as satin, and they were hard as bone.

Her (mare) clean-cut head, with prominent, bright, spirited eyes, broadened out at the open nostrils, that showed the red blood in the cartilage within.

About all her (mare) figure, and especially her (mare) head, there was a certain expression of energy, and, at the same time, of softness.

She (mare) was one of those creatures which seem only not to speak because the mechanism of their mouth does not allow them to.

Directly Vronsky went towards her (mare), she (mare) drew in a deep breath, and, turning back her (mare) prominent eye till the white looked bloodshot, she (mare) started at the approaching figures from the opposite side, shaking her (mare) muzzle, and shifting lightly from one leg to the other.

To Vronsky, at any rate, it seemed that she (mare) understood all he (their) felt at that moment, looking at her (mare). '' There, you see how fidgety she (mare) is,'' said the Englishman.

'' There, darling! There!'' said Vronsky, going up to the mare and speaking soothingly to her (mare). But the nearer he (Vronsky) came, the more excited she (mare) grew.

Vronsky patted her (mare) strong neck, straightened over her (mare) sharp withers a stray lock of her (mare) mane that had fallen on the other side, and moved his (Vronsky) face near her (mare) dilated nostrils, transparent as a bat's wing.

She (mare) drew a loud breath and snorted out through her (mare) tense nostrils, started, pricked up her (mare) sharp ear, and put out her (mare) strong, black lip towards Vronsky, as though she (mare) would nip hold of his (lip) sleeve.

Only when he (lip) stood by her (mare) head, she (mare) was suddenly quieter, while the muscles quivered under her (mare) soft, delicate coat. But remembering the muzzle, she (mare) shook it and again began restlessly stamping one after the other her (mare) shapely legs.

he (lip) said, patting her (mare) again over her (mare) hind-quarters; and with a glad sense that his (lip) mare was in the best possible condition, he (lip) went out of the horse-box.

He (lip) felt that his (lip) heart was throbbing, and that he (lip), too, like the mare, longed to move, to bite; it was both dreadful and delicious.

'' Quiet, darling, quiet! '' The mare's excitement had infected Vronsky. '' Well, I rely on you, then,'' he (lip) said to the Englishman;

``half-past six on the ground.'' (the Englishman)

'' All right,'' said the Englishman. '' Oh, where are you going, my lord? '' he (lord) asked suddenly, using the title

``my lord,'' (he)
which he (lord) had scarcely ever used before.

Vronsky in amazement raised his (lord) head, and stared, as he (lord) knew how to stare, not into the Englishman's eyes, but at his (Englishman) forehead, astounded at the impertinence of his (Englishman) question.

But realizing that in asking this the Englishman had been looking at him (Englishman) not as an employer, but as a jockey, he (Englishman) answered: ``I've got to go to Bryansky's

``How often I'm asked that question today!'' (Bryansky)
he (Englishman) said to himself, and he (Englishman) blushed, a thing which rarely happened to him (Englishman).

The Englishman looked gravely at him (Englishman); and, as though he (Englishman), too, knew where Vronsky was going, he (Vronsky) added:

``The great thing's to keep quiet before a race,'' (he)
said he (Vronsky);
``don't get out of temper or upset about anything.

; I shall be home within an hour. '' (he)

'' '' All right,'' answered Vronsky, smiling; and jumping into his (Vronsky) carriage, he (Vronsky) told the man to drive to Peterhof.

Before he (Vronsky) had driven many paces away, the dark clouds that had been threatening rain all day broke, and there was a heavy downpour of rain.

'' What a pity!'' thought Vronsky, putting up the roof of the carriage. '' It was muddy before, now it will be a perfect swamp.

As he (Vronsky) sat in solitude in the closed carriage, he (Vronsky) took out his (Vronsky) mother's letter and his (Vronsky) brother's note, and read them through.

'' Yes, it was the same thing over and over again. Everyone, his (Vronsky) mother, his (Vronsky) brother, everyone thought fit to interfere in the affairs of his (Vronsky) heart.

This interference aroused in him (Vronsky) a feeling of angry hatred--a feeling he (Vronsky) had rarely known before. '' What business is it of theirs?

Why does everybody feel called upon to concern himself about me? And why do they worry me so? Just because they see that this is something they can't understand.

They feel that this is something different, that this is not a mere pastime, that this woman is dearer to me than life.

If it were a common, vulgar, worldly intrigue, they would have left me alone. And this is incomprehensible, and that's why it annoys them.

Whatever our destiny is or may be, we have made it ourselves, and we do not complain of it,'' he (they) said, in the word we linking himself with Anna.

They haven't an idea of what happiness is; they don't know that without our love, for us there is neither happiness nor unhappiness--no life at all,'' he (they) thought.

He (they) was angry with all of them for their interference just because he (they) felt in his (they) soul that they, all these people, were right.

He (they) felt that the love that bound him (they) to Anna was not a momentary impulse, which would pass, as worldly intrigues do pass, leaving no other traces in the life of either but pleasant or unpleasant memories.

He (they) felt all the torture of his (they) own and her (Anna) position, all the difficulty there was for them, conspicuous as they were in the eye of all the world, in concealing their love, in lying and deceiving; and in lying, deceiving, feigning, and continually thinking of others, when the passion that united them was so intense that they were both oblivious of everything else but their love.

He (they) vividly recalled all the constantly recurring instances of inevitable necessity for lying and deceit, which were so against his (they) natural bent.

He (they) recalled particularly vividly the shame he (they) had more than once detected in her (they) at this necessity for lying and deceit.

'' No, they must needs teach us how to live. And he (they) experienced the strange feeling that had sometimes come upon him (they) since his (they) secret love for Anna.

This was a feeling of loathing for something--whether for Alexey Alexandrovitch, or for himself, or for the whole world, he (Alexandrovitch) could not have said.

But he (Alexandrovitch) always drove away this strange feeling. Now, too, he (Alexandrovitch) shook it off and continued the thread of his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts.

Yes, she (Anna) was unhappy before, but proud and at peace; and now she (Anna) cannot be at peace and feel secure in her (Anna) dignity, though she (Anna) does not show it.

And for the first time the idea clearly presented itself that it was essential to put an end to this false position, and the sooner the better.

'' Yes, we must put an end to it,'' he (Alexandrovitch) decided. '' Throw up everything, she (Anna) and I, and hide ourselves somewhere alone with our love,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself.

The rain did not last long, and by the time Vronsky arrived, his (Alexandrovitch) shaft-horse trotting at full speed and dragging the trace-horses galloping through the mud, with their reins hanging loose, the sun had peeped out again, the roofs of the summer villas and the old limetrees in the gardens on both sides of the principal streets sparkled with wet brilliance, and from the twigs came a pleasant drip and from the roofs rushing streams of water.

He (Alexandrovitch) thought no more of the shower spoiling the race course, but was rejoicing now that--thanks to the rain--he (Alexandrovitch) would be sure to find her (Alexandrovitch) at home and alone, as he (Alexandrovitch) knew that Alexey Alexandrovitch, who had lately returned from a foreign watering place, had not moved from Petersburg.

Hoping to find her (Alexandrovitch) alone, Vronsky alighted, as he (Vronsky) always did, to avoid attracting attention, before crossing the bridge, and walked to the house.

Chapter 22 He (Vronsky) did not go up the steps to the street door, but went into the court. '' Has your master come?

'' he (master) asked a gardener. '' No, sir. The mistress is at home. But will you please go to the front door; there are servants there,'' the gardener answered.

And feeling satisfied that she (mistress) was alone, and wanting to take her (mistress) by surprise, since he (gardener) had not promised to be there today, and she (mistress) would certainly not expect him (gardener) to come before the races, he (gardener) walked, holding his (gardener) sword and stepping cautiously over the sandy path, bordered with flowers, to the terrace that looked out upon the garden.

'' They'll open the door.'' '' No, I'll go in from the garden. '' Vronsky forgot now all that he (gardener) had thought on the way of the hardships and difficulties of their position.

He (gardener) thought of nothing but that he (gardener) would see her (mistress) directly, not in imagination, but living, all of her (mistress), as she (mistress) was in reality.

He (gardener) was just going in, stepping on his (gardener) whole foot so as not to creak, up the worn steps of the terrace, when he (gardener) suddenly remembered what he (gardener) always forgot, and what caused the most torturing side of his (gardener) relations with her (mistress), her (mistress) son with his (gardener) questioning--hostile, as he (gardener) fancied--eyes.

When he (gardener) was present, both Vronsky and Anna did not merely avoid speaking of anything that they could not have repeated before everyone; they did not even allow themselves to refer by hints to anything the boy did not understand.

This boy was more often than anyone else a check upon their freedom. They had made no agreement about this, it had settled itself.

But in spite of this caution, Vronsky often saw the child's intent, bewildered glance fixed upon him (boy), and a strange shyness, uncertainty, at one time friendliness, at another, coldness and reserve, in the boy's manner to him (boy); as though the child felt that between this man and his (man) mother there existed some important bond, the significance of which he (man) could not understand.

As a fact, the boy did feel that he (boy) could not understand this relation, and he (boy) tried painfully, and was not able to make clear to himself what feeling he (boy) ought to have for this man.

With a child's keen instinct for every manifestation of feeling, he (boy) saw distinctly that his (boy) father, his (boy) governess, his (boy) nurse,--all did not merely dislike Vronsky, but looked on him (boy) with horror and aversion, though they never said anything about him (boy), while his (boy) mother looked on him (boy) as her (mother) greatest friend.

They would have felt it wounding themselves to deceive the child. In his (boy) presence they talked like acquaintances. '' What does it mean?

Who is he (boy)? How ought I to love him (boy)? If I don't know, it's my fault; either I'm stupid or a naughty boy,'' thought the child.

And this was what caused his (boy) dubious, inquiring, sometimes hostile, expression, and the shyness and uncertainty which Vronsky found so irksome.

This child's presence always and infallibly called up in Vronsky that strange feeling of inexplicable loathing which he (boy) had experienced of late.

a feeling akin to the feeling of a sailor who sees by the compass that the direction in which he (sailor) is swiftly moving is far from the right one, but that to arrest his (sailor) motion is not in his (sailor) power, that every instant is carrying him (sailor) further and further away, and that to admit to himself his (sailor) deviation from the right direction is the same as admitting his (sailor) certain ruin.

This child, with his (sailor) innocent outlook upon life, was the compass that showed them the point to which they had departed from what they knew, but did not want to know.

This child's presence called up both in Vronsky and in Anna This time Seryozha was not at home, and she (Anna) was completely alone.

She (Anna) was sitting on the terrace waiting for the return of her (Anna) son, who had gone out for his (son) walk and been caught in the rain.

Dressed in a white gown, deeply embroidered, she (Anna) was sitting in a corner of the terrace behind some flowers, and did not hear him (son).

Bending her (Anna) curly black head, she (Anna) pressed her (Anna) forehead against a cool watering pot that stood on the parapet, and both her (Anna) lovely hands, with the rings he (son) knew so well, clasped the pot.

The beauty of her (Anna) whole figure, her (Anna) head, her (Anna) neck, her (Anna) hands, struck Vronsky every time as something new and unexpected.

She (Anna) had sent a manservant and a maid out to look for him (son). He (son) stood still, gazing at her (Anna) in ecstasy.

But, directly he (son) would have made a step to come nearer to her (Anna), she (Anna) was aware of his (son) presence, pushed away the watering pot, and turned her (Anna) flushed face towards him (son).

He (son) would have run to her (Anna), but remembering that there might be spectators, he (son) looked round towards the balcony door, and reddened a little, as he (son) always reddened, feeling that he (son) had to be afraid and be on his (son) guard.

'' What's the matter? You are ill? '' he (son) said to her (Anna) in French, going up to her (Anna). '' No, I'm quite well,'' she (Anna) said, getting up and pressing his (son) outstretched hand tightly.

'' I did not expect...thee.''

He (son) saw it, and his (son) face expressed that utter subjection, that slavish devotion, which had done so much to win her (Betsy).

But at the same time, he (God) felt that the turning-point he (God) had been longing for had come now; that it was impossible to go on concealing things from her (Betsy) husband, and it was inevitable in one way or another that they should soon put an end to their unnatural position.

On hearing it, he (husband) felt come upon him (husband) with tenfold intensity that strange feeling of loathing of someone. But, besides that, her (Betsy) emotion physically affected him (husband) in the same way.

'' Yes,'' he (husband) said, going up to her (Betsy) resolutely. '' Neither you nor I have looked on our relations as a passing amusement, and now our fate is sealed.

``to the deception in which we are living.'' (he)
``Put an end?

How put an end, Alexey? '' (she)

'' Leave your husband and make our life one.''

``It is one as it is,'' (she)

'' Is there any way out of such a position? Am I not the wife of my husband?'' '' There is a way out of every position.

We must take our line,'' he (husband) said. '' Anything's better than the position in which you're living. Of course, I see how you torture yourself over everything--the world and your son and your husband.''

'' Oh, not over my husband,'' she (wife) said, with a quiet smile. '' I don't know him (husband), I don't think of him (husband).

Oh, he (husband) doesn't even know,'' she (wife) said, and suddenly a hot flush came over her (wife) face; her (wife) cheeks, her (wife) brow, her (wife) neck crimsoned, and tears of shame came into her (wife) eyes.

He (husband) doesn't exist. '' '' You're not speaking sincerely. I know you. You worry about him (husband) too.'' '' '' But we won't talk of him (husband).

Chapter 23 Vronsky had several times already, though not so resolutely as now, tried to bring her (wife) to consider their position, and every time he (husband) had been confronted by the same superficiality and triviality with which she (wife) met his (husband) appeal now.

It was as though there were something in this which she (wife) could not or would not face, as though directly she (wife) began to speak of this, she (wife), the real Anna, retreated somehow into herself, and another strange and unaccountable woman came out, whom he (husband) did not love, and whom he (husband) feared, and who was in opposition to him (husband).

'' But today he (husband) was resolved to have it out. '' Whether he (husband) knows or not,'' said Vronsky, in his (husband) usual quiet and resolute tone,

``that's nothing to do with us.

We cannot... you cannot stay like this, especially now. '' (Vronsky)

'' What's to be done, according to you? '' she (woman) asked with the same frivolous irony.

She (woman) who had so feared he (husband) would take her (woman) condition too lightly was now vexed with him (husband) for deducing from it the necessity of taking some step.

He (son)'s not a man, but a machine, and a spiteful machine when he (son)'s angry,'' she (woman) added, recalling Alexey Alexandrovitch as she (woman) spoke, with all the peculiarities of his (Alexandrovitch) figure and manner of speaking, and reckoning against him (Alexandrovitch) every defect she (woman) could find in him (Alexandrovitch), softening nothing for the great wrong she (woman) herself was doing him (Alexandrovitch).

Vronsky could not understand how she (Anna), with her (Anna) strong and truthful nature, could endure this state of deceit, and not long to get out of it.

But he (son) did not suspect that the chief cause of it was the word-- son , which she (Anna) could not bring herself to pronounce.

When she (Anna) thought of her (Anna) son, and his (son) future attitude to his (son) mother, who had abandoned his (son) father, she (Anna) felt such terror at what she (Anna) had done, that she (Anna) could not face it; but, like a woman, could only try to comfort herself with lying assurances that everything would remain as it always had been, and that it was possible to forget the fearful question of how it would be with her (Anna) son.

I beg you, I entreat you,'' she (Anna) said suddenly, taking his (son) hand, and speaking in quite a different tone, sincere and tender,

``never speak to me of that!'' (she)

I know all the baseness, all the horror of my position; but it's not so easy to arrange as you think.

'' '' But, Anna...''

``Never. Leave it to me. And leave it to me, and do what I say. Never speak to me of it.

Do you promise me?... No, no, promise!... '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

``I promise everything, but I can't be at peace, especially after what you have told me.

I can't be at peace, when you can't be at peace... '' (she)

``I? '' (she)
she (Anna) repeated. '' Yes, I am worried sometimes; but that will pass, if you will never talk about this.

When you talk about it--it's only then it worries me.''

``I don't understand,'' (he)
he (it) said. '' I know,'' she (Anna) interrupted him (it),
``how hard it is for your truthful nature to lie, and I grieve for you.

I often think that you have ruined your whole life for me.'' (him)

``I was just thinking the very same thing,'' (he)
he (it) said;
``how could you sacrifice everything for my sake?

I can't forgive myself that you're unhappy!'' (he)

``I unhappy? '' (she)
she (Anna) said, coming closer to him (it), and looking at him (it) with an ecstatic smile of love.

'' I am like a hungry man who has been given food. He (man) may be cold, and dressed in rags, and ashamed, but he (man) is not unhappy.

She (Anna) could hear the sound of her (Anna) son's voice coming towards them, and glancing swiftly round the terrace, she (Anna) got up impulsively.

Her (Anna) eyes glowed with the fire he (son) knew so well; with a rapid movement she (Anna) raised her (Anna) lovely hands, covered with rings, took his (son) head, looked a long look into his (son) face, and, putting up her (Anna) face with smiling, parted lips, swiftly kissed his (son) mouth and both eyes, and pushed him (son) away.

I unhappy? No, this is my unhappiness... '' She (Anna) would have gone, but he (son) held her (Anna) back. '' When? '' he (son) murmured in a whisper, gazing in ecstasy at her (Anna).

Tonight, at one o'clock,'' she (Anna) whispered, and, with a heavy sigh, she (Anna) walked with her (Anna) light, swift step to meet her (Anna) son.

Seryozha had been caught by the rain in the big garden, and he (son) and his (son) nurse had taken shelter in an arbor.

'' '' Well, au revoir ,'' she (nurse) said to Vronsky. '' I must soon be getting ready for the races. Betsy promised to fetch me.

When Vronsky looked at his (son) watch on the Karenins' balcony, he (son) was so greatly agitated and lost in his (son) thoughts that he (son) saw the figures on the watch's face, but could not take in what time it was.

'' Vronsky, looking at his (son) watch, went away hurriedly. Chapter 24 He (son) came out on to the high road and walked, picking his (son) way carefully through the mud, to his (son) carriage.

He (son) was so completely absorbed in his (son) feeling for Anna, that he (son) did not even think what o'clock it was, and whether he (son) had time to go to Bryansky's.

He (son) had left him (son), as often happens, only the external faculty of memory, that points out each step one has to take, one after the other.

He (son) went up to his (son) coachman, who was dozing on the box in the shadow, already lengthening, of a thick limetree; he (son) admired the shifting clouds of midges circling over the hot horses, and, waking the coachman, he (son) jumped into the carriage, and told him (son) to drive to Bryansky's.

It was only after driving nearly five miles that he (son) had sufficiently recovered himself to look at his (son) watch, and realize that it was half-past five, and he (son) was late.

There were several races fixed for that day: the Mounted Guards' race, then the officers' mile-and-a-half race, then the three-mile race, and then the race for which he (son) was entered.

He (son) could still be in time for his (son) race, but if he (son) went to Bryansky's he (son) could only just be in time, and he (son) would arrive when the whole of the court would be in their places.

But he (son) had promised Bryansky to come, and so he (son) decided to drive on, telling the coachman not to spare the horses.

All that was painful in his (son) relations with Anna, all the feeling of indefiniteness left by their conversation, had slipped out of his (son) mind.

He (son) was thinking now with pleasure and excitement of the race, of his (son) being anyhow, in time, and now and then the thought of the blissful interview awaiting him (son) that night flashed across his (son) imagination like a flaming light.

The excitement of the approaching race gained upon him (son) as he (son) drove further and further into the atmosphere of the races, overtaking carriages driving up from the summer villas or out of Petersburg.

At his (son) quarters no one was left at home; all were at the races, and his (son) valet was looking out for him (son) at the gate.

While he (son) was changing his (son) clothes, his (son) valet told him (son) that the second race had begun already, that a lot of gentlemen had been to ask for him (son), and a boy had twice run up from the stables.

That would be a pity. He (boy) reached Bryansky's, spent five minutes there, and galloped back. This rapid drive calmed him (boy). Dressing without hurry -LRB-he (boy) never hurried himself, and never lost his (boy) self-possession-RRB-, Vronsky drove to the sheds.

From the sheds he (Vronsky) could see a perfect sea of carriages, and people on foot, soldiers surrounding the race course, and pavilions swarming with people.

Going towards the stable, he (Vronsky) met the white-legged chestnut, Mahotin's Gladiator, being led to the race-course in a blue forage horsecloth, with what looked like huge ears edged with blue.

The second race was apparently going on, for just as he (Vronsky) went into the sheds he (Vronsky) heard a bell ringing. ''

Where's Cord? '' he (Vronsky) asked the stable-boy. '' In the stable, putting on the saddle. '' In the open horse-box stood Frou-Frou, saddled ready.

They were just going to lead her (Vronsky) out. '' I'm not too late?'' '' All right! All right!'' said the Englishman;

``don't upset yourself!

Vronsky once more took in in one glance the exquisite lines of his (Englishman) favorite mare; who was quivering all over, and with an effort he (Englishman) tore himself from the sight of her (mare), and went out of the stable.

The mile-and-a-half race was just finishing, and all eyes were fixed on the horse-guard in front and the light hussar behind, urging their horses on with a last effort close to the winning post.

From the center and outside of the ring all were crowding to the winning post, and a group of soldiers and officers of the horse-guards were shouting loudly their delight at the expected triumph of their officer and comrade.

Vronsky moved into the middle of the crowd unnoticed, almost at the very moment when the bell rang at the finish of the race, and the tall, mudspattered horse-guard who came in first, bending over the saddle, let go the reins of his (comrade) panting gray horse that looked dark with sweat.

The horse, stiffening out its legs, with an effort stopped its rapid course, and the officer of the horse-guards looked round him (officer) like a man waking up from a heavy sleep, and just managed to smile.

'' (the Englishman)

He (officer) went towards the pavilions at the most favorable moment for escaping attention. A crowd of friends and outsiders pressed round him (officer).

Vronsky intentionally avoided that select crowd of the upper world, which was moving and talking with discreet freedom before the pavilions.

He (officer) knew that Madame Karenina was there, and Betsy, and his (officer) brother's wife, and he (officer) purposely did not go near them for fear of something distracting his (officer) attention.

But he (officer) was continually met and stopped by acquaintances, who told him (officer) about the previous races, and kept asking him (officer) why he (officer) was so late.

At the time when the racers had to go to the pavilion to receive the prizes, and all attention was directed to that point, Vronsky's elder brother, Alexander, a colonel with heavy fringed epaulets, came up to him (Alexander).

He (Alexander) was not tall, though as broadly built as Alexey, and handsomer and rosier than he (Alexey); he (Alexey) had a red nose, and an open, drunken-looking face.

Alexander Vronsky, in spite of the dissolute life, and in especial the drunken habits, for which he (Vronsky) was notorious, was quite one of the court circle.

Now, as he (Vronsky) talked to his (Vronsky) brother of a matter bound to be exceedingly disagreeable to him (Vronsky), knowing that the eyes of many people might be fixed upon him (Vronsky), he (Vronsky) kept a smiling countenance, as though he (Vronsky) were jesting with his (Vronsky) brother about something of little moment.

'' Did you get my note? '' he (Vronsky) said. '' There's never any finding you.'' '' I got it, and I really can't make out what you are worrying yourself about,'' said Alexey.

I'm worrying myself because the remark has just been made to me that you weren't here, and that you were seen in Peterhof on Monday.

'' '' '' There are matters which only concern those directly interested in them, and the matter you are so worried about is...

'' '' Yes, but if so, you may as well cut the service... ''

``I beg you not to meddle, and that's all I have to say.

Being a man of very warm heart, he (man) was seldom angry; but when he (man) was angry, and when his (man) chin quivered, then, as Alexander Vronsky knew, he (Vronsky) was dangerous.

'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)

Alexey Vronsky's frowning face turned white, and his (Vronsky) prominent lower jaw quivered, which happened rarely with him (Vronsky). Alexander Vronsky smiled gaily.

'' I only wanted to give you Mother's letter. Answer it, and don't worry about anything just before the race. Bonne chance,'' he (Vronsky) added, smiling and he (Vronsky) moved away from him (Vronsky).

How are you, mon cher?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, as conspicuously brilliant in the midst of all the Petersburg brilliance as he (Vronsky) was in Moscow, his (Vronsky) face rosy, and his (Vronsky) whiskers sleek and glossy.

But after him (Vronsky) another friendly greeting brought Vronsky to a standstill. '' So you won't recognize your friends! '' I came up yesterday, and I'm delighted that I shall see your triumph.

``Come tomorrow to the messroom,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, and squeezing him (Vronsky) by the sleeve of his (Vronsky) coat, with apologies, he (Vronsky) moved away to the center of the race course, where the horses were being led for the great steeplechase.

The horses who had run in the last race were being led home, steaming and exhausted, by the stable-boys, and one after another the fresh horses for the coming race made their appearance, for the most part English racers, wearing horsecloths, and looking with their drawn-up bellies like strange, huge birds.

On the right was led in Frou-Frou, lean and beautiful, lifting up her (Vronsky) elastic, rather long pasterns, as though moved by springs.

The strong, exquisite, perfectly correct lines of the stallion, with his (stallion) superb hind-quarters and excessively short pasterns almost over his (stallion) hoofs, attracted Vronsky's attention in spite of himself.

When shall we meet?'' Not far from her (Vronsky) they were taking the rug off the lop-eared Gladiator. He (stallion) would have gone up to his (stallion) mare, but he (stallion) was again detained by an acquaintance.

'' Oh, there's Karenin! '' said the acquaintance with whom he (acquaintance) was chatting. '' He (acquaintance)'s looking for his (acquaintance) wife, and she (wife)'s in the middle of the pavilion.

No,'' answered Vronsky, and without even glancing round towards the pavilion where his (acquaintance) friend was pointing out Madame Karenina, he (acquaintance) went up to his (acquaintance) mare.

Vronsky had not had time to look at the saddle, about which he (acquaintance) had to give some direction, when the competitors were summoned to the pavilion to receive their numbers and places in the row at starting.

Didn't you see her (mare)?'' '' Seventeen officers, looking serious and severe, many with pale faces, met together in the pavilion and drew the numbers.

'' Feeling that with the others riding in the race, he (acquaintance) was the center upon which all eyes were fastened, Vronsky walked up to his (Vronsky) mare in that state of nervous tension in which he (Vronsky) usually became deliberate and composed in his (Vronsky) movements.

Cord, in honor of the races, had put on his (Vronsky) best clothes, a black coat buttoned up, a stiffly starched collar, which propped up his (Vronsky) cheeks, a round black hat, and top boots.

He (Vronsky) was calm and dignified as ever, and was with his (Vronsky) own hands holding Frou-Frou by both reins, standing straight in front of her (mare).

Vronsky drew the number seven. The cry was heard:

``Mount! Frou-Frou was still trembling as though in a fever. Her (mare) eye, full of fire, glanced sideways at Vronsky.

Vronsky slipped his (Vronsky) finger under the saddle-girth. The mare glanced aslant at him (Vronsky), drew up her (mare) lip, and twitched her (mare) ear.

The Englishman puckered up his (Englishman) lips, intending to indicate a smile that anyone should verify his (Englishman) saddling. '' (unknown)

Get up; you won't feel so excited.

'' Vronsky looked round for the last time at his (Englishman) rivals. He (Englishman) knew that he (Englishman) would not see them during the race.

Galtsin, a friend of Vronsky's and one of his (friend) more formidable rivals, was moving round a bay horse that would not let him (friend) mount.

A little light hussar in tight riding breeches rode off at a gallop, crouched up like a cat on the saddle, in imitation of English jockeys.

Prince Kuzovlev sat with a white face on his (Prince) thoroughbred mare from the Grabovsky stud, while an English groom led her (mare) by the bridle.

Two were already riding forward to the point from which they were to start. Vronsky and all his (groom) comrades knew Kuzovlev and his (groom) peculiarity of

``weak nerves'' (Kuzovlev)
and terrible vanity.

But now, just because it was terrible, because people broke their necks, and there was a doctor standing at each obstacle, and an ambulance with a cross on it, and a sister of mercy, he (doctor) had made up his (doctor) mind to take part in the race.

They knew that he (doctor) was afraid of everything, afraid of riding a spirited horse. Their eyes met, and Vronsky gave him (Vronsky) a friendly and encouraging nod.

Only one he (Vronsky) did not see, his (Vronsky) chief rival, Mahotin on Gladiator.

``Don't be in a hurry,'' (Vronsky)
said Cord to Vronsky,
``and remember one thing:

don't hold her (sister) in at the fences, and don't urge her (sister) on; let her (sister) go as she (sister) likes. '' (Vronsky)

'' All right, all right,'' said Vronsky, taking the reins.

Before the mare had time to move, Vronsky stepped with an agile, vigorous movement into the steel-toothed stirrup, and lightly and firmly seated himself on the creaking leather of the saddle.

Getting his (Vronsky) right foot in the stirrup, he (Vronsky) smoothed the double reins, as he (Vronsky) always did, between his (Vronsky) fingers, and Cord let go.

As though she (mare) did not know which foot to put first, Frou-Frou started, dragging at the reins with her (mare) long neck, and as though she (mare) were on springs, shaking her (mare) rider from side to side.

'' If you can, lead the race; but don't lose heart till the last minute, even if you're behind. '' Cord quickened his (rider) step, following him (rider).

The excited mare, trying to shake off her (mare) rider first on one side and then the other, pulled at the reins, and Vronsky tried in vain with voice and hand to soothe her (mare).

Several of the riders were in front and several behind, when suddenly Vronsky heard the sound of a horse galloping in the mud behind him (rider), and he (rider) was overtaken by Mahotin on his (rider) white-legged, lop-eared Gladiator.

They were just reaching the dammed-up stream on their way to the starting point. Mahotin smiled, showing his (rider) long teeth, but Vronsky looked angrily at him (Vronsky).

He (Vronsky) did not like him (Vronsky), and regarded him (Vronsky) now as his (Vronsky) most formidable rival. He (Vronsky) was angry with him (Vronsky) for galloping past and exciting his (Vronsky) mare.

Frou-Frou started into a gallop, her (mare) left foot forward, made two bounds, and fretting at the tightened reins, passed into a jolting trot, bumping her (mare) rider up and down.

Cord, too, scowled, and followed Vronsky almost at a trot. Chapter 25 There were seventeen officers in all riding in this race.

On this course nine obstacles had been arranged: the stream, a big and solid barrier five feet high, just before the pavilion, a dry ditch, a ditch full of water, a precipitous slope, an Irish barricade -LRB-one of the most difficult obstacles, consisting of a mound fenced with brushwood, beyond which was a ditch out of sight for the horses, so that the horse had to clear both obstacles or might be killed-RRB-; then two more ditches filled with water, and one dry one; and the end of the race was just facing the pavilion.

But the race began not in the ring, but two hundred yards away from it, and in that part of the course was the first obstacle, a dammed-up stream, seven feet in breadth, which the racers could leap or wade through as they preferred.

Three times they were ranged ready to start, but each time some horse thrust itself out of line, and they had to begin again.

The umpire who was starting them, Colonel Sestrin, was beginning to lose his (Colonel) temper, when at last for the fourth time he (Colonel) shouted

``Away!'' (he)
and the racers started.

Every eye, every opera glass, was turned on the brightly colored group of riders at the moment they were in line to start.

The race course was a large three-mile ring of the form of an ellipse in front of the pavilion. '' They're off!

They're starting!'' was heard on all sides after the hush of expectation. And little groups and solitary figures among the public began running from place to place to get a better view.

In the very first minute the close group of horsemen drew out, and it could be seen that they were approaching the stream in twos and threes and one behind another.

To the spectators it seemed as though they had all started simultaneously, but to the racers there were seconds of difference that had great value to them.

Frou-Frou, excited and over-nervous, had lost the first moment, and several horses had started before her (horsemen), but before reaching the stream, Vronsky, who was holding in the mare with all his (them) force as she (mare) tugged at the bridle, easily overtook three, and there were left in front of him (them) Mahotin's chestnut Gladiator, whose hind-quarters were moving lightly and rhythmically up and down exactly in front of Vronsky, and in front of all, the dainty mare Diana bearing Kuzovlev more dead than alive.

For the first instant Vronsky was not master either of himself or his (them) mare. Up to the first obstacle, the stream, he (them) could not guide the motions of his (them) mare.

Gladiator and Diana came up to it together and almost at the same instant; simultaneously they rose above the stream and flew across to the other side; Frou-Frou darted after them, as if flying; but at the very moment when Vronsky felt himself in the air, he (Vronsky) suddenly saw almost under his (Vronsky) mare's hoofs Kuzovlev, who was floundering with Diana on the further side of the stream.

-LRB-Kuzovlev had let go the reins as he (Vronsky) took the leap, and the mare had sent him (Vronsky) flying over her (mare) head.-RRB-

Those details Vronsky learned later; at the moment all he (Vronsky) saw was that just under him (Vronsky), where Frou-Frou must alight, Diana's legs or head might be in the way.

But Frou-Frou drew up her (Diana) legs and back in the very act of leaping, like a falling cat, and, clearing the other mare, alighted beyond her (mare).

After crossing the stream Vronsky had complete control of his (Vronsky) mare, and began holding her (mare) in, intending to cross the great barrier behind Mahotin, and to try to overtake him (Vronsky) in the clear ground of about five hundred yards that followed it.

The Tsar and the whole court and crowds of people were all gazing at them--at him (Tsar), and Mahotin a length ahead of him (Tsar), as they drew near the

``devil,'' (him)
as the solid barrier was called.

Vronsky was aware of those eyes fastened upon him (Vronsky) from all sides, but he (Vronsky) saw nothing except the ears and neck of his (Vronsky) own mare, the ground racing to meet him (Vronsky), and the back and white legs of Gladiator beating time swiftly before him (Vronsky), and keeping always the same distance ahead.

'' O the darling!'' thought Vronsky. The great barrier stood just in front of the imperial pavilion. Gladiator rose, with no sound of knocking against anything.

With a wave of his (Vronsky) short tail he (Vronsky) disappeared from Vronsky's sight.

``Bravo!'' (unknown)
cried a voice. At the same instant, under Vronsky's eyes, right before him (Bravo) flashed the palings of the barrier.

Without the slightest change in her (Vronsky) action his (Bravo) mare flew over it; the palings vanished, and he (Bravo) heard only a crash behind him (Bravo).

The mare, excited by Gladiator's keeping ahead, had risen too soon before the barrier, and grazed it with her (mare) hind hoofs.

But her (mare) pace never changed, and Vronsky, feeling a spatter of mud in his (Gladiator) face, realized that he (Gladiator) was once more the same distance from Gladiator.

Once more he (Gladiator) perceived in front of him (Gladiator) the same back and short tail, and again the same swiftly moving white legs that got no further away.

At the very moment when Vronsky thought that now was the time to overtake Mahotin, Frou-Frou herself, understanding his (Gladiator) thoughts, without any incitement on his (Gladiator) part, gained ground considerably, and began getting alongside of Mahotin on the most favorable side, close to the inner cord.

Vronsky had hardly formed the thought that he (Gladiator) could perhaps pass on the outer side, when Frou-Frou shifted her (Gladiator) pace and began overtaking him (Gladiator) on the other side.

Mahotin would not let her (Gladiator) pass that side. Frou-Frou's shoulder, beginning by now to be dark with sweat, was even with Gladiator's back.

But before the obstacle they were approaching, Vronsky began working at the reins, anxious to avoid having to take the outer circle, and swiftly passed Mahotin just upon the declivity.

For a few lengths they moved evenly. He (Gladiator) caught a glimpse of his (Gladiator) mud-stained face as he (Gladiator) flashed by. He (Gladiator) even fancied that he (Gladiator) smiled.

Vronsky passed Mahotin, but he (Gladiator) was immediately aware of him (Gladiator) close upon him (Gladiator), and he (Gladiator) never ceased hearing the even-thudding hoofs and the rapid and still quite fresh breathing of Gladiator.

The next two obstacles, the water course and the barrier, were easily crossed, but Vronsky began to hear the snorting and thud of Gladiator closer upon him (Vronsky).

He (Vronsky) urged on his (Vronsky) mare, and to his (Vronsky) delight felt that she (mare) easily quickened her (mare) pace, and the thud of Gladiator's hoofs was again heard at the same distance away.

Vronsky was at the head of the race, just as he (Gladiator) wanted to be and as Cord had advised, and now he (Gladiator) felt sure of being the winner.

He (Gladiator) longed to look round again, but he (Gladiator) did not dare do this, and tried to be cool and not to urge on his (Gladiator) mare so to keep the same reserve of force in her (mare) as he (Gladiator) felt that Gladiator still kept.

There remained only one obstacle, the most difficult; if he (Gladiator) could cross it ahead of the others he (Gladiator) would come in first.

He (Gladiator) was flying towards the Irish barricade, Frou-Frou and he (Gladiator) both together saw the barricade in the distance, and both the man and the mare had a moment's hesitation.

He (man) saw the uncertainty in the mare's ears and lifted the whip, but at the same time felt that his (man) fears were groundless; the mare knew what was wanted.

She (mare) quickened her (mare) pace and rose smoothly, just as he (man) had fancied she (mare) would, and as she (mare) left the ground gave herself up to the force of her (mare) rush, which carried her (mare) far beyond the ditch; and with the same rhythm, without effort, with the same leg forward, Frou-Frou fell back into her (mare) pace again.

he (man) heard shouts from a knot of men--he (man) knew they were his (man) friends in the regiment--who were standing at the obstacle.

His (man) excitement, his (man) delight, and his (man) tenderness for Frou-Frou grew keener and keener. '' Bravo, Vronsky!'' He (Bravo) could not fail to recognize Yashvin's voice though he (Bravo) did not see him (Bravo).

'' O my sweet! '' he (Bravo) said inwardly to Frou-Frou, as he (Bravo) listened for what was happening behind. '' He (Bravo)'s cleared it!

'' he (Bravo) thought, catching the thud of Gladiator's hoofs behind him (Gladiator). There remained only the last ditch, filled with water and five feet wide.

Vronsky did not even look at it, but anxious to get in a long way first began sawing away at the reins, lifting the mare's head and letting it go in time with her (mare) paces.

He (Gladiator) felt that the mare was at her (mare) very last reserve of strength; not her (mare) neck and shoulders merely were wet, but the sweat was standing in drops on her (mare) mane, her (mare) head, her (mare) sharp ears, and her (mare) breath came in short, sharp gasps.

It was only from feeling himself nearer the ground and from the peculiar smoothness of his (Gladiator) motion that Vronsky knew how greatly the mare had quickened her (mare) pace.

But he (Vronsky) knew that she (mare) had strength left more than enough for the remaining five hundred yards. She (mare) flew over the ditch as though not noticing it.

She (mare) flew over it like a bird; but at the same instant Vronsky, to his (Vronsky) horror, felt that he (Vronsky) had failed to keep up with the mare's pace, that he (Vronsky) had, he (Vronsky) did not know how, made a fearful, unpardonable mistake, in recovering his (Vronsky) seat in the saddle.

He (Vronsky) could not yet make out what had happened, when the white legs of a chestnut horse flashed by close to him (Vronsky), and Mahotin passed at a swift gallop.

All at once his (Vronsky) position had shifted and he (Vronsky) knew that something awful had happened. Vronsky was touching the ground with one foot, and his (Vronsky) mare was sinking on that foot.

He (Vronsky) just had time to free his (Vronsky) leg when she (mare) fell on one side, gasping painfully, and, making vain efforts to rise with her (mare) delicate, soaking neck, she (mare) fluttered on the ground at his (Vronsky) feet like a shot bird.

At that moment he (Vronsky) knew only that Mahotin had flown swiftly by, while he (Vronsky) stood staggering alone on the muddy, motionless ground, and Frou-Frou lay gasping before him (Vronsky), bending her (mare) head back and gazing at him (Vronsky) with her (mare) exquisite eyes.

The clumsy movement made by Vronsky had broken her (mare) back. But that he (Vronsky) only knew much later. Still unable to realize what had happened, Vronsky tugged at his (Vronsky) mare's reins.

Again she (mare) struggled all over like a fish, and her (mare) shoulders setting the saddle heaving, she (mare) rose on her (mare) front legs but unable to lift her (mare) back, she (mare) quivered all over and again fell on her (mare) side.

With a face hideous with passion, his (Vronsky) lower jaw trembling, and his (Vronsky) cheeks white, Vronsky kicked her (mare) with his (Vronsky) heel in the stomach and again fell to tugging at the rein.

She (mare) did not stir, but thrusting her (mare) nose into the ground, she (mare) simply gazed at her (mare) master with her (mare) speaking eyes.

'' A--a--a! '' groaned Vronsky, clutching at his (master) head. '' Ah! what have I done! '' he (master) cried. '' The race lost!

And my fault! shameful, unpardonable! And the poor darling, ruined mare! Ah! what have I done! '' A crowd of men, a doctor and his (doctor) assistant, the officers of his (doctor) regiment, ran up to him (doctor).

To his (doctor) misery he (doctor) felt that he (doctor) was whole and unhurt. The mare had broken her (mare) back, and it was decided to shoot her (mare).

He (doctor) turned, and without picking up his (doctor) cap that had fallen off, walked away from the race course, not knowing where he (doctor) was going.

For the first time in his (doctor) life he (doctor) knew the bitterest sort of misfortune, misfortune beyond remedy, and caused by his (doctor) own fault.

Vronsky could not answer questions, could not speak to anyone. He (doctor) felt utterly wretched. Yashvin overtook him (Yashvin) with his (Yashvin) cap, and led him (Yashvin) home, and half an hour later Vronsky had regained his (Vronsky) self-possession.

But the memory of that race remained for long in his (Vronsky) heart, the cruelest and bitterest memory of his (Vronsky) life. Chapter 26

The external relations of Alexey Alexandrovitch and his (Alexandrovitch) wife had remained unchanged. The sole difference lay in the fact that he (Alexandrovitch) was more busily occupied than ever.

As in former years, at the beginning of the spring he (Alexandrovitch) had gone to a foreign watering-place for the sake of his (Alexandrovitch) health, deranged by the winter's work that every year grew heavier.

As usual, too, his (Alexandrovitch) wife had moved for the summer to a villa out of town, while he (Alexandrovitch) remained in Petersburg.

From the date of their conversation after the party at Princess Tverskaya's he (Alexandrovitch) had never spoken again to Anna of his (Alexandrovitch) suspicions and his (Alexandrovitch) jealousies, and that habitual tone of his (Alexandrovitch) bantering mimicry was the most convenient tone possible for his (Alexandrovitch) present attitude to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

And just as always he (Alexandrovitch) returned in July and at once fell to work as usual with increased energy. He (Alexandrovitch) was a little colder to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

He (Alexandrovitch) simply seemed to be slightly displeased with her (wife) for that first midnight conversation, which she (wife) had repelled. In his (Alexandrovitch) attitude to her (wife) there was a shade of vexation, but nothing more.

'' You would not be open with me,'' he (Alexandrovitch) seemed to say, mentally addressing her (wife);

``so much the worse for you.

Now you may beg as you please, but I won't be open with you. So much the worse for you! '' (he)

he (Alexandrovitch) said mentally, like a man who, after vainly attempting to extinguish a fire, should fly in a rage with his (Alexandrovitch) vain efforts and say, ``Oh, very well then!

This man, so subtle and astute in official life, did not realize all the senselessness of such an attitude to his (man) wife.

He (man) did not realize it, because it was too terrible to him (man) to realize his (man) actual position, and he (man) shut down and locked and sealed up in his (man) heart that secret place where lay hid his (man) feelings towards his (man) family, that is, his (man) wife and son.

He (man) who had been such a careful father, had from the end of that winter become peculiarly frigid to his (man) son, and adopted to him (man) just the same bantering tone he (man) used with his (man) wife.

Alexey Alexandrovitch asserted and believed that he (Alexandrovitch) had never in any previous year had so much official business as that year.

But he (Alexandrovitch) was not aware that he (Alexandrovitch) sought work for himself that year, that this was one of the means for keeping shut

that secret place where lay hid his (Alexandrovitch) feelings towards his (Alexandrovitch) wife and son and his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts about them, which became more terrible the longer they lay there.

If anyone had had the right to ask Alexey Alexandrovitch what he (Alexandrovitch) thought of his (Alexandrovitch) wife's behavior, the mild and peaceable Alexey Alexandrovitch would have made no answer, but he (Alexandrovitch) would have been greatly angered with any man who should question him (Alexandrovitch) on that subject.

For this reason there positively came into Alexey Alexandrovitch's face a look of haughtiness and severity whenever anyone inquired after his (Alexandrovitch) wife's health.

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not want to think at all about his (Alexandrovitch) wife's behavior, and he (Alexandrovitch) actually succeeded in not thinking about it at all.

Alexey Alexandrovitch's permanent summer villa was in Peterhof, and the Countess Lidia Ivanovna used as a rule to spend the summer there, close to Anna, and constantly seeing her (Anna).

That year Countess Lidia Ivanovna declined to settle in Peterhof, was not once at Anna Arkadyevna's, and in conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch hinted at the unsuitability of Anna's close intimacy with Betsy and Vronsky.

Alexey Alexandrovitch sternly cut her (Betsy) short, roundly declaring his (Alexandrovitch) wife to be above suspicion, and from that time began to avoid Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not want to see, and did not see, that many people in society cast dubious glances on his (Alexandrovitch) wife; he (Alexandrovitch) did not want to understand, and did not understand, why his (Alexandrovitch) wife had so particularly insisted on staying at Tsarskoe, where Betsy was staying, and not far from the camp of Vronsky's regiment.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not allow himself to think about it, and he (Alexandrovitch) did not think about it; but all the same though he (Alexandrovitch) never admitted it to himself, and had no proofs, not even suspicious evidence, in the bottom of his (Alexandrovitch) heart he (Alexandrovitch) knew beyond all doubt that he (Alexandrovitch) was a deceived husband, and he (Alexandrovitch) was profoundly miserable about it.

How often during those eight years of happy life with his (Alexandrovitch) wife Alexey Alexandrovitch had looked at other men's faithless wives and other deceived husbands and asked himself:

``How can people descend to that?

you shall burn for this!'' (husbands)

'' Aha, young man!'' was the greeting with which he (man) met him (man). how is it they don't put an end to such a hideous position?

But now, when the misfortune had come upon himself, he (man) was so far from thinking of putting an end to the position that he (man) would not recognize it at all, would not recognize it just because it was too awful, too unnatural.

Once he (man) dined there, another time he (man) spent the evening there with a party of friends, but he (man) had not once stayed the night there, as it had been his (man) habit to do in previous years.

The day of the races had been a very busy day for Alexey Alexandrovitch; but when mentally sketching out the day in the morning, he (Alexandrovitch) made up his (Alexandrovitch) mind to go to their country house to see his (Alexandrovitch) wife immediately after dinner, and from there to the races, which all the Court were to witness, and at which he (witness) was bound to be present.

He (witness) was going to see his (witness) wife, because he (witness) had determined to see her (wife) once a week to keep up appearances.

And besides, on that day, as it was the fifteenth, he (witness) had to give his (witness) wife some money for her (wife) expenses, according to their usual arrangement.

With his (witness) habitual control over his (witness) thoughts, though he (witness) thought all this about his (witness) wife, he (witness) did not let his (witness) thoughts stray further in regard to her (wife).

'' Since his (witness) return from abroad Alexey Alexandrovitch had twice been at their country villa. That morning was a very full one for Alexey Alexandrovitch.

The evening before, Countess Lidia Ivanovna had sent him (Alexandrovitch) a pamphlet by a celebrated traveler in China, who was staying in Petersburg, and with it she (Ivanovna) enclosed a note begging him (Alexandrovitch) to see the traveler himself, as he (Alexandrovitch) was an extremely interesting person from various points of view, and likely to be useful.

Then people began arriving with petitions, and there came the reports, interviews, appointments, dismissals, apportionment of rewards, pensions, grants, notes, the workaday round, as Alexey Alexandrovitch called it, that always took up so much time.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had not had time to read the pamphlet through in the evening, and finished it in the morning. Then there was private business of his (Alexandrovitch) own, a visit from the doctor and the steward who managed his (Alexandrovitch) property.

He (Alexandrovitch) simply gave Alexey Alexandrovitch the money he (Alexandrovitch) needed together with a brief statement of the position of his (Alexandrovitch) affairs, which was not altogether satisfactory, as it had happened that during that year, owing to increased expenses, more had been paid out than usual, and there was a deficit.

But the doctor, a celebrated Petersburg doctor, who was an intimate acquaintance of Alexey Alexandrovitch, took up a great deal of time.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had not expected him (Alexandrovitch) that day, and was surprised at his (Alexandrovitch) visit, and still more so when the doctor questioned him (doctor) very carefully about his (doctor) health, listened to his (doctor) breathing, and tapped at his (doctor) liver.

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not know that his (Alexandrovitch) friend Lidia Ivanovna, noticing that he (Alexandrovitch) was not as well as usual that year, had begged the doctor to go and examine him (doctor).

The steward did not take up much time.

``Do this for my sake,'' (Countess)
the Countess Lidia Ivanovna had said to him (steward).

'' I will do it for the sake of Russia, countess,'' replied the doctor. '' A priceless man!'' said the Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

He (man) found the liver considerably enlarged, and the digestive powers weakened, while the course of mineral waters had been quite without effect.

He (man) prescribed more physical exercise as far as possible, and as far as possible less mental strain, and above all no worry--in other words, just what was as much out of Alexey Alexandrovitch's power as abstaining from breathing.

Then he (Alexandrovitch) withdrew, leaving in Alexey Alexandrovitch an unpleasant sense that something was wrong with him (Alexandrovitch), and that there was no chance of curing it.

As he (Alexandrovitch) was coming away, the doctor chanced to meet on the staircase an acquaintance of his (doctor), Sludin, who was secretary of Alexey Alexandrovitch's department.

They had been comrades at the university, and though they rarely met, they thought highly of each other and were excellent friends, and so there was no one to whom the doctor would have given his (doctor) opinion of a patient so freely as to Sludin.

The doctor was extremely dissatisfied with Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' How glad I am you've been seeing him (Alexandrovitch)!'' said Sludin. '' He (Alexandrovitch)'s not well, and I fancy....

Well, what do you think of him (Alexandrovitch)?''

``I'll tell you,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor, beckoning over Sludin's head to his (doctor) coachman to bring the carriage round.

It's just this,'' said the doctor, taking a finger of his (doctor) kid glove in his (doctor) white hands and pulling it,

``if you don't strain the strings, and then try to break them, you'll find it a difficult job; but strain a string to its very utmost, and the mere weight of one finger on the strained string will snap it.

And with his (doctor) close assiduity, his (doctor) conscientious devotion to his (doctor) work, he (doctor)'s strained to the utmost; and there's some outside burden weighing on him (doctor), and not a light one,'' (kid)

concluded the doctor, raising his (doctor) eyebrows significantly.

'' '' Will you be at the races? '' he (doctor) added, as he (doctor) sank into his (doctor) seat in the carriage. ''

Yes, yes, to be sure; it does waste a lot of time,'' the doctor responded vaguely to some reply of Sludin's he (doctor) had not caught.

Directly after the doctor, who had taken up so much time, came the celebrated traveler, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, by means of the pamphlet he (Alexandrovitch) had only just finished reading and his (Alexandrovitch) previous acquaintance with the subject, impressed the traveler by the depth of his (Alexandrovitch) knowledge of the subject and the breadth and enlightenment of his (Alexandrovitch) view of it.

At the same time as the traveler there was announced a provincial marshal of nobility on a visit to Petersburg, with whom Alexey Alexandrovitch had to have some conversation.

After his (Alexandrovitch) departure, he (Alexandrovitch) had to finish the daily routine of business with his (Alexandrovitch) secretary, and then he (Alexandrovitch) still had to drive round to call on a certain great personage on a matter of grave and serious import.

Alexey Alexandrovitch only just managed to be back by five o'clock, his (Alexandrovitch) dinner-hour, and after dining with his (Alexandrovitch) secretary, he (Alexandrovitch) invited him (Alexandrovitch) to drive with him (Alexandrovitch) to his (Alexandrovitch) country villa and to the races.

Though he (Alexandrovitch) did not acknowledge it to himself, Alexey Alexandrovitch always tried nowadays to secure the presence of a third person in his (Alexandrovitch) interviews with his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

Chapter 27 Anna was upstairs, standing before the looking glass, and, with Annushka's assistance, pinning the last ribbon on her (Anna) gown when she (Anna) heard carriage wheels crunching the gravel at the entrance.

It's too early for Betsy,'' she (Betsy) thought, and glancing out of the window she (Betsy) caught sight of the carriage and the black hat of Alexey Alexandrovitch, and the ears that she (Betsy) knew so well sticking up each side of it.

she (Betsy) wondered, and the thought of all that might come of such a chance struck her (Betsy) as so awful and terrible that, without dwelling on it for a moment, she (Betsy) went down to meet him (Alexandrovitch) with a bright and radiant face; and conscious of the presence of that spirit of falsehood and deceit in herself that she (Betsy) had come to know of late, she (Betsy) abandoned herself to that spirit and began talking, hardly knowing what she (Betsy) was saying.

'' '' How unlucky! Can he (Alexandrovitch) be going to stay the night? '' '' Ah, how nice of you! '' she (Betsy) said, giving her (Betsy) husband her (Betsy) hand, and greeting Sludin, who was like one of the family, with a smile.

'' You're staying the night, I hope? '' was the first word the spirit of falsehood prompted her (Betsy) to utter;

``and now we'll go together.

Only it's a pity I've promised Betsy. She (Betsy)'s coming for me. '' (her)

Alexey Alexandrovitch knit his (Alexandrovitch) brows at Betsy's name. ''

Oh, I'm not going to separate the inseparables,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said in his (Alexandrovitch) usual bantering tone. '' I'm going with Mihail Vassilievitch.

I'm ordered exercise by the doctors too. I'll walk, and fancy myself at the springs again. '' '' There's no hurry,'' said Anna.

'' Would you like tea? '' She (Anna) rang.

``Bring in tea, and tell Seryozha that Alexey Alexandrovitch is here. Well, tell me, how have you been?

Mihail Vassilievitch, you've not been to see me before. Look how lovely it is out on the terrace,'' (she)

she (Anna) said, turning first to one and then to the other.

She (Anna) was the more aware of this from noticing in the inquisitive look Mihail Vassilievitch turned on her (Anna) that he (Alexandrovitch) was, as it were, keeping watch on her (Anna).

She (Anna) spoke very simply and naturally, but too much and too fast. Mihail Vassilievitch promptly went out on the terrace. She (Anna) sat down beside her (Anna) husband.

'' You don't look quite well,'' she (Anna) said. '' Yes,'' he (husband) said;

``the doctor's been with me today and wasted an hour of my time.

I feel that some one of our friends must have sent him (husband): my health's so precious, it seems.'' (he)

'' No; what did he (husband) say?

She (Anna) questioned him (husband) about his (husband) health and what he (husband) had been doing, and tried to persuade him (husband) to take a rest and come out to her (Anna).

'' All this she (Anna) said brightly, rapidly, and with a peculiar brilliance in her (Anna) eyes. But Alexey Alexandrovitch did not now attach any special significance to this tone of hers.

There was nothing remarkable in all this conversation, but never after could Anna recall this brief scene without an agonizing pang of shame.

He (Alexandrovitch) heard only her (Anna) words and gave them only the direct sense they bore. And he (Alexandrovitch) answered simply, though jestingly. Seryozha came in preceded by his (Alexandrovitch) governess.

If Alexey Alexandrovitch had allowed himself to observe he (Alexandrovitch) would have noticed the timid and bewildered eyes with which Seryozha glanced first at his (Alexandrovitch) father and then at his (Alexandrovitch) mother.

But he (Alexandrovitch) would not see anything, and he (Alexandrovitch) did not see it. '' Ah, the young man! He (Alexandrovitch)'s grown. Really, he (Alexandrovitch)'s getting quite a man.

Seryozha had been shy of his (Alexandrovitch) father before, and now, ever since Alexey Alexandrovitch had taken to calling him (Alexandrovitch) young man, and since that insoluble question had occurred to him (Alexandrovitch) whether Vronsky were a friend or a foe, he (foe) avoided his (foe) father.

How are you, young man? '' And he (foe) gave his (foe) hand to the scared child. He (foe) looked round towards his (foe) mother as though seeking shelter.

Meanwhile, Alexey Alexandrovitch was holding his (Alexandrovitch) son by the shoulder while he (Alexandrovitch) was speaking to the governess, and Seryozha was so miserably uncomfortable that Anna saw he (Alexandrovitch) was on the point of tears.

Anna, who had flushed a little the instant her (Anna) son came in, noticing that Seryozha was uncomfortable, got up hurriedly, took Alexey Alexandrovitch's hand from her (Anna) son's shoulder, and kissing the boy, led him (Alexandrovitch) out onto the terrace, and quickly came back.

It was only with his (Alexandrovitch) mother that he (Alexandrovitch) was at ease. '' It's time to start, though,'' said she (mother), glancing at her (mother) watch.

'' How is it Betsy doesn't come?... '' '' Yes,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, and getting up, he (Alexandrovitch) folded his (Alexandrovitch) hands and cracked his (Alexandrovitch) fingers.

'' I've come to bring you some money, too, for nightingales, we know, can't live on fairy tales,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. ''

You want it, I expect?'' '' No, I don't... yes, I do,'' she (fairy) said, not looking at him (Alexandrovitch), and crimsoning to the roots of her (fairy) hair.

And here's the glory of Peterhof, Princess Tverskaya,'' he (Alexandrovitch) added, looking out of the window at the elegant English carriage with the tiny seats placed extremely high.

'' But you'll come back here after the races, I suppose?'' '' Oh, yes!'' answered Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' '' What elegance!

Princess Tverskaya did not get out of her (Tverskaya) carriage, but her (Tverskaya) groom, in high boots, a cape, and black hat, darted out at the entrance.

; good-bye!'' said Anna, and kissing her (Anna) son, she (Anna) went up to Alexey Alexandrovitch and held out her (Anna) hand to him (Alexandrovitch).

Charming! Well, let us be starting too, then. '' '' I'm going '' It was ever so nice of you to come.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch kissed her (Anna) hand. '' Well, au revoir , then! You'll come back for some tea; that's delightful! ''

But as soon as she (Anna) no longer saw him (Alexandrovitch), she (Anna) was aware of the spot on her (Anna) hand that his (Alexandrovitch) lips had touched, and she (Anna) shuddered with repulsion.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch reached the race-course, Anna was already sitting in the pavilion beside Betsy, in that pavilion where all the highest society had gathered.

Two men, her (Anna) husband and her (Anna) lover, were the two centers of her (Anna) existence, and unaided by her (Anna) external senses she (Anna) was aware of their nearness.

She (Anna) was aware of her (Anna) husband approaching a long way off, and she (Anna) could not help following him (husband) in the surging crowd in the midst of which he (husband) was moving.

She (Anna) watched his (husband) progress towards the pavilion, saw him (husband) now responding condescendingly to an ingratiating bow, now exchanging friendly, nonchalant greetings with his (husband) equals, now assiduously trying to catch the eye of some great one of this world, and taking off his (husband) big round hat that squeezed the tips of his (husband) ears.

she (Anna) said, and went out, gay and radiant. Chapter 28 She (Anna) caught sight of her (Anna) husband in the distance. All these ways of his (husband) she (Anna) knew, and all were hateful to her (Anna).

``Nothing but ambition, nothing but the desire to get on, that's all there is in his (husband) soul,'' (she)
she (Anna) thought;
``as for these lofty ideals, love of culture, religion, they are only so many tools for getting on.

``I'm sure you don't see your wife: here she (Betsy) is.

'' (him)

He (Alexandrovitch) smiled his (Alexandrovitch) chilly smile. '' There's so much splendor here that one's eyes are dazzled,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, and he (Alexandrovitch) went into the pavilion.

He (Alexandrovitch) smiled to his (Alexandrovitch) wife as a man should smile on meeting his (Alexandrovitch) wife after only just parting from her (wife), and greeted the princess and other acquaintances, giving to each what was due--that is to say, jesting with the ladies and dealing out friendly greetings among the men.

Below, near the pavilion, was standing an adjutant-general of whom Alexey Alexandrovitch had a high opinion, noted for his (Alexandrovitch) intelligence and culture.

Alexey Alexandrovitch entered into conversation with him (Alexandrovitch). There was an interval between the races, and so nothing hindered conversation. The adjutant-general expressed his (Alexandrovitch) disapproval of races.

Anna heard his (Alexandrovitch) high, measured tones, not losing one word, and every word struck her (Anna) as false, and stabbed her (Anna) ears with pain.

When the three-mile steeplechase was beginning, she (Anna) bent forward and gazed with fixed eyes at Vronsky as he (Alexandrovitch) went up to his (Alexandrovitch) horse and mounted, and at the same time she (Anna) heard that loathsome, never-ceasing voice of her (Anna) husband.

She (Anna) was in an agony of terror for Vronsky, but a still greater agony was the never-ceasing, as it seemed to her (Anna), stream of her (Anna) husband's shrill voice with its familiar intonations.

Alexey Alexandrovitch replied defending them. '' I'm a wicked woman, a lost woman,'' she (woman) thought;

``but I don't like lying , I can't endure falsehood, while as for him (Alexandrovitch) -LRB-her (woman) husband-RRB- it's the breath of his (husband) life--falsehood.

He (husband) knows all about it, he (husband) sees it all; what does he (husband) care if he (husband) can talk so calmly? If he (husband) were to kill me, if he (husband) were to kill Vronsky, I might respect him (husband).

No, all he (husband) wants is falsehood and propriety,'' (she)

Anna said to herself, not considering exactly what it was she (Anna) wanted of her (Anna) husband, and how she (Anna) would have liked to see him (husband) behave.

She (Anna) did not understand either that Alexey Alexandrovitch's peculiar loquacity that day, so exasperating to her (Anna), was merely the expression of his (Alexandrovitch) inward distress and uneasiness.
