As a child that has been hurt skips about, putting all his (Alexandrovitch) muscles into movement to drown the pain, in the same way Alexey Alexandrovitch needed mental exercise to drown the thoughts of his (Alexandrovitch) wife that in her (wife) presence and in Vronsky's, and with the continual iteration of his (Alexandrovitch) name, would force themselves on his (Alexandrovitch) attention.

And it was as natural for him (Alexandrovitch) to talk well and cleverly, as it is natural for a child to skip about.

If England can point to the most brilliant feats of cavalry in military history, it is simply owing to the fact that she (wife) has historically developed this force both in beasts and in men.

He (Alexandrovitch) was saying:

``Danger in the races of officers, of cavalry men, is an essential element in the race. Sport has, in my opinion, a great value, and as is always the case, we see nothing

but what is most superficial. '' (He)

'' It's not superficial,'' said Princess Tverskaya. '' One of the officers, they say, has broken two ribs.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled his (Alexandrovitch) smile, which uncovered his (Alexandrovitch) teeth, but revealed nothing more. '' We'll admit, princess, that that's not superficial,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said,

``but internal.

But that's not the point,'' (he)

and he (Alexandrovitch) turned again to the general with whom he (Alexandrovitch) was talking seriously;
``we mustn't forget that those who are taking part in the race are military men, who have chosen that career, and one must allow that every calling has its disagreeable side.

It forms an integral part of the duties of an officer. Low sports, such as prize-fighting or Spanish bull-fights, are a sign of barbarity.

But specialized trials of skill are a sign of development. '' (he)

'' No, I shan't come another time; it's too upsetting,'' said Princess Betsy.

``Isn't it, Anna?'' (another lady)
'' It is upsetting, but one can't tear oneself away,'' said another lady. '' If I'd been a Roman woman I should never have missed a single circus.

'' Anna said nothing, and keeping her (Anna) opera glass up, gazed always at the same spot. At that moment a tall general walked through the pavilion.

Breaking off what he (Anna) was saying, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up hurriedly, though with dignity, and bowed low to the general. ''

And though the answer meant nothing, the general looked as though he (Alexandrovitch) had heard a witty remark from a witty man, and fully relished la pointe de la sauce .

You're not racing? '' the officer asked, chaffing him (officer). '' My race is a harder one,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch responded deferentially. ''

There are two aspects,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed:

``those who take part and those who look on; and love for such spectacles is an unmistakable proof of a low degree of development in the spectator, I admit, but...

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

``Princess, bets! '' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
sounded Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice from below, addressing Betsy. '' Who's your favorite?'' '' Anna and I are for Kuzovlev,'' replied Betsy.

'' I'm for Vronsky. A pair of gloves?''

``Done!'' (unknown)
'' But it is a pretty sight, isn't it? '' Alexey Alexandrovitch paused while there was talking about him (Alexandrovitch), but he (Alexandrovitch) began again directly.

'' I admit that manly sports do not... '' he (Alexandrovitch) was continuing. But at that moment the racers started, and all conversation ceased.

Alexey Alexandrovitch took no interest in the race, and so he (Alexandrovitch) did not watch the racers, but fell listlessly to scanning the spectators with his (Alexandrovitch) weary eyes.

Alexey Alexandrovitch too was silent, and everyone stood up and turned towards the stream. His (Alexandrovitch) eyes rested upon Anna. Her (Anna) face was white and set.

She (Anna) was obviously seeing nothing and no one but one man. Her (Anna) hand had convulsively clutched her (Anna) fan, and she (Anna) held her (Anna) breath.

He (fan) looked at her (Anna) and hastily turned away, scrutinizing other faces. '' But here's this lady too, and others very much moved as well

; it's very natural,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch told himself. He (Alexandrovitch) tried not to look at her (lady), but unconsciously his (Alexandrovitch) eyes were drawn to her (lady).

He (Alexandrovitch) examined that face again, trying not to read what was so plainly written on it, and against his (Alexandrovitch) own will, with horror read on it what he (Alexandrovitch) did not want to know.

Kuzovlev's, at the stream--agitated everyone, but Alexey Alexandrovitch saw distinctly on Anna's pale, triumphant face that the man she (Anna) was watching had not fallen.

When, after Mahotin and Vronsky had cleared the worst barrier, the next officer had been thrown straight on his (officer) head at it and fatally injured, and a shudder of horror passed over the whole public, Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that Anna did not even notice it, and had some difficulty in realizing what they were talking of about her (Anna).

Anna, wholly engrossed as she (Anna) was with the race, became aware of her (Anna) husband's cold eyes fixed upon her (Anna) from one side.

The first fall-- But more and more often, and with greater persistence, he (husband) watched her (Anna). She (Anna) glanced round for an instant, looked inquiringly at him (husband), and with a slight frown turned away again.

'' Ah, I don't care! '' she (Anna) seemed to say to him (husband), and she (Anna) did not once glance at him (husband) again.

The race was an unlucky one, and of the seventeen officers who rode in it more than half were thrown and hurt.

Towards the end of the race everyone was in a state of agitation, which was intensified by the fact that the Tsar was displeased.

Everyone was loudly expressing disapprobation, everyone was repeating a phrase some one had uttered--

``The lions and gladiators will be the next thing,'' (everyone)
and everyone was feeling horrified; so that when Vronsky fell to the ground, and Anna moaned aloud, there was nothing very out of the way in it.

She (Anna) began fluttering like a caged bird, at one moment would have got up and moved away, at the next turned to Betsy.

Chapter 29 But afterwards a change came over Anna's face which really was beyond decorum. She (Anna) utterly lost her (Anna) head. ''

Let us go, let us go! '' she (Anna) said. But Betsy did not hear her (Betsy). She (Betsy) was bending down, talking to a general who had come up to her (Betsy).

Let us go, if you like,'' he (general) said in French, but Anna was listening to the general and did not notice her (Anna) husband.

Alexey Alexandrovitch went up to Anna and courteously offered her (Anna) his (Alexandrovitch) arm. '' '' He (Alexandrovitch)'s broken his (Alexandrovitch) leg too, so they say,'' the general was saying.

Without answering her (Anna) husband, Anna lifted her (Anna) opera glass and gazed towards the place where Vronsky had fallen; but it was so far off, and there was such a crowd of people about it, that she (Anna) could make out nothing.

She (Anna) laid down the opera glass, and would have moved away, but at that moment an officer galloped up and made some announcement to the Tsar.

'' This is beyond everything. '' Anna craned forward, listening.

``Stiva! Stiva! '' (she)
she (Anna) cried to her (Anna) brother. But her (Anna) brother did not hear her (Anna).

Again she (Anna) would have moved away. '' Once more I offer you my arm if you want to be going,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, reaching towards her (Anna) hand.

She (Anna) drew back from him (Alexandrovitch) with aversion, and without looking in his (Alexandrovitch) face answered:

``No, no, let me be, I'll stay.

'' (him)

She (Anna) saw now that from the place of Vronsky's accident an officer was running across the course towards the pavilion.

Betsy waved her (Betsy) handkerchief to him (officer). The officer brought the news that the rider was not killed, but the horse had broken its back.

Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that she (Betsy) was weeping, and could not control her (Betsy) tears, nor even the sobs that were shaking her (Betsy) bosom.

On hearing this Anna sat down hurriedly, and hid her (Anna) face in her (Anna) fan. Alexey Alexandrovitch stood so as to screen her (Anna), giving her (Anna) time to recover herself.

'' For the third time I offer you my arm,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to her (Anna) after a little time, turning to her (Anna).

Anna gazed at him (Alexandrovitch) and did not know what to say. Princess Betsy came to her (Betsy) rescue. '' No, Alexey Alexandrovitch; I brought Anna and I promised to take her (Anna) home,'' put in Betsy.

Excuse me, princess,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, smiling courteously but looking her (Betsy) very firmly in the face,

``but I see that Anna's not very well, and I wish her (Anna) to come home with me.'' (he)

'' Anna looked about her (Anna) in a frightened way, got up submissively, and laid her (Anna) hand on her (Anna) husband's arm. ''

As they left the pavilion, Alexey Alexandrovitch, as always, talked to those he (Alexandrovitch) met, and Anna had, as always, to talk and answer; but she (Anna) was utterly beside herself, and moved hanging on her (Anna) husband's arm as though in a dream.

I'll send to him (husband) and find out, and let you know,'' Betsy whispered to her (Betsy). '' Is he (husband) killed or not?

Is it true? Will he (husband) come or not? Shall I see him (husband) today? '' she (Betsy) was thinking. She (Betsy) took her (Betsy) seat in her (Betsy) husband's carriage in silence, and in silence drove out of the crowd of carriages.

In spite of all he (husband) had seen, Alexey Alexandrovitch still did not allow himself to consider his (Alexandrovitch) wife's real condition. He (Alexandrovitch) merely saw the outward symptoms.

He (Alexandrovitch) saw that she (wife) was behaving unbecomingly, and considered it his (Alexandrovitch) duty to tell her (wife) so. But it was very difficult for him (Alexandrovitch) not to say more, to tell her (wife) nothing but that.

He (Alexandrovitch) opened his (Alexandrovitch) mouth to tell her (wife) she (wife) had behaved unbecomingly, but he (Alexandrovitch) could not help saying something utterly different. ''

What an inclination we all have, though, for these cruel spectacles,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. '' I observe... ''

``Eh? I don't understand,'' (I)
said Anna contemptuously.

He (Alexandrovitch) was offended, and at once began to say what he (Alexandrovitch) had meant to say. '' I am obliged to tell you,'' he (Alexandrovitch) began.

'' So now we are to have it out,'' she (Anna) thought, and she (Anna) felt frightened. '' I am obliged to tell you that your behavior has been unbecoming today,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to her (Anna) in French.

she (Anna) said aloud, turning her (Anna) head swiftly and looking him (Alexandrovitch) straight in the face, not with the bright expression that seemed covering something, but with a look of determination, under which she (Anna) concealed with difficulty the dismay she (Anna) was feeling.

'' In what way has my behavior been unbecoming? '' '' Mind,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, pointing to the open window opposite the coachman.

He (Alexandrovitch) got up and pulled up the window. '' What did you consider unbecoming? '' she (Anna) repeated. '' The despair you were unable to conceal at the accident to one of the riders.

I have already begged you so to conduct yourself in society that even malicious tongues can find nothing to say against you.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) waited for her (Anna) to answer, but she (Anna) was silent, looking straight before her (Anna). '' There was a time when I spoke of your inward attitude, but I am not speaking of that now.

Now I speak only of your external attitude. You have behaved improperly, and I would wish it not to occur again.

She (Anna) did not hear half of what he (Alexandrovitch) was saying; she (Anna) felt panic-stricken before him (Alexandrovitch), and was thinking whether it was true that Vronsky was not killed.

Was it of him (Alexandrovitch) they were speaking when they said the rider was unhurt, but the horse had broken its back?

She (Anna) merely smiled with a pretense of irony when he (rider) finished, and made no reply, because she (Anna) had not heard what he (rider) said.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had begun to speak boldly, but as he (Alexandrovitch) realized plainly what he (Alexandrovitch) was speaking of, the dismay she (Anna) was feeling infected him (Alexandrovitch) too.

Yes, she (Anna) will tell me directly what she (Anna) told me before; that there is no foundation for my suspicions, that it's absurd.

At that moment, when the revelation of everything was hanging over him (Alexandrovitch), there was nothing he (Alexandrovitch) expected so much as that she (Anna) would answer mockingly as before that his (Alexandrovitch) suspicions were absurd and utterly groundless.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) saw the smile, and a strange misapprehension came over him (Alexandrovitch). '' She (Anna) is smiling at my suspicions. '' So terrible to him (Alexandrovitch) was what he (Alexandrovitch) knew that now he (Alexandrovitch) was ready to believe anything.

But the expression of her (Anna) face, scared and gloomy, did not now promise even deception. '' Possibly I was mistaken,'' said he (Alexandrovitch).

'' If so, I beg your pardon.'' '' No, you were not mistaken,'' she (Anna) said deliberately, looking desperately into his (Alexandrovitch) cold face.

'' You were not mistaken. I was, and I could not help being in despair. I hear you, but I am thinking of him (Alexandrovitch).

I love him (Alexandrovitch), I am his (Alexandrovitch) mistress; I can't bear you; I'm afraid of you, and I hate you.... You can do what you like to me.

'' And dropping back into the corner of the carriage, she (mistress) broke into sobs, hiding her (mistress) face in her (mistress) hands. Alexey Alexandrovitch did not stir, and kept looking straight before him (Alexandrovitch).

But his (Alexandrovitch) whole face suddenly bore the solemn rigidity of the dead, and his (Alexandrovitch) expression did not change during the whole time of the drive home.

On reaching the house he (Alexandrovitch) turned his (Alexandrovitch) head to her (mistress), still with the same expression. '' Very well! But I expect a strict observance of the external forms of propriety till such time''--his (Alexandrovitch) voice

shook--

``as I may take measures to secure my honor and communicate them to you. '' (I)
He (Alexandrovitch) got out first and helped her (mistress) to get out.

Before the servants he (Alexandrovitch) pressed her (mistress) hand, took his (Alexandrovitch) seat in the carriage, and drove back to Petersburg. Immediately afterwards a footman came from Princess Betsy and brought Anna a note.

'' I sent to Alexey to find out how he (Alexey) is, and he (Alexey) writes me he (Alexey) is quite well and unhurt, but in despair.''

'' So he (Alexey) will be here,'' she (Anna) thought. '' What a good thing I told him (Alexey) all!'' She (Anna) glanced at her (Anna) watch.

She (Anna) had still three hours to wait, and the memories of their last meeting set her (Anna) blood in flame. '' My God, how light it is!

It's dreadful, but I do love to see his (God) face, and I do love this fantastic light.... My husband! Oh! yes....

In the little German watering-place to which the Shtcherbatskys had betaken themselves, as in all places indeed where people are gathered together, the usual process, as it were, of the crystallization of society went on, assigning to each member of that society a definite and unalterable place.

Just as the particle of water in frost, definitely and unalterably, takes the special form of the crystal of snow, so each new person that arrived at the springs was at once placed in his (member) special place.

F√ºrst Shtcherbatsky, sammt Gemahlin und Tochter , by the apartments they took, and from their name and from the friends they made, were immediately crystallized into a definite place marked out for them.

There was visiting the watering-place that year a real German F√ºrstin, in consequence of which the crystallizing process went on more vigorously than ever.

Princess Shtcherbatskaya wished, above everything, to present her (Shtcherbatskaya) daughter to this German princess, and the day after their arrival she (Shtcherbatskaya) duly performed this rite.

Kitty made a low and graceful curtsey in the very simple , that is to say, very elegant frock that had been ordered her (Kitty) from Paris.

The German princess said,

``I hope the roses will soon come back to this pretty little face,'' (The princess)
and for the Shtcherbatskys certain definite lines of existence were at once laid down from which there was no departing.

The Shtcherbatskys made the acquaintance too of the family of an English Lady Somebody, and of a German countess and her (countess) son, wounded in the last war, and of a learned Swede, and of M. Canut and his (Swede) sister.

But yet inevitably the Shtcherbatskys were thrown most into the society of a Moscow lady, Marya Yevgenyevna Rtishtcheva and her (lady) daughter, whom Kitty disliked, because she (Kitty) had fallen ill, like herself, over a love affair, and a Moscow colonel, whom Kitty had known from childhood, and always seen in uniform and epaulets, and who now, with his (colonel) little eyes and his (colonel) open neck and flowered cravat, was uncommonly ridiculous and tedious, because there was no getting rid of him (colonel).

When all this was so firmly established, Kitty began to be very much bored, especially as the prince went away to Carlsbad

Well, thank God! everything's over with him (God). '' Chapter 30 and she (Kitty) was left alone with her (Kitty) mother. She (Kitty) took no interest in the people she (Kitty) knew, feeling that nothing fresh would come of them.

Her (Kitty) chief mental interest in the watering-place consisted in watching and making theories about the people she (Kitty) did not know. It was characteristic of Kitty that she (Kitty) always imagined everything in people in the most favorable light possible,

And now as she (Kitty) made surmises as to who people were, what were their relations to one another, and what they were like, Kitty endowed them with the most marvelous and noble characters, and found confirmation of her (Kitty) idea in her (Kitty) observations.

Of these people the one that attracted her (Kitty) most was a Russian girl who had come to the watering-place with an invalid Russian lady, Madame Stahl, as everyone called her (lady).

Madame Stahl belonged to the highest society, but she (lady) was so ill that she (lady) could not walk, and only on exceptionally fine days made her (lady) appearance at the springs in an invalid carriage.

But it was not so much from ill-health as from pride--so Princess Shtcherbatskaya interpreted it--that Madame Stahl had not made the acquaintance of anyone among the Russians there.

The Russian girl looked after Madame Stahl, and besides that, she (girl) was, as Kitty observed, on friendly terms with all the invalids who were seriously ill, and there were many of them at the springs, and looked after them in the most natural way.

especially so in those she (Kitty) did not know. This Russian girl was not, as Kitty gathered, related to Madame Stahl, nor was she (Kitty) a paid attendant.

Apart from the interest Kitty took in this girl's relations with Madame Stahl and with other unknown persons, Kitty, as often happened, felt an inexplicable attraction to Mademoiselle Varenka, and was aware when their eyes met that she (Kitty) too liked her (Kitty).

Of Mademoiselle Varenka one would not say that she (Kitty) had passed her (Kitty) first youth, but she (Kitty) was, as it were, a creature without youth; she (Kitty) might have been taken for nineteen or for thirty.

If her (Kitty) features were criticized separately, she (Kitty) was handsome rather than plain, in spite of the sickly hue of her (Kitty) face.

She (Kitty) would have been a good figure, too, if it had not been for her (Kitty) extreme thinness and the size of her (Kitty) head, which was too large for her (Kitty) medium height.

Madame Stahl called her (Kitty) Varenka, and other people called her (Kitty)

``Mademoiselle Varenka. '' (her)
But she (Kitty) was not likely to be attractive to men.

Moreover, she (Kitty) would have been unattractive to men also from the lack of just what Kitty had too much of--of the suppressed fire of vitality, and the consciousness of her (Kitty) own attractiveness.

She (Kitty) always seemed absorbed in work about which there could be no doubt, and so it seemed she (Kitty) could not take interest in anything outside it.

She (Kitty) was like a fine flower, already past its bloom and without fragrance, though the petals were still unwithered. It was just this contrast with her (Kitty) own position that was for Kitty the great attraction of Mademoiselle Varenka.

Kitty felt that in her (Kitty), in her (Kitty) manner of life, she (Kitty) would find an example of what she (Kitty) was now so painfully seeking: interest in life, a dignity in life--apart from the worldly relations of girls with men, which so revolted Kitty, and appeared to her (Kitty) now as a shameful hawking about of goods in search of a purchaser.

The more attentively Kitty watched her (Kitty) unknown friend, the more convinced she (Kitty) was this girl was the perfect creature she (Kitty) fancied her (Kitty), and the more eagerly she (Kitty) wished to make her (Kitty) acquaintance.

The two girls used to meet several times a day, and every time they met, Kitty's eyes said:

``Who are you?

But for goodness' sake don't suppose,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

her (Kitty) eyes added,
``that I would force my acquaintance on you, I simply admire you and like you.'' (unknown)

What are you? Are you really the exquisite creature I imagine you to be?

``I like you too, and you're very, very sweet.

And I should like you better still, if I had time,'' (the girl)

answered the eyes of the unknown girl. Kitty saw indeed, that she (Kitty) was always busy.

Either she (Kitty) was taking the children of a Russian family home from the springs, or fetching a shawl for a sick lady, and wrapping her (lady) up in it, or trying to interest an irritable invalid, or selecting and buying cakes for tea for someone.

Soon after the arrival of the Shtcherbatskys there appeared in the morning crowd at the springs two persons who attracted universal and unfavorable attention.

These were a tall man with a stooping figure, and huge hands, in an old coat too short for him (man), with black, simple, and yet terrible eyes, and a pockmarked, kind-looking woman, very badly and tastelessly dressed.

But the princess, having ascertained from the visitors' list that this was Nikolay Levin and Marya Nikolaevna, explained to Kitty what a bad man this Levin was, and all her (Kitty) fancies about these two people vanished.

Not so much from what her (Kitty) mother told her (Kitty), as from the fact that it was Konstantin's brother, this pair suddenly seemed to Kitty intensely unpleasant.

Recognizing these persons as Russians, Kitty had already in her (Kitty) imagination begun constructing a delightful and touching romance about them. This Levin, with his (Levin) continual twitching of his (Levin) head, aroused in her (Kitty) now an irrepressible feeling of disgust.

It seemed to her (Kitty) that his (Levin) big, terrible eyes, which persistently pursued her (Kitty), expressed a feeling of hatred and contempt, and she (Kitty) tried to avoid meeting him (Levin).

It was a wet day; it had been raining all the morning, and the invalids, with their parasols, had flocked into the arcades.

Kitty was walking there with her (Kitty) mother and the Moscow colonel, smart and jaunty in his (colonel) European coat, bought ready-made at Frankfort.

Chapter 31 They were walking on one side of the arcade, trying to avoid Levin, who was walking on the other side.

Varenka, in her (Kitty) dark dress, in a black hat with a turn-down brim, was walking up and down the whole length of the arcade with a blind Frenchwoman, and, every time she (Frenchwoman) met Kitty, they exchanged friendly glances.

Mamma, couldn't I speak to her (Kitty)?'' said Kitty, watching her (Kitty) unknown friend, and noticing that she (Kitty) was going up to the spring, and that they might come there together.

Oh, if you want to so much, I'll find out about her (Kitty) first and make her (Kitty) acquaintance myself,'' answered her (Kitty) mother.

If you like, I'll make acquaintance with Madame Stahl; I used to know her (Kitty) belle-soeur ,'' added the princess, lifting her (Kitty) head haughtily.

'' '' '' What do you see in her (Kitty) out of the way? A companion, she (Kitty) must be. Kitty knew that the princess was offended that Madame Stahl had seemed to avoid making her (Kitty) acquaintance.

Kitty did not insist. '' How wonderfully sweet she (Kitty) is! '' she (Kitty) said, gazing at Varenka just as she (Kitty) handed a glass to the Frenchwoman.

'' Look how natural and sweet it all is.'' '' It's so funny to see your engouements ,'' said the princess.

No, we'd better go back,'' she (princess) added, noticing Levin coming towards them with his (Levin) companion and a German doctor, to whom he (Levin) was talking very noisily and angrily.

'' They turned to go back, when suddenly they heard, not noisy talk, but shouting. Levin, stopping short, was shouting at the doctor, and the doctor, too, was excited.

The princess and Kitty beat a hasty retreat, while the colonel joined the crowd to find out what was the matter.

A crowd gathered about them. A few minutes later the colonel overtook them. '' What was it?'' inquired the princess. ''

That tall gentleman was abusing the doctor, flinging all sorts of insults at him (doctor) because he (doctor) wasn't treating him (doctor) quite as he (doctor) liked, and he (doctor) began waving his (doctor) stick at him (doctor).

Scandalous and disgraceful!'' answered the colonel. '' The one thing to be dreaded is meeting Russians abroad. It's simply a scandal!''

'' Oh, how unpleasant!'' said the princess. '' Well, and how did it end?'' '' Luckily at that point that...the one in the mushroom hat... intervened.

A Russian lady, I think she (lady) is,'' said the colonel. '' Mademoiselle Varenka? '' asked Kitty. '' Yes, yes. She (Kitty) came to the rescue before anyone; she (Kitty) took the man by the arm and led him (man) away.

The next day, as she (Kitty) watched her (Kitty) unknown friend, Kitty noticed that Mademoiselle Varenka was already on the same terms with Levin and his (Levin) companion as with her (Kitty) other prot√©g√©s .

She (Kitty) went up to them, entered into conversation with them, and served as interpreter for the woman, who could not speak any foreign language.

'' '' There, mamma,'' said Kitty;

``you wonder that I'm enthusiastic about her (Kitty). '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Kitty began to entreat her (Kitty) mother still more urgently to let her (Kitty) make friends with Varenka.

And, disagreeable as it was to the princess to seem to take the first step in wishing to make the acquaintance of Madame Stahl, who thought fit to give herself airs, she (princess) made inquiries about Varenka, and, having ascertained particulars about her (princess) tending to prove that there could be no harm though little good in the acquaintance, she (princess) herself approached Varenka and made acquaintance with her (princess).

Choosing a time when her (princess) daughter had gone to the spring, while Varenka had stopped outside the baker's, the princess went up to her (princess).

``Allow me to make your acquaintance,'' (she)
she (princess) said, with her (princess) dignified smile. '' My daughter has lost her (princess) heart to you,'' she (princess) said.

'' Possibly you do not know me. I am...'' '' That feeling is more than reciprocal, princess,'' Varenka answered hurriedly. ''

What a good deed you did yesterday to our poor compatriot! '' said the princess. Varenka flushed a little. '' I don't remember.

I don't think I did anything,'' she (princess) said. '' Why, you saved that Levin from disagreeable consequences. ''

``Yes, sa compagne called me, and I tried to pacify him (Levin)

, he (Levin)'s very ill, and was dissatisfied with the doctor. I'm used to looking after such invalids.'' (I)

'' Yes, I've heard you live at Mentone with your aunt--I think-- Madame Stahl:

I call her (aunt) mamma, but I am not related to her (aunt); I was brought up by her (aunt),'' answered Varenka, flushing a little again.

This was so simply said, and so sweet was the truthful and candid expression of her (aunt) face, that the princess saw why Kitty had taken such a fancy to Varenka.

I used to know her (Kitty) belle-soeur .'' '' No, she (Kitty)'s not my aunt. '' Well, and what's this Levin going to do?'' asked the princess.

At that instant Kitty came up from the spring beaming with delight that her (Kitty) mother had become acquainted with her (Kitty) unknown friend.

'' He (friend)'s going away,'' answered Varenka. '' Well, see, Kitty, your intense desire to make friends with Mademoiselle...''

``Varenka,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
Varenka put in smiling,
``that's what everyone calls me.'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)

Kitty blushed with pleasure, and slowly, without speaking, pressed her (Kitty) new friend's hand, which did not respond to her (Kitty) pressure, but lay motionless in her (Kitty) hand.

The hand did not respond to her (Kitty) pressure, but the face of Mademoiselle Varenka glowed with a soft, glad, though rather mournful smile, that showed large but handsome teeth.

Oh, no, I'm not at all busy,'' answered Varenka, but at that moment she (Kitty) had to leave her (Kitty) new friends because two little Russian girls, children of an invalid, ran up to her (Kitty).

'' I have long wished for this too,'' she (Kitty) said. '' But you are so busy. '' ''

``Varenka, mamma's calling!

The particulars which the princess had learned in regard to Varenka's past and her (princess) relations with Madame Stahl were as follows:

'' (unknown)

they cried. And Varenka went after them. Chapter 32 Madame Stahl, of whom some people said that she (princess) had worried her (princess) husband out of his (Stahl) life,

while others said it was he (Stahl) who had made her (princess) wretched by his (Stahl) immoral behavior, had always been a woman of weak health and enthusiastic temperament.

When, after her (princess) separation from her (princess) husband, she (princess) gave birth to her (princess) only child, the child had died almost immediately, and the family of Madame Stahl, knowing her (princess) sensibility, and fearing the news would kill her (princess), had substituted another child, a baby born the same night and in the same house in Petersburg, the daughter of the chief cook of the Imperial Household.

Madame Stahl learned later on that Varenka was not her (daughter) own child, but she (daughter) went on bringing her (daughter) up, especially as very soon afterwards

This was Varenka. Varenka had not a relation of her (daughter) own living. Madame Stahl had now been living more than ten years continuously abroad, in the south, never leaving her (daughter) couch.

And some people said that Madame Stahl had made her (daughter) social position as a philanthropic, highly religious woman; other people said she (daughter) really was at heart the highly ethical being, living for nothing but the good of her (daughter) fellow creatures, which she (daughter) represented herself to be.

No one knew what her (daughter) faith was--Catholic, Protestant, or Orthodox. But one fact was indubitable--she (daughter) was in amicable relations with the highest dignitaries of all the churches and sects.

Varenka lived with her (daughter) all the while abroad, and everyone who knew Madame Stahl knew and liked Mademoiselle Varenka, as everyone called her (daughter).

Having learned all these facts, the princess found nothing to object to in her (princess) daughter's intimacy with Varenka, more especially as Varenka's breeding and education were of the best--she (princess) spoke French and English extremely well--and what was of the most weight, brought a message from Madame Stahl expressing her (princess) regret that she (princess) was prevented by her (princess) ill health from making the acquaintance of the princess.

After getting to know Varenka, Kitty became more and more fascinated by her (Kitty) friend, and every day she (Kitty) discovered new virtues in her (Kitty).

The princess, hearing that Varenka had a good voice, asked her (Kitty) to come and sing to them in the evening. ''

Kitty plays, and we have a piano; not a good one, it's true, but you will give us so much pleasure,'' said the princess with her (princess) affected smile, which Kitty disliked particularly just then, because she (Kitty) noticed that Varenka had no inclination to sing.

Varenka came, however, in the evening and brought a roll of music with her (Kitty). The princess had invited Marya Yevgenyevna and her (princess) daughter and the colonel.

Varenka seemed quite unaffected by there being persons present she (princess) did not know, and she (princess) went directly to the piano. She (princess) could not accompany herself, but she (princess) could sing music at sight very well.

Kitty, who played well, accompanied her (Kitty). '' You have an extraordinary talent,'' the princess said to her (princess) after Varenka had sung the first song extremely well.

Marya Yevgenyevna and her (Yevgenyevna) daughter expressed their thanks and admiration. '' Look,'' said the colonel, looking out of the window,

``what an audience has collected to listen to you.

'' (the colonel)

There actually was quite a considerable crowd under the windows. '' I am very glad it gives you pleasure,'' Varenka answered simply.

She (Yevgenyevna) was enchanted by her (Yevgenyevna) talent, and her (Yevgenyevna) voice, and her (Yevgenyevna) face, but most of all by her (Yevgenyevna) manner, by the way Varenka obviously thought nothing of her (Yevgenyevna) singing and was quite unmoved by their praises.

Kitty looked with pride at her (Kitty) friend. She (Kitty) seemed only to be asking:

``Am I to sing again, or is that enough?'' (She)

'' If it had been I,'' thought Kitty,

``how proud I should have been! How delighted I should have been to see that crowd under the windows!

But she (Kitty)'s utterly unmoved by it. Her (Kitty) only motive is to avoid refusing and to please mamma. What is there in her (Kitty)?

What is it gives her (Kitty) the power to look down on everything, to be calm independently of everything? How I should like to know it and to learn it of her (Kitty)!

The princess asked Varenka to sing again, and Varenka sang another song, also smoothly, distinctly, and well, standing erect at the piano and beating time on it with her (princess) thin, dark-skinned hand.

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

thought Kitty, gazing into her (Kitty) serene face. The next song in the book was an Italian one. Kitty played the opening bars, and looked round at Varenka.

'' Let's skip that,'' said Varenka, flushing a little. Kitty let her (Kitty) eyes rest on Varenka's face, with a look of dismay and inquiry.

Very well, the next one,'' she (Kitty) said hurriedly, turning over the pages, and at once feeling that there was something connected with the song.

'' '' No,'' answered Varenka with a smile, laying her (Kitty) hand on the music,

``no, let's have that one. '' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
And she (Kitty) sang it just as quietly, as coolly, and as well as the others.

When she (Kitty) had finished, they all thanked her (Kitty) again, and went off to tea. Kitty and Varenka went out into the little garden that adjoined the house.

'' Am I right, that you have some reminiscences connected with that song? '' said Kitty. '' Don't tell me,'' she (Kitty) added hastily,

``only say if I'm right.'' (she)

'' No, why not? I'll tell you simply,'' said Varenka, and, without waiting for a reply, she (Kitty) went on:

``Yes, it brings up memories, once painful ones.

I cared for someone once, and I used to sing him (you) that song. '' (she)

Kitty with big, wide-open eyes gazed silently, sympathetically at Varenka.

I cared for him (you), and he (you) cared for me; but his (you) mother did not wish it, and he (you) married another girl.

You didn't think I had a love story too,'' she (girl) said, and there was a faint gleam in her (girl) handsome face of that fire which Kitty felt must once have glowed all over her (Kitty).

'' He (you)'s living now not far from us, and I see him (you) sometimes. '' I didn't think so? Why, if I were a man, I could never care for anyone else after knowing you.

Only I can't understand how he (man) could, to please his (man) mother, forget you and make you unhappy; he (man) had no heart.''

'' Oh, no, he (man)'s a very good man, and I'm not unhappy; quite the contrary , I'm very happy. Well, so we shan't be singing any more now,'' she (mother) added, turning towards the house.

'' How good you are! how good you are! '' cried Kitty, and stopping her (Kitty), she (Kitty) kissed her (Kitty). '' If I could only be even a little like you!''

``Why should you be like anyone? You're nice as you are,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka, smiling her (Kitty) gentle, weary smile. '' No, I'm not nice at all.

Come, tell me.... Stop a minute, let's sit down,'' said Kitty, making her (Kitty) sit down again beside her (Kitty). '' Tell me, isn't it humiliating to think that a man has disdained your love, that he (man) hasn't cared for it?...''

but if it hadn't been on account of his (man) mother, if it had been his (man) own doing?...'' said Kitty, feeling she (Kitty) was giving away her (Kitty) secret, and that her (Kitty) face, burning with the flush of shame, had betrayed her (Kitty) already.

'' But he (man) didn't disdain it; I believe he (man) cared for me, but he (man) was a dutiful son...'' '' Yes, ''

In that case he (man) would have done wrong, and I should not have regretted him (man),'' answered Varenka, evidently realizing that they were now talking not of her (Kitty), but of Kitty.

But the humiliation,'' said Kitty,

``the humiliation one can never forget, can never forget,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
she (Kitty) said, remembering her (Kitty) look at the last ball during the pause in the music.

'' '' Where is the humiliation? Why, you did nothing wrong?''

``Worse than wrong--shameful. '' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
Varenka shook her (Kitty) head and laid her (Kitty) hand on Kitty's hand.

'' Why, what is there shameful? '' she (Kitty) said. '' You didn't tell a man, who didn't care for you, that you loved him (man), did you?''

``Of course not ; I never said a word, but he (man) knew it. No, no, there are looks, there are ways

; I can't forget it, if I live a hundred years. '' (unknown)

``Why so? I don't understand. The whole point is whether you love him (man) now or not,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka, who called everything by its name.

'' I hate him (man); I can't forgive myself.''

``Why, what for?'' (unknown)
'' The shame, the humiliation!'' '' Oh! if everyone were as sensitive as you are!'' said Varenka.

'' There isn't a girl who hasn't been through the same. And it's all so unimportant. ''

``Why, what is important?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
said Kitty, looking into her (Kitty) face with inquisitive wonder.

'' Oh, there's so much that's important,'' said Varenka, smiling. '' Why, what?'' '' Oh, so much that's more important,'' answered Varenka, not knowing what to say.

But at that instant they heard the princess's voice from the window. '' Kitty, it's cold! Either get a shawl, or come indoors.

''

``It really is time to go in!'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka, getting up. '' I have to go on to Madame Berthe's; she (Kitty) asked me to.''

Kitty held her (Kitty) by the hand, and with passionate curiosity and entreaty her (Kitty) eyes asked her (Kitty):

``What is it, what is this of such importance that gives you such tranquillity?

She (Kitty) merely thought that she (Kitty) had to go to see Madame Berthe too that evening, and to make haste home in time for maman's tea at twelve o'clock.

You know, tell me!'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

But Varenka did not even know what Kitty's eyes were asking her (Kitty). She (Kitty) went indoors, collected her (Kitty) music, and saying good-bye to everyone, was about to go.

``Allow me to see you home,'' (the colonel)
said the colonel. '' Yes, how can you go alone at night like this? '' chimed in the princess.

'' Anyway, I'll send Parasha. '' Kitty saw that Varenka could hardly restrain a smile at the idea that she (Kitty) needed an escort.

And kissing Kitty once more, without saying what was important, she (Kitty) stepped out courageously with the music under her (Kitty) arm and vanished into the twilight of the summer night, bearing away with her (Kitty) her (Kitty) secret of what was important and what gave her (Kitty) the calm and dignity so much to be envied.

Chapter 33 Kitty made the acquaintance of Madame Stahl too, and this acquaintance, together with her (Kitty) friendship with Varenka, did not merely exercise a great influence on her (Kitty), it also comforted her (Kitty) in her (Kitty) mental distress.

She (Kitty) found this comfort through a completely new world being opened to her (Kitty) by means of this acquaintance, a world having nothing in common with her (Kitty) past, an exalted, noble world, from the height of which she (Kitty) could contemplate her (Kitty) past calmly.

It was revealed to her (Kitty) that besides the instinctive life to which Kitty had given herself up hitherto there was a spiritual life.

This life was disclosed in religion, but a religion having nothing in common with that one which Kitty had known from childhood, and which found expression in litanies and all-night services at the Widow's Home, where one might meet one's friends, and in learning by heart Slavonic texts with the priest.

This was a lofty, mysterious religion connected with a whole series of noble thoughts and feelings, which one could do more than merely believe because one was told to, which one could love.

'' No, I always go about alone and nothing ever happens to me,'' she (Kitty) said, taking her (Kitty) hat. Kitty found all this out not from words.

Madame Stahl talked to Kitty as to a charming child that one looks on with pleasure as on the memory of one's youth, and only once she (Kitty) said in passing that in all human sorrows nothing gives comfort but love and faith, and that in the sight of Christ's compassion for us no sorrow is trifling--and immediately talked of other things.

But in every gesture of Madame Stahl, in every word, in every heavenly--as Kitty called it--look, and above all in the whole story of her (Kitty) life, which she (Kitty) heard from Varenka, Kitty recognized that something

``that was important,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
of which, till then, she (Kitty) had known nothing.

Yet, elevated as Madame Stahl's character was, touching as was her (Kitty) story, and exalted and moving as was her (Kitty) speech, Kitty could not help detecting in her (Kitty) some traits which perplexed her (Kitty).

She (Kitty) noticed that when questioning her (Kitty) about her (Kitty) family, Madame Stahl had smiled contemptuously, which was not in accord with Christian meekness.

She (Kitty) noticed, too, that when she (Kitty) had found a Catholic priest with her (Kitty), Madame Stahl had studiously kept her (Kitty) face in the shadow of the lamp-shade and had smiled in a peculiar way.

But on the other hand Varenka, alone in the world, without friends or relations, with a melancholy disappointment in the past, desiring nothing, regretting nothing, was just that perfection of which Kitty dared hardly dream.

In Varenka she (Kitty) realized that one has but to forget oneself and love others, and one will be calm, happy, and noble.

Trivial as these two observations were, they perplexed her (Kitty), and she (Kitty) had her (Kitty) doubts as to Madame Stahl. And that was what Kitty longed to be.

Seeing now clearly what was the most important , Kitty was not satisfied with being enthusiastic over it; she (Kitty) at once gave herself up with her (Kitty) whole soul to the new life that was opening to her (Kitty).

From Varenka's accounts of the doings of Madame Stahl and other people whom she (Kitty) mentioned, Kitty had already constructed the plan of her (Kitty) own future life.

She (Kitty) would, like Madame Stahl's niece, Aline, of whom Varenka had talked to her (Aline) a great deal, seek out those who were in trouble, wherever she (Aline) might be living, help them as far as she (Aline) could, give them the Gospel, read the Gospel to the sick, to criminals, to the dying.

The idea of reading the Gospel to criminals, as Aline did, particularly fascinated Kitty. But all these were secret dreams, of which Kitty did not talk either to her (Kitty) mother or to Varenka.

While awaiting the time for carrying out her (Kitty) plans on a large scale, however, Kitty, even then at the springs, where there were so many people ill and unhappy, readily found a chance for practicing her (Kitty) new principles in imitation of Varenka.

At first the princess noticed nothing but that Kitty was much under the influence of her (Kitty) engouement , as she (Kitty) called it, for Madame Stahl, and still more for Varenka.

She (Kitty) saw that Kitty did not merely imitate Varenka in her (Kitty) conduct, but unconsciously imitated her (Kitty) in her (Kitty) manner of walking, of talking, of blinking her (Kitty) eyes.

But later on the princess noticed that, apart from this adoration, some kind of serious spiritual change was taking place in her (Kitty) daughter.

The princess saw that in the evenings Kitty read a French testament that Madame Stahl had given her (Kitty)--a thing she (Kitty) had never done before; that she (Kitty) avoided society acquaintances and associated with the sick people who were under Varenka's protection, and especially one poor family, that of a sick painter, Petrov.

All this was well enough, and the princess had nothing to say against it, especially as Petrov's wife was a perfectly nice sort of woman, and that the German princess, noticing Kitty's devotion, praised her (Kitty), calling her (Kitty) an angel of consolation.

Kitty was unmistakably proud of playing the part of a sister of mercy in that family. All this would have been very well, if there had been no exaggeration.

But the princess saw that her (princess) daughter was rushing into extremes, and so indeed she (princess) told her (princess). '' Il ne faut jamais rien outrer ,'' she (princess) said to her (princess).

Her (princess) daughter made her (princess) no reply, only in her (princess) heart she (princess) thought that one could not talk about exaggeration where Christianity was concerned.

What exaggeration could there be in the practice of a doctrine wherein one was bidden to turn the other cheek when one was smitten, and give one's cloak if one's coat were taken?

But the princess disliked this exaggeration, and disliked even more the fact that she (princess) felt her (princess) daughter did not care to show her (daughter) all her (daughter) heart.

She (daughter) concealed them not because she (daughter) did not respect or did not love her (daughter) mother, but simply because she (daughter) was her (daughter) mother.

Kitty did in fact conceal her (Kitty) new views and feelings from her (Kitty) mother. She (Kitty) would have revealed them to anyone sooner than to her (Kitty) mother.

'' How is it Anna Pavlovna's not been to see us for so long? '' the princess said one day of Madame Petrova.

'' I've asked her (princess), but she (princess) seems put out about something. '' '' No, I've not noticed it, maman,'' said Kitty, flushing hotly.

We're meaning to make an expedition to the mountains tomorrow,'' answered Kitty,

``Well, you can go,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
answered the princess, gazing at her (Kitty) daughter's embarrassed face and trying to guess the cause of her (Kitty) embarrassment.

That day Varenka came to dinner and told them that Anna Pavlovna had changed her (Pavlovna) mind and given up the expedition for the morrow.

'' Is it long since you went to see them?'' '' And the princess noticed again that Kitty reddened. '' Kitty, haven't you had some misunderstanding with the Petrovs?'' said the princess, when they were left alone.

Kitty answered that nothing had happened between them, and that she (Kitty) could not tell why Anna Pavlovna seemed displeased with her (Pavlovna).

'' Why has she (Pavlovna) given up sending the children and coming to see us?'' Kitty answered perfectly truly. She (Kitty) did not know the reason Anna Pavlovna had changed to her (Pavlovna), but she (Pavlovna) guessed it.

It was one of those things which one knows but which one can never speak of even to oneself, so terrible and shameful

She (Pavlovna) guessed at something which she (Pavlovna) could not tell her (Pavlovna) mother, which she (Pavlovna) did not put into words to herself. would it be to be mistaken.

She (Pavlovna) remembered the simple delight expressed on the round, good-humored face of Anna Pavlovna at their meetings; she (Pavlovna) remembered their secret confabulations about the invalid, their plots to draw him (Pavlovna) away from the work which was forbidden him (Pavlovna), and to get him (Pavlovna) out-of-doors; the devotion of the youngest boy, who used to call her (Pavlovna)

``my Kitty,'' (the boy)
and would not go to bed without her (Kitty).

Then she (Kitty) recalled the thin, terribly thin figure of Petrov, with his (Petrov) long neck, in his (Petrov) brown coat, his (Petrov) scant, curly hair, his (Petrov) questioning blue eyes that were so terrible to Kitty at first, and his (Petrov) painful attempts to seem hearty and lively in her (Kitty) presence.

She (Kitty) recalled the efforts she (Kitty) had made at first to overcome the repugnance she (Kitty) felt for him (Petrov), as for all consumptive people, and the pains it had cost her (Kitty) to think of things to say to him (Petrov).

She (Kitty) recalled the timid, softened look with which he (Petrov) gazed at her (Kitty), and the strange feeling of compassion and awkwardness, and later of a sense of her (Kitty) own goodness, which she (Kitty) had felt at it.

Again and again she (Kitty) went over in her (Kitty) memory all her (Kitty) relations with the family. How nice it all was! How nice it all was!

But all that was at first. Now, a few days ago, everything was suddenly spoiled. Anna Pavlovna had met Kitty with affected cordiality, and had kept continual watch on her (Pavlovna) and on her (Pavlovna) husband.

Yes,'' she (Pavlovna) mused,

``there was something unnatural about Anna Pavlovna, and utterly unlike her (Pavlovna) good nature, when she (Pavlovna) said angrily the day before yesterday: `There, he (husband) will keep waiting for you; he (husband) wouldn't drink his (husband) coffee without you, though he (husband)'s grown so dreadfully weak.''' (she)

Could that touching pleasure he (husband) showed when she (Pavlovna) came near be the cause of Anna Pavlovna's coolness? '' '' Yes, perhaps, too, she (Pavlovna) didn't like it when I gave him (husband) the rug.

It was all so simple, but he (husband) took it so awkwardly, and was so long thanking me, that I felt awkward too.

And then that portrait of me he (husband) did so well. And most of all that look of confusion and tenderness! Yes, yes, that's it!''

Kitty repeated to herself with horror. '' No, it can't be, it oughtn't to be! He (husband)'s so much to be pitied!

Before the end of the course of drinking the waters, Prince Shtcherbatsky, who had gone on from Carlsbad to Baden and Kissingen to Russian friends--to get a breath of Russian air, as he (Russian) said--came back to his (Russian) wife and daughter.

'' she (daughter) said to herself directly after. This doubt poisoned the charm of her (daughter) new life. Chapter 34 The views of the prince and of the princess on life abroad were completely opposed.

The princess thought everything delightful, and in spite of her (princess) established position in Russian society, she (princess) tried abroad to be like a European fashionable lady, which she (princess) was not--for the simple reason that she (princess) was a typical Russian gentlewoman; and so she (princess) was affected, which did not altogether suit her (princess).

The prince, on the contrary, thought everything foreign detestable, got sick of European life, kept to his (prince) Russian habits, and purposely tried to show himself abroad less European than he (prince) was in reality.

The prince returned thinner, with the skin hanging in loose bags on his (prince) cheeks, but in the most cheerful frame of mind.

The news of Kitty's friendship with Madame Stahl and Varenka, and the reports the princess gave him (Stahl) of some kind of change she (princess) had noticed in Kitty, troubled the prince and aroused his (prince) habitual feeling of jealousy of everything that drew his (prince) daughter away from him (prince), and a dread that his (prince) daughter might have got out of the reach of his (prince) influence into regions inaccessible to him (prince).

But these unpleasant matters were all drowned in the sea of kindliness and good humor which was always within him (prince), and more so than ever since his (prince) course of Carlsbad waters.

The day after his (prince) arrival the prince, in his (prince) long overcoat, with his (prince) Russian wrinkles and baggy cheeks propped up by a starched collar, set off with his (prince) daughter to the spring in the greatest good humor.

It was a lovely morning: the bright, cheerful houses with their little gardens, the sight of the red-faced, red-armed, beer-drinking German waitresses, working away merrily, did the heart good.

But the nearer they got to the springs the oftener they met sick people; and their appearance seemed more pitiable than ever among the everyday conditions of prosperous German life.

The bright sun, the brilliant green of the foliage, the strains of the music were for her (daughter) the natural setting of all these familiar faces, with their changes to greater emaciation or to convalescence, for which she (daughter) watched.

But to the prince the brightness and gaiety of the June morning, and the sound of the orchestra playing a gay waltz then in fashion, and above all, the appearance of the healthy attendants, seemed something unseemly and monstrous, in conjunction with these slowly moving, dying figures gathered together from all parts of Europe.

In spite of his (prince) feeling of pride and, as it were, of the return of youth, with his (prince) favorite daughter on his (prince) arm, he (prince) felt awkward, and almost ashamed of his (prince) vigorous step and his (prince) sturdy, stout limbs.

His (prince) good humor was even greater when he (prince) saw Kitty completely recovered. Kitty was no longer struck by this contrast. He (prince) felt almost like a man not dressed in a crowd.

'' Present me to your new friends,'' he (prince) said to his (prince) daughter, squeezing her (daughter) hand with his (prince) elbow. '' I like even your horrid Soden for making you so well again.

Only it's melancholy, very melancholy here. Who's that?'' Kitty mentioned the names of all the people they met, with some of whom she (Kitty) was acquainted and some not.

At the entrance of the garden they met the blind lady, Madame Berthe, with her (lady) guide, and the prince was delighted to see the old Frenchwoman's face light up when she (lady) heard Kitty's voice.

She (Kitty) at once began talking to him (prince) with French exaggerated politeness, applauding him (prince) for having such a delightful daughter, extolling Kitty to the skies before her (Kitty) face, and calling her (Kitty) a treasure, a pearl, and a consoling angel.

'' Well, she (Kitty)'s the second angel, then,'' said the prince, smiling. '' she (Kitty) calls Mademoiselle Varenka angel number one.'' '' Oh!

Mademoiselle Varenka, she (Kitty)'s a real angel, allez,'' Madame Berthe assented. In the arcade they met Varenka herself. She (Kitty) was walking rapidly towards them carrying an elegant red bag.

a movement between a bow and a curtsey, and immediately began talking to the prince, without shyness, naturally, as she (Kitty) talked to everyone.

Of course I know you; I know you very well,'' the prince said to her (Kitty) with a smile, in which Kitty detected with joy that her (Kitty) father liked her (Kitty) friend.

'' Here is papa come,'' Kitty said to her (Kitty). Varenka made--simply and naturally as she (Kitty) did everything-- '' '' Where are you off to in such haste?

''

``Maman's here,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said, turning to Kitty. '' She (Kitty) has not slept all night, and the doctor advised her (Kitty) to go out.

I'm taking her (Kitty) her (Kitty) work. '' '' So that's angel number one? '' said the prince when Varenka had gone on.

Kitty saw that her (Kitty) father had meant to make fun of Varenka, but that he (father) could not do it because he (father) liked her (Kitty).

'' Come, so we shall see all your friends,'' he (father) went on,

``even Madame Stahl, if she (Kitty) deigns to recognize me.'' (he)

``Why, did you know her (Kitty), papa?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Kitty asked apprehensively, catching the gleam of irony that kindled in the prince's eyes at the mention of Madame Stahl.

'' I used to know her (Kitty) husband, and her (Kitty) too a little, before she (Kitty)'d joined the Pietists.'' '' What is a Pietist, papa?

'' asked Kitty, dismayed to find that what she (Kitty) prized so highly in Madame Stahl had a name. '' I don't quite know myself.

I only know that she (Kitty) thanks God for everything, for every misfortune, and thanks God too that her (Kitty) husband died. And that's rather droll, as they didn't get on together.

he (God) asked, noticing a sick man of medium height sitting on a bench, wearing a brown overcoat and white trousers that fell in strange folds about his (God) long, fleshless legs.

This man lifted his (man) straw hat, showed his (man) scanty curly hair and high forehead, painfully reddened by the pressure of the hat.

And that's his (man) wife,'' she (wife) added, indicating Anna Pavlovna, who, as though on purpose, at the very instant they approached walked away after a child that had run off along a path.

'' '' Who's that? What a piteous face! '' '' That's Petrov, an artist,'' answered Kitty, blushing. '' '' Poor fellow!

and what a nice face he (fellow) has! '' said the prince. '' Why don't you go up to him (fellow)? He (fellow) wanted to speak to you.''

'' Well, let us go, then,'' said Kitty, turning round resolutely. '' How are you feeling today? '' she (Kitty) asked Petrov.

Petrov got up, leaning on his (Petrov) stick, and looked shyly at the prince. '' This is my daughter,'' said the prince.

``Let me introduce myself. '' (The painter)
The painter bowed and smiled, showing his (painter) strangely dazzling white teeth. '' We expected you yesterday, princess,'' he (painter) said to Kitty.

He (painter) staggered as he (painter) said this, and then repeated the motion, trying to make it seem as if it had been intentional.

'' I meant to come, but Varenka said that Anna Pavlovna sent word you were not going. ''

``Not going!'' (Petrov)
said Petrov, blushing, and immediately beginning to cough, and his (Petrov) eyes sought his (Petrov) wife.

'' Anita! Anita! '' he (Petrov) said loudly, and the swollen veins stood out like cords on his (Petrov) thin white neck. Anna Pavlovna came up.

'' So you sent word to the princess that we weren't going! '' he (Petrov) whispered to her (Pavlovna) angrily, losing his (Petrov) voice.

'' Good morning, princess,'' said Anna Pavlovna, with an assumed smile utterly unlike her (Pavlovna) former manner. '' Very glad to make your acquaintance,'' she (Pavlovna) said to the prince.

'' You've long been expected, prince. '' '' What did you send word to the princess that we weren't going for?

the artist whispered hoarsely once more, still more angrily, obviously exasperated that his (artist) voice failed him (artist) so that he (artist) could not give his (artist) words the expression he (artist) would have liked to.

'' '' Oh, mercy on us! I thought we weren't going,'' his (artist) wife answered crossly. '' What, when... '' He (artist) coughed and waved his (artist) hand.

The prince took off his (prince) hat and moved away with his (prince) daughter. '' Ah! ah!'' he (prince) sighed deeply. '' Oh, poor things!''

He (prince) gets something from the Academy,'' she (daughter) went on briskly, trying to drown the distress that the queer change in Anna Pavlovna's manner to her (Pavlovna) had aroused in her (Pavlovna).

Oh, here's Madame Stahl,'' said Kitty, indicating an invalid carriage, where, propped on pillows, something in gray and blue was lying under a sunshade.

``Yes, papa,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
answered Kitty. '' And you must know they've three children, no servant, and scarcely any means. '' This was Madame Stahl.

Behind her (Kitty) stood the gloomy, healthy-looking German workman who pushed the carriage. Close by was standing a flaxen-headed Swedish count, whom Kitty knew by name.

Several invalids were lingering near the low carriage, staring at the lady as though she (Kitty) were some curiosity. The prince went up to her (Kitty), and Kitty detected that disconcerting gleam of irony in his (prince) eyes.

He (prince) went up to Madame Stahl, and addressed her (Kitty) with extreme courtesy and affability in that excellent French that so few speak nowadays.

I don't know if you remember me, but I must recall myself to thank you for your kindness to my daughter,'' he (Stahl) said, taking off his (Stahl) hat and not putting it on again.

'' '' Prince Alexander Shtcherbatsky,'' said Madame Stahl, lifting upon him (Stahl) her (daughter) heavenly eyes, in which Kitty discerned a look of annoyance.

'' Delighted! I have taken a great fancy to your daughter.''

``You are still in weak health?'' (unknown)
'' Yes; I'm used to it,'' said Madame Stahl, and she (daughter) introduced the prince to the Swedish count.

'' You are scarcely changed at all,'' the prince said to her (daughter). '' It's ten or eleven years since I had the honor of seeing you.''

'' Yes; God sends the cross and sends the strength to bear it. Often one wonders what is the goal of this life?...

The other side! '' she (daughter) said angrily to Varenka, who had rearranged the rug over her (daughter) feet not to her (daughter) satisfaction.

'' To do good, probably,'' said the prince with a twinkle in his (prince) eye. '' That is not for us to judge,'' said Madame Stahl, perceiving the shade of expression on the prince's face.

'' So you will send me that book, dear count? I'm very grateful to you,'' she (daughter) said to the young Swede.

``Ah!'' (the prince)
cried the prince, catching sight of the Moscow colonel standing near, and with a bow to Madame Stahl he (Stahl) walked away with his (Stahl) daughter and the Moscow colonel, who joined them.

'' That's our aristocracy, prince! '' the Moscow colonel said with ironical intention. He (colonel) cherished a grudge against Madame Stahl for not making his (Stahl) acquaintance.

'' She (daughter)'s just the same,'' replied the prince. '' Did you know her (daughter) before her (daughter) illness, prince--that's to say before she (daughter) took to her (daughter) bed?''

'' Yes. She (daughter) took to her (daughter) bed before my eyes,'' said the prince. '' They say it's ten years since she (daughter) has stood on her (daughter) feet.''

``She (daughter) doesn't stand up because her (daughter) legs are too short. She (daughter)'s a very bad figure.'' (Papa)
'' Papa, it's not possible!'' cried Kitty.

'' That's what wicked tongues say, my darling. And your Varenka catches it too,'' he (Papa) added. '' Oh, these invalid ladies!''

'' Oh, no, papa!'' Kitty objected warmly. '' Varenka worships her (Kitty). And then she (Kitty) does so much good! Ask anyone! Everyone knows her (Kitty) and Aline Stahl.''

``Perhaps so,'' (the prince)
said the prince, squeezing her (Kitty) hand with his (prince) elbow;
``but it's better when one does good so that you may ask everyone and no one knows.

Kitty did not answer, not because she (Kitty) had nothing to say, but because she (Kitty) did not care to reveal her (Kitty) secret thoughts even to her (Kitty) father.

But, strange to say, although she (Kitty) had so made up her (Kitty) mind not to be influenced by her (Kitty) father's views, not to let him (father) into her (Kitty) inmost sanctuary, she (Kitty) felt that the heavenly image of Madame Stahl, which she (Kitty) had carried for a whole month in her (Kitty) heart, had vanished, never to return, just as the fantastic figure made up of some clothes thrown down at random vanishes when one sees that it is only some garment lying there.

All that was left was a woman with short legs, who lay down because she (woman) had a bad figure, and worried patient Varenka for not arranging her (woman) rug to her (woman) liking.

The prince communicated his (prince) good humor to his (prince) own family and his (prince) friends, and even to the German landlord in whose rooms the Shtcherbatskys were staying.

On coming back with Kitty from the springs, the prince, who had asked the colonel, and Marya Yevgenyevna, and Varenka all to come and have coffee with them, gave orders for a table and chairs to be taken into the garden under the chestnut tree, and lunch to be laid there.

'' (the prince)

And by no effort of the imagination could Kitty bring back the former Madame Stahl. Chapter 35 The landlord and the servants, too, grew brisker under the influence of his (Stahl) good spirits.

They knew his (Stahl) open-handedness; and half an hour later the invalid doctor from Hamburg, who lived on the top floor, looked enviously out of the window at the merry party of healthy Russians assembled under the chestnut tree.

In the trembling circles of shadow cast by the leaves, at a table, covered with a white cloth, and set with coffeepot, bread-and-butter, cheese, and cold game, sat the princess in a high cap with lilac ribbons, distributing cups and bread-and-butter.

The prince had spread out near him (prince) his (prince) purchases, carved boxes, and knick-knacks, paper-knives of all sorts, of which he (prince) bought a heap at every watering-place, and bestowed them upon everyone, including Lieschen, the servant girl, and the landlord, with whom he (prince) jested in his (prince) comically bad German, assuring him (prince) that it was not the water had cured Kitty, but his (prince) splendid cookery, especially his (prince) plum soup.

The princess laughed at her (princess) husband for his (prince) Russian ways, but she (princess) was more lively and good-humored than she (princess) had been all the while she (princess) had been at the waters.

The colonel smiled, as he (colonel) always did, at the prince's jokes, but as far as regards Europe, of which he (colonel) believed himself to be making a careful study, he (colonel) took the princess's side.

The simple-hearted Marya Yevgenyevna simply roared with laughter at everything absurd the prince said, and his (prince) jokes made Varenka helpless with feeble but infectious laughter, which was something Kitty had never seen before.

At the other end sat the prince, eating heartily, and talking loudly and merrily. Kitty was glad of all this, but she (Kitty) could not be light-hearted.

She (Kitty) could not solve the problem her (Kitty) father had unconsciously set her (Kitty) by his (father) goodhumored view of her (Kitty) friends, and of the life that had so attracted her (Kitty).

To this doubt there was joined the change in her (Kitty) relations with the Petrovs, which had been so conspicuously and unpleasantly marked that morning.

She (Kitty) felt a feeling such as she (Kitty) had known in childhood, when she (Kitty) had been shut in her (Kitty) room as a punishment, and had heard her (Kitty) sisters' merry laughter outside.

Well, but what did you buy this mass of things for?'' said the princess, smiling, and handing her (princess) husband a cup of coffee.

Everyone was good humored, but Kitty could not feel good humored, and this increased her (Kitty) distress. '' '' One goes for a walk, one looks in a shop, and they ask you to buy. '

Erlaucht, Durchlaucht? ' Directly they say ' Durchlaucht ,' I can't hold out. I lose ten thalers. '' '' It's simply from boredom,'' said the princess.

'' Of course it is. Such boredom, my dear, that one doesn't know what to do with oneself.''

``How can you be bored, prince?

There's so much that's interesting now in Germany,'' (Marya Yevgenyevna)

said Marya Yevgenyevna. '' But I know everything that's interesting: the plum soup I know, and the pea sausages I know.

I know everything.'' '' No, you may say what you like, prince, there's the interest of their institutions,'' said the colonel.

'' But what is there interesting about it? They're all as pleased as brass halfpence. They've conquered everybody, and why am I to be pleased at that?

I haven't conquered anyone; and I'm obliged to take off my own boots, yes, and put them away too; in the morning, get up and dress at once, and go to the dining room to drink bad tea!

How different it is at home! You get up in no haste, you get cross, grumble a little, and come round again.

You've time to think things over, and no hurry.'' '' But time's money, you forget that,'' said the colonel. '' Time, indeed, that depends!

Why, there's time one would give a month of for sixpence, and time you wouldn't give half an hour of for any money.

Isn't that so, Katinka? What is it? why are you so depressed?'' '' I'm not depressed.''

``Where are you off to?

Stay a little longer,'' (he)

he (colonel) said to Varenka. '' I must be going home,'' said Varenka, getting up, and again she (it) went off into a giggle.

When she (it) had recovered, she (it) said good-bye, and went into the house to get her (it) hat. Kitty followed her (it). Even Varenka struck her (it) as different.

She (it) was not worse, but different from what she (it) had fancied her (it) before. '' Oh, dear! it's a long while since I've laughed so much!'' said Varenka, gathering up her (it) parasol and her (it) bag.

'' How nice he (it) is, your father!'' Kitty did not speak. '' When shall I see you again?'' asked Varenka. ''

Mamma meant to go and see the Petrovs. Won't you be there?'' said Kitty, to try Varenka. '' Yes,'' answered Varenka.

'' They're getting ready to go away, so I promised to help them pack.'' '' Well, I'll come too, then.'' ''

No, why should you?''

``Why not? why not? why not? '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
said Kitty, opening her (Kitty) eyes wide, and clutching at Varenka's parasol, so as not to let her (Kitty) go.

'' No, wait a minute; why not? '' '' Oh, nothing; your father has come, and besides, they will feel awkward at your helping.''

'' No, tell me why you don't want me to be often at the Petrovs'. You don't want me to--why not?

''

``I didn't say that,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka quietly. '' No, please tell me!''
``Tell you everything? '' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
asked Varenka. '' Everything, everything!''

Well, there's really nothing of any consequence; only that Mihail Alexeyevitch'' -LRB-that was the artist's name-RRB-

``had meant to leave earlier, and now he (artist) doesn't want to go away,'' (the artist)
said Varenka, smiling.

Kitty assented. '' '' Well, well!'' Kitty urged impatiently, looking darkly at Varenka. '' Well, and for some reason Anna Pavlovna told him (artist) that he (artist) didn't want to go because you are here.

Of course, that was nonsense; but there was a dispute over it--over you. You know how irritable these sick people are.''

Kitty, scowling more than ever, kept silent, and Varenka went on speaking alone, trying to soften or soothe her (Kitty), and seeing a storm coming

--she (Kitty) did not know whether of tears or of words. '' So you'd better not go.... You understand; you won't be offended?...''

'' And it serves me right! And it serves me right!'' Kitty cried quickly, snatching the parasol out of Varenka's hand, and looking past her (Kitty) friend's face.

Varenka felt inclined to smile, looking at her (Kitty) childish fury, but she (Kitty) was afraid of wounding her (Kitty). '' How does it serve you

It serves me right, because it was all sham; because it was all done on purpose, and not from the heart.

And so it's come about that I'm a cause of quarrel, and that I've done what nobody asked me to do.

right? I don't understand,'' she (Kitty) said. '' What business had I to interfere with outsiders? Because it was all a sham!

a sham! a sham!... ''

``A sham! with what object?'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka gently. '' Oh, it's so idiotic! so hateful! There was no need whatever for me....

Nothing but sham! '' she (Kitty) said, opening and shutting the parasol. '' But with what object?'' '' To seem better to people, to myself, to God; to deceive everyone.

No! now I won't descend to that. I'll be bad; but anyway not a liar, a cheat.'' '' But who is a cheat?'' said Varenka reproachfully.

'' You speak as if...'' But Kitty was in one of her (Kitty) gusts of fury, and she (Kitty) would not let her (Kitty) finish.

'' I don't talk about you, not about you at all. You're perfection. Yes, yes, I know you're all perfection; but what am I to do if I'm bad?

This would never have been if I weren't bad. So let me be what I am. I won't be a sham.

What have I to do with Anna Pavlovna? Let them go their way, and me go mine. I can't be different....

And yet it's not that, it's not that.'' '' What is not that?'' asked Varenka in bewilderment. '' Everything. I can't act except from the heart, and you act from principle.

I liked you simply, but you most likely only wanted to save me, to improve me.''

``You are unjust,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka.

'' But I'm not speaking of other people, I'm speaking of myself.''

``Kitty,'' (mother)
they heard her (Kitty) mother's voice,
``come here, show papa your necklace.

Kitty, with a haughty air, without making peace with her (Kitty) friend, took the necklace in a little box from the table and went to her (Kitty) mother.

'' (mother)

'' What's the matter? Why are you so red? '' her (Kitty) mother and father said to her (Kitty) with one voice.

'' Nothing,'' she (Kitty) answered. '' I'll be back directly,'' and she (Kitty) ran back. '' She (Kitty)'s still here,'' she (Kitty) thought. '' What am I to say to her (Kitty)?

Oh, dear! what have I done, what have I said? Why was I rude to her (Kitty)? What am I to do?

Varenka in her (Kitty) hat and with the parasol in her (Kitty) hands was sitting at the table examining the spring which Kitty had broken.

What am I to say to her (Kitty)? '' thought Kitty, and she (Kitty) stopped in the doorway. She (Kitty) lifted her (Kitty) head. ''

Varenka, forgive me, do forgive me,'' whispered Kitty, going up to her (Kitty). '' I don't remember what I said. I...''

``I really didn't mean to hurt you,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
said Varenka, smiling.

Peace was made. But with her (Kitty) father's coming all the world in which she (Kitty) had been living was transformed for Kitty.

She (Kitty) did not give up everything she (Kitty) had learned, but she (Kitty) became aware that she (Kitty) had deceived herself in supposing she (Kitty) could be what she (Kitty) wanted to be.

Her (Kitty) eyes were, it seemed, opened; she (Kitty) felt all the difficulty of maintaining herself without hypocrisy and self-conceit on the pinnacle to which she (Kitty) had wished to mount.

Moreover, she (Kitty) became aware of all the dreariness of the world of sorrow, of sick and dying people, in which she (Kitty) had been living.

The efforts she (Kitty) had made to like it seemed to her (Kitty) intolerable, and she (Kitty) felt a longing to get back quickly into the fresh air, to Russia, to Ergushovo, where, as she (Kitty) knew from letters, her (Kitty) sister Dolly had already gone with her (Kitty) children.

But her (Kitty) affection for Varenka did not wane. As she (Kitty) said good-bye, Kitty begged her (Kitty) to come to them in Russia.

'' I'll come when you get married,'' said Varenka. '' I shall never marry.'' '' Well, then, I shall never come.

'' '' Well, then, I shall be married simply for that. Mind now, remember your promise,'' said Kitty. The doctor's prediction was fulfilled.

Kitty returned home to Russia cured. She (Kitty) was not so gay and thoughtless as before, but she (Kitty) was serene. Her (Kitty) Moscow troubles had become a memory to her (Kitty).

THREE Chapter 1 Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev wanted a rest from mental work, and instead of going abroad as he (Koznishev) usually did, he (Koznishev) came towards the end of May to stay in the country with his (Koznishev) brother.

PART In his (Koznishev) judgment the best sort of life was a country life. He (Koznishev) had come now to enjoy such a life at his (Koznishev) brother's.

But in spite of his (Koznishev) affection and respect for Sergey Ivanovitch, Konstantin Levin was uncomfortable with his (Levin) brother in the country.

Konstantin Levin was very glad to have him (Levin), especially as he (Levin) did not expect his (Levin) brother Nikolay that summer. It made him (Levin) uncomfortable, and it positively annoyed him (Levin) to see his (Levin) brother's attitude to the country.

To Sergey Ivanovitch the country meant on one hand rest from work, on the other a valuable antidote to the corrupt influences of town, which he (Ivanovitch) took with satisfaction and a sense of its utility.

To Konstantin Levin the country was good first because it afforded a field for labor, of the usefulness of which there could be no doubt.

To Konstantin Levin the country was the background of life, that is of pleasures, endeavors, labor. To Sergey Ivanovitch the country was particularly good, because there it was possible and fitting to do nothing.

Sergey Ivanovitch used to say that he (Ivanovitch) knew and liked the peasantry, and he (Ivanovitch) often talked to the peasants, which he (Ivanovitch) knew how to do without affectation or condescension, and from every such conversation he (Ivanovitch) would deduce general conclusions in favor of the peasantry and in confirmation of his (Ivanovitch) knowing them.

Moreover, Sergey Ivanovitch's attitude to the peasants rather piqued Konstantin. Konstantin Levin did not like such an attitude to the peasants.
