To Konstantin the peasant was simply the chief partner in their common labor, and in spite of all the respect and the love, almost like that of kinship, he (Konstantin) had for the peasant-- sucked in probably, as he (Konstantin) said himself, with the milk of his (Konstantin) peasant nurse--still as a fellow-worker with him (Konstantin), while sometimes enthusiastic over the vigor, gentleness, and justice of these men, he (Konstantin) was very often, when their common labors called for other qualities, exasperated with the peasant for his (peasant) carelessness, lack of method, drunkenness, and lying.

If he (peasant) had been asked whether he (peasant) liked or didn't like the peasants, Konstantin Levin would have been absolutely at a loss what to reply.

He (Levin) liked and did not like the peasants, just as he (Levin) liked and did not like men in general. Of course, being a good-hearted man, he (man) liked men

he (man) could not, not only because he (man) lived with

``the people,'' (he)
and all his (man) interests were bound up with theirs, but also because he (man) regarded himself as a part of
``the people,'' (he)
did not see any special qualities or failings distinguishing himself and
``the people,'' (he)
and could not contrast himself with them.

Moreover, although he (man) had lived so long in the closest relations with the peasants, as farmer and arbitrator, and what was more, as adviser -LRB-the peasants trusted him (adviser), and for thirty miles round they would come to ask his (adviser) advice-RRB-, he (adviser) had no definite views of

``the people,'' (he)
and would have been as much at a loss to answer the question whether he (adviser) knew
``the people'' (he)
as the question whether he (adviser) liked them.

rather than he (adviser) disliked them, and so too with the peasants. But like or dislike

``the people'' (him)
as something apart For him (adviser) to say he (adviser) knew the peasantry would have been the same as to say he (adviser) knew men.

He (adviser) was continually watching and getting to know people of all sorts, and among them peasants, whom he (adviser) regarded as good and interesting people, and he (adviser) was continually observing new points in them, altering his (adviser) former views of them and forming new ones.

Just as he (adviser) liked and praised a country life in comparison with the life he (adviser) did not like, so too he (adviser) liked the peasantry in contradistinction to the class of men he (adviser) did not like, and so too he (adviser) knew the peasantry as something distinct from and opposed to men generally.

In his (adviser) methodical brain there were distinctly formulated certain aspects of peasant life, deduced partly from that life itself, but chiefly from contrast with other modes of life.

With Sergey Ivanovitch it was quite the contrary. He (Ivanovitch) never changed his (Ivanovitch) opinion of the peasantry and his (Ivanovitch) sympathetic attitude towards them.

In the discussions that arose between the brothers on their views of the peasantry, Sergey Ivanovitch always got the better of his (Ivanovitch) brother, precisely because Sergey Ivanovitch had definite ideas about the peasant--his (Ivanovitch) character, his (Ivanovitch) qualities, and his (Ivanovitch) tastes.

Konstantin Levin had no definite and unalterable idea on the subject, and so in their arguments Konstantin was readily convicted of contradicting himself.

In Sergey Ivanovitch's eyes his (Ivanovitch) younger brother was a capital fellow, with his (Ivanovitch) heart in the right place -LRB-as he (Ivanovitch) expressed it in French-RRB-, but with a mind which, though fairly quick, was too much influenced by the impressions of the moment, and consequently filled with contradictions.

With all the condescension of an elder brother he (brother) sometimes explained to him (brother) the true import of things, but he (brother) derived little satisfaction from arguing with him (brother) because he (brother) got the better of him (brother) too easily.

Konstantin Levin regarded his (Levin) brother as a man of immense intellect and culture, as generous in the highest sense of the word, and possessed of a special faculty for working for the public good.

But in the depths of his (Levin) heart, the older he (Levin) became, and the more intimately he (Levin) knew his (Levin) brother, the more and more frequently the thought struck him (Levin) that this faculty of working for the public good, of which he (Levin) felt himself utterly devoid, was possibly not so much a quality as a lack of something --not a lack of good, honest, noble desires and tastes, but a lack of vital force, of what is called heart, of that impulse which drives a man to choose someone out of the innumerable paths of life, and to care only for that one.

The better he (man) knew his (man) brother, the more he (man) noticed that Sergey Ivanovitch, and many other people who worked for the public welfare, were not led by an impulse of the heart to care for the public good, but reasoned from intellectual considerations that it was a right thing to take interest in public affairs, and consequently took interest in them.

Levin was confirmed in this generalization by observing that his (Levin) brother did not take questions affecting the public welfare or the question of the immortality of the soul a bit more to heart than he (brother) did chess problems, or the ingenious construction of a new machine.

Besides this, Konstantin Levin was not at his (Levin) ease with his (Levin) brother, because in summer in the country Levin was continually busy with work on the land, and the long summer day was not long enough for him (Levin) to get through all he (Levin) had to do, while Sergey Ivanovitch was taking a holiday.

But though he (Ivanovitch) was taking a holiday now, that is to say, he (Ivanovitch) was doing no writing, he (Ivanovitch) was so used to intellectual activity that he (Ivanovitch) liked to put into concise and eloquent shape the ideas that occurred to him (Ivanovitch), and liked to have someone to listen to him (Ivanovitch).

His (Ivanovitch) most usual and natural listener was his (Ivanovitch) brother. And so in spite of the friendliness and directness of their relations, Konstantin felt an awkwardness in leaving him (Konstantin) alone.

Sergey Ivanovitch liked to stretch himself on the grass in the sun, and to lie so, basking and chatting lazily. ''

You wouldn't believe,'' he (Ivanovitch) would say to his (Ivanovitch) brother,

``what a pleasure this rural laziness is to me. Not an idea in one's brain, as empty as a drum!'' (brother)

But Konstantin Levin found it dull sitting and listening to him (Levin), especially when he (Levin) knew that while he (Levin) was away they would be carting dung onto the fields not ploughed ready for it, and heaping it all up anyhow; and would not screw the shares in the ploughs, but would let them come off and then say that the new ploughs were a silly invention, and there was nothing like the old Andreevna plough, and so on.

No, I must just run round to the counting-house for a minute,'' Levin would answer, and he (Levin) would run off to the fields.

Chapter 2 Early in June it happened that Agafea Mihalovna, the old nurse and housekeeper, in carrying to the cellar a jar of mushrooms she (housekeeper) had just pickled, slipped, fell, and sprained her (housekeeper) wrist.

'' Come, you've done enough trudging about in the heat,'' Sergey Ivanovitch would say to him (Ivanovitch). '' The district doctor, a talkative young medical student, who had just finished his (Ivanovitch) studies, came to see her (housekeeper).

He (Ivanovitch) examined the wrist, said it was not broken, was delighted at a chance of talking to the celebrated Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev, and to show his (Koznishev) advanced views of things told him (Koznishev) all the scandal of the district, complaining of the poor state into which the district council had fallen.

Sergey Ivanovitch listened attentively, asked him (Ivanovitch) questions, and, roused by a new listener, he (Ivanovitch) talked fluently, uttered a few keen and weighty observations, respectfully appreciated by the young doctor, and was soon in that eager frame of mind

his (doctor) brother knew so well, which always, with him (doctor), followed a brilliant and eager conversation. After the departure of the doctor, he (doctor) wanted to go with a fishing rod to the river.

Sergey Ivanovitch was fond of angling, and was, it seemed, proud of being able to care for such a stupid occupation.

Konstantin Levin, whose presence was needed in the plough land and meadows, had come to take his (Levin) brother in the trap.

It was that time of the year, the turning-point of summer, when the crops of the present year are a certainty, when one begins to think of the sowing for next year, and the mowing is at hand; when the rye is all in ear, though its ears are still light, not yet full, and it waves in gray-green billows in the wind; when the green oats, with tufts of yellow grass scattered here and there among it, droop irregularly over the late-sown fields; when the early buckwheat is already out and hiding the ground; when the fallow lands, trodden hard as stone by the cattle, are half ploughed over, with paths left untouched by the plough; when from the dry dung-heaps carted onto the fields there comes at sunset a smell of manure mixed with meadow-sweet, and on the low-lying lands the riverside meadows are a thick sea of grass waiting for the mowing, with blackened heaps of the stalks of sorrel among it.

It was the time when there comes a brief pause in the toil of the fields before the beginning of the labors of harvest--every year recurring, every year straining every nerve of the peasants.

The crop was a splendid one, and bright, hot summer days had set in with short, dewy nights. The brothers had to drive through the woods to reach the meadows.

Sergey Ivanovitch was all the while admiring the beauty of the woods, which were a tangled mass of leaves, pointing out to his (Ivanovitch) brother now an old lime tree on the point of flowering, dark on the shady side, and brightly spotted with yellow stipules, now the young shoots of this year's saplings brilliant with emerald.

Konstantin Levin did not like talking and hearing about the beauty of nature. Words for him (Levin) took away the beauty of what he (Levin) saw.

When they came out of the woods, all his (Levin) attention was engrossed by the view of the fallow land on the upland, in parts yellow with grass, in parts trampled and checkered with furrows, in parts dotted with ridges of dung, and in parts even ploughed.

He (Levin) assented to what his (Levin) brother said, but he (Levin) could not help beginning to think of other things. A string of carts was moving across it.

Levin counted the carts, and was pleased that all that were wanted had been brought, and at the sight of the meadows his (Levin) thoughts passed to the mowing.

He (Levin) always felt something special moving him (Levin) to the quick at the hay-making. On reaching the meadow Levin stopped the horse.

The morning dew was still lying on the thick undergrowth of the grass, and that he (Levin) might not get his (Levin) feet wet, Sergey Ivanovitch asked his (Ivanovitch) brother to drive him (Ivanovitch) in the trap up to the willow tree from which the carp was caught.

The high grass softly turned about the wheels and the horse's legs, leaving its seeds clinging to the wet axles and spokes of the wheels.

His (Ivanovitch) brother seated himself under a bush, arranging his (Ivanovitch) tackle, while Levin led the horse away, fastened him (Levin) up, and walked into the vast gray-green sea of grass unstirred by the wind.

Sorry as Konstantin Levin was to crush down his (Levin) mowing grass, he (Levin) drove him (Levin) into the meadow. The silky grass with its ripe seeds came almost to his (Levin) waist in the dampest spots.

Crossing the meadow, Konstantin Levin came out onto the road, and met an old man with a swollen eye, carrying a skep on his (Levin) shoulder.

'' What? taken a stray swarm, Fomitch? '' he (Levin) asked. '' No, indeed, Konstantin Dmitrich! All we can do to keep our own!

This is the second swarm that has flown away.... Luckily the lads caught them. They were ploughing your field. They unyoked the horses and galloped after them.''

'' Well, what do you say, Fomitch--start mowing or wait a bit?''

``Eh, well. Our way's to wait till St. Peter's Day.

But you always mow sooner. Well, to be sure, please God, the hay's good. There'll be plenty for the beasts. '' (unknown)

'' What do you think about the weather?'' '' That's in God's hands. Maybe it will be fine. '' Levin went up to his (Levin) brother.

Sergey Ivanovitch had caught nothing, but he (Ivanovitch) was not bored, and seemed in the most cheerful frame of mind. Levin saw that, stimulated by his (Levin) conversation with the doctor, he (Levin) wanted to talk.

Levin, on the other hand, would have liked to get home as soon as possible to give orders about getting together the mowers for next day, and to set at rest his (Levin) doubts about the mowing, which greatly absorbed him (Levin).

'' Well, let's be going,'' he (Levin) said. '' Why be in such a hurry? Let's stay a little. But how wet you are!

Even though one catches nothing, it's nice. That's the best thing about every part of sport, that one has to do with nature.

How exquisite this steely water is!'' said Sergey Ivanovitch. '' These riverside banks always remind me of the riddle--do you know it? '

The grass says to the water: we quiver and we quiver.' ''

``I don't know the riddle,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
answered Levin wearily. Chapter 3

``Do you know, I've been thinking about you,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
said Sergey Ivanovitch. '' It's beyond everything what's being done in the district, according to what this doctor tells me.

And as I've told you before, I tell you again: it's not right for you not to go to the meetings, and altogether to keep out of the district business.

We pay the money, and it all goes in salaries, and there are no schools, nor district nurses, nor midwives, nor drugstores-- nothing.''

He (doctor)'s a very intelligent fellow. If decent people won't go into it, of course it's bound to go all wrong. ''

Well, I did try, you know,'' Levin said slowly and unwillingly. '' I can't! and so there's no help for it.''

'' But why can't you? I must own I can't make it out. Indifference, incapacity--I won't admit; surely it's not simply laziness?''

'' None of those things. I've tried, and I see I can do nothing,'' said Levin. He (Levin) had hardly grasped what his (Levin) brother was saying.

Looking towards the plough land across the river, he (Levin) made out something black, but he (Levin) could not distinguish whether it was a horse or the bailiff on horseback.

'' Why is it you can do nothing? You made an attempt and didn't succeed, as you think, and you give in.

How can you have so little self-respect?''

``Self-respect!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, stung to the quick by his (Levin) brother's words;
``I don't understand.

If they'd told me at college that other people understood the integral calculus, and I didn't, then pride would have come in.

But in this case one wants first to be convinced that one has certain qualifications for this sort of business, and especially that all this business is of great importance.'' (brother)

do you mean to say it's not of importance?'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, stung to the quick too at his (Ivanovitch) brother's considering anything of no importance that interested him (Ivanovitch), and still more at his (Ivanovitch) obviously paying little attention to what he (Ivanovitch) was saying.

I don't think it important; it does not take hold of me, I can't help it,'' answered Levin, making out that what he (Levin) saw was the bailiff, and that the bailiff seemed to be letting the peasants go off the ploughed land.

``What! '' (unknown)
They were turning the plough over. '' Can they have finished ploughing? '' he (bailiff) wondered.
``Come, really though,'' (the brother)
said the elder brother, with a frown on his (brother) handsome, clever face,
``there's a limit to everything.

It's very well to be original and genuine, and to dislike everything conventional--I know all about that; but really, what you're saying either has no meaning, or it has a very wrong meaning.

How can you think it a matter of no importance whether the peasant, whom you love as you assert...'' (the brother)

``I never did assert it,'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
thought Konstantin Levin.

The ignorant peasant-women starve the children, and the people stagnate in darkness, and are helpless in the hands of every village clerk, while you have at your disposal a means of helping them, and don't help them because to your mind it's of no importance.

And Sergey Ivanovitch put before him (Ivanovitch) the alternative: either you are so undeveloped that you can't see all that you can do, or you won't sacrifice your ease, your vanity, or whatever it is, to do it.

Konstantin Levin felt that there was no course open to him (Levin) but to submit, or to confess to a lack of zeal for the public good.

'' ...dies without help? '' And this mortified him (Levin) and hurt his (Levin) feelings. '' It's both,'' he (Levin) said resolutely:

``I don't see that it was possible...

'' (he)

``What! was it impossible, if the money were properly laid out, to provide medical aid?'' (he)
``Impossible, as it seems to me....

For the three thousand square miles of our district, what with our thaws, and the storms, and the work in the fields, I don't see how it is possible to provide medical aid all over.

And besides, I don't believe in medicine.'' (I)

'' Oh, well, that's unfair... I can quote to you thousands of instances.... But the schools, anyway.

''

``Why have schools?'' (unknown)
'' What do you mean? Can there be two opinions of the advantage of education? If it's a good thing for you, it's a good thing for everyone.

Konstantin Levin felt himself morally pinned against a wall, and so he (Levin) got hot, and unconsciously blurted out the chief cause of his (Levin) indifference to public business.

Perhaps it may all be very good; but why should I worry myself about establishing dispensaries which I shall never make use of, and schools to which I shall never send my children, to which even the peasants don't want to send their children, and to which I've no very firm faith that they ought to send them?

Sergey Ivanovitch was for a minute surprised at this unexpected view of the subject; but he (Ivanovitch) promptly made a new plan of attack.

'' '' '' said he (Ivanovitch). He (Ivanovitch) was silent for a little, drew out a hook, threw it in again, and turned to his (Ivanovitch) brother smiling.

``Come, now.... In the first place, the dispensary is needed. We ourselves sent for the district doctor for Agafea Mihalovna.'' (I)
''

Oh, well, but I fancy her (Ivanovitch) wrist will never be straight again.'' '' That remains to be proved.... Next, the peasant who can read and write is as a workman of more use and value to you.''

No, you can ask anyone you like,'' Konstantin Levin answered with decision,

``the man that can read and write is much inferior as a workman.

'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)

And mending the highroads is an impossibility; and as soon as they put up bridges they're stolen.''
``Still, that's not the point,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
said Sergey Ivanovitch, frowning.

He (Ivanovitch) disliked contradiction, and still more, arguments that were continually skipping from one thing to another, introducing new and disconnected points, so that there was no knowing to which to reply.

``Yes, I admit it,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin without thinking, and he (Levin) was conscious immediately that he (Levin) had said what he (Levin) did not think.

'' Do you admit that education is a benefit for the people?'' He (Levin) felt that if he (Levin) admitted that, it would be proved that he (Levin) had been talking meaningless rubbish.

How it would be proved he (Levin) could not tell, but he (Levin) knew that this would inevitably be logically proved to him (Levin), and he (Levin) awaited the proofs.

If you admit that it is a benefit,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch,

``then, as an honest man, you cannot help caring about it and sympathizing with the movement, and so wishing to work for it.

The argument turned out to be far simpler than he (Ivanovitch) had expected. '' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

'' '' But I still do not admit this movement to be just,'' said Konstantin Levin, reddening a little.

``What! But you said just now...'' (I)
'' That's to say, I don't admit it's being either good or possible. ''
``That you can't tell without making the trial.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Well, supposing that's so,'' said Levin, though he (Levin) did not suppose so at all,

``supposing that is so, still I don't see, all the same, what I'm to worry myself about it for.

'' (he)

''
``How so?'' (unknown)
'' No; since we are talking, explain it to me from the philosophical point of view,'' said Levin.

'' I can't see where philosophy comes in,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, in a tone, Levin fancied, as though he (Levin) did not admit his (Levin) brother's right to talk about philosophy.

And that irritated Levin. '' I'll tell you, then,'' he (Levin) said with heat,

``I imagine the mainspring of all our actions is, after all, self-interest.

Now in the local institutions I, as a nobleman, see nothing that could conduce to my prosperity, and the roads are not better and could not be better; my horses carry me well enough over bad ones.

Doctors and dispensaries are no use to me. An arbitrator of disputes is no use to me. I never appeal to him (arbitrator), and never shall appeal to him (arbitrator).

For me the district institutions simply mean the liability to pay fourpence halfpenny for every three acres, to drive into the town, sleep with bugs, and listen to all sorts of idiocy and loathsomeness, and self-interest offers me no inducement.'' (he)

``Excuse me,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
Sergey Ivanovitch interposed with a smile,
``self-interest did not induce us to work for the emancipation of the serfs, but we did work for it.'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

The schools are no good to me, but positively harmful, as I told you.

``No!'' (Konstantin Levin/Konstantin/Konstantin Dmitrievitch)
Konstantin Levin broke in with still greater heat; ``the emancipation of the serfs was a different matter.

But to be a town councilor and discuss how many dustmen are needed, and how chimneys shall be constructed in the town in which I don't live--to serve on a jury and try a peasant who's stolen a flitch of bacon, and listen for six hours at a stretch to all sorts of jabber from the counsel for the defense and the prosecution, and the president cross-examining my old half-witted Alioshka, `Do you admit, prisoner in the dock, the fact of the removal of the bacon?'

There self-interest did come in. One longed to throw off that yoke that crushed us, all decent people among us. `Eh?'

Konstantin Levin had warmed to his (Levin) subject, and began mimicking the president and the half-witted Alioshka: it seemed to him (Levin) that it was all to the point.

``I simply mean to say that those rights that touch me...my interest, I shall always defend to the best of my ability; that when they made raids on us students, and the police read our letters, I was ready to defend those rights to the utmost, to defend my rights to education and freedom.

I can understand compulsory military service, which affects my children, my brothers, and myself, I am ready to deliberate on what concerns me; but deliberating on how to spend forty thousand roubles of district council money, or judging the half-witted Alioshka--I don't understand, and I can't do it.

'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

But Sergey Ivanovitch shrugged his (Ivanovitch) shoulders. '' Well, what do you mean to say, then?'' '' Konstantin Levin spoke as though the floodgates of his (Levin) speech had burst open.

But tomorrow it'll be your turn to be tried; would it have suited your tastes better to be tried in the old criminal tribunal?''

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled. '' '' I'm not going to be tried. I shan't murder anybody, and I've no need of it.

Well, I tell you what,'' he (Ivanovitch) went on, flying off again to a subject quite beside the point,

``our district self-government and all the rest of it--

it's just like the birch branches we stick in the ground on Trinity Day, for instance, to look like a copse which has grown up of itself in Europe, and I can't gush over these birch branches and believe in them.

Sergey Ivanovitch merely shrugged his (Ivanovitch) shoulders, as though to express his (Ivanovitch) wonder how the birch branches had come into their argument at that point, though he (Ivanovitch) did really understand at once what his (Ivanovitch) brother meant.

But Konstantin Levin wanted to justify himself for the failing, of which he (Levin) was conscious, of lack of zeal for the public welfare, and he (Levin) went on.

I imagine,'' (he)

he (Levin) said,
``that no sort of activity is likely to be lasting if it is not founded on self-interest, that's a universal principle, a philosophical principle,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, repeating the word
``philosophical'' (he)
with determination, as though wishing to show that he (Levin) had as much right as any one else to talk of philosophy.

'' '' Excuse me, but you know one really can't argue in that way,'' he (Levin) observed. '' Sergey Ivanovitch smiled. ''

He (Ivanovitch) too has a philosophy of his (Ivanovitch) own at the service of his (Ivanovitch) natural tendencies,'' he (Ivanovitch) thought. '' Come, you'd better let philosophy alone,'' he (Ivanovitch) said.

The chief problem of the philosophy of all ages consists just in finding the indispensable connection which exists between individual and social interests.

'' But that's not to the point; what is to the point is a correction I must make in your comparison.

The birches are not simply stuck in, but some are sown and some are planted, and one must deal carefully with them.

It's only those peoples that have an intuitive sense of what's of importance and significance in their institutions, and know how to value them

And Sergey Ivanovitch carried the subject into the regions of philosophical history where Konstantin Levin could not follow him (Levin), and showed him (Levin) all the incorrectness of his (Levin) view.

, that have a future before them--it's only those peoples that one can truly call historical. '' '' As for your dislike of it, excuse my saying

so, that's simply our Russian sloth and old serf-owner's ways, and I'm convinced that in you it's a temporary error and will pass.

He (Levin) felt himself vanquished on all sides, but he (Levin) felt at the same time that what he (Levin) wanted to say was unintelligible to his (Levin) brother.

Only he (Levin) could not make up his (Levin) mind whether it was unintelligible because he (Levin) was not capable of expressing his (Levin) meaning clearly, or because his (Levin) brother would not or could not understand him (Levin).

But he (Levin) did not pursue the speculation, and without replying, he (Levin) fell to musing on a quite different and personal matter.

'' Konstantin was silent. Sergey Ivanovitch wound up the last line, untied the horse, and they drove off. Chapter 4 The personal matter that absorbed Levin during his (Levin) conversation with his (Levin) brother was this.

Once in a previous year he (Levin) had gone to look at the mowing, and being made very angry by the bailiff he (bailiff) had recourse to his (bailiff) favorite means for regaining his (bailiff) temper,-- he (bailiff) took a scythe from a peasant and began mowing.

He (bailiff) had cut the whole of the meadow in front of his (bailiff) house, and this year ever since the early spring he (bailiff) had cherished a plan for mowing for whole days together with the peasants.

He (bailiff) liked the work so much that he (bailiff) had several times tried his (bailiff) hand at mowing since. Ever since his (bailiff) brother's arrival, he (bailiff) had been in doubt whether to mow or not.

He (bailiff) was loath to leave his (bailiff) brother alone all day long, and he (bailiff) was afraid his (bailiff) brother would laugh at him (bailiff) about it.

But as he (bailiff) drove into the meadow, and recalled the sensations of mowing, he (bailiff) came near deciding that he (bailiff) would go mowing.

I must have physical exercise, or my temper'll certainly be ruined,'' he (bailiff) thought, and he (bailiff) determined he (bailiff) would go mowing, however awkward he (bailiff) might feel about it with his (bailiff) brother or the peasants.

Towards evening Konstantin Levin went to his (Levin) counting house, gave directions as to the work to be done, and sent about the village to summon the mowers for the morrow, to cut the hay in Kalinov meadow, the largest and best of his (Levin) grass lands.

After the irritating discussion with his (Levin) brother, he (Levin) pondered over this intention again. '' '' And send my scythe, please, to Tit, for him (Levin) to set it, and bring it round tomorrow.

I shall maybe do some mowing myself too,'' he (Levin) said, trying not to be embarrassed. The bailiff smiled and said:

``Yes, sir.

'' (The bailiff)

At tea the same evening Levin said to his (Levin) brother:
``I fancy the fine weather will last. Tomorrow I shall start mowing.'' (brother)

'' I'm so fond of that form of field labor,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch. '' I'm awfully fond of it. I sometimes mow myself with the peasants, and tomorrow I want to try mowing the whole day.

'' Sergey Ivanovitch lifted his (Ivanovitch) head, and looked with interest at his (Ivanovitch) brother. '' How do you mean? Just like one of the peasants, all day long?''

'' Yes, it's very pleasant,'' said Levin. '' It's splendid as exercise, only you'll hardly be able to stand it,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, without a shade of irony.

'' I've tried it. It's hard work at first, but you get into it. I dare say I shall manage to keep it up...''

``Really! what an idea! But tell me, how do the peasants look at it? I suppose they laugh in their sleeves at their master's being such a queer fish?'' (I)

No, I don't think so; but it's so delightful, and at the same time such hard work, that one has no time to think about it.''

'' '' But how will you do about dining with them? To send you a bottle of Lafitte and roast turkey out there would be a little awkward.''

Next morning Konstantin Levin got up earlier than usual, but he (Levin) was detained giving directions on the farm, and when he (Levin) reached the mowing grass the mowers were already at their second row.

From the uplands he (Levin) could get a view of the shaded cut part of the meadow below, with its grayish ridges of cut grass, and the black heaps of coats, taken off by the mowers at the place from which they had started cutting.

Gradually, as he (Levin) rode towards the meadow, the peasants came into sight, some in coats, some in their shirts mowing, one behind another in a long string, swinging their scythes differently.

'' No, I'll simply come home at the time of their noonday rest. '' He (Levin) counted forty-two of them. They were mowing slowly over the uneven, low-lying parts of the meadow, where there had been an old dam.

Here was old Yermil in a very long white smock, bending forward to swing a scythe; there was a young fellow, Vaska, who had been a coachman of Levin's, taking every row with a wide sweep.

Levin recognized some of his (Levin) own men. Here, too, was Tit, Levin's preceptor in the art of mowing, a thin little peasant.

Levin got off his (Levin) mare, and fastening her (mare) up by the roadside went to meet Tit, who took a second scythe out of a bush and gave it to him (Levin).

It's ready, sir; it's like a razor, cuts of itself,'' said Tit, taking off his (Levin) cap with a smile and giving him (Levin) the scythe.

He (Levin) was in front of all, and cut his (Levin) wide row without bending, as though playing with the scythe. '' Levin took the scythe, and began trying it.

As they finished their rows, the mowers, hot and good-humored, came out into the road one after another, and, laughing a little, greeted the master.

They all stared at him (master), but no one made any remark, till a tall old man, with a wrinkled, beardless face, wearing a short sheepskin jacket, came out into the road and accosted him (man).

'' Look`ee now, master, once take hold of the rope there's no letting it go! '' he (master) said, and Levin heard smothered laughter among the mowers.

I'll try not to let it go,'' he (Levin) said, taking his (Levin) stand behind Tit, and waiting for the time to begin.

The grass was short close to the road, and Levin, who had not done any mowing for a long while, and was disconcerted by the eyes fastened upon him (Levin), cut badly for the first moments, though he (Levin) swung his (Levin) scythe vigorously.

Behind him (Levin) he (Levin) heard voices:

``It's not set right; handle's too high; see how he (Levin) has to stoop to it,'' (he)
said one.

'' '' Mind`ee,'' repeated the old man. Tit made room, and Levin started behind him (Levin). '' Press more on the heel,'' said another.

'' Never mind, he (Levin)'ll get on all right,'' the old man resumed. '' He (man)'s made a start.... You swing it too wide, you'll tire yourself out....

The master, sure, does his (master) best for himself! But see the grass missed out! For such work us fellows would catch it!''

The grass became softer, and Levin, listening without answering, followed Tit, trying to do the best he (Levin) could. They moved a hundred paces.

Tit kept moving on, without stopping, not showing the slightest weariness, but Levin was already beginning to be afraid he (Levin) would not be able to keep it up: he (Levin) was so tired.

He (Levin) felt as he (Levin) swung his (Levin) scythe that he (Levin) was at the very end of his (Levin) strength, and was making up his (Levin) mind to ask Tit to stop.

But at that very moment Tit stopped of his (Levin) own accord, and stooping down picked up some grass, rubbed his (Levin) scythe, and began whetting it.

Behind him (Levin) came a peasant, and he (peasant) too was evidently tired, for he (peasant) stopped at once without waiting to mow up to Levin, and began whetting his (Levin) scythe.

Levin straightened himself, and drawing a deep breath looked round. Tit sharpened his (Levin) scythe and Levin's, and they went on. The next time it was just the same.

Tit moved on with sweep after sweep of his (Levin) scythe, not stopping nor showing signs of weariness. Levin followed him (Levin), trying not to get left behind, and he (Levin) found it harder and harder

: the moment came when he (Levin) felt he (Levin) had no strength left, but at that very moment Tit stopped and whetted the scythes.

So they mowed the first row. And this long row seemed particularly hard work to Levin; but when the end was reached and

Tit, shouldering his (Levin) scythe, began with deliberate stride returning on the tracks left by his (Levin) heels in the cut grass, and Levin walked back in the same way over the space he (Levin) had cut, in spite of the sweat that ran in streams over his (Levin) face and fell in drops down his (Levin) nose, and drenched his (Levin) back as though he (Levin) had been soaked in water, he (Levin) felt very happy.

What delighted him (Levin) particularly was that now he (Levin) knew he (Levin) would be able to hold out. His (Levin) pleasure was only disturbed by his (Levin) row not being well cut.

I will swing less with my arm and more with my whole body,'' he (Levin) thought, comparing Tit's row, which looked as if it had been cut with a line, with his (Levin) own unevenly and irregularly lying grass.

The first row, as Levin noticed, Tit had mowed specially quickly, probably wishing to put his (Levin) master to the test, and the row happened to be a long one.

He (Levin) thought of nothing, wished for nothing, but not to be left behind the peasants, and to do his (Levin) work as well as possible.

'' The next rows were easier, but still Levin had to strain every nerve not to drop behind the peasants. He (Levin) heard nothing but the swish of scythes, and saw before him (Levin)

Tit's upright figure mowing away, the crescent-shaped curve of the cut grass, the grass and flower heads slowly and rhythmically falling before the blade of his (Levin) scythe, and ahead of him (Levin) the end of the row, where would come the rest.

Suddenly, in the midst of his (Levin) toil, without understanding what it was or whence it came, he (Levin) felt a pleasant sensation of chill on his (Levin) hot, moist shoulders.

He (Levin) glanced at the sky in the interval for whetting the scythes. A heavy, lowering storm cloud had blown up, and big raindrops were falling.

Some of the peasants went to their coats and put them on; others--just like Levin himself--merely shrugged their shoulders, enjoying the pleasant coolness of it.

Another row, and yet another row, followed--long rows and short rows, with good grass and with poor grass. Levin lost all sense of time, and could not have told whether it was late or early now.

In the midst of his (Levin) toil there were moments during which he (Levin) forgot what he (Levin) was doing, and it came all easy to him (Levin), and at those same moments his (Levin) row was almost as smooth and well cut as Tit's.

But so soon as he (Levin) recollected what he (Levin) was doing, and began trying to do better, he (Levin) was at once conscious of all the difficulty of his (Levin) task, and the row was badly mown.

On finishing yet another row he (Levin) would have gone back to the top of the meadow again to begin the next, but Tit stopped, and going up to the old man said something in a low voice to him (man).

A change began to come over his (man) work, which gave him (man) immense satisfaction. They both looked at the sun. '' What are they talking about, and why doesn't he (man) go back?

'' thought Levin, not guessing that the peasants had been mowing no less than four hours without stopping, and it was time for their lunch.

Levin gave his (Levin) scythe to Tit, and together with the peasants, who were crossing the long stretch of mown grass, slightly sprinkled with rain, to get their bread from the heap of coats, he (Levin) went towards his (Levin) house.

Only then he (Levin) suddenly awoke to the fact that he (Levin) had been wrong about the weather and the rain was drenching his (Levin) hay.

'' Lunch, sir,'' said the old man. '' Is it really time? That's right; lunch, then. '' '' The hay will be spoiled,'' he (man) said.

'' Not a bit of it, sir; mow in the rain, and you'll rake in fine weather!'' said the old man.

When he (man) had drunk his (man) coffee, Levin rode back again to the mowing before Sergey Ivanovitch had had time to dress and come down to the dining room.

After lunch Levin was not in the same place in the string of mowers as before, but stood between the old man who had accosted him (man) jocosely, and now invited him (man) to be his (man) neighbor, and a young peasant, who had only been married in the autumn, and who was mowing this summer for the first time.

The old man, holding himself erect, moved in front, with his (man) feet turned out, taking long, regular strides, and with a precise and regular action which seemed to cost him (man) no more effort than swinging one's arms in walking, as though it were in play, he (man) laid down the high, even row of grass.

Levin untied his (Levin) horse and rode home to his (Levin) coffee. Sergey Ivanovitch was only just getting up. Chapter 5 It was as though it were not he (Ivanovitch) but the sharp scythe of itself swishing through the juicy grass.

His (Ivanovitch) pretty, boyish face, with a twist of fresh grass bound round his (Ivanovitch) hair, was all working with effort; but whenever anyone looked at him (Ivanovitch) he (Ivanovitch) smiled.

Behind Levin came the lad Mishka. He (Levin) would clearly have died sooner than own it was hard work for him (Levin). Levin kept between them.

The perspiration with which he (Levin) was drenched cooled him (Levin), while the sun, that burned his (Levin) back, his (Levin) head, and his (Levin) arms, bare to the elbow, gave a vigor and dogged energy to his (Levin) labor; and more and more often now came those moments of unconsciousness, when it was possible not to think what one was doing.

In the very heat of the day the mowing did not seem such hard work to him (Levin). The scythe cut of itself.

Still more delightful were the moments when they reached the stream where the rows ended, and the old man rubbed his (man) scythe with the wet, thick grass, rinsed its blade in the fresh water of the stream, ladled out a little in a tin dipper, and offered Levin a drink.

And truly Levin had never drunk any liquor so good as this warm water with green bits floating in it, and a taste of rust from the tin dipper.

And immediately after this came the delicious, slow saunter, with his (Levin) hand on the scythe, during which he (Levin) could wipe away the streaming sweat, take deep breaths of air, and look about at the long string of mowers and at what was happening around in the forest and the country.

The longer Levin mowed, the oftener he (Levin) felt the moments of unconsciousness in which it seemed not his (Levin) hands that swung the scythe, but the scythe mowing of itself, a body full of life and consciousness of its own, and as though by magic, without thinking of it, the work turned out regular and well-finished of itself.

These were happy moments. '' What do you say to my home-brew, eh? Good, eh?'' said he (Levin), winking. These were the most blissful moments.

It was only hard work when he (Levin) had to break off the motion, which had become unconscious, and to think; when he (Levin) had to mow round a hillock or a tuft of sorrel.

When a hillock came he (Levin) changed his (Levin) action, and at one time with the heel, and at another with the tip of his (Levin) scythe, clipped the hillock round both sides with short strokes.

And while he (Levin) did this he (Levin) kept looking about and watching what came into his (Levin) view: at one moment he (Levin) picked a wild berry and ate it or offered it to Levin, then he (Levin) flung away a twig with the blade of the scythe, then he (Levin) looked at a quail's nest, from which the bird flew just under the scythe, or caught a snake that crossed his (Levin) path, and lifting it on the scythe as though on a fork showed it to Levin and threw it away.

The old man did this easily. For both Levin and the young peasant behind him (Levin), such changes of position were difficult.

Both of them, repeating over and over again the same strained movement, were in a perfect frenzy of toil, and were incapable of shifting their position and at the same time watching what was before them.

Levin did not notice how time was passing. If he (Levin) had been asked how long he (Levin) had been working he (Levin) would have said half an hour--

As they were walking back over the cut grass, the old man called Levin's attention to the little girls and boys who were coming from different directions, hardly visible through the long grass, and along the road towards the mowers, carrying sacks of bread dragging at their little hands and pitchers of the sour rye-beer, with cloths wrapped round them.

and it was getting on for dinner time.

``Look`ee, the little emmets crawling! '' (he)
he (Levin) said, pointing to them, and he (Levin) shaded his (Levin) eyes with his (Levin) hand to look at the sun.

And on reaching the stream the mowers moved off across the lines of cut grass towards their pile of coats, where the children who had brought their dinners were sitting waiting for them.

They mowed two more rows; the old man stopped.

``Come, master, dinner time! '' (he)
he (man) said briskly. The peasants gathered into groups--those further away under a cart, those nearer under a willow bush.

Levin sat down by them; he (Levin) felt disinclined to go away. All constraint with the master had disappeared long ago. The peasants got ready for dinner.

Some washed, the young lads bathed in the stream, others made a place comfortable for a rest, untied their sacks of bread, and uncovered the pitchers of rye-beer.

The old man crumbled up some bread in a cup, stirred it with the handle of a spoon, poured water on it from the dipper, broke up some more bread, and having seasoned it with salt, he (man) turned to the east to say his (man) prayer.

``Come, master, taste my sop,'' (he)
said he (master), kneeling down before the cup. The sop was so good that Levin gave up the idea of going home.

He (Levin) dined with the old man, and talked to him (Levin) about his (Levin) family affairs, taking the keenest interest in them, and told him (Levin) about his (Levin) own affairs and all the circumstances that could be of interest to the old man.

He (man) felt much nearer to him (man) than to his (man) brother, and could not help smiling at the affection he (man) felt for this man.

When the old man got up again, said his (man) prayer, and lay down under a bush, putting some grass under his (man) head for a pillow

, Levin did the same, and in spite of the clinging flies that were so persistent in the sunshine, and the midges that tickled his (Levin) hot face and body, he (Levin) fell asleep at once and only waked when the sun had passed to the other side of the bush and reached him (Levin).

The old man had been awake a long while, and was sitting up whetting the scythes of the younger lads. Levin looked about him (Levin) and hardly recognized the place, everything was so changed.

The immense stretch of meadow had been mown and was sparkling with a peculiar fresh brilliance, with its lines of already sweet-smelling grass in the slanting rays of the evening sun.

And the bushes about the river had been cut down, and the river itself, not visible before, now gleaming like steel in its bends, and the moving, ascending, peasants, and the sharp wall of grass of the unmown part of the meadow, and the hawks hovering over the stripped meadow--all was perfectly new.

Raising himself, Levin began considering how much had been cut and how much more could still be done that day. The work done was exceptionally much for forty-two men.

They had cut the whole of the big meadow, which had, in the years of serf labor, taken thirty scythes two days to mow.

But Levin felt a longing to get as much mowing done that day as possible, and was vexed with the sun sinking so quickly in the sky.

He (Levin) felt no weariness; all he (Levin) wanted was to get his (Levin) work done more and more quickly and as much done as possible.

Only the corners remained to do, where the rows were short. '' Could you cut Mashkin Upland too?--what do you think?

'' he (Levin) said to the old man. '' As God wills, the sun's not high. A little vodka for the lads?

At the afternoon rest, when they were sitting down again, and those who smoked had lighted their pipes, the old man told the men that

``Mashkin Upland's to be cut--

'' (the men)

there'll be some vodka. ''
``Why not cut it? Come on, Tit! We'll look sharp! We can eat at night.

Come on! '' (unknown)

cried voices, and eating up their bread, the mowers went back to work.
``Come, lads, keep it up!'' (unknown)
said Tit, and ran on ahead almost at a trot.

Get along, get along!'' said the old man, hurrying after him (man) and easily overtaking him (man),

``I'll mow you down, look out!

But however fast they worked, they did not spoil the grass, and the rows were laid just as neatly and exactly.

'' (him)

'' And young and old mowed away, as though they were racing with one another. The little piece left uncut in the corner was mown in five minutes.

The last of the mowers were just ending their rows while the foremost snatched up their coats onto their shoulders, and crossed the road towards Mashkin Upland.

The sun was already sinking into the trees when they went with their jingling dippers into the wooded ravine of Mashkin Upland.

The grass was up to their waists in the middle of the hollow, soft, tender, and feathery, spotted here and there among the trees with wild heart's-ease.

After a brief consultation--whether to take the rows lengthwise or diagonally--Prohor Yermilin, also a renowned mower, a huge, black-haired peasant, went on ahead.

He (peasant) went up to the top, turned back again and started mowing, and they all proceeded to form in line behind him (peasant), going downhill through the hollow and uphill right up to the edge of the forest.

The dew was falling by now; the mowers were in the sun only on the hillside, but below, where a mist was rising, and on the opposite side, they mowed into the fresh, dewy shade.

The sun sank behind the forest. The work went rapidly. The grass cut with a juicy sound, and was at once laid in high, fragrant rows.

The mowers from all sides, brought closer together in the short row, kept urging one another on to the sound of jingling dippers and clanging scythes, and the hiss of the whetstones sharpening them, and good-humored shouts.

The old man, who had put on his (man) short sheepskin jacket, was just as good-humored, jocose, and free in his (man) movements.

Levin still kept between the young peasant and the old man. Among the trees they were continually cutting with their scythes the so-called

``birch mushrooms,'' (unknown)
swollen fat in the succulent grass.

But the old man bent down every time he (man) came across a mushroom, picked it up and put it in his (man) bosom.

Easy as it was to mow the wet, soft grass, it was hard work going up and down the steep sides of the ravine.

'' Another present for my old woman,'' he (man) said as he (man) did so. But this did not trouble the old man.

Swinging his (man) scythe just as ever, and moving his (man) feet in their big, plaited shoes with firm, little steps, he (man) climbed slowly up the steep place, and though his (man) breeches hanging out below his (man) smock, and his (man) whole frame trembled with effort, he (man) did not miss one blade of grass or one mushroom on his (man) way, and kept making jokes with the peasants and Levin.

Levin walked after him (Levin) and often thought he (Levin) must fall, as he (Levin) climbed with a scythe up a steep cliff where it would have been hard work to clamber without anything.

But he (Levin) climbed up and did what he (Levin) had to do. He (Levin) felt as though some external force were moving him (Levin).

Chapter 6 Mashkin Upland was mown, the last row finished, the peasants had put on their coats and were gaily trudging home.

On the hillside he (Levin) looked back; he (Levin) could not see them in the mist that had risen from the valley; he (Levin) could only hear rough, good-humored voices, laughter, and the sound of clanking scythes.

Sergey Ivanovitch had long ago finished dinner, and was drinking iced lemon and water in his (Ivanovitch) own room, looking through the reviews and papers which he (Ivanovitch) had only just received by post, when Levin rushed into the room, talking merrily, with his (Levin) wet and matted hair sticking to his (Levin) forehead, and his (Levin) back and chest grimed and moist.

Levin got on his (Levin) horse and, parting regretfully from the peasants, rode homewards. '' We mowed the whole meadow! Oh, it is nice, delicious!

And how have you been getting on?'' said Levin, completely forgetting the disagreeable conversation of the previous day. '' Mercy! what do you look like!'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, for the first moment looking round with some dissatisfaction.

'' And the door, do shut the door! '' he (Ivanovitch) cried. '' You must have let in a dozen at least.

Sergey Ivanovitch could not endure flies, and in his (Ivanovitch) own room he (Ivanovitch) never opened the window except at night, and carefully kept the door shut.

'' '' Not one, on my honor. But if I have, I'll catch them. You wouldn't believe what a pleasure it is!

How have you spent the day?''

``Very well. But have you really been mowing the whole day? I expect you're as hungry as a wolf.

Kouzma has got everything ready for you.'' (I)

'' No, I don't feel hungry even. I had something to eat there. But I'll go and wash.

``Yes, go along, go along, and I'll come to you directly,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
said Sergey Ivanovitch, shaking his (Ivanovitch) head as he (Ivanovitch) looked at his (Ivanovitch) brother.

'' '' Go along, make haste,'' he (Ivanovitch) added smiling, and gathering up his (Ivanovitch) books, he (Ivanovitch) prepared to go too. He (Ivanovitch), too, felt suddenly good-humored and disinclined to leave his (Ivanovitch) brother's side.

'' But what did you do while it was raining?''

``Rain? Why, there was scarcely a drop. I'll come directly. So you had a nice day too?

That's first-rate. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

And Levin went off to change his (Levin) clothes. Five minutes later the brothers met in the dining room.

Although it seemed to Levin that he (Levin) was not hungry, and he (Levin) sat down to dinner simply so as not to hurt Kouzma's feelings, yet when he (Levin) began to eat the dinner struck him (Levin) as extraordinarily good.

Sergey Ivanovitch watched him (Ivanovitch) with a smile. '' Oh, by the way, there's a letter for you,'' said he (Ivanovitch). '' Kouzma, bring it down, please.

Oblonsky wrote to him (Ivanovitch) from Petersburg:

``I have had a letter from Dolly; she (Dolly)'s at Ergushovo, and everything seems going wrong there.

And mind you shut the doors. '' (him)

The letter was from Oblonsky. Levin read it aloud. Do ride over and see her (Dolly), please; help her (Dolly) with advice; you know all about it.

She (Dolly) will be so glad to see you. She (Dolly)'s quite alone, poor thing. My mother-in-law and all of them are still abroad.

'' '' That's capital! I will certainly ride over to her (mother-in-law),'' said Levin. '' Or we'll go together. She (mother-in-law)'s such a splendid woman, isn't she (mother-in-law)?''

'' They're not far from here, then?''

``Twenty-five miles. Or perhaps it is thirty. But a capital road. Capital, we'll drive over.'' (unknown)

``I shall be delighted,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
said Sergey Ivanovitch, still smiling. The sight of his (Ivanovitch) younger brother's appearance had immediately put him (Ivanovitch) in a good humor.

'' Well, you have an appetite! '' he (Ivanovitch) said, looking at his (Ivanovitch) dark-red, sunburnt face and neck bent over the plate.

'' Splendid! You can't imagine what an effectual remedy it is for every sort of foolishness. I want to enrich medicine with a new word:

Arbeitskur .'' '' Well, but you don't need it, I should fancy.'' '' No, but for all sorts of nervous invalids.

I had meant to come to the mowing to look at you, but it was so unbearably hot that I got no further than the forest.

I sat there a little, and went on by the forest to the village, met your old nurse, and sounded her (nurse) as to the peasants' view of you.

''

``Yes, it ought to be tried. As far as I can make out, they don't approve of this. She (nurse) said: `It's not a gentleman's work.'

Altogether, I fancy that in the people's ideas there are very clear and definite notions of certain, as they call it, `gentlemanly' lines of action.

And they don't sanction the gentry's moving outside bounds clearly laid down in their ideas. '' (unknown)

'' Maybe so; but anyway it's a pleasure such as I have never known in my life.

And there's no harm in it, you know. Is there?'' answered Levin. '' I can't help it if they don't like it.

Though I do believe it's all right. Eh?'' '' Altogether,'' pursued Sergey Ivanovitch,

``you're satisfied with your day?'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)
``Quite satisfied. We cut the whole meadow.

And such a splendid old man I made friends with there! You can't fancy how delightful he (man) was!'' (unknown)

'' Well, so you're content with your day.

And so am I. First , I solved two chess problems, and one a very pretty one--a pawn opening. I'll show it you.

'' said Levin, blissfully dropping his (Levin) eyelids and drawing deep breaths after finishing his (Levin) dinner, and absolutely incapable of recalling what their conversation yesterday was about.

Our difference of opinion amounts to this, that you make the mainspring self-interest, while I suppose that interest in the common weal is bound to exist in every man of a certain degree of advancement.

And then--I thought over our conversation yesterday.''

``Eh! our conversation yesterday? '' (I)
I think you are partly right. Possibly you are right too, that action founded on material interest would be more desirable.

You are altogether, as the French say, too primesauti√®re a nature; you must have intense, energetic action, or nothing. '' Levin listened to his (Levin) brother and did not understand a single word, and did not want to understand.

He (Levin) was only afraid his (Levin) brother might ask him (Levin) some question which would make it evident he (Levin) had not heard. ''

So that's what I think it is, my dear boy,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, touching him (Ivanovitch) on the shoulder. '' Yes, of course.

But, do you know? I won't stand up for my view,'' answered Levin, with a guilty, childlike smile. '' Whatever was it

I was disputing about? '' he (Levin) wondered. '' Of course, I'm right, and he (Levin)'s right, and it's all first-rate. Only I must go round to the counting house and see to things.

If you want to go out, let's go together,'' he (Levin) said, disinclined to be parted from his (Levin) brother, who seemed positively breathing out freshness and energy.

'' He (Levin) got up, stretching and smiling. Sergey Ivanovitch smiled too. '' '' Come, we'll go to the counting house, if you have to go there.''

'' Oh, heavens!'' shouted Levin, so loudly that Sergey Ivanovitch was quite frightened. '' What, what is the matter? '' ''

How's Agafea Mihalovna's hand?'' said Levin, slapping himself on the head. '' I'd positively forgotten her (you) even.'' '' It's much better.''

'' Well, anyway I'll run down to her (you). Before you've time to get your hat on, I'll be back. '' And he (Levin) ran downstairs, clattering with his (Levin) heels like a spring-rattle.

Chapter 7 Stephan Arkadyevitch had gone to Petersburg to perform the most natural and essential official duty--so familiar to everyone in the government service, though incomprehensible to outsiders-- that duty, but for which one could hardly be in government service, of reminding the ministry of his (Stephan) existence--and having, for the due performance of this rite, taken all the available cash from home, was gaily and agreeably spending his (Stephan) days at the races and in the summer villas.

She (Levin) had gone to Ergushovo, the estate that had been her (Levin) dowry, and the one where in spring the forest had been sold.

Meanwhile Dolly and the children had moved into the country, to cut down expenses as much as possible. It was nearly forty miles from Levin's Pokrovskoe.

The big, old house at Ergushovo had been pulled down long ago, and the old prince had had the lodge done up and built on to.

Twenty years before, when Dolly was a child, the lodge had been roomy and comfortable, though, like all lodges, it stood sideways to the entrance avenue, and faced the south.

When Stepan Arkadyevitch had gone down in the spring to sell the forest, Dolly had begged him (prince) to look over the house and order what repairs might be needed.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, like all unfaithful husbands indeed, was very solicitous for his (prince) wife's comfort, and he (prince) had himself looked over the house, and given instructions about everything that he (prince) considered necessary.

What he (prince) considered necessary was to cover all the furniture with cretonne, to put up curtains, to weed the garden, to make a little bridge on the pond, and to plant flowers.

But by now this lodge was old and dilapidated. But he (prince) forgot many other essential matters, the want of which greatly distressed Darya Alexandrovna later on.

In spite of Stepan Arkadyevitch's efforts to be an attentive father and husband, he (husband) never could keep in his (husband) mind that he (husband) had a wife and children.

On his (husband) return to Moscow he (husband) informed his (husband) wife with pride that everything was ready, that the house would be a little paradise, and that he (husband) advised her (wife) most certainly to go.

His (husband) wife's staying away in the country was very agreeable to Stepan Arkadyevitch from every point of view: it did the children good, it decreased expenses, and it left him (husband) more at liberty.

Darya Alexandrovna regarded staying in the country for the summer as essential for the children, especially for the little girl, who had not succeeded in regaining her (girl) strength after the scarlatina, and also as a means of escaping the petty humiliations, the little bills owing to the wood-merchant, the fishmonger, the shoemaker, which made her (girl) miserable.

Besides this, she (girl) was pleased to go away to the country because she (girl) was dreaming of getting her (girl) sister Kitty to stay with her (girl) there.

He (shoemaker) had bachelor tastes, and it was in accordance with them that he (shoemaker) shaped his (shoemaker) life. Kitty was to be back from abroad in the middle of the summer, and bathing had been prescribed for her (Kitty).

Kitty wrote that no prospect was so alluring as to spend the summer with Dolly at Ergushovo, full of childish associations for both of them.

She (Dolly) used to stay in the country as a child, and the impression she (Dolly) had retained of it was that the country was a refuge from all the unpleasantness of the town, that life there, though not luxurious--Dolly could easily make up her (Dolly) mind to that--was cheap and comfortable; that there was plenty of everything

The first days of her (Dolly) existence in the country were very hard for Dolly. , everything was cheap, everything could be got, and children were happy.

But now coming to the country as the head of a family, she (Dolly) perceived that it was all utterly unlike what she (Dolly) had fancied.

The day after their arrival there was a heavy fall of rain, and in the night the water came through in the corridor and in the nursery, so that the beds had to be carried into the drawing room.

There was no kitchen maid to be found; of the nine cows, it appeared from the words of the cowherd-woman that some were about to calve, others had just calved, others were old, and others again hard-uddered; there was not butter nor milk enough even for the children.

There were no eggs. They could get no fowls; old, purplish, stringy cocks were all they had for roasting and boiling.

Impossible to get women to scrub the floors--all were potato-hoeing. Driving was out of the question, because one of the horses was restive, and bolted in the shafts.

There was no place where they could bathe; the whole of the river-bank was trampled by the cattle and open to the road; even walks were impossible, for the cattle strayed into the garden through a gap in the hedge, and there was one terrible bull, who bellowed, and therefore might be expected to gore somebody.

There were no proper cupboards for their clothes; what cupboards there were either would not close at all, or burst open whenever anyone passed by them.

There were no pots and pans; there was no copper in the washhouse, nor even an ironing-board in the maids' room.

Finding instead of peace and rest all these, from her (maids) point of view, fearful calamities, Darya Alexandrovna was at first in despair.

She (maids) exerted herself to the utmost, felt the hopelessness of the position, and was every instant suppressing the tears that started into her (maids) eyes.

The bailiff, a retired quartermaster, whom Stepan Arkadyevitch had taken a fancy to and had appointed bailiff on account of his (bailiff) handsome and respectful appearance as a hall-porter, showed no sympathy for Darya Alexandrovna's woes.

He (bailiff) said respectfully,

``nothing can be done, the peasants are such a wretched lot,'' (He)
and did nothing to help her (maids). The position seemed hopeless.

But in the Oblonskys' household, as in all families indeed, there was one inconspicuous but most valuable and useful person, Marya Philimonovna.

-LRB-it was her (Philimonovna) expression, and Matvey had borrowed it from her (Philimonovna)-RRB-, and without fuss or hurry proceeded to set to work herself.

She (Philimonovna) had immediately made friends with the bailiff's wife, and on the very first day she (Philimonovna) drank tea with her (Philimonovna) and the bailiff under the acacias, and reviewed all the circumstances of the position.

Very soon Marya Philimonovna had established her (Philimonovna) club, so to say, under the acacias, and there it was, in this club, consisting of the bailiff's wife, the village elder, and the counting house clerk, that the difficulties of existence were gradually smoothed away, and in a week's time everything actually had come round.

The roof was mended, a kitchen maid was found--a crony of the village elder's--hens were bought, the cows began giving milk, the garden hedge was stopped up with stakes, the carpenter made a mangle, hooks were put in the cupboards, and they ceased to burst open spontaneously, and an ironing-board covered with army cloth was placed across from the arm of a chair to the chest of drawers, and there was a smell of flatirons in the maids' room.

She (maid) soothed her (maid) mistress, assured her (maid) that everything would come round '' Just see, now, and you were quite in despair,'' said Marya Philimonovna, pointing to the ironing-board.

Lily began to bathe, and Darya Alexandrovna began to realize, if only in part, her (Lily) expectations, if not of a peaceful, at least of a comfortable, life in the country.

One would fall ill, another might easily become so, a third would be without something necessary, a fourth would show symptoms of a bad disposition, and so on.

They even rigged up a bathing-shed of straw hurdles. Peaceful with six children Darya Alexandrovna could not be. Rare indeed were the brief periods of peace.

Had it not been for them, she (Lily) would have been left alone to brood over her (Lily) husband who did not love her (Lily).

And besides, hard though it was for the mother to bear the dread of illness, the illnesses themselves, and the grief of seeing signs of evil propensities in her (mother) children--the children themselves were even now repaying her (mother) in small joys for her (mother) sufferings.

Those joys were so small that they passed unnoticed, like gold in sand, and at bad moments she (mother) could see nothing but the pain, nothing but sand; but there were good moments too when she (mother) saw nothing but the joy, nothing but gold.

But these cares and anxieties were for Darya Alexandrovna the sole happiness possible. Now in the solitude of the country, she (mother) began to be more and more frequently aware of those joys.

Often, looking at them, she (mother) would make every possible effort to persuade herself that she (mother) was mistaken, that she (mother) as a mother was partial to her (mother) children.

All the same, she (mother) could not help saying to herself that she (mother) had charming children, all six of them in different ways, but a set of children such as is not often to be met with, and she (mother) was happy in them, and proud of them.

Chapter 8 Towards the end of May, when everything had been more or less satisfactorily arranged, she (mother) received her (mother) husband's answer to her (mother) complaints of the disorganized state of things in the country.

He (husband) wrote begging her (mother) forgiveness for not having thought of everything before, and promised to come down at the first chance.

This chance did not present itself, and till the beginning of June Darya Alexandrovna stayed alone in the country. On the Sunday in St. Peter's week Darya Alexandrovna drove to mass for all her (mother) children to take the sacrament.

Darya Alexandrovna in her (mother) intimate, philosophical talks with her (mother) sister, her (mother) mother, and her (mother) friends very often astonished them by the freedom of her (mother) views in regard to religion.

She (mother) had a strange religion of transmigration of souls all her (mother) own, in which she (mother) had firm faith, troubling herself little about the dogmas of the Church.

But in her (mother) family she (mother) was strict in carrying out all that was required by the Church--and not merely in order to set an example, but with all her (mother) heart in it.

The fact that the children had not been at the sacrament for nearly a year worried her (mother) extremely, and with the full approval and sympathy of Marya Philimonovna she (Philimonovna) decided that this should take place now in the summer.

For several days before, Darya Alexandrovna was busily deliberating on how to dress all the children. Frocks were made or altered and washed, seams and flounces were let out,

buttons were sewn on, and ribbons got ready. One dress, Tanya's, which the English governess had undertaken, cost Darya Alexandrovna much loss of temper.

The English governess in altering it had made the seams in the wrong place, had taken up the sleeves too much, and altogether spoilt the dress.

It was so narrow on Tanya's shoulders that it was quite painful to look at her (Tanya). But Marya Philimonovna had the happy thought of putting in gussets, and adding a little shoulder-cape.

On the morning, however, all was happily arranged, and towards ten o'clock--the time at which they had asked the priest to wait for them for the mass--the children in their new dresses, with beaming faces, stood on the step before the carriage waiting for their mother.

To the carriage, instead of the restive Raven, they had harnessed, thanks to the representations of Marya Philimonovna, the bailiff's horse, Brownie, and Darya Alexandrovna, delayed by anxiety over her (Philimonovna) own attire, came out and got in, dressed in a white muslin gown.

The dress was set right, but there was nearly a quarrel with the English governess. Darya Alexandrovna had done her (Philimonovna) hair, and dressed with care and excitement.

In the old days she (Philimonovna) had dressed for her (Philimonovna) own sake to look pretty and be admired. Later on, as she (Philimonovna) got older, dress became more and more distasteful to her (Philimonovna).

She (Philimonovna) saw that she (Philimonovna) was losing her (Philimonovna) good looks. But now she (Philimonovna) began to feel pleasure and interest in dress again.

Now she (Philimonovna) did not dress for her (Philimonovna) own sake, not for the sake of her (Philimonovna) own beauty, but simply that as the mother of those exquisite creatures she (Philimonovna) might not spoil the general effect.

Not nice as she (Philimonovna) would have wished to look nice in old days at a ball, but nice for the object which she (Philimonovna) now had in view.

And looking at herself for the last time in the looking-glass she (Philimonovna) was satisfied with herself. She (Philimonovna) looked nice. In the church there was no one but the peasants, the servants and their women-folk.

The children were not only beautiful to look at in their smart little dresses, but they were charming in the way they behaved.

Aliosha, it is true, did not stand quite correctly; he (they) kept turning round, trying to look at his (they) little jacket from behind; but all the same he (they) was wonderfully sweet.

But Darya Alexandrovna saw, or fancied she (Philimonovna) saw, the sensation produced by her (Philimonovna) children and her (Philimonovna). Tanya behaved like a grownup person, and looked after the little ones.

And the smallest, Lily, was bewitching in her (Lily) na√Øve astonishment at everything, and it was difficult not to smile when, after taking the sacrament, she (Lily) said in English,

``Please, some more.

Everything went happily at home too; but at lunch Grisha began whistling, and, what was worse, was disobedient to the English governess, and was forbidden to have any tart.

'' (she)

On the way home the children felt that something solemn had happened, and were very sedate. Darya Alexandrovna would not have let things go so far on such a day

had she (Lily) been present; but she (Lily) had to support the English governess's authority, and she (Lily) upheld her (Lily) decision that Grisha should have no tart.

Grisha cried, declaring that Nikolinka had whistled too, and he (Lily) was not punished, and that he (Lily) wasn't crying for the tart--he (Lily) didn't care--but at being unjustly treated.

This was really too tragic, and Darya Alexandrovna made up her (Lily) mind to persuade the English governess to forgive Grisha, and she (Lily) went to speak to her (Lily).

But on the way, as she (Lily) passed the drawing room, she (Lily) beheld a scene, filling her (Lily) heart with such pleasure that the tears came into her (Lily) eyes, and she (Lily) forgave the delinquent herself.

The culprit was sitting at the window in the corner of the drawing room; beside him (culprit) was standing Tanya with a plate.

On the pretext of wanting to give some dinner to her (Tanya) dolls, she (Tanya) had asked the governess's permission to take her (Tanya) share of tart to the nursery, and had taken it instead to her (Tanya) brother.

While still weeping over the injustice of his (brother) punishment, he (brother) was eating the tart, and kept saying through his (brother) sobs,

``Eat yourself; let's eat it together...together.

Tanya had at first been under the influence of her (Tanya) pity for Grisha, then of a sense of her (Tanya) noble action, and tears were standing in her (Tanya) eyes too; but she (Tanya) did not refuse, and ate her (Tanya) share.

On catching sight of their mother they were dismayed, but, looking into her (Tanya) face, they saw they were not doing wrong.

They burst out laughing, and, with their mouths full of tart, they began wiping their smiling lips with their hands, and smearing their radiant faces all over with tears and jam.

This rather spoiled the general good humor. '' (he)

``Mercy! Your new white frock! Tanya! Grisha! '' (mother)
said their mother, trying to save the frock, but with tears in her (Tanya) eyes, smiling a blissful, rapturous smile.

The new frocks were taken off, and orders were given for the little girls to have their blouses put on, and the boys their old jackets, and the wagonette to be harnessed; with Brownie, to the bailiff's annoyance, again in the shafts, to drive out for mushroom picking and bathing.

A roar of delighted shrieks arose in the nursery, and never ceased till they had set off for the bathing-place. They gathered a whole basketful of mushrooms; even Lily found a birch mushroom.

It had always happened before that Miss Hoole found them and pointed them out to her (Hoole); but this time she (Hoole) found a big one quite of herself, and there was a general scream of delight,

``Lily has found a mushroom!'' (a scream)
Then they reached the river, put the horses under the birch trees, and went to the bathing-place.

The coachman, Terenty, fastened the horses, who kept whisking away the flies, to a tree, and, treading down the grass, lay down in the shade of a birch and smoked his (them) shag, while the never-ceasing shrieks of delight of the children floated across to him (them) from the bathing-place.

Though it was hard work to look after all the children and restrain their wild pranks, though it was difficult too to keep in one's head and not mix up all the stockings, little breeches, and shoes for the different legs, and to undo and to do up again all the tapes and buttons, Darya Alexandrovna, who had always liked bathing herself, and believed it to be very good for the children, enjoyed nothing so much as bathing with all the children.

To go over all those fat little legs, pulling on their stockings, to take in her (herself) arms and dip those little naked bodies, and to hear their screams of delight and alarm, to see the breathless faces with wide-open, scared, and happy eyes of all her (herself) splashing cherubs, was a great pleasure to her (herself).

When half the children had been dressed, some peasant women in holiday dress, out picking herbs, came up to the bathing-shed and stopped shyly.

Marya Philimonovna called one of them and handed her (Philimonovna) a sheet and a shirt that had dropped into the water for her (Philimonovna) to dry them, and Darya Alexandrovna began to talk to the women.

At first they laughed behind their hands and did not understand her (Philimonovna) questions, but soon they grew bolder and began to talk, winning Darya Alexandrovna's heart at once by the genuine admiration of the children that they showed.

'' My, what a beauty! as white as sugar,'' said one, admiring Tanitchka, and shaking her (Philimonovna) head;

``but thin... '' (she)
''

Yes, she (Philimonovna) has been ill.'' '' And so they've been bathing you too,'' said another to the baby. '' No; he (you)'s only three months old,'' answered Darya Alexandrovna with pride.

'' You don't say so!'' '' And have you any children?''

``I've had four; I've two living--a boy and a girl.

I weaned her (girl) last carnival. '' (unknown)

``How old is she (girl)?'' (unknown)
``Why, two years old. '' (unknown)
``Why did you nurse her (nurse) so long?'' (unknown)

'' It's our custom; for three fasts... '' And the conversation became most interesting to Darya Alexandrovna. What sort of time did she (nurse) have?

Darya Alexandrovna felt disinclined to leave the peasant women, so interesting to her (nurse) was their conversation, so completely identical were all their interests.

What pleased her (nurse) most of all was that she (nurse) saw clearly what all the women admired more than anything was her (nurse) having so many children, and such fine ones.

The peasant women even made Darya Alexandrovna laugh, and offended the English governess, because she (nurse) was the cause of the laughter she (nurse) did not understand.

One of the younger women kept staring at the Englishwoman, who was dressing after all the rest, and when she (Englishwoman) put on her (Englishwoman) third petticoat she (Englishwoman) could not refrain from the remark,

``My, she (Englishwoman) keeps putting on and putting on, and she (Englishwoman)'ll never have done!

What was the matter with the boy? Where was her (Englishwoman) husband? Did it often happen? '' (she)

she (Englishwoman) said, and they all went off into roars.
