On the drive home, as Darya Alexandrovna, with all her (Englishwoman) children round her (Englishwoman), their heads still wet from their bath, and a kerchief tied over her (Englishwoman) own head, was getting near the house, the coachman said,

``There's some gentleman coming: the master of Pokrovskoe, I do believe.

Darya Alexandrovna peeped out in front, and was delighted when she (Englishwoman) recognized in the gray hat and gray coat the familiar figure of Levin walking to meet them.

She (Englishwoman) was glad to see him (Levin) at any time, but at this moment she (Englishwoman) was specially glad he (Levin) should see her (Englishwoman) in all her (Englishwoman) glory.

Chapter 9 '' (the coachman)

No one was better able to appreciate her (Englishwoman) grandeur than Levin. Seeing her (Englishwoman), he (Levin) found himself face to face with one of the pictures of his (Levin) daydream of family life.

'' You're like a hen with your chickens, Darya Alexandrovna.''

``Ah, how glad I am to see you!'' (she)
she (Englishwoman) said, holding out her (Englishwoman) hand to him (Levin).

'' Glad to see me, but you didn't let me know. My brother's staying with me. I got a note from Stiva that you were here.''

Yes; he (brother) writes that you are here, and that he (brother) thinks you might allow me to be of use to you,'' said Levin, and as he (Levin) said it he (Levin) became suddenly embarrassed, and, stopping abruptly, he (Levin) walked on in silence by the wagonette, snapping off the buds of the lime trees and nibbling them.

He (Levin) was embarrassed through a sense that Darya Alexandrovna would be annoyed by receiving from an outsider help that should by rights have come from her (Levin) own husband.

``From Stiva? '' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
Darya Alexandrovna asked with surprise. '' Darya Alexandrovna certainly did not like this little way of Stepan Arkadyevitch's of foisting his (husband) domestic duties on others.

And she (Levin) was at once aware that Levin was aware of this. It was just for this fineness of perception, for this delicacy, that Darya Alexandrovna liked Levin.

I know, of course,'' said Levin,

``that that simply means that you would like to see me, and I'm exceedingly glad.

Though I can fancy that, used to town housekeeping as you are, you must feel in the wilds here, and if there's anything wanted, I'm altogether at your disposal.

capitally-- thanks to my old nurse,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

she (nurse) said, indicating Marya Philimonovna, who, seeing that they were speaking of her (nurse), smiled brightly and cordially to Levin.

She (nurse) knew him (Levin), and knew that he (Levin) would be a good match for her (nurse) young lady, and was very keen to see the matter settled.

'' '' '' Oh, no! '' said Dolly. '' At first things were rather uncomfortable, but now we've settled everything ''

Won't you get in, sir, we'll make room this side! '' she (Dolly) said to him (Levin). '' No, I'll walk. Children, who'd like to race the horses with me?

The children knew Levin very little, and could not remember when they had seen him (Levin), but they experienced in regard to him (Levin) none of that strange feeling of shyness and hostility which children so often experience towards hypocritical, grown-up people, and for which they are so often and miserably punished.

Hypocrisy in anything whatever may deceive the cleverest and most penetrating man, but the least wide-awake of children recognizes it, and is revolted by it, however ingeniously it may be disguised.

Whatever faults Levin had, there was not a trace of hypocrisy in him (Levin), and so the children showed him (Levin) the same friendliness that they saw in their mother's face.

On his (Levin) invitation, the two elder ones at once jumped out to him (Levin) and ran with him (Levin) as simply as they would have done with their nurse or Miss Hoole or their mother.

Lily, too, began begging to go to him (Levin), and her (Lily) mother handed her (Lily) to him (Levin); he (Levin) sat her (Lily) on his (Levin) shoulder and ran along with her (Lily).

'' '' Don't be afraid, don't be afraid, Darya Alexandrovna! '' he (Levin) said, smiling good-humoredly to the mother;

``there's no chance of my hurting or dropping her (mother).

And, looking at his (Levin) strong, agile, assiduously careful and needlessly wary movements, the mother felt her (mother) mind at rest, and smiled gaily and approvingly as she (mother) watched him (Levin).

Here, in the country, with children, and with Darya Alexandrovna, with whom he (Levin) was in sympathy, Levin was in a mood not infrequent with him (Levin), of childlike light-heartedness that she (mother) particularly liked in him (Levin).

As he (Levin) ran with the children, he (Levin) taught them gymnastic feats, set Miss Hoole laughing with his (Levin) queer English accent, and talked to Darya Alexandrovna of his (Levin) pursuits in the country.

'' (the mother)

After dinner, Darya Alexandrovna, sitting alone with him (Levin) on the balcony, began to speak of Kitty. '' You know, Kitty's coming here, and is going to spend the summer with me.''

``Really,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, flushing, and at once, to change the conversation, he (Levin) said:
``Then I'll send you two cows, shall I?

If you insist on a bill you shall pay me five roubles a month; but it's really too bad of you.'' (he)

Oh, well, then, I'll have a look at your cows, and if you'll allow me, I'll give directions about their food.

'' And Levin, to turn the conversation, explained to Darya Alexandrovna the theory of cow-keeping, based on the principle that the cow is simply a machine for the transformation of food into milk, and so on.

He (Levin) talked of this, and passionately longed to hear more of Kitty, and, at the same time, was afraid of hearing it.

'' No, thank you. We can manage very well now.'' '' Everything depends on their food. He (Levin) dreaded the breaking up of the inward peace he (Levin) had gained with such effort.

'' Yes, but still all this has to be looked after, and who is there to look after it?'' Darya Alexandrovna responded, without interest.

She (Kitty) had by now got her (Kitty) household matters so satisfactorily arranged, thanks to Marya Philimonovna, that she (Philimonovna) was disinclined to make any change in them; besides, she (Philimonovna) had no faith in Levin's knowledge of farming.

General principles, as to the cow being a machine for the production of milk, she (Philimonovna) looked on with suspicion. It seemed to her (Philimonovna) that such principles could only be a hindrance in farm management.

It all seemed to her (Philimonovna) a far simpler matter: all that was needed, as Marya Philimonovna had explained, was to give Brindle and Whitebreast more food and drink, and not to let the cook carry all the kitchen slops to the laundry maid's cow.

That was clear. But general propositions as to feeding on meal and on grass were doubtful and obscure. And, what was most important, she (maid) wanted to talk about Kitty.

``Kitty writes to me that there's nothing she (Kitty) longs for so much as quiet and solitude,'' (Dolly)
Dolly said after the silence that had followed.

Chapter 10 '' And how is she (Dolly)--better? '' Levin asked in agitation. '' Thank God, she (Dolly)'s quite well again. I never believed her (Dolly) lungs were affected.''

Oh, I'm very glad!'' said Levin, and Dolly fancied she (Dolly) saw something touching, helpless, in his (Levin) face as he (Levin) said this and looked silently into her (Dolly) face.

Let me ask you, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' said Darya Alexandrovna, smiling her (Dolly) kindly and rather mocking smile,

``why is it you are angry with Kitty?'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)

'' ''

``I? I'm not angry with her (Kitty),'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin. '' Yes, you are angry. Why was it you did not come to see us nor them when you were in Moscow?''

``Darya Alexandrovna,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, blushing up to the roots of his (Levin) hair,
``I wonder really that with your kind heart you don't feel this.

How it is you feel no pity for me, if nothing else, when you know... '' (he)

'' What do I know?''

You know I made an offer and that I was refused,'' said Levin, and all the tenderness he (Levin) had been feeling for Kitty a minute before was replaced by a feeling of anger for the slight he (Levin) had suffered.

'' '' What makes you suppose I know? '' '' Because everybody knows it... '' '' That's just where you are mistaken; I did not know it, though I had guessed it was so.''

All I knew was that something had happened that made her (Kitty) dreadfully miserable, and that she (Kitty) begged me never to speak of it.

'' Well, now you know it. '' '' And if she (Kitty) would not tell me, she (Kitty) would certainly not speak of it to anyone else.

But what did pass between you? Tell me.''

``I have told you.'' (unknown)
'' When was it?'' '' When I was at their house the last time.

''

``Do you know that,'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna,
``I am awfully, awfully sorry for her (Kitty). You suffer only from pride... '' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
``Perhaps so,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin,
``but...

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

She (Kitty) interrupted him (Levin). '' But she (Kitty), poor girl... I am awfully, awfully sorry for her (Kitty). Now I see it all.

'' '' Well, Darya Alexandrovna, you must excuse me,'' he (Levin) said, getting up. '' Good-bye, Darya Alexandrovna, till we meet again.''

``Please, please, don't let us talk of this,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, sitting down, and at the same time feeling rise up and stir within his (Levin) heart a hope he (Levin) had believed to be buried.

If I did not like you,'' she (Kitty) said, and tears came into her (Kitty) eyes;

``if I did not know you, as I do know you ...

'' (she)

No, wait a minute,'' she (Kitty) said, clutching him (Levin) by the sleeve. '' Wait a minute, sit down.'' '' '' The feeling that had seemed dead revived more and more, rose up and took possession of Levin's heart.

You can't understand it; for you men, who are free and make your own choice, it's always clear whom you love.

But a girl's in a position of suspense, with all a woman's or maiden's modesty, a girl who sees you men from afar, who takes everything on trust,-- a girl may have, and often has, such a feeling that she (girl) cannot tell what to say.

'' Yes, I understand it all now,'' said Darya Alexandrovna. '' '' '' Yes, if the heart does not speak...'' ''

No, the heart does speak; but just consider: you men have views about a girl, you come to the house, you make friends, you criticize, you wait to see if you have found what you love, and then, when you are sure you love her (girl), you make an offer...

``Anyway you make an offer, when your love is ripe or when the balance has completely turned between the two you are choosing from.

'' (her)

'' Well, that's not quite it. '' But a girl is not asked. She (girl) is expected to make her (girl) choice, and yet she (girl) cannot choose, she (girl) can only answer `yes' or `no.'''

``Yes, to choose between me and Vronsky,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
thought Levin, and the dead thing that had come to life within him (Levin) died again, and only weighed on his (Levin) heart and set it aching.

'' Darya Alexandrovna,'' he (Levin) said, ``that's how one chooses a new dress or some purchase or other, not love. The choice has been made, and so much the better...

``Ah, pride, pride!'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna, as though despising him (Levin) for the baseness of this feeling in comparison with that other feeling which only women know.

And there can be no repeating it.'' '' At the time when you made Kitty an offer she (Kitty) was just in a position in which she (Kitty) could not answer.

She (Kitty) was in doubt. Doubt between you and Vronsky. Him (Levin) she (Kitty) was seeing every day, and you she (Kitty) had not seen for a long while.

Supposing she (Kitty) had been older... I, for instance, in her (Kitty) place could have felt no doubt. I always disliked him (Levin), and so it has turned out.

'' Levin recalled Kitty's answer. She (Kitty) had said: '' No, that cannot be ... ''

``Darya Alexandrovna,'' (She)
he (Levin) said dryly, ``I appreciate your confidence in me; I believe you are making a mistake.

But whether I am right or wrong, that pride you so despise makes any thought of Katerina Alexandrovna out of the question for me,-- you understand, utterly out of the question.

``I will only say one thing more: you know that I am speaking of my sister, whom I love as I love my own children.

I don't say she (sister) cared for you, all I meant to say is that her (sister) refusal at that moment proves nothing.

'' (unknown)

''
``I don't know!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, jumping up. '' If you only knew how you are hurting me. It's just as if a child of yours were dead, and they were to say to you:

He (Levin) would have been like this and like that, and he (Levin) might have lived, and how happy you would have been in him (Levin).

But he (Levin)'s dead, dead, dead!...''

``How absurd you are!'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna, looking with mournful tenderness at Levin's excitement. '' Yes, I see it all more and more clearly,'' she (It) went on musingly.

Of course I won't avoid meeting Katerina Alexandrovna, but as far as I can, I will try to save her (Alexandrovna) the annoyance of my presence.''

'' So you won't come to see us, then, when Kitty's here?'' '' No, I shan't come. '' You are very, very absurd,'' repeated Darya Alexandrovna, looking with tenderness into his (Levin) face.

'' Very well then, let it be as though we had not spoken of this. What have you come for, Tanya?

'' she (Tanya) said in French to the little girl who had come in. '' Where's my spade, mamma?''

``I speak French, and you must too.

The little girl tried to say it in French, but could not remember the French for spade; the mother prompted her (mother), and then told her (mother) in French where to look for the spade.

Everything in Darya Alexandrovna's house and children struck him (girl) now as by no means so charming as a little while before.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

And this made a disagreeable impression on Levin. '' And what does she (mother) talk French with the children for? ''

Learning French and unlearning sincerity,'' he (Levin) thought to himself, unaware that Darya Alexandrovna had thought all that over twenty times already, and yet, even at the cost of some loss of sincerity, believed it necessary to teach her (mother) children French in that way.

he (Levin) thought;

``how unnatural and false it is! And the children feel it so: '' (he)
But why are you going? Do stay a little.

After tea he (Levin) went out into the hall to order his (Levin) horses to be put in, and, when he (Levin) came back, he (Levin) found Darya Alexandrovna greatly disturbed, with a troubled face, and tears in her (mother) eyes.

While Levin had been outside, an incident had occurred which had utterly shattered all the happiness she (mother) had been feeling that day, and her (mother) pride in her (mother) children.

'' Levin stayed to tea; but his (Levin) good-humor had vanished, and he (Levin) felt ill at ease. Grisha and Tanya had been fighting over a ball.

Tanya was pulling Grisha's hair, while he (Levin), with a face hideous with rage, was beating her (Tanya) with his (Levin) fists wherever he (Levin) could get at her (Tanya).

Darya Alexandrovna, hearing a scream in the nursery, ran in and saw a terrible sight. Something snapped in Darya Alexandrovna's heart when she (Tanya) saw this.

It was as if darkness had swooped down upon her (Tanya) life; she (Tanya) felt that these children of hers, that she (Tanya) was so proud of, were not merely most ordinary, but positively bad, ill-bred children, with coarse, brutal propensities--wicked children.

Levin saw she (Tanya) was unhappy and tried to comfort her (Tanya), saying that it showed nothing bad, that all children fight; but, even as he (Levin) said it, he (Levin) was thinking in his (Levin) heart:

She (Tanya) could not talk or think of anything else, and she (Tanya) could not speak to Levin of her (Tanya) misery.

``No, I won't be artificial and talk French with my children; but my children won't be like that.

All one has to do is not spoil children, not to distort their nature, and they'll be delightful. No, my children won't be like that.

In the middle of July the elder of the village on Levin's sister's estate, about fifteen miles from Pokrovskoe, came to Levin to report on how things were going there and on the hay.

'' (He)

He (Levin) said good-bye and drove away, and she (sister) did not try to keep him (Levin). Chapter 11 The chief source of income on his (chief) sister's estate was from the riverside meadows.

When Levin took over the management of the estate, he (Levin) thought on examining the grasslands that they were worth more, and he (Levin) fixed the price at twenty-five roubles the three acres.

In former years the hay had been bought by the peasants for twenty roubles the three acres. The peasants would not give that price, and, as Levin suspected, kept off other purchasers.

Then Levin had driven over himself, and arranged to have the grass cut, partly by hired labor, partly at a payment of a certain proportion of the crop.

His (Levin) own peasants put every hindrance they could in the way of this new arrangement, but it was carried out, and the first year the meadows had yielded a profit almost double.

The previous year--which was the third year--the peasants had maintained the same opposition to the arrangement, and the hay had been cut on the same system.

This year the peasants were doing all the mowing for a third of the hay crop, and the village elder had come now to announce that the hay had been cut, and that, fearing rain, they had invited the counting-house clerk over, had divided the crop in his (peasants) presence, and had raked together eleven stacks as the owner's share.

From the vague answers to his (peasants) question how much hay had been cut on the principal meadow, from the hurry of the village elder who had made the division, not asking leave, from the whole tone of the peasant, Levin perceived that there was something wrong in the division of the hay, and made up his (Levin) mind to drive over himself to look into the matter.

Arriving for dinner at the village, and leaving his (Levin) horse at the cottage of an old friend of his (Levin), the husband of his (Levin) brother's wet-nurse, Levin went to see the old man in his (Levin) bee-house, wanting to find out from him (Levin) the truth about the hay.

Parmenitch, a talkative, comely old man, gave Levin a very warm welcome, showed him (Levin) all he (Levin) was doing, told him (Levin) everything about his (Levin) bees and the swarms of that year; but gave vague and unwilling answers to Levin's inquiries about the mowing.

This confirmed Levin still more in his (Levin) suspicions. He (Levin) went to the hay fields and examined the stacks. The haystacks could not possibly contain fifty wagon-loads each, and to convict the peasants

Levin ordered the wagons that had carried the hay to be brought up directly, to lift one stack, and carry it into the barn.

In spite of the village elder's assertions about the compressibility of hay, and its having settled down in the stacks, and his (Levin) swearing that everything had been done in the fear of God, Levin stuck to his (Levin) point that the hay had been divided without his (Levin) orders, and that, therefore, he (Levin) would not accept that hay as fifty loads to a stack.

After a prolonged dispute the matter was decided by the peasants taking these eleven stacks, reckoning them as fifty loads each.

There turned out to be only thirty-two loads in the stack. The arguments and the division of the haycocks lasted the whole afternoon.

When the last of the hay had been divided, Levin, intrusting the superintendence of the rest to the counting-house clerk, sat down on a haycock marked off by a stake of willow, and looked admiringly at the meadow swarming with peasants.

In front of him (Levin), in the bend of the river beyond the marsh, moved a bright-colored line of peasant women, and the scattered hay was being rapidly formed into gray winding rows over the pale green stubble.

After the women came the men with pitchforks, and from the gray rows there were growing up broad, high, soft haycocks.

To the left, carts were rumbling over the meadow that had been already cleared, and one after another the haycocks vanished, flung up in huge forkfuls, and in their place there were rising heavy cartloads of fragrant hay hanging over the horses' hind-quarters.

'' What weather for haying! What hay it'll be!'' said an old man, squatting down beside Levin. '' It's tea, not hay!

It's like scattering grain to the ducks, the way they pick it up! '' he (Levin) added, pointing to the growing haycocks.

'' he (Levin) shouted to a young peasant, who drove by, standing in the front of an empty cart, shaking the cord reins.

the lad shouted back, pulling in the horse, and, smiling, he (lad) looked round at a bright, rosy-checked peasant girl who sat in the cart smiling too, and drove on.

'' Since dinnertime they've carried a good half of it.'' '' The last load, eh? '' The last, dad! '' ''

Who's that? Your son?'' asked Levin. '' My baby,'' said the old man with a tender smile. '' What a fine fellow!''

'' The lad's all right. ''

``Married already?'' (unknown)
``Yes, it's two years last St. Philip's day.'' (unknown)
``Any children?'' (unknown)
``Children indeed! Why, for over a year he (Philip) was innocent as a babe himself, and bashful too,'' (the man)
answered the old man.

'' Well, the hay! It's as fragrant as tea! '' he (man) repeated, wishing to change the subject. Levin looked more attentively at Ivan Parmenov and his (Levin) wife.

Ivan Parmenov was standing on the cart, taking, laying in place, and stamping down the huge bundles of hay, which his (Parmenov) pretty young wife deftly handed up to him (Parmenov), at first in armfuls, and then on the pitchfork.

They were loading a haycock onto the cart not far from him (Parmenov). The young wife worked easily, merrily, and dexterously. The close-packed hay did not once break away off her (wife) fork.

First she (wife) gathered it together, stuck the fork into it, then with a rapid, supple movement leaned the whole weight of her (wife) body on it, and at once with a bend of her (wife) back under the red belt she (wife) drew herself up, and arching her (wife) full bosom under the white smock, with a smart turn swung the fork in her (wife) arms, and flung the bundle of hay high onto the cart.

Ivan, obviously doing his (Ivan) best to save her (wife) every minute of unnecessary labor, made haste, opening his (Ivan) arms to clutch the bundle and lay it in the cart.

As she (wife) raked together what was left of the hay, the young wife shook off the bits of hay that had fallen on her (wife) neck, and straightening the red kerchief that had dropped forward over her (wife) white brow, not browned like her (wife) face by the sun, she (wife) crept under the cart to tie up the load.

Ivan directed her (wife) how to fasten the cord to the cross-piece, and at something she (wife) said he (Ivan) laughed aloud. In the expressions of both faces was to be seen vigorous, young, freshly awakened love.

The young wife flung the rake up on the load, and with a bold step, swinging her (wife) arms, she (wife) went to join the women, who were forming a ring for the haymakers' dance.

Chapter 12 The load was tied on. Ivan jumped down and took the quiet, sleek horse by the bridle. Ivan drove off to the road and fell into line with the other loaded carts.

The peasant women, with their rakes on their shoulders, gay with bright flowers, and chattering with ringing, merry voices, walked behind the hay cart.

One wild untrained female voice broke into a song, and sang it alone through a verse, and then the same verse was taken up and repeated by half a hundred strong healthy voices, of all sorts, coarse and fine, singing in unison.

The women, all singing, began to come close to Levin, and he (Levin) felt as though a storm were swooping down upon him (Levin) with a thunder of merriment.

The storm swooped down, enveloped him (Levin) and the haycock on which he (Levin) was lying, and the other haycocks, and the wagon-loads, and the whole meadow and distant fields all seemed to be shaking and singing to the measures of this wild merry song with its shouts and whistles and clapping.

Levin felt envious of this health and mirthfulness; he (Levin) longed to take part in the expression of this joy of life.

When the peasants, with their singing, had vanished out of sight and hearing, a weary feeling of despondency at his (Levin) own isolation, his (Levin) physical inactivity, his (Levin) alienation from this world, came over Levin.

Some of the very peasants who had been most active in wrangling with him (Levin) over the hay, some whom he (Levin) had treated with contumely, and who had tried to cheat him (Levin), those very peasants had greeted him (Levin) goodhumoredly, and evidently had not, were incapable of having any feeling of rancor against him (Levin), any regret, any recollection even of having tried to deceive him (Levin).

But he (Levin) could do nothing, and had to lie and look on and listen. All that was drowned in a sea of merry common labor.

God gave the day, God gave the strength. And the day and the strength were consecrated to labor, and that labor was its own reward.

Often Levin had admired this life, often he (Levin) had a sense of envy of the men who led this life; but today for the first time, especially under the influence of what he (Levin) had seen in the attitude of Ivan Parmenov to his (Parmenov) young wife, the idea presented itself definitely to his (Parmenov) mind that it was in his (Parmenov) power to exchange the dreary, artificial, idle, and individualistic life he (Parmenov) was leading for this laborious, pure, and socially delightful life.

For whom the labor? What would be its fruits? These were idle considerations-- beside the point. The old man who had been sitting beside him (man) had long ago gone home; the people had all separated.

Those who lived near had gone home, while those who came from far were gathered into a group for supper, and to spend the night in the meadow.

Levin, unobserved by the peasants, still lay on the haycock, and still looked on and listened and mused. The peasants who remained for the night in the meadow scarcely slept all the short summer night.

At first there was the sound of merry talk and laughing all together over the supper, then singing again and laughter.

All the long day of toil had left no trace in them but lightness of heart. Before the early dawn all was hushed.

Nothing was to be heard but the night sounds of the frogs that never ceased in the marsh, and the horses snorting in the mist that rose over the meadow before the morning.

Rousing himself, Levin got up from the haycock, and looking at the stars, he (Levin) saw that the night was over. ''

he (Levin) said to himself, trying to express to himself all the thoughts and feelings he (Levin) had passed through in that brief night.

Well, what am I going to do? How am I to set about it? '' All the thoughts and feelings he (Levin) had passed through fell into three separate trains of thought.

One was the renunciation of his (Levin) old life, of his (Levin) utterly useless education. This renunciation gave him (Levin) satisfaction, and was easy and simple.

The simplicity, the purity, the sanity of this life he (Levin) felt clearly, and he (Levin) was convinced he (Levin) would find in it the content, the peace, and the dignity, of the lack of which he (Levin) was so miserably conscious.

But a third series of ideas turned upon the question how to effect this transition from the old life to the new.

Another series of thoughts and mental images related to the life he (Levin) longed to live now. And there nothing took clear shape for him (Levin).

``Have a wife? Have work and the necessity of work? Leave Pokrovskoe? Buy land? Become a member of a peasant community?

Marry a peasant girl? How am I to set about it? '' (he)

he (peasant) asked himself again, and could not find an answer.

'' I haven't slept all night, though, and I can't think it out clearly,'' he (peasant) said to himself. '' I'll work it out later.

One thing's certain, this night has decided my fate. All my old dreams of home life were absurd, not the real thing,'' he (peasant) told himself.

he (peasant) thought, looking at the strange, as it were, mother-of-pearl shell of white fleecy cloudlets resting right over his (peasant) head in the middle of the sky.

'' It's all ever so much simpler and better... ''

``How beautiful! '' (unknown)
'' How exquisite it all is in this exquisite night!

And when was there time for that cloud-shell to form? Just now I looked at the sky, and there was nothing in it--only two white streaks.

Yes, and so imperceptibly too my views of life changed!'' He (peasant) went out of the meadow and walked along the highroad towards the village.

A slight wind arose, and the sky looked gray and sullen. The gloomy moment had come that usually precedes the dawn, the full triumph of light over darkness.

Shrinking from the cold, Levin walked rapidly, looking at the ground. '' What's that? Someone coming,'' he (Levin) thought, catching the tinkle of bells, and lifting his (Levin) head.

Forty paces from him (Levin) a carriage with four horses harnessed abreast was driving towards him (Levin) along the grassy road on which he (Levin) was walking.

The shaft-horses were tilted against the shafts by the ruts, but the dexterous driver sitting on the box held the shaft over the ruts, so that the wheels ran on the smooth part of the road.

In the coach was an old lady dozing in one corner, and at the window, evidently only just awake, sat a young girl holding in both hands the ribbons of a white cap.

With a face full of light and thought, full of a subtle, complex inner life, that was remote from Levin, she (girl) was gazing beyond him (Levin) at the glow of the sunrise.

This was all Levin noticed, and without wondering who it could be, he (Levin) gazed absently at the coach. At the very instant when this apparition was vanishing, the truthful eyes glanced at him (Levin).

She (girl) recognized him (Levin), and her (girl) face lighted up with wondering delight. He (Levin) could not be mistaken. There were no other eyes like those in the world.

There was only one creature in the world that could concentrate for him (Levin) all the brightness and meaning of life. It was she (girl).

And everything that had been stirring Levin during that sleepless night, all the resolutions he (Levin) had made, all vanished at once.

It was Kitty. He (Levin) understood that she (Kitty) was driving to Ergushovo from the railway station. He (Levin) recalled with horror his (Levin) dreams of marrying a peasant girl.

There only, in the carriage that had crossed over to the other side of the road, and was rapidly disappearing, there only could he (Levin) find the solution of the riddle of his (Levin) life, which had weighed so agonizingly upon him (Levin) of late.

She (girl) did not look out again. The sound of the carriage-springs was no longer audible, the bells could scarcely be heard.

The barking of dogs showed the carriage had reached the village, and all that was left was the empty fields all round, the village in front, and he (Levin) himself isolated and apart from it all, wandering lonely along the deserted highroad.

He (Levin) glanced at the sky, expecting to find there the cloud shell he (Levin) had been admiring and taking as the symbol of the ideas and feelings of that night.

There was nothing in the sky in the least like a shell. There, in the remote heights above, a mysterious change had been accomplished.

There was no trace of shell, and there was stretched over fully half the sky an even cover of tiny and ever tinier cloudlets.

The sky had grown blue and bright; and with the same softness, but with the same remoteness, it met his (Levin) questioning gaze.

No,'' he (Levin) said to himself,

``however good that life of simplicity and toil may be, I cannot go back to it.

Chapter 13 None but those who were most intimate with Alexey Alexandrovitch knew that, while on the surface the coldest and most reasonable of men, he (Alexandrovitch) had one weakness quite opposed to the general trend of his (Alexandrovitch) character.

'' (he)

I love her (Levin) . '' Alexey Alexandrovitch could not hear or see a child or woman crying without being moved.

The chief secretary of his (secretary) department and his (secretary) private secretary were aware of this, and used to warn women who came with petitions on no account to give way to tears, if they did not want to ruin their chances.

The sight of tears threw him (secretary) into a state of nervous agitation, and he (secretary) utterly lost all power of reflection. ''

And as a fact, in such cases the emotional disturbance set up in Alexey Alexandrovitch by the sight of tears found expression in hasty anger.

He (Alexandrovitch) will get angry, and will not listen to you,'' they used to say. '' I can do nothing. Kindly leave the room!

When returning from the races Anna had informed him (Alexandrovitch) of her (Anna) relations with Vronsky, and immediately afterwards had burst into tears, hiding her (Anna) face in her (Anna) hands, Alexey Alexandrovitch, for all the fury aroused in him (Alexandrovitch) against her (Anna), was aware at the same time of a rush of that emotional disturbance always produced in him (Alexandrovitch) by tears.

Conscious of it, and conscious that any expression of his (Alexandrovitch) feelings at that minute would be out of keeping with the position, he (Alexandrovitch) tried to suppress every manifestation of life in himself, and so neither stirred nor looked at her (Anna).

'' he (Alexandrovitch) would commonly cry in such cases. This was what had caused that strange expression of deathlike rigidity in his (Alexandrovitch) face which had so impressed Anna.

When they reached the house he (Alexandrovitch) helped her (Anna) to get out of the carriage, and making an effort to master himself, took leave of her (Anna) with his (Alexandrovitch) usual urbanity, and uttered that phrase that bound him (Alexandrovitch) to nothing; he (Alexandrovitch) said that tomorrow he (Alexandrovitch) would let her (Anna) know his (Alexandrovitch) decision.

His (Alexandrovitch) wife's words, confirming his (Alexandrovitch) worst suspicions, had sent a cruel pang to the heart of Alexey Alexandrovitch. That pang was intensified by the strange feeling of physical pity for her (Anna) set up by her (Anna) tears.

But when he (Alexandrovitch) was all alone in the carriage Alexey Alexandrovitch, to his (Alexandrovitch) surprise and delight, felt complete relief both from this pity and from the doubts and agonies of jealousy.

After a fearful agony and a sense of something huge, bigger than the head itself, being torn out of his (Alexandrovitch) jaw, the sufferer, hardly able to believe in his (Alexandrovitch) own good luck, feels all at once that what has so long poisoned his (Alexandrovitch) existence and enchained his (Alexandrovitch) attention, exists no longer, and that he (Alexandrovitch) can live and think again, and take interest in other things besides his (Alexandrovitch) tooth.

He (Alexandrovitch) experienced the sensations of a man who has had a tooth out after suffering long from toothache. This feeling Alexey Alexandrovitch was experiencing.

The agony had been strange and terrible, but now it was over; he (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) could live again and think of something other than his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

I always knew it and always saw it, though I tried to deceive myself to spare her (wife),'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself.

And it actually seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) that he (Alexandrovitch) always had seen it: he (Alexandrovitch) recalled incidents of their past life, in which he (Alexandrovitch) had never seen anything wrong before--now these incidents proved clearly that she (wife) had always been a corrupt woman.

I made a mistake in linking my life to hers; but there was nothing wrong in my mistake, and so I cannot be unhappy.

'' No honor, no heart, no religion; a corrupt woman. '' It's not I that am to blame,'' he (Alexandrovitch) told himself,

``but she (woman).

Everything relating to her (woman) and her (woman) son, towards whom his (son) sentiments were as much changed as towards her (woman), ceased to interest him (son).

The only thing that interested him (son) now was the question of in what way he (son) could best, with most propriety and comfort for himself, and thus with most justice, extricate himself from the mud with which she (woman) had spattered him (son) in her (woman) fall, and then proceed along his (son) path of active, honorable, and useful existence.

But I have nothing to do with her (woman). She (woman) does not exist for me... '' (he)

'' I cannot be made unhappy by the fact that a contemptible woman has committed a crime.

I have only to find the best way out of the difficult position in which she (woman) has placed me. And I shall find it,'' he (son) said to himself, frowning more and more.

And to say nothing of historical instances dating from the

``Fair Helen'' (Menelaus)
of Menelaus, recently revived in the memory of all, a whole list of contemporary examples of husbands with unfaithful wives in the highest society rose before Alexey Alexandrovitch's imagination.

'' I'm not the first nor the last. '' '' Daryalov, Poltavsky, Prince Karibanov, Count Paskudin, Dram.... Yes, even Dram, such an honest, capable fellow...

Admitting that a certain quite irrational ridicule falls to the lot of these men, yet I never saw anything but a misfortune in it, and always felt sympathy for it,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch said to himself, though indeed this was not the fact, and he (Alexandrovitch) had never felt sympathy for misfortunes of that kind, but the more frequently he (Alexandrovitch) had heard of instances of unfaithful wives betraying their husbands, the more highly he (Alexandrovitch) had thought of himself.

Semyonov, Tchagin, Sigonin,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch remembered. '' '' It is a misfortune which may befall anyone. And this misfortune has befallen me.

And he (Alexandrovitch) began passing in review the methods of proceeding of men who had been in the same position that he (Alexandrovitch) was in.

The only thing to be done is to make the best of the position. '' '' Daryalov fought a duel... ''

The duel had particularly fascinated the thoughts of Alexey Alexandrovitch in his (Alexandrovitch) youth, just because he (Alexandrovitch) was physically a coward, and was himself well aware of the fact.

Alexey Alexandrovitch could not without horror contemplate the idea of a pistol aimed at himself, and had never made use of any weapon in his (Alexandrovitch) life.

This horror had in his (Alexandrovitch) youth set him (Alexandrovitch) pondering on dueling, and picturing himself in a position in which he (Alexandrovitch) would have to expose his (Alexandrovitch) life to danger.

Having attained success and an established position in the world, he (Alexandrovitch) had long ago forgotten this feeling; but the habitual bent of feeling reasserted itself, and dread of his (Alexandrovitch) own cowardice proved even now so strong that Alexey Alexandrovitch spent a long while thinking over the question of dueling in all its aspects, and hugging the idea of a duel, though he (Alexandrovitch) was fully aware beforehand that he (Alexandrovitch) would never under any circumstances fight one.

There's no doubt our society is still so barbarous -LRB-it's not the same in England-RRB- that very many''--and among these were those whose opinion Alexey Alexandrovitch particularly valued--

``look favorably on the duel; but what result is attained by it?

Suppose I call him (Alexandrovitch) out,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

Alexey Alexandrovitch went on to himself, and vividly picturing the night he (Alexandrovitch) would spend after the challenge, and the pistol aimed at him (Alexandrovitch), he (Alexandrovitch) shuddered, and knew that he (Alexandrovitch) never would do it--
``suppose I call him (Alexandrovitch) out.

Suppose I am taught,'' (he)

he (Alexandrovitch) went on musing,
``to shoot; I press the trigger,'' (he)
he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself, closing his (Alexandrovitch) eyes,
``and it turns out I have killed him (Alexandrovitch),'' (he)
Alexey Alexandrovitch said to himself, and he (Alexandrovitch) shook his (Alexandrovitch) head as though to dispel such silly ideas.

'' '' What sense is there in murdering a man in order to define one's relation to a guilty wife and son?

I should still just as much have to decide what I ought to do with her (wife). But what is more probable and what would doubtless occur--I should be killed or wounded.

I, the innocent person, should be the victim--killed or wounded. It's even more senseless. But apart from that, a challenge to fight would be an act hardly honest on my side.

Don't I know perfectly well that my friends would never allow me to fight a duel--would never allow the life of a statesman, needed by Russia, to be exposed to danger?

Knowing perfectly well beforehand that the matter would never come to real danger, it would amount to my simply trying to gain a certain sham reputation by such a challenge.

That would be dishonest, that would be false, that would be deceiving myself and others. A duel is quite irrational, and no one expects it of me.

Official duties, which had always been of great consequence in Alexey Alexandrovitch's eyes, seemed of special importance to his (Alexandrovitch) mind at this moment.

My aim is simply to safeguard my reputation, which is essential for the uninterrupted pursuit of my public duties. '' Considering and rejecting the duel, Alexey Alexandrovitch turned to divorce--

Passing in mental review all the instances he (Alexandrovitch) knew of divorces -LRB-there were plenty of them in the very highest society with which he (Alexandrovitch) was very familiar-RRB-, Alexey Alexandrovitch could not find a single example in which the object of divorce was that which he (Alexandrovitch) had in view.

In all these instances the husband had practically ceded or sold his (husband) unfaithful wife, and the very party which, being in fault, had not the right to contract a fresh marriage, had formed counterfeit, pseudo-matrimonial ties with a self-styled husband.

In his (husband) own case, Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that a legal divorce, that is to say, one in which only the guilty wife would be repudiated, was impossible of attainment.

He (Alexandrovitch) saw that the complex conditions of the life they led made the coarse proofs of his (Alexandrovitch) wife's guilt, required by the law, out of the question; he (Alexandrovitch) saw that a certain refinement in that life would not admit of such proofs being brought forward, even if he (Alexandrovitch) had them, and that to bring forward such proofs would damage him (Alexandrovitch) in the public estimation more than it would her (wife).

An attempt at divorce could lead to nothing but a public scandal, which would be a perfect godsend to his (Alexandrovitch) enemies for calumny and attacks on his (Alexandrovitch) high position in society.

His (Alexandrovitch) chief object, to define the position with the least amount of disturbance possible, would not be attained by divorce either.

Moreover, in the event of divorce, or even of an attempt to obtain a divorce, it was obvious that the wife broke off all relations with the husband and threw in her (wife) lot with the lover.

And in spite of the complete, as he (lover) supposed, contempt and indifference he (lover) now felt for his (lover) wife, at the bottom of his (lover) heart Alexey Alexandrovitch still had one feeling left in regard to her (wife)--a disinclination to see her (wife) free to throw in her (wife) lot with Vronsky, so that her (wife) crime would be to her (wife) advantage.

The mere notion of this so exasperated Alexey Alexandrovitch, that directly it rose to his (Alexandrovitch) mind he (Alexandrovitch) groaned with inward agony, and got up and changed his (Alexandrovitch) place in the carriage, and for a long while after, he (Alexandrovitch) sat with scowling brows, wrapping his (Alexandrovitch) numbed and bony legs in the fleecy rug. ''

Apart from formal divorce, One might still do like Karibanov, Paskudin, and that good fellow Dram--that is, separate from one's wife,'' he (fellow) went on thinking, when he (fellow) had regained his (fellow) composure.

But this step too presented the same drawback of public scandal as a divorce, and what was more, a separation, quite as much as a regular divorce, flung his (fellow) wife into the arms of Vronsky.

another solution selected by several of the husbands he (fellow) remembered. '' No, it's out of the question, out of the question!

'' he (fellow) said again, twisting his (fellow) rug about him (fellow) again. '' I cannot be unhappy, but neither she (wife) nor he (fellow) ought to be happy.

The feeling of jealousy, which had tortured him (fellow) during the period of uncertainty, had passed away at the instant when the tooth had been with agony extracted by his (fellow) wife's words.

But that feeling had been replaced by another, the desire, not merely that she (wife) should not be triumphant, but that she (wife) should get due punishment for her (wife) crime.

He (fellow) did not acknowledge this feeling, but at the bottom of his (fellow) heart he (fellow) longed for her (wife) to suffer for having destroyed his (fellow) peace of mind--his (fellow) honor.

And going once again over the conditions inseparable from a duel, a divorce, a separation, and once again rejecting them, Alexey Alexandrovitch felt convinced that there was only one solution,--to keep her (wife) with him (Alexandrovitch), concealing what had happened from the world, and using every measure in his (Alexandrovitch) power to break off the intrigue, and still more--though this he (Alexandrovitch) did not admit to himself--to punish her (wife).

I must inform her (wife) of my conclusion, that thinking over the terrible position in which she (wife) has placed her (wife) family, all other solutions will be worse for both sides than an external status quo , and that such I agree to retain, on the strict condition of obedience on her (wife) part to my wishes, that is to say, cessation of all intercourse with her (wife) lover.

'' '' '' When this decision had been finally adopted, another weighty consideration occurred to Alexey Alexandrovitch in support of it.

'' By such a course only shall I be acting in accordance with the dictates of religion,'' he (Alexandrovitch) told himself. ''

In adopting this course, I am not casting off a guilty wife, but giving her (wife) a chance of amendment; and, indeed, difficult as the task will be to me, I shall devote part of my energies to her (wife) reformation and salvation.

Though Alexey Alexandrovitch was perfectly aware that he (Alexandrovitch) could not exert any moral influence over his (Alexandrovitch) wife, that such an attempt at reformation could lead to nothing but falsity; though in passing through these difficult moments he (Alexandrovitch) had not once thought of seeking guidance in religion, yet now, when his (Alexandrovitch) conclusion corresponded, as it seemed to him (Alexandrovitch), with the requirements of religion, this religious sanction to his (Alexandrovitch) decision gave him (Alexandrovitch) complete satisfaction, and to some extent restored his (Alexandrovitch) peace of mind.

He (Alexandrovitch) was pleased to think that, even in such an important crisis in life, no one would be able to say that he (Alexandrovitch) had not acted in accordance with the principles of that religion whose banner he (Alexandrovitch) had always held aloft amid the general coolness and indifference.

As he (Alexandrovitch) pondered over subsequent developments, Alexey Alexandrovitch did not see, indeed, why his (Alexandrovitch) relations with his (Alexandrovitch) wife should not remain practically the same as before.

No doubt, she (wife) could never regain his (Alexandrovitch) esteem, but there was not, and there could not be, any sort of reason that his (Alexandrovitch) existence should be troubled, and that he (Alexandrovitch) should suffer because she (wife) was a bad and faithless wife.

Yes, time will pass; time, which arranges all things, and the old relations will be reestablished,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch told himself;

``so far reestablished, that is, that I shall not be sensible of a break in the continuity of my life.

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

'' She (wife) is bound to be unhappy, but I am not to blame, and so I cannot be unhappy. ''

As he (Alexandrovitch) neared Petersburg, Alexey Alexandrovitch not only adhered entirely to his (Alexandrovitch) decision, but was even composing in his (Alexandrovitch) head the letter he (Alexandrovitch) would write to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

Going into the porter's room, Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced at the letters and papers brought from his (Alexandrovitch) office, and directed that they should be brought to him (Alexandrovitch) in his (Alexandrovitch) study.

The horses can be taken out and I will see no one,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said in answer to the porter, with a certain pleasure, indicative of his (Alexandrovitch) agreeable frame of mind, emphasizing the words,

``see no one.

In his (Alexandrovitch) study Alexey Alexandrovitch walked up and down twice, and stopped at an immense writing-table, on which six candles had already been lighted by the valet who had preceded him (valet).

Putting his (valet) elbows on the table, he (valet) bent his (valet) head on one side, thought a minute, and began to write, without pausing for a second.

He (valet) wrote without using any form of address to her (valet), and wrote in French, making use of the plural '' (the porter)

vous ,'' which has not the same note of coldness as the corresponding Russian form.

At our last conversation, I notified you of my intention to communicate to you my decision in regard to the subject of that conversation.

Chapter 14 '' '' He (valet) cracked his (valet) knuckles and sat down, sorting out his (valet) writing appurtenances. '' Having carefully considered everything, I am writing now with the object of fulfilling that promise.

Whatever your conduct may have been, I do not consider myself justified in breaking the ties in which we are bound by a Higher Power.

The family cannot be broken up by a whim, a caprice, or even by the sin of one of the partners in the marriage, and our life must go on as it has done in the past.

I am fully persuaded that you have repented and do repent of what has called forth the present letter, and that you will cooperate with me in eradicating the cause of our estrangement, and forgetting the past.

My decision is as follows. This is essential for me, for you, and for our son. In the contrary event, you can conjecture what awaits you and your son.

As the season is drawing to a close, I would beg you to return to Petersburg as quickly as possible, not later than Tuesday.

All this I hope to discuss more in detail in a personal interview. All necessary preparations shall be made for your arrival here.

I beg you to note that I attach particular significance to compliance with this request. A. Karenin

``P.S.--I enclose the money which may be needed for your expenses.

He (son) read the letter through and felt pleased with it, and especially that he (son) had remembered to enclose money: there was not a harsh word, not a reproach in it, nor was there undue indulgence.

Folding the letter and smoothing it with a massive ivory knife, and putting it in an envelope with the money, he (son) rang the bell with the gratification it always afforded him (son) to use the well arranged appointments of his (son) writing-table.

'' (unknown)

Most of all, it was a golden bridge for return.
``Give this to the courier to be delivered to Anna Arkadyevna tomorrow at the summer villa,'' (he)
he (courier) said, getting up.

Alexey Alexandrovitch ordered tea to be brought to the study, and playing with the massive paper-knife, he (Alexandrovitch) moved to his (Alexandrovitch) easy chair, near which there had been placed ready for him (Alexandrovitch) a lamp and the French work on Egyptian hieroglyphics that he (Alexandrovitch) had begun.

Over the easy chair there hung in a gold frame an oval portrait of Anna, a fine painting by a celebrated artist.

'' Certainly, your excellency; tea to be served in the study?'' Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced at it. The unfathomable eyes gazed ironically and insolently at him (Alexandrovitch).

Insufferably insolent and challenging was the effect in Alexey Alexandrovitch's eyes of the black lace about the head, admirably touched in by the painter, the black hair and handsome white hand with one finger lifted, covered with rings.

After looking at the portrait for a minute, Alexey Alexandrovitch shuddered so that his (Alexandrovitch) lips quivered and he (Alexandrovitch) uttered the sound

``brrr,'' (he)
and turned away.

He (Alexandrovitch) made haste to sit down in his (Alexandrovitch) easy chair and opened the book. He (Alexandrovitch) tried to read, but he (Alexandrovitch) could not revive the very vivid interest he (Alexandrovitch) had felt before in Egyptian hieroglyphics.

He (Alexandrovitch) thought not of his (Alexandrovitch) wife, but of a complication that had arisen in his (Alexandrovitch) official life, which at the time constituted the chief interest of it.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) had penetrated more deeply than ever before into this intricate affair, and that he (Alexandrovitch) had originated a leading idea--he (Alexandrovitch) could say it without self-flattery--calculated to clear up the whole business, to strengthen him (Alexandrovitch) in his (Alexandrovitch) official career, to discomfit his (Alexandrovitch) enemies, and thereby to be of the greatest benefit to the government.

He (Alexandrovitch) looked at the book and thought of something else. Directly the servant had set the tea and left the room, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up and went to the writing-table.

Moving into the middle of the table a portfolio of papers, with a scarcely perceptible smile of self-satisfaction, he (Alexandrovitch) took a pencil from a rack and plunged into the perusal of a complex report relating to the present complication.

The complication was of this nature: Alexey Alexandrovitch's characteristic quality as a politician, that special individual qualification that every rising functionary possesses, the qualification that with his (functionary) unflagging ambition, his (functionary) reserve, his (functionary) honesty, and with his (functionary) self-confidence had made his (functionary) career, was his (functionary) contempt for red tape, his (functionary) cutting down of correspondence, his (functionary) direct contact, wherever possible, with the living fact, and his (functionary) economy.

It happened that the famous Commission of the 2nd of June had set on foot an inquiry into the irrigation of lands in the Zaraisky province, which fell under Alexey Alexandrovitch's department, and was a glaring example of fruitless expenditure and paper reforms.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was aware of the truth of this. The irrigation of these lands in the Zaraisky province had been initiated by the predecessor of Alexey Alexandrovitch's predecessor.

And vast sums of money had actually been spent and were still being spent on this business, and utterly unproductively, and the whole business could obviously lead to nothing whatever.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had perceived this at once on entering office, and would have liked to lay hands on the Board of Irrigation.

But at first, when he (Alexandrovitch) did not yet feel secure in his (Alexandrovitch) position, he (Alexandrovitch) knew it would affect too many interests, and would be injudicious.

Later on he (Alexandrovitch) had been engrossed in other questions, and had simply forgotten the Board of Irrigation. It went of itself, like all such boards, by the mere force of inertia.

-LRB-Many people gained their livelihood by the Board of Irrigation, especially one highly conscientious and musical family: all the daughters played on stringed instruments, and Alexey Alexandrovitch knew the family and had stood godfather to one of the elder daughters.-RRB-

The raising of this question by a hostile department was in Alexey Alexandrovitch's opinion a dishonorable proceeding, seeing that in every department there were things similar and worse, which no one inquired into, for well-known reasons of official etiquette.

However, now that the glove had been thrown down to him (Alexandrovitch), he (Alexandrovitch) had boldly picked it up and demanded the appointment of a special commission to investigate and verify the working of the Board of Irrigation of the lands in the Zaraisky province.

But in compensation he (Alexandrovitch) gave no quarter to the enemy either. He (Alexandrovitch) demanded the appointment of another special commission to inquire into the question of the Native Tribes Organization Committee.

The question of the Native Tribes had been brought up incidentally in the Commission of the 2nd of June, and had been pressed forward actively by Alexey Alexandrovitch as one admitting of no delay on account of the deplorable condition of the native tribes.

The department hostile to Alexey Alexandrovitch proved that the condition of the native tribes was exceedingly flourishing, that the proposed reconstruction might be the ruin of their prosperity, and that if there were anything wrong, it arose mainly from the failure on the part of Alexey Alexandrovitch's department to carry out the measures prescribed by law.

First, that a new commission should be formed which should be empowered to investigate the condition of the native tribes on the spot; secondly, if it should appear that the condition of the native tribes actually was such as it appeared to be from the official documents in the hands of the committee, that another new scientific commission should be appointed to investigate the deplorable condition of the native tribes from the---LRB-1-RRB- political, -LRB-2-RRB- administrative, -LRB-3-RRB- economic, -LRB-4-RRB- ethnographical, -LRB-5-RRB- material, and -LRB-6-RRB- religious points of view; thirdly, that evidence should be required from the rival department of the measures that had been taken during the last ten years by that department for averting the disastrous conditions in which the native tribes were now placed; and fourthly and finally, that that department explain why it had, as appeared from the evidence before the committee, from No. 17,015 and 18,038, from December 5, 1863, and June 7, 1864, acted in direct contravention of the intent of the law T...Act 18, and the note to Act 36.

A flash of eagerness suffused the face of Alexey Alexandrovitch as he (Alexandrovitch) rapidly wrote out a synopsis of these ideas for his (Alexandrovitch) own benefit.

Having filled a sheet of paper, he (Alexandrovitch) got up, rang, and sent a note to the chief secretary of his (secretary) department to look up certain necessary facts for him (secretary).

In the commission this question had been a ground of contention between several departments. Now Alexey Alexandrovitch intended to demand: Getting up and walking about the room, he (Alexandrovitch) glanced again at the portrait, frowned, and smiled contemptuously.

After reading a little more of the book on Egyptian hieroglyphics, and renewing his (Alexandrovitch) interest in it, Alexey Alexandrovitch went to bed at eleven o'clock, and recollecting as he (Alexandrovitch) lay in bed the incident with his (Alexandrovitch) wife, he (Alexandrovitch) saw it now in by no means such a gloomy light.

Though Anna had obstinately and with exasperation contradicted Vronsky when he (Alexandrovitch) told her (Anna) their position was impossible, at the bottom of her (Anna) heart she (Anna) regarded her (Anna) own position as false and dishonorable, and she (Anna) longed with her (Anna) whole soul to change it.

On the way home from the races she (Anna) had told her (Anna) husband the truth in a moment of excitement, and in spite of the agony she (Anna) had suffered in doing so, she (Anna) was glad of it.

After her (Anna) husband had left her (Anna), she (Anna) told herself that she (Anna) was glad, that now everything was made clear, and at least there would be no more lying and deception.

It might be bad, this new position, but it would be clear; there would be no indefiniteness or falsehood about it.

The pain she (Anna) had caused herself and her (Anna) husband in uttering those words would be rewarded now by everything being made clear, she (Anna) thought.

That evening she (Anna) saw Vronsky, but she (Anna) did not tell him (Vronsky) of what had passed between her (Anna) and her (Anna) husband, though, to make the position definite

Chapter 15 It seemed to her (Anna) beyond doubt that her (Anna) position was now made clear forever. , it was necessary to tell him (husband).

When she (Anna) woke up next morning the first thing that rose to her (Anna) mind was what she (Anna) had said to her (Anna) husband, and those words seemed to her (Anna) so awful that she (Anna) could not conceive now how she (Anna) could have brought herself to utter those strange, coarse words, and could not imagine what would come of it.

But the words were spoken, and Alexey Alexandrovitch had gone away without saying anything. '' I saw Vronsky and did not tell him (Vronsky).

I would have turned him (Vronsky) back and told him (Vronsky), but I changed my mind, because it was strange that I had not told him (Vronsky) the first minute.

At the very instant he (Vronsky) was going away Why was it I wanted to tell him (Vronsky) and did not tell him (Vronsky)?

'' And in answer to this question a burning blush of shame spread over her (it) face. She (it) knew what had kept her (it) from it, she (it) knew that she (it) had been ashamed.

Her (it) position, which had seemed to her (it) simplified the night before, suddenly struck her (it) now as not only not simple, but as absolutely hopeless.

She (it) felt terrified at the disgrace, of which she (it) had not ever thought before. Directly she (it) thought of what her (it) husband would do, the most terrible ideas came to her (it) mind.

She (it) asked herself where she (it) should go when she (it) was turned out of the house, and she (it) could not find an answer.

When she (it) thought of Vronsky, it seemed to her (it) that he (husband) did not love her (it), that he (husband) was already beginning to be tired of her (it), that she (it) could not offer herself to him (husband), and she (it) felt bitter against him (husband) for it.

It seemed to her (it) that the words that she (it) had spoken to her (it) husband, and had continually repeated in her (it) imagination, she (it) had said to everyone, and everyone had heard them.

She (it) had a vision of being turned out of the house, of her (it) shame being proclaimed to all the world. She (it) could not bring herself to look those of her (it) own household in the face.

She (it) could not bring herself to call her (it) maid, and still less go downstairs and see her (it) son and his (son) governess.

The maid, who had been listening at her (maid) door for a long while, came into her (maid) room of her (maid) own accord.

Anna glanced inquiringly into her (Anna) face, and blushed with a scared look. The maid begged her (maid) pardon for coming in, saying that she (maid) had fancied the bell rang.

Betsy reminded her (Betsy) that Liza Merkalova and Baroness Shtoltz were coming to play croquet with her (Merkalova) that morning with their adorers, Kaluzhsky and old Stremov.

She (Merkalova) brought her (Merkalova) clothes and a note. The note was from Betsy. '' Come, if only as a study in morals.

I shall expect you,'' she (Betsy) finished. Anna read the note and heaved a deep sigh. '' Nothing, I need nothing,'' she (Anna) said to Annushka, who was rearranging the bottles and brushes on the dressing table.

Annushka went out, but Anna did not begin dressing, and sat in the same position, her (Anna) head and hands hanging listlessly, and every now and then she (Anna) shivered all over, seemed as though she (Anna) would make some gesture, utter some word, and sank back into lifelessness again.

'' You can go. I'll dress at once and come down. I need nothing. '' She (Anna) repeated continually,

``My God! my God!'' (She)

The idea of seeking help in her (Anna) difficulty in religion was as remote from her (Anna) as seeking help from Alexey Alexandrovitch himself, although she (Anna) had never had doubts of the faith in which she (Anna) had been brought up.

She (Anna) knew that the support of religion was possible only upon condition of renouncing what made up for her (Anna) the whole meaning of life.

She (Anna) was not simply miserable, she (Anna) began to feel alarm at the new spiritual condition, never experienced before, in which she (Anna) found herself.

She (Anna) felt as though everything were beginning to be double in her (Anna) soul, just as objects sometimes appear double to over-tired eyes.

But neither

``God'' (her)
nor
``my'' (her)
had any meaning to her (Anna). She (Anna) hardly knew at times what it was she (Anna) feared, and what she (Anna) hoped for.

Whether she (Anna) feared or desired what had happened, or what was going to happen, and exactly what she (Anna) longed for, she (Anna) could not have said.

'' Ah, what am I doing! '' she (Anna) said to herself, feeling a sudden thrill of pain in both sides of her (Anna) head.

When she (Anna) came to herself, she (Anna) saw that she (Anna) was holding her (Anna) hair in both hands, each side of her (Anna) temples, and pulling it.

The coffee is ready, and mademoiselle and Seryozha are waiting,'' said Annushka, coming back again and finding Anna in the same position.

She (Anna) jumped up, and began walking about. '' '' Seryozha? What about Seryozha? '' Anna asked, with sudden eagerness, recollecting her (Anna) son's existence for the first time that morning.

'' He (son)'s been naughty, I think,'' answered Annushka with a smile. '' In what way?'' '' Some peaches were lying on the table in the corner room.

I think he (son) slipped in and ate one of them on the sly. '' The recollection of her (Anna) son suddenly roused Anna from the helpless condition in which she (Anna) found herself.

She (Anna) recalled the partly sincere, though greatly exaggerated, r√¥le of the mother living for her (mother) child, which she (mother) had taken up of late years, and she (mother) felt with joy that in the plight in which she (mother) found herself she (mother) had a support, quite apart from her (mother) relation to her (mother) husband or to Vronsky.

Her (mother) husband might put her (mother) to shame and turn her (mother) out, Vronsky might grow cold to her (mother) and go on living his (husband) own life apart

This support was her (mother) son. In whatever position she (mother) might be placed, she (mother) could not lose her (mother) son. -LRB-she (mother) thought of him (son) again with bitterness and reproach-RRB-; she (mother) could not leave her (mother) son.

And she (mother) must act; act to secure this relation to her (mother) son, so that he (son) might not be taken from her (mother).

She (mother) had an aim in life. Quickly indeed, as quickly as possible, she (mother) must take action before he (son) was taken from her (mother).

She (mother) must take her (mother) son and go away. Here was the one thing she (mother) had to do now. She (mother) needed consolation.

She (mother) must be calm, and get out of this insufferable position. The thought of immediate action binding her (mother) to her (mother) son, of going away somewhere with him (son), gave her (mother) this consolation.

She (mother) dressed quickly, went downstairs, and with resolute steps walked into the drawing room, where she (mother) found, as usual, waiting for her (mother), the coffee, Seryozha, and his (son) governess.

Seryozha, all in white, with his (son) back and head bent, was standing at a table under a looking-glass, and with an expression of intense concentration which she (mother) knew well, and in which he (son) resembled his (son) father, he (son) was doing something to the flowers he (son) carried.

Seryozha screamed shrilly, as he (son) often did,

``Ah, mamma!'' (he)
and stopped, hesitating whether to go to greet his (son) mother and put down the flowers, or to finish making the wreath and go with the flowers.

The governess had a particularly severe expression. The governess, after saying good-morning, began a long and detailed account of Seryozha's naughtiness, but Anna did not hear her (Anna)

; she (Anna) was considering whether she (Anna) would take her (Anna) with her (Anna) or not. '' No, I won't take her (Anna),'' she (Anna) decided.

``Yes, it's very wrong,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, and taking her (Anna) son by the shoulder she (Anna) looked at him (son), not severely, but with a timid glance that bewildered and delighted the boy, and she (Anna) kissed him (boy).

Leave him (boy) to me,'' she (Anna) said to the astonished governess, and not letting go of her (Anna) son, she (Anna) sat down at the table, where coffee was set ready for her (Anna). ''

'' I'll go alone with my child.'' '' Mamma! I... I... didn't... '' he (son) said, trying to make out from her (Anna) expression what was in store for him (son) in regard to the peaches.

'' Seryozha,'' she (Anna) said, as soon as the governess had left the room ,

``that was wrong, but you'll never do it again, will you?...

You love me?'' (the governess)

She (Anna) felt that the tears were coming into her (Anna) eyes. '' Can I help loving him (son)? '' she (Anna) said to herself, looking deeply into his (son) scared and at the same time delighted eyes.

Tears were already flowing down her (Anna) face, and to hide them she (Anna) got up abruptly and almost ran out on to the terrace.

'' And can he (son) ever join his (son) father in punishing me? Is it possible he (son) will not feel for me?'' After the thunder showers of the last few days, cold, bright weather had set in.

She (Anna) shivered, both from the cold and from the inward horror which had clutched her (Anna) with fresh force in the open air.

Run along, run along to Mariette,'' she (Anna) said to Seryozha, who had followed her (Anna) out, and she (Anna) began walking up and down on the straw matting of the terrace.

The air was cold in the bright sun that filtered through the freshly washed leaves. '' '' Can it be that they won't forgive me, won't understand how it all couldn't be helped?

Standing still, and looking at the tops of the aspen trees waving in the wind, with their freshly washed, brightly shining leaves in the cold sunshine, she (Anna) knew that they would not forgive her (Anna), that everyone and everything would be merciless to her (Anna) now as was that sky, that green.

'' she (Anna) said to herself. And again she (Anna) felt that everything was split in two in her (Anna) soul. '' I mustn't, mustn't think,'' she (Anna) said to herself.

'' I must get ready. To go where? When? Whom to take with me? Yes, to Moscow by the evening train.

She (Anna) went quickly indoors into her (Anna) boudoir, sat down at the table, and wrote to her (Anna) husband:--

``After what has happened, I cannot remain any longer in your house.

Annushka and Seryozha, and only the most necessary things. But first I must write to them both. '' (husband)

I am going away, and taking my son with me.

I don't know the law, and so I don't know with which of the parents the son should remain; but I take him (son) with me because I cannot live without him (son).

Up to this point she (Anna) wrote rapidly and naturally, but the appeal to his (son) generosity, a quality she (Anna) did not recognize in him (son), and the necessity of winding up the letter with something touching, pulled her (Anna) up.

Be generous, leave him (son) to me. '' '' Of my fault and my remorse I cannot speak, because... '' She (Anna) stopped again, finding no connection in her (Anna) ideas.

No,'' she (Anna) said to herself,

``there's no need of anything,'' (she)
and tearing up the letter, she (Anna) wrote it again, leaving out the allusion to generosity, and sealed it up.

'' Another letter had to be written to Vronsky. '' I have told my husband,'' she (Anna) wrote, and she (Anna) sat a long while unable to write more.

It was so coarse, so unfeminine. '' And what more am I to write to him (husband)? '' she (Anna) said to herself.

Again a flush of shame spread over her (Anna) face; she (Anna) recalled his (husband) composure, and a feeling of anger against him (husband) impelled her (Anna) to tear the sheet with the phrase she (Anna) had written into tiny bits.

No need of anything,'' she (Anna) said to herself, and closing her (Anna) blotting-case she (Anna) went upstairs, told the governess and the servants that she (Anna) was going that day to Moscow, and at once set to work to pack up her (Anna) things.

Chapter 16 All the rooms of the summer villa were full of porters, gardeners, and footmen going to and fro carrying out things.

Cupboards and chests were open; twice they had sent to the shop for cord; pieces of newspaper were tossing about on the floor.

'' Two trunks, some bags and strapped-up rugs, had been carried down into the hall. The carriage and two hired cabs were waiting at the steps.

Anna, forgetting her (Anna) inward agitation in the work of packing, was standing at a table in her (Anna) boudoir, packing her (Anna) traveling bag, when Annushka called her (Anna) attention to the rattle of some carriage driving up.

Anna looked out of the window and saw Alexey Alexandrovitch's courier on the steps, ringing at the front door bell. ''

Run and find out what it is,'' she (Anna) said, and with a calm sense of being prepared for anything, she (Anna) sat down in a low chair, folding her (Anna) hands on her (Anna) knees.

A footman brought in a thick packet directed in Alexey Alexandrovitch's hand. '' The courier has orders to wait for an answer,'' he (courier) said.

Very well,'' she (Anna) said, and as soon as he (courier) had left the room she (Anna) tore open the letter with trembling fingers.

'' A roll of unfolded notes done up in a wrapper fell out of it. She (Anna) disengaged the letter and began reading it at the end.

She (Anna) ran on, then back, read it all through, and once more read the letter all through again from the beginning.

When she (Anna) had finished, she (Anna) felt that she (Anna) was cold all over, and that a fearful calamity, such as she (Anna) had not expected, had burst upon her (Anna).

In the morning she (Anna) had regretted that she (Anna) had spoken to her (Anna) husband, and wished for nothing so much as that those words could be unspoken.

'' Preparations shall be made for your arrival here... I attach particular significance to compliance... '' she (Anna) read. And here this letter regarded them as unspoken, and gave her (Anna) what she (Anna) had wanted.

But now this letter seemed to her (Anna) more awful than anything she (Anna) had been able to conceive. '' He (husband)'s right! ''

she (Anna) said;

``of course, he (husband)'s always right; he (husband)'s a Christian, he (husband)'s generous! Yes, vile, base creature! And no one understands it except me, and no one ever will; and I can't explain it.

They don't know how he (husband) has crushed my life for eight years, crushed everything that was living in me--he (husband) has not once even thought that I'm a live woman who must have love.

They say he (husband)'s so religious, so high-principled, so upright, so clever; but they don't see what I've seen. They don't know how at every step he (husband)'s humiliated me, and been just as pleased with himself.

Haven't I striven, striven with all my strength, to find something to give meaning to my life? Haven't I struggled to love him (husband), to love my son when I could not love my husband?

But the time came when I knew that I couldn't cheat myself any longer, that I was alive, that I was not to blame, that God has made me so that I must love and live.

If he (God)'d killed me, if he (God)'d killed him (God), I could have borne anything, I could have forgiven anything; but, no, he (God)....

And now what does he (God) do? How was it I didn't guess what he (God) would do? He (God)'s doing just what's characteristic of his (God) mean character.

He (God)'ll keep himself in the right, while me, in my ruin, he (God)'ll drive still lower to worse ruin yet... '' (she)

She (God) recalled the words from the letter.

'' You can conjecture what awaits you and your son...'' '' That's a threat to take away my child, and most likely by their stupid law he (son) can.

He (son) doesn't believe even in my love for my child, or he (son) despises it -LRB-just as he (son) always used to ridicule it-RRB-.

He (son) despises that feeling in me, but he (son) knows that I won't abandon my child, that I can't abandon my child, that there could be no life for me without my child, even with him (son) whom I love; but that if I abandoned my child and ran away from him (son), I should be acting like the most infamous, basest of women.

But I know very well why he (son) says it. He (son) knows that, and knows that I am incapable of doing that.

'' She (I) recalled another sentence in the letter. '' Our life must go on as it has done in the past...

'' '' That life was miserable enough in the old days; it has been awful of late. What will it be now?

And he (son) knows all that; he (son) knows that I can't repent that I breathe, that I love; he (son) knows that it can lead to nothing but lying and deceit; but he (son) wants to go on torturing me.

I know him (son); I know that he (son)'s at home and is happy in deceit, like a fish swimming in the water.

No, I won't give him (son) that happiness. I'll break through the spiderweb of lies in which he (son) wants to catch me, come what may.

Anything's better than lying and deceit. '' But how? My God! my God! Was ever a woman so miserable as I am?...''

'' No; I will break through it, I will break through it! '' she (woman) cried, jumping up and keeping back her (woman) tears.

But at the bottom of her (woman) heart she (woman) felt that she (woman) was not strong enough to break through anything, that she (woman) was not strong enough to get out of her (woman) old position, however false and dishonorable it might be.
