She (woman) sat down at the writing table, but instead of writing she (woman) clasped her (woman) hands on the table, and, laying her (woman) head on them, burst into tears, with sobs and heaving breast like a child crying.

And she (woman) went to the writing table to write him (woman) another letter. She (woman) was weeping that her (woman) dream of her (woman) position being made clear and definite had been annihilated forever.

She (woman) knew beforehand that everything would go on in the old way, and far worse, indeed, than in the old way.

She (woman) felt that the position in the world that she (woman) enjoyed, and that had seemed to her (woman) of so little consequence in the morning, that this position was precious to her (woman), that she (woman) would not have the strength to exchange it for the shameful position of a woman who has abandoned husband and child to join her (woman) lover; that however much she (woman) might struggle, she (woman) could not be stronger than herself.

She (woman) would never know freedom in love, but would remain forever a guilty wife, with the menace of detection hanging over her (woman) at every instant; deceiving her (woman) husband for the sake of a shameful connection with a man living apart and away from her (woman), whose life she (woman) could never share.

She (woman) knew that this was how it would be, and at the same time it was so awful that she (woman) could not even conceive what it would end in.

The sound of the footman's steps forced her (woman) to rouse herself, and, hiding her (woman) face from him (footman), she (woman) pretended to be writing.

And she (woman) cried without restraint, as children cry when they are punished. '' The courier asks if there's an answer,'' the footman announced.

'' An answer? Yes,'' said Anna.

``Let him (footman) wait. I'll ring. '' (unknown)
``What can I write? '' (she)
she (Anna) thought. '' What can I decide upon alone?

What do I know? What do I want? What is there I care for? '' Again she (Anna) felt that her (Anna) soul was beginning to be split in two.

She (Anna) was terrified again at this feeling, and clutched at the first pretext for doing something which might divert her (Anna) thoughts from herself.

'' I ought to see Alexey'' -LRB-so she (Anna) called Vronsky in her (Anna) thoughts-RRB-;

``no one but he (Alexey) can tell me what I ought to do.

I'll go to Betsy's, perhaps I shall see him (Alexey) there,'' (Vronsky)

she (Betsy) said to herself, completely forgetting that when she (Betsy) had told him (Alexey) the day before that she (Betsy) was not going to Princess Tverskaya's, he (Alexey) had said that in that case he (Alexey) should not go either.

She (Tverskaya) went up to the table, wrote to her (Tverskaya) husband,

``I have received your letter. --A.'' (husband)
; and, ringing the bell, gave it to the footman.

'' We are not going,'' she (Tverskaya) said to Annushka, as she (Tverskaya) came in. '' Not going at all?'' '' No; don't unpack till tomorrow, and let the carriage wait.

I'm going to the princess's. '' '' Which dress am I to get ready?'' Chapter 17 The croquet party to which the Princess Tverskaya had invited Anna was to consist of two ladies and their adorers.

These two ladies were the chief representatives of a select new Petersburg circle, nicknamed, in imitation of some imitation, les sept merveilles du monde .

These ladies belonged to a circle which, though of the highest society, was utterly hostile to that in which Anna moved.

Moreover, Stremov, one of the most influential people in Petersburg, and the elderly admirer of Liza Merkalova, was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the political world.

From all these considerations Anna had not meant to go, and the hints in Princess Tverskaya's note referred to her (Princess) refusal.

But now Anna was eager to go, in the hope of seeing Vronsky. Anna arrived at Princess Tverskaya's earlier than the other guests.

At the same moment as she (Anna) entered, Vronsky's footman, with side-whiskers combed out like a Kammerjunker , went in too. He (footman) stopped at the door, and, taking off his (footman) cap, let her (Anna) pass.

Anna recognized him (footman), and only then recalled that Vronsky had told her (Anna) the day before that he (Vronsky) would not come. Most likely he (Vronsky) was sending a note to say so.

As she (Anna) took off her (Anna) outer garment in the hall, she (Anna) heard the footman, pronouncing his (footman)

``r's'' (the footman)
even like a Kammerjunker , say,
``From the count for the princess,'' (the footman)
and hand the note.

She (princess) longed to turn back and send him (footman) a letter to come and see her (princess), or to go herself to see him (footman).

She (princess) longed to question him (footman) as to where his (footman) master was. But neither the first nor the second nor the third course was possible.

Already she (princess) heard bells ringing to announce her (princess) arrival ahead of her (princess), and Princess Tverskaya's footman was standing at the open door waiting for her (Princess) to go forward into the inner rooms.

'' The princess is in the garden; they will inform her (princess) immediately. Would you be pleased to walk into the garden?

The position of uncertainty, of indecision, was still the same as at home--worse, in fact, since it was impossible to take any step, impossible to see Vronsky, and she (princess) had to remain here among outsiders, in company so uncongenial to her (princess) present mood.

She (princess) was not alone; all around was that luxurious setting of idleness that she (princess) was used to, and she (princess) felt less wretched than at home.

'' announced another footman in another room. But she (princess) was wearing a dress that she (princess) knew suited her (princess). She (princess) was not forced to think what she (princess) was to do.

On meeting Betsy coming towards her (Betsy) in a white gown that struck her (Betsy) by its elegance, Anna smiled at her (Anna) just as she (Anna) always did.

Princess Tverskaya was walking with Tushkevitch and a young lady, a relation, who, to the great joy of her (Tverskaya) parents in the provinces, was spending the summer with the fashionable princess.

I slept badly,'' answered Anna, looking intently at the footman who came to meet them, and, as she (Anna) supposed, brought Vronsky's note.

Everything would be done of itself. There was probably something unusual about Anna, for Betsy noticed it at once. '' ''

How glad I am you've come!'' said Betsy. '' I'm tired, and was just longing to have some tea before they come.

You might go''-- she (Betsy) turned to Tushkevitch--

``with Masha, and try the croquet ground over there where they've been cutting it. We shall have time to talk a little over tea; we'll have a cozy chat, eh?

'' (Tushkevitch)

she (Masha) said in English to Anna, with a smile, pressing the hand with which she (Anna) held a parasol. '' Yes, especially as I can't stay very long with you.

I've been promising to go for a century,'' said Anna, to whom lying, alien as it was to her (Anna) nature, had become not merely simple and natural in society, but a positive source of satisfaction.

I'm forced to go on to old Madame Vrede. Why she (Anna) said this, which she (Anna) had not thought of a second before, she (Anna) could not have explained.

She (Anna) had said it simply from the reflection that as Vronsky would not be here, she (Anna) had better secure her (Anna) own freedom, and try to see him (I) somehow.

But why she (Anna) had spoken of old Madame Vrede, whom she (Anna) had to go and see, as she (Anna) had to see many other people, she (Anna) could not have explained; and yet, as it afterwards turned out, had she (Anna) contrived the most cunning devices to meet Vronsky, she (Anna) could have thought of nothing better.

'' No. I'm not going to let you go for anything,'' answered Betsy, looking intently into Anna's face. '' Really, if I were not fond of you, I should feel offended.

Tea in the little dining room, please,'' she (Anna) said, half closing her (Anna) eyes, as she (Anna) always did when addressing the footman.

Alexey's playing us false,'' she (Anna) said in French;

``he (Alexey) writes that he (Alexey) can't come,'' (French)
she (Anna) added in a tone as simple and natural as though it could never enter her (Anna) head that Vronsky could mean anything more to Anna than a game of croquet.

Anna knew that Betsy knew everything, but, hearing how she (Anna) spoke of Vronsky before her (Anna), she (Anna) almost felt persuaded for a minute that she (Anna) knew nothing.

One would think you were afraid my society would compromise you. Taking the note from him (Alexey), she (Anna) read it. '' ''

Ah!'' said Anna indifferently, as though not greatly interested in the matter, and she (Anna) went on smiling:

``How can you or your friends compromise anyone?'' (she)

This playing with words, this hiding of a secret, had a great fascination for Anna, as, indeed, it has for all women.

And it was not the necessity of concealment, not the aim with which the concealment was contrived, but the process of concealment itself which attracted her (Anna).

'' I can't be more Catholic than the Pope,'' she (Anna) said. '' Stremov and Liza Merkalova, why, they're the cream of the cream of society.

Besides, they're received everywhere, and I ''--she (Merkalova) laid special stress on the I--

``have never been strict and intolerant. It's simply that I haven't the time.'' (she)

'' No; you don't care, perhaps, to meet Stremov? Let him (Pope) and Alexey Alexandrovitch tilt at each other in the committee--

that's no affair of ours. But in the world, he (Alexandrovitch)'s the most amiable man I know, and a devoted croquet player.

And, in spite of his (player) absurd position as Liza's lovesick swain at his (player) age, you ought to see how he (player) carries off the absurd position.

Betsy said all this, and, at the same time, from her (Betsy) good-humored, shrewd glance, Anna felt that she (Anna) partly guessed her (Anna) plight, and was hatching something for her (Anna) benefit.

You shall see. He (player)'s very nice. Sappho Shtoltz you don't know? Oh, that's a new type, quite new. '' They were in the little boudoir.

I must write to Alexey though,'' and Betsy sat down to the table, scribbled a few lines, and put the note in an envelope.

'' '' I'm telling him (Alexey) to come to dinner. I've one lady extra to dinner with me, and no man to take her (lady) in.

Look what I've said, will that persuade him (man)? Excuse me, I must leave you for a minute. Would you seal it up, please, and send it off?

Without a moment's thought, Anna sat down to the table with Betsy's letter, and, without reading it, wrote below:

``It's essential for me to see you.

'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)

she (Anna) said from the door;
``I have to give some directions. '' (she)
Come to the Vrede garden. I shall be there at six o'clock.

At tea, which was brought them on a little tea-table in the cool little drawing room, the cozy chat promised by Princess Tverskaya before the arrival of her (Princess) visitors really did come off between the two women.

'' She (Princess) sealed it up, and, Betsy coming back, in her (Betsy) presence handed the note to be taken. They criticized the people they were expecting, and the conversation fell upon Liza Merkalova.

'' She (Merkalova)'s very sweet, and I always liked her (Merkalova),'' said Anna. '' You ought to like her (Anna). She (Anna) raves about you.

She (Anna) says you're a real heroine of romance, and that if she (Anna) were a man she (Anna) would do all sorts of mad things for your sake.

Yesterday she (Anna) came up to me after the races and was in despair at not finding you. Stremov says she (Anna) does that as it is.''

But do tell me, please, I never could make it out,'' said Anna, after being silent for some time, speaking in a tone that showed she (Anna) was not asking an idle question, but that what she (Anna) was asking was of more importance to her (Anna) than it should have been;

``do tell me, please, what are her (Anna) relations with Prince Kaluzhsky, Mishka, as he (Kaluzhsky)'s called?

'' (she)

I've met them so little. What does it mean? '' Betsy smiled with her (Betsy) eyes, and looked intently at Anna.

'' It's a new manner,'' she (Anna) said. '' They've all adopted that manner. They've flung their caps over the windmills. But there are ways and ways of flinging them.''

'' Yes, but what are her (Anna) relations precisely with Kaluzhsky? '' Betsy broke into unexpectedly mirthful and irrepressible laughter, a thing which rarely happened with her (Betsy).

That's the question of an enfant terrible ,'' and Betsy obviously tried to restrain herself, but could not, and went off into peals of that infectious laughter that people laugh who do not laugh often.

'' You're encroaching on Princess Myakaya's special domain now. '' You'd better ask them,'' she (Princess) brought out, between tears of laughter.

'' No; you laugh,'' said Anna, laughing too in spite of herself,

``but I never could understand it. I can't understand the husband's r√¥le in it.'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

'' The husband? Liza Merkalova's husband carries her (Merkalova) shawl, and is always ready to be of use. But anything more than that in reality, no one cares to inquire.

You know in decent society one doesn't talk or think even of certain details of the toilet. That's how it is with this.''

I don't think so,'' answered Betsy, and, without looking at her (Betsy) friend, she (Betsy) began filling the little transparent cups with fragrant tea.

``Will you be at Madame Rolandak's f√™te? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
asked Anna, to change the conversation. '' Putting a cup before Anna, she (Anna) took out a cigarette, and, fitting it into a silver holder, she (Anna) lighted it.

It's like this, you see: I'm in a fortunate position,'' she (Anna) began, quite serious now, as she (Anna) took up her (Anna) cup.

'' '' I understand you, and I understand Liza. Liza now is one of those na√Øve natures that, like children, don't know what's good and what's bad.

Anyway, she (Liza) didn't comprehend it when she (Liza) was very young. And now she (Liza)'s aware that the lack of comprehension suits her (Liza).

The very same thing, don't you see, may be looked at tragically, and turned into a misery, or it may be looked at simply and even humorously.

Now, perhaps, she (Liza) doesn't know on purpose,'' said Betsy, with a subtle smile. '' But, anyway, it suits her (Betsy). Possibly you are inclined to look at things too tragically.

said Anna, seriously and dreamily. '' Am I worse than other people, or better?

They heard the sound of steps and a man's voice, then a woman's voice and laughter, and immediately thereafter there walked in the expected guests: Sappho Shtoltz, and a young man beaming with excess of health, the so-called Vaska.

I think I'm worse.'' '' Enfant terrible, enfant terrible! '' repeated Betsy. '' But here they are. '' Chapter 18 It was evident that ample supplies of beefsteak, truffles, and Burgundy never failed to reach him (Vaska) at the fitting hour.

He (Vaska) walked after Sappho into the drawing-room, and followed her (Betsy) about as though he (Vaska) were chained to her (Betsy), keeping his (Vaska) sparkling eyes fixed on her (Betsy) as though he (Vaska) wanted to eat her (Betsy).

Vaska bowed to the two ladies, and glanced at them, but only for one second. Sappho Shtoltz was a blonde beauty with black eyes.

Anna had never met this new star of fashion, and was struck by her (Anna) beauty, the exaggerated extreme to which her (Anna) dress was carried, and the boldness of her (Anna) manners.

On her (Anna) head there was such a superstructure of soft, golden hair--her (Anna) own and false mixed--that her (Anna) head was equal in size to the elegantly rounded bust, of which so much was exposed in front.

The impulsive abruptness of her (Anna) movements was such that at every step the lines of her (Anna) knees and the upper part of her (Anna) legs were distinctly marked under her (Anna) dress, and the question involuntarily rose to the mind where in the undulating, piled-up mountain of material at the back the real body of the woman, so small and slender, so naked in front, and so hidden behind and below, really came to an end.

She (woman) walked with smart little steps in high-heeled shoes, and shook hands with the ladies vigorously like a man. Betsy made haste to introduce her (Betsy) to Anna.

Only fancy, we all but ran over two soldiers,'' she (Anna) began telling them at once, using her (Anna) eyes, smiling and twitching away her (Anna) tail, which she (Anna) flung back at one stroke all on one side.

And mentioning his (man) surname she (Anna) introduced the young man, and reddening a little, broke into a ringing laugh at her (Anna) mistake--that is, at her (Anna) having called him (man) Vaska to a stranger.

'' '' I drove here with Vaska.... Ah, to be sure, you don't know each other. '' Vaska bowed once more to Anna, but he (Vaska) said nothing to her (Anna).

He (Vaska) addressed Sappho:

``You've lost your bet. We got here first. Pay up,'' (Sappho/Sappho Shtoltz)
said he (Vaska), smiling. Sappho laughed still more festively.

``Very well, very well. Oh, yes.

'' (She)

She (Anna) turned suddenly to Princess Betsy:
``I am a nice person... I positively forgot it... I've brought you a visitor.

The unexpected young visitor, whom Sappho had invited, and whom she (Betsy) had forgotten, was, however, a personage of such consequence that, in spite of his (visitor) youth, both the ladies rose on his (visitor) entrance.

And here he (visitor) comes. '' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)

He (visitor) was a new admirer of Sappho's. He (visitor) now dogged her (Betsy) footsteps, like Vaska. Soon after Prince Kaluzhsky arrived, and Liza Merkalova with Stremov.

The tone of her (Merkalova) dark dress -LRB-Anna immediately observed and appreciated the fact-RRB- was in perfect harmony with her (Anna) style of beauty.

Liza Merkalova was a thin brunette, with an Oriental, languid type of face, and--as everyone used to say--exquisite enigmatic eyes. Liza was as soft and enervated as Sappho was smart and abrupt.

Betsy had said to Anna that she (Betsy) had adopted the pose of an innocent child, but when Anna saw her (Anna), she (Anna) felt that this was not the truth.

But to Anna's taste Liza was far more attractive. She (Liza) really was both innocent and corrupt, but a sweet and passive woman.

It is true that her (woman) tone was the same as Sappho's; that like Sappho, she (woman) had two men, one young and one old, tacked onto her (woman), and devouring her (woman) with their eyes.

But there was something in her (woman) higher than what surrounded her (woman). There was in her (woman) the glow of the real diamond among glass imitations.

The weary, and at the same time passionate, glance of those eyes, encircled by dark rings, impressed one by its perfect sincerity.

This glow shone out in her (woman) exquisite, truly enigmatic eyes. Everyone looking into those eyes fancied he (Sappho) knew her (woman) wholly, and knowing her (woman), could not but love her (woman).

At the sight of Anna, her (Anna) whole face lighted up at once with a smile of delight. '' Ah, how glad I am to see you!''

she (Anna) said, going up to her (Anna). '' Yesterday at the races all I wanted was to get to you, but you'd gone away.

I did so want to see you, yesterday especially. Wasn't it awful? '' she (Anna) said, looking at Anna with eyes that seemed to lay bare all her (Anna) soul.

'' Yes; I had no idea it would be so thrilling,'' said Anna, blushing. The company got up at this moment to go into the garden.

'' I'm not going,'' said Liza, smiling and settling herself close to Anna. '' You won't go either, will you? Who wants to play croquet?''

'' Oh, I like it,'' said Anna. '' There, how do you manage never to be bored by things? It's delightful to look at you.

You're alive, but I'm bored. ''

``How can you be bored? Why, you live in the liveliest set in Petersburg,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna.

Possibly the people who are not of our set are even more bored; but we--I certainly--are not happy, but awfully, awfully bored.

'' '' Sappho smoking a cigarette went off into the garden with the two young men. Betsy and Stremov remained at the tea-table.

'' What, bored!'' said Betsy. '' Sappho says they did enjoy themselves tremendously at your house last night. ''

``Ah, how dreary it all was!'' (Liza Merkalova/Liza)
said Liza Merkalova.

'' We all drove back to my place after the races. And always the same people, always the same. Always the same thing.

We lounged about on sofas all the evening. What is there to enjoy in that? No; do tell me how you manage never to be bored?

One has but to look at you and one sees, here's a woman who may be happy or unhappy, but isn't bored.

'' she (woman) said, addressing Anna again. '' Tell me how you do it?''

``I do nothing,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
answered Anna, blushing at these searching questions.

'' That's the best way,'' Stremov put in. Stremov was a man of fifty, partly gray, but still vigorous-looking, very ugly, but with a characteristic and intelligent face.

On meeting Anna Karenina, as he (man) was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the government, he (man) tried, like a shrewd man and a man of the world, to be particularly cordial with her (Karenina), the wife of his (man) enemy. '''

Liza Merkalova was his (man) wife's niece, and he (man) spent all his (man) leisure hours with her (Merkalova). Nothing,''' he (man) put in with a subtle smile,

``that's the very best way.

I told you long ago,'' (he)

he (man) said, turning to Liza Merkalova,
``that if you don't want to be bored, you mustn't think you're going to be bored.

It's just as you mustn't be afraid of not being able to fall asleep, if you're afraid of sleeplessness. That's just what Anna Arkadyevna has just said.

'' (Liza Merkalova/Liza)

``I should be very glad if I had said it, for it's not only clever but true,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, smiling.

'' No, do tell me why it is one can't go to sleep, and one can't help being bored?'' '' To sleep well one ought to work, and to enjoy oneself one ought to work too.

'' '' What am I to work for when my work is no use to anybody? And I can't and won't knowingly make a pretense about it.

As he (it) rarely met Anna, he (it) could say nothing but commonplaces to her (Anna), but he (it) said those commonplaces as to when she (Anna) was returning to Petersburg, and how fond Countess Lidia Ivanovna was of her (Ivanovna), with an expression which suggested that he (it) longed with his (it) whole soul to please her (Ivanovna) and show his (it) regard for her (Ivanovna) and even more than that.

'' '' You're incorrigible,'' said Stremov, not looking at her (Ivanovna), and he (it) spoke again to Anna. Tushkevitch came in, announcing that the party were awaiting the other players to begin croquet.

'' No, don't go away, please don't,'' pleaded Liza Merkalova, hearing that Anna was going. Stremov joined in her (Anna) entreaties. ''

And besides, you will only give her (Anna) a chance for talking scandal, while here you arouse none but such different feelings of the highest and most opposite kind,'' he (it) said to her (Anna).

It's too violent a transition,'' he (it) said,

``to go from such company to old Madame Vrede. Anna pondered for an instant in uncertainty.

This shrewd man's flattering words, the na√Øve, childlike affection shown her (Anna) by Liza Merkalova, and all the social atmosphere she (Anna) was used to,-- it was all so easy, and what was in store for her (Anna) was so difficult, that she (Anna) was for a minute in uncertainty whether to remain, whether to put off a little longer the painful moment of explanation.

But remembering what was in store for her (Anna) alone at home, if she (Anna) did not come to some decision, remembering that gesture--terrible even in memory--when she (Anna) had clutched her (Anna) hair in both hands--she (Anna) said good-bye and went away.

In early youth in the Corps of Pages, he (it) had experienced the humiliation of a refusal, when he (it) had tried, being in difficulties, to borrow money, and since then he (it) had never once put himself in the same position again.

In order to keep his (it) affairs in some sort of order, he (it) used about five times a year -LRB-more or less frequently, according to circumstances-RRB- to shut himself up alone and put all his (it) affairs into definite shape.

Chapter 19 In spite of Vronsky's apparently frivolous life in society, he (it) was a man who hated irregularity. This he (it) used to call his (it) day of reckoning or faire la lessive .

On waking up the day after the races, Vronsky put on a white linen coat, and without shaving or taking his (it) bath, he (it) distributed about the table moneys, bills, and letters, and set to work.

Petritsky, who knew he (it) was ill-tempered on such occasions, on waking up and seeing his (it) comrade at the writing-table, quietly dressed and went out without getting in his (it) way.

Every man who knows to the minutest details all the complexity of the conditions surrounding him (man), cannot help imagining that the complexity of these conditions, and the difficulty of making them clear, is something exceptional and personal, peculiar to himself, and never supposes that others are surrounded by just as complicated an array of personal affairs as he (man) is.

And not without inward pride, and not without reason, he (man) thought that any other man would long ago have been in difficulties, would have been forced to some dishonorable course, if he (man) had found himself in such a difficult position.

But Vronsky felt that now especially it was essential for him (Vronsky) to clear up and define his (Vronsky) position if he (Vronsky) were to avoid getting into difficulties.

Writing out on note paper in his (Vronsky) minute hand all that he (Vronsky) owed, he (Vronsky) added up the amount and found that his (Vronsky) debts amounted to seventeen thousand and some odd hundreds, which he (Vronsky) left out for the sake of clearness.

Reckoning up his (Vronsky) money and his (Vronsky) bank book, he (Vronsky) found that he (Vronsky) had left one thousand eight hundred roubles, and nothing coming in before the New Year.

So indeed it seemed to Vronsky. What Vronsky attacked first as being the easiest was his (Vronsky) pecuniary position. Reckoning over again his (Vronsky) list of debts, Vronsky copied it, dividing it into three classes.

In the first class he (Vronsky) put the debts which he (Vronsky) would have to pay at once, or for which he (Vronsky) must in any case have the money ready so that on demand for payment there could not be a moment's delay in paying.

Such debts amounted to about four thousand: one thousand five hundred for a horse, and two thousand five hundred as surety for a young comrade, Venovsky, who had lost that sum to a cardsharper in Vronsky's presence.

-LRB-he (comrade) had that amount then-RRB-, but Venovsky and Yashvin had insisted that they would pay and not Vronsky, who had not played.

That was so far well, but Vronsky knew that in this dirty business, though his (Vronsky) only share in it was undertaking by word of mouth to be surety for Venovsky, it was absolutely necessary for him (Vronsky) to have the two thousand five hundred roubles so as to be able to fling it at the swindler, and have no more words with him (swindler).

Vronsky had wanted to pay the money at the time And so for this first and most important division he (swindler) must have four thousand roubles.

These were principally accounts owing in connection with his (swindler) race horses, to the purveyor of oats and hay, the English saddler, and so on.

He (saddler) would have to pay some two thousand roubles on these debts too, in order to be quite free from anxiety.

The second class--eight thousand roubles--consisted of less important debts. The last class of debts--to shops, to hotels, to his (saddler) tailor--were such as need not be considered.

For a man with one hundred thousand roubles of revenue, which was what everyone fixed as Vronsky's income, such debts, one would suppose, could hardly be embarrassing; but the fact was that he (man) was far from having one hundred thousand.

So that he (man) needed at least six thousand roubles for current expenses, and he (man) only had one thousand eight hundred. His (man) father's immense property, which alone yielded a yearly income of two hundred thousand, was left undivided between the brothers.

At the time when the elder brother, with a mass of debts, married Princess Varya Tchirkova, the daughter of a Decembrist without any fortune whatever, Alexey had given up to his (Alexey) elder brother almost the whole income from his (Alexey) father's estate, reserving for himself only twenty-five thousand a year from it.

Alexey had said at the time to his (Alexey) brother that that sum would be sufficient for him (Alexey) until he (Alexey) married, which he (Alexey) probably never would do.

And his (Alexey) brother, who was in command of one of the most expensive regiments, and was only just married, could not decline the gift.

His (Alexey) mother, who had her (mother) own separate property, had allowed Alexey every year twenty thousand in addition to the twenty-five thousand he (Alexey) had reserved, and Alexey had spent it all.

Of late his (Alexey) mother, incensed with him (Alexey) on account of his (Alexey) love affair and his (Alexey) leaving Moscow, had given up sending him (Alexey) the money.

And in consequence of this, Vronsky, who had been in the habit of living on the scale of forty-five thousand a year, having only received twenty thousand that year, found himself now in difficulties.

Her (mother) last letter, which he (Alexey) had received the day before, had particularly exasperated him (Alexey) by the hints in it that she (mother) was quite ready to help him (Alexey) to succeed in the world and in the army, but not to lead a life which was a scandal to all good society.

To get out of these difficulties, he (Alexey) could not apply to his (Alexey) mother for money. His (Alexey) mother's attempt to buy him (Alexey) stung him (Alexey) to the quick and made him (Alexey) feel colder than ever to her (mother).

But he (Alexey) could not draw back from the generous word when it was once uttered, even though he (Alexey) felt now, vaguely foreseeing certain eventualities in his (Alexey) intrigue with Madame Karenina, that this generous word had been spoken thoughtlessly, and that even though he (Alexey) were not married he (Alexey) might need all the hundred thousand of income.

He (Alexey) had only to recall his (Alexey) brother's wife, to remember how that sweet, delightful Varya sought, at every convenient opportunity, to remind him (Alexey) that she (Varya) remembered his (Alexey) generosity and appreciated it, to grasp the impossibility of taking back his (Alexey) gift.

One thing only could and ought to be done, and Vronsky determined upon it without an instant's hesitation: to borrow money from a money-lender, ten thousand roubles, a proceeding which presented no difficulty, to cut down his (Alexey) expenses generally, and to sell his (Alexey) race horses.

Resolving on this, he (Alexey) promptly wrote a note to Rolandak, who had more than once sent to him (Alexey) with offers to buy horses from him (Alexey).

Then he (Alexey) sent for the Englishman and the money-lender, and divided what money he (Alexey) had according to the accounts he (Alexey) intended to pay.

Having finished this business, he (Alexey) wrote a cold and cutting answer Anna's, read them again, burned them, and remembering their conversation on the previous day, he (Alexey) sank into meditation.

Chapter 20 Vronsky's life was particularly happy in that he (Alexey) had a code of principles, which defined with unfailing certitude what he (Alexey) ought and what he (Alexey) ought not to do.

This code of principles covered only a very small circle of contingencies, but then the principles were never doubtful, and Vronsky, as he (Alexey) never went outside that circle, had never had a moment's hesitation about doing what he (Alexey) ought to do.

These principles laid down as invariable rules: that one must pay a cardsharper, but need not pay a tailor; that one must never tell a lie to a man, but one may to a woman; that one must never cheat anyone, but one may a husband; that one must never pardon an insult, but one may give one and so on.

These principles were possibly not reasonable and not good, but they were of unfailing certainty, and so long as he (husband) adhered to them, Vronsky felt that his (Vronsky) heart was at peace and he (Vronsky) could hold his (Vronsky) head up.

Only quite lately in regard to his (Vronsky) relations with Anna, Vronsky had begun to feel that his (Vronsky) code of principles did not fully cover all possible contingencies, and to foresee in the future difficulties and perplexities for which he (Vronsky) could find no guiding clue.

But it was impossible to draw back. It was as impossible as beating a woman, stealing, or lying. His (Vronsky) present relation to Anna and to her (Anna) husband was to his (Vronsky) mind clear and simple.

She (Anna) was an honorable woman who had bestowed her (Anna) love upon him (Vronsky), and he (Vronsky) loved her (Anna), and therefore she (Anna) was in his (Vronsky) eyes a woman who had a right to the same, or even more, respect than a lawful wife.

He (Vronsky) would have had his (Vronsky) hand chopped off before he (Vronsky) would have allowed himself by a word, by a hint, to humiliate her (wife), or even to fall short of the fullest respect a woman could look for.

It was clearly and precisely defined in the code of principles by which he (Vronsky) was guided. His (Vronsky) attitude to society, too, was clear.

If any did so, he (Vronsky) was ready to force all who might speak to be silent and to respect the non-existent honor of the woman he (Vronsky) loved.

Everyone might know, might suspect it, but no one might dare to speak of it. His (Vronsky) attitude to the husband was the clearest of all.

From the moment that Anna loved Vronsky, he (Vronsky) had regarded his (Vronsky) own right over her (Anna) as the one thing unassailable. Her (Anna) husband was simply a superfluous and tiresome person.

The one thing the husband had a right to was to demand satisfaction with a weapon in his (husband) hand, and Vronsky was prepared for this at any minute.

No doubt he (Vronsky) was in a pitiable position, but how could that be helped? But of late new inner relations had arisen between him (Vronsky) and her (Anna), which frightened Vronsky by their indefiniteness.

And he (Vronsky) felt that this fact and what she (Anna) expected of him (Vronsky) called for something not fully defined in that code of principles by which he (Vronsky) had hitherto steered his (Vronsky) course in life.

And he (Vronsky) had been indeed caught unawares, and at the first moment when she (Anna) spoke to him (Vronsky) of her (Anna) position, his (Vronsky) heart had prompted him (Vronsky) to beg her (Anna) to leave her (Anna) husband.

He (Vronsky) had said that, but now thinking things over he (Vronsky) saw clearly that it would be better to manage to avoid that; and at the same time, as he (Vronsky) told himself so

Only the day before she (Anna) had told him (Vronsky) that she (Anna) was with child. , he (Vronsky) was afraid whether it was not wrong.

If I told her (Anna) to leave her (Anna) husband, that must mean uniting her (Anna) life with mine; am I prepared for that?

'' (he)

How can I take her (Anna) away now, when I have no money? Supposing I could arrange.... But how can I take her (Anna) away while I'm in the service?

If I say that--I ought to be prepared to do it, that is, I ought to have the money and to retire from the army.

The question whether to retire from the service or not brought him (husband) to the other and perhaps the chief though hidden interest of his (chief) life, of which none knew but he (chief).

Ambition was the old dream of his (chief) youth and childhood, a dream which he (chief) did not confess even to himself, though it was so strong that now this passion was even doing battle with his (chief) love.

His (chief) first steps in the world and in the service had been successful, but two years before he (chief) had made a great mistake.

Anxious to show his (chief) independence and to advance, he (chief) had refused a post that had been offered him (chief), hoping that this refusal would heighten his (chief) value; but it turned out that he (chief) had been too bold, and he (chief) was passed over.

And having, whether he (chief) liked or not, taken up for himself the position of an independent man, he (man) carried it off with great tact and good sense, behaving as though he (man) bore no grudge against anyone, did not regard himself as injured in any way, and cared for nothing but to be left alone since he (man) was enjoying himself.

In reality he (man) had ceased to enjoy himself as long ago as the year before, when he (man) went away to Moscow.

He (man) felt that this independent attitude of a man who might have done anything, but cared to do nothing, was already beginning to pall, that many people were beginning to fancy that he (man) was not really capable of anything but being a straightforward, good-natured fellow.

His (fellow) connection with Madame Karenina, by creating so much sensation and attracting general attention, had given him (fellow) a fresh distinction which soothed his (fellow) gnawing worm of ambition for a while, but a week before that worm had been roused up again with fresh force.

The friend of his (friend) childhood, a man of the same set, of the same coterie, his (friend) comrade in the Corps of Pages, Serpuhovskoy, who had left school with him (friend) and had been his (friend) rival in class, in gymnastics, in their scrapes and their dreams of glory, had come back a few days before from Central Asia, where he (friend) had gained two steps up in rank, and an order rarely bestowed upon generals so young.

As soon as he (friend) arrived in Petersburg, people began to talk about him (friend) as a newly risen star of the first magnitude.

A schoolfellow of Vronsky's and of the same age, he (friend) was a general and was expecting a command, which might have influence on the course of political events; while Vronsky, independent and brilliant and beloved by a charming woman though he (friend) was, was simply a cavalry captain who was readily allowed to be as independent as ever he (friend) liked.

Of course I don't envy Serpuhovskoy and never could envy him (friend); but his (friend) advancement shows me that one has only to watch one's opportunity, and the career of a man like me may be very rapidly made.

'' And he (man) grew thoughtful. '' Three years ago he (man) was in just the same position as I am. If I retire, I burn my ships.

If I remain in the army, I lose nothing. She (I) said herself she (I) did not wish to change her (I) position. And with her (I) love I cannot feel envious of Serpuhovskoy.

His (man) eyes shone particularly brightly, and he (man) felt in that confident, calm, and happy frame of mind which always came after he (man) had thoroughly faced his (man) position.

'' And slowly twirling his (man) mustaches, he (man) got up from the table and walked about the room. Everything was straight and clear, just as after former days of reckoning.

He (man) shaved, took a cold bath, dressed and went out. Chapter 21

The smile in his (Vronsky) eyes gleamed more brightly than ever.

Having once made up his (Vronsky) mind that he (Vronsky) was happy in his (Vronsky) love, that he (Vronsky) sacrificed his (Vronsky) ambition to it--having anyway taken up this position, Vronsky was incapable of feeling either envious of Serpuhovskoy or hurt with him (Vronsky) for not coming first to him (Vronsky) when he (Vronsky) came to the regiment.

Serpuhovskoy was a good friend, and he (Vronsky) was delighted he (Vronsky) had come. '' Ah, I'm very glad! '' The colonel, Demin, had taken a large country house.

In the courtyard the first objects that met Vronsky's eyes were a band of singers in white linen coats, standing near a barrel of vodka, and the robust, good-humored figure of the colonel surrounded by officers.

He (colonel) had gone out as far as the first step of the balcony and was loudly shouting across the band that played Offenbach's quadrille, waving his (colonel) arms and giving some orders to a few soldiers standing on one side.

The whole party were in the wide lower balcony. A group of soldiers, a quartermaster, and several subalterns came up to the balcony with Vronsky.

The colonel returned to the table, went out again onto the steps with a tumbler in his (colonel) hand, and proposed the toast,

``To the health of our former comrade, the gallant general, Prince Serpuhovskoy.

Hurrah! '' (The colonel)

The colonel was followed by Serpuhovskoy, who came out onto the steps smiling, with a glass in his (colonel) hand.

You always get younger, Bondarenko,'' he (colonel) said to the rosy-checked, smart-looking quartermaster standing just before him (colonel), still youngish looking though doing his (colonel) second term of service.

He (colonel) looked more robust, had let his (colonel) whiskers grow, but was still the same graceful creature, whose face and figure were even more striking from their softness and nobility than their beauty.

The only change Vronsky detected in him (colonel) was that subdued, continual radiance of beaming content which settles on the faces of men who are successful and are sure of the recognition of their success by everyone.

'' It was three years since Vronsky had seen Serpuhovskoy. Vronsky knew that radiant air, and immediately observed it in Serpuhovskoy.

Then the colonel, who began to show signs of feebleness, sat down on a bench in the courtyard and began demonstrating to Yashvin the superiority of Russia over Poland, especially in cavalry attack, and there was a lull in the revelry for a moment.

Serpuhovskoy went into the house to the bathroom to wash his (colonel) hands and found Vronsky there; Vronsky was drenching his (Vronsky) head with water.

He (Vronsky) had taken off his (Vronsky) coat and put his (Vronsky) sunburnt, hairy neck under the tap, and was rubbing it and his (Vronsky) head with his (Vronsky) hands.

Then, to the accompaniment of the band, the colonel himself danced with Petritsky. When he (colonel) had finished, Vronsky sat down by Serpuhovskoy.

They both sat down in the bathroom on a lounge, and a conversation began which was very interesting to both of them.

'' I've always been hearing about you through my wife,'' said Serpuhovskoy. '' I'm glad you've been seeing her (wife) pretty often.

'' '' She (wife)'s friendly with Varya, and they're the only women in Petersburg I care about seeing,'' answered Vronsky, smiling. He (Vronsky) smiled because he (Vronsky) foresaw the topic the conversation would turn on, and he (Vronsky) was glad of it.

Yes; and I heard news of you, but not only through your wife,'' said Vronsky, checking his (Vronsky) hint by a stern expression of face.

'' The only ones? '' Serpuhovskoy queried, smiling. '' '' I was greatly delighted to hear of your success, but not a bit surprised.

I expected even more. '' Serpuhovskoy smiled. Such an opinion of him (Vronsky) was obviously agreeable to him (Vronsky), and he (Vronsky) did not think it necessary to conceal it.

'' Well, I on the contrary expected less--I'll own frankly. But I'm glad, very glad. I'm ambitious; that's my weakness, and I confess to it.

''

``Perhaps you wouldn't confess to it if you hadn't been successful,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky. '' I don't suppose so,'' said Serpuhovskoy, smiling again.

'' I won't say life wouldn't be worth living without it, but it would be dull. Of course I may be mistaken, but I fancy

``and so the nearer I get to it, the better pleased I am.

``Perhaps that is true for you, but not for everyone.

I used to think so too, but here I live and think life worth living not only for that.'' (unknown)

And I think your action was good in itself, but you didn't do it quite in the way you ought to have done.

But there are ways of doing everything. '' '' What's done can't be undone, and you know I never go back on what I've done.

And besides, I'm very well off.''

'' Yes, but that's not the only thing. Such men as you are wanted.''

``How do you mean? Bertenev's party against the Russian communists?'' (Serpuhovskoy)
'' No,'' said Serpuhovskoy, frowning with vexation at being suspected of such an absurdity.

'' Tout √ßa est une blague . That's always been and always will be. There are no communists. But intriguing people have to invent a noxious, dangerous party.

It's an old trick. No, what's wanted is a powerful party of independent men like you and me.'' '' But why so?

``Simply because they have not, or have not had from birth, an independent fortune; they've not had a name, they've not been close to the sun and center as we have.

'' (Vronsky)

Vronsky mentioned a few men who were in power. '' Why aren't they independent men?'' They can be bought either by money or by favor.

And they bring forward some notion, some policy that they don't believe in, that does harm; and the whole policy is really only a means to a government house and so much income.

And they have to find a support for themselves in inventing a policy. Cela n'est pas plus fin que √ßa , when you get a peep at their cards.

I may be inferior to them, stupider perhaps, though I don't see why I should be inferior to them. But you and I have one important advantage over them for certain, in being more difficult to buy.

Vronsky listened attentively, but he (I) was not so much interested by the meaning of the words as by the attitude of Serpuhovskoy who was already contemplating a struggle with the existing powers, and already had his (I) likes and dislikes in that higher world, while his (I) own interest in the governing world did not go beyond the interests of his (I) regiment.

Vronsky felt, too, how powerful Serpuhovskoy might become through his (I) unmistakable faculty for thinking things out and for taking things in, through his (I) intelligence and gift of words, so rarely met with in the world in which he (I) moved.

And such men are more needed than ever. '' And, ashamed as he (I) was of the feeling, he (I) felt envious. ''

Still I haven't the one thing of most importance for that,'' he (I) answered;

``I haven't the desire for power. I had it once, but it's gone.

'' (he)

answered Vronsky. '' You say perhaps ,'' Serpuhovskoy went on, as though guessing his (I) thoughts,

Serpohovskoy's smile and gestures told Vronsky that he (Vronsky) mustn't be afraid, that he (Vronsky) would be tender and careful in touching the sore place.

But I'm married, and believe me, in getting to know thoroughly one's wife, if one loves her (wife), as someone has said, one gets to know all women better than if one knew thousands of them.''

But listen: we're the same age, you've known a greater number of women perhaps than I have. '' '' '' We're coming directly!

'' Vronsky shouted to an officer, who looked into the room and called them to the colonel. Vronsky was longing now to hear to the end and know what Serpuhovskey would say to him (colonel).

'' And here's my opinion for you. Women are the chief stumbling block in a man's career. It's hard to love a woman and do anything.

There's only one way of having love conveniently without its being a hindrance--that's marriage. How, how am I to tell you what I mean?

Yes, just as you can only carry a fardeau and do something with your hands, when the fardeau is tied on your back, and that's marriage.

'' said Serpuhovskoy, who liked similes. '' Wait a minute, wait a minute! And that's what I felt when I was married.

But to drag that fardeau about with you without marriage, your hands will always be so full that you can do nothing.

My hands were suddenly set free. Look at Mazankov, at Krupov. They've ruined their careers for the sake of women. ''

``What women!'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, recalling the Frenchwoman and the actress with whom the two men he (Serpuhovskoy) had mentioned were connected. ''

``We'll talk about it later on; I'll look you up in Petersburg. '' (unknown)
Chapter 22 It was a roomy, old-fashioned fly, with seats for four.

A vague sense of the order into which his (Vronsky) affairs had been brought, a vague recollection of the friendliness and flattery of Serpuhovskoy, who had considered him (Vronsky) a man that was needed, and most of all, the anticipation of the interview before him (Vronsky)--all blended into a general, joyous sense of life.

He (Vronsky) sat in one corner, stretched his (Vronsky) legs out on the front seat, and sank into meditation. This feeling was so strong that he (Vronsky) could not help smiling.

He (Vronsky) dropped his (Vronsky) legs, crossed one leg over the other knee, and taking it in his (Vronsky) hand, felt the springy muscle of the calf, where it had been grazed the day before by his (Vronsky) fall, and leaning back he (Vronsky) drew several deep breaths.

He (Vronsky) had often before had this sense of physical joy in his (Vronsky) own body, but he (Vronsky) had never felt so fond of himself, of his (Vronsky) own body, as at that moment.

He (Vronsky) enjoyed the slight ache in his (Vronsky) strong leg, he (Vronsky) enjoyed the muscular sensation of movement in his (Vronsky) chest as he (Vronsky) breathed.

The bright, cold August day, which had made Anna feel so hopeless, seemed to him (Vronsky) keenly stimulating, and refreshed his (Vronsky) face and neck that still tingled from the cold water.

'' I'm happy, very happy!'' he (Vronsky) said to himself. The scent of brilliantine on his (Vronsky) whiskers struck him (Vronsky) as particularly pleasant in the fresh air.

Everything he (Vronsky) saw from the carriage window, everything in that cold pure air, in the pale light of the sunset, was as fresh, and gay, and strong as he (Vronsky) was himself: the roofs of the houses shining in the rays of the setting sun, the sharp outlines of fences and angles of buildings, the figures of passers-by, the carriages that met him (Vronsky) now and then, the motionless green of the trees and grass, the fields with evenly drawn furrows of potatoes, and the slanting shadows that fell from the houses, and trees, and bushes, and even from the rows of potatoes--everything was bright like a pretty landscape just finished and freshly varnished.

he (Vronsky) said to the driver, putting his (Vronsky) head out of the window, and pulling a three-rouble note out of his (Vronsky) pocket he (Vronsky) handed it to the man as he (Vronsky) looked round.

The driver's hand fumbled with something at the lamp, the whip cracked, and the carriage rolled rapidly along the smooth highroad.

I want nothing, nothing but this happiness,'' he (Vronsky) thought, staring at the bone button of the bell in the space between the windows, and picturing to himself Anna just as he (Vronsky) had seen her (Anna) last time.

``Get on, get on! '' (I)
'' '' And as I go on, I love her (Anna) more and more. Here's the garden of the Vrede Villa.

'' he (Vronsky) thought, wondering now for the first time at it. But there was now no time for wonder. There was no one in the avenue; but looking round to the right he (Vronsky) caught sight of her (Anna).

Her (Anna) face was hidden by a veil, but he (Vronsky) drank in with glad eyes the special movement in walking, peculiar to her (Anna) alone, the slope of the shoulders, and the setting of the head, and at once a sort of electric shock ran all over him (Vronsky).

With fresh force, he (Vronsky) felt conscious of himself from the springy motions of his (Vronsky) legs to the movements of his (Vronsky) lungs as he (Vronsky) breathed, and something set his (Vronsky) lips twitching.

He (Vronsky) saw that something had happened, and that the interview would not be a joyous one.

In her (Anna) presence he (Vronsky) had no will of his (Vronsky) own: without knowing the grounds of her (Anna) distress, he (Vronsky) already felt the same distress unconsciously passing over him (Vronsky).

'' What is it? what? '' he (Vronsky) asked her (Anna), squeezing her (Anna) hand with his (Vronsky) elbow, and trying to read her (Anna) thoughts in her (Anna) face.

She (Anna) walked on a few steps in silence, gathering up her (Anna) courage; then suddenly she (Anna) stopped. '' I did not tell you yesterday,'' she (Anna) began, breathing quickly and painfully,

``that coming home with Alexey Alexandrovitch

He (Alexandrovitch) heard her (Anna), unconsciously bending his (Alexandrovitch) whole figure down to her (Anna) as though hoping in this way to soften the hardness of her (Anna) position for her (Anna).

'' Yes, yes, that's better, a thousand times better!

I know how painful it was,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. But she (wife) was not listening to his (Alexandrovitch) words, she (wife) was reading his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts from the expression of his (Alexandrovitch) face.

She (wife) could not guess that that expression arose from the first idea that presented itself to Vronsky--that a duel was now inevitable.

The idea of a duel had never crossed her (wife) mind, and so she (wife) put a different interpretation on this passing expression of hardness.

When she (wife) got her (wife) husband's letter, she (wife) knew then at the bottom of her (wife) heart that everything would go on in the old way, that she (wife) would not have the strength of will to forego her (wife) position, to abandon her (wife) son, and to join her (wife) lover.

The morning spent at Princess Tverskaya's had confirmed her (Princess) still more in this. But this interview was still of the utmost gravity for her (Princess).

If on hearing this news he (lover) were to say to her (Princess) resolutely, passionately, without an instant's wavering:

she (Princess) would give up her (Princess) son and go away with him (son).

'' It was not in the least painful to me. It happened of itself,'' she (Princess) said irritably;

``and see... '' (she)
she (Princess) pulled her (Princess) husband's letter out of her (Princess) glove.

The one thing I longed for, the one thing I prayed for, was to cut short this position, so as to devote my life to your happiness.''

``Why do you tell me that? '' (she)
she (Princess) said. '' Do you suppose I can doubt it? If I doubted... '' ''

Who's that coming?'' said Vronsky suddenly, pointing to two ladies walking towards them. '' Perhaps they know us!'' and he (us) hurriedly turned off, drawing her (Princess) after him (us) into a side path.

'' Oh, I don't care! '' she (Princess) said. Her (Princess) lips were quivering. And he (us) fancied that her (Princess) eyes looked with strange fury at him (us) from under the veil.

Again, just as at the first moment of hearing of her (Princess) rupture with her (Princess) husband, Vronsky, on reading the letter, was unconsciously carried away by the natural sensation aroused in him (husband) by his (husband) own relation to the betrayed husband.

Now while he (husband) held his (husband) letter in his (husband) hands, he (husband) could not help picturing the challenge, which he (husband) would most likely find at home today or tomorrow, and the duel itself, in which, with the same cold and haughty expression that his (husband) face was assuming at this moment he (husband) would await the injured husband's shot, after having himself fired into the air.

And at that instant there flashed across his (husband) mind the thought of what Serpuhovskoy had just said to him (husband), and what he (husband) had himself been thinking in the morning--that it was better not to bind himself

'' She (husband) stood still again. --and he (husband) knew that this thought he (husband) could not tell her (husband). Having read the letter, he (husband) raised his (husband) eyes to her (husband), and there was no determination in them.

She (husband) saw at once that he (husband) had been thinking about it before by himself. She (husband) knew that whatever he (husband) might say to her (husband), he (husband) would not say all he (husband) thought.

And she (husband) knew that her (husband) last hope had failed her (husband). This was not what she (husband) had been reckoning on. '' You see the sort of man he (man) is,'' she (husband) said, with a shaking voice;

``he (man)...'' (she)
``Forgive me, but I rejoice at it,'' (she)
Vronsky interrupted. '' For God's sake, let me finish! '' he (God) added, his (God) eyes imploring her (husband) to give him (God) time to explain his (God) words.

'' I rejoice, because things cannot, cannot possibly remain as he (God) supposes. ''

``Why can't they? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
Anna said, restraining her (Anna) tears, and obviously attaching no sort of consequence to what he (God) said.

She (Anna) felt that her (Anna) fate was sealed. Vronsky meant that after the duel--inevitable, he (God) thought-- things could not go on as before, but he (God) said something different.

'' It can't go on. I hope that now you will leave him (God). I hope''-- he (God) was confused, and reddened--

``that you will let me arrange and plan our life.

I should have to leave him (God), and I can't and won't do that.'' '' But, for God's sake, which is better?--leave your child, or keep up this degrading position?''

'' To whom is it degrading?''

``To all, and most of all to you.'' (unknown)
'' You say degrading... don't say that.

Those words have no meaning for me,'' she (Anna) said in a shaking voice. She (Anna) did not want him (God) now to say what was untrue.

She (Anna) had nothing left her (Anna) but his (God) love, and she (Anna) wanted to love him (God). '' Don't you understand that from the day I loved you everything has changed for me?

For me there is one thing, and one thing only--your love. If that's mine, I feel so exalted, so strong, that nothing can be humiliating to me.

I am proud of my position, because...proud of being... proud... '' She (Anna) could not say what she (Anna) was proud of. Tears of shame and despair choked her (Anna) utterance.

He (God) felt, too, something swelling in his (God) throat and twitching in his (God) nose, and for the first time in his (God) life he (God) felt on the point of weeping.

He (God) felt sorry for her (Anna), and he (God) felt he (God) could not help her (Anna), and with that he (God) knew that he (God) was to blame for her (Anna) wretchedness, and that he (God) had done something wrong.

She (Anna) stood still and sobbed. He (God) could not have said exactly what it was touched him (God) so.

``Is not a divorce possible?'' (he)
he (God) said feebly.

She (Anna) shook her (Anna) head, not answering. '' Couldn't you take your son, and still leave him (son)?'' '' Yes; but it all depends on him (son).

Now I must go to him (son),'' she (Anna) said shortly. Her (Anna) presentiment that all would again go on in the old way had not deceived her (Anna).

'' On Tuesday I shall be in Petersburg, and everything can be settled. '' '' Yes,'' she (Anna) said. '' But don't let us talk any more of it.

Anna's carriage, which she (Anna) had sent away, and ordered to come back to the little gate of the Vrede garden, drove up.

'' Anna said good-bye to Vronsky, and drove home. Chapter 23 On Monday there was the usual sitting of the Commission of the 2nd of June.

Alexey Alexandrovitch walked into the hall where the sitting was held, greeted the members and the president, as usual, and sat down in his (president) place, putting his (president) hand on the papers laid ready before him (president).

Among these papers lay the necessary evidence and a rough outline of the speech he (president) intended to make. But he (president) did not really need these documents.

He (president) knew that when the time came, and when he (president) saw his (president) enemy facing him (president), and studiously endeavoring to assume an expression of indifference, his (president) speech would flow of itself better than he (president) could prepare it now.

He (president) remembered every point, and did not think it necessary to go over in his (president) memory what he (president) would say. He (president) felt that the import of his (president) speech was of such magnitude that every word of it would have weight.

No one, looking at his (president) white hands, with their swollen veins and long fingers, so softly stroking the edges of the white paper that lay before him (president), and at the air of weariness with which his (president) head drooped on one side, would have suspected that in a few minutes a torrent of words would flow from his (president) lips that would arouse a fearful storm, set the members shouting and attacking one another, and force the president to call for order.

When the report was over, Alexey Alexandrovitch announced in his (Alexandrovitch) subdued, delicate voice that he (Alexandrovitch) had several points to bring before the meeting in regard to the Commission for the Reorganization of the Native Tribes.

Meantime, as he (Alexandrovitch) listened to the usual report, he (Alexandrovitch) had the most innocent and inoffensive air. All attention was turned upon him (Alexandrovitch).

Alexey Alexandrovitch cleared his (Alexandrovitch) throat, and not looking at his (Alexandrovitch) opponent, but selecting, as he (Alexandrovitch) always did while he (Alexandrovitch) was delivering his (Alexandrovitch) speeches, the first person sitting opposite him (Alexandrovitch), an inoffensive little old man, who never had an opinion of any sort in the Commission, began to expound his (Alexandrovitch) views.

Stremov, who was also a member of the Commission, and also stung to the quick, began defending himself, and altogether a stormy sitting followed; but Alexey Alexandrovitch triumphed, and his (Alexandrovitch) motion was carried, three new commissions were appointed, and the next day in a certain Petersburg circle nothing else was talked of but this sitting.

When he (Alexandrovitch) reached the point about the fundamental and radical law, his (Alexandrovitch) opponent jumped up and began to protest. Alexey Alexandrovitch's success had been even greater than he (Alexandrovitch) had anticipated.

Next morning, Tuesday, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on waking up, recollected with pleasure his (Alexandrovitch) triumph of the previous day, and he (Alexandrovitch) could not help smiling, though he (Alexandrovitch) tried to appear indifferent, when the chief secretary of his (secretary) department, anxious to flatter him (secretary), informed him (secretary) of the rumors that had reached him (secretary) concerning what had happened in the Commission.

Absorbed in business with the chief secretary, Alexey Alexandrovitch had completely forgotten that it was Tuesday, the day fixed by him (Alexandrovitch) for the return of Anna Arkadyevna, and he (Alexandrovitch) was surprised and received a shock of annoyance when a servant came in to inform him (servant) of her (Arkadyevna) arrival.

Anna had arrived in Petersburg early in the morning; the carriage had been sent to meet her (Anna) in accordance with her (Anna) telegram, and so Alexey Alexandrovitch might have known of her (Anna) arrival.

But when she (Anna) arrived, he (Alexandrovitch) did not meet her (Anna). She (Anna) was told that he (Alexandrovitch) had not yet gone out, but was busy with his (Alexandrovitch) secretary.

She (Anna) sent word to her (Anna) husband that she (Anna) had come, went to her (Anna) own room, and occupied herself in sorting out her (Anna) things, expecting he (Alexandrovitch) would come to her (Anna).

She (Anna) went into the dining room on the pretext of giving some directions, and spoke loudly on purpose, expecting him (Alexandrovitch) to come out there; but he (Alexandrovitch) did not come, though she (Anna) heard him (Alexandrovitch) go to the door of his (Alexandrovitch) study as he (Alexandrovitch) parted from the chief secretary.

She (Anna) knew that he (Alexandrovitch) usually went out quickly to his (Alexandrovitch) office, and she (Anna) wanted to see him (Alexandrovitch) before that, so that their attitude to one another might be defined.

When she (Anna) went into his (Alexandrovitch) study he (Alexandrovitch) was in official uniform, obviously ready to go out, sitting at a little table on which he (Alexandrovitch) rested his (Alexandrovitch) elbows, looking dejectedly before him (Alexandrovitch).

But an hour passed; he (Alexandrovitch) did not come. She (Anna) walked across the drawing room and went resolutely to him (Alexandrovitch). She (Anna) saw him (Alexandrovitch) before he (Alexandrovitch) saw her (Anna), and she (Anna) saw that he (Alexandrovitch) was thinking of her (Anna).

On seeing her (Anna), he (Alexandrovitch) would have risen, but changed his (Alexandrovitch) mind, then his (Alexandrovitch) face flushed hotly--a thing Anna had never seen before, and he (Alexandrovitch) got up quickly and went to meet her (Anna), looking not at her (Anna) eyes, but above them at her (Anna) forehead and hair.

I am very glad you have come,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, sitting down beside her (Anna), and obviously wishing to say something, he (Alexandrovitch) stuttered.

He (Alexandrovitch) went up to her (Anna), took her (Anna) by the hand, and asked her (Anna) to sit down. '' Several times he (Alexandrovitch) tried to begin to speak, but stopped.

In spite of the fact that, preparing herself for meeting him (Alexandrovitch), she (Anna) had schooled herself to despise and reproach him (Alexandrovitch), she (Anna) did not know what to say to him (Alexandrovitch), and she (Anna) felt sorry for him (Alexandrovitch).

he (Alexandrovitch) said, and not waiting for an answer, he (Alexandrovitch) added:

``I shan't be dining at home today, and I have got to go out directly.'' (he)

And so the silence lasted for some time. '' Is Seryozha quite well? ''

``I had thought of going to Moscow,'' (she)
she (Anna) said.

'' No, you did quite, quite right to come,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, and was silent again. Seeing that he (Alexandrovitch) was powerless to begin the conversation, she (Anna) began herself.

Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' she (Anna) said, looking at him (Alexandrovitch) and not dropping her (Anna) eyes under his (Alexandrovitch) persistent gaze at her (Anna) hair, ``I'm a guilty woman, I'm a bad woman, but I am the same as I was, as I told you then, and

``I have asked you no question about that,'' (I)
he (Alexandrovitch) said, all at once, resolutely and with hatred looking her (woman) straight in the face;
``that was as I had supposed.

'' (he)

I have come to tell you that I can change nothing. '' '' Under the influence of anger he (Alexandrovitch) apparently regained complete possession of all his (Alexandrovitch) faculties.

But as I told you then, and have written to you,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said in a thin, shrill voice, ``I repeat now, that I am not bound to know this.

Not all wives are so kind as you, to be in such a hurry to communicate such agreeable news to their husbands.

``I shall ignore it so long as the world knows nothing of it, so long as my name is not disgraced.

And so I simply inform you that our relations must be just as they have always been, and that only in the event of your compromising me I shall be obliged to take steps to secure my honor.'' (I)

'' I ignore it. '' He (it) laid special emphasis on the word

``agreeable.'' (He)
'' But our relations cannot be the same as always,'' Anna began in a timid voice, looking at him (it) with dismay.

When she (Anna) saw once more those composed gestures, heard that shrill, childish, and sarcastic voice, her (Anna) aversion for him (it) extinguished her (Anna) pity for him (it), and she (Anna) felt only afraid, but at all costs she (Anna) wanted to make clear her (Anna) position.

'' I cannot be your wife while I... '' she (Anna) began. He (it) laughed a cold and malignant laugh. '' The manner of life you have chosen is reflected, I suppose, in your ideas.

I have too much respect or contempt, or both... I respect your past and despise your present...that I was far from the interpretation you put on my words.

Though indeed I fail to comprehend how, with the independence you show,'' he (it) went on, getting hot, ''--announcing your infidelity to your husband and seeing nothing reprehensible in it, apparently--you can see anything reprehensible in performing a wife's duties in relation to your husband.

``I want you not to meet that man here, and to conduct yourself so that neither the world nor the servants can reproach you...not to see him (man).

'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

Anna sighed and bowed her (Anna) head. '' ''
``Alexey Alexandrovitch! What is it you want of me?'' (I)
That's not much, I think.

And in return you will enjoy all the privileges of a faithful wife without fulfilling her (wife) duties. That's all I have to say to you.

Now it's time for me to go. I'm not dining at home. '' He (Alexandrovitch) got up and moved towards the door.

Anna got up too. Bowing in silence, he (Alexandrovitch) let her (Anna) pass before him (Alexandrovitch). Chapter 24 The night spent by Levin on the haycock did not pass without result for him (Levin).

In spite of the magnificent harvest, never had there been, or, at least, never it seemed to him (Levin), had there been so many hindrances and so many quarrels between him (Levin) and the peasants as that year, and the origin of these failures and this hostility was now perfectly comprehensible to him (Levin).

The delight he (Levin) had experienced in the work itself, and the consequent greater intimacy with the peasants, the envy he (Levin) felt of them, of their life, the desire to adopt that life, which had been to him (Levin) that night not a dream but an intention, the execution of which he (Levin) had thought out in detail --all this had so transformed his (Levin) view of the farming of the land as he (Levin) had managed it, that he (Levin) could not take his (Levin) former interest in it, and could not help seeing that unpleasant relation between him (Levin) and the workpeople which was the foundation of it all.

The herd of improved cows such as Pava, the whole land ploughed over and enriched, the nine level fields surrounded with hedges, the two hundred and forty acres heavily manured, the seed sown in drills, and all the rest of it--it was all splendid if only the work had been done for themselves, or for themselves and comrades --people in sympathy with them.

But he (Levin) saw clearly now -LRB-his (Levin) work on a book of agriculture, in which the chief element in husbandry was to have been the laborer, greatly assisted him (laborer) in this-RRB- that the sort of farming he (laborer) was carrying on was nothing but a cruel and stubborn struggle between him (laborer) and the laborers, in which there was on one side--his (laborer) side--a continual intense effort to change everything to a pattern he (laborer) considered better; on the other side, the natural order of things.

And in this struggle he (laborer) saw that with immense expenditure of force on his (laborer) side, and with no effort or even intention on the other side, all that was attained was that the work did not go to the liking of either side, and that splendid tools, splendid cattle and land were spoiled with no good to anyone.

The way in which he (laborer) had been managing his (laborer) land revolted him (laborer) and had lost all attraction for him (laborer). Worst of all, the energy expended on this work was not simply wasted.

He (laborer) could not help feeling now, since the meaning of this system had become clear to him (laborer), that the aim of his (laborer) energy was a most unworthy one.

He (laborer) was struggling for every farthing of his (laborer) share -LRB-and he (laborer) could not help it, for he (laborer) had only to relax his (laborer) efforts, and he (laborer) would not have had the money to pay his (laborer) laborers' wages-RRB-, while they were only struggling to be able to do their work easily and agreeably, that is to say, as they were used to doing it.

It was for his (laborer) interests that every laborer should work as hard as possible, and that while doing so he (laborer) should keep his (laborer) wits about him (laborer), so as to try not to break the winnowing machines, the horse rakes, the thrashing machines, that he (laborer) should attend to what he (laborer) was doing.

What the laborer wanted was to work as pleasantly as possible, with rests, and above all, carelessly and heedlessly, without thinking.

He (laborer) sent the men to mow some clover for hay, picking out the worst patches where the clover was overgrown with grass and weeds and of no use for seed; again and again they mowed the best acres of clover, justifying themselves by the pretense that the bailiff had told them to, and trying to pacify him (bailiff) with the assurance that it would be splendid hay; but he (bailiff) knew that it was owing to those acres being so much easier to mow.

He (bailiff) sent out a hay machine for pitching the hay--it was broken at the first row because it was dull work for a peasant to sit on the seat in front with the great wings waving above him (peasant).

In reality, what was the struggle about? That summer Levin saw this at every step. And he (Levin) was told, ``Don't trouble, your honor, sure, the womenfolks will pitch it quick enough.

The ploughs were practically useless, because it never occurred to the laborer to raise the share when he (laborer) turned the plough, and forcing it round, he (laborer) strained the horses and tore up the ground, and Levin was begged not to mind about it.

The horses were allowed to stray into the wheat because not a single laborer would consent to be night-watchman, and in spite of orders to the contrary, the laborers insisted on taking turns for night duty, and Ivan, after working all day long, fell asleep, and was very penitent for his (Ivan) fault, saying,

``Do what you will to me, your honor.

They killed three of the best calves by letting them into the clover aftermath without care as to their drinking, and nothing would make the men believe that they had been blown out by the clover, but they told him (Ivan), by way of consolation, that one of his (Ivan) neighbors had lost a hundred and twelve head of cattle in three days.

All this happened, not because anyone felt ill-will to Levin or his (Levin) farm; on the contrary, he (Levin) knew that they liked him (Levin), thought him (Levin) a simple gentleman -LRB-their highest praise-RRB-; but it happened simply because all they wanted was to work merrily and carelessly, and his (gentleman) interests were not only remote and incomprehensible to them, but fatally opposed to their most just claims.

'' (Ivan/Ivan Parmenov)

'' Long before, Levin had felt dissatisfaction with his (Long) own position in regard to the land. He (Long) saw where his (Long) boat leaked, but he (Long) did not look for the leak, perhaps purposely deceiving himself.

The farming of the land, as he (Long) was managing it, had become not merely unattractive but revolting to him (Long), and he (Long) could take no further interest in it.

To this now was joined the presence, only twenty-five miles off, of Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, whom he (Long) longed to see and could not see.

Darya Alexandrovna Oblonskaya had invited him (Long), when he (Long) was over there, to come; to come with the object of renewing his (Long) offer to her (Shtcherbatskaya) sister, who would, so she (Shtcherbatskaya) gave him (Long) to understand, accept him (Long) now.

Levin himself had felt on seeing Kitty Shtcherbatskaya that he (Levin) had never ceased to love her (Shtcherbatskaya); but he (Levin) could not go over to the Oblonskys', knowing she (Shtcherbatskaya) was there.

The fact that he (Levin) had made her (Shtcherbatskaya) an offer, and she (Shtcherbatskaya) had refused him (Levin), had placed an insuperable barrier between her (Shtcherbatskaya) and him (Levin).

I can't ask her (Shtcherbatskaya) to be my wife merely because she (Shtcherbatskaya) can't be the wife of the man she (Shtcherbatskaya) wanted to marry,'' he (man) said to himself.

-LRB-Nothing would be left him (man) if he (man) lost faith in it.-RRB- But now he (man) could deceive himself no longer. '' The thought of this made him (man) cold and hostile to her (Shtcherbatskaya).

I should not be able to speak to her (Shtcherbatskaya) without a feeling of reproach; I could not look at her (Shtcherbatskaya) without resentment; and she (Shtcherbatskaya) will only hate me all the more, as she (Shtcherbatskaya)'s bound to.

'' And besides, how can I now, after what Darya Alexandrovna told me, go to see them? Can I help showing that I know what she (Shtcherbatskaya) told me?

And me to go magnanimously to forgive her (Shtcherbatskaya), and have pity on her (Shtcherbatskaya)! Me go through a performance before her (Shtcherbatskaya) of forgiving, and deigning to bestow my love on her (Shtcherbatskaya)!...

By chance I might have seen her (Shtcherbatskaya), then everything would have happened of itself; but, as it is, it's out of the question, out of the question!''

What induced Darya Alexandrovna to tell me that? Darya Alexandrovna sent him (me) a letter, asking him (me) for a side-saddle for Kitty's use.

'' I'm told you have a side-saddle,'' she (Kitty) wrote to him (me);

``I hope you will bring it over yourself. '' (him)
This was more than he (me) could stand.

How could a woman of any intelligence, of any delicacy, put her (woman) sister in such a humiliating position! He (me) wrote ten notes, and tore them all up, and sent the saddle without any reply.

To write that he (me) would go was impossible, because he (me) could not go; to write that he (me) could not come because something prevented him (me), or that he (me) would be away, that was still worse.

He (me) sent the saddle without an answer, and with a sense of having done something shameful; he (me) handed over all the now revolting business of the estate to the bailiff, and set off next day to a remote district to see his (bailiff) friend Sviazhsky, who had splendid marshes for grouse in his (bailiff) neighborhood, and had lately written to ask him (bailiff) to keep a long-standing promise to stay with him (bailiff).

The grouse-marsh, in the Surovsky district, had long tempted Levin, but he (Levin) had continually put off this visit on account of his (Levin) work on the estate.

Now he (Levin) was glad to get away from the neighborhood of the Shtcherbatskys, and still more from his (Levin) farm work, especially on a shooting expedition, which always in trouble served as the best consolation.

In the Surovsky district there was no railway nor service of post horses, and Levin drove there with his (Levin) own horses in his (Levin) big, old-fashioned carriage.

A bald, well-preserved old man, with a broad, red beard, gray on his (man) cheeks, opened the gate, squeezing against the gatepost to let the three horses pass.
