You're in the right; but I'm going all the same. '' These were the only words that had been spoken sincerely between them.

Levin knew that those words meant,

``You see, and you know, that I'm in a bad way, and maybe we shall not see each other again.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Levin knew this, and the tears gushed from his (Levin) eyes. He (Levin) kissed his (Levin) brother once more, but he (Levin) could not speak, and knew not what to say.

Three days after his (Levin) brother's departure, Levin too set off for his (Levin) foreign tour. Happening to meet Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's cousin, in the railway train, Levin greatly astonished him (Levin) by his (Levin) depression.

'' What's the matter with you? '' Shtcherbatsky asked him (Shtcherbatsky). '' Oh, nothing ; there's not much happiness in life. ''

``Not much? You come with me to Paris instead of to Mulhausen. You shall see how to be happy.'' (I)
'' No, I've done with it all.

It's time I was dead.'' '' Well, that's a good one!'' said Shtcherbatsky, laughing;

``why, I'm only just getting ready to begin.

'' (Shtcherbatsky/Prince Shtcherbatsky/Prince)

'' Yes, I thought the same not long ago, but now I know I shall soon be dead. '' Levin said what he (Levin) had genuinely been thinking of late.

He (Levin) saw nothing but death or the advance towards death in everything. But his (Levin) cherished scheme only engrossed him (Levin) the more.

Darkness had fallen upon everything for him (Levin); but just because of this darkness he (Levin) felt that the one guiding clue in the darkness was his (Levin) work, and he (Levin) clutched it and clung to it with all his (Levin) strength.

The Karenins, husband and wife, continued living in the same house, met every day, but were complete strangers to one another.

Alexey Alexandrovitch made it a rule to see his (Alexandrovitch) wife every day, so that the servants might have no grounds for suppositions, but avoided dining at home.

Vronsky was never at Alexey Alexandrovitch's house, but Anna saw him (Alexandrovitch) away from home, and her (Anna) husband was aware of it.

The position was one of misery for all three; and not one of them would have been equal to enduring this position for a single day, if it had not been for the expectation that it would change, that it was merely a temporary painful ordeal which would pass over.

Alexey Alexandrovitch hoped that this passion would pass, as everything does pass, that everyone would forget about it, and his (Alexandrovitch) name would remain unsullied.

Anna, on whom the position depended, and for whom it was more miserable than for anyone, endured it because she (Anna) not merely hoped, but firmly believed, that it would all very soon be settled and come right.

She (Anna) had not the least idea what would settle the position, but she (Anna) firmly believed that something would very soon turn up now.

Vronsky, against his (Alexandrovitch) own will or wishes, followed her (Anna) lead, hoped too that something, apart from his (Alexandrovitch) own action, would be sure to solve all difficulties.

Life had to be got through somehow till death did come. PART 4 Chapter 1 In the middle of the winter Vronsky spent a very tiresome week.

A foreign prince, who had come on a visit to Petersburg, was put under his (prince) charge, and he (prince) had to show him (prince) the sights worth seeing.

Vronsky was of distinguished appearance; he (prince) possessed, moreover, the art of behaving with respectful dignity, and was used to having to do with such grand personages--that was how he (prince) came to be put in charge of the prince.

The prince was anxious to miss nothing of which he (prince) would be asked at home, had he (prince) seen that in Russia?

But he (prince) felt his (prince) duties very irksome. And on his (prince) own account he (prince) was anxious to enjoy to the utmost all Russian forms of amusement.

Vronsky was obliged to be his (prince) guide in satisfying both these inclinations. The mornings they spent driving to look at places of interest; the evenings they passed enjoying the national entertainments.

By gymnastics and careful attention to his (prince) health he (prince) had brought himself to such a point that in spite of his (prince) excess in pleasure he (prince) looked as fresh as a big glossy green Dutch cucumber.

The prince had traveled a great deal, and considered one of the chief advantages of modern facilities of communication was the accessibility of the pleasures of all nations.

He (chief) had been in Spain, and there had indulged in serenades and had made friends with a Spanish girl who played the mandolin.

The prince rejoiced in health exceptional even among princes. In Switzerland he (prince) had killed chamois. In England he (prince) had galloped in a red coat over hedges and killed two hundred pheasants for a bet.

In Turkey he (prince) had got into a harem; in India he (prince) had hunted on an elephant, and now in Russia he (prince) wished to taste all the specially Russian forms of pleasure.

Vronsky, who was, as it were, chief master of the ceremonies to him (master), was at great pains to arrange all the Russian amusements suggested by various persons to the prince.

They had race horses, and Russian pancakes and bear hunts and three-horse sledges, and gypsies and drinking feasts, with the Russian accompaniment of broken crockery.

And the prince with surprising ease fell in with the Russian spirit, smashed trays full of crockery, sat with a gypsy girl on his (prince) knee, and seemed to be asking--what more, and does the whole Russian spirit consist in just this?

Vronsky was used to princes, but, either because he (prince) had himself changed of late, or that he (prince) was in too close proximity to the prince, that week seemed fearfully wearisome to him (prince).

The whole of that week he (prince) experienced a sensation such as a man might have set in charge of a dangerous madman, afraid of the madman, and at the same time, from being with him (madman), fearing for his (madman) own reason.

Vronsky was continually conscious of the necessity of never for a second relaxing the tone of stern official respectfulness, that he (madman) might not himself be insulted.

The prince's manner of treating the very people who, to Vronsky's surprise, were ready to descend to any depths to provide him (prince) with Russian amusements, was contemptuous.

In reality, of all the Russian entertainments the prince liked best French actresses and ballet dancers and white-seal champagne. His (prince) criticisms of Russian women, whom he (prince) wished to study, more than once made Vronsky crimson with indignation.

The chief reason why the prince was so particularly disagreeable to Vronsky was that he (Vronsky) could not help seeing himself in him (Vronsky).

And what he (Vronsky) saw in this mirror did not gratify his (Vronsky) self-esteem. He (Vronsky) was a very stupid and very self-satisfied and very healthy and very well-washed man, and nothing else.

He (man) was equable and not cringing with his (man) superiors, was free and ingratiating in his (man) behavior with his (man) equals, and was contemptuously indulgent with his (man) inferiors.

He (man) was a gentleman--that was true, and Vronsky could not deny it. Vronsky was himself the same, and regarded it as a great merit to be so.

But for this prince he (prince) was an inferior, and his (prince) contemptuous and indulgent attitude to him (prince) revolted him (prince). '' Brainless beef!

Be that as it might, when, on the seventh day, he (prince) parted from the prince, who was starting for Moscow, and received his (prince) thanks, he (prince) was happy to be rid of his (prince) uncomfortable position and the unpleasant reflection of himself.

He (prince) said good-bye to him (prince) at the station on their return from a bear hunt, at which they had had a display of Russian prowess kept up all night.

can I be like that? '' he (prince) thought. Chapter 2 When he (prince) got home, Vronsky found there a note from Anna.

She (Anna) wrote,

``I am ill and unhappy. I cannot come out, but I cannot go on longer without seeing you. Come in this evening.

Thinking for an instant of the strangeness of her (Anna) bidding him (prince) come straight to her (Anna), in spite of her (Anna) husband's insisting on her (Anna) not receiving him (prince), he (prince) decided to go.

Alexey Alexandrovitch goes to the council at seven and will be there till ten. '' (She)

Vronsky had that winter got his (Vronsky) promotion, was now a colonel, had left the regimental quarters, and was living alone.

After having some lunch, he (Vronsky) lay down on the sofa immediately, and in five minutes memories of the hideous scenes he (Vronsky) had witnessed during the last few days were confused together and joined on to a mental image of Anna and of the peasant who had played an important part in the bear hunt, and Vronsky fell asleep.

He (peasant) waked up in the dark, trembling with horror, and made haste to light a candle. '' What was it? What?

Yes, yes; I think a little dirty man with a disheveled beard was stooping down doing something, and all of a sudden he (man) began saying some strange words in French.

What was the dreadful thing I dreamed? Yes, there was nothing else in the dream,'' he (man) said to himself. '' But why was it so awful?

He (man) vividly recalled the peasant again and those incomprehensible French words the peasant had uttered, and a chill of horror ran down his (peasant) spine.

He (peasant) rang up his (peasant) servant, dressed in haste, and went out onto the steps, completely forgetting the dream and only worried at being late.

As he (peasant) drove up to the Karenins' entrance he (peasant) looked at his (peasant) watch and saw it was ten minutes to nine.

'' '' What nonsense!'' thought Vronsky, and glanced at his (peasant) watch. It was half-past eight already. A high, narrow carriage with a pair of grays was standing at the entrance.

He (peasant) recognized Anna's carriage. '' She (Anna) is coming to me,'' thought Vronsky,

``and better she (Anna) should. I don't like going into that house.

But no matter; I can't hide myself,'' (Vronsky)

he (peasant) thought, and with that manner peculiar to him (peasant) from childhood, as of a man who has nothing to be ashamed of, Vronsky got out of his (Vronsky) sledge and went to the door.

Vronsky, though he (Vronsky) did not usually notice details, noticed at this moment the amazed expression with which the porter glanced at him (porter).

The door opened, and the hall porter with a rug on his (porter) arm called the carriage. In the very doorway Vronsky almost ran up against Alexey Alexandrovitch.

The gas jet threw its full light on the bloodless, sunken face under the black hat and on the white cravat, brilliant against the beaver of the coat.

Karenin's fixed, dull eyes were fastened upon Vronsky's face. Vronsky bowed, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, chewing his (Alexandrovitch) lips, lifted his (Alexandrovitch) hand to his (Alexandrovitch) hat and went on.

Vronsky saw him (Alexandrovitch) without looking round get into the carriage, pick up the rug and the opera-glass at the window and disappear.

Vronsky went into the hall. His (Alexandrovitch) brows were scowling, and his (Alexandrovitch) eyes gleamed with a proud and angry light in them.

If he (Alexandrovitch) would fight, would stand up for his (Alexandrovitch) honor, I could act, could express my feelings; but this weakness or baseness...

'' What a position!'' he (Alexandrovitch) thought. '' He (Alexandrovitch) puts me in the position of playing false, which I never meant and never mean to do.

Unconsciously yielding to the weakness of Anna--who had surrendered herself up to him (Alexandrovitch) utterly, and simply looked to him (Alexandrovitch) to decide her (Anna) fate, ready to submit to anything--he (Alexandrovitch) had long ceased to think that their tie might end as he (Alexandrovitch) had thought then.

His (Alexandrovitch) ambitious plans had retreated into the background again, and feeling that he (Alexandrovitch) had got out of that circle of activity in which everything was definite, he (Alexandrovitch) had given himself entirely to his (Alexandrovitch) passion, and that passion was binding him (Alexandrovitch) more and more closely to her (Anna).

'' Vronsky's ideas had changed since the day of his (Alexandrovitch) conversation with Anna in the Vrede garden. He (Alexandrovitch) was still in the hall when he (Alexandrovitch) caught the sound of her (Anna) retreating footsteps.

He (Alexandrovitch) knew she (Anna) had been expecting him (Alexandrovitch), had listened for him (Alexandrovitch), and was now going back to the drawing room. ''

No,'' she (Anna) cried, on seeing him (Alexandrovitch), and at the first sound of her (Anna) voice the tears came into her (Anna) eyes. ''

No; if things are to go on like this, the end will come much, much too soon. ''

``What is it, dear one?'' (unknown)

``What? I've been waiting in agony for an hour, two hours... No, I won't... I can't quarrel with you. Of course you couldn't come.

She (Anna) laid her (Anna) two hands on his (Alexandrovitch) shoulders, and looked a long while at him (Alexandrovitch) with a profound, passionate, and at the same time searching look.

She (Anna) was, every time she (Anna) saw him (Alexandrovitch), making the picture of him (Alexandrovitch) in her (Anna) imagination -LRB-incomparably superior, impossible in reality-RRB- fit with him (Alexandrovitch) as he (Alexandrovitch) really was.

No, I won't. '' (She)

She (Anna) was studying his (Alexandrovitch) face to make up for the time she (Anna) had not seen him (Alexandrovitch). Chapter 3 ''

You met him (Alexandrovitch)? '' she (Anna) asked, when they had sat down at the table in the lamplight. '' You're punished, you see, for being late.''

'' Yes; but how was it? Wasn't he (Alexandrovitch) to be at the council?'' '' He (Alexandrovitch) had been and come back, and was going out somewhere again.

But that's no matter. Don't talk about it. Where have you been? With the prince still? '' She (Anna) knew every detail of his (prince) existence.

He (prince) was going to say that he (prince) had been up all night and had dropped asleep, but looking at her (Anna) thrilled and rapturous face, he (prince) was ashamed.

And he (prince) said he (prince) had had to go to report on the prince's departure. '' But it's over now? He (prince) is gone?''

``Thank God it's over! You wouldn't believe how insufferable it's been for me.'' (unknown)
``Why so? Isn't it the life all of you, all young men, always lead?

'' Yes, yes,'' she (Anna) said, evidently trying to suppress her (Anna) jealous thoughts. '' But if only you knew how wretched I am!

I believe you, I believe you.... What were you saying? '' But he (I) could not at once recall what he (I) had been going to say.

These fits of jealousy, which of late had been more and more frequent with her (Anna), horrified him (I), and however much he (I) tried to disguise the fact, made him (I) feel cold to her (Anna), although he (I) knew the cause of her (Anna) jealousy was her (Anna) love for him (I).

How often he (I) had told himself that her (Anna) love was happiness; and now she (Anna) loved him (I) as a woman can love when love has outweighed for her (woman) all the good things of life--and he (I) was much further from happiness than when he (I) had followed her (woman) from Moscow.

Then he (I) had thought himself unhappy, but happiness was before him (I); now he (I) felt that the best happiness was already left behind.

She (woman) was utterly unlike what she (woman) had been when he (I) first saw her (woman). Both morally and physically she (woman) had changed for the worse.

She (woman) had broadened out all over, and in her (woman) face at the time when she (woman) was speaking of the actress there was an evil expression of hatred that distorted it.

He (I) looked at her (woman) as a man looks at a faded flower he (I) has gathered, with difficulty recognizing in it the beauty for which he (I) picked and ruined it.

And in spite of this he (I) felt that then, when his (I) love was stronger, he (I) could, if he (I) had greatly wished it, have torn that love out of his (I) heart; but now, when as at that moment it seemed to him (I) he (I) felt no love for her (woman), he (I) knew that what bound him (I) to her (woman) could not be broken.

'' Well, well, what was it you were going to say about the prince? I have driven away the fiend,'' she (woman) added.

The fiend was the name they had given her (woman) jealousy. '' What did you begin to tell me about the prince?

Why did you find it so tiresome?'' '' Oh, it was intolerable! '' he (prince) said, trying to pick up the thread of his (prince) interrupted thought.

If you want him (prince) defined, here he (prince) is: a prime, well-fed beast such as takes medals at the cattle shows, and nothing more,'' he (prince) said, with a tone of vexation that interested her (woman).

'' He (prince) does not improve on closer acquaintance. '' No; how so? '' she (woman) replied. '' He (prince)'s seen a great deal, anyway; he (prince)'s cultured?''

'' It's an utterly different culture--their culture. He (prince)'s cultivated, one sees, simply to be able to despise culture, as they despise everything but animal pleasures.''

'' But don't you all care for these animal pleasures? '' she (woman) said, and again he (prince) noticed a dark look in her (woman) eyes that avoided him (prince).

I'm not defending him (prince), it's nothing to me; but I imagine, if you had not cared for those pleasures yourself, you might have got out of them.

'' How is it you're defending him (prince)? '' he (prince) said, smiling. '' But if it affords you satisfaction to gaze at Th√®r√©se in the attire of Eve...''

``Again, the devil again,'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
Vronsky said, taking the hand she (woman) had laid on the table and kissing it. '' Yes; but I can't help it.

I'm not jealous: I believe you when you're here; but when you're away somewhere leading your life, so incomprehensible to me...

She (woman) turned away from him (Vronsky), pulled the hook at last out of the crochet work, and rapidly, with the help of her (woman) forefinger, began working loop after loop of the wool that was dazzling white in the lamplight, while the slender wrist moved swiftly, nervously in the embroidered cuff.

You don't know what I have suffered waiting for you. I believe I'm not jealous. '' '' How was it, then?

Where did you meet Alexey Alexandrovitch? '' Her (woman) voice sounded in an unnatural and jarring tone. '' We ran up against each other in the doorway.''

She (woman) drew a long face, and half-closing her (woman) eyes, quickly transformed her (woman) expression, folded her (woman) hands, and Vronsky suddenly saw in her (woman) beautiful face the very expression with which Alexey Alexandrovitch had bowed to him (Alexandrovitch).

'' And he (Alexandrovitch) bowed to you like this? '' He (Alexandrovitch) smiled, while she (woman) laughed gaily, with that sweet, deep laugh, which was one of her (woman) greatest charms.

If after your avowal to him (Alexandrovitch) at your country house he (Alexandrovitch) had broken with you, if he (Alexandrovitch) had called me out--but this

'' I don't understand him (Alexandrovitch) in the least,'' said Vronsky. '' I can't understand. How can he (Alexandrovitch) put up with such a position?

He (Alexandrovitch) feels it, that's evident.''

``He (Alexandrovitch)? '' (she)
she (woman) said sneeringly. '' He (Alexandrovitch)'s perfectly satisfied. '' '' What are we all miserable for, when everything might be so happy?''

``Only not he (Alexandrovitch). Don't I know him (Alexandrovitch), the falsity in which he (Alexandrovitch)'s utterly steeped?... Could one, with any feeling, live as he (Alexandrovitch) is living with me?

He (Alexandrovitch) understands nothing, and feels nothing. Could a man of any feeling live in the same house with his (man) unfaithful wife?

Could he (man) talk to her (wife), call her (wife) `my dear'? '' (she)

And again she (wife) could not help mimicking him (man): ''`Anna, ma ch√®re ; Anna, dear'!''

'' He (man)'s not a man, not a human being--he (man)'s a doll! No one knows him (man); but I know him (man). Oh, if I'd been in his (man) place, I'd long ago have killed, have torn to pieces a wife like me.

I wouldn't have said, `Anna, ma chere'! He (man)'s not a man, he (man)'s an official machine. He (man) doesn't understand that I'm your wife, that he (man)'s outside, that he (man)'s superfluous....

Don't let's talk of him (man)!... ''

``You're unfair, very unfair, dearest,'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
said Vronsky, trying to soothe her (wife). '' But never mind, don't let's talk of him (Vronsky).

Tell me what you've been doing? What is the matter? What has been wrong with you, and what did the doctor say?

Evidently she (wife) had hit on other absurd and grotesque aspects in her (wife) husband and was awaiting the moment to give expression to them.

'' She (wife) looked at him (husband) with mocking amusement. But he (husband) went on:

``I imagine that it's not illness, but your condition.

The ironical light died away in her (wife) eyes, but a different smile, a consciousness of something, he (husband) did not know what, and of quiet melancholy, came over her (wife) face.

When will it be? '' (he)

'' Soon, soon. You say that our position is miserable, that we must put an end to it.

If you knew how terrible it is to me, what I would give to be able to love you freely and boldly!

I should not torture myself and torture you with my jealousy.... And it will come soon, but not as we expect.

And at the thought of how it would come, she (wife) seemed so pitiable to herself that tears came into her (wife) eyes, and she (wife) could not go on.

'' She (wife) laid her (wife) hand on his (me) sleeve, dazzling and white with its rings in the lamplight. '' It won't come as we suppose.

I didn't mean to say this to you, but you've made me. Soon, soon, all will be over, and we shall all, all be at peace, and suffer no more.''

``I don't understand,'' (he)
he (me) said, understanding her (wife). '' You asked when? Soon. And I shan't live through it. Don't interrupt me!''

and she (wife) made haste to speak. '' I know it; I know for certain. I shall die; and I'm very glad I shall die, and release myself and you.

Tears dropped from her (wife) eyes; he (me) bent down over her (wife) hand and began kissing it, trying to hide his (me) emotion, which, he (me) knew, had no sort of grounds, though he (me) could not control it.

'' '' Yes, it's better so,'' she (wife) said, tightly gripping his (me) hand. '' That's the only way, the only way left us.

'' He (me) had recovered himself, and lifted his (me) head. '' How absurd! What absurd nonsense you are talking!'' '' No, it's the truth.

''

``What, what's the truth?'' (unknown)
``That I shall die. I have had a dream. '' (unknown)
'' A dream? '' repeated Vronsky, and instantly he (me) recalled the peasant of his (me) dream.

I dreamed that I ran into my bedroom, that I had to get something there, to find out something; you know how it is in dreams,'' she (me) said, her (me) eyes wide with horror;

``and in the bedroom, in the corner, stood something.'' (she)

'' Yes, a dream,'' she (me) said. '' It's a long while since I dreamed it. '' Oh, what nonsense! How can you believe...

'' But she (me) would not let him (me) interrupt her (me). What she (me) was saying was too important to her (me). '' And the something turned round, and I saw it was a peasant with a disheveled beard, little, and dreadful looking.

I wanted to run away, but he (peasant) bent down over a sack, and was fumbling there with his (peasant) hands... '' She (me) showed how he (peasant) had moved his (peasant) hands.

There was terror in her (me) face. And Vronsky, remembering his (peasant) dream, felt the same terror filling his (peasant) soul. '' He (peasant) was fumbling and kept talking quickly, quickly in French, you know:

Il faut le battre, le fer, le brayer, le p√©trir .... And in my horror I tried to wake up, and woke up...but woke up in the dream.

And I began asking myself what it meant. And Korney said to me: `In childbirth you'll die, ma'am, you'll die...' And I woke up.''

'' What nonsense, what nonsense!'' said Vronsky; but he (Vronsky) felt himself that there was no conviction in his (Vronsky) voice. '' But don't let's talk of it.

Ring the bell, I'll have tea. And stay a little now; it's not long I shall... '' But all at once she (Vronsky) stopped.

The expression of her (Vronsky) face instantaneously changed. Horror and excitement were suddenly replaced by a look of soft, solemn, blissful attention.

He (Vronsky) could not comprehend the meaning of the change. She (Vronsky) was listening to the stirring of the new life within her (Vronsky).

Chapter 4 Alexey Alexandrovitch, after meeting Vronsky on his (Alexandrovitch) own steps, drove, as he (Alexandrovitch) had intended, to the Italian opera. He (Alexandrovitch) sat through two acts there, and saw everyone he (Alexandrovitch) had wanted to see.

On returning home, he (Alexandrovitch) carefully scrutinized the hat stand, and noticing that there was not a military overcoat there, he (Alexandrovitch) went, as usual, to his (Alexandrovitch) own room.

But, contrary to his (Alexandrovitch) usual habit, he (Alexandrovitch) did not go to bed, he (Alexandrovitch) walked up and down his (Alexandrovitch) study till three o'clock in the morning.

The feeling of furious anger with his (Alexandrovitch) wife, who would not observe the proprieties and keep to the one stipulation he (Alexandrovitch) had laid on her (wife), not to receive her (wife) lover in her (wife) own home, gave him (Alexandrovitch) no peace.

She (wife) had not complied with his (Alexandrovitch) request, and he (Alexandrovitch) was bound to punish her (wife) and carry out his (Alexandrovitch) threat--obtain a divorce and take away his (Alexandrovitch) son.

He (Alexandrovitch) knew all the difficulties connected with this course, but he (Alexandrovitch) had said he (Alexandrovitch) would do it, and now he (Alexandrovitch) must carry out his (Alexandrovitch) threat.

Countess Lidia Ivanovna had hinted that this was the best way out of his (Alexandrovitch) position, and of late the obtaining of divorces had been brought to such perfection that Alexey Alexandrovitch saw a possibility of overcoming the formal difficulties.

Misfortunes never come singly, and the affairs of the reorganization of the native tribes, and of the irrigation of the lands of the Zaraisky province, had brought such official worries upon Alexey Alexandrovitch that he (Alexandrovitch) had been of late in a continual condition of extreme irritability.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not sleep the whole night, and his (Alexandrovitch) fury, growing in a sort of vast, arithmetical progression, reached its highest limits in the morning.

He (Alexandrovitch) dressed in haste, and as though carrying his (Alexandrovitch) cup full of wrath, and fearing to spill any over, fearing to lose with his (Alexandrovitch) wrath the energy necessary for the interview with his (Alexandrovitch) wife, he (Alexandrovitch) went into her (wife) room directly he (Alexandrovitch) heard she (wife) was up.

Anna, who had thought she (Anna) knew her (Anna) husband so well, was amazed at his (Alexandrovitch) appearance when he (Alexandrovitch) went in to her (Anna).

His (Alexandrovitch) brow was lowering, and his (Alexandrovitch) eyes stared darkly before him (Alexandrovitch), avoiding her (Anna) eyes; his (Alexandrovitch) mouth was tightly and contemptuously shut.

In his (Alexandrovitch) walk, in his (Alexandrovitch) gestures, in the sound of his (Alexandrovitch) voice there was a determination and firmness such as his (Alexandrovitch) wife had never seen in him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) went into her (wife) room, and without greeting her (wife), walked straight up to her (wife) writing-table, and taking her (wife) keys, opened a drawer.

They're not here,'' she (wife) said, shutting the drawer; but from that action he (Alexandrovitch) saw he (Alexandrovitch) had guessed right, and roughly pushing away her (wife) hand, he (Alexandrovitch) quickly snatched a portfolio in which he (Alexandrovitch) knew she (wife) used to put her (wife) most important papers.

'' What do you want? '' she (wife) cried. '' Your lover's letters,'' he (lover) said. '' She (wife) tried to pull the portfolio away, but he (lover) pushed her (wife) back.

I have to speak to you,'' he (lover) said, putting the portfolio under his (lover) arm, and squeezing it so tightly with his (lover) elbow that his (lover) shoulder stood up.

``Sit down! Amazed and intimidated, she (wife) gazed at him (lover) in silence. '' (I)
I told you that I would not allow you to receive your lover in this house.''

``I had to see him (lover) to... '' (She)
She (wife) stopped, not finding a reason. '' I do not enter into the details of why a woman wants to see her (woman) lover.''

``I meant, I only...'' (she)
she (woman) said, flushing hotly. This coarseness of his (lover) angered her (woman), and gave her (woman) courage. '' Surely you must feel how easy it is for you to insult me?

An honest man and an honest woman may be insulted, but to tell a thief he (thief)'s a thief is simply la constatation d'un fait .''

You call it cruelty for a husband to give his (husband) wife liberty, giving her (wife) the honorable protection of his (husband) name, simply on the condition of observing the proprieties: is that cruelty?''

'' she (wife) said. '' '' This cruelty is something new I did not know in you.'' '' '' It's worse than cruel--it's base, if you want to know!''

'' he (husband) shrieked, in his (husband) shrill voice, which pitched a note higher than usual even, and his (husband) big hands clutching her (wife) by the arm so violently that red marks were left from the bracelet he (husband) was squeezing, he (husband) forcibly sat her (wife) down in her (wife) place.

If you care to use that word, what is base is to forsake husband and child for a lover, while you eat your husband's bread!''

Anna cried, in a rush of hatred, and getting up, she (Anna) was going away. '' No! ``Base! She (Anna) bowed her (Anna) head.

She (Anna) did not say what she (Anna) had said the evening before to her (Anna) lover, that he (lover) was her (Anna) husband, and her (Anna) husband was superfluous; she (Anna) did not even think that.

She (Anna) felt all the justice of his (husband) words, and only said softly:

``You cannot describe my position as worse than I feel it to be myself; but what are you saying all this for?'' (She)

That you may know that since you have not carried out my wishes in regard to observing outward decorum, I will take measures to put an end to this state of things.''

``Soon, very soon, it will end, anyway,'' (she)
she (Anna) said; and again, at the thought of death near at hand and now desired, tears came into her (Anna) eyes.

'' What am I saying it for? what for? '' he (I) went on, as angrily. '' '' It will end sooner than you and your lover have planned!

If you must have the satisfaction of animal passion... ''

``Alexey Alexandrovitch! I won't say it's not generous, but it's not like a gentleman to strike anyone who's down.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you only think of yourself! But the sufferings of a man who was your husband have no interest for you.

You don't care that his (husband) whole life is ruined, that he (husband) is thuff...thuff... '' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

She (Alexandrovitch) wanted to laugh, and was immediately ashamed that anything could amuse her (Alexandrovitch) at such a moment.

And for the first time, for an instant, she (Alexandrovitch) felt for him (Alexandrovitch), put herself in his (Alexandrovitch) place, and was sorry for him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) too was silent for some time, and then began speaking in a frigid, less shrill voice, emphasizing random words that had no special significance.

But what could she (Alexandrovitch) say or do? Her (Alexandrovitch) head sank, and she (Alexandrovitch) sat silent. '' I came to tell you...'' he (Alexandrovitch) said.

My son is going to my sister's,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, with an effort recalling what he (Alexandrovitch) had meant to say about his (Alexandrovitch) son.

Alexey Alexandrovitch flew into a rage, and, snatching his (Alexandrovitch) hand from her (sister), he (Alexandrovitch) went out of the room without a word.

I shall soon be confined; leave him (Alexandrovitch)!'' Chapter 5 The waiting-room of the celebrated Petersburg lawyer was full when Alexey Alexandrovitch entered it.

Three ladies--an old lady, a young lady, and a merchant's wife--and three gentlemen-- one a German banker with a ring on his (banker) finger, the second a merchant with a beard, and the third a wrathful-looking government clerk in official uniform, with a cross on his (banker) neck-- had obviously been waiting a long while already.

Two clerks were writing at tables with scratching pens. The appurtenances of the writing-tables, about which Alexey Alexandrovitch was himself very fastidious, were exceptionally good.

He (Alexandrovitch) could not help observing this. One of the clerks, without getting up, turned wrathfully to Alexey Alexandrovitch, half closing his (Alexandrovitch) eyes.

He (Alexandrovitch) is engaged,'' the clerk responded severely, and he (Alexandrovitch) pointed with his (Alexandrovitch) pen at the persons waiting, and went on writing.

'' What are you wanting? '' He (Alexandrovitch) replied that he (Alexandrovitch) had to see the lawyer on some business. '' '' Can't he (Alexandrovitch) spare time to see me?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

``Then I must trouble you to give him (Alexandrovitch) my card,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch said with dignity, seeing the impossibility of preserving his (Alexandrovitch) incognito.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) has no time free; he (Alexandrovitch) is always busy. Kindly wait your turn.'' The clerk took the card and, obviously not approving of what he (Alexandrovitch) read on it, went to the door.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was in principle in favor of the publicity of legal proceedings, though for some higher official considerations he (Alexandrovitch) disliked the application of the principle in Russia, and disapproved of it, as far as he (Alexandrovitch) could disapprove of anything instituted by authority of the Emperor.

His (Emperor) whole life had been spent in administrative work, and consequently, when he (Emperor) did not approve of anything, his (Emperor) disapproval was softened by the recognition of the inevitability of mistakes and the possibility of reform in every department.

But till then he (Emperor) had had nothing to do with the law courts, and so had disapproved of their publicity simply in theory; now his (Emperor) disapprobation was strengthened by the unpleasant impression made on him (Emperor) in the lawyer's waiting room.

Coming immediately,'' said the clerk; and two minutes later there did actually appear in the doorway the large figure of an old solicitor who had been consulting with the lawyer himself.

In the new public law courts he (lawyer) disliked the restrictions laid on the lawyers conducting cases. '' The lawyer was a little, squat, bald man, with a dark, reddish beard, light-colored long eyebrows, and an overhanging brow.

He (lawyer) was attired as though for a wedding, from his (lawyer) cravat to his (lawyer) double watch-chain and varnished boots. His (lawyer) face was clever and manly, but his (lawyer) dress was dandified and in bad taste.

'' Pray walk in,'' said the lawyer, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch; and, gloomily ushering Karenin in before him (Alexandrovitch), he (Alexandrovitch) closed the door.

He (Alexandrovitch) sat down himself, and, rubbing his (Alexandrovitch) little hands with short fingers covered with white hairs, he (Alexandrovitch) bent his (Alexandrovitch) head on one side.

'' Won't you sit down?'' He (Alexandrovitch) indicated an armchair at a writing table covered with papers. But as soon as he (Alexandrovitch) was settled in this position a moth flew over the table.

The lawyer, with a swiftness that could never have been expected of him (lawyer), opened his (lawyer) hands, caught the moth, and resumed his (lawyer) former attitude.

Before beginning to speak of my business,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, following the lawyer's movements with wondering eyes,

``I ought to observe that the business about which I have to speak to you is to be strictly private.

'' (the lawyer)

'' The lawyer's overhanging reddish mustaches were parted in a scarcely perceptible smile. '' I should not be a lawyer if I could not keep the secrets confided to me.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch glanced at his (Alexandrovitch) face, and saw that the shrewd, gray eyes were laughing, and seemed to know all about it already.

But if you would like proof... '' You know my name?'' Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed. '' I know you and the good''--again

he (Alexandrovitch) caught a moth--

``work you are doing, like every Russian,'' (he)
said the lawyer, bowing. Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed, plucking up his (Alexandrovitch) courage.

But having once made up his (Alexandrovitch) mind he (Alexandrovitch) went on in his (Alexandrovitch) shrill voice, without timidity--or hesitation, accentuating here and there a word.

I have the misfortune,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch began,

``to have been deceived in my married life, and I desire to break off all relations with my wife by legal means--that is, to be divorced, but to do this so that my son may not remain with his (son) mother.

The lawyer's gray eyes tried not to laugh, but they were dancing with irrepressible glee, and Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that it was not simply the delight of a man who has just got a profitable job: there was triumph and joy

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

'' , there was a gleam like the malignant gleam he (Alexandrovitch) saw in his (Alexandrovitch) wife's eyes. '' You desire my assistance in securing a divorce?''

'' Yes, precisely so; but I ought to warn you that I may be wasting your time and attention. I have come simply to consult you as a preliminary step.

It is very possible that if that form does not correspond with my requirements I may give up a legal divorce.''

I want a divorce, but the form in which it is possible is of great consequence to me. '' Oh, that's always the case,'' said the lawyer,

``and that's always for you to decide.

He (lawyer) let his (lawyer) eyes rest on Alexey Alexandrovitch's feet, feeling that he (Alexandrovitch) might offend his (Alexandrovitch) client by the sight of his (Alexandrovitch) irrepressible amusement.

He (Alexandrovitch) looked at a moth that flew before his (Alexandrovitch) nose, and moved his (Alexandrovitch) hands, but did not catch it from regard for Alexey Alexandrovitch's position.

Though in their general features our laws on this subject are known to me,'' (the lawyer)

pursued Alexey Alexandrovitch, ``I should be glad to have an idea of the forms in which such things are done in practice.

``You would be glad,'' (the lawyer)

``for me to lay before you all the methods by which you could secure what you desire?

And on receiving an assuring nod from Alexey Alexandrovitch, he (Alexandrovitch) went on, stealing a glance now and then at Alexey Alexandrovitch's face, which was growing red in patches.

Divorce by our laws,'' (client)

he (Alexandrovitch) said, with a slight shade of disapprobation of our laws,

'' (he)

In the following cases: physical defect in the married parties, desertion without communication for five years,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, crooking a short finger covered with hair,

``subdivided as follows'' (he)

As by now all his (husband) fingers were used up, he (husband) uncrooked all his (husband) fingers and went on:

``This is the theoretical view; but I imagine you have done me the honor to apply to me in order to learn its application in practice.

And therefore, guided by precedents, I must inform you that in practice cases of divorce may all be reduced to the following-- there's no physical defect, I may assume, nor desertion?...

--May be reduced to the following: adultery of one of the married parties, and the detection in the fact of the guilty party by mutual agreement, and failing such agreement, accidental detection.

It must be admitted that the latter case is rarely met with in practice,'' (he)

said the lawyer, and stealing a glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch he (Alexandrovitch) paused, as a man selling pistols, after enlarging on the advantages of each weapon, might await his (Alexandrovitch) customer's choice.

But Alexey Alexandrovitch said nothing, and therefore the lawyer went on:

``The most usual and simple, the sensible course, I consider, is adultery by mutual consent.

I should not permit myself to express it so, speaking with a man of no education,'' (the lawyer)

he (man) said,
``but I imagine that to you this is comprehensible.

'' (he)

'' '' '' '' Wait a little! '' ... '' '' Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed his (Alexandrovitch) head in assent. '' ''

Alexey Alexandrovitch was, however, so perturbed that he (Alexandrovitch) did not immediately comprehend all the good sense of adultery by mutual consent, and his (Alexandrovitch) eyes expressed this uncertainty; but the lawyer promptly came to his (lawyer) assistance.

'' People cannot go on living together--here you have a fact. And if both are agreed about it, the details and formalities become a matter of no importance.

And at the same time this is the simplest and most certain method. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch fully understood now. But he (Alexandrovitch) had religious scruples, which hindered the execution of such a plan.

'' That is out of the question in the present case,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. '' Only one alternative is possible: undesigned detection, supported by letters which I have.

At the mention of letters the lawyer pursed up his (lawyer) lips, and gave utterance to a thin little compassionate and contemptuous sound.

Kindly consider,'' he (lawyer) began,

``cases of that kind are, as you are aware, under ecclesiastical jurisdiction; the reverend fathers are fond of going into the minutest details in cases of that kind,'' (he)
he (reverend) said with a smile, which betrayed his (reverend) sympathy with the reverend fathers' taste.

Letters may, of course, be a partial confirmation; but detection in the fact there must be of the most direct kind, that is, by eyewitnesses.

In fact, if you do me the honor to intrust your confidence to me, you will do well to leave me the choice of the measures to be employed.

Alexey Alexandrovitch began, suddenly turning white; but at that moment the lawyer rose and again went to the door to speak to the intruding clerk.

'' '' '' If one wants the result, one must admit the means. '' '' If it is so... '' ''

Tell her (clerk) we don't haggle over fees! '' he (lawyer) said, and returned to Alexey Alexandrovitch. On his (Alexandrovitch) way back he (Alexandrovitch) caught unobserved another moth.

'' Nice state my rep curtains will be in by the summer! '' he (Alexandrovitch) thought, frowning. '' And so you were saying?...

'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. '' I will communicate my decision to you by letter,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, getting up, and he (Alexandrovitch) clutched at the table.

After standing a moment in silence, he (Alexandrovitch) said:

``From your words I may consequently conclude that a divorce may be obtained?

I would ask you to let me know what are your terms.'' (he)

``It may be obtained if you give me complete liberty of action,'' (the lawyer)
said the lawyer, not answering his (lawyer) question.

'' When can I reckon on receiving information from you? '' he (lawyer) asked, moving towards the door, his (lawyer) eyes and his (lawyer) varnished boots shining.

Your answer as to whether you will undertake to conduct the case, and on what terms, you will be so good as to communicate to me.

The lawyer bowed respectfully, let his (lawyer) client out of the door, and, left alone, gave himself up to his (lawyer) sense of amusement.

He (lawyer) felt so mirthful that, contrary to his (lawyer) rules, he (lawyer) made a reduction in his (lawyer) terms to the haggling lady, and gave up catching moths, finally deciding that next winter he (lawyer) must have the furniture covered with velvet, like Sigonin's.

Chapter 6 Alexey Alexandrovitch had gained a brilliant victory at the sitting of the Commission of the 17th of August, but in the sequel this victory cut the ground from under his (Alexandrovitch) feet.

The new commission for the inquiry into the condition of the native tribes in all its branches had been formed and despatched to its destination with an unusual speed and energy inspired by Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' In a week's time. ''

``Very good. '' (unknown)
Within three months a report was presented. The condition of the native tribes was investigated in its political, administrative, economic, ethnographic, material, and religious aspects.

To all these questions there were answers admirably stated, and answers admitting no shade of doubt, since they were not a product of human thought, always liable to error, but were all the product of official activity.

The answers were all based on official data furnished by governors and heads of churches, and founded on the reports of district magistrates and ecclesiastical superintendents, founded in their turn on the reports of parochial overseers and parish priests; and so all of these answers were unhesitating and certain.

All such questions as, for instance, of the cause of failure of crops, of the adherence of certain tribes to their ancient beliefs, etc.-- questions which, but for the convenient intervention of the official machine, are not, and cannot be solved for ages-- received full, unhesitating solution.

But Stremov, who had felt stung to the quick at the last sitting, had, on the reception of the commission's report, resorted to tactics which Alexey Alexandrovitch had not anticipated.

Stremov, carrying with him (Alexandrovitch) several members, went over to Alexey Alexandrovitch's side, and not contenting himself with warmly defending the measure proposed by Karenin, proposed other more extreme measures in the same direction.

These measures, still further exaggerated in opposition to what was Alexey Alexandrovitch's fundamental idea, were passed by the commission, and then the aim of Stremov's tactics became apparent.

Carried to an extreme, the measures seemed at once to be so absurd that the highest authorities, and public opinion, and intellectual ladies, and the newspapers, all at the same time fell foul of them, expressing their indignation both with the measures and their nominal father, Alexey Alexandrovitch.

And this solution was in favor of Alexey Alexandrovitch's contention. Stremov drew back, affecting to have blindly followed Karenin, and to be astounded and distressed at what had been done.

This meant the defeat of Alexey Alexandrovitch. But in spite of failing health, in spite of his (Alexandrovitch) domestic griefs, he (Alexandrovitch) did not give in.

Some members, with Stremov at their head, justified their mistake on the ground that they had put faith in the commission of revision, instituted by Alexey Alexandrovitch, and maintained that the report of the commission was rubbish, and simply so much waste paper.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, with a following of those who saw the danger of so revolutionary an attitude to official documents, persisted in upholding the statements obtained by the revising commission.

In consequence of this, in the higher spheres, and even in society, all was chaos, and although everyone was interested, no one could tell whether the native tribes really were becoming impoverished and ruined, or whether they were in a flourishing condition.

The position of Alexey Alexandrovitch, owing to this, and partly owing to the contempt lavished on him (Alexandrovitch) for his (Alexandrovitch) wife's infidelity, became very precarious.

To the astonishment of the commission, he (Alexandrovitch) announced that he (Alexandrovitch) should ask permission to go himself to investigate the question on the spot.

There was a split in the commission. And in this position he (Alexandrovitch) took an important resolution. And having obtained permission, Alexey Alexandrovitch prepared to set off to these remote provinces.

Alexey Alexandrovitch's departure made a great sensation, the more so as just before he (Alexandrovitch) started he (Alexandrovitch) officially returned the posting-fares allowed him (Alexandrovitch) for twelve horses, to drive to his (Alexandrovitch) destination.

'' I think it very noble,'' Betsy said about this to the Princess Myakaya. '' Why take money for posting-horses when everyone knows that there are railways everywhere now?

It's all very well for you to talk,'' said she (Betsy),

``when you have I don't know how many millions; but I am very glad when my husband goes on a revising tour in the summer.

It's very good for him (husband) and pleasant traveling about, and it's a settled arrangement for me to keep a carriage and coachman on the money.

'' (she)

But Princess Myakaya did not agree, and the Princess Tverskaya's opinion annoyed her (Princess) indeed. '' '' On his (husband) way to the remote provinces Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped for three days at Moscow.

At the crossroads by Gazetoy Place, where there are always crowds of carriages and sledges, Alexey Alexandrovitch suddenly heard his (Alexandrovitch) name called out in such a loud and cheerful voice that he (Alexandrovitch) could not help looking round.

At the corner of the pavement, in a short, stylish overcoat and a low-crowned fashionable hat, jauntily askew, with a smile that showed a gleam of white teeth and red lips, stood Stepan Arkadyevitch, radiant, young, and beaming.

The day after his (Alexandrovitch) arrival he (Alexandrovitch) was driving back from calling on the governor-general. He (Alexandrovitch) called him (Alexandrovitch) vigorously and urgently, and insisted on his (Alexandrovitch) stopping.

He (Alexandrovitch) had one arm on the window of a carriage that was stopping at the corner, and out of the window were thrust the heads of a lady in a velvet hat, and two children.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was smiling and beckoning to his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law. The lady smiled a kindly smile too, and she (lady) too waved her (lady) hand to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

It was Dolly with her (lady) children. Alexey Alexandrovitch did not want to see anyone in Moscow, and least of all his (Alexandrovitch) wife's brother.

He (Alexandrovitch) raised his (Alexandrovitch) hat and would have driven on, but Stepan Arkadyevitch told his (Alexandrovitch) coachman to stop, and ran across the snow to him (Alexandrovitch).

I was at Dussot's yesterday and saw `Karenin' on the visitors' list, but it never entered my head that it was you,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, sticking his (Karenin) head in at the window of the carriage,

``or I should have looked you up.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Well, what a shame not to have let us know! Been here long? I am glad to see you! ''

he (Karenin) said, knocking one foot against the other to shake the snow off. '' What a shame of you not to let us know!

'' he (Karenin) repeated. '' I had no time; I am very busy,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch responded dryly.

``Come to my wife, she (wife) does so want to see you.

Alexey Alexandrovitch unfolded the rug in which his (Alexandrovitch) frozen feet were wrapped, and getting out of his (Alexandrovitch) carriage made his (Alexandrovitch) way over the snow to Darya Alexandrovna.

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

'' Why, Alexey Alexandrovitch, what are you cutting us like this for?'' said Dolly, smiling. '' I was very busy.

Delighted to see you! '' he (Alexandrovitch) said in a tone clearly indicating that he (Alexandrovitch) was annoyed by it. '' How are you?''

``Tell me, how is my darling Anna?'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch mumbled something and would have gone on. But Stepan Arkadyevitch stopped him (Alexandrovitch).

'' I tell you what we'll do tomorrow. Dolly, ask him (Alexandrovitch) to dinner. We'll ask Koznishev and Pestsov, so as to entertain him (Koznishev) with our Moscow celebrities.''

``Yes, please, do come,'' (Dolly)
said Dolly;
``we will expect you at five, or six o'clock, if you like. How is my darling Anna?

How long...'' (Dolly)

``She (Anna) is quite well,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch mumbled, frowning.
``Delighted!'' (he)
and he (Alexandrovitch) moved away towards his (Alexandrovitch) carriage. '' You will come?''

Dolly called after him (Alexandrovitch). Alexey Alexandrovitch said something which Dolly could not catch in the noise of the moving carriages. ''

I shall come round tomorrow!'' Stepan Arkadyevitch shouted to him (Alexandrovitch). Alexey Alexandrovitch got into his (Alexandrovitch) carriage, and buried himself in it so as neither to see nor be seen.

'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch to his (Alexandrovitch) wife, and glancing at his (Alexandrovitch) watch, he (Alexandrovitch) made a motion of his (Alexandrovitch) hand before his (Alexandrovitch) face, indicating a caress to his (Alexandrovitch) wife and children, and walked jauntily along the pavement.

'' Queer fish!

``Stiva! Stiva! '' (Dolly)
Dolly called, reddening. He (Alexandrovitch) turned round. '' I must get coats, you know, for Grisha and Tanya.

Give me the money. ''

``Never mind; you tell them I'll pay the bill!'' (he)
and he (Alexandrovitch) vanished, nodding genially to an acquaintance who drove by.

Stepan Arkadyevitch went to the Grand Theater to a rehearsal of the ballet, and gave Masha Tchibisova, a pretty dancing-girl whom he (Alexandrovitch) had just taken under his (Alexandrovitch) protection, the coral necklace he (Alexandrovitch) had promised her (Tchibisova) the evening before, and behind the scenes in the dim daylight of the theater, managed to kiss her (Tchibisova) pretty little face, radiant over her (Tchibisova) present.

Chapter 7 The next day was Sunday. Besides the gift of the necklace he (Alexandrovitch) wanted to arrange with her (Tchibisova) about meeting after the ballet.

After explaining that he (Alexandrovitch) could not come at the beginning of the ballet, he (Alexandrovitch) promised he (Alexandrovitch) would come for the last act and take her (Tchibisova) to supper.

From the theater Stepan Arkadyevitch drove to Ohotny Row, selected himself the fish and asparagus for dinner, and by twelve o'clock was at Dussot's, where he (Alexandrovitch) had to see three people, luckily all staying at the same hotel:

Levin, who had recently come back from abroad and was staying there; the new head of his (Levin) department, who had just been promoted to that position, and had come on a tour of revision to Moscow; and his (Levin) brother-in-law, Karenin, whom he (Levin) must see, so as to be sure of bringing him (Levin) to dinner.

Stepan Arkadyevitch liked dining, but still better he (Levin) liked to give a dinner, small, but very choice, both as regards the food and drink and as regards the selection of guests.

There would be fresh perch, asparagus, and la pi√®ce de resistance -- first-rate, but quite plain, roast beef, and wines to suit: so much for the eating and drinking.

Kitty and Levin would be of the party, and that this might not be obtrusively evident, there would be a girl cousin too, and young Shtcherbatsky, and la pi√®ce de resistance among the guests--Sergey Koznishev and Alexey Alexandrovitch.

He (Alexandrovitch) particularly liked the program of that day's dinner. Sergey Ivanovitch was a Moscow man, and a philosopher; Alexey Alexandrovitch a Petersburger, and a practical politician.

He (Alexandrovitch) was asking, too, the well-known eccentric enthusiast, Pestsov, a liberal, a great talker, a musician, an historian, and the most delightfully youthful person of fifty, who would be a sauce or garnish for Koznishev and Karenin.

The second installment for the forest had been received from the merchant and was not yet exhausted; Dolly had been very amiable and goodhumored of late, and the idea of the dinner pleased Stepan Arkadyevitch from every point of view.

There were two circumstances a little unpleasant, but these two circumstances were drowned in the sea of good-humored gaiety which flooded the soul of Stepan Arkadyevitch.

These two circumstances were: first, that on meeting Alexey Alexandrovitch the day before in the street he (Alexandrovitch) had noticed that he (Alexandrovitch) was cold and reserved with him (Alexandrovitch), and putting the expression of Alexey Alexandrovitch's face and the fact that he (Alexandrovitch) had not come to see them or let them know of his (Alexandrovitch) arrival with the rumors he (Alexandrovitch) had heard about Anna and Vronsky, Stepan Arkadyevitch guessed that something was wrong between the husband and wife.

The other slightly disagreeable fact was that the new head of his (husband) department, like all new heads, had the reputation already of a terrible person, who got up at six o'clock in the morning, worked like a horse, and insisted on his (husband) subordinates working in the same way.

Moreover, this new head had the further reputation of being a bear in his (husband) manners, and was, according to all reports, a man of a class in all respects the opposite of that to which his (husband) predecessor had belonged, and to which Stepan Arkadyevitch had hitherto belonged himself.

On the previous day Stepan Arkadyevitch had appeared at the office in a uniform, and the new chief had been very affable and had talked to him (chief) as to an acquaintance.

He (chief) would provoke them and set them off. He (chief) was in the most light-hearted mood. That was one disagreeable thing. Consequently Stepan Arkadyevitch deemed it his (chief) duty to call upon him (chief) in his (chief) non-official dress.

The thought that the new chief might not tender him (chief) a warm reception was the other unpleasant thing. But Stepan Arkadyevitch instinctively felt that everything would come round all right.

'' They're all people, all men, like us poor sinners; why be nasty and quarrelsome? '' he (chief) thought as he (chief) went into the hotel.

Good-day, Vassily,'' he (chief) said, walking into the corridor with his (chief) hat cocked on one side, and addressing a footman he (chief) knew;

``why, you've let your whiskers grow!

'' (he)

Levin, number seven, eh? Take me up, please. And find out whether Count Anitchkin'' -LRB-this was the new head-RRB-
``is receiving.'' (Vassily/Vassily Fedorovitch)

'' Yes, sir,'' Vassily responded, smiling. '' You've not been to see us for a long while.''

``I was here yesterday, but at the other entrance.

Levin was standing with a peasant from Tver in the middle of the room, measuring a fresh bearskin, when Stepan Arkadyevitch went in.

Is this number seven? '' (unknown)

'' What! you killed him (Levin)? '' cried Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Well done! A she-bear? How are you, Arhip!''

He (Levin) shook hands with the peasant and sat down on the edge of a chair, without taking off his (Levin) coat and hat.

'' Come, take off your coat and stay a little,'' said Levin, taking his (Levin) hat. '' No, I haven't time; I've only looked in for a tiny second,'' answered Stepan Arkadyevitch.

He (Levin) threw open his (Levin) coat, but afterwards did take it off, and sat on for a whole hour, talking to Levin about hunting and the most intimate subjects.

``Come, tell me, please, what you did abroad? Where have you been?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, when the peasant had gone. ''

Oh, I stayed in Germany, in Prussia, in France, and in England-- not in the capitals, but in the manufacturing towns, and saw a great deal that was new to me.

And I'm glad I went. '' '' Yes, I knew your idea of the solution of the labor question. ''

``Not a bit: in Russia there can be no labor question.

In Russia the question is that of the relation of the working people to the land; though the question exists there too--but there it's a matter of repairing what's been ruined, while with us...

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Stepan Arkadyevitch listened attentively to Levin. '' Yes, yes!'' he (Levin) said,
``it's very possible you're right. But I'm glad you're in good spirits, and are hunting bears, and working, and interested.

Shtcherbatsky told me another story--he (Shtcherbatsky) met you--that you were in such a depressed state, talking of nothing but death...'' (he)

'' Well, what of it?

I've not given up thinking of death,'' said Levin. '' It's true that it's high time I was dead; and that all this is nonsense.

I do value my idea and my work awfully; but in reality only consider this: all this world of ours is nothing but a speck of mildew, which has grown up on a tiny planet.

It's the truth I'm telling you. And for us to suppose we can have something great--ideas, work--it's all dust and ashes.''

'' But all that's as old as the hills, my boy!''

``It is old; but do you know, when you grasp this fully, then somehow everything becomes of no consequence.

When you understand that you will die tomorrow, if not today, and nothing will be left, then everything is so unimportant!

And I consider my idea very important, but it turns out really to be as unimportant too, even if it were carried out, as doing for that bear.

So one goes on living, amusing oneself with hunting, with work--anything so as not to think of death!'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled a subtle affectionate smile as he (you) listened to Levin.

'' Well, of course! Here you've come round to my point. Do you remember you attacked me for seeking enjoyment in life?

Don't be so severe, O moralist!'' '' No; all the same, what's fine in life is... '' Levin hesitated-- '' oh, I don't know.

All I know is that we shall soon be dead.''

``Why so soon? '' (unknown)
'' And do you know, there's less charm in life, when one thinks of death, but there's more peace.

''

``On the contrary, the finish is always the best. But I must be going,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting up for the tenth time.

'' Oh, no, stay a bit!'' said Levin, keeping him (Levin). '' Now, when shall we see each other again? I'm going tomorrow.

''

``I'm a nice person! Why, that's just what I came for! You simply must come to dinner with us today.

Your brother's coming, and Karenin, my brother-in-law. '' (unknown)

``You don't mean to say he (Karenin)'s here?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, and he (Levin) wanted to inquire about Kitty.

He (Levin) had heard at the beginning of the winter that she (Kitty) was at Petersburg with her (Kitty) sister, the wife of the diplomat, and he (diplomat) did not know whether she (Kitty) had come back or not; but he (diplomat) changed his (diplomat) mind and did not ask.

'' Whether she (Kitty)'s coming or not, I don't care,'' he (diplomat) said to himself. '' So you'll come?''

``Of course. '' (unknown)
``At five o'clock, then, and not evening dress.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

And Stepan Arkadyevitch got up and went down below to the new head of his (diplomat) department. Instinct had not misled Stepan Arkadyevitch.

The terrible new head turned out to be an extremely amenable person, and Stepan Arkadyevitch lunched with him (diplomat) and stayed on, so that it was four o'clock before he (diplomat) got to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

He (diplomat) had two pieces of business before him (diplomat) that morning; first, to receive and send on a deputation from the native tribes which was on its way to Petersburg, and now at Moscow; secondly, to write the promised letter to the lawyer.

The deputation, though it had been summoned at Alexey Alexandrovitch's instigation, was not without its discomforting and even dangerous aspect, and he (Alexandrovitch) was glad he (Alexandrovitch) had found it in Moscow.

Chapter 8 Alexey Alexandrovitch, on coming back from church service, had spent the whole morning indoors. The members of this deputation had not the slightest conception of their duty and the part they were to play.

They na√Øvely believed that it was their business to lay before the commission their needs and the actual condition of things, and to ask assistance of the government, and utterly failed to grasp that some of their statements and requests supported the contention of the enemy's side, and so spoiled the whole business.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was busily engaged with them for a long while, drew up a program for them from which they were not to depart, and on dismissing them wrote a letter to Petersburg for the guidance of the deputation.

She (enemy) was a specialist in the matter of deputations, and no one knew better than she (enemy) how to manage them, and put them in the way they should go.

He (specialist) had his (specialist) chief support in this affair in the Countess Lidia Ivanovna. Having completed this task, Alexey Alexandrovitch wrote the letter to the lawyer.

Without the slightest hesitation he (Alexandrovitch) gave him (Alexandrovitch) permission to act as he (Alexandrovitch) might judge best. In the letter he (Alexandrovitch) enclosed three of Vronsky's notes to Anna, which were in the portfolio he (Alexandrovitch) had taken away.

Since Alexey Alexandrovitch had left home with the intention of not returning to his (Alexandrovitch) family again, and since he (Alexandrovitch) had been at the lawyer's and had spoken, though only to one man, of his (man) intention, since especially he (man) had translated the matter from the world of real life to the world of ink and paper, he (man) had grown more and more used to his (man) own intention, and by now distinctly perceived the feasibility of its execution.

He (man) was sealing the envelope to the lawyer, when he (man) heard the loud tones of Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice. Stepan Arkadyevitch was disputing with Alexey Alexandrovitch's servant, and insisting on being announced.

I will inform him (Alexandrovitch) at once of my position in regard to his (Alexandrovitch) sister, and explain why it is I can't dine with him (Alexandrovitch).''

'' No matter,'' thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, ``so much the better.

``Come in! '' (he)
he (Alexandrovitch) said aloud, collecting his (Alexandrovitch) papers, and putting them in the blotting-paper.

'' responded Stepan Arkadyevitch's voice, addressing the servant, who had refused to let him (servant) in, and taking off his (servant) coat as he (servant) went, Oblonsky walked into the room.

'' There, you see, you're talking nonsense, and he (servant)'s at home! '' Well, I'm awfully glad I've found you! So I hope...

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch began cheerfully. '' I cannot come,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch said coldly, standing and not asking his (Alexandrovitch) visitor to sit down.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had thought to pass at once into those frigid relations in which he (Alexandrovitch) ought to stand with the brother of a wife against whom he (Alexandrovitch) was beginning a suit for divorce.

But he (Alexandrovitch) had not taken into account the ocean of kindliness brimming over in the heart of Stepan Arkadyevitch. Stepan Arkadyevitch opened wide his (Alexandrovitch) clear, shining eyes.

'' Why can't you? What do you mean? '' he (Alexandrovitch) asked in perplexity, speaking in French. '' Oh, but it's a promise.

``I want to tell you that I can't dine at your house, because the terms of relationship which have existed between us must cease.

And we're all counting on you.'' (unknown)

''
``How? How do you mean? What for? '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch with a smile.

But, before Alexey Alexandrovitch had time to finish his (Alexandrovitch) sentence, Stepan Arkadyevitch was behaving not at all as he (Alexandrovitch) had expected.

'' Because I am beginning an action for divorce against your sister, my wife. I ought to have... '' He (Alexandrovitch) groaned and sank into an armchair.

'' No, Alexey Alexandrovitch! What are you saying? '' cried Oblonsky, and his (Alexandrovitch) suffering was apparent in his (Alexandrovitch) face. '' It is so.''

Alexey Alexandrovitch sat down, feeling that his (Alexandrovitch) words had not had the effect he (Alexandrovitch) anticipated, and that it would be unavoidable for him (Alexandrovitch) to explain his (Alexandrovitch) position, and that, whatever explanations he (Alexandrovitch) might make, his (Alexandrovitch) relations with his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law would remain unchanged.

'' Excuse me, I can't, I can't believe it!'' '' Yes, I am brought to the painful necessity of seeking a divorce,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said.

'' I will say one thing, Alexey Alexandrovitch. I know you for an excellent, upright man; I know Anna-- excuse me,

I can't change my opinion of her (Anna)--for a good, an excellent woman; and so, excuse me, I cannot believe it. There is some misunderstanding,'' said he (Alexandrovitch).

'' Oh, if it were merely a misunderstanding!...''

``Pardon, I understand,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
interposed Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' But of course.... One thing: you must not act in haste.

``I am not acting in haste,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch said coldly,
``but one cannot ask advice of anyone in such a matter.

You must not, you must not act in haste!'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

I have quite made up my mind.'' '' This is awful!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' I would do one thing, Alexey Alexandrovitch. I beseech you, do it! '' he (Alexandrovitch) said. '' No action has yet been taken, if I understand rightly.

Before you take advice, see my wife, talk to her (wife). She (wife) loves Anna like a sister, she (wife) loves you, and she (wife)'s a wonderful woman.

For God's sake, talk to her (wife)! Do me that favor, I beseech you!'' Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, and Stepan Arkadyevitch looked at him (Alexandrovitch) sympathetically, without interrupting his (Alexandrovitch) silence.

'' You will go to see her (wife)?''

``I don't know. That was just why I have not been to see you.

Allow me to believe that apart from our connection you have for me, at least in part, the same friendly feeling I have always had for you...and sincere esteem,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pressing his (Alexandrovitch) hand.

Even if your worst suppositions were correct, I don't--and never would--take on myself to judge either side, and I see no reason why our relations should be affected.

I imagine our relations must change. ''

``Why so? I don't see that. '' (wife)
But now, do this, come and see my wife.''

'' Well, we look at the matter differently,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch coldly. '' However, we won't discuss it.'' '' No; why shouldn't you come today to dine, anyway?

My wife's expecting you. Please, do come. And, above all, talk it over with her (wife). She (wife)'s a wonderful woman. For God's sake, on my knees, I implore you!''

And, anxious to change the conversation, he (God) inquired about what interested them both--the new head of Stepan Arkadyevitch's department, a man not yet old, who had suddenly been promoted to so high a position.

``If you so much wish it, I will come,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, sighing. Alexey Alexandrovitch had previously felt no liking for Count Anitchkin, and had always differed from him (Alexandrovitch) in his (Alexandrovitch) opinions.

But now, from a feeling readily comprehensible to officials--that hatred felt by one who has suffered a defeat in the service for one who has received a promotion, he (Alexandrovitch) could not endure him (Alexandrovitch).

'' Well, have you seen him (Alexandrovitch)?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch with a malignant smile. '' Of course; he (Alexandrovitch) was at our sitting yesterday.

He (Alexandrovitch) seems to know his (Alexandrovitch) work capitally, and to be very energetic.'' '' Yes, but what is his (Alexandrovitch) energy directed to?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' Is he (Alexandrovitch) aiming at doing anything, or simply undoing what's been done? It's the great misfortune of our government--this paper administration, of which he (Alexandrovitch)'s a worthy representative.''

``Really, I don't know what fault one could find with him (Alexandrovitch). His (Alexandrovitch) policy I don't know, but one thing--he (Alexandrovitch)'s a very nice fellow,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
answered Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' I've just been seeing him (Alexandrovitch), and he (Alexandrovitch)'s really a capital fellow. We lunched together, and I taught him (Alexandrovitch) how to make, you know that drink, wine and oranges.

It's so cooling. And it's a wonder he (Alexandrovitch) didn't know it. He (Alexandrovitch) liked it awfully. No, really he (Alexandrovitch)'s a capital fellow.

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch glanced at his (Alexandrovitch) watch. '' Why, good heavens, it's four already, and I've still to go to Dolgovushin's!

The way in which Alexey Alexandrovitch saw his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law out was very different from the manner in which he (Alexandrovitch) had met him (Alexandrovitch).

So please come round to dinner. You can't imagine how you will grieve my wife and me. '' '' I've promised, and I'll come,'' he (Alexandrovitch) answered wearily.

'' Believe me, I appreciate it, and I hope you won't regret it,'' answered Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling. And, putting on his (Alexandrovitch) coat as he (Alexandrovitch) went, he (Alexandrovitch) patted the footman on the head, chuckled, and went out.

'' At five o'clock, and not evening dress, please,'' he (Alexandrovitch) shouted once more, turning at the door. Chapter 9 It was past five, and several guests had already arrived, before the host himself got home.

He (Alexandrovitch) went in together with Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev and Pestsov, who had reached the street door at the same moment. These were the two leading representatives of the Moscow intellectuals, as Oblonsky had called them.

They respected each other, but were in complete and hopeless disagreement upon almost every subject, not because they belonged to opposite parties, but precisely because they were of the same party -LRB-their enemies refused to see any distinction between their views-RRB-; but, in that party, each had his (Koznishev) own special shade of opinion.

And since no difference is less easily overcome than the difference of opinion about semi-abstract questions, they never agreed in any opinion, and had long, indeed, been accustomed to jeer without anger, each at the other's incorrigible aberrations.

Both were men respected for their character and their intelligence. They were just going in at the door, talking of the weather, when Stepan Arkadyevitch overtook them.

In the drawing room there were already sitting Prince Alexander Dmitrievitch Shtcherbatsky, young Shtcherbatsky, Turovtsin, Kitty, and Karenin. Stepan Arkadyevitch saw immediately that things were not going well in the drawing-room without him (Karenin).

Darya Alexandrovna, in her (Kitty) best gray silk gown, obviously worried about the children, who were to have their dinner by themselves in the nursery, and by her (Kitty) husband's absence, was not equal to the task of making the party mix without him (husband).

All were sitting like so many priests' wives on a visit -LRB-so the old prince expressed it-RRB-, obviously wondering why they were there, and pumping up remarks simply to avoid being silent.

Turovtsin--good, simple man--felt unmistakably a fish out of water, and the smile with which his (man) thick lips greeted Stepan Arkadyevitch said, as plainly as words:

``Well, old boy, you have popped me down in a learned set!

The old prince sat in silence, his (prince) bright little eyes watching Karenin from one side, and Stepan Arkadyevitch saw that he (prince) had already formed a phrase to sum up that politician of whom guests were invited to partake as though he (prince) were a sturgeon.

Kitty was looking at the door, calling up all her (Kitty) energies to keep her (Kitty) from blushing at the entrance of Konstantin Levin.

Young Shtcherbatsky, who had not been introduced to Karenin, was trying to look as though he (Karenin) were not in the least conscious of it.

Karenin himself had followed the Petersburg fashion for a dinner with ladies and was wearing evening dress and a white tie.

Stepan Arkadyevitch saw by his (Karenin) face that he (Karenin) had come simply to keep his (Karenin) promise, and was performing a disagreeable duty in being present at this gathering.

A drinking party now, or the Ch√¢teau des Fleurs , would be more in my line!'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

He (Karenin) was indeed the person chiefly responsible for the chill benumbing all the guests before Stepan Arkadyevitch came in.

On entering the drawing room Stepan Arkadyevitch apologized, explaining that he (Karenin) had been detained by that prince, who was always the scapegoat for all his (prince) absences and unpunctualities, and in one moment he (prince) had made all the guests acquainted with each other, and, bringing together Alexey Alexandrovitch and Sergey Koznishev, started them on a discussion of the Russification of Poland, into which they immediately plunged with Pestsov.

Slapping Turovtsin on the shoulder, he (Alexandrovitch) whispered something comic in his (Alexandrovitch) ear, and set him (Alexandrovitch) down by his (Alexandrovitch) wife and the old prince.

In a moment he (Alexandrovitch) had so kneaded together the social dough that the drawing room became very lively, and there was a merry buzz of voices.

Then he (Alexandrovitch) told Kitty she (Kitty) was looking very pretty that evening, and presented Shtcherbatsky to Karenin. Konstantin Levin was the only person who had not arrived.

But this was so much the better, as going into the dining room, Stepan Arkadyevitch found to his (Levin) horror that the port and sherry had been procured from Depr√®, and not from Levy, and, directing that the coachman should be sent off as speedily as possible to Levy's, he (Levy) was going back to the drawing room.

In the dining room he (Levy) was met by Konstantin Levin. '' I'm not late?''

``You can never help being late!'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, taking his (Levin) arm.

'' Have you a lot of people? Who's here? '' asked Levin, unable to help blushing, as he (Levin) knocked the snow off his (Levin) cap with his (Levin) glove.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, for all his (Levin) liberal views, was well aware that to meet Karenin was sure to be felt a flattering distinction, and so treated his (Karenin) best friends to this honor.

But at that instant Konstantin Levin was not in a condition to feel all the gratification of making such an acquaintance.

He (Levin) had not seen Kitty since that memorable evening when he (Levin) met Vronsky, not counting, that is, the moment when he (Levin) had had a glimpse of her (Kitty) on the highroad.
