'' All our own set. Kitty's here. Come along, I'll introduce you to Karenin. '' He (Karenin) had known at the bottom of his (Karenin) heart that he (Karenin) would see her (Kitty) here today.

Now when he (Karenin) heard that she (Kitty) was here, he (Karenin) was suddenly conscious of such delight, and at the same time of such dread, that his (Karenin) breath failed him (Karenin) and he (Karenin) could not utter what he (Karenin) wanted to say.

But to keep his (Karenin) thoughts free, he (Karenin) had tried to persuade himself that he (Karenin) did not know it. '' What is she (Kitty) like, what is she (Kitty) like?

Like what she (Kitty) used to be, or like what she (Kitty) was in the carriage? What if Darya Alexandrovna told the truth?

Oh, please, introduce me to Karenin,'' he (Karenin) brought out with an effort, and with a desperately determined step he (Karenin) walked into the drawing room and beheld her (Kitty).

Why shouldn't it be the truth? '' he (Karenin) thought. '' She (Kitty) was not the same as she (Kitty) used to be, nor was she (Kitty) as she (Kitty) had been in the carriage

; she (Kitty) was quite different. She (Kitty) was scared, shy, shame-faced, and still more charming from it. She (Kitty) saw him (Karenin) the very instant he (Karenin) walked into the room.

She (Kitty) was delighted, and so confused at her (Kitty) own delight that there was a moment, the moment when he (Karenin) went up to her (Kitty) sister and glanced again at her (Kitty), when she (Kitty), and he (Karenin), and Dolly, who saw it all, thought she (Dolly) would break down and would begin to cry.

She (Dolly) had been expecting him (Karenin). She (Dolly) crimsoned, turned white, crimsoned again, and grew faint, waiting with quivering lips for him (Karenin) to come to her (Dolly).

Except for the slight quiver of her (Dolly) lips and the moisture in her (Dolly) eyes that made them brighter, her (Dolly) smile was almost calm as she (Dolly) said:

``How long it is since we've seen each other!'' (she)
and with desperate determination she (Dolly) pressed his (Karenin) hand with her (Dolly) cold hand.

He (Karenin) went up to her (Dolly), bowed, and held out his (Karenin) hand without speaking. '' You've not seen me, but I've seen you,'' said Levin, with a radiant smile of happiness.

'' I saw you when you were driving from the railway station to Ergushovo. ''

``When? '' (she)
she (Dolly) asked, wondering. ''

You were driving to Ergushovo,'' said Levin, feeling as if he (Levin) would sob with the rapture that was flooding his (Levin) heart.

'' And how dared I associate a thought of anything not innocent with this touching creature? And, yes, I do believe it's true what Darya Alexandrovna told me,'' he (Levin) thought.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took him (Levin) by the arm and led him (Levin) away to Karenin. '' Let me introduce you. '' He (Karenin) mentioned their names.

'' Very glad to meet you again,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch coldly, shaking hands with Levin. '' You are acquainted?'' Stepan Arkadyevitch asked in surprise.

We spent three hours together in the train,'' said Levin smiling,

``but got out, just as in a masquerade, quite mystified--at least I was.

The men went into the dining-room and went up to a table, laid with six sorts of spirits and as many kinds of cheese, some with little silver spades and some without, caviar, herrings, preserves of various kinds, and plates with slices of French bread.

The men stood round the strong-smelling spirits and salt delicacies, and the discussion of the Russification of Poland between Koznishev, Karenin, and Pestsov died down in anticipation of dinner.

Sergey Ivanovitch was unequaled in his (Ivanovitch) skill in winding up the most heated and serious argument by some unexpected pinch of Attic salt that changed the disposition of his (Ivanovitch) opponent.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

''
``Nonsense! Come along, please,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing in the direction of the dining room. He (Ivanovitch) did this now.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had been maintaining that the Russification of Poland could only be accomplished as a result of larger measures which ought to be introduced by the Russian government.

Pestsov insisted that one country can only absorb another when it is the more densely populated. Koznishev admitted both points, but with limitations.

As they were going out of the drawing room to conclude the argument, Koznishev said, smiling:

``So, then, for the Russification of our foreign populations there is but one method--to bring up as many children as one can.

My brother and I are terribly in fault, I see. You married men, especially you, Stepan Arkadyevitch, are the real patriots: what number have you reached?

'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

he (brother) said, smiling genially at their host and holding out a tiny wine glass to him (brother). Everyone laughed, and Stepan Arkadyevitch with particular good humor.

'' Oh, yes, that's the best method! '' he (brother) said, munching cheese and filling the wine-glass with a special sort of spirit.

The conversation dropped at the jest. '' This cheese is not bad. Shall I give you some?'' said the master of the house.

'' Why, have you been going in for gymnastics again? '' he (master) asked Levin, pinching his (Levin) muscle with his (Levin) left hand.

Levin smiled, bent his (Levin) arm, and under Stepan Arkadyevitch's fingers the muscles swelled up like a sound cheese, hard as a knob of iron, through the fine cloth of the coat.

'' What biceps! A perfect Samson!''

``I imagine great strength is needed for hunting bears,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
observed Alexey Alexandrovitch, who had the mistiest notions about the chase.

He (Alexandrovitch) cut off and spread with cheese a wafer of bread fine as a spider-web. Levin smiled. '' Not at all.

Quite the contrary; a child can kill a bear,'' he (Levin) said, with a slight bow moving aside for the ladies, who were approaching the table.

You have killed a bear, I've been told!'' said Kitty, trying assiduously to catch with her (Kitty) fork a perverse mushroom that would slip away, and setting the lace quivering over her (Kitty) white arm.

'' '' Are there bears on your place? '' she (Kitty) added, turning her (Kitty) charming little head to him (Levin) and smiling. There was apparently nothing extraordinary in what she (Kitty) said, but

what unutterable meaning there was for him (Levin) in every sound, in every turn of her (Kitty) lips, her (Kitty) eyes, her (Kitty) hand as she (Kitty) said it!

There was entreaty for forgiveness, and trust in him (Levin), and tenderness-- soft, timid tenderness--and promise and hope and love for him (Levin), which he (Levin) could not but believe in and which choked him (Levin) with happiness.

It was coming back from there that I met your beaufr√®re in the train, or your beaufr√®re's brother-in-law,'' he (brother-in-law) said with a smile.

And he (brother-in-law) began telling with droll good-humor how, after not sleeping all night, he (brother-in-law) had, wearing an old fur-lined, full-skirted coat, got into Alexey Alexandrovitch's compartment.

The conductor, forgetting the proverb, would have chucked me out on account of my attire; but thereupon I began expressing my feelings in elevated language, and...

you, too,'' he (conductor) said, addressing Karenin and forgetting his (conductor) name,

``at first would have ejected me on the ground of the old coat, but afterwards you took my part, for which I am extremely grateful.'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

The rights of passengers generally to choose their seats are too ill-defined,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, rubbing the tips of his (Alexandrovitch) fingers on his (Alexandrovitch) handkerchief.

I saw you were in uncertainty about me,'' said Levin, smiling good-naturedly,

``but I made haste to plunge into intellectual conversation to smooth over the defects of my attire.

Sergey Ivanovitch, while he (Ivanovitch) kept up a conversation with their hostess, had one ear for his (Ivanovitch) brother, and he (Ivanovitch) glanced askance at him (Ivanovitch).

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

No, we've been hunting in the Tver province. '' It was an amusing meeting. '' '' '' '' '' ''

What is the matter with him (Ivanovitch) today? Why such a conquering hero? '' he (hero) thought. He (hero) did not know that Levin was feeling as though he (Levin) had grown wings.

Levin knew she (hostess) was listening to his (Levin) words and that she (hostess) was glad to listen to him (Levin). And this was the only thing that interested him (Levin).

Not in that room only, but in the whole world, there existed for him (Levin) only himself, with enormously increased importance and dignity in his (Levin) own eyes, and she (hostess).

He (Levin) felt himself on a pinnacle that made him (Levin) giddy, and far away down below were all those nice excellent Karenins, Oblonskys, and all the world.

Quite without attracting notice, without glancing at them, as though there were no other places left, Stepan Arkadyevitch put Levin and Kitty side by side.

'' Oh, you may as well sit there,'' he (Levin) said to Levin. The dinner was as choice as the china, in which Stepan Arkadyevitch was a connoisseur.

The soupe Marie-Louise was a splendid success; the tiny pies eaten with it melted in the mouth and were irreproachable. The two footmen and Matvey, in white cravats, did their duty with the dishes and wines unobtrusively, quietly, and swiftly.

The conversation, at times general and at times between individuals, never paused, and towards the end the company was so lively that the men rose from the table, without stopping speaking, and even Alexey Alexandrovitch thawed.

Chapter 10 Pestsov liked thrashing an argument out to the end, and was not satisfied with Sergey Ivanovitch's words, especially as he (Ivanovitch) felt the injustice of his (Ivanovitch) view.

I did not mean,'' he (Ivanovitch) said over the soup, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch,

``mere density of population alone, but in conjunction with fundamental ideas, and not by means of principles.'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

On the material side the dinner was a success; it was no less so on the immaterial. ''

``It seems to me,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch said languidly, and with no haste,
``that that's the same thing.

In my opinion, influence over another people is only possible to the people which has the higher development, which...'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

'' But that's just the question,'' Pestsov broke in in his (Alexandrovitch) bass.

He (Alexandrovitch) was always in a hurry to speak, and seemed always to put his (Alexandrovitch) whole soul into what he (Alexandrovitch) was saying.

'' In what are we to make higher development consist? The English, the French, the Germans, which is at the highest stage of development?

Which of them will nationalize the other? We see the Rhine provinces have been turned French, but the Germans are not at a lower stage!

``I fancy that the greater influence is always on the side of true civilization,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, slightly lifting his (Alexandrovitch) eyebrows.

'' he (Alexandrovitch) shouted. '' There is another law at work there.'' '' But what are we to lay down as the outward signs of true civilization?'' said Pestsov.

'' I imagine such signs are generally very well known,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' But are they fully known? '' Sergey Ivanovitch put in with a subtle smile.

It is the accepted view now that real culture must be purely classical; but we see most intense disputes on each side of the question, and there is no denying that the opposite camp has strong points in its favor.

I am not expressing my own opinion of either form of culture,'' Sergey Ivanovitch said, holding out his (Ivanovitch) glass with a smile of condescension, as to a child.

'' ''

``You are for classics, Sergey Ivanovitch. Will you take red wine?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' '' I only say that both sides have strong arguments to support them,'' he (Ivanovitch) went on, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' My sympathies are classical from education, but in this discussion I am personally unable to arrive at a conclusion. I see no distinct grounds for classical studies being given a preeminence over scientific studies.''

``The natural sciences have just as great an educational value,'' (unknown)
put in Pestsov.
``Take astronomy, take botany, or zoology with its system of general principles.'' (me)

``It seems to me that one must admit that the very process of studying the forms of language has a peculiarly favorable influence on intellectual development.

Moreover, it cannot be denied that the influence of the classical authors is in the highest degree moral, while, unfortunately, with the study of the natural sciences are associated the false and noxious doctrines which are the curse of our day.

``I cannot quite agree with that,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
responded Alexey Alexandrovitch '' Sergey Ivanovitch would have said something, but Pestsov interrupted him (Alexandrovitch) in his (Alexandrovitch) rich bass.

He (Alexandrovitch) began warmly contesting the justice of this view. Sergey Ivanovitch waited serenely to speak, obviously with a convincing reply ready.

But,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling subtly, and addressing Karenin,

``One must allow that to weigh all the advantages and disadvantages of classical and scientific studies is a difficult task, and the question which form of education was to be preferred would not have been so quickly and conclusively decided if there had not been in favor of classical education, as you expressed it just now, its moral--disons le mot--anti-nihilist influence.

If it had not been for the distinctive property of anti-nihilistic influence on the side of classical studies, we should have considered the subject more, have weighed the arguments on both sides,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

said Sergey Ivanovitch with a subtle smile,
``we should have given elbow-room to both tendencies.

But now we know that these little pills of classical learning possess the medicinal property of anti-nihilism, and we boldly prescribe them to our patients....

At Sergey Ivanovitch's little pills, everyone laughed; Turovtsin in especial roared loudly and jovially, glad at last to have found something to laugh at, all he (Ivanovitch) ever looked for in listening to conversation.

'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

''
``Undoubtedly.'' (unknown)
'' But what if they had no such medicinal property? '' he (Ivanovitch) wound up humorously. Stepan Arkadyevitch had not made a mistake in inviting Pestsov.

With Pestsov intellectual conversation never flagged for an instant. Directly Sergey Ivanovitch had concluded the conversation with his (Ivanovitch) jest, Pestsov promptly started a new one.

'' I can't agree even,'' said he (Ivanovitch),

``that the government had that aim. The government obviously is guided by abstract considerations, and remains indifferent to the influence its measures may exercise.

The education of women, for instance, would naturally be regarded as likely to be harmful, but the government opens schools and universities for women.

Alexey Alexandrovitch expressed the idea that the education of women is apt to be confounded with the emancipation of women, and that it is only so that it can be considered dangerous.

'' (he)

And the conversation at once passed to the new subject of the education of women. '' I consider, on the contrary, that the two questions are inseparably connected together,'' said Pestsov;
``it is a vicious circle.

We must not forget that the subjection of women is so complete, and dates from such ages back that we are often unwilling to recognize the gulf that separates them from us,'' (Pestsov)

said he (it).

Woman is deprived of rights from lack of education, and the lack of education results from the absence of rights. ''

You said rights,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till Pestsov had finished,

``meaning the right of sitting on juries, of voting, of presiding at official meetings, the right of entering the civil service, of sitting in parliament...

But if women, as a rare exception, can occupy such positions, it seems to me you are wrong in using the expression `rights.'

Every man will agree that in doing the duty of a juryman, a witness, a telegraph clerk, we feel we are performing duties.

'' (Pestsov)

``Undoubtedly.'' (unknown)
'' It would be more correct to say duties. And therefore it would be correct to say that women are seeking duties, and quite legitimately.

And one can but sympathize with this desire to assist in the general labor of man. ''

``Quite so,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch assented.

'' The question, I imagine, is simply whether they are fitted for such duties.''

``They will most likely be perfectly fitted,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch,
``when education has become general among them.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

``How about the proverb?'' (the prince)
said the prince, who had a long while been intent on the conversation, his (prince) little comical eyes twinkling.

We see this... '' I can say it before my daughter: her (daughter) hair is long, because her (daughter) wit is... ''

``Just what they thought of the negroes before their emancipation!'' (daughter hair)
said Pestsov angrily.

What seems strange to me is that women should seek fresh duties,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch,

``while we see, unhappily, that men usually try to avoid them.

Just as though I should seek the right to be a wet-nurse and feel injured because women are paid for the work, while no one will take me,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

said the old prince.

'' '' '' Duties are bound up with rights--power, money, honor; those are what women are seeking,'' said Pestsov. '' Turovtsin exploded in a loud roar of laughter and Sergey Ivanovitch regretted that he (Ivanovitch) had not made this comparison.

No, there was an Englishman who did suckle his (Englishman) baby on board ship,'' said the old prince, feeling this freedom in conversation permissible before his (prince) own daughters.

Even Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled. '' Yes, but a man can't nurse a baby,'' said Pestsov,

``while a woman...'' (Pestsov)
'' '' There are as many such Englishmen as there would be women officials,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch.

'' put in Stepan Arkadyevitch, thinking of Masha Tchibisova, whom he (Ivanovitch) had had in his (Ivanovitch) mind all along, in sympathizing with Pestsov and supporting him (Ivanovitch).

If the story of such a girl were thoroughly sifted, you would find she (girl) had abandoned a family--her (girl) own or a sister's, where she (girl) might have found a woman's duties,'' Darya Alexandrovna broke in unexpectedly in a tone of exasperation, probably suspecting what sort of girl Stepan Arkadyevitch was thinking of.

'' Yes, but what is a girl to do who has no family? '' '' But we take our stand on principle as the ideal,'' replied Pestsov in his (Ivanovitch) mellow bass.

'' Woman desires to have rights, to be independent, educated. She (Woman) is oppressed, humiliated by the consciousness of her (Woman) disabilities.'' ''

And I'm oppressed and humiliated that they won't engage me at the Foundling,'' the old prince said again, to the huge delight of Turovtsin, who in his (prince) mirth dropped his (prince) asparagus with the thick end in the sauce.

At first, when they were talking of the influence that one people has on another, there rose to Levin's mind what he (Levin) had to say on the subject.

But these ideas, once of such importance in his (Levin) eyes, seemed to come into his (Levin) brain as in a dream, and had now not the slightest interest for him (Levin).

It even struck him (Levin) as strange that they should be so eager to talk of what was of no use to anyone.

Kitty, too, should, one would have supposed, have been interested in what they were saying of the rights and education of women.

How often she (Kitty) had mused on the subject, thinking of her (Kitty) friend abroad, Varenka, of her (Kitty) painful state of dependence, how often she (Kitty) had wondered about herself what would become of her (Kitty) if she (Kitty) did not marry, and how often she (Kitty) had argued with her (Kitty) sister about it!

She (Kitty) and Levin had a conversation of their own, yet not a conversation, but some sort of mysterious communication, which brought them every moment nearer, and stirred in both a sense of glad terror before the unknown into which they were entering.

At first Levin, in answer to Kitty's question how he (Levin) could have seen her (Kitty) last year in the carriage, told her (Kitty) how he (Levin) had been coming home from the mowing along the highroad and had met her (Kitty).

Chapter 11 Everyone took part in the conversation except Kitty and Levin. But it did not interest her (Kitty) at all. ''

It was very, very early in the morning. You were probably only just awake. Your mother was asleep in the corner.

It was a splendid set of four horses with bells, and in a second you flashed by, and I saw you at the window--you were sitting like this, holding the strings of your cap in both hands, and thinking awfully deeply about something,'' he (Levin) said, smiling.

It was an exquisite morning. I was walking along wondering who it could be in a four-in-hand? '' How I should like to know what you were thinking about then!

'' she (mother) wondered, but seeing the smile of ecstasy these reminiscences called up, she (mother) felt that the impression she (mother) had made had been very good.

Something important?'' ``Wasn't I dreadfully untidy? She (mother) blushed and laughed with delight;

``Really I don't remember. '' (She)
``How nicely Turovtsin laughs!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, admiring his (Levin) moist eyes and shaking chest.

'' Have you known him (Levin) long? '' asked Kitty. '' Oh, everyone knows him (Levin)!'' '' And I see you think he (Levin)'s a horrid man?''

``Not horrid, but nothing in him (Levin).'' (unknown)
'' Oh, you're wrong! And you must give up thinking so directly!'' said Kitty. ''

I used to have a very poor opinion of him (Levin) too, but he (Levin), he (Levin)'s an awfully nice and wonderfully good-hearted man.

He (man) has a heart of gold. ''

``How could you find out what sort of heart he (man) has?'' (unknown)
``We are great friends.

Last winter, soon after...you came to see us,'' (she)

she (Kitty) said, with a guilty and at the same time confiding smile,
``all Dolly's children had scarlet fever, and he (man) happened to come and see her (Dolly).

And only fancy,'' (she)

she (Dolly) said in a whisper,
``he (man) felt so sorry for her (Dolly) that he (man) stayed and began to help her (Dolly) look after the children.

I know him (man) very well. Yes, and for three weeks he (man) stopped with them, and looked after the children like a nurse.'' (she)

Yes, it was wonderful, noble!'' said Dolly, glancing towards Turovtsin, who had become aware they were talking of him (man), and smiling gently to him (man).

``I am telling Konstantin Dmitrievitch about Turovtsin in the scarlet fever,'' (she)
she (Dolly) said, bending over to her (Dolly) sister. '' Levin glanced once more at Turovtsin, and wondered how it was he (Levin) had not realized all this man's goodness before.

'' I'm sorry , I'm sorry, and I'll never think ill of people again! '' he (Levin) said gaily, genuinely expressing what he (Levin) felt at the moment.

Chapter 12 Connected with the conversation that had sprung up on the rights of women there were certain questions as to the inequality of rights in marriage improper to discuss before the ladies.

Pestsov had several times during dinner touched upon these questions, but Sergey Ivanovitch and Stepan Arkadyevitch carefully drew him (Ivanovitch) off them.

When they rose from the table and the ladies had gone out, Pestsov did not follow them, but addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch, began to expound the chief ground of inequality.

The inequality in marriage, in his (Alexandrovitch) opinion, lay in the fact that the infidelity of the wife and the infidelity of the husband are punished unequally, both by the law and by public opinion.

No, I don't smoke,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch answered calmly, and as though purposely wishing to show that he (Alexandrovitch) was not afraid of the subject, he (Alexandrovitch) turned to Pestsov with a chilly smile.

I imagine that such a view has a foundation in the very nature of things,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, and would have gone on to the drawing room.

Stepan Arkadyevitch went hurriedly up to Alexey Alexandrovitch and offered him (Alexandrovitch) a cigar. '' '' But at this point Turovtsin broke suddenly and unexpectedly into the conversation, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch.

You heard, perhaps, about Pryatchnikov?'' said Turovtsin, warmed up by the champagne he (Alexandrovitch) had drunk, and long waiting for an opportunity to break the silence that had weighed on him (Alexandrovitch).

Vasya Pryatchnikov,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, with a good-natured smile on his (Alexandrovitch) damp, red lips, addressing himself principally to the most important guest, Alexey Alexandrovitch, ``they told me today he (Alexandrovitch) fought a duel with Kvitsky at Tver, and has killed him (Alexandrovitch).

Just as it always seems that one bruises oneself on a sore place, so Stepan Arkadyevitch felt now that the conversation would by ill luck fall every moment on Alexey Alexandrovitch's sore spot.

He (Alexandrovitch) would again have got his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law away, but Alexey Alexandrovitch himself inquired, with curiosity:

``What did Pryatchnikov fight about?'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
``His (Alexandrovitch) wife.

'' (a man)

'' '' Acted like a man, he (Alexandrovitch) did! Called him (Alexandrovitch) out and shot him (Alexandrovitch)!''
``Ah!'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch indifferently, and lifting his (Alexandrovitch) eyebrows, he (Alexandrovitch) went into the drawing room.

'' How glad I am you have come,'' Dolly said with a frightened smile, meeting him (Alexandrovitch) in the outer drawing room.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, with the same expression of indifference, given him (Alexandrovitch) by his (Alexandrovitch) lifted eyebrows, sat down beside Darya Alexandrovna, and smiled affectedly.

'' I must talk to you. Let's sit here. '' '' It's fortunate,'' said he (Alexandrovitch),

``especially as I was meaning to ask you to excuse me, and to be taking leave.

Darya Alexandrovna was firmly convinced of Anna's innocence, and she (Anna) felt herself growing pale and her (Anna) lips quivering with anger at this frigid, unfeeling man, who was so calmly intending to ruin her (Anna) innocent friend.

Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' (he)

she (Anna) said, with desperate resolution looking him (Alexandrovitch) in the face,
``I asked you about Anna, you made me no answer.

I have to start tomorrow. '' (him)

'' How is she (Anna)?'' '' She (Anna) is, I believe, quite well, Darya Alexandrovna,'' replied Alexey Alexandrovitch, not looking at her (Anna).

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch, forgive me, I have no right... but I love Anna as a sister, and esteem her (Anna) ; I beg, I beseech you to tell me what is wrong between you?

I presume that your husband has told you the grounds on which I consider it necessary to change my attitude to Anna Arkadyevna?

what fault do you find with her (Arkadyevna)? '' Alexey Alexandrovitch frowned, and almost closing his (Alexandrovitch) eyes, dropped his (Alexandrovitch) head. '' ''

he (Alexandrovitch) said, not looking her (Arkadyevna) in the face, but eyeing with displeasure Shtcherbatsky, who was walking across the drawing room. ''

I don't believe it, I don't believe it, I can't believe it!'' Dolly said, clasping her (Dolly) bony hands before her (Dolly) with a vigorous gesture.

She (Dolly) rose quickly, and laid her (Dolly) hand on Alexey Alexandrovitch's sleeve. '' We shall be disturbed here. Come this way, please.

'' Dolly's agitation had an effect on Alexey Alexandrovitch. He (Alexandrovitch) got up and submissively followed her (Dolly) to the schoolroom. They sat down to a table covered with an oilcloth cut in slits by penknives.

'' I don't, I don't believe it!'' Dolly said, trying to catch his (Alexandrovitch) glance that avoided her (Dolly). '' One cannot disbelieve facts, Darya Alexandrovna,'' said he (Alexandrovitch), with an emphasis on the word

``facts.

'' (he)

'' But what has she (Dolly) done?'' said Darya Alexandrovna. '' What precisely has she (Dolly) done?'' '' She (Dolly) has forsaken her (Dolly) duty, and deceived her (Dolly) husband.

That's what she (Dolly) has done,'' said he (husband). '' No, no, it can't be! No, for God's sake, you are mistaken,'' said Dolly, putting her (Dolly) hands to her (Dolly) temples and closing her (Dolly) eyes.

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled coldly, with his (Alexandrovitch) lips alone, meaning to signify to her (Dolly) and to himself the firmness of his (Alexandrovitch) conviction; but this warm defense, though it could not shake him (Alexandrovitch), reopened his (Alexandrovitch) wound.

It is extremely difficult to be mistaken when a wife herself informs her (wife) husband of the fact--informs him (husband) that eight years of her (wife) life, and a son, all that's a mistake, and that she (wife) wants to begin life again,'' he (son) said angrily, with a snort.

``Darya Alexandrovna,'' (he)
he (son) said, now looking straight into Dolly's kindly, troubled face, and feeling that his (son) tongue was being loosened in spite of himself,
``I would give a great deal for doubt to be still possible.

He (son) began to speak with greater heat. '' (Dolly)

'' Anna and sin--I cannot connect them, I cannot believe it!'' When I doubted, I was miserable, but it was better than now.

I am in such doubt of everything that I even hate my son, and sometimes do not believe he (son) is my son.

When I doubted, I had hope; but now there is no hope, and still I doubt of everything. I am very unhappy.

Darya Alexandrovna had seen that as soon as he (son) glanced into her (Anna) face; and she (Anna) felt sorry for him (son), and her (Anna) faith in the innocence of her (Anna) friend began to totter.

'' He (friend) had no need to say that. '' Oh, this is awful, awful! But can it be true that you are resolved on a divorce?''

``I am resolved on extreme measures. There is nothing else for me to do.'' (she)
'' Nothing else to do, nothing else to do...

'' she (Anna) replied, with tears in her (Anna) eyes. '' Oh no, don't say nothing else to do! '' she (Anna) said. ''

What is horrible in a trouble of this kind is that one cannot, as in any other--in loss, in death--bear one's trouble in peace, but that one must act,'' said he (Anna), as though guessing her (Anna) thought.

'' One must get out of the humiliating position in which one is placed; one can't live √† trois . ''

She (Anna) was silent for a little, thinking of herself, of her (Anna) own grief in her (Anna) family, and all at once, with an impulsive movement, she (Anna) raised her (Anna) head and clasped her (Anna) hands with an imploring gesture.

``I understand, I quite understand that,'' (Dolly)
said Dolly, and her (Dolly) head sank. '' But wait a little! You are a Christian.

Think of her (Dolly)! What will become of her (Dolly), if you cast her (Dolly) off?''

``I have thought, Darya Alexandrovna, I have thought a great deal,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

His (Alexandrovitch) face turned red in patches, and his (Alexandrovitch) dim eyes looked straight before him (Alexandrovitch). Darya Alexandrovna at that moment pitied him (Alexandrovitch) with all her (Dolly) heart.

That was what I did indeed when she (Dolly) herself made known to me my humiliation; I left everything as of old.

'' I gave her (Dolly) a chance to reform, I tried to save her (Dolly). And with what result? She (Dolly) would not regard the slightest request--that she (Dolly) should observe decorum,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, getting heated.

One may save anyone who does not want to be ruined; but if the whole nature is so corrupt, so depraved, that ruin itself seems to be her (Dolly) salvation, what's to be done?''

''

``Anything, only not divorce!'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
answered Darya Alexandrovna
``But what is anything?'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
'' No, it is awful! She (Dolly) will be no one's wife, she (Dolly) will be lost!''

The recollection of his (Alexandrovitch) wife's last act had so incensed him (Alexandrovitch) that he (Alexandrovitch) had become frigid, as at the beginning of the conversation.

``What can I do?'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, raising his (Alexandrovitch) shoulders and his (Alexandrovitch) eyebrows. '' I am very grateful for your sympathy, but I must be going,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, getting up.

I was married, and my husband deceived me; in anger and jealousy, I would have thrown up everything, I would myself...

'' No, wait a minute. You must not ruin her (wife). Wait a little; I will tell you about myself. But I came to myself again; and who did it?

The children are growing up, my husband has come back to his (husband) family, and feels his (husband) fault, is growing purer, better, and I live on....

Anna saved me. And here I am living on. I have forgiven it, and you ought to forgive! '' Alexey Alexandrovitch heard her (Anna), but her (Anna) words had no effect on him (Alexandrovitch) now.

He (Alexandrovitch) shook himself, and said in a shrill, loud voice:--

``Forgive I cannot, and do not wish to, and I regard it as wrong.

I have done everything for this woman, and she (woman) has trodden it all in the mud to which she (woman) is akin.

I am not a spiteful man, I have never hated anyone, but I hate her (woman) with my whole soul, and I cannot even forgive her (woman), because I hate her (woman) too much for all the wrong she (woman) has done me!

All the hatred of that day when he (man) had resolved on a divorce had sprung up again in his (man) soul. '' (He)

he (man) said, with tones of hatred in his (man) voice.

'' Love those that hate you... '' Darya Alexandrovna whispered timorously. Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled contemptuously. That he (Alexandrovitch) knew long ago, but it could not be applied to his (Alexandrovitch) case.

'' Love those that hate you, but to love those one hates is impossible. Forgive me for having troubled you. Everyone has enough to bear in his (Alexandrovitch) own grief!''

When they rose from table, Levin would have liked to follow Kitty into the drawing room; but he (Levin) was afraid she (Kitty) might dislike this, as too obviously paying her (Kitty) attention.

He (Levin) remained in the little ring of men, taking part in the general conversation, and without looking at Kitty, he (Levin) was aware of her (Kitty) movements, her (Kitty) looks, and the place where she (Kitty) was in the drawing room.

He (Levin) did at once, and without the smallest effort, keep the promise he (Levin) had made her (Kitty)--always to think well of all men, and to like everyone always.

The conversation fell on the village commune, in which Pestsov saw a sort of special principle, called by him (Levin) the choral principle.

Levin did not agree with Pestsov, nor with his (Levin) brother, who had a special attitude of his (Levin) own, both admitting and not admitting the significance of the Russian commune.

And regaining his (Levin) self-possession, Alexey Alexandrovitch quietly took leave and went away. Chapter 13 But he (Alexandrovitch) talked to them, simply trying to reconcile and soften their differences.

He (Alexandrovitch) was not in the least interested in what he (Alexandrovitch) said himself, and even less so in what they said; all he (Alexandrovitch) wanted was that they and everyone should be happy and contented.

He (Alexandrovitch) knew now the one thing of importance; and that one thing was at first there, in the drawing room, and then began moving across and came to a standstill at the door.

Without turning round he (Alexandrovitch) felt the eyes fixed on him (Alexandrovitch), and the smile, and he (Alexandrovitch) could not help turning round. She (Alexandrovitch) was standing in the doorway with Shtcherbatsky, looking at him (Shtcherbatsky).

'' I thought you were going towards the piano,'' said he (Shtcherbatsky), going up to her (Alexandrovitch). '' That's something I miss in the country--music.

No; we only came to fetch you and thank you,'' she (Alexandrovitch) said, rewarding him (Shtcherbatsky) with a smile that was like a gift,

``for coming.

Yes; that's true,'' (him)

said Levin;
``it generally happens that one argues warmly simply because one can't make out what one's opponent wants to prove.

Levin had often noticed in discussions between the most intelligent people that after enormous efforts, and an enormous expenditure of logical subtleties and words, the disputants finally arrived at being aware that what they had so long been struggling to prove to one another had long ago, from the beginning of the argument, been known to both, but that they liked different things, and would not define what they liked for fear of its being attacked.

He (Levin) had often had the experience of suddenly in a discussion grasping what it was his (Levin) opponent liked and at once liking it too, and immediately he (Levin) found himself agreeing, and then all arguments fell away as useless.

Sometimes, too, he (Levin) had experienced the opposite, expressing at last what he (Levin) liked himself, which he (Levin) was devising arguments to defend, and, chancing to express it well and genuinely, he (Levin) had found his (Levin) opponent at once agreeing and ceasing to dispute his (Levin) position.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' What do they want to argue for? No one ever convinces anyone, you know. '' '' '' He (Levin) tried to say this.

She (Levin) knitted her (Levin) brow, trying to understand. But directly he (Levin) began to illustrate his (Levin) meaning, she (Levin) understood at once. '' I know: one must find out what he (Levin) is arguing for, what is precious to him (Levin), then one can...

Levin smiled joyfully; he (Levin) was struck by this transition from the confused, verbose discussion with Pestsov and his (Levin) brother to this laconic, clear, almost wordless communication of the most complex ideas.

Shtcherbatsky moved away from them, and Kitty, going up to a card table, sat down, and, taking up the chalk, began drawing diverging circles over the new green cloth.

'' She (Kitty) had completely guessed and expressed his (Shtcherbatsky) badly expressed idea. They began again on the subject that had been started at dinner-- the liberty and occupations of women.

Levin was of the opinion of Darya Alexandrovna that a girl who did not marry should find a woman's duties in a family.

He (Levin) supported this view by the fact that no family can get on without women to help; that in every family, poor or rich, there are and must be nurses,

No,'' said Kitty, blushing, but looking at him (Levin) all the more boldly with her (Kitty) truthful eyes;

``a girl may be so circumstanced that she (Kitty) cannot live in the family without humiliation, while she (Kitty) herself...

either relations or hired. '' (him)

'' At the hint he (Levin) understood her (Kitty). '' Oh, yes,'' he (Levin) said. '' Yes, yes, yes--you're right

And he (Levin) saw all that Pestsov had been maintaining at dinner of the liberty of woman, simply from getting a glimpse of the terror of an old maid's existence and its humiliation in Kitty's heart; and loving her (Kitty), he (Levin) felt that terror and humiliation, and at once gave up his (Levin) arguments.

; you're right! '' A silence followed. She (Kitty) was still drawing with the chalk on the table. Her (Kitty) eyes were shining with a soft light.

Under the influence of her (Kitty) mood he (Levin) felt in all his (Levin) being a continually growing tension of happiness. '' Ah! I've scribbled all over the table!

'' she (Kitty) said, and, laying down the chalk, she (Kitty) made a movement as though to get up. '' What! shall I be left alone--without her (Kitty)?

'' he (Levin) thought with horror, and he (Levin) took the chalk. '' Wait a minute,'' he (Levin) said, sitting down to the table.

'' I've long wanted to ask you one thing. '' He (Levin) looked straight into her (Kitty) caressing, though frightened eyes. '' Please, ask it.''

``Here,'' (he)
he (Levin) said; and he (Levin) wrote the initial letters, w, y, t, m, i, c, n, b, d, t, m, n, o, t .

There seemed no likelihood that she (Kitty) could make out this complicated sentence; but he (Levin) looked at her (Kitty) as though his (Levin) life depended on her (Kitty) understanding the words.

``When you told me it could never be, did that mean never, or then?'' (She)

'' (she)

Dolly was completely comforted in the depression caused by her (Dolly) conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch when she (Dolly) caught sight of the two figures:

Kitty with the chalk in her (Kitty) hand, with a shy and happy smile looking upwards at Levin, and his (Levin) handsome figure bending over the table with glowing eyes fastened one minute on the table and the next on her (Kitty).

He (Levin) was suddenly radiant: he (Levin) had understood. It meant,

took the chalk and at once answered.

And he (Levin) wrote three letters. '' You're playing secr√©taire ?'' said the old prince. '' But we must really be getting along if you want to be in time at the theater.

In their conversation everything had been said; it had been said that she (Kitty) loved him (prince), and that she (Kitty) would tell her (Kitty) father and mother that he (father) would come tomorrow morning.

When Kitty had gone and Levin was left alone, he (Levin) felt such uneasiness without her (Kitty), and such an impatient longing to get as quickly, as quickly as possible, to tomorrow morning, when he (Levin) would see her (Kitty) again and be plighted to her (Kitty) forever, that he (Levin) felt afraid, as though of death, of those fourteen hours that he (Levin) had to get through without her (Kitty).

It was essential for him (Levin) to be with someone to talk to, so as not to be left alone, to kill time.

Stepan Arkadyevitch would have been the companion most congenial to him (companion), but he (companion) was going out, he (companion) said, to a soir√®e , in reality to the ballet.

Levin only had time to tell him (Levin) he (Levin) was happy, and that he (Levin) loved him (Levin), and would never, never forget what he (Levin) had done for him (Levin).

'' Levin got up and escorted Kitty to the door. Chapter 14 The eyes and the smile of Stepan Arkadyevitch showed Levin that he (Levin) comprehended that feeling fittingly.

'' Oh, so it's not time to die yet?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pressing Levin's hand with emotion. '' N-n-no! '' said Levin.

Darya Alexandrovna too, as she (Kitty) said good-bye to him (Levin), gave him (Levin) a sort of congratulation, saying,

``How glad I am you have met Kitty again!

One must value old friends. '' (him)

Levin did not like these words of Darya Alexandrovna's. Levin said good-bye to them, but, not to be left alone, he (Levin) attached himself to his (Levin) brother.

'' Where are you going?'' '' I'm going to a meeting. '' '' Well, I'll come with you. May I?''

``What for?

Yes, come along,'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling. '' What is the matter with you today?''

said Levin, letting down the window of the carriage they were driving in.

'' You don't mind?--it's so stifling. It's happiness is the matter with me! Why is it you have never married? ''

Sergey Ivanovitch smiled. '' I am very glad, she (I) seems a nice gi... '' Sergey Ivanovitch was beginning. '' Don't say it!

don't say it! '' shouted Levin, clutching at the collar of his (Levin) fur coat with both hands, and muffling him (Levin) up in it.

Well, is it possible for me to be present at the meeting?'' (he)

``Of course it is. '' (unknown)
'' What is your discussion about today?

Levin heard the secretary hesitatingly read the minutes which he (Levin) obviously did not himself understand; but Levin saw from this secretary's face what a good, nice, kind-hearted person he (Levin) was.

'' asked Levin, never ceasing smiling. They arrived at the meeting. This was evident from his (Levin) confusion and embarrassment in reading the minutes.

They were disputing about the misappropriation of certain sums and the laying of certain pipes, and Sergey Ivanovitch was very cutting to two members, and said something at great length with an air of triumph; and another member, scribbling something on a bit of paper, began timidly at first, but afterwards answered him (member) very viciously and delightfully.

Levin listened to them, and saw clearly that these missing sums and these pipes were not anything real, and that they were not at all angry, but were all the nicest, kindest people, and everything was as happy and charming as possible among them.

Then the discussion began. And then Sviazhsky -LRB-he (Levin) was there too-RRB- said something too, very handsomely and nobly. They did no harm to anyone, and were all enjoying it.

What struck Levin was that he (Levin) could see through them all today, and from little, almost imperceptible signs knew the soul of each, and saw distinctly that they were all good at heart.

That was evident from the way they spoke to him (Levin), from the friendly, affectionate way even those he (Levin) did not know looked at him (Levin).

And Levin himself in particular they were all extremely fond of that day. '' Well, did you like it?'' Sergey Ivanovitch asked him (Ivanovitch).

'' Very much. I never supposed it was so interesting! Capital! Splendid! '' Sviazhsky went up to Levin and invited him (Levin) to come round to tea with him (Levin).

Levin was utterly at a loss to comprehend or recall what it was he (Levin) had disliked in Sviazhsky, what he (Levin) had failed to find in him (Levin).

And from a queer association of ideas, because in his (Levin) imagination the idea of Sviazhsky's sister-in-law was connected with marriage, it occurred to him (Levin) that there was no one to whom he (Levin) could more suitably speak of his (Levin) happiness, and he (Levin) was very glad to go and see them.

Sviazhsky questioned him (Levin) about his (Levin) improvements on his (Levin) estate, presupposing, as he (Levin) always did, that there was no possibility of doing anything not done already in Europe, and now this did not in the least annoy Levin.

On the contrary, he (Levin) felt that Sviazhsky was right, that the whole business was of little value, and he (Levin) saw the wonderful softness and consideration with which Sviazhsky avoided fully expressing his (Levin) correct view.

He (Levin) was a clever and wonderfully good-hearted man. '' Most delighted,'' he (Levin) said, and asked after his (Levin) wife and sister-in-law. The ladies of the Sviazhsky household were particularly delightful.

He (Levin) stayed with them one hour, two, three, talking of all sorts of subjects but the one thing that filled his (Levin) heart, and did not observe that he (Levin) was boring them dreadfully, and that it was long past their bedtime.

It seemed to Levin that they knew all about it already and sympathized with him (Levin), saying nothing merely from delicacy. Sviazhsky went with him (Levin) into the hall, yawning and wondering at the strange humor his (Levin) friend was in.

It was past one o'clock. Levin went back to his (Levin) hotel, and was dismayed at the thought that all alone now with his (Levin) impatience

The servant, whose turn it was to be up all night, lighted his (Levin) candles, and would have gone away, but Levin stopped him (Levin).

he (Levin) had ten hours still left to get through. This servant, Yegor, whom Levin had noticed before, struck him (Levin) as a very intelligent, excellent, and, above all, good-hearted man.

'' Well, Yegor, it's hard work not sleeping, isn't it?'' '' One's got to put up with it! It's part of our work, you see.

It appeared that Yegor had a family, three boys and a daughter, a sempstress, whom he (Levin) wanted to marry to a cashier in a saddler's shop.

Levin, on hearing this, informed Yegor that, in his (Levin) opinion, in marriage the great thing was love, and that with love one would always be happy, for happiness rests only on oneself.

Yegor listened attentively, and obviously quite took in Levin's idea, but by way of assent to it he (Levin) enunciated, greatly to Levin's surprise, the observation that when he (Levin) had lived with good masters he (Levin) had always been satisfied with his (Levin) masters, and now was perfectly satisfied with his (Levin) employer, though he (Levin) was a Frenchman.

In a gentleman's house it's easier; but then here one makes more. '' '' Wonderfully good-hearted fellow! '' thought Levin. ''

Well, but you yourself, Yegor, when you got married, did you love your wife?''

``Ay! and why not?'' (Yegor)
responded Yegor. And Levin saw that Yegor too was in an excited state and intending to express all his (Levin) most heartfelt emotions.

'' My life, too, has been a wonderful one. From a child up...'' he (Levin) was beginning with flashing eyes, apparently catching Levin's enthusiasm, just as people catch yawning.

He (Levin) had eaten scarcely anything at dinner, had refused tea and supper at Sviazhsky's, but he (Levin) was incapable of thinking of supper.

But at that moment a ring was heard. Yegor departed, and Levin was left alone. He (Levin) had not slept the previous night, but was incapable of thinking of sleep either.

His (Levin) room was cold, but he (Levin) was oppressed by heat. He (Levin) opened both the movable panes in his (Levin) window and sat down to the table opposite the open panes.

Over the snow-covered roofs could be seen a decorated cross with chains, and above it the rising triangle of Charles's Wain with the yellowish light of Capella.

He (Charles) gazed at the cross, then at the stars, drank in the fresh freezing air that flowed evenly into the room, and followed as though in a dream the images and memories that rose in his (Charles) imagination.

At four o'clock he (Charles) heard steps in the passage and peeped out at the door. It was the gambler Myaskin, whom he (gambler) knew, coming from the club.

He (gambler) walked gloomily, frowning and coughing. '' Poor, unlucky fellow! '' thought Levin, and tears came into his (Levin) eyes from love and pity for this man.

He (Levin) would have talked with him (Levin), and tried to comfort him (Levin), but remembering that he (Levin) had nothing but his (Levin) shirt on, he (Levin) changed his (Levin) mind and sat down again at the open pane to bathe in the cold air and gaze at the exquisite lines of the cross, silent, but full of meaning for him (Levin), and the mounting lurid yellow star.

At seven o'clock there was a noise of people polishing the floors, and bells ringing in some servants' department, and Levin felt that he (Levin) was beginning to get frozen.

He (Levin) closed the pane, washed, dressed, and went out into the street. Chapter 15 The streets were still empty. Levin went to the house of the Shtcherbatskys.

The visitors' doors were closed and everything was asleep. He (Levin) walked back, went into his (Levin) room again, and asked for coffee.

The day servant, not Yegor this time, brought it to him (servant). Levin would have entered into conversation with him (Levin), but a bell rang for the servant, and he (Levin) went out.

Levin tried to drink coffee and put some roll in his (Levin) mouth, but his (Levin) mouth was quite at a loss what to do with the roll.

Levin, rejecting the roll, put on his (Levin) coat and went out again for a walk. It was nine o'clock when he (Levin) reached the Shtcherbatskys' steps the second time.

In the house they were only just up, and the cook came out to go marketing. He (cook) had to get through at least two hours more.

He (cook) had eaten nothing for a whole day, he (cook) had not slept for two nights, had spent several hours undressed in the frozen air, and felt not simply fresher and stronger than ever, but felt utterly independent of his (cook) body; he (cook) moved without muscular effort, and felt as if he (cook) could do anything.

All that night and morning Levin lived perfectly unconsciously, and felt perfectly lifted out of the conditions of material life. He (Levin) was convinced he (Levin) could fly upwards or lift the corner of the house, if need be.

He (Levin) spent the remainder of the time in the street, incessantly looking at his (Levin) watch and gazing about him (Levin). And what he (Levin) saw then, he (Levin) never saw again after.

The children especially going to school, the bluish doves flying down from the roofs to the pavement, and the little loaves covered with flour, thrust out by an unseen hand, touched him (Levin).

It all happened at the same time: a boy ran towards a dove and glanced smiling at Levin; the dove, with a whir of her (Levin) wings, darted away, flashing in the sun, amid grains of snow that quivered in the air, while from a little window there came a smell of fresh-baked bread, and the loaves were put out.

Those loaves, those doves, and those two boys were not earthly creatures. All of this together was so extraordinarily nice that Levin laughed and cried with delight.

Going a long way round by Gazetny Place and Kislovka, he (Levin) went back again to the hotel, and putting his (Levin) watch before him (Levin), he (Levin) sat down to wait for twelve o'clock.

In the next room they were talking about some sort of machines, and swindling, and coughing their morning coughs. They did not realize that the hand was near twelve.

The hand reached it. Levin went out onto the steps. The sledge-drivers clearly knew all about it. They crowded round Levin with happy faces, quarreling among themselves, and offering their services.

Trying not to offend the other sledge drivers, and promising to drive with them too, Levin took one and told him (Levin) to drive to the Shtcherbatskys'.

The sledge was high and comfortable, and altogether such a one as Levin never drove in after, and the horse was a good one, and tried to gallop but didn't seem to move.

The driver knew the Shtcherbatskys' house, and drew up at the entrance with a curve of his (driver) arm and a

``Wo!'' (The driver)
especially indicative of respect for his (driver) fare.

The sledge-driver was splendid in a white shirt-collar sticking out over his (driver) overcoat and into his (driver) strong, full-blooded red neck. The Shtcherbatskys' hall-porter certainly knew all about it.

This was evident from the smile in his (driver) eyes and the way he (driver) said:

``Well, it's a long while since you've been to see us, Konstantin Demitrievitch!'' (he)

Not only he (Demitrievitch) knew all about it, but he (Demitrievitch) was unmistakably delighted and making efforts to conceal his (Demitrievitch) joy. Looking into his (Demitrievitch) kindly old eyes, Levin realized even something new in his (Levin) happiness.

'' Are they up?''

``Pray walk in! Leave it here,'' (he)
said he (Levin), smiling, as Levin would have come back to take his (Levin) hat.

The footman, though a young man, and one of the new school of footmen, a dandy, was a very kind-hearted, good fellow, and he (fellow) too knew all about it.

That meant something. '' To whom shall I announce your honor?'' asked the footman. '' The princess...the prince...the young princess...'' said Levin.

The first person he (Levin) saw was Mademoiselle Linon. She (princess) walked across the room, and her (princess) ringlets and her (princess) face were beaming.

He (Levin) had only just spoken to her (princess), when suddenly he (Levin) heard the rustle of a skirt at the door, and Mademoiselle Linon vanished from Levin's eyes, and a joyful terror came over him (Levin) at the nearness of his (Levin) happiness.

Directly she (princess) had gone out, swift, swift light steps sounded on the parquet, and his (Levin) bliss, his (Levin) life, himself--what was best in himself, what he (Levin) had so long sought and longed for--was quickly, so quickly approaching him (Levin).

Mademoiselle Linon was in great haste, and leaving him (Levin), went out at the other door. She (princess) did not walk, but seemed, by some unseen force, to float to him (Levin).

He (Levin) saw nothing but her (princess) clear, truthful eyes, frightened by the same bliss of love that flooded his (Levin) heart. Those eyes were shining nearer and nearer, blinding him (Levin) with their light of love.

She (princess) stopped still close to him (Levin), touching him (Levin). Her (princess) hands rose and dropped onto his (Levin) shoulders. She (princess) had done all she (princess) could--she (princess) had run up to him (Levin) and given herself up entirely, shy and happy.

He (Levin) put his (Levin) arms round her (princess) and pressed his (Levin) lips to her (princess) mouth that sought his (Levin) kiss. She (princess) too had not slept all night, and had been expecting him (Levin) all the morning.

Her (princess) mother and father had consented without demur, and were happy in her (princess) happiness. She (princess) had been waiting for him (father). She (princess) wanted to be the first to tell him (father) her (princess) happiness and his (father).

She (princess) had got ready to see him (father) alone, and had been delighted at the idea, and had been shy and ashamed, and did not know herself what she (princess) was doing.

She (princess) had heard his (father) steps and voice, and had waited at the door for Mademoiselle Linon to go. Mademoiselle Linon had gone away.

Without thinking, without asking herself how and what, she (princess) had gone up to him (father), and did as she (princess) was doing.

``Let us go to mamma!

For a long while he (father) could say nothing, not so much because he (father) was afraid of desecrating the loftiness of his (father) emotion by a word, as that every time he (father) tried to say something, instead of words he (father) felt that tears of happiness were welling up.

'' (she)

she (princess) said, taking him (father) by the hand. He (father) took her (princess) hand and kissed it. '' Can it be true? ''

he (father) said at last in a choked voice. '' I can't believe you love me, dear!'' She (princess) smiled at that

``dear,'' (She)
and at the timidity with which he (father) glanced at her (princess).

'' Yes!'' she (princess) said significantly, deliberately. '' I am so happy!'' Not letting go his (father) hands, she (princess) went into the drawing room.

The princess, seeing them, breathed quickly, and immediately began to cry and then immediately began to laugh, and with a vigorous step Levin had not expected, ran up to him (Levin), and hugging his (Levin) head, kissed him (Levin), wetting his (Levin) cheeks with her (princess) tears.

You've not been long settling things,'' said the old prince, trying to seem unmoved; but Levin noticed that his (Levin) eyes were wet when he (Levin) turned to him (Levin).

'' So it is all settled! I am glad. Love her (princess). I am glad.... Kitty!'' '' '' I've long, always wished for this!'' said the prince, taking Levin by the arm and drawing him (Levin) towards himself.

'' Even when this little feather-head fancied...''

``Papa! '' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
shrieked Kitty, and shut his (Papa) mouth with her (Kitty) hands. '' Well, I won't!

'' he (Papa) said. '' I'm very, very ...plea ... Oh, what a fool I am... '' He (fool) embraced Kitty, kissed her (Kitty) face, her (Kitty) hand, her (Kitty) face again, and made the sign of the cross over her (Kitty).

And there came over Levin a new feeling of love for this man, till then so little known to him (Levin), when he (Levin) saw how slowly and tenderly Kitty kissed his (Levin) muscular hand.

Chapter 16 The princess sat in her (princess) armchair, silent and smiling; the prince sat down beside her (princess). Kitty stood by her (Kitty) father's chair, still holding his (prince) hand.

All were silent. The princess was the first to put everything into words, and to translate all thoughts and feelings into practical questions.

And all equally felt this strange and painful for the first minute. '' When is it to be? We must have the benediction and announcement.

And when's the wedding to be? What do you think, Alexander?''

``Here he (Alexander) is,'' (the prince)
said the old prince, pointing to Levin--
``he (Levin)'s the principal person in the matter.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``When?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin blushing. '' Tomorrow; If you ask me, I should say, the benediction today and the wedding tomorrow.''

``Come, mon cher , that's nonsense!'' (unknown)
'' Well, in a week.'' '' He (Levin)'s quite mad.'' '' No, why so?'' '' Well, upon my word!

'' said the mother, smiling, delighted at this haste. '' How about the trousseau?''

``Will there really be a trousseau and all that?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Levin thought with horror. '' But can the trousseau and the benediction and all that--can it spoil my happiness? Nothing can spoil it!''

He (Levin) glanced at Kitty, and noticed that she (Kitty) was not in the least, not in the very least, disturbed by the idea of the trousseau.

'' Then it must be all right,'' he (Levin) thought. '' Oh, I know nothing about it; I only said what I should like,'' he (Levin) said apologetically.

The princess went up to her (princess) husband, kissed him (Levin), and would have gone away, but he (Levin) kept her (princess), embraced her (princess), and, tenderly as a young lover, kissed her (princess) several times, smiling.

The old people were obviously muddled for a moment, and did not quite know whether it was they who were in love again or their daughter.

'' We'll talk it over, then. The benediction and announcement can take place now. That's very well. '' When the prince and the princess had gone, Levin went up to his (Levin) betrothed and took her (princess) hand.

He (Levin) was self-possessed now and could speak, and he (Levin) had a great deal he (Levin) wanted to tell her (princess). But he (Levin) said not at all what he (Levin) had to say.

'' How I knew it would be so! I never hoped for it; and yet in my heart I was always sure,'' he (Levin) said.

She (princess) stopped and went on again, looking at him (Levin) resolutely with her (princess) truthful eyes,

``Even when I thrust from me my happiness.

'' (him)

I believe that it was ordained.'' '' And I!'' she (princess) said. '' Even when... '' I always loved you alone, but I was carried away.

I ought to tell you.... Can you forgive that?''

``Perhaps it was for the best. You will have to forgive me so much.

He (Levin) had resolved from the first to tell her (princess) two things--that he (Levin) was not chaste as she (princess) was, and that he (Levin) was not a believer.

I ought to tell you... '' (he)

This was one of the things he (Levin) had meant to speak about. It was agonizing, but he (Levin) considered he (Levin) ought to tell her (princess) both these facts.

'' No, not now, later! '' he (Levin) said. '' Very well, later, but you must certainly tell me. I'm not afraid of anything.

I want to know everything. Now it is settled. '' He (Levin) added:

``Settled that you'll take me whatever I may be--you won't give me up?

Yes?'' (He)

'' Yes, yes. '' Their conversation was interrupted by Mademoiselle Linon, who with an affected but tender smile came to congratulate her (princess) favorite pupil.

Then relations arrived, and there began that state of blissful absurdity from which Levin did not emerge till the day after his (Levin) wedding.

Levin was in a continual state of awkwardness and discomfort, but the intensity of his (Levin) happiness went on all the while increasing.

He (Levin) felt continually that a great deal was being expected of him (Levin)--what, he (Levin) did not know; and he (Levin) did everything he (Levin) was told, and it all gave him (Levin) happiness.

He (Levin) had thought his (Levin) engagement would have nothing about it like others, that the ordinary conditions of engaged couples would spoil his (Levin) special happiness; but it ended in his (Levin) doing exactly as other people did, and his (Levin) happiness being only increased thereby and becoming more and more special, more and more unlike anything that had ever happened.

Before she (Levin) had gone, the servants came in with their congratulations. '' Now we shall have sweetmeats to eat,'' said Mademoiselle Linon-- and Levin drove off to buy sweetmeats.

'' Well, I'm very glad,'' said Sviazhsky. '' I advise you to get the bouquets from Fomin's.''

``Oh, are they wanted?

'' (he)

And he (Levin) drove to Fomin's. His (Levin) brother offered to lend him (Levin) money, as he (Levin) would have so many expenses, presents to give....

And at the confectioner's, and at Fomin's, and at Foulde's he (Levin) saw that he (Levin) was expected; that they were pleased to see him (Levin), and prided themselves on his (Levin) happiness, just as every one whom he (Levin) had to do with during those days.

What was extraordinary was that everyone not only liked him (Levin), but even people previously unsympathetic, cold, and callous, were enthusiastic over him (Levin), gave way to him (Levin) in everything, treated his (Levin) feeling with tenderness and delicacy, and shared his (Levin) conviction that he (Levin) was the happiest man in the world because his (Levin) betrothed was beyond perfection.

When Countess Nordston ventured to hint that she (Nordston) had hoped for something better, Kitty was so angry and proved so conclusively that nothing in the world could be better than Levin, that Countess Nordston had to admit it, and in Kitty's presence never met Levin without a smile of ecstatic admiration.

'' Oh, are presents wanted? '' And he (Levin) galloped to Foulde's. Kitty too felt the same thing. The confession he (Levin) had promised was the one painful incident of this time.

He (Levin) consulted the old prince, and with his (Levin) sanction gave Kitty his (Levin) diary, in which there was written the confession that tortured him (Levin).

He (Levin) had written this diary at the time with a view to his (Levin) future wife. Two things caused him (Levin) anguish: his (Levin) lack of purity and his (Levin) lack of faith.

She (wife) was religious, had never doubted the truths of religion, but his (Levin) external unbelief did not affect her (wife) in the least.

Through love she (wife) knew all his (Levin) soul, and in his (Levin) soul she (wife) saw what she (wife) wanted, and that such a state of soul should be called unbelieving was to her (wife) a matter of no account.

His (Levin) confession of unbelief passed unnoticed. The other confession set her (wife) weeping bitterly. Levin, not without an inner struggle, handed her (wife) his (Levin) diary.

He (Levin) knew that between him (Levin) and her (wife) there could not be, and should not be, secrets, and so he (Levin) had decided that so it must be.

But he (Levin) had not realized what an effect it would have on her (wife), he (Levin) had not put himself in her (wife) place.

It was only when the same evening he (Levin) came to their house before the theater, went into her (wife) room and saw her (wife) tear-stained, pitiful, sweet face, miserable with suffering he (Levin) had caused and nothing could undo, he (Levin) felt the abyss that separated his (Levin) shameful past from her (wife) dovelike purity, and was appalled at what he (Levin) had done.

``Take them, take these dreadful books! '' (she)
she (wife) said, pushing away them me? No, it was better anyway,'' she (wife) added, touched by his (Levin) despairing face.

'' But it's awful, awful! '' His (Levin) head sank, and he (Levin) was silent. He (Levin) could say nothing. '' You can't forgive me,'' he (Levin) whispered.

'' Yes, I forgive you; but it's terrible! '' But his (Levin) happiness was so immense that this confession did not shatter it, it only added another shade to it.

She (wife) forgave him (Levin); but from that time more than ever he (Levin) considered himself unworthy of her (wife), morally bowed down lower than ever before her (wife), and prized more highly than ever his (Levin) undeserved happiness.

Chapter 17 Unconsciously going over in his (Levin) memory the conversations that had taken place during and after dinner, Alexey Alexandrovitch returned to his (Alexandrovitch) solitary room.

The applicability or non-applicability of the Christian precept to his (Christian) own case was too difficult a question to be discussed lightly, and this question had long ago been answered by Alexey Alexandrovitch in the negative.

Darya Alexandrovna's words about forgiveness had aroused in him (Alexandrovitch) nothing but annoyance. Of all that had been said, what stuck most in his (Alexandrovitch) memory was the phrase of stupid, good-natured Turovtsin--

'' Acted like a man, he (man) did! Called him (man) out and shot him (man)! '' Everyone had apparently shared this feeling, though from politeness they had not expressed it.

And thinking of nothing but the journey before him (man), and the revision work he (man) had to do, he (man) went into his (man) room and asked the porter who escorted him (man) where his (man) man was.

'' But the matter is settled, it's useless thinking about it,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch told himself. The porter said that the man had only just gone out.

Alexey Alexandrovitch ordered tea to be sent him (Alexandrovitch), sat down route of his (Alexandrovitch) journey. '' Two telegrams,'' said his (Alexandrovitch) manservant, coming into the room.

'' I beg your pardon, your excellency; I'd only just that minute gone out. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch took the telegrams and opened them.

Alexey Alexandrovitch flung the telegram down, and flushing a little, got up and began to pace up and down the room.

The first telegram was the announcement of Stremov's appointment to the very post Karenin had coveted. '' Quos vult perdere dementat ,'' he (Karenin) said, meaning by quos the persons responsible for this appointment.

He (Karenin) was not so much annoyed that he (Karenin) had not received the post, that he (Karenin) had been conspicuously passed over; but it was incomprehensible, amazing to him (Karenin) that they did not see that the wordy phrase-monger Stremov was the last man fit for it.

How could they fail to see how they were ruining themselves, lowering their prestige by this appointment? '' Something else in the same line,'' he (man) said to himself bitterly, opening the second telegram.

The telegram was from his (man) wife. Her (wife) name, written in blue pencil,

``Anna,'' (I)
was the first thing that caught his (man) eye.

'' I am dying; I beg, I implore you to come. I shall die easier with your forgiveness,'' he (man) read. He (man) smiled contemptuously, and flung down the telegram.

That this was a trick and a fraud, of that, he (man) thought for the first minute, there could be no doubt.

'' There is no deceit she (Anna) would stick at. She (Anna) was near her (Anna) confinement. Perhaps it is the confinement. But what can be their aim?

To legitimize the child, to compromise me, and prevent a divorce,'' he (man) thought. '' But something was said in it: I am dying...

'' He (man) read the telegram again, and suddenly the plain meaning of what was said in it struck him (man). '' And if it is true?'' he (man) said to himself.

If it is true that in the moment of agony and nearness to death she (Anna) is genuinely penitent, and I, taking it for a trick, refuse to go?

'' That would not only be cruel, and everyone would blame me, but it would be stupid on my part. ''

``Piotr, call a coach; I am going to Petersburg,'' (he)
he (coach) said to his (coach) servant.

Alexey Alexandrovitch decided that he (Alexandrovitch) would go to Petersburg and see his (Alexandrovitch) wife. If her (wife) illness was a trick, he (Alexandrovitch) would say nothing and go away again.

If she (wife) was really in danger, and wished to see him (Alexandrovitch) before her (wife) death, he (Alexandrovitch) would forgive her (wife) if he (Alexandrovitch) found her (wife) alive, and pay her (wife) the last duties if he (Alexandrovitch) came too late.

With a sense of weariness and uncleanness from the night spent in the train, in the early fog of Petersburg Alexey Alexandrovitch drove through the deserted Nevsky and stared straight before him (Alexandrovitch), not thinking of what was awaiting him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) could not think about it, because in picturing what would happen, he (Alexandrovitch) could not drive away the reflection that her (wife) death would at once remove all the difficulty of his (Alexandrovitch) position.

Bakers, closed shops, night-cabmen, porters sweeping the pavements flashed past his (Alexandrovitch) eyes, and he (Alexandrovitch) watched it all, trying to smother the thought of what was awaiting him (Alexandrovitch), and what he (Alexandrovitch) dared not hope for, and yet was hoping for.

All the way he (Alexandrovitch) thought no more of what he (Alexandrovitch) ought to do. He (Alexandrovitch) drove up to the steps. A sledge and a carriage with the coachman asleep stood at the entrance.

As he (Alexandrovitch) went into the entry, Alexey Alexandrovitch, as it were, got out his (Alexandrovitch) resolution from the remotest corner of his (Alexandrovitch) brain, and mastered it thoroughly.

Its meaning ran:

``If it's a trick, then calm contempt and departure. If truth, do what is proper. '' (The porter)
The porter opened the door before Alexey Alexandrovitch rang.

The porter, Kapitonitch, looked queer in an old coat, without a tie, and in slippers. '' How is your mistress?'' ''

A successful confinement yesterday. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped short and turned white. He (Alexandrovitch) felt distinctly now how intensely he (Alexandrovitch) had longed for her (mistress) death.

'' And how is she (mistress)? '' Korney in his (Alexandrovitch) morning apron ran downstairs. '' Very ill,'' he (Alexandrovitch) answered. '' There was a consultation yesterday, and the doctor's here now.

``Take my things,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, and feeling some relief at the news that there was still hope of her (mistress) death, he (Alexandrovitch) went into the hall.

'' On the hatstand there was a military overcoat. Alexey Alexandrovitch noticed it and asked:

``Who is here?'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
'' The doctor, the midwife, and Count Vronsky.

In the drawing room there was no one; at the sound of his (Alexandrovitch) steps there came out of her (midwife) boudoir the midwife in a cap with lilac ribbons.

She (midwife) went up to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and with the familiarity given by the approach of death took him (Alexandrovitch) by the arm and drew him (Alexandrovitch) towards the bedroom.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch went into the inner rooms. '' Thank God you've come! She (midwife) keeps on about you and nothing but you,'' she (midwife) said.

``Make haste with the ice! '' (the doctor)
the doctor's peremptory voice said from the bedroom. Alexey Alexandrovitch went into her (midwife) boudoir. At the table, sitting sideways in a low chair, was Vronsky, his (Alexandrovitch) face hidden in his (Alexandrovitch) hands, weeping.

Seeing the husband, he (Alexandrovitch) was so overwhelmed that he (Alexandrovitch) sat down again, drawing his (Alexandrovitch) head down to his (Alexandrovitch) shoulders, as if he (Alexandrovitch) wanted to disappear; but he (Alexandrovitch) made an effort over himself, got up and said:

``She (midwife) is dying.

He (Alexandrovitch) jumped up at the doctor's voice, took his (Alexandrovitch) hands from his (Alexandrovitch) face, and saw Alexey Alexandrovitch. The doctors say there is no hope.

'' (he)

Alexey Alexandrovitch, seeing Vronsky's tears, felt a rush of that nervous emotion always produced in him (Alexandrovitch) by the sight of other people's suffering, and turning away his (Alexandrovitch) face, he (Alexandrovitch) moved hurriedly to the door, without hearing the rest of his (Alexandrovitch) words.

I am entirely in your power, only let me be here...though I am at your disposal. I... From the bedroom came the sound of Anna's voice saying something.

Her (Anna) voice was lively, eager, with exceedingly distinct intonations. Alexey Alexandrovitch went into the bedroom, and went up to the bed.

Her (Anna) cheeks were flushed crimson, her (Anna) eyes glittered, her (Anna) little white hands thrust out from the sleeves of her (Anna) dressing gown were playing with the quilt, twisting it about.

She (Anna) was lying turned with her (Anna) face towards him (Alexandrovitch). It seemed as though she (Anna) were not only well and blooming, but in the happiest frame of mind.

For Alexey--I am speaking of Alexey Alexandrovitch -LRB-what a strange and awful thing that both are Alexey, isn't it?-RRB---Alexey would not refuse me.

She (Anna) was talking rapidly, musically, and with exceptionally correct articulation and expressive intonation. '' I should forget, he (Alexey) would forgive.... But why doesn't he (Alexey) come?

He (Alexey)'s so good he (Alexey) doesn't know himself how good he (Alexey) is. Ah, my God, what agony! Give me some water, quick!

Oh, that will be bad for her (Anna), my little girl! Oh, very well then, give her (Anna) to a nurse. Yes, I agree, it's better in fact.

He (God)'ll be coming; it will hurt him (God) to see her (Anna). Give her (Anna) to the nurse.''

``Anna Arkadyevna, he (God) has come. Here he (God) is!'' (the midwife)
said the midwife, trying to attract her (midwife) attention to Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' Oh, what nonsense! '' Anna went on, not seeing her (Anna) husband. '' No, give her (Anna) to me; give me my little one!

He (husband) has not come yet. You say he (husband) won't forgive me, because you don't know him (husband). No one knows him (husband). I'm the only one, and it was hard for me even.

His (husband) eyes I ought to know --Seryozha has just the same eyes--and I can't bear to see them because of it.

Has Seryozha had his (husband) dinner? I know everyone will forget him (husband). He (husband) would not forget. Seryozha must be moved into the corner room, and Mariette must be asked to sleep with him (husband).

All of a sudden she (Seryozha) shrank back, was silent; and in terror, as though expecting a blow, as though to defend herself, she (Seryozha) raised her (Seryozha) hands to her (Seryozha) face.

'' She (Seryozha) had seen her (Seryozha) husband. '' No, no! '' she (Seryozha) began. '' I am not afraid of him (husband); I am afraid of death.
