I am in a hurry, because I've no time, I've not long left to live; the fever will begin directly and I shall understand nothing more.

Alexey Alexandrovitch's wrinkled face wore an expression of agony; he (Alexandrovitch) took her (Seryozha) by the hand and tried to say something, but he (Alexandrovitch) could not utter it; his (Alexandrovitch) lower lip quivered, but he (Alexandrovitch) still went on struggling with his (Alexandrovitch) emotion, and only now and then glanced at her (Seryozha).

And each time he (Alexandrovitch) glanced at her (Seryozha), he (Alexandrovitch) saw her (Seryozha) eyes gazing at him (Alexandrovitch) with such passionate and triumphant tenderness as he (Alexandrovitch) had never seen in them.

Alexey, come here. Now I understand, I understand it all, I see it all!'' '' Wait a minute, you don't know...stay a little, stay!...

'' She (Seryozha) stopped, as though collecting her (Seryozha) ideas. '' Yes,'' she (Seryozha) began;

``yes, yes, yes. This is what I wanted to say.

, I'm afraid of her (Seryozha): she (Seryozha) loved that man, and I tried to hate you, and could not forget about her (Seryozha) that used to be.

Don't be surprised at me. I'm still the same.... But there is another woman in me I'm not that woman. Now I'm my real self, all myself.

I'm dying now, I know I shall die, ask him (man). Even now I feel--see here, the weights on my feet, on my hands, on my fingers.

My fingers--see how huge they are! But this will soon all be over.... Only one thing I want: forgive me, forgive me quite.

And I'll go to Rome; there's a wilderness, and there I shall be no trouble to any one, only I'll take Seryozha and the little one

I'm terrible, but my nurse used to tell me; the holy martyr--what was her (nurse) name? She (nurse) was worse. .... No, you can't forgive me!

I know, it can't be forgiven! No, no, go away, you're too good! '' (she)

She (nurse) held his (martyr) hand in one burning hand, while she (nurse) pushed him (martyr) away with the other.

The nervous agitation of Alexey Alexandrovitch kept increasing, and had by now reached such a point that he (Alexandrovitch) ceased to struggle with it.

He (Alexandrovitch) suddenly felt that what he (Alexandrovitch) had regarded as nervous agitation was on the contrary a blissful spiritual condition that gave him (Alexandrovitch) all at once a new happiness he (Alexandrovitch) had never known.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not think that the Christian law that he (Alexandrovitch) had been all his (Alexandrovitch) life trying to follow, enjoined on him (Alexandrovitch) to forgive and love his (Alexandrovitch) enemies; but a glad feeling of love and forgiveness for his (Alexandrovitch) enemies filled his (Alexandrovitch) heart.

He (Alexandrovitch) knelt down, and laying his (Alexandrovitch) head in the curve of her (Alexandrovitch) arm, which burned him (Alexandrovitch) as with fire through the sleeve, he (Alexandrovitch) sobbed like a little child.

She (Alexandrovitch) put her (Alexandrovitch) arm around his (Alexandrovitch) head, moved towards him (Alexandrovitch), and with defiant pride lifted up her (Alexandrovitch) eyes. '' That is he (Alexandrovitch).

I knew him (Alexandrovitch)! Now, forgive me, everyone, forgive me!... They've come again; why don't they go away?... Oh, take these cloaks off me!''

The doctor unloosed her (Alexandrovitch) hands, carefully laying her (Alexandrovitch) on the pillow, and covered her (Alexandrovitch) up to the shoulders. She (Alexandrovitch) lay back submissively, and looked before her (Alexandrovitch) with beaming eyes.

'' Remember one thing, that I needed nothing but forgiveness, and I want nothing more.... Why doesn't he (doctor) come? '' she (Alexandrovitch) said, turning to the door towards Vronsky.

'' Do come, do come! Give him (doctor) your hand. '' Vronsky came to the side of the bed, and seeing Anna, again hid his (doctor) face in his (doctor) hands.

'' Uncover your face--look at him (doctor)! He (doctor)'s a saint,'' she (Anna) said. '' Oh! uncover your face, do uncover it! '' she (Anna) said angrily.

Alexey Alexandrovitch took Vronsky's hands and drew them away from his (Alexandrovitch) face, which was awful with the expression of agony and shame upon it.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch, do uncover his (Alexandrovitch) face! I want to see him (Alexandrovitch). '' '' Give him (Alexandrovitch) your hand. Forgive him (Alexandrovitch). ''

Alexey Alexandrovitch gave him (Alexandrovitch) his (Alexandrovitch) hand, not attempting to restrain the tears that streamed from his (Alexandrovitch) eyes. '' Thank God, thank God!''

she (Anna) said,

``now everything is ready. Only to stretch my legs a little. There, that's capital. How badly these flowers are done--not a bit like a violet,'' (she)
she (Anna) said, pointing to the hangings.

'' My God, my God! when will it end? Give me some morphine. Doctor, give me some morphine! Oh, my God, my God!''

The doctors said that it was puerperal fever, and that it was ninety-nine chances in a hundred it would end in death.

And she (Anna) tossed about on the bed. The whole day long there was fever, delirium, and unconsciousness. At midnight the patient lay without consciousness, and almost without pulse.

Vronsky had gone home, but in the morning he (patient) came to inquire, and Alexey Alexandrovitch meeting him (Alexandrovitch) in the hall, said:

``Better stay, she (Anna) might ask for you,'' (him)
and himself led him (Alexandrovitch) to his (Alexandrovitch) wife's boudoir.

The end was expected every minute. Towards morning, there was a return again of excitement, rapid thought and talk, and again it ended in unconsciousness.

On the third day it was the same thing, and the doctors said there was hope. That day Alexey Alexandrovitch went into the boudoir where Vronsky was sitting, and closing the door sat down opposite him (Vronsky).

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' said Vronsky, feeling that a statement of the position was coming, ``I can't speak, I can't understand. Spare me!

He (Vronsky) would have risen; but Alexey Alexandrovitch took him (Alexandrovitch) by the hand and said:

``I beg you to hear me out; it is necessary.

I must explain my feelings, the feelings that have guided me and will guide me, so that you may not be in error regarding me.

However hard it is for you , believe me, it is more terrible for me. '' (him)

You know I had resolved on a divorce, and had even begun to take proceedings.

, I was in misery; I will confess that I was pursued by a desire to revenge myself on you and on her (I).

When I got the telegram, I came here with the same feelings; I will say more, I longed for her (I) death.

I won't conceal from you that in beginning this I was in uncertainty But... '' He (it) paused, pondering whether to disclose or not to disclose his (it) feeling to him (it).

'' But I saw her (I) and forgave her (I). And the happiness of forgiveness has revealed to me my duty. I forgive completely.

I would offer the other cheek, I would give my cloak if my coat be taken. I pray to God only not to take from me the bliss of forgiveness!''

This is my position: you can trample me in the mud, make me the laughing-stock of the world, I will not abandon her (I), and I will never utter a word of reproach to you,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch went on.

Tears stood in his (Alexandrovitch) eyes, and the luminous, serene look in them impressed Vronsky. '' '' My duty is clearly marked for me; I ought to be with her (I), and I will be.

If she (I) wishes to see you, I will let you know, but now I suppose it would be better for you to go away.

Vronsky too was getting up, and in a stooping, not yet erect posture, looked up at him (Alexandrovitch) from under his (Alexandrovitch) brows.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not understand Alexey Alexandrovitch's feeling, but he (Alexandrovitch) felt that it was something higher and even unattainable for him (Alexandrovitch) with his (Alexandrovitch) view of life.

After the conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch, Vronsky went out onto the steps of the Karenins' house and stood still, with difficulty remembering where he (Vronsky) was, and where he (Vronsky) ought to walk or drive.

'' He (Vronsky) got up, and sobs cut short his (Vronsky) words. Chapter 18 He (Vronsky) felt disgraced, humiliated, guilty, and deprived of all possibility of washing away his (Vronsky) humiliation.

He (Vronsky) felt thrust out of the beaten track along which he (Vronsky) had so proudly and lightly walked till then. All the habits and rules of his (Vronsky) life that had seemed so firm, had turned out suddenly false and inapplicable.

The betrayed husband, who had figured till that time as a pitiful creature, an incidental and somewhat ludicrous obstacle to his (husband) happiness, had suddenly been summoned by her (husband) herself, elevated to an awe-inspiring pinnacle, and on the pinnacle that husband had shown himself, not malignant, not false, not ludicrous, but kind and straightforward and large.

Vronsky could not but feel this, and the parts were suddenly reversed. Vronsky felt his (husband) elevation and his (husband) own abasement, his (husband) truth and his (husband) own falsehood.

He (husband) felt that the husband was magnanimous even in his (husband) sorrow, while he (husband) had been base and petty in his (husband) deceit.

But this sense of his (husband) own humiliation before the man he (husband) had unjustly despised made up only a small part of his (husband) misery.

He (husband) felt unutterably wretched now, for his (husband) passion for Anna, which had seemed to him (husband) of late to be growing cooler, now that he (husband) knew he (husband) had lost her (Anna) forever, was stronger than ever it had been.

He (husband) had seen all of her (Anna) in her (Anna) illness, had come to know her (Anna) very soul, and it seemed to him (husband) that he (husband) had never loved her (Anna) till then.

And now when he (husband) had learned to know her (Anna), to love her (Anna) as she (Anna) should be loved, he (husband) had been humiliated before her (Anna), and had lost her (Anna) forever, leaving with her (Anna) nothing of himself but a shameful memory.

Most terrible of all had been his (husband) ludicrous, shameful position when Alexey Alexandrovitch had pulled his (Alexandrovitch) hands away from his (Alexandrovitch) humiliated face.

He (Alexandrovitch) stood on the steps of the Karenins' house like one distraught, and did not know what to do. '' A sledge, sir?

On getting home, after three sleepless nights, Vronsky, without undressing, lay down flat on the sofa, clasping his (Alexandrovitch) hands and laying his (Alexandrovitch) head on them.

'' asked the porter. '' Yes, a sledge. '' His (Alexandrovitch) head was heavy. Images, memories, and ideas of the strangest description followed one another with extraordinary rapidity and vividness.

First it was the medicine he (Alexandrovitch) had poured out for the patient and spilt over the spoon, then the midwife's white hands, then the queer posture of Alexey Alexandrovitch on the floor beside the bed.

To forget!'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself with the serene confidence of a healthy man that if he (man) is tired and sleepy, he (man) will go to sleep at once.

'' To sleep! And the same instant his (man) head did begin to feel drowsy and he (man) began to drop off into forgetfulness.

The waves of the sea of unconsciousness had begun to meet over his (man) head, when all at once--it was as though a violent shock of electricity had passed over him (man).

He (man) started so that he (man) leaped up on the springs of the sofa, and leaning on his (man) arms got in a panic onto his (man) knees.

The heaviness in his (man) head and the weariness in his (man) limbs that he (man) had felt a minute before had suddenly gone.

You may trample me in the mud,'' he (man) heard Alexey Alexandrovitch's words and saw him (man) standing before him (man), and saw Anna's face with its burning flush and glittering eyes, gazing with love and tenderness not at him (man) but at Alexey Alexandrovitch; he (Alexandrovitch) saw his (Alexandrovitch) own, as he (Alexandrovitch) fancied, foolish and ludicrous figure when Alexey Alexandrovitch took his (Alexandrovitch) hands away from his (Alexandrovitch) face.

His (Alexandrovitch) eyes were wide open as though he (Alexandrovitch) had never been asleep. '' He (Alexandrovitch) stretched out his (Alexandrovitch) legs again and flung himself on the sofa in the same position and shut his (Alexandrovitch) eyes.

But with his (Alexandrovitch) eyes shut he (Alexandrovitch) saw more distinctly than ever Anna's face as it had been on the memorable evening before the races.

``To sleep! To forget!'' (he)
he (Alexandrovitch) repeated to himself. '' That is not and will not be, and she (Anna) wants to wipe it out of her (Anna) memory.

But I cannot live without it. How can we be reconciled? how can we be reconciled? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said aloud, and unconsciously began to repeat these words.

This repetition checked the rising up of fresh images and memories, which he (Alexandrovitch) felt were thronging in his (Alexandrovitch) brain. But repeating words did not check his (Alexandrovitch) imagination for long.

Again in extraordinarily rapid succession his (Alexandrovitch) best moments rose before his (Alexandrovitch) mind, and then his (Alexandrovitch) recent humiliation.

``Take away his (Alexandrovitch) hands,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
Anna's voice says.

He (Alexandrovitch) still lay down, trying to sleep, though he (Alexandrovitch) felt there was not the smallest hope of it, and kept repeating stray words from some chain of thought, trying by this to check the rising flood of fresh images.

He (Alexandrovitch) listened, and heard in a strange, mad whisper words repeated:

``I did not appreciate it, did not make enough of it.

He (Alexandrovitch) takes away his (Alexandrovitch) hands and feels the shamestruck and idiotic expression of his (Alexandrovitch) face. I did not appreciate it, did not make enough of it.

What makes men go out of their minds; what makes men shoot themselves?'' (He)

he (Alexandrovitch) answered himself, and opening his (Alexandrovitch) eyes, he (Alexandrovitch) saw with wonder an embroidered cushion beside him (Alexandrovitch), worked by Varya, his (Alexandrovitch) brother's wife.

'' '' What's this? Am I going out of my mind? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself. '' Perhaps. He (Alexandrovitch) touched the tassel of the cushion, and tried to think of Varya, of when he (Alexandrovitch) had seen her (Varya) last.

He (Alexandrovitch) moved the cushion up, and pressed his (Alexandrovitch) head into it, but he (Alexandrovitch) had to make an effort to keep his (Alexandrovitch) eyes shut.

But to think of anything extraneous was an agonizing effort. '' No, I must sleep!'' He (Alexandrovitch) jumped up and sat down.

'' That's all over for me,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself. '' I must think what to do. What is left? ''

His (Alexandrovitch) mind rapidly ran through his (Alexandrovitch) life apart from his (Alexandrovitch) love of Anna. '' Ambition? Serpuhovskoy? Society? The court? '' He (Alexandrovitch) could not come to a pause anywhere.

He (Alexandrovitch) got up from the sofa, took off his (Alexandrovitch) coat, undid his (Alexandrovitch) belt, and uncovering his (Alexandrovitch) hairy chest to breathe more freely, walked up and down the room.

All of it had had meaning before, but now there was no reality in it. '' This is how people go mad,'' he (Alexandrovitch) repeated,

``and how they shoot themselves...to escape humiliation,'' (he)
he (Alexandrovitch) added slowly.

He (Alexandrovitch) went to the door and closed it, then with fixed eyes and clenched teeth he (Alexandrovitch) went up to the table, took a revolver, looked round him (Alexandrovitch), turned it to a loaded barrel, and sank into thought.

For two minutes, his (Alexandrovitch) head bent forward with an expression of an intense effort of thought, he (Alexandrovitch) stood with the revolver in his (Alexandrovitch) hand, motionless, thinking.

Of course,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself, as though a logical, continuous, and clear chain of reasoning had brought him (Alexandrovitch) to an indubitable conclusion.

In reality this

``of course,'' (him)
that seemed convincing to him (Alexandrovitch), was simply the result of exactly the same circle of memories and images through which he (Alexandrovitch) had passed ten times already during the last hour--memories of happiness lost forever.

'' There was the same conception of the senselessness of everything to come in life, the same consciousness of humiliation. Even the sequence of these images and emotions was the same.

Of course,'' he (Alexandrovitch) repeated, when for the third time his (Alexandrovitch) thought passed again round the same spellbound circle of memories and images, and pulling the revolver to the left side of his (Alexandrovitch) chest, and clutching it vigorously with his (Alexandrovitch) whole hand, as it were, squeezing it in his (Alexandrovitch) fist, he (Alexandrovitch) pulled the trigger.

He (Alexandrovitch) tried to clutch at the edge of the table, dropped the revolver, staggered, and sat down on the ground, looking about him (Alexandrovitch) in astonishment.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not recognize his (Alexandrovitch) room, looking up from the ground, at the bent legs of the table, at the wastepaper basket, and the tiger-skin rug.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) did not hear the sound of the shot, but a violent blow on his (Alexandrovitch) chest sent him (Alexandrovitch) reeling. The hurried, creaking steps of his (Alexandrovitch) servant coming through the drawing room brought him (Alexandrovitch) to his (Alexandrovitch) senses.

He (Alexandrovitch) made an effort at thought, and was aware that he (Alexandrovitch) was on the floor; and seeing blood on the tiger-skin rug and on his (Alexandrovitch) arm, he (Alexandrovitch) knew he (Alexandrovitch) had shot himself.

Still feeling for it, he (Alexandrovitch) stretched out to the other side, and not being strong enough to keep his (Alexandrovitch) balance, fell over, streaming with blood.

The elegant, whiskered manservant, who used to be continually complaining to his (Alexandrovitch) acquaintances of the delicacy of his (Alexandrovitch) nerves, was so panic-stricken on seeing his (Alexandrovitch) master lying on the floor, that he (Alexandrovitch) left him (Alexandrovitch) losing blood while he (Alexandrovitch) ran for assistance.

An hour later Varya, his (Alexandrovitch) brother's wife, had arrived, and with the assistance of three doctors, whom she (Varya) had sent for in all directions, and who all appeared at the same moment, she (Varya) got the wounded man to bed, and remained to nurse him (man).

The mistake made by Alexey Alexandrovitch in that, when preparing for seeing his (Alexandrovitch) wife, he (Alexandrovitch) had overlooked the possibility that her (wife) repentance might be sincere, and he (Alexandrovitch) might forgive her (wife), and she (wife) might not die--this mistake was two months after his (Alexandrovitch) return from Moscow brought home to him (Alexandrovitch) in all its significance.

But the mistake made by him (Alexandrovitch) had arisen not simply from his (Alexandrovitch) having overlooked that contingency, but also from the fact that until that day of his (Alexandrovitch) interview with his (Alexandrovitch) dying wife, he (Alexandrovitch) had not known his (Alexandrovitch) own heart.

At his (Alexandrovitch) sick wife's bedside he (Alexandrovitch) had for the first time in his (Alexandrovitch) life given way to that feeling of sympathetic suffering always roused in him (Alexandrovitch) by the sufferings of others, and hitherto looked on by him (Alexandrovitch) with shame as a harmful weakness.

And pity for her (wife), and remorse for having desired her (wife) death, and most of all, the joy of forgiveness, made him (Alexandrovitch) at once conscious, not simply of the relief of his (Alexandrovitch) own sufferings, but of a spiritual peace he (Alexandrovitch) had never experienced before.

He (Alexandrovitch) suddenly felt that the very thing that was the source of his (Alexandrovitch) sufferings had become the source of his (Alexandrovitch) spiritual joy; that what had seemed insoluble while he (Alexandrovitch) was judging, blaming, and hating, had become clear and simple when he (Alexandrovitch) forgave and loved.

``Idiotic! Missed! '' (he)
he (Alexandrovitch) said, fumbling after the revolver. The revolver was close beside him (Alexandrovitch)--he (Alexandrovitch) sought further off. Chapter 19 He (Alexandrovitch) forgave his (Alexandrovitch) wife and pitied her (wife) for her (wife) sufferings and her (wife) remorse.

He (Alexandrovitch) forgave Vronsky, and pitied him (Alexandrovitch), especially after reports reached him (Alexandrovitch) of his (Alexandrovitch) despairing action. He (Alexandrovitch) felt more for his (Alexandrovitch) son than before.

And he (Alexandrovitch) blamed himself now for having taken too little interest in him (Alexandrovitch). But for the little newborn baby he (Alexandrovitch) felt a quite peculiar sentiment, not of pity, only, but of tenderness.

At first, from a feeling of compassion alone, he (Alexandrovitch) had been interested in the delicate little creature, who was not his (Alexandrovitch) child, and who was cast on one side during her (wife) mother's illness, and would certainly have died if he (Alexandrovitch) had not troubled about her (wife), and he (Alexandrovitch) did not himself observe how fond he (Alexandrovitch) became of her (wife).

He (Alexandrovitch) would go into the nursery several times a day, and sit there for a long while, so that the nurses, who were at first afraid of him (Alexandrovitch), got quite used to his (Alexandrovitch) presence.

Sometimes for half an hour at a stretch he (Alexandrovitch) would sit silently gazing at the saffron-red, downy, wrinkled face of the sleeping baby, watching the movements of the frowning brows, and the fat little hands, with clenched fingers, that rubbed the little eyes and nose.

At such moments particularly, Alexey Alexandrovitch had a sense of perfect peace and inward harmony, and saw nothing extraordinary in his (Alexandrovitch) position, nothing that ought to be changed.

But as time went on, he (Alexandrovitch) saw more and more distinctly that however natural the position now seemed to him (Alexandrovitch), he (Alexandrovitch) would not long be allowed to remain in it.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that besides the blessed spiritual force controlling his (Alexandrovitch) soul, there was another, a brutal force, as powerful, or more powerful, which controlled his (Alexandrovitch) life, and that this force would not allow him (Alexandrovitch) that humble peace he (Alexandrovitch) longed for.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that everyone was looking at him (Alexandrovitch) with inquiring wonder, that he (Alexandrovitch) was not understood, and that something was expected of him (Alexandrovitch).

When the softening effect of the near approach of death had passed away, Alexey Alexandrovitch began to notice that Anna was afraid of him (Alexandrovitch), ill at ease with him (Alexandrovitch), and could not look him (Alexandrovitch) straight in the face.

She (Anna) seemed to be wanting, and not daring, to tell him (Alexandrovitch) something; and as though foreseeing their present relations could not continue, she (Anna) seemed to be expecting something from him (Alexandrovitch).

Above all, he (Alexandrovitch) felt the instability and unnaturalness of his (Alexandrovitch) relations with his (Alexandrovitch) wife. Towards the end of February it happened that Anna's baby daughter, who had been named Anna too, fell ill.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was in the nursery in the morning, and leaving orders for the doctor to be sent for, he (Alexandrovitch) went to his (Alexandrovitch) office.

Going into the hall he (Alexandrovitch) saw a handsome groom, in a braided livery and a bear fur cape, holding a white fur cloak.

On finishing his (Alexandrovitch) work, he (Alexandrovitch) returned home at four. '' Who is here?'' asked Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' Princess Elizaveta Federovna Tverskaya,'' the groom answered, and it seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch that he (Alexandrovitch) grinned.

During all this difficult time Alexey Alexandrovitch had noticed that his (Alexandrovitch) worldly acquaintances, especially women, took a peculiar interest in him (Alexandrovitch) and his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

All these acquaintances he (Alexandrovitch) observed with difficulty concealing their mirth at something; the same mirth that he (Alexandrovitch) had perceived in the lawyer's eyes, and just now in the eyes of this groom.

Everyone seemed, somehow, hugely delighted, as though they had just been at a wedding. When they met him (groom), with ill-disguised enjoyment they inquired after his (groom) wife's health.

The presence of Princess Tverskaya was unpleasant to Alexey Alexandrovitch from the memories associated with her (Tverskaya), and also because he (Alexandrovitch) disliked her (Tverskaya), and he (Alexandrovitch) went straight to the nursery.

In the day nursery Seryozha, leaning on the table with his (Alexandrovitch) legs on a chair, was drawing and chatting away merrily.

The English governess, who had during Anna's illness replaced the French one, was sitting near the boy knitting a shawl. She (Anna) hurriedly got up, curtseyed, and pulled Seryozha.

Alexey Alexandrovitch stroked his (Alexandrovitch) son's hair, answered the governess's inquiries about his (Alexandrovitch) wife, and asked what the doctor had said of the baby.

'' The doctor said it was nothing serious, and he (doctor) ordered a bath, sir.'' '' But she (wife) is still in pain,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, listening to the baby's screaming in the next room.

'' I think it's the wet-nurse, sir,'' the Englishwoman said firmly. '' What makes you think so? '' he (Alexandrovitch) asked, stopping short.

'' It's just as it was at Countess Paul's, sir. They gave the baby medicine, and it turned out that the baby was simply hungry:

the nurse had no milk, sir. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, and after standing still a few seconds he (Alexandrovitch) went in at the other door.

The baby was lying with its head thrown back, stiffening itself in the nurse's arms, and would not take the plump breast offered it; and it never ceased screaming in spite of the double hushing of the wet-nurse and the other nurse, who was bending over her (nurse).

'' Still no better?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' She (nurse)'s very restless,'' answered the nurse in a whisper. '' Miss Edwarde says that perhaps the wet-nurse has no milk,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said.

'' I think so too, Alexey Alexandrovitch.'' '' Then why didn't you say so?'' '' Who's one to say it to?

Anna Arkadyevna still ill...'' said the nurse discontentedly. The nurse was an old servant of the family. And in her (nurse) simple words there seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch an allusion to his (Alexandrovitch) position.

The nurse, with a gesture of despair, went to it, took it from the wet-nurse's arms, and began walking up and down, rocking it.

The baby screamed louder than ever, struggling and sobbing. '' You must ask the doctor to examine the wet-nurse,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

The smartly dressed and healthy-looking nurse, frightened at the idea of losing her (nurse) place, muttered something to herself, and covering her (nurse) bosom, smiled contemptuously at the idea of doubts being cast on her (nurse) abundance of milk.

In that smile, too, Alexey Alexandrovitch saw a sneer at his (Alexandrovitch) position. '' Luckless child!'' said the nurse, hushing the baby, and still walking up and down with it.

When the child at last was still, and had been put in a deep bed, and the nurse, after smoothing the little pillow, had left her (nurse), Alexey Alexandrovitch got up, and walking awkwardly on tiptoe, approached the baby.

For a minute he (Alexandrovitch) was still, and with the same despondent face gazed at the baby; but all at once a smile

, that moved his (Alexandrovitch) hair and the skin of his (Alexandrovitch) forehead, came out on his (Alexandrovitch) face, and he (Alexandrovitch) went as softly out of the room.

In the dining room he (Alexandrovitch) rang the bell, and told the servant who came in to send again for the doctor.

He (doctor) felt vexed with his (doctor) wife for not being anxious about this exquisite baby, and in this vexed humor he (doctor) had no wish to go to her (wife); he (doctor) had no wish, either, to see Princess Betsy.

But his (doctor) wife might wonder why he (doctor) did not go to her (wife) as usual; and so, overcoming his (doctor) disinclination, he (doctor) went towards the bedroom.

As he (doctor) walked over the soft rug towards the door, he (doctor) could not help overhearing a conversation he (doctor) did not want to hear.

Alexey Alexandrovitch sat down, and with a despondent and suffering face watched the nurse walking to and fro. '' If he (Alexandrovitch) hadn't been going away, I could have understood your answer and his (Alexandrovitch) too.

But your husband ought to be above that,'' Betsy was saying. '' It's not for my husband; for myself I don't wish it.

Don't say that! '' answered Anna's excited voice. '' Yes, but you must care to say good-bye to a man who has shot himself on your account...''

'' That's just why I don't want to. '' With a dismayed and guilty expression, Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped and would have gone back unobserved.

But reflecting that this would be undignified, he (Alexandrovitch) turned back again, and clearing his (Alexandrovitch) throat, he (Alexandrovitch) went up to the bedroom.

Anna, in a gray dressing gown, with a crop of short clustering black curls on her (Anna) round head, was sitting on a settee.

The eagerness died out of her (Anna) face, as it always did, at the sight of her (Anna) husband; she (Anna) dropped her (Anna) head and looked round uneasily at Betsy.

Betsy, dressed in the height of the latest fashion, in a hat that towered somewhere over her (Betsy) head like a shade on a lamp, in a blue dress with violet crossway stripes slanting one way on the bodice and the other way on the skirt, was sitting beside Anna, her (Anna) tall flat figure held erect.

The voices were silent, and he (husband) went in. Bowing her (Anna) head, she (Anna) greeted Alexey Alexandrovitch with an ironical smile.

``Ah! '' (she)
she (Anna) said, as though surprised.

'' I'm very glad you're at home. You never put in an appearance anywhere, and I haven't seen you ever since Anna has been ill.

she (Anna) said, with a meaning and affable air, as though she (Anna) were bestowing an order of magnanimity on him (Alexandrovitch) for his (Alexandrovitch) conduct to his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

I have heard all about it--your anxiety. Yes, you're a wonderful husband! '' Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed frigidly, and kissing his (Alexandrovitch) wife's hand, asked how she (wife) was.

'' Better, I think,'' she (wife) said, avoiding his (Alexandrovitch) eyes. '' But you've rather a feverish-looking color,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, laying stress on the word

``feverish.'' (he)

'' We've been talking too much,'' said Betsy. '' I feel it's selfishness on my part, and I am going away.

'' She (Betsy) got up, but Anna, suddenly flushing, quickly caught at her (Anna) hand. '' No, wait a minute, please. I must tell you...no, you.

'' she (Anna) turned to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and her (Anna) neck and brow were suffused with crimson. '' I won't and can't keep anything secret from you,'' she (Anna) said.

Alexey Alexandrovitch cracked his (Alexandrovitch) fingers and bowed his (Alexandrovitch) head. '' Betsy's been telling me that Count Vronsky wants to come here to say good-bye before his (Alexandrovitch) departure for Tashkend.

She (Betsy) did not look at her (Betsy) husband, and was evidently in haste to have everything out, however hard it might be for her (Betsy).

'' '' I told her (Betsy) I could not receive him (husband).'' '' You said, my dear, that it would depend on Alexey Alexandrovitch,'' Betsy corrected her (Betsy).

'' Oh, no, I can't receive him (Alexandrovitch); and what object would there... '' She (Betsy) stopped suddenly, and glanced inquiringly at her (Betsy) husband -LRB-he (husband) did not look at her (Betsy)-RRB-.

Her (Betsy) first impulse was to jerk back her (Betsy) hand from the damp hand with big swollen veins that sought hers, but with an obvious effort to control herself she (Betsy) pressed his (husband) hand.

'' In short, I don't wish it... '' Alexey Alexandrovitch advanced and would have taken her (Betsy) hand. '' I am very grateful to you for your confidence, but...

he (Alexandrovitch) said, feeling with confusion and annoyance that what he (Alexandrovitch) could decide easily and clearly by himself, he (Alexandrovitch) could not discuss before Princess Tverskaya, who to him (Alexandrovitch) stood for the incarnation of that brute force which would inevitably control him (Alexandrovitch) in the life he (Alexandrovitch) led in the eyes of the world, and hinder him (Alexandrovitch) from giving way to his (Alexandrovitch) feeling of love and forgiveness.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) stopped short, looking at Princess Tverskaya. '' Well, good-bye, my darling,'' said Betsy, getting up. She (Betsy) kissed Anna, and went out.

I know you are a truly magnanimous man,'' said Betsy, stopping in the little drawing-room, and with special warmth shaking hands with him (man) once more.

Alexey Alexandrovitch escorted her (Betsy) out. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch! '' I am an outsider, but I so love her (Betsy) and respect you that I venture to advise.

Receive him (Alexandrovitch). Alexey Vronsky is the soul of honor, and he (Vronsky) is going away to Tashkend.''

``Thank you, princess, for your sympathy and advice.

He (Vronsky) said this from habit, lifting his (Vronsky) brows with dignity, and reflected immediately that whatever his (Vronsky) words might be, there could be no dignity in his (Vronsky) position.

But the question of whether my wife can or cannot see anyone she (wife) must decide herself.'' (he)

And he (Vronsky) saw this by the suppressed, malicious, and ironical smile with which Betsy glanced at him (Vronsky) after this phrase.

She (Betsy) was lying down, but hearing his (Vronsky) steps she (Betsy) sat up hastily in her (Betsy) former attitude, and looked in a scared way at him (Vronsky).

Chapter 20 Alexey Alexandrovitch took leave of Betsy in the drawing room, and went to his (Alexandrovitch) wife. He (Alexandrovitch) saw she (Betsy) had been crying.

'' I am very grateful for your confidence in me. '' He (Alexandrovitch) repeated gently in Russian the phrase he (Alexandrovitch) had said in Betsy's presence in French, and sat down beside her (Betsy).

When he (Alexandrovitch) spoke to her (Betsy) in Russian, using the Russian

``thou'' (Russian)
of intimacy and affection, it was insufferably irritating to Anna.

I, too, imagine that since he (Russian) is going away, there is no sort of necessity for Count Vronsky to come here.

'' And I am very grateful for your decision. However, if...'' '' But I've said so already, so why repeat it?

No sort of necessity,'' she (Anna) thought,

``for a man to come and say good-bye to the woman he (man) loves, for whom he (man) was ready to ruin himself, and has ruined himself, and who cannot live without him (man).

'' (she)

Anna suddenly interrupted him (man) with an irritation she (Anna) could not succeed in repressing. '' No sort of necessity! '' she (Anna) compressed her (Anna) lips, and dropped her (Anna) burning eyes to his (man) hands with their swollen veins.

They were rubbing each other.

``Let us never speak of it,'' (she)
she (Anna) added more calmly. '' I have left this question to you to decide, and I am very glad to see...

That my wish coincides with your own,'' she (Anna) finished quickly, exasperated at his (man) talking so slowly while she (Anna) knew beforehand all he (man) would say.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch was beginning. '' '' Yes,'' he (Alexandrovitch) assented;

``and Princess Tverskaya's interference in the most difficult private affairs is utterly uncalled for.

She (Princess) especially...'' (he)

``I don't believe a word of what's said about her (Princess),'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna quickly. '' I know she (Anna) really cares for me.

She (Anna) played nervously with the tassel of her (Anna) dressing-gown, glancing at him (Alexandrovitch) with that torturing sensation of physical repulsion for which she (Anna) blamed herself, though she (Anna) could not control it.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed and said nothing. Her (Anna) only desire now was to be rid of his (Alexandrovitch) oppressive presence. '' I have just sent for the doctor,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' I am very well; what do I want the doctor for?'' '' No, the little one cries, and they say the nurse hasn't enough milk.

''

``Why didn't you let me nurse her (nurse), when I begged to? Anyway'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
-LRB-Alexey Alexandrovitch knew what was meant by that
``anyway'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
-RRB-,
``she (nurse)'s a baby, and they're killing her (nurse).

'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

She (nurse) rang the bell and ordered the baby to be brought her (nurse). '' I begged to nurse her (nurse), I wasn't allowed to, and now I'm blamed for it.''

``I don't blame...'' (unknown)
``Yes, you do blame me! My God! why didn't I die! '' (she)
And she (nurse) broke into sobs. ''

Forgive me, I'm nervous, I'm unjust,'' she (nurse) said, controlling herself,

``but do go away...'' (she)
``No, it can't go on like this,'' (she)
Alexey Alexandrovitch said to himself decidedly as he (Alexandrovitch) left his (Alexandrovitch) wife's room.

Never had the impossibility of his (Alexandrovitch) position in the world's eyes, and his (Alexandrovitch) wife's hatred of him (Alexandrovitch), and altogether the might of that mysterious brutal force that guided his (Alexandrovitch) life against his (Alexandrovitch) spiritual inclinations, and exacted conformity with its decrees and change in his (Alexandrovitch) attitude to his (Alexandrovitch) wife, been presented to him (Alexandrovitch) with such distinctness as that day.

He (Alexandrovitch) saw clearly that all the world and his (Alexandrovitch) wife expected of him (Alexandrovitch) something, but what exactly, he (Alexandrovitch) could not make out.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that this was rousing in his (Alexandrovitch) soul a feeling of anger destructive of his (Alexandrovitch) peace of mind and of all the good of his (Alexandrovitch) achievement.

He (Alexandrovitch) believed that for Anna herself it would be better to break off all relations with Vronsky; but if they all thought this out of the question, he (Alexandrovitch) was even ready to allow these relations to be renewed, so long as the children were not disgraced, and he (Alexandrovitch) was not deprived of them nor forced to change his (Alexandrovitch) position.

Bad as this might be, it was anyway better than a rupture, which would put her (Anna) in a hopeless and shameful position, and deprive him (Alexandrovitch) of everything he (Alexandrovitch) cared for.

But he (Alexandrovitch) felt helpless; he (Alexandrovitch) knew beforehand that every one was against him (Alexandrovitch), and that he (Alexandrovitch) would not be allowed to do what seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) now so natural and right, but would be forced to do what was wrong, though it seemed the proper thing to them.

Before Betsy had time to walk out of the drawing-room, she (Betsy) was met in the doorway by Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just come from Yeliseev's, where a consignment of fresh oysters had been received.

Chapter 21 '' Ah! princess! what a delightful meeting! '' he (Alexandrovitch) began. '' I've been to see you.''

``A meeting for one minute, for I'm going,'' (Betsy/Tverskaya/Betsy Tverskaya)
said Betsy, smiling and putting on her (Betsy) glove.

'' Don't put on your glove yet, princess; let me kiss your hand. There's nothing I'm so thankful to the revival of the old fashions for as the kissing the hand.

'' He (Alexandrovitch) kissed Betsy's hand. '' When shall we see each other?'' '' You don't deserve it,'' answered Betsy, smiling. ''

Oh, yes, I deserve a great deal, for I've become a most serious person. I don't only manage my own affairs, but other people's too,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, with a significant expression.

'' Oh, I'm so glad! '' answered Betsy, at once understanding that he (Alexandrovitch) was speaking of Anna. And going back into the drawing room, they stood in a corner.

``I'm so glad you think so,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, shaking his (Alexandrovitch) head with a serious and sympathetically distressed expression,
``that's what I've come to Petersburg for.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

He (Alexandrovitch)'s killing her (Anna),'' said Betsy in a whisper full of meaning. '' It's impossible, impossible...'' '' '' The whole town's talking of it,'' she (Betsy) said.

'' It's an impossible position. She (Betsy) pines and pines away. He (Alexandrovitch) doesn't understand that she (Betsy)'s one of those women who can't trifle with their feelings.

One of two things: either let him (Alexandrovitch) take her (Betsy) away, act with energy, or give her (Betsy) a divorce. This is stifling her (Betsy).''

'' Yes, yes...just so... '' Oblonsky said, sighing. '' That's what I've come for. At least not solely for that ...

I've been made a Kammerherr ; of course, one has to say thank you. But the chief thing was having to settle this.''

After accompanying Betsy to the outside hall, once more kissing her (Betsy) hand above the glove, at the point where the pulse beats, and murmuring to her (Betsy) such unseemly nonsense that she (Betsy) did not know whether to laugh or be angry, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to his (Betsy) sister.

Although he (Betsy) happened to be bubbling over with good spirits, Stepan Arkadyevitch immediately and quite naturally fell into the sympathetic, poetically emotional tone which harmonized with her (sister) mood.

'' Well, God help you!'' said Betsy. He (God) found her (Betsy) in tears. He (God) asked her (Betsy) how she (Betsy) was, and how she (Betsy) had spent the morning.

'' Very, very miserably. Today and this morning and all past days and days to come,'' she (Betsy) said. '' I think you're giving way to pessimism.

``I have heard it said that women love men even for their vices,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
Anna began suddenly,
``but I hate him (God) for his (God) virtues.

You must rouse yourself, you must look life in the face. I know it's hard, but...'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

I can't live with him (God).

Do you understand? the sight of him (God) has a physical effect on me, it makes me beside myself. I can't, I can't live with him (God).

I have been unhappy, and used to think one couldn't be more unhappy, but the awful state of things I am going through now, I could never have conceived.

Would you believe it, that knowing he (God)'s a good man, a splendid man, that I'm not worth his (God) little finger, still I hate him (God).

What am I to do? I hate him (God) for his (God) generosity. And there's nothing left for me but... '' She (I) would have said death, but Stepan Arkadyevitch would not let her (I) finish.

'' You are ill and overwrought,'' he (God) said;

``believe me, you're exaggerating dreadfully. There's nothing so terrible in it. '' (he)
And Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled.

No one else in Stepan Arkadyevitch's place, having to do with such despair, would have ventured to smile -LRB-the smile would have seemed brutal-RRB-; but in his (God) smile there was so much of sweetness and almost feminine tenderness that his (God) smile did not wound, but softened and soothed.

His (God) gentle, soothing words and smiles were as soothing and softening as almond oil. And Anna soon felt this. '' No, Stiva,'' she (Anna) said,

``I'm lost, lost! worse than lost!

I can't say yet that all is over; on the contrary, I feel that it's not over. I'm an overstrained string that must snap.

But it's not ended yet...and it will have a fearful end.'' (she)

'' No matter, we must let the string be loosened, little by little.

Again he (Stiva) knew from her (Anna) terrified eyes that this one way of escape in her (Anna) thought was death, and he (Stiva) would not let her (Anna) say it.

There's no position from which there is no way of escape. ''

``I have thought, and thought. Only one...'' (he)
'' Not at all,'' he (Stiva) said.

``Listen to me. You can't see your own position as I can. Let me tell you candidly my opinion. '' (he)
Again he (Stiva) smiled discreetly his (Stiva) almond-oil smile.

'' I'll begin from the beginning. You married a man twenty years older than yourself. You married him (man) without love and not knowing what love was.

It was a mistake, let's admit. ''

``A fearful mistake!'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna. '' But I repeat, it's an accomplished fact. Then you had, let us say, the misfortune to love a man not your husband.

That was a misfortune; but that, too, is an accomplished fact. And your husband knew it and forgave it. '' He (husband) stopped at each sentence, waiting for her (Anna) to object, but she (Anna) made no answer.

'' That's so. Now the question is: can you go on living with your husband? Do you wish it? Does he (husband) wish it?''

``I know nothing, nothing.'' (him)
'' But you said yourself that you can't endure him (husband).'' '' No, I didn't say so. I deny it.

I can't tell, I don't know anything about it.'' '' Yes, but let...''

``You can't understand. I feel I'm lying head downwards in a sort of pit, but I ought not to save myself.

And I can't ... '' (unknown)

``Never mind, we'll slip something under and pull you out. I understand you: I understand that you can't take it on yourself to express your wishes, your feelings.'' (I)

'' There's nothing, nothing I wish...except for it to be all over.'' '' But he (I) sees this and knows it. And do you suppose it weighs on him (I) any less than on you?

You're wretched, he (I)'s wretched, and what good can come of it? while divorce would solve the difficulty completely. '' With some effort Stepan Arkadyevitch brought out his (I) central idea, and looked significantly at her (I).

'' Don't speak, don't say a word! God grant only that I may speak as I feel. I'm going to him (God).

Chapter 22 Stepan Arkadyevitch, with the same somewhat solemn expression with which he (God) used to take his (God) presidential chair at his (God) board, walked into Alexey Alexandrovitch's room.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was walking about his (Alexandrovitch) room with his (Alexandrovitch) hands behind his (Alexandrovitch) back, thinking of just what Stepan Arkadyevitch had been discussing with his (Alexandrovitch) wife.

I'm not interrupting you?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, on the sight of his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law becoming suddenly aware of a sense of embarrassment unusual with him (Alexandrovitch).

To conceal this embarrassment he (Alexandrovitch) took out a cigarette case he (Alexandrovitch) had just bought that opened in a new way, and sniffing the leather, took a cigarette out of it.

'' Anna looked at him (Alexandrovitch) with dreamy, shining eyes, and said nothing. '' '' No. Do you want anything? '' Alexey Alexandrovitch asked without eagerness.

'' Yes, I wished... I wanted... yes, I wanted to talk to you,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, with surprise aware of an unaccustomed timidity.

This feeling was so unexpected and so strange that he (Alexandrovitch) did not believe it was the voice of conscience telling him (Alexandrovitch) that what he (Alexandrovitch) was meaning to do was wrong.

I hope you believe in my love for my sister and my sincere affection and respect for you,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, reddening.

Stepan Arkadyevitch made an effort and struggled with the timidity that had come over him (Alexandrovitch). '' Alexey Alexandrovitch stood still and said nothing, but his (Alexandrovitch) face struck Stepan Arkadyevitch by its expression of an unresisting sacrifice.

I wanted to have a little talk with you about my sister and your mutual position,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, still struggling with an unaccustomed constraint.

Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled mournfully, looked at his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law, and without answering went up to the table, took from it an unfinished letter, and handed it to his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law.

And here is what I had begun writing, thinking I could say it better by letter, and that my presence irritates her (sister),'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, as he (Alexandrovitch) gave him (Alexandrovitch) the letter.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took the letter, looked with incredulous surprise at the lusterless eyes fixed so immovably on him (Alexandrovitch), and began to read.

'' I intended... '' I think unceasingly of the same thing. '' I see that my presence is irksome to you.

I don't blame you, and God is my witness that on seeing you at the time of your illness I resolved with my whole heart to forget all that had passed between us and to begin a new life.

I do not regret, and shall never regret, what I have done; but I have desired one thing--your good, the good of your soul--and now I see I have not attained that.

Painful as it is to me to believe it, I see that it is so, and cannot be otherwise. Tell me yourself what will give you true happiness and peace to your soul.

Stepan Arkadyevitch handed back the letter, and with the same surprise continued looking at his (your) brother-in-law, not knowing what to say.

This silence was so awkward for both of them that Stepan Arkadyevitch's lips began twitching nervously, while he (your) still gazed without speaking at Karenin's face.

I put myself entirely in your hands, and trust to your feeling of what's right. '' '' That's what I wanted to say to her (yourself),'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, turning away.

'' Yes, yes...'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, not able to answer for the tears that were choking him (Alexandrovitch). '' Yes, yes, I understand you,'' he (Alexandrovitch) brought out at last.

'' I want to know what she (yourself) would like,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' I am afraid she (yourself) does not understand her (yourself) own position.

If she (yourself) were to read this letter, she (yourself) would be incapable of saying anything, she (yourself) would only hang her (yourself) head lower than ever.''

She (yourself) is not a judge,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, recovering himself. '' She (yourself) is crushed, simply crushed by your generosity. '' Yes, but what's to be done in that case?

``If you will allow me to give my opinion, I think that it lies with you to point out directly the steps you consider necessary to end the position.'' (unknown)

how explain, how find out her (yourself) wishes?'' '' So you consider it must be ended? '' Alexey Alexandrovitch interrupted him (Alexandrovitch). ''

But how?'' he (Alexandrovitch) added, with a gesture of his (Alexandrovitch) hands before his (Alexandrovitch) eyes not usual with him (Alexandrovitch). '' I see no possible way out of it.

'' '' There is some way of getting out of every position,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, standing up and becoming more cheerful.

'' There was a time when you thought of breaking off.... If you are convinced now that you cannot make each other happy...

But suppose that I agree to everything, that I want nothing: what way is there of getting out of our position?''

If you care to know my opinion,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch with the same smile of softening, almond-oil tenderness with which he (I) had been talking to Anna.

His (I) kindly smile was so winning that Alexey Alexandrovitch, feeling his (Alexandrovitch) own weakness and unconsciously swayed by it, was ready to believe what Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying.

But one thing is possible, one thing she (Anna) might desire,'' he (Alexandrovitch) went on,

``that is the cessation of your relations and all memories associated with them.

'' (he)

``Happiness may be variously understood. '' (She)
'' She (Anna) will never speak out about it. To my thinking, in your position what's essential is the formation of a new attitude to one another.

And that can only rest on a basis of freedom on both sides.''

``Divorce,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
Alexey Alexandrovitch interrupted, in a tone of aversion.

That is from every point of view the most rational course for married people who find themselves in the position you are in.

'' Yes, I imagine that divorce--yes, divorce,'' Stepan Arkadyevitch repeated, reddening. '' What can be done if married people find that life is impossible for them together?

That may always happen. '' Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed heavily and closed his (Alexandrovitch) eyes. '' There's only one point to be considered: is either of the parties desirous of forming new ties?

If not, it is very simple,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, feeling more and more free from constraint. Alexey Alexandrovitch, scowling with emotion, muttered something to himself, and made no answer.

All that seemed so simple to Stepan Arkadyevitch, Alexey Alexandrovitch had thought over thousands of times. And, so far from being simple, it all seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) utterly impossible.

Divorce, the details of which he (Alexandrovitch) knew by this time, seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) now out of the question, because the sense of his (Alexandrovitch) own dignity and respect for religion forbade his (Alexandrovitch) taking upon himself a fictitious charge of adultery, and still more suffering his (Alexandrovitch) wife, pardoned and beloved by him (Alexandrovitch), to be caught in the fact and put to public shame.

Divorce appeared to him (Alexandrovitch) impossible also on other still more weighty grounds. What would become of his (Alexandrovitch) son in case of a divorce?

The divorced mother would have her (mother) own illegitimate family, in which his (Alexandrovitch) position as a stepson and his (Alexandrovitch) education would not be good.

To leave him (Alexandrovitch) with his (Alexandrovitch) mother was out of the question. Keep him (Alexandrovitch) with him (Alexandrovitch)? He (Alexandrovitch) knew that would be an act of vengeance on his (Alexandrovitch) part, and that he (Alexandrovitch) did not want.

But apart from this, what more than all made divorce seem impossible to Alexey Alexandrovitch was, that by consenting to a divorce he (Alexandrovitch) would be completely ruining Anna.

The saying of Darya Alexandrovna at Moscow, that in deciding on a divorce he (Alexandrovitch) was thinking of himself, and not considering that by this he (Alexandrovitch) would be ruining her (Anna) irrevocably, had sunk into his (Alexandrovitch) heart.

And connecting this saying with his (Alexandrovitch) forgiveness of her (Anna), with his (Alexandrovitch) devotion to the children, he (Alexandrovitch) understood it now in his (Alexandrovitch) own way.

To consent to a divorce, to give her (Anna) her (Anna) freedom, meant in his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts to take from himself the last tie that bound him (Alexandrovitch) to life--the children whom he (Alexandrovitch) loved; and to take from her (Anna) the last prop that stayed her (Anna) on the path of right, to thrust her (Anna) down to her (Anna) ruin.

If she (Anna) were divorced, he (Alexandrovitch) knew she (Anna) would join her (Anna) life to Vronsky's, and their tie would be an illegitimate and criminal one, since a wife, by the interpretation of the ecclesiastical law, could not marry while her (wife) husband was living.

She (wife) will join him (husband), and in a year or two he (husband) will throw her (wife) over, or she (wife) will form a new tie,'' thought Alexey Alexandrovitch.

He (Alexandrovitch) had thought it all over hundreds of times, and was convinced that a divorce was not at all simple, as Stepan Arkadyevitch had said, but was utterly impossible.

He (Alexandrovitch) did not believe a single word Stepan Arkadyevitch said to him (Alexandrovitch); to every word he (Alexandrovitch) had a thousand objections to make, but he (Alexandrovitch) listened to him (Alexandrovitch), feeling that his (Alexandrovitch) words were the expression of that mighty brutal force which controlled his (Alexandrovitch) life and to which he (Alexandrovitch) would have to submit.

'' '' And I, by agreeing to an unlawful divorce, shall be to blame for her (Arkadyevitch) ruin. '' '' The only question is on what terms you agree to give her (Arkadyevitch) a divorce.

She (Arkadyevitch) does not want anything, does not dare ask you for anything, she (Arkadyevitch) leaves it all to your generosity.'' '' My God, my God!

'' thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, remembering the details of divorce proceedings in which the husband took the blame on himself, and with just the same gesture with which Vronsky had done the same, he (Vronsky) hid his (Vronsky) face for shame in his (Vronsky) hands.

But if you think it over...''

thought Alexey Alexandrovitch.
