The thought of the harm caused to her (Anna) husband aroused in her (Anna) a feeling like repulsion, and akin to what a drowning man might feel who has shaken off another man clinging to him (man).

It was an evil action, of course, but it was the sole means of escape, and better not to brood over these fearful facts.

One consolatory reflection upon her (Anna) conduct had occurred to her (Anna) at the first moment of the final rupture, and when now she (Anna) recalled all the past, she (Anna) remembered that one reflection.

On the other side her (Anna) husband's unhappiness had given her (Anna) too much happiness to be regretted. That man did drown. ''

I too am suffering, and shall suffer; I am losing what I prized above everything--I am losing my good name and my son.

I have inevitably made that man wretched,'' she (Anna) thought;

``but I don't want to profit by his (man) misery. I have done wrong, and so I don't want happiness

, I don't want a divorce, and shall suffer from my shame and the separation from my child. '' (she)

But, however sincerely Anna had meant to suffer, she (Anna) was not suffering.

With the tact of which both had such a large share, they had succeeded in avoiding Russian ladies abroad, and so had never placed themselves in a false position, and everywhere they had met people who pretended that they perfectly understood their position, far better indeed than they did themselves.

The baby girl-- his (my) child--was so sweet, and had so won Anna's heart, since she (Anna) was all that was left her (Anna), that Anna rarely thought of her (Anna) son.

The desire for life, waxing stronger with recovered health, was so intense, and the conditions of life were so new and pleasant, that Anna felt unpardonably happy.

Shame there was not. Separation from the son she (Anna) loved--even that did not cause her (Anna) anguish in these early days. The more she (Anna) got to know Vronsky, the more she (Anna) loved him (Vronsky).

She (Anna) loved him (Vronsky) for himself, and for his (Vronsky) love for her (Anna). Her (Anna) complete ownership of him (Vronsky) was a continual joy to her (Anna).

His (Vronsky) presence was always sweet to her (Anna). All the traits of his (Vronsky) character, which she (Anna) learned to know better and better, were unutterably dear to her (Anna).

His (Vronsky) appearance, changed by his (Vronsky) civilian dress, was as fascinating to her (Anna) as though she (Anna) were some young girl in love.

In everything he (Vronsky) said, thought, and did, she (Anna) saw something particularly noble and elevated. Her (Anna) adoration of him (Vronsky) alarmed her (Anna) indeed; she (Anna) sought and could not find in him (Vronsky) anything not fine.

It seemed to her (Anna) that, knowing this, he (Vronsky) might sooner cease to love her (Anna); and she (Anna) dreaded nothing now so much as losing his (Vronsky) love, though she (Anna) had no grounds for fearing it.

She (Anna) dared not show him (Vronsky) her (Anna) sense of her (Anna) own insignificance beside him (Vronsky). But she (Anna) could not help being grateful to him (Vronsky) for his (Vronsky) attitude to her (Anna), and showing that she (Anna) appreciated it.

He (Vronsky), who had in her (Anna) opinion such a marked aptitude for a political career, in which he (Vronsky) would have been certain to play a leading part--he (Vronsky) had sacrificed his (Vronsky) ambition for her (Anna) sake, and never betrayed the slightest regret.

He (Vronsky) was more lovingly respectful to her (Anna) than ever, and the constant care that she (Anna) should not feel the awkwardness of her (Anna) position never deserted him (Vronsky) for a single instant.

He (Vronsky), so manly a man, never opposed her (Anna), had indeed, with her (Anna), no will of his (Vronsky) own, and was anxious, it seemed, for nothing but to anticipate her (Anna) wishes.

And she (Anna) could not but appreciate this, even though the very intensity of his (Vronsky) solicitude for her (Anna), the atmosphere of care with which he (Vronsky) surrounded her (Anna), sometimes weighed upon her (Anna).

He (Vronsky) soon felt that the realization of his (Vronsky) desires gave him (Vronsky) no more than a grain of sand out of the mountain of happiness he (Vronsky) had expected.

Vronsky, meanwhile, in spite of the complete realization of what he (Vronsky) had so long desired, was not perfectly happy. It showed him (Vronsky) the mistake men make in picturing to themselves happiness as the realization of their desires.

For a time after joining his (Vronsky) life to hers, and putting on civilian dress, he (Vronsky) had felt all the delight of freedom in general of which he (Vronsky) had known nothing before, and of freedom in his (Vronsky) love,--and he (Vronsky) was content, but not for long.

He (Vronsky) was soon aware that there was springing up in his (Vronsky) heart a desire for desires-- ennui . Without conscious intention he (Vronsky) began to clutch at every passing caprice, taking it for a desire and an object.

Sixteen hours of the day must be occupied in some way, since they were living abroad in complete freedom, outside the conditions of social life which filled up time in Petersburg.

As for the amusements of bachelor existence, which had provided Vronsky with entertainment on previous tours abroad, they could not be thought of, since the sole attempt of the sort had led to a sudden attack of depression in Anna, quite out of proportion with the cause--a late supper with bachelor friends.

Relations with the society of the place--foreign and Russian--were equally out of the question owing to the irregularity of their position.

The inspection of objects of interest, apart from the fact that everything had been seen already, had not for Vronsky, a Russian and a sensible man, the immense significance Englishmen are able to attach to that pursuit.

And just as the hungry stomach eagerly accepts every object it can get, hoping to find nourishment in it, Vronsky quite unconsciously clutched first at politics, then at new books, and then at pictures.

As he (man) had from a child a taste for painting, and as, not knowing what to spend his (man) money on, he (man) had begun collecting engravings, he (man) came to a stop at painting, began to take interest in it, and concentrated upon it the unoccupied mass of desires which demanded satisfaction.

He (man) had a ready appreciation of art, and probably, with a taste for imitating art, he (man) supposed himself to have the real thing essential for an artist, and after hesitating for some time which style of painting to select--religious, historical, realistic, or genre painting--he (man) set to work to paint.

He (man) appreciated all kinds, and could have felt inspired by any one of them; but he (man) had no conception of the possibility of knowing nothing at all of any school of painting, and of being inspired directly by what is within the soul, without caring whether what is painted will belong to any recognized school.

Since he (man) knew nothing of this, and drew his (man) inspiration, not directly from life, but indirectly from life embodied in art, his (man) inspiration came very quickly and easily, and as quickly and easily came his (man) success in painting something very similar to the sort of painting he (man) was trying to imitate.

More than any other style he (man) liked the French--graceful and effective--and in that style he (man) began to paint Anna's portrait in Italian costume, and the portrait seemed to him (man), and to everyone who saw it, extremely successful.

The old neglected palazzo, with its lofty carved ceilings and frescoes on the walls, with its floors of mosaic, with its heavy yellow stuff curtains on the windows, with its vases on pedestals, and its open fireplaces, its carved doors and gloomy reception rooms, hung with pictures--this palazzo did much, by its very appearance after they had moved into it, to confirm in Vronsky the agreeable illusion that he (man) was not so much a Russian country gentleman, a retired army officer, as an enlightened amateur and patron of the arts, himself a modest artist who had renounced the world, his (artist) connections, and his (artist) ambition for the sake of the woman he (artist) loved.

The pose chosen by Vronsky with their removal into the palazzo was completely successful, and having, through Golenishtchev, made acquaintance with a few interesting people, for a time he (acquaintance) was satisfied.

Chapter 9 He (acquaintance) painted studies from nature under the guidance of an Italian professor of painting, and studied mediaeval Italian life.

Mediaeval Italian life so fascinated Vronsky that he (acquaintance) even wore a hat and flung a cloak over his (acquaintance) shoulder in the mediaeval style, which, indeed, was extremely becoming to him (acquaintance).

Here we live, and know nothing of what's going on,'' Vronsky said to Golenishtchev as he (Vronsky) came to see him (Vronsky) one morning.

he (Vronsky) said, handing him (Vronsky) a Russian gazette he (Vronsky) had received that morning, and pointing to an article on a Russian artist, living in the very same town, and just finishing a picture which had long been talked about, and had been bought beforehand.

'' '' Have you seen Mihailov's picture? '' The article reproached the government and the academy for letting so remarkable an artist be left without encouragement and support.

'' I've seen it,'' answered Golenishtchev. '' Of course, he (artist)'s not without talent, but it's all in a wrong direction. It's all the Ivanov-Strauss-Renan attitude to Christ and to religious painting.

'' '' What is the subject of the picture?'' asked Anna. '' Christ before Pilate. Christ is represented as a Jew with all the realism of the new school.

And the question of the subject of the picture having brought him (Christ) to one of his (Christ) favorite theories, Golenishtchev launched forth into a disquisition on it.

'' '' I can't understand how they can fall into such a gross mistake. Christ always has His (Christ) definite embodiment in the art of the great masters.

And therefore, if they want to depict, not God, but a revolutionist or a sage, let them take from history a Socrates, a Franklin, a Charlotte Corday, but not Christ.

They take the very figure which cannot be taken for their art, and then...'' '' And is it true that this Mihailov is in such poverty?

'' asked Vronsky, thinking that, as a Russian Maecenas, it was his (Vronsky) duty to assist the artist regardless of whether the picture were good or bad.

'' I should say not. He (Vronsky)'s a remarkable portrait-painter. Have you ever seen his (Vronsky) portrait of Madame Vassiltchikova? But I believe he (Vronsky) doesn't care about painting any more portraits, and so very likely he (Vronsky) is in want.

I maintain that... ''

``Couldn't we ask him (Vronsky) to paint a portrait of Anna Arkadyevna?'' (I)
said Vronsky. '' Why mine?'' said Anna.

Here she (Anna) is,'' she (Anna) added, looking out of the window at the handsome Italian nurse, who was carrying the child out into the garden, and immediately glancing unnoticed at Vronsky.

The handsome nurse, from whom Vronsky was painting a head for his (Vronsky) picture, was the one hidden grief in Anna's life.

He (Vronsky) painted with her (Anna) as his (Vronsky) model, admired her (Anna) beauty and mediaevalism, and Anna dared not confess to herself that she (Anna) was afraid of becoming jealous of this nurse, and was for that reason particularly gracious and condescending both to her (Anna) and her (Anna) little son.

Vronsky, too, glanced out of the window and into Anna's eyes, and, turning at once to Golenishtchev, he (son) said:

``Do you know this Mihailov?'' (he)

'' After yours I don't want another portrait. Better have one of Annie'' -LRB-so she (Annie) called her (Annie) baby girl-RRB-. ''

``I have met him (son).

You know, one of those uncouth new people one's so often coming across nowadays, one of those free-thinkers you know, who are reared d'embl√©e in theories of atheism, scepticism, and materialism.

In former days,'' (Golenishtchev)

said Golenishtchev, not observing, or not willing to observe, that both Anna and Vronsky wanted to speak, ``in former days the free-thinker was a man who had been brought up in ideas of religion, law, and morality, and only through conflict and struggle came to free-thought; but now there has sprung up a new type of born free-thinkers who grow up without even having heard of principles of morality or of religion, of the existence of authorities, who grow up directly in ideas of negation in everything, that is to say, savages.

But he (Vronsky)'s a queer fish, and quite without breeding. Well, he (Vronsky)'s of that class. He (Vronsky)'s the son, it appears, of some Moscow butler, and has never had any sort of bringing-up.

When he (Vronsky) got into the academy and made his (Vronsky) reputation he (Vronsky) tried, as he (Vronsky)'s no fool, to educate himself. And he (Vronsky) turned to what seemed to him (Vronsky) the very source of culture--the magazines.

In old times, you see, a man who wanted to educate himself--a Frenchman, for instance--would have set to work to study all the classics and theologians and tragedians and historiaris and philosophers, and, you know, all the intellectual work that came in his (man) way.

But in our day he (man) goes straight for the literature of negation, very quickly assimilates all the extracts of the science of negation, and he (man)'s ready.

twenty years ago he (man) would have found in that literature traces of conflict with authorities, with the creeds of the ages; he (man) would have perceived from this conflict that there was something else; but now he (man) comes at once upon a literature in which the old creeds do not even furnish matter for discussion, but it is stated baldly that there is nothing else--evolution, natural selection, struggle for existence--and that's all.

``I tell you what,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, who had for a long while been exchanging wary glances with Vronsky, and knew that he (man) was not in the least interested in the education of this artist, but was simply absorbed by the idea of assisting him (man), and ordering a portrait of him (man);
``I tell you what,'' (him)
she (Anna) said, resolutely interrupting Golenishtchev, who was still talking away,
``let's go and see him (man)!'' (Golenishtchev)

And that's not all-- In my article I've...'' Golenishtchev recovered his (man) self-possession and readily agreed. But as the artist lived in a remote suburb, it was decided to take the carriage.

An hour later Anna, with Golenishtchev by her (Anna) side and Vronsky on the front seat of the carriage, facing them, drove up to a new ugly house in the remote suburb.

On learning from the porter's wife, who came out to them, that Mihailov saw visitors at his (porter) studio, but that at that moment he (porter) was in his (porter) lodging only a couple of steps off, they sent her (wife) to him (porter) with their cards, asking permission to see his (porter) picture.

Chapter 10 The artist Mihailov was, as always, at work when the cards of Count Vronsky and Golenishtchev were brought to him (porter).

On getting home he (porter) flew into a rage with his (porter) wife for not having managed to put off the landlady, who had been asking for money.

In the morning he (porter) had been working in his (porter) studio at his (porter) big picture. '' I've said it to you twenty times, don't enter into details.

You're fool enough at all times, and when you start explaining things in Italian you're a fool three times as foolish,'' he (fool) said after a long dispute.

'' Don't let it run so long; it's not my fault. If I had the money...''

``Leave me in peace, for God's sake!'' (I)

Mihailov shrieked, with tears in his (God) voice, and, stopping his (God) ears, he (God) went off into his (God) working room, the other side of a partition wall, and closed the door after him (God).

he (God) said to himself, sat down to the table, and, opening a portfolio, he (God) set to work at once with peculiar fervor at a sketch he (God) had begun.

Never did he (God) work with such fervor and success as when things went ill with him (God), and especially when he (God) quarreled with his (God) wife.

``Idiotic woman! '' (unknown)
'' Oh! damn them all! '' he (God) thought as he (God) went on working. He (God) was making a sketch for the figure of a man in a violent rage.

A sketch had been made before, but he (God) was dissatisfied with it. '' No, that one was better...where is it? ''

He (God) went back to his (God) wife, and scowling, and not looking at her (wife), asked his (God) eldest little girl, where was that piece of paper he (God) had given them?

Still, he (God) took the sketch, laid it on his (God) table, and, moving a little away, screwing up his (God) eyes, he (God) fell to gazing at it.

The paper with the discarded sketch on it was found, but it was dirty, and spotted with candle-grease. All at once he (God) smiled and gesticulated gleefully.

'' That's it! that's it! '' he (God) said, and, at once picking up the pencil, he (God) began rapidly drawing. The spot of tallow had given the man a new pose.

He (man) had sketched this new pose, when all at once he (man) recalled the face of a shopkeeper of whom he (man) had bought cigars, a vigorous face with a prominent chin, and he (man) sketched this very face, this chin on to the figure of the man.

He (man) laughed aloud with delight. The figure from a lifeless imagined thing had become living, and such that it could never be changed.

The sketch might be corrected in accordance with the requirements of the figure, the legs, indeed, could and must be put differently, and the position of the left hand must be quite altered; the hair too might be thrown back.

That figure lived, and was clearly and unmistakably defined. But in making these corrections he (man) was not altering the figure but simply getting rid of what concealed the figure.

Each new feature only brought out the whole figure in all its force and vigor, as it had suddenly come to him (man) from the spot of tallow.

He (man) was, as it were, stripping off the wrappings which hindered it from being distinctly seen. He (man) was carefully finishing the figure when the cards were brought him (man).

'' Coming, coming!'' He (man) went in to his (man) wife.

``Come, Sasha, don't be cross! '' (he)
he (man) said, smiling timidly and affectionately at her (wife).

And having made peace with his (man) wife he (man) put on an olive-green overcoat with a velvet collar and a hat, and went towards his (man) studio.

'' You were to blame. I was to blame. I'll make it all right. '' The successful figure he (man) had already forgotten.

Now he (man) was delighted and excited at the visit of these people of consequence, Russians, who had come in their carriage.

Of his (man) picture, the one that stood now on his (man) easel, he (man) had at the bottom of his (man) heart one conviction--that no one had ever painted a picture like it.

He (man) did not believe that his (man) picture was better than all the pictures of Raphael, but he (Raphael) knew that what he (Raphael) tried to convey in that picture, no one ever had conveyed.

But other people's criticisms, whatever they might be, had yet immense consequence in his (Raphael) eyes, and they agitated him (Raphael) to the depths of his (Raphael) soul.

Any remark, the most insignificant, that showed that the critic saw even the tiniest part of what he (critic) saw in the picture, agitated him (critic) to the depths of his (critic) soul.

He (critic) always attributed to his (critic) critics a more profound comprehension than he (critic) had himself, and always expected from them something he (critic) did not himself see in the picture.

This he (critic) knew positively, and had known a long while, ever since he (critic) had begun to paint it. And often in their criticisms he (critic) fancied that he (critic) had found this.

He (critic) walked rapidly to the door of his (critic) studio, and in spite of his (critic) excitement he (critic) was struck by the soft light on Anna's figure as she (Anna) stood in the shade of the entrance listening to Golenishtchev, who was eagerly telling her (Anna) something, while she (Anna) evidently wanted to look round at the artist.

He (artist) was himself unconscious how, as he (artist) approached them, he (artist) seized on this impression and absorbed it, as he (artist) had the chin of the shopkeeper who had sold him (artist) the cigars, and put it away somewhere to be brought out when he (artist) wanted it.

Thick-set and of middle height, with nimble movements, with his (artist) brown hat, olive-green coat and narrow trousers--though wide trousers had been a long while in fashion,--most of all, with the ordinariness of his (artist) broad face, and the combined expression of timidity and anxiety to keep up his (artist) dignity, Mihailov made an unpleasant impression.

The visitors, not agreeably impressed beforehand by Golenishtchev's account of the artist, were still less so by his (artist) personal appearance. ''

Please step in,'' he (artist) said, trying to look indifferent, and going into the passage he (artist) took a key out of his (artist) pocket and opened the door.

On entering the studio, Mihailov once more scanned his (artist) visitors and noted down in his (artist) imagination Vronsky's expression too, and especially his (artist) jaws.

Although his (artist) artistic sense was unceasingly at work collecting materials, although he (artist) felt a continually increasing excitement as the moment of criticizing his (artist) work drew nearer, he (artist) rapidly and subtly formed, from imperceptible signs, a mental image of these three persons.

Chapter 11 That fellow -LRB-Golenishtchev-RRB- was a Russian living here. Mihailov did not remember his (fellow) surname nor where he (fellow) had met him (fellow), nor what he (fellow) had said to him (fellow).

He (fellow) only remembered his (fellow) face as he (fellow) remembered all the faces he (fellow) had ever seen; but he (fellow) remembered, too, that it was one of the faces laid by in his (fellow) memory in the immense class of the falsely consequential and poor in expression.

The abundant hair and very open forehead gave an appearance of consequence to the face, which had only one expression--a petty, childish, peevish expression, concentrated just above the bridge of the narrow nose.

Vronsky and Madame Karenina must be, Mihailov supposed, distinguished and wealthy Russians, knowing nothing about art, like all those wealthy Russians, but posing as amateurs and connoisseurs.

Most likely they've already looked at all the antiques, and now they're making the round of the studios of the new people, the German humbug, and the cracked Pre-Raphaelite English fellow, and have only come to me to make the point of view complete,'' he (fellow) thought.

He (fellow) was well acquainted with the way dilettanti have -LRB-the cleverer they were the worse he (fellow) found them-RRB- of looking at the works of contemporary artists with the sole object of being in a position to say that art is a thing of the past, and that the more one sees of the new men the more one sees how inimitable the works of the great old masters have remained.

He (fellow) expected all this; he (fellow) saw it all in their faces, he (fellow) saw it in the careless indifference with which they talked among themselves, stared at the lay figures and busts, and walked about in leisurely fashion, waiting for him (fellow) to uncover his (fellow) picture.

But in spite of this, while he (fellow) was turning over his (fellow) studies, pulling up the blinds and taking off the sheet, he (fellow) was in intense excitement, especially as, in spite of his (fellow) conviction that all distinguished and wealthy Russians were certain to be beasts and fools, he (fellow) liked Vronsky, and still more Anna.

Here, if you please,'' he (fellow) said, moving on one side with his (fellow) nimble gait and pointing to his (fellow) picture,

``it's the exhortation to Pilate.

'' (he)

'' Matthew, chapter xxvii,'' he (Matthew) said, feeling his (Matthew) lips were beginning to tremble with emotion. He (Matthew) moved away and stood behind them.

For the few seconds during which the visitors were gazing at the picture in silence Mihailov too gazed at it with the indifferent eye of an outsider.

For those few seconds he (outsider) was sure in anticipation that a higher, juster criticism would be uttered by them, by those very visitors whom he (outsider) had been so despising a moment before.

He (outsider) forgot all he (outsider) had thought about his (outsider) picture before during the three years he (outsider) had been painting it; he (outsider) forgot all its qualities which had been absolutely certain to him (outsider)--he (outsider) saw the picture with their indifferent, new, outside eyes, and saw nothing good in it.

He (outsider) saw in the foreground Pilate's irritated face and the serene face of Christ, and in the background the figures of Pilate's retinue and the face of John watching what was happening.

Every face that, with such agony, such blunders and corrections had grown up within him (John) with its special character, every face that had given him (John) such torments and such raptures, and all these faces so many times transposed for the sake of the harmony of the whole, all the shades of color and tones that he (John) had attained with such labor--all of this together seemed to him (John) now, looking at it with their eyes, the merest vulgarity, something that had been done a thousand times over.

The face dearest to him (John), the face of Christ, the center of the picture, which had given him (Christ) such ecstasy as it unfolded itself to him (Christ), was utterly lost to him (Christ) when he (Christ) glanced at the picture with their eyes.

He (Christ) saw a well-painted -LRB-no, not even that--he (Christ) distinctly saw now a mass of defects-RRB- repetition of those endless Christs of Titian, Raphael, Rubens, and the same soldiers and Pilate.

They would be justified in repeating hypocritically civil speeches in the presence of the painter, and pitying him (painter) and laughing at him (painter) when they were alone again.

It was all common, poor, and stale, and positively badly painted--weak and unequal. The silence -LRB-though it lasted no more than a minute-RRB- became too intolerable to him (painter).

I think I've had the pleasure of meeting you,'' he (painter) said, looking uneasily first at Anna, then at Vronsky, in fear of losing any shade of their expression.

To break it, and to show he (Vronsky) was not agitated, he (Vronsky) made an effort and addressed Golenishtchev. '' '' To be sure!

We met at Rossi's, do you remember, at that soir√©e when that Italian lady recited--the new Rachel?'' Golenishtchev answered easily, removing his (Rossi) eyes without the slightest regret from the picture and turning to the artist.

Noticing, however, that Mihailov was expecting a criticism of the picture, he (Rossi) said:

``Your picture has got on a great deal since I saw it last time; and what strikes me particularly now, as it did then, is the figure of Pilate.

One so knows the man: a good-natured, capital fellow, but an official through and through, who does not know what it is he (official)'s doing.

But I fancy... '' (he)

All Mihailov's mobile face beamed at once; his (official) eyes sparkled. He (official) tried to say something, but he (official) could not speak for excitement, and pretended to be coughing.

Low as was his (official) opinion of Golenishtchev's capacity for understanding art, trifling as was the true remark upon the fidelity of the expression of Pilate as an official, and offensive as might have seemed the utterance of so unimportant an observation while nothing was said of more serious points, Mihailov was in an ecstasy of delight at this observation.

The fact that this reflection was but one of millions of reflections, which as Mihailov knew for certain would be true, did not diminish for him (Pilate) the significance of Golenishtchev's remark.

He (Pilate) had himself thought about Pilate's figure just what Golenishtchev said. His (Pilate) heart warmed to Golenishtchev for this remark, and from a state of depression he (Pilate) suddenly passed to ecstasy.

Mihailov again tried to say that that was how he (Pilate) understood Pilate, but his (Pilate) lips quivered intractably, and he (Pilate) could not pronounce the words.

Vronsky and Anna too said something in that subdued voice in which, partly to avoid hurting the artist's feelings and partly to avoid saying out loud something silly--so easily said when talking of art--people usually speak at exhibitions of pictures.

At once the whole of his (artist) picture lived before him (artist) in all the indescribable complexity of everything living. Mihailov fancied that the picture had made an impression on them too.

Of all she (Anna) saw she (Anna) liked that expression most of all, and she (Anna) felt that it was the center of the picture, and so praise of it would be pleasant to the artist.

He (artist) went up to them. '' How marvelous Christ's expression is!'' said Anna. '' One can see that He (Christ) is pitying Pilate.

This again was one of the million true reflections that could be found in his (Pilate) picture and in the figure of Christ.

In Christ's expression there ought to be indeed an expression of pity, since there is an expression of love, of heavenly peace, of readiness for death, and a sense of the vanity of words.

Of course there is the expression of an official in Pilate and of pity in Christ, seeing that one is the incarnation of the fleshly and the other of the spiritual life.

'' She (official) said that He (Christ) was pitying Pilate. All this and much more flashed into Mihailov's thoughts. '' Yes, and how that figure is done--what atmosphere!

One can walk round it,'' said Golenishtchev, unmistakably betraying by this remark that he (Pilate) did not approve of the meaning and idea of the figure.

There you have technique,'' he (Pilate) said, addressing Golenishtchev, alluding to a conversation between them about Vronsky's despair of attaining this technique.

'' Yes, there's a wonderful mastery!'' said Vronsky. '' How those figures in the background stand out! '' Yes, yes, marvelous!

In spite of the excited condition in which he (Pilate) was, the sentence about technique had sent a pang to Mihailov's heart, and looking angrily at Vronsky he (Pilate) suddenly scowled.

'' Golenishtchev and Anna assented. He (Pilate) had often heard this word technique, and was utterly unable to understand what was understood by it.

He (Pilate) had noticed often that even in actual praise technique was opposed to essential quality, as though one could paint well something that was bad.

He (Pilate) knew that a great deal of attention and care was necessary in taking off the coverings, to avoid injuring the creation itself, and to take off all the coverings; but there was no art of painting--no technique of any sort--about it.

If to a little child or to his (Pilate) cook were revealed what he (Pilate) saw, it or she (Pilate) would have been able to peel the wrappings off what was seen.

And the most experienced and adroit painter could not by mere mechanical facility paint anything if the lines of the subject were not revealed to him (painter) first.

He (painter) knew that by this term was understood a mechanical facility for painting or drawing, entirely apart from its subject. Besides, he (painter) saw that if it came to talking about technique, it was impossible to praise him (painter) for it.

In all he (painter) had painted and repainted he (painter) saw faults that hurt his (painter) eyes, coming from want of care in taking off the wrappings--faults he (painter) could not correct now without spoiling the whole.

And in almost all the figures and faces he (painter) saw, too, remnants of the wrappings not perfectly removed that spoiled the picture.

'' One thing might be said, if you will allow me to make the remark... '' observed Golenishtchev. '' Oh, I shall be delighted, I beg you,'' said Mihailov with a forced smile.

'' That is, that you make Him (painter) the man-god, and not the God-man. But I know that was what you meant to do.

''

``I cannot paint a Christ that is not in my heart,'' (Mihailov)
said Mihailov gloomily. '' Yes; but in that case, if you will allow me to say what I think....

Your picture is so fine that my observation cannot detract from it, and, besides, it is only my personal opinion. With you it is different.

I imagine that if Christ is brought down to the level of an historical character, it would have been better for Ivanov to select some other historical subject, fresh, untouched.''

Your very motive is different. But let us take Ivanov. '' But if this is the greatest subject presented to art?

And before the picture of Ivanov the question arises for the believer and the unbeliever alike, `Is it God, or is it not God?'

''

``If one looked one would find others. But the point is that art cannot suffer doubt and discussion. and the unity of the impression is destroyed.'' (Golenishtchev)

Golenishtchev did not agree with this, and confounded Mihailov by his (God) support of his (God) first idea of the unity of the impression being essential to art.

``Why so? I think that for educated people,'' (Mihailov)
said Mihailov,
``the question cannot exist. '' (Mihailov)
Mihailov was greatly perturbed, but he (God) could say nothing in defense of his (God) own idea.

Chapter 12 Anna and Vronsky had long been exchanging glances, regretting their friend's flow of cleverness. At last Vronsky, without waiting for the artist, walked away to another small picture.

'' Oh, how exquisite! What a lovely thing! A gem! How exquisite! '' they cried with one voice. '' What is it they're so pleased with?'' thought Mihailov.

He (artist) had forgotten all the agonies and the ecstasies he (artist) had lived through with that picture when for several months it had been the one thought haunting him (artist) day and night.

He (artist) had positively forgotten that picture he (artist) had painted three years ago. He (artist) had forgotten, as he (artist) always forgot, the pictures he (artist) had finished.

He (artist) did not even like to look at it, and had only brought it out because he (artist) was expecting an Englishman who wanted to buy it.

'' Oh, that's only an old study,'' he (artist) said. '' How fine!'' said Golenishtchev, he (artist) too, with unmistakable sincerity, falling under the spell of the picture.

The elder had just dropped in the hook, and was carefully pulling the float from behind a bush, entirely absorbed in what he (artist) was doing.

The other, a little younger, was lying in the grass leaning on his (artist) elbows, with his (artist) tangled, flaxen head in his (artist) hands, staring at the water with his (artist) dreamy blue eyes.

The enthusiasm over this picture stirred some of the old feeling for it in Mihailov, but he (artist) feared and disliked this waste of feeling for things past, and so, even though this praise was grateful to him (artist), he (artist) tried to draw his (artist) visitors away to a third picture.

Two boys were angling in the shade of a willow-tree. What was he (artist) thinking of? But Vronsky asked whether the picture was for sale.

To Mihailov at that moment, excited by visitors, it was extremely distasteful to speak of money matters. '' It is put up there to be sold,'' he (Vronsky) answered, scowling gloomily.

When the visitors had gone, Mihailov sat down opposite the picture of Pilate and Christ, and in his (Christ) mind went over what had been said, and what, though not said, had been implied by those visitors.

And, strange to say, what had had such weight with him (Christ), while they were there and while he (Christ) mentally put himself at their point of view, suddenly lost all importance for him (Christ).

He (Christ) began to look at his (Christ) picture with all his (Christ) own full artist vision, and was soon in that mood of conviction of the perfectibility, and so of the significance, of his (Christ) picture--a conviction essential to the most intense fervor, excluding all other interests--in which alone he (Christ) could work.

As he (Christ) corrected the leg he (Christ) looked continually at the figure of John in the background, which his (John) visitors had not even noticed, but which he (John) knew was beyond perfection.

Christ's foreshortened leg was not right, though. He (Christ) took his (Christ) palette and began to work. When he (Christ) had finished the leg he (Christ) wanted to touch that figure, but he (Christ) felt too much excited for it.

He (Christ) was equally unable to work when he (Christ) was cold and when he (Christ) was too much affected and saw everything too much.

There was only one stage in the transition from coldness to inspiration, at which work was possible. Today he (Christ) was too much agitated.

He (Christ) would have covered the picture, but he (Christ) stopped, holding the cloth in his (Christ) hand, and, smiling blissfully, gazed a long while at the figure of John.

At last, as it were regretfully tearing himself away, he (John) dropped the cloth, and, exhausted but happy, went home. Vronsky, Anna, and Golenishtchev, on their way home, were particularly lively and cheerful.

The word talent , by which they meant an inborn, almost physical, aptitude apart from brain and heart, and in which they tried to find an expression for all the artist had gained from life, recurred particularly often in their talk, as though it were necessary for them to sum up what they had no conception of, though they wanted to talk of it.

They said that there was no denying his (artist) talent, but that his (artist) talent could not develop for want of education--the common defect of our Russian artists.

They talked of Mihailov and his (artist) pictures. But the picture of the boys had imprinted itself on their memories, and they were continually coming back to it.

'' What an exquisite thing! How he (artist) has succeeded in it, and how simply! He (artist) doesn't even comprehend how good it is.

Yes, I mustn't let it slip; I must buy it,'' said Vronsky. Chapter 13 Mihailov sold Vronsky his (artist) picture, and agreed to paint a portrait of Anna.

On the day fixed he (artist) came and began the work. From the fifth sitting the portrait impressed everyone, especially Vronsky, not only by its resemblance, but by its characteristic beauty.

One needs to know and love her (Anna) as I have loved her (Anna) to discover the very sweetest expression of her (Anna) soul,'' Vronsky thought, though it was only from this portrait that he (artist) had himself learned this sweetest expression of her (Anna) soul.

It was strange how Mihailov could have discovered just her (Anna) characteristic beauty. '' But the expression was so true that he (artist), and others too, fancied they had long known it.

I have been struggling on for ever so long without doing anything,'' he (artist) said of his (artist) own portrait of her (Anna), ``and he (artist) just looked and painted it.

``That will come,'' (him)
was the consoling reassurance given him (artist) by Golenishtchev, in whose view Vronsky had both talent, and what was most important, culture, giving him (artist) a wider outlook on art.

Golenishtchev's faith in Vronsky's talent was propped up by his (artist) own need of Vronsky's sympathy and approval for his (Vronsky) own articles and ideas, and he (Vronsky) felt that the praise and support must be mutual.

In another man's house, and especially in Vronsky's palazzo, Mihailov was quite a different man from what he (man) was in his (man) studio.

'' That's where technique comes in.'' He (man) behaved with hostile courtesy, as though he (man) were afraid of coming closer to people he (man) did not respect.

He (man) called Vronsky

``your excellency,'' (Vronsky)
and notwithstanding Anna's and Vronsky's invitations, he (man) would never stay to dinner, nor come except for the sittings.

Anna was even more friendly to him (man) than to other people, and was very grateful for her (Anna) portrait. Vronsky was more than cordial with him (man), and was obviously interested to know the artist's opinion of his (artist) picture.

Golenishtchev never let slip an opportunity of instilling sound ideas about art into Mihailov. But Mihailov remained equally chilly to all of them.

Vronsky's talk about his (Vronsky) painting he (Vronsky) met with stubborn silence, and he (Vronsky) was as stubbornly silent when he (Vronsky) was shown Vronsky's picture.

Anna was aware from his (Vronsky) eyes that he (Vronsky) liked looking at her (Anna), but he (Vronsky) avoided conversation with her (Anna). He (Vronsky) was unmistakably bored by Golenishtchev's conversation, and he (Vronsky) did not attempt to oppose him (Vronsky).

Altogether Mihailov, with his (Vronsky) reserved and disagreeable, as it were, hostile attitude, was quite disliked by them as they got to know him (Vronsky) better; and they were glad when the sittings were over, and they were left with a magnificent portrait in their possession, and he (Vronsky) gave up coming.

Golenishtchev was the first to give expression to an idea that had occurred to all of them, which was that Mihailov was simply jealous of Vronsky.

Not envious, let us say, since he (Vronsky) has talent ; but it annoys him (Vronsky) that a wealthy man of the highest society, and a count, too -LRB-you know they all detest a title-RRB-, can, without any particular trouble, do as well, if not better, than he (man) who has devoted all his (man) life to it.

Vronsky defended Mihailov, but at the bottom of his (man) heart he (man) believed it, because in his (man) view a man of a different, lower world would be sure to be envious.

Anna's portrait--the same subject painted from nature both by him (man) and by Mihailov--ought to have shown Vronsky the difference between him (man) and Mihailov; but he (man) did not see it.

Only after Mihailov's portrait was painted he (man) left off painting his (man) portrait of Anna, deciding that it was now not needed.

'' And more than all, it's a question of culture, which he (man) is without. '' His (man) picture of mediaeval life he (man) went on with.

And he (man) himself, and Golenishtchev, and still more Anna, thought it very good, because it was far more like the celebrated pictures they knew than Mihailov's picture.

Mihailov meanwhile, although Anna's portrait greatly fascinated him (man), was even more glad than they were when the sittings were over, and he (man) had no longer to listen to Golenishtchev's disquisitions upon art, and could forget about Vronsky's painting.

He (Vronsky) knew that Vronsky could not be prevented from amusing himself with painting; he (Vronsky) knew that he (Vronsky) and all dilettanti had a perfect right to paint what they liked, but it was distasteful to him (Vronsky).

But if the man were to come with the doll and sit before a man in love, and begin caressing his (man) doll as the lover caressed the woman he (man) loved, it would be distasteful to the lover.

Just such a distasteful sensation was what Mihailov felt at the sight of Vronsky's painting: he (man) felt it both ludicrous and irritating, both pitiable and offensive.

A man could not be prevented from making himself a big wax doll, and kissing it. Vronsky's interest in painting and the Middle Ages did not last long.

He (man) was vaguely aware that its defects, inconspicuous at first, would be glaring if he (man) were to go on with it.

The same experience befell him (man) as Golenishtchev, who felt that he (man) had nothing to say, and continually deceived himself with the theory that his (man) idea was not yet mature, that he (man) was working it out and collecting materials.

He (man) had enough taste for painting to be unable to finish his (man) picture. The picture came to a standstill. This exasperated and tortured Golenishtchev, but Vronsky was incapable of deceiving and torturing himself, and even more incapable of exasperation.

But without this occupation, the life of Vronsky and of Anna, who wondered at his (Vronsky) loss of interest in it, struck them as intolerably tedious in an Italian town.

The palazzo suddenly seemed so obtrusively old and dirty, the spots on the curtains, the cracks in the floors, the broken plaster on the cornices became so disagreeably obvious, and the everlasting sameness of Golenishtchev, and the Italian professor and the German traveler became so wearisome, that they had to make some change.

With his (professor) characteristic decision, without explanation or apology, he (professor) simply ceased working at painting. They resolved to go to Russia, to the country.

In Petersburg Vronsky intended to arrange a partition of the land with his (professor) brother, while Anna meant to see her (Anna) son.

The summer they intended to spend on Vronsky's great family estate. Chapter 14 Levin had been married three months. He (Levin) was happy, but not at all in the way he (Levin) had expected to be.

He (Levin) was happy; but on entering upon family life he (Levin) saw at every step that it was utterly different from what he (Levin) had imagined.

At every step he (Levin) experienced what a man would experience who, after admiring the smooth, happy course of a little boat on a lake, should get himself into that little boat.

He (man) saw that it was not all sitting still, floating smoothly; that one had to think too, not for an instant to forget where one was floating; and that there was water under one, and that one must row; and that his (man) unaccustomed hands would be sore; and that it was only to look at it

At every step he (man) found his (man) former dreams disappointed, and new, unexpected surprises of happiness. that was easy; but that doing it, though very delightful, was very difficult.

As a bachelor, when he (bachelor) had watched other people's married life, seen the petty cares, the squabbles, the jealousy, he (bachelor) had only smiled contemptuously in his (bachelor) heart.

In his (bachelor) future married life there could be, he (bachelor) was convinced, nothing of that sort; even the external forms, indeed, he (bachelor) fancied, must be utterly unlike the life of others in everything.

And all of a sudden, instead of his (bachelor) life with his (bachelor) wife being made on an individual pattern, it was, on the contrary, entirely made up of the pettiest details, which he (bachelor) had so despised before, but which now, by no will of his (bachelor) own, had gained an extraordinary importance that it was useless to contend against.

And Levin saw that the organization of all these details was by no means so easy as he (Levin) had fancied before.

Although Levin believed himself to have the most exact conceptions of domestic life, unconsciously, like all men, he (Levin) pictured domestic life as the happiest enjoyment of love, with nothing to hinder and no petty cares to distract.

He (Levin) ought, as he (Levin) conceived the position, to do his (Levin) work, and to find repose from it in the happiness of love.

And he (Levin) was surprised that she (it), his (Levin) poetic, exquisite Kitty, could, not merely in the first weeks, but even in the first days of their married life, think, remember, and busy herself about tablecloths, and furniture, about mattresses for visitors, about a tray, about the cook, and the dinner, and so on.

While they were still engaged, he (cook) had been struck by the definiteness with which she (Kitty) had declined the tour abroad and decided to go into the country, as though she (Kitty) knew of something she (Kitty) wanted, and could still think of something outside her (Kitty) love.

She (Kitty) ought to be beloved, and nothing more. But, like all men, he (cook) forgot that she (Kitty) too would want work. This had jarred upon him (cook) then, and now her (Kitty) trivial cares and anxieties jarred upon him (cook) several times.

And, loving her (Kitty) as he (cook) did, though he (cook) did not understand the reason of them, and jeered at these domestic pursuits, he (cook) could not help admiring them.

He (cook) jeered at the way in which she (Kitty) arranged the furniture they had brought from Moscow; rearranged their room; hung up curtains; prepared rooms for visitors; a room for Dolly; saw after an abode for her (Dolly) new maid; ordered dinner of the old cook; came into collision with Agafea Mihalovna, taking from her (Dolly) the charge of the stores.

He (cook) saw how the old cook smiled, admiring her (Dolly), and listening to her (Dolly) inexperienced, impossible orders, how mournfully and tenderly Agafea Mihalovna shook her (Dolly) head over the young mistress's new arrangements.

He (cook) saw that Kitty was extraordinarily sweet when, laughing and crying, she (Kitty) came to tell him (cook) that her (Kitty) maid, Masha, was used to looking upon her (Kitty) as her (Kitty) young lady, and so no one obeyed her (Kitty).

But he (cook) saw that this was essential for her (Kitty). It seemed to him (cook) sweet, but strange, and he (cook) thought it would have been better without this.

He (cook) did not know how great a sense of change she (Kitty) was experiencing; she (Kitty), who at home had sometimes wanted some favorite dish, or sweets, without the possibility of getting either, now could order what she (Kitty) liked, buy pounds of sweets, spend as much money as she (Kitty) liked, and order any puddings she (Kitty) pleased.

She (Kitty) was dreaming with delight now of Dolly's coming to them with her (Dolly) children, especially because she (Dolly) would order for the children their favorite puddings

and Dolly would appreciate all her (Dolly) new housekeeping. She (Dolly) did not know herself why and wherefore, but the arranging of her (Dolly) house had an irresistible attraction for her (Dolly).

Instinctively feeling the approach of spring, and knowing that there would be days of rough weather too, she (Dolly) built her (Dolly) nest as best she (Dolly) could, and was in haste at the same time to build it and to learn how to do it.

This care for domestic details in Kitty, so opposed to Levin's ideal of exalted happiness, was at first one of the disappointments; and this sweet care of her (Kitty) household, the aim of which he (Levin) did not understand, but could not help loving, was one of the new happy surprises.

Levin could never have conceived that between him (Levin) and his (Levin) wife any relations could arise other than tender, respectful and loving, and all at once in the very early days they quarreled, so that she (wife) said he (Levin) did not care for her (wife), that he (Levin) cared for no one but himself, burst into tears, and wrung her (wife) arms.

This first quarrel arose from Levin's having gone out to a new farmhouse and having been away half an hour too long, because he (Levin) had tried to get home by a short cut and had lost his (Levin) way.

He (Levin) drove home thinking of nothing but her (wife), of her (wife) love, of his (Levin) own happiness, and the nearer he (Levin) drew to home, the warmer was his (Levin) tenderness for her (wife).

He (Levin) ran into the room with the same feeling, with an even stronger feeling than he (Levin) had had when he (Levin) reached the Shtcherbatskys' house to make his (Levin) offer.

Another disappointment and happy surprise came in their quarrels. And suddenly he (Levin) was met by a lowering expression he (Levin) had never seen in her (wife).

He (Levin) would have kissed her (wife); she (wife) pushed him (Levin) away. '' What is it?'' '' You've been enjoying yourself,'' she (wife) began, trying to be calm and spiteful.

But as soon as she (wife) opened her (wife) mouth, a stream of reproach, of senseless jealousy, of all that had been torturing her (wife) during that half hour which she (wife) had spent sitting motionless at the window, burst from her (wife).

It was only then, for the first time, that he (Levin) clearly understood what he (Levin) had not understood when he (Levin) led her (wife) out of the church after the wedding.

He (Levin) felt now that he (Levin) was not simply close to her (wife), but that he (Levin) did not know where he (Levin) ended and she (wife) began.

He (Levin) was offended for the first instant, but the very same second he (Levin) felt that he (Levin) could not be offended by her (wife), that she (wife) was himself.

He (Levin) felt for the first moment as a man feels when, having suddenly received a violent blow from behind, he (man) turns round, angry and eager to avenge himself, to look for his (man) antagonist, and finds that it is he (man) himself who has accidentally struck himself, that there is no one to be angry with, and that he (man) must put up with and try to soothe the pain.

Never afterwards did he (man) feel it with such intensity, but this first time he (man) could not for a long while get over it.

His (man) natural feeling urged him (man) to defend himself, to prove to her (man) she (man) was wrong; but to prove her (man) wrong would mean irritating her (man) still more and making the rupture greater that was the cause of all his (man) suffering.

He (man) felt this from the agonizing sensation of division that he (man) experienced at that instant. One habitual feeling impelled him (man) to get rid of the blame and to pass it on to her (man).

Another feeling, even stronger, impelled him (man) as quickly as possible to smooth over the rupture without letting it grow greater. To remain under such undeserved reproach was wretched, but to make her (man) suffer by justifying himself was worse still.

Like a man half-awake in an agony of pain, he (man) wanted to tear out, to fling away the aching place, and coming to his (man) senses, he (man) felt that the aching place was himself.

He (man) could do nothing but try to help the aching place to bear it, and this he (man) tried to do. They made peace.

She (man), recognizing that she (man) was wrong, though she (man) did not say so, became tenderer to him (man), and they experienced new, redoubled happiness in their love.

But that did not prevent such quarrels from happening again, and exceedingly often too, on the most unexpected and trivial grounds.

These quarrels frequently arose from the fact that they did not yet know what was of importance to each other and that all this early period they were both often in a bad temper.

When one was in a good temper, and the other in a bad temper, the peace was not broken; but when both happened to be in an ill-humor, quarrels sprang up from such incomprehensibly trifling causes, that they could never remember afterwards what they had quarreled about.

It is true that when they were both in a good temper their enjoyment of life was redoubled. But still this first period of their married life was a difficult time for them.

During all this early time they had a peculiarly vivid sense of tension, as it were, a tugging in opposite directions of the chain by which they were bound.

Altogether their honeymoon--that is to say, the month after their wedding--from which from tradition Levin expected so much, was not merely not a time of sweetness, but remained in the memories of both as the bitterest and most humiliating period in their lives.

They both alike tried in later life to blot out from their memories all the monstrous, shameful incidents of that morbid period, when both were rarely in a normal frame of mind, both were rarely quite themselves.

It was only in the third month of their married life, after their return from Moscow, where they had been staying for a month, that their life began to go more smoothly.

Chapter 15 They had just come back from Moscow, and were glad to be alone. He (their) was sitting at the writing table in his (their) study, writing.

She (their), wearing the dark lilac dress she (their) had worn during the first days of their married life, and put on again today, a dress particularly remembered and loved by him (their), was sitting on the sofa, the same old-fashioned leather sofa which had always stood in the study in Levin's father's and grandfather's days.

His (Levin) work, both on the land and on the book, in which the principles of the new land system were to be laid down, had not been abandoned; but just as formerly these pursuits and ideas had seemed to him (Levin) petty and trivial in comparison with the darkness that overspread all life, now they seemed as unimportant and petty in comparison with the life that lay before him (Levin) suffused with the brilliant light of happiness.

He (Levin) went on with his (Levin) work, but he (Levin) felt now that the center of gravity of his (Levin) attention had passed to something else, and that consequently he (Levin) looked at his (Levin) work quite differently and more clearly.

She (Levin) was sewing at broderie anglaise . He (Levin) thought and wrote, never losing the happy consciousness of her (Levin) presence. Formerly this work had been for him (Levin) an escape from life.

Formerly he (Levin) had felt that without this work his (Levin) life would be too gloomy. Now these pursuits were necessary for him (Levin) that life might not be too uniformly bright.

Taking up his (Levin) manuscript, reading through what he (Levin) had written, he (Levin) found with pleasure that the work was worth his (Levin) working at.

Many of his (Levin) old ideas seemed to him (Levin) superfluous and extreme, but many blanks became distinct to him (Levin) when he (Levin) reviewed the whole thing in his (Levin) memory.

He (Levin) maintained that the poverty of Russia arises not merely from the anomalous distribution of landed property and misdirected reforms, but that what had contributed of late years to this result was the civilization from without abnormally grafted upon Russia, especially facilities of communication, as railways, leading to centralization in towns, the development of luxury, and the consequent development of manufactures, credit and its accompaniment of speculation--all to the detriment of agriculture.

It seemed to him (Levin) that in a normal development of wealth in a state all these phenomena would arise only when a considerable amount of labor had been put into agriculture, when it had come under regular, or at least definite, conditions; that the wealth of a country ought to increase proportionally, and especially in such a way that other sources of wealth should not outstrip agriculture; that in harmony with a certain stage of agriculture there should be means of communication corresponding to it, and that in our unsettled condition of the land, railways, called into being by political and not by economic needs, were premature, and instead of promoting agriculture, as was expected of them, they were competing with agriculture and promoting the development of manufactures and credit, and so arresting its progress; and that just as the one-sided and premature development of one organ in an animal would hinder its general development, so in the general development of wealth in Russia, credit, facilities of communication, manufacturing activity, indubitably necessary in Europe, where they had arisen in their proper time, had with us only done harm, by throwing into the background the chief question calling for settlement--the question of the organization of agriculture.

While he (they) was writing his (they) ideas she (they) was thinking how unnaturally cordial her (they) husband had been to young Prince Tcharsky, who had, with great want of tact, flirted with her (they) the day before they left Moscow.

He (Prince) was writing now a new chapter on the causes of the present disastrous condition of agriculture in Russia. '' He (Prince)'s jealous,'' she (they) thought.

If he (Prince) knew that I think no more of them than of Piotr the cook,'' she (they) thought, looking at his (Prince) head and red neck with a feeling of possession strange to herself.

Though it's a pity to take him (Prince) from his (Prince) work -LRB-but he (Prince) has plenty of time!-RRB-, I must look at his (Prince) face; will he (Prince) feel I'm looking at him (Prince)?

'' Goodness! how sweet and silly he (Prince) is! He (Prince)'s jealous of me! '' I wish he (Prince)'d turn round... I'll will him (Prince) to!''

Yes, they draw away all the sap and give a false appearance of prosperity,'' he (Prince) muttered, stopping to write, and, feeling that she (Prince) was looking at him (Prince) and smiling, he (Prince) looked round.

and she (Prince) opened her (Prince) eyes wide, as though to intensify the influence of her (Prince) gaze. '' '' Well?'' he (Prince) queried, smiling, and getting up.

It's nothing; I wanted you to look round,'' she (Prince) said, watching him (Prince), and trying to guess whether he (Prince) was vexed at being interrupted or not.

How happy we are alone together!--I am, that is,'' he (Prince) said, going up to her (Prince) with a radiant smile of happiness.

Levin smiled at his (Levin) own thoughts, and shook his (Levin) head disapprovingly at those thoughts; a feeling akin to remorse fretted him (Levin).

'' There was something shameful, effeminate, Capuan, as he (Levin) called it to himself, in his (Levin) present mode of life.

'' It's not right to go on like this,'' he (Levin) thought. '' It'll soon be three months, and I'm doing next to nothing.

Today, almost for the first time, I set to work seriously, and what happened? I did nothing but begin and throw it aside.

Even my ordinary pursuits I have almost given up. On the land I scarcely walk or drive about at all to look after things.

And I used to think that, before marriage, life was nothing much, somehow didn't count, but that after marriage, life began in earnest.

Either I am loath to leave her (I), or I see she (I)'s dull alone. And here almost three months have passed, and I have spent my time so idly and unprofitably.

I ought myself to be firmer, to maintain my masculine independence of action; or else I shall get into such ways, and she (I)'ll get used to them too....

No, this won't do; I must begin. Of course, it's not her (I) fault. She (I)'s not to blame in any way. Of course she (I)'s not to blame,'' he (I) told himself.

But it is hard for anyone who is dissatisfied not to blame someone else, and especially the person nearest of all to him (I), for the ground of his (I) dissatisfaction.

And it vaguely came into Levin's mind that she (I) herself was not to blame -LRB-she (I) could not be to blame for anything-RRB-, but what was to blame was her (I) education, too superficial and frivolous.

Yes, apart from her (I) interest in the house -LRB-that she (I) has-RRB-, apart from dress and broderie anglaise , she (I) has no serious interests.

Levin, in his (Levin) heart, censured this, and did not as yet understand that she (I) was preparing for that period of activity which was to come for her (I) when she (I) would at once be the wife of her (I) husband and mistress of the house, and would bear, and nurse, and bring up children.

He (husband) knew not that she (I) was instinctively aware of this, and preparing herself for this time of terrible toil, did not reproach herself for the moments of carelessness and happiness in her (I) love that she (I) enjoyed now while gaily building her (I) nest for the future.

When Levin went upstairs, his (Levin) wife was sitting near the new silver samovar behind the new tea service, and, having settled old Agafea Mihalovna at a little table with a full cup of tea, was reading a letter from Dolly, with whom they were in continual and frequent correspondence.

You see, your good lady's settled me here, told me to sit a bit with her (lady),'' said Agafea Mihalovna, smiling affectionately at Kitty.

In these words of Agafea Mihalovna, Levin read the final act of the drama which had been enacted of late between her (Kitty) and Kitty.

He (Levin) saw that, in spite of Agafea Mihalovna's feelings being hurt by a new mistress taking the reins of government out of her (mistress) hands, Kitty had yet conquered her (Kitty) and made her (Kitty) love her (Kitty).

'' Chapter 16 '' '' Here, I opened your letter too,'' said Kitty, handing him (Levin) an illiterate letter. '' It's from that woman, I think, your brother's...'' she (Kitty) said.

'' I did not read it through. This is from my people and from Dolly. Fancy! Dolly took Tanya and Grisha to a children's ball at the Sarmatskys': Tanya was a French marquise.

'' But Levin did not hear her (Tanya). Flushing, he (Levin) took the letter from Marya Nikolaevna, his (Levin) brother's former mistress, and began to read it.

In the first letter, Marya Nikolaevna wrote that his (Levin) brother had sent her (Nikolaevna) away for no fault of hers, and, with touching simplicity, added that though she (Nikolaevna) was in want again, she (Nikolaevna) asked for nothing, and wished for nothing, but was only tormented by the thought that Nikolay Dmitrievitch would come to grief without her (Nikolaevna), owing to the weak state of his (Levin) health, and begged his (Levin) brother to look after him (Levin).

She (Nikolaevna) had found Nikolay Dmitrievitch, had again made it up with him (Levin) in Moscow, and had moved with him (Levin) to a provincial town, where he (Levin) had received a post in the government service.

But that he (Levin) had quarreled with the head official, and was on his (Levin) way back to Moscow, only he (Levin) had been taken so ill on the road that it was doubtful if he (Levin) would ever leave his (Levin) bed again, she (Nikolaevna) wrote.

This was the second letter he (Levin) had received from Marya Nikolaevna. Now she (Nikolaevna) wrote quite differently. '' It's always of you he (Levin) has talked, and, besides, he (Levin) has no more money left.''

And this lack of candor in a matter of such gravity infuriated him (Levin). '' It's out of the question,'' he (Levin) said sternly.

Agafea Mihalovna, seeing that it was coming to a quarrel, gently put down her (Kitty) cup and withdrew. Kitty did not even notice her (Kitty).

The tone in which her (Kitty) husband had said the last words wounded her (Kitty), especially because he (husband) evidently did not believe what she (Kitty) had said.

I tell you, that if you go, I shall come with you; I shall certainly come,'' she (Kitty) said hastily and wrathfully.

'' '' Why out of the question? Why do you say it's out of the question? '' '' Because it'll be going God knows where, by all sorts of roads and to all sorts of hotels.

it wasn't ... '' No; this is awful! To be such a slave! '' cried Levin, getting up, and unable to restrain his (Levin) anger any longer.

Why did you, if you regret it? '' she (Levin) said, getting up and running away into the drawing room. When he (Levin) went to her (Levin), she (Levin) was sobbing.

He (Levin) began to speak, trying to find words not to dissuade but simply to soothe her (Levin). But she (Levin) did not heed him (Levin), and would not agree to anything.

Levin told his (Levin) wife that he (Levin) believed she (wife) wanted to go simply in order to be of use, agreed that Marya Nikolaevna's being with his (Levin) brother did not make her (Nikolaevna) going improper, but he (Levin) set off at the bottom of his (Levin) heart dissatisfied both with her (Nikolaevna) and with himself.

Chapter 17 The hotel of the provincial town where Nikolay Levin was lying ill was one of those provincial hotels which are constructed on the newest model of modern improvements, with the best intentions of cleanliness, comfort, and even elegance, but owing to the public that patronizes them, are with astounding rapidity transformed into filthy taverns with a pretension of modern improvement that only makes them worse than the old-fashioned, honestly filthy hotels.

This hotel had already reached that stage, and the soldier in a filthy uniform smoking in the entry, supposed to stand for a hall-porter, and the cast-iron, slippery, dark, and disagreeable staircase, and the free and easy waiter in a filthy frock coat, and the common dining room with a dusty bouquet of wax flowers adorning the table, and filth, dust, and disorder everywhere, and at the same time the sort of modern up-to-date self-complacent railway uneasiness of this hotel, aroused a most painful feeling in Levin after their fresh young life, especially because the impression of falsity made by the hotel was so out of keeping with what awaited them.

As is invariably the case, after they had been asked at what price they wanted rooms, it appeared that there was not one decent room for them; one decent room had been taken by the inspector of railroads, another by a lawyer from Moscow, a third by Princess Astafieva from the country.

It was decided that they should go together the next day. There remained only one filthy room, next to which they promised that another should be empty by the evening.

Feeling angry with his (lawyer) wife because what he (lawyer) had expected had come to pass, which was that at the moment of arrival, when his (lawyer) heart throbbed with emotion and anxiety to know how his (lawyer) brother was getting on, he (lawyer) should have to be seeing after her (wife), instead of rushing straight to his (lawyer) brother, Levin conducted her (wife) to the room assigned them.

He (Levin) went out of the door without a word, and at once stumbled over Marya Nikolaevna, who had heard of his (Levin) arrival and had not dared to go in to see him (Levin).

She (Nikolaevna) was just the same as when he (Levin) saw her (Nikolaevna) in Moscow; the same woolen gown, and bare arms and neck, and the same good-naturedly stupid, pockmarked face, only a little plumper.

'' Go, do go! '' she (Nikolaevna) said, looking at him (Levin) with timid and guilty eyes. '' Well, how is he (Levin)? how is he (Levin)?''

``Very bad. He (Levin) can't get up. He (Levin) has kept expecting you. He (Levin).... Are you...with your wife?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin did not for the first moment understand what it was confused her (wife), but she (wife) immediately enlightened him (Levin).

'' I'll go away. I'll go down to the kitchen,'' she (wife) brought out. '' Nikolay Dmitrievitch will be delighted. He (Levin) heard about it, and knows your lady, and remembers her (lady) abroad.

'' Levin realized that she (lady) meant his (Levin) wife, and did not know what answer to make. '' Come along, come along to him (Levin)!

Levin crimsoned both from shame and anger with his (Levin) wife, who had put herself and him (Levin) in such a difficult position; but Marya Nikolaevna crimsoned still more.

She (Nikolaevna) positively shrank together and flushed to the point of tears, and clutching the ends of her (Nikolaevna) apron in both hands, twisted them in her (Nikolaevna) red fingers without knowing what to say and what to do.

For the first instant Levin saw an expression of eager curiosity in the eyes with which Kitty looked at this awful woman, so incomprehensible to her (Kitty); but it lasted only a single instant.

'' he (Levin) said. But as soon as he (Levin) moved, the door of his (Levin) room opened and Kitty peeped out. '' Well! how is he (Levin)?

'' she (Kitty) turned to her (Kitty) husband and then to her (Kitty). '' But one can't go on talking in the passage like this!''

Levin said, looking angrily at a gentleman who walked jauntily at that instant across the corridor, as though about his (Levin) affairs.

Well then, come in,'' said Kitty, turning to Marya Nikolaevna, who had recovered herself, but noticing her (Kitty) husband's face of dismay,

``or go on; go, and then come for me,'' (husband)
she (Kitty) said, and went back into the room.

'' Levin went to his (Levin) brother's room. He (Levin) had not in the least expected what he (Levin) saw and felt in his (Levin) brother's room.

He (Levin) had expected to find him (Levin) in the same state of self-deception which he (Levin) had heard was so frequent with the consumptive, and which had struck him (Levin) so much during his (Levin) brother's visit in the autumn.

He (Levin) had expected to find the physical signs of the approach of death more marked--greater weakness, greater emaciation, but still almost the same condition of things.

He (Levin) had expected himself to feel the same distress at the loss of the brother he (brother) loved and the same horror in face of death as he (brother) had felt then, only in a greater degree.

In a little dirty room with the painted panels of its walls filthy with spittle, and conversation audible through the thin partition from the next room, in a stifling atmosphere saturated with impurities, on a bedstead moved away from the wall, there lay covered with a quilt, a body.

One arm of this body was above the quilt, and the wrist, huge as a rake-handle, was attached, inconceivably it seemed, to the thin, long bone of the arm smooth from the beginning to the middle.

And he (its) had prepared himself for this; but he (its) found something utterly different. The head lay sideways on the pillow. Levin could see the scanty locks wet with sweat on the temples and tense, transparent-looking forehead.

'' It cannot be that that fearful body was my brother Nikolay?'' thought Levin. But he (Levin) went closer, saw the face, and doubt became impossible.

In spite of the terrible change in the face, Levin had only to glance at those eager eyes raised at his (Levin) approach, only to catch the faint movement of the mouth under the sticky mustache, to realize the terrible truth that this death-like body was his (Levin) living brother.

The glittering eyes looked sternly and reproachfully at his (Levin) brother as he (Levin) drew near. And immediately this glance established a living relationship between living men.

Levin immediately felt the reproach in the eyes fixed on him (Levin), and felt remorse at his (Levin) own happiness. When Konstantin took him (Konstantin) by the hand, Nikolay smiled.

The smile was faint, scarcely perceptible, and in spite of the smile the stern expression of the eyes was unchanged. ''

You did not expect to find me like this,'' he (Nikolay) articulated with effort. '' Yes...no,'' said Levin, hesitating over his (Levin) words.

'' How was it you didn't let me know before, that is, at the time of my wedding? I made inquiries in all directions.

He (Levin) had to talk so as not to be silent, and he (Levin) did not know what to say, especially as his (Levin) brother made no reply, and simply stared without dropping his (Levin) eyes, and evidently penetrated to the inner meaning of each word.

'' Levin told his (Levin) brother that his (Levin) wife had come with him (Levin). Nikolay expressed pleasure, but said he (Nikolay) was afraid of frightening her (wife) by his (Nikolay) condition.

Levin expected something of peculiar gravity and importance from the expression of his (Levin) face, but Nikolay began speaking of his (Nikolay) health.

A silence followed. Suddenly Nikolay stirred, and began to say something. He (Nikolay) found fault with the doctor, regretting he (Nikolay) had not a celebrated Moscow doctor.

Seizing the first moment of silence, Levin got up, anxious to escape, if only for an instant, from his (Levin) agonizing emotion, and said that he (Levin) would go and fetch his (Levin) wife.

Levin saw that he (Levin) still hoped. '' Very well, and I'll tell her (wife) to tidy up here. It's dirty and stinking here, I expect.

Marya! clear up the room,'' the sick man said with effort. '' Oh, and when you've cleared up, go away yourself,'' he (man) added, looking inquiringly at his (man) brother.

He (man) had said he (man) would fetch his (man) wife, but now, taking stock of the emotion he (man) was feeling, he (man) decided that he (man) would try on the contrary to persuade her (wife) not to go in to the sick man.

Levin made no answer. Going out into the corridor, he (Levin) stopped short. '' Why should she (wife) suffer as I am suffering?

'' he (Levin) thought. '' Well, how is he (Levin)?'' Kitty asked with a frightened face. '' Oh, it's awful, it's awful! What did you come for?'' said Levin.

Kitty was silent for a few seconds, looking timidly and ruefully at her (Kitty) husband; then she (Kitty) went up and took him (Levin) by the elbow with both hands.

'' Kostya! take me to him (Kostya); it will be easier for us to bear it together. You only take me, take me to him (Kostya), please, and go away,'' she (Kitty) said.

'' You must understand that for me to see you, and not to see him (Kostya), is far more painful. There I might be a help to you and to him (Kostya).

Levin was obliged to agree, and regaining his (Levin) composure, and completely forgetting about Marya Nikolaevna by now, he (Levin) went again in to his (Levin) brother with Kitty.

Stepping lightly, and continually glancing at her (Kitty) husband, showing him (husband) a valorous and sympathetic face, Kitty went into the sick-room, and, turning without haste, noiselessly closed the door.

With inaudible steps she (Kitty) went quickly to the sick man's bedside, and going up so that he (man) had not to turn his (man) head, she (Kitty) immediately clasped in her (Kitty) fresh young hand the skeleton of his (man) huge hand, pressed it, and began speaking with that soft eagerness, sympathetic and not jarring, which is peculiar to women.

Please, let me! '' she (Kitty) besought her (Kitty) husband, as though the happiness of her (Kitty) life depended on it. '' We have met, though we were not acquainted, at Soden,'' she (Kitty) said.

'' You never thought I was to be your sister?''

``You would not have recognized me? '' (he)
he (Soden) said, with a radiant smile at her (Kitty) entrance.

'' Yes, I should. What a good thing you let us know! Not a day has passed that Kostya has not mentioned you, and been anxious.

Before she (Kitty) had finished speaking, there had come back into his (Kostya) face the stern, reproachful expression of the dying man's envy of the living.

I am afraid you are not quite comfortable here,'' she (Kitty) said, turning away from his (Kostya) fixed stare, and looking about the room.

'' But the sick man's interest did not last long. '' '' We must ask about another room,'' she (Kitty) said to her (Kitty) husband,

``so that we might be nearer.

Chapter 18 Levin could not look calmly at his (Levin) brother; he (Levin) could not himself be natural and calm in his (Levin) presence.

When he (Levin) went in to the sick man, his (Levin) eyes and his (Levin) attention were unconsciously dimmed, and he (Levin) did not see and did not distinguish the details of his (Levin) brother's position.

He (Levin) smelt the awful odor, saw the dirt, disorder, and miserable condition, and heard the groans, and felt that nothing could be done to help.

It never entered his (Levin) head to analyze the details of the sick man's situation, to consider how that body was lying under the quilt, how those emaciated legs and thighs and spine were lying huddled up, and whether they could not be made more comfortable, whether anything could not be done to make things, if not better, at least less bad.

'' (husband)
