It made his (Levin) blood run cold when he (Levin) began to think of all these details. He (Levin) was absolutely convinced that nothing could be done to prolong his (Levin) brother's life or to relieve his (Levin) suffering.

But a sense of his (Levin) regarding all aid as out of the question was felt by the sick man, and exasperated him (man).

And this made it still more painful for Levin. To be in the sick-room was agony to him (Levin), not to be there still worse.

And he (Levin) was continually, on various pretexts, going out of the room, and coming in again, because he (Levin) was unable to remain alone.

And pity in her (man) womanly heart did not arouse at all that feeling of horror and loathing that it aroused in her (man) husband, but a desire to act, to find out all the details of his (husband) state, and to remedy them.

And since she (man) had not the slightest doubt that it was her (man) duty to help him (husband), she (man) had no doubt either that it was possible, and immediately set to work.

But Kitty thought, and felt, and acted quite differently. On seeing the sick man, she (Kitty) pitied him (man). The very details, the mere thought of which reduced her (Kitty) husband to terror, immediately engaged her (Kitty) attention.

She (Kitty) sent for the doctor, sent to the chemist's, set the maid who had come with her (Kitty) and Marya Nikolaevna to sweep and dust and scrub; she (Nikolaevna) herself washed up something, washed out something else, laid something under the quilt.

She (Nikolaevna) herself went several times to her (Nikolaevna) room, regardless of the men she (Nikolaevna) met in the corridor, got out and brought in sheets, pillow cases, towels, and shirts.

The waiter, who was busy with a party of engineers dining in the dining hall, came several times with an irate countenance in answer to her (Nikolaevna) summons, and could not avoid carrying out her (Nikolaevna) orders, as she (Nikolaevna) gave them with such gracious insistence that there was no evading her (Nikolaevna).

Something was by her (Nikolaevna) directions brought into the sick-room, something else was carried out. Levin did not approve of all this; he (Levin) did not believe it would be of any good to the patient.

But the sick man, though he (man) seemed and was indifferent about it, was not angry, but only abashed, and on the whole as it were interested in what she (Nikolaevna) was doing with him (man).

Coming back from the doctor to whom Kitty had sent him (doctor), Levin, on opening the door, came upon the sick man at the instant when, by Kitty's directions, they were changing his (man) linen.

The long white ridge of his (man) spine, with the huge, prominent shoulder blades and jutting ribs and vertebrae, was bare, and Marya Nikolaevna and the waiter were struggling with the sleeve of the night shirt, and could not get the long, limp arm into it.

Kitty, hurriedly closing the door after Levin, was not looking that way; but the sick man groaned, and she (Kitty) moved rapidly towards him (man).

Above all, he (man) feared the patient would be angry at it.

``Make haste,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said. '' Oh, don't you come,'' said the sick man angrily.

'' I'll do it my myself...''

``What say?'' (I)
queried Marya Nikolaevna. But Kitty heard and saw he (man) was ashamed and uncomfortable at being naked before her (Kitty).

'' I'm not looking, I'm not looking! '' she (Kitty) said, putting the arm in. '' Marya Nikolaevna, you come this side, you do it,'' she (Nikolaevna) added.

Please go for me, there's a little bottle in my small bag,'' she (Nikolaevna) said, turning to her (Nikolaevna) husband,

``you know, in the side pocket; bring it, please, and meanwhile they'll finish clearing up here.

The heavy smell was replaced by the smell of aromatic vinegar, which Kitty with pouting lips and puffed-out, rosy cheeks was squirting through a little pipe.

'' (husband)

'' Returning with the bottle, Levin found the sick man settled comfortably and everything about him (Levin) completely changed. There was no dust visible anywhere, a rug was laid by the bedside.

On the table stood medicine bottles and decanters tidily arranged, and the linen needed was folded up there, and Kitty's broderie anglaise .

The sick man himself, washed and combed, lay in clean sheets on high raised pillows, in a clean night-shirt with a white collar about his (man) astoundingly thin neck, and with a new expression of hope looked fixedly at Kitty.

The doctor brought by Levin, and found by him (Levin) at the club, was not the one who had been attending Nikolay Levin, as the patient was dissatisfied with him (Levin).

The new doctor took up a stethoscope and sounded the patient, shook his (patient) head, prescribed medicine, and with extreme minuteness explained first how to take the medicine and then what diet was to be kept to.

On the other table by the patient's bed there were candles and drink and powders. He (patient) advised eggs, raw or hardly cooked, and seltzer water, with warm milk at a certain temperature.

When the doctor had gone away the sick man said something to his (man) brother, of which Levin could distinguish only the last words:

``Your Katya.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

By the expression with which he (Levin) gazed at her (Katya), Levin saw that he (Levin) was praising her (Katya). He (Levin) called indeed to Katya, as he (Levin) called her (Katya).

'' I'm much better already,'' he (Levin) said. '' Why, with you I should have got well long ago. How nice it is!

'' he (Levin) took her (Katya) hand and drew it towards his (Levin) lips, but as though afraid she (Katya) would dislike it he (Levin) changed his (Levin) mind, let it go, and only stroked it.

Kitty took his (Levin) hand in both hers and pressed it. '' Now turn me over on the left side and go to bed,'' he (Levin) said.

No one could make out what he (Levin) said but Kitty; she (Kitty) alone understood. She (Kitty) understood because she (Kitty) was all the while mentally keeping watch on what he (Levin) needed.

'' On the other side,'' she (Kitty) said to her (Kitty) husband,

``he (husband) always sleeps on that side. Turn him (husband) over, it's so disagreeable calling the servants.

Terrible as it was to Levin to put his (Levin) arms round that terrible body, to take hold of that under the quilt, of which he (Levin) preferred to know nothing, under his (Levin) wife's influence he (Levin) made his (Levin) resolute face that she (wife) knew so well, and putting his (Levin) arms into the bed took hold of the body, but in spite of his (Levin) own strength he (Levin) was struck by the strange heaviness of those powerless limbs.

While he (Levin) was turning him (Levin) over, conscious of the huge emaciated arm about his (Levin) neck, Kitty swiftly and noiselessly turned the pillow, beat it up and settled in it the sick man's head, smoothing back his (man) hair, which was sticking again to his (man) moist brow.

I'm not strong enough. Can you?'' (husband)

she (Kitty) said to Marya Nikolaevna. '' I'm afraid not,'' answered Marya Nikolaevna. The sick man kept his (man) brother's hand in his (man) own.

Levin felt that he (Levin) meant to do something with his (Levin) hand and was pulling it somewhere. Levin yielded with a sinking heart: yes, he (Levin) drew it to his (Levin) mouth and kissed it.

Levin, shaking with sobs and unable to articulate a word, went out of the room. Chapter 19

``Thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

So Levin thought about his (Levin) wife as he (Levin) talked to her (wife) that evening. Levin thought of the text, not because he (Levin) considered himself
``wise and prudent.

He (Levin) did not so consider himself, but he (Levin) could not help knowing that he (Levin) had more intellect than his (Levin) wife and Agafea Mihalovna, and he (Levin) could not help knowing that when he (Levin) thought of death, he (Levin) thought with all the force of his (Levin) intellect.

He (Levin) knew too that the brains of many great men, whose thoughts he (Levin) had read, had brooded over death and yet knew not a hundredth part of what his (Levin) wife and Agafea Mihalovna knew about it.

'' (he)

Different as those two women were, Agafea Mihalovna and Katya, as his (Levin) brother Nikolay had called her (Katya), and as Levin particularly liked to call her (Katya) now, they were quite alike in this.

Both knew, without a shade of doubt, what sort of thing life was and what was death, and though neither of them could have answered, and would even not have understood the questions that presented themselves to Levin, both had no doubt of the significance of this event, and were precisely alike in their way of looking at it, which they shared with millions of people.

The proof that they knew for a certainty the nature of death lay in the fact that they knew without a second of hesitation how to deal with the dying, and were not frightened of them.

Levin and other men like him (Levin), though they could have said a great deal about death, obviously did not know this since they were afraid of death, and were absolutely at a loss what to do when people were dying.

If Levin had been alone now with his (Levin) brother Nikolay, he (Levin) would have looked at him (Levin) with terror, and with still greater terror waited, and would not have known what else to do.

More than that, he (Levin) did not know what to say, how to look, how to move. To talk of outside things seemed to him (Levin) shocking, impossible, to talk of death and depressing subjects--also impossible.

If I look at him (Levin) he (Levin) will think I am studying him (Levin), I am afraid; if I don't look at him (Levin), he (Levin)'ll think I'm thinking of other things.

To be silent, also impossible. '' If I walk on tiptoe, he (Levin) will be vexed; to tread firmly, I'm ashamed. ''

Kitty evidently did not think of herself, and had no time to think about herself: she (Kitty) was thinking about him (Levin) because she (Kitty) knew something, and all went well.

She (Kitty) told him (Levin) about herself even and about her (Kitty) wedding, and smiled and sympathized with him (Levin) and petted him (Levin), and talked of cases of recovery and all went well; so then she (Kitty) must know.

The proof that her (Kitty) behavior and Agafea Mihalovna's was not instinctive, animal, irrational, was that apart from the physical treatment, the relief of suffering, both Agafea Mihalovna and Kitty required for the dying man something else more important than the physical treatment, and something which had nothing in common with physical conditions.

Agafea Mihalovna, speaking of the man just dead, had said:

``Well, thank God, he (God) took the sacrament and received absolution; God grant each one of us such a death.

Katya in just the same way, besides all her (Katya) care about linen, bedsores, drink, found time the very first day to persuade the sick man of the necessity of taking the sacrament and receiving absolution.

On getting back from the sick-room to their own two rooms for the night, Levin sat with hanging head not knowing what to do.

Not to speak of supper, of preparing for bed, of considering what they were going to do, he (Levin) could not even talk to his (Levin) wife; he (Levin) was ashamed to.

She (wife) ordered supper to be brought, herself unpacked their things, and herself helped to make the beds, and did not even forget to sprinkle them with Persian powder.

She (wife) showed that alertness, that swiftness of reflection comes out in men before a battle, in conflict, in the dangerous and decisive moments of life--those moments when a man shows once and for all his (man) value, and that all his (man) past has not been wasted but has been a preparation for these moments.

Everything went rapidly in her (wife) hands, and before it was twelve o'clock all their things were arranged cleanly and tidily in her (wife) rooms, in such a way that the hotel rooms seemed like home: the beds were made, brushes, combs, looking-glasses were put out, table napkins were spread.

Levin felt that it was unpardonable to eat, to sleep, to talk even now, and it seemed to him (Levin) that every movement he (Levin) made was unseemly.

'' (the man)

Kitty, on the contrary, was more active than usual. She (Kitty) was even livelier than usual. She (Kitty) arranged the brushes, but she (Kitty) did it all so that there was nothing shocking in it.

They could neither of them eat, however, and for a long while they could not sleep, and did not even go to bed.

I am very glad I persuaded him (Levin) to receive extreme unction tomorrow,'' she (Kitty) said, sitting in her (Kitty) dressing jacket before her (Kitty) folding looking glass, combing her (Kitty) soft, fragrant hair with a fine comb.

'' '' I have never seen it, but I know, mamma has told me, there are prayers said for recovery. ''

``Do you suppose he (Levin) can possibly recover?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, watching a slender tress at the back of her (Kitty) round little head that was continually hidden when she (Kitty) passed the comb through the front.

'' I asked the doctor; he (doctor) said he (doctor) couldn't live more than three days. But can they be sure? I'm very glad, anyway, that I persuaded him (doctor),'' she (Kitty) said, looking askance at her (Kitty) husband through her (Kitty) hair.

Anything is possible,'' she (Kitty) added with that peculiar, rather sly expression that was always in her (Kitty) face when she (Kitty) spoke of religion.

Since their conversation about religion when they were engaged neither of them had ever started a discussion of the subject, but she (Kitty) performed all the ceremonies of going to church, saying her (Kitty) prayers, and so on, always with the unvarying conviction that this ought to be so.

In spite of his (husband) assertion to the contrary, she (Kitty) was firmly persuaded that he (husband) was as much a Christian as she (Kitty), and indeed a far better one; and all that he (husband) said about it was simply one of his (husband) absurd masculine freaks, just as he (husband) would say about her (Kitty) broderie anglaise that good people patch holes, but that she (Kitty) cut them on purpose, and so on.

'' '' Yes, you see this woman, Marya Nikolaevna, did not know how to manage all this,'' said Levin. '' And...I must own

He (Levin) took her (Nikolaevna) hand and did not kiss it -LRB-to kiss her (Nikolaevna) hand in such closeness to death seemed to him (Levin) improper-RRB-; he (Levin) merely squeezed it with a penitent air, looking at her (Nikolaevna) brightening eyes.

It would have been miserable for you to be alone,'' she (Nikolaevna) said, and lifting her (Nikolaevna) hands which hid her (Nikolaevna) cheeks flushing with pleasure, twisted her (Nikolaevna) coil of hair on the nape of her (Nikolaevna) neck and pinned it there.

I'm very, very glad you came. You are such purity that... '' '' '' No,'' she (Nikolaevna) went on,

``she (Nikolaevna) did not know how....

Luckily, I learned a lot at Soden.'' (she)

``Surely there are not people there so ill?'' (unknown)
``Worse. '' (me)
'' What's so awful to me is that I can't see him (Soden) as he (Soden) was when he (Soden) was young.

You would not believe how charming he (Soden) was as a youth, but I did not understand him (Soden) then.''

``I can quite, quite believe it.

she (Nikolaevna) said; and, distressed at what she (Nikolaevna) had said, she (Nikolaevna) looked round at her (Nikolaevna) husband, and tears came into her (Nikolaevna) eyes.

How I feel that we might have been friends! '' (he)

'' Yes, might have been ,'' he (husband) said mournfully. '' He (husband)'s just one of those people of whom they say they're not for this world.''

'' But we have many days before us; we must go to bed,'' said Kitty, glancing at her (Kitty) tiny watch. Chapter 20

His (husband) great eyes, fastened on the holy image that was set out on a card table covered with a colored napkin, expressed such passionate prayer and hope that it was awful to Levin to see it.

Levin knew that this passionate prayer and hope would only make him (Levin) feel more bitterly parting from the life he (Levin) so loved.

Levin knew his (Levin) brother and the workings of his (Levin) intellect: he (Levin) knew that his (Levin) unbelief came not from life being easier for him (Levin) without faith, but had grown up because step by step the contemporary scientific interpretation of natural phenomena crushed out the possibility of faith; and so he (Levin) knew that his (Levin) present return was not a legitimate one, brought about by way of the same working of his (Levin) intellect, but simply a temporary, interested return to faith in a desperate hope of recovery.

The next day the sick man received the sacrament and extreme unction. During the ceremony Nikolay Levin prayed fervently. Levin knew too that Kitty had strengthened his (Levin) hope by accounts of the marvelous recoveries she (Kitty) had heard of.

Levin knew all this; and it was agonizingly painful to him (Levin) to behold the supplicating, hopeful eyes and the emaciated wrist, lifted with difficulty, making the sign of the cross on the tense brow, and the prominent shoulders and hollow, gasping chest, which one could not feel consistent with the life the sick man was praying for.

He (man) said, addressing God,

``If Thou dost exist, make this man to recover'' (God)
-LRB-of course this same thing has been repeated many times-RRB-,
``and Thou wilt save him (man) and me.'' (God)

During the sacrament Levin did what he (Levin), an unbeliever, had done a thousand times. After extreme unction the sick man became suddenly much better.

He (man) did not cough once in the course of an hour, smiled, kissed Kitty's hand, thanking her (Kitty) with tears, and said he (man) was comfortable, free from pain, and that he (man) felt strong and had an appetite.

Hopelessly ill as he (man) was, obvious as it was at the first glance that he (man) could not recover, Levin and Kitty were for that hour both in the same state of excitement, happy, though fearful of being mistaken.

He (Levin) even raised himself when his (Levin) soup was brought, and asked for a cutlet as well. '' Is he (Levin) better?'' ''

Yes, much. '' '' It's wonderful.'' '' There's nothing wonderful in it. ''

``Anyway, he (Levin)'s better,'' (unknown)
they said in a whisper, smiling to one another.

This self-deception was not of long duration. The sick man fell into a quiet sleep, but he (man) was waked up half an hour later by his (man) cough.

The reality of his (man) suffering crushed all hopes in Levin and Kitty and in the sick man himself, leaving no doubt, no memory even of past hopes.

Without referring to what he (Levin) had believed in half an hour before, as though ashamed even to recall it, he (Levin) asked for iodine to inhale in a bottle covered with perforated paper.

Levin gave him (Levin) the bottle, and the same look of passionate hope with which he (Levin) had taken the sacrament was now fastened on his (Levin) brother, demanding from him (Levin) the confirmation of the doctor's words that inhaling iodine worked wonders.

And all at once every hope vanished in those about him (Levin) and in himself. '' Is Katya not here? '' he (Levin) gasped, looking round while Levin reluctantly assented to the doctor's words.

'' No; so I can say it.... It was for her (Katya) sake I went through that farce. She (Katya)'s so sweet; but you and I can't deceive ourselves.

This is what I believe in,'' he (Levin) said, and, squeezing the bottle in his (Levin) bony hand, he (Levin) began breathing over it.

At eight o'clock in the evening Levin and his (Levin) wife were drinking tea in their room when Marya Nikolaevna ran in to them breathlessly.

She (Nikolaevna) was pale, and her (Nikolaevna) lips were quivering. '' He (Levin) is dying! '' she (Nikolaevna) whispered. '' I'm afraid will die this minute.

'' Both of them ran to him (Levin). He (Levin) was sitting raised up with one elbow on the bed, his (Levin) long back bent, and his (Levin) head hanging low.

'' How do you feel?'' Levin asked in a whisper, after a silence. '' I feel I'm setting off,'' Nikolay said with difficulty, but with extreme distinctness, screwing the words out of himself.

He (Nikolay) did not raise his (Nikolay) head, but simply turned his (Nikolay) eyes upwards, without their reaching his (Nikolay) brother's face. '' Katya, go away!

'' he (Nikolay) added. Levin jumped up, and with a peremptory whisper made her (Katya) go out. '' I'm setting off,'' he (Levin) said again.

'' Why do you think so?'' said Levin, so as to say something. '' Because I'm setting off,'' he (Levin) repeated, as though he (Levin) had a liking for the phrase.

'' It's the end. '' Marya Nikolaevna went up to him (Levin). '' You had better lie down; you'd be easier,'' she (Nikolaevna) said.

'' I shall lie down soon enough,'' he (Levin) pronounced slowly,

``when I'm dead,'' (he)
he (Levin) said sarcastically, wrathfully. '' Well, you can lay me down if you like.

The dying man lay with closed eyes, but the muscles twitched from time to time on his (man) forehead, as with one thinking deeply and intensely.

Levin involuntarily thought with him (Levin) of what it was that was happening to him (Levin) now, but in spite of all his (Levin) mental efforts to go along with him (Levin) he (Levin) saw by the expression of that calm, stern face that for the dying man all was growing clearer and clearer that was still as dark as ever for Levin.

'' Levin laid his (Levin) brother on his (Levin) back, sat down beside him (Levin), and gazed at his (Levin) face, holding his (Levin) breath. ''

Yes, yes, so,'' the dying man articulated slowly at intervals. '' Wait a little. '' He (Levin) was silent. '' Right! '' he (Levin) pronounced all at once reassuringly, as though all were solved for him (Levin).

'' O Lord! '' he (Levin) murmured, and sighed deeply. Marya Nikolaevna felt his (Levin) feet. '' They're getting cold,'' she (Nikolaevna) whispered. For a long while, a very long while it seemed to Levin, the sick man lay motionless.

But he (Levin) was still alive, and from time to time he (Levin) sighed. Levin by now was exhausted from mental strain. He (Levin) felt that, with no mental effort, could he (Levin) understand what it was that was right .

He (Levin) could not even think of the problem of death itself, but with no will of his (Levin) own thoughts kept coming to him (Levin) of what he (Levin) had to do next; closing the dead man's eyes, dressing him (man), ordering the coffin.

And, strange to say, he (man) felt utterly cold, and was not conscious of sorrow nor of loss, less still of pity for his (man) brother.

If he (man) had any feeling for his (man) brother at that moment, it was envy for the knowledge the dying man had now that he (man) could not have.

A long time more he (man) sat over him (man) so, continually expecting the end. But the end did not come. The door opened and Kitty appeared.

Levin got up to stop her (Kitty). But at the moment he (Levin) was getting up, he (Levin) caught the sound of the dying man stirring.

'' Don't go away,'' said Nikolay and held out his (Nikolay) hand. Levin gave him (Levin) his (Levin), and angrily waved to his (Levin) wife to go away.

With the dying man's hand in his (Levin) hand, he (Levin) sat for half an hour, an hour, another hour. He (Levin) did not think of death at all now.

He (Levin) wondered what Kitty was doing; who lived in the next room; whether the doctor lived in a house of his (doctor) own.

He (doctor) longed for food and for sleep. He (doctor) cautiously drew away his (doctor) hand and felt the feet. The feet were cold, but the sick man was still breathing.

Levin tried again to move away on tiptoe, but the sick man stirred again and said:

``Don't go. '' (the man)
* * * * * * * * The dawn came; the sick man's condition was unchanged.

Levin stealthily withdrew his (Levin) hand, and without looking at the dying man, went off to his (man) own room and went to sleep.

When he (man) woke up, instead of news of his (man) brother's death which he (man) expected, he (man) learned that the sick man had returned to his (man) earlier condition.

He (man) had begun sitting up again, coughing, had begun eating again, talking again, and again had ceased to talk of death, again had begun to express hope of his (man) recovery, and had become more irritable and more gloomy than ever.

He (man) was angry with everyone, and said nasty things to everyone, reproached everyone for his (man) sufferings, and insisted that they should get him (man) a celebrated doctor from Moscow.

To all inquiries made him (man) as to how he (man) felt, he (man) made the same answer with an expression of vindictive reproachfulness,

``I'm suffering horribly, intolerably!

The sick man was suffering more and more, especially from bedsores, which it was impossible now to remedy, and grew more and more angry with everyone about him (man), blaming them for everything, and especially for not having brought him (man) a doctor from Moscow.

Kitty tried in every possible way to relieve him (man), to soothe him (man); but it was all in vain, and Levin saw that she (Kitty) herself was exhausted both physically and morally, though she (Kitty) would not admit it.

The sense of death, which had been evoked in all by his (Levin) taking leave of life on the night when he (Levin) had sent for his (Levin) brother, was broken up.

No one, neither his (Levin) brother nor Kitty, could soothe him (Levin). '' (he)

Everyone knew that he (Levin) must inevitably die soon, that he (Levin) was half dead already.

Everyone wished for nothing but that he (Levin) should die as soon as possible, and everyone, concealing this, gave him (Levin) medicines, tried to find remedies and doctors, and deceived him (Levin) and themselves and each other.

And owing to the bent of his (Levin) character, and because he (Levin) loved the dying man more than anyone else did, Levin was most painfully conscious of this deceit.

Levin, who had long been possessed by the idea of reconciling his (Levin) brothers, at least in face of death, had written to his (Levin) brother, Sergey Ivanovitch, and having received an answer from him (Levin), he (Levin) read this letter to the sick man.

All this was falsehood, disgusting, irreverent deceit. Sergey Ivanovitch wrote that he (Ivanovitch) could not come himself, and in touching terms he (Ivanovitch) begged his (Ivanovitch) brother's forgiveness.

The sick man said nothing. '' What am I to write to him (man)?'' said Levin. '' I hope you are not angry with him (Levin)?''

'' No, not the least!'' Nikolay answered, vexed at the question.

``Tell him (Nikolay) to send me a doctor. '' (unknown)
Three more days of agony followed; the sick man was still in the same condition.

The sense of longing for his (man) death was felt by everyone now at the mere sight of him (man), by the waiters and the hotel-keeper and all the people staying in the hotel, and the doctor and Marya Nikolaevna and Levin and Kitty.

The sick man alone did not express this feeling, but on the contrary was furious at their not getting him (man) doctors, and went on taking medicine and talking of life.

Only at rare moments, when the opium gave him (man) an instant's relief from the never-ceasing pain, he (man) would sometimes, half asleep, utter what was ever more intense in his (man) heart than in all the others:

``Oh, if it were only the end!'' (the others)
or:
``When will it be over? '' (the others)
His (man) sufferings, steadily growing more intense, did their work and prepared him (man) for death.

There was no position in which he (man) was not in pain, there was not a minute in which he (man) was unconscious of it, not a limb, not a part of his (man) body that did not ache and cause him (man) agony.

Even the memories, the impressions, the thoughts of this body awakened in him (man) now the same aversion as the body itself.

Those about him (man) felt this, and instinctively did not allow themselves to move freely, to talk, to express their wishes before him (man).

The sight of other people, their remarks, his (man) own reminiscences, everything was for him (man) a source of agony. All his (man) life was merged in the one feeling of suffering and desire to be rid of it.

There was evidently coming over him (man) that revulsion that would make him (man) look upon death as the goal of his (man) desires, as happiness.

Hitherto each individual desire, aroused by suffering or privation, such as hunger, fatigue, thirst, had been satisfied by some bodily function giving pleasure.

And so all desires were merged in one--the desire to be rid of all his (man) sufferings and their source, the body.

But he (man) had no words to express this desire of deliverance, and so he (man) did not speak of it, and from habit asked for the satisfaction of desires which could not now be satisfied.

``Turn me over on the other side,'' (he)
he (man) would say, and immediately after he (man) would ask to be turned back again as before.

But now no physical craving or suffering received relief, and the effort to relieve them only caused fresh suffering.

``Give me some broth.

Take away the broth. Talk of something: why are you silent? '' (he)

And directly they began to talk he (man) would close his (man) eyes, and would show weariness, indifference, and loathing.

On the tenth day from their arrival at the town, Kitty was unwell. She (Kitty) suffered from headache and sickness, and she (Kitty) could not get up all the morning.

The doctor opined that the indisposition arose from fatigue and excitement, and prescribed rest. After dinner, however, Kitty got up and went as usual with her (Kitty) work to the sick man.

He (man) looked at her (Kitty) sternly when she (Kitty) came in, and smiled contemptuously when she (Kitty) said she (Kitty) had been unwell. That day he (man) was continually blowing his (man) nose, and groaning piteously.

'' How do you feel? '' she (Kitty) asked him (man). '' Worse,'' he (man) articulated with difficulty. '' In pain!''

``In pain, where?'' (the man)

Though it was said in a whisper, the sick man, whose hearing Levin had noticed was very keen, must have heard.

``Everywhere.'' (unknown)
``It will be over today, you will see,'' (Marya Nikolaevna/Marya)
said Marya Nikolaevna. Levin said hush to her (Nikolaevna), and looked round at the sick man.

Nikolay had heard; but these words produced no effect on him (Nikolay). His (Nikolay) eyes had still the same intense, reproachful look. ''

Why do you think so? '' Levin asked her (Nikolaevna), when she (Nikolaevna) had followed him (Levin) into the corridor. '' He (Levin) has begun picking at himself,'' said Marya Nikolaevna.

'' How do you mean?''

``Like this,'' (she)
she (Nikolaevna) said, tugging at the folds of her (Nikolaevna) woolen skirt. Levin noticed, indeed, that all that day the patient pulled at himself, as it were, trying to snatch something away.

Towards night the sick man was not able to lift his (man) hands, and could only gaze before him (man) with the same intensely concentrated expression in his (man) eyes.

Marya Nikolaevna's prediction came true. Even when his (man) brother or Kitty bent over him (man), so that he (man) could see them, he (man) looked just the same.

Kitty sent for the priest to read the prayer for the dying. While the priest was reading it, the dying man did not show any sign of life; his (man) eyes were closed.

Levin, Kitty, and Marya Nikolaevna stood at the bedside. The priest had not quite finished reading the prayer when the dying man stretched, sighed, and opened his (man) eyes.

The priest, on finishing the prayer, put the cross to the cold forehead, then slowly returned it to the stand, and after standing for two minutes more in silence, he (priest) touched the huge, bloodless hand that was turning cold.

He (priest) is gone,'' said the priest, and would have moved away; but suddenly there was a faint stir in the mustaches of the dead man that seemed glued together, and quite distinctly in the hush they heard from the bottom of the chest the sharply defined sounds:

And a minute later the face brightened, a smile came out under the mustaches, and the women who had gathered round began carefully laying out the corpse.

The sight of his (man) brother, and the nearness of death, revived in Levin that sense of horror in face of the insoluble enigma, together with the nearness and inevitability of death, that had come upon him (Levin) that autumn evening when his (Levin) brother had come to him (Levin).

This feeling was now even stronger than before; even less than before did he (Levin) feel capable of apprehending the meaning of death, and its inevitability rose up before him (Levin) more terrible than ever.

''

``Not quite...soon. '' (wife)
But now, thanks to his (Levin) wife's presence, that feeling did not reduce him (Levin) to despair. In spite of death, he (Levin) felt the need of life and love.

He (Levin) felt that love saved him (Levin) from despair, and that this love, under the menace of despair, had become still stronger and purer.

The one mystery of death, still unsolved, had scarcely passed before his (Levin) eyes, when another mystery had arisen, as insoluble, urging him (Levin) to love and to life.

Chapter 21 From the moment when Alexey Alexandrovitch understood from his (Alexandrovitch) interviews with Betsy and with Stepan Arkadyevitch that all that was expected of him (Alexandrovitch) was to leave his (Alexandrovitch) wife in peace, without burdening her (wife) with his (Alexandrovitch) presence, and that his (Alexandrovitch) wife herself desired this, he (Alexandrovitch) felt so distraught that he (Alexandrovitch) could come to no decision of himself

; he (Alexandrovitch) did not know himself what he (Alexandrovitch) wanted now, and putting himself in the hands of those who were so pleased to interest themselves in his (Alexandrovitch) affairs, he (Alexandrovitch) met everything with unqualified assent.

It was only when Anna had left his (Alexandrovitch) house, and the English governess sent to ask him (Alexandrovitch) whether she (Anna) should dine with him (Alexandrovitch) or separately, that for the first time he (Alexandrovitch) clearly comprehended his (Alexandrovitch) position, and was appalled by it.

Most difficult of all in this position was the fact that he (Alexandrovitch) could not in any way connect and reconcile his (Alexandrovitch) past with what was now.

The doctor confirmed his (doctor) suppositions in regard to Kitty. Her (Kitty) indisposition was a symptom that she (Kitty) was with child. It was not the past when he (doctor) had lived happily with his (doctor) wife that troubled him (doctor).

The transition from that past to a knowledge of his (doctor) wife's unfaithfulness he (doctor) had lived through miserably already; that state was painful, but he (doctor) could understand it.

If his (doctor) wife had then, on declaring to him (doctor) her (wife) unfaithfulness, left him (doctor), he (doctor) would have been wounded, unhappy, but he (doctor) would not have been in the hopeless position--incomprehensible to himself--in which he (doctor) felt himself now.

He (doctor) could not now reconcile his (doctor) immediate past, his (doctor) tenderness, his (doctor) love for his (doctor) sick wife, and for the other man's child with what was now the case, that is with the fact that, as it were, in return for all this he (doctor) now found himself alone, put to shame, a laughing-stock, needed by no one, and despised by everyone.

For the first two days after his (doctor) wife's departure Alexey Alexandrovitch received applicants for assistance and his (Alexandrovitch) chief secretary, drove to the committee, and went down to dinner in the dining room as usual.

Without giving himself a reason for what he (Alexandrovitch) was doing, he (Alexandrovitch) strained every nerve of his (Alexandrovitch) being for those two days, simply to preserve an appearance of composure, and even of indifference.

Answering inquiries about the disposition of Anna Arkadyevna's rooms and belongings, he (Alexandrovitch) had exercised immense self-control to appear like a man in whose eyes what had occurred was not unforeseen nor out of the ordinary course of events, and he (Alexandrovitch) attained his (Alexandrovitch) aim

But on the second day after her (Arkadyevna) departure, when Korney gave him (Alexandrovitch) a bill from a fashionable draper's shop, which Anna had forgotten to pay, and announced that the clerk from the shop was waiting, Alexey Alexandrovitch told him (Alexandrovitch) to show the clerk up.

: no one could have detected in him (Alexandrovitch) signs of despair. '' Excuse me, your excellency, for venturing to trouble you.

Alexey Alexandrovitch pondered, as it seemed to the clerk, and all at once, turning round, he (Alexandrovitch) sat down at the table.

Letting his (Alexandrovitch) head sink into his (Alexandrovitch) hands, he (Alexandrovitch) sat for a long while in that position, several times attempted to speak and stopped short.

But if you direct us to apply to her (clerk) excellency, would you graciously oblige us with her (clerk) address?'' Korney, perceiving his (Alexandrovitch) master's emotion, asked the clerk to call another time.

Left alone, Alexey Alexandrovitch recognized that he (Alexandrovitch) had not the strength to keep up the line of firmness and composure any longer.

He (Alexandrovitch) gave orders for the carriage that was awaiting him (Alexandrovitch) to be taken back, and for no one to be admitted, and he (Alexandrovitch) did not go down to dinner.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) could not endure the weight of universal contempt and exasperation, which he (Alexandrovitch) had distinctly seen in the face of the clerk and of Korney, and of everyone, without exception, whom he (Alexandrovitch) had met during those two days.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that he (Alexandrovitch) could not turn aside from himself the hatred of men, because that hatred did not come from his (Alexandrovitch) being bad -LRB-in that case he (Alexandrovitch) could have tried to be better-RRB-, but from his (Alexandrovitch) being shamefully and repulsively unhappy.

He (Alexandrovitch) knew that for this, for the very fact that his (Alexandrovitch) heart was torn with grief, they would be merciless to him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) knew that his (Alexandrovitch) sole means of security against people was to hide his (Alexandrovitch) wounds from them, and instinctively he (Alexandrovitch) tried to do this for two days, but now he (Alexandrovitch) felt incapable of keeping up the unequal struggle.

He (Alexandrovitch) felt that men would crush him (Alexandrovitch) as dogs strangle a torn dog yelping with pain. His (Alexandrovitch) despair was even intensified by the consciousness that he (Alexandrovitch) was utterly alone in his (Alexandrovitch) sorrow.

In all Petersburg there was not a human being to whom he (Alexandrovitch) could express what he (Alexandrovitch) was feeling, who would feel for him (Alexandrovitch), not as a high official, not as a member of society, but simply as a suffering man; indeed he (man) had not such a one in the whole world.

Alexey Alexandrovitch grew up an orphan. There were two brothers. They did not remember their father, and their mother died when Alexey Alexandrovitch was ten years old.

Their uncle, Karenin, a government official of high standing, at one time a favorite of the late Tsar, had brought them up.

On completing his (Tsar) high school and university courses with medals, Alexey Alexandrovitch had, with his (Alexandrovitch) uncle's aid, immediately started in a prominent position in the service, and from that time forward he (Alexandrovitch) had devoted himself exclusively to political ambition.

In the high school and the university, and afterwards in the service, Alexey Alexandrovitch had never formed a close friendship with anyone.

His (Alexandrovitch) brother had been the person nearest to his (Alexandrovitch) heart, but he (Alexandrovitch) had a post in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and was always abroad, where he (Alexandrovitch) had died shortly after Alexey Alexandrovitch's marriage.

The property was a small one. While he (Alexandrovitch) was governor of a province, Anna's aunt, a wealthy provincial lady, had thrown him (Alexandrovitch)--

middle-aged as he (Alexandrovitch) was, though young for a governor--with her (aunt) niece, and had succeeded in putting him (Alexandrovitch) in such a position that he (Alexandrovitch) had either to declare himself or to leave the town.

There were at the time as many reasons for the step as against it, and there was no overbalancing consideration to outweigh his (Alexandrovitch) invariable rule of abstaining when in doubt.

But Anna's aunt had through a common acquaintance insinuated that he (acquaintance) had already compromised the girl, and that he (acquaintance) was in honor bound to make her (girl) an offer.

Alexey Alexandrovitch was not long in hesitation. He (Alexandrovitch) made the offer, and concentrated on his (Alexandrovitch) betrothed and his (Alexandrovitch) wife all the feeling of which he (Alexandrovitch) was capable.

The attachment he (Alexandrovitch) felt to Anna precluded in his (Alexandrovitch) heart every need of intimate relations with others. And now among all his (Alexandrovitch) acquaintances he (Alexandrovitch) had not one friend.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had plenty of people whom he (Alexandrovitch) could invite to dinner, to whose sympathy he (Alexandrovitch) could appeal in any public affair he (Alexandrovitch) was concerned about, whose interest he (Alexandrovitch) could reckon upon for anyone he (Alexandrovitch) wished to help, with whom he (Alexandrovitch) could candidly discuss other people's business and affairs of state.

But his (Alexandrovitch) relations with these people were confined to one clearly defined channel, and had a certain routine from which it was impossible to depart.

There was one man, a comrade of his (man) at the university, with whom he (man) had made friends later, and with whom he (man) could have spoken of a personal sorrow; but this friend had a post in the Department of Education in a remote part of Russia.

He (friend) had plenty of so-called connections, but no friendships. Of the people in Petersburg the most intimate and most possible were his (friend) chief secretary and his (friend) doctor.

Mihail Vassilievitch Sludin, the chief secretary, was a straightforward, intelligent, good-hearted, and conscientious man, and Alexey Alexandrovitch was aware of his (Alexandrovitch) personal goodwill.

But their five years of official work together seemed to have put a barrier between them that cut off warmer relations.

After signing the papers brought him (Alexandrovitch), Alexey Alexandrovitch had sat for a long while in silence, glancing at Mihail Vassilievitch, and several times he (Alexandrovitch) attempted to speak, but could not.

He (Alexandrovitch) had already prepared the phrase:

``You have heard of my trouble?'' (He)
But he (Alexandrovitch) ended by saying, as usual:
``So you'll get this ready for me?

The other person was the doctor, who had also a kindly feeling for him (doctor); but there had long existed a taciturn understanding between them that both were weighed down by work, and always in a hurry.

'' (he)

and with that dismissed him (doctor). Of his (doctor) women friends, foremost amongst them Countess Lidia Ivanovna, Alexey Alexandrovitch never thought. All women, simply as women, were terrible and distasteful to him (Alexandrovitch).

At the bitterest moment of his (Alexandrovitch) lonely despair she (Ivanovna) came to him (Alexandrovitch), and without waiting to be announced, walked straight into his (Alexandrovitch) study.

Chapter 22 Alexey Alexandrovitch had forgotten the Countess Lidia Ivanovna, but she (Ivanovna) had not forgotten him (Alexandrovitch). She (Ivanovna) found him (Alexandrovitch) as he (Alexandrovitch) was sitting with his (Alexandrovitch) head in both hands.

'' J'ai forc√© la consigne ,'' she (Ivanovna) said, walking in with rapid steps and breathing hard with excitement and rapid exercise.

'' I have heard all! Alexey Alexandrovitch! Dear friend! '' she (Ivanovna) went on, warmly squeezing his (Alexandrovitch) hand in both of hers and gazing with her (Ivanovna) fine pensive eyes into his (Alexandrovitch).

Alexey Alexandrovitch, frowning, got up, and disengaging his (Alexandrovitch) hand, moved her (Ivanovna) a chair. '' Won't you sit down, countess? I'm seeing no one because I'm unwell, countess,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, and his (Alexandrovitch) lips twitched.

'' repeated Countess Lidia Ivanovna, never taking her (Ivanovna) eyes off his (Alexandrovitch), and suddenly her (Ivanovna) eyebrows rose at the inner corners, describing a triangle on her (Ivanovna) forehead, her (Ivanovna) ugly yellow face became still uglier, but Alexey Alexandrovitch felt that she (Ivanovna) was sorry for him (Alexandrovitch) and was preparing to cry.

'' Dear friend! And he (Alexandrovitch) too was softened; he (Alexandrovitch) snatched her (Ivanovna) plump hand and proceeded to kiss it. '' Dear friend!

'' she (Ivanovna) said in a voice breaking with emotion. '' You ought not to give way to grief. Your sorrow is a great one, but you ought to find consolation.''

``I am crushed, I am annihilated, I am no longer a man!'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, letting go her (Ivanovna) hand, but still gazing into her (Ivanovna) brimming eyes.

``You will find support; seek it--not in me, though I beseech you to believe in my friendship,'' (she)
she (Ivanovna) said, with a sigh.

'' My position is so awful because I can find nowhere, I cannot find within me strength to support me.'' ''

Our support is love, that love that He (Alexandrovitch) has vouchsafed us. His (Alexandrovitch) burden is light,'' she (Ivanovna) said, with the look of ecstasy Alexey Alexandrovitch knew so well.

Although there was in these words a flavor of that sentimental emotion at her (Ivanovna) own lofty feelings, and that new mystical fervor which had lately gained ground in Petersburg, and which seemed to Alexey Alexandrovitch disproportionate

'' He (Alexandrovitch) will be your support and your succor. '' , still it was pleasant to him (Alexandrovitch) to hear this now.

'' I am weak. I am crushed. I foresaw nothing, and now I understand nothing. '' '' Dear friend,'' repeated Lidia Ivanovna.

'' It's not the loss of what I have not now, it's not that!'' pursued Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' I do not grieve for that.

But I cannot help feeling humiliated before other people for the position I am placed in. It is wrong, but I can't help it, I can't help it.

``Not you it was performed that noble act of forgiveness, at which I was moved to ecstasy, and everyone else too, but He (Alexandrovitch), working within your heart,'' (Countess)
said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, raising her (Ivanovna) eyes rapturously,
``and so you cannot be ashamed of your act.

'' (Lidia Ivanovna/Lidia)

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch knitted his (Alexandrovitch) brows, and crooking his (Alexandrovitch) hands, he (Alexandrovitch) cracked his (Alexandrovitch) fingers. '' One must know all the facts,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said in his (Alexandrovitch) thin voice.

The whole day I have had to be making arrangements, arrangements about household matters arising'' -LRB-he (Alexandrovitch) emphasized the word arising -RRB-

``from my new, solitary position.

'' (he)

A man's strength has its limits, countess, and I have reached my limits. The servants, the governess, the accounts.... These pinpricks have stabbed me to the heart, and I have not the strength to bear it.

At dinner... yesterday, I was almost getting up from the dinner table. I could not bear the way my son looked at me.

He (son) did not ask me the meaning of it all, but he (son) wanted to ask, and I could not bear the look in his (son) eyes.

He (son) was afraid to look at me, but that is not all... '' Alexey Alexandrovitch would have referred to the bill that had been brought him (Alexandrovitch), but his (Alexandrovitch) voice shook, and he (Alexandrovitch) stopped.

That bill on blue paper, for a hat and ribbons, he (Alexandrovitch) could not recall without a rush of self-pity. '' I understand, dear friend,'' said Lidia Ivanovna.

'' I understand it all. Succor and comfort you will find not in me, though I have come only to aid you if I can.

If I could take from off you all these petty, humiliating cares... I understand that a woman's word, a woman's superintendence is needed.

You will intrust it to me? '' Silently and gratefully Alexey Alexandrovitch pressed her (woman) hand. '' Together we will take care of Seryozha.

Practical affairs are not my strong point. But I will set to work. I will be your housekeeper. Don't thank me.

But, dear friend, do not give way to the feeling of which you spoke--being ashamed of what is the Christian's highest glory: he (Christian) who humbles himself shall be exalted .

I do it not from myself...''

``I cannot help thanking you.'' (I)
'' And you cannot thank me. You must thank Him (Christian), and pray to Him (Christian) for succor.

In Him (Christian) alone we find peace, consolation, salvation, and love,'' she (housekeeper) said, and turning her (housekeeper) eyes heavenwards, she (housekeeper) began praying, as Alexey Alexandrovitch gathered from her (housekeeper) silence.

Alexey Alexandrovitch listened to her (housekeeper) now, and those expressions which had seemed to him (Alexandrovitch), if not distasteful, at least exaggerated, now seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) natural and consolatory.

He (Alexandrovitch) was a believer, who was interested in religion primarily in its political aspect, and the new doctrine which ventured upon several new interpretations, just because it paved the way to discussion and analysis, was in principle disagreeable to him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) had hitherto taken up a cold and even antagonistic attitude to this new doctrine, and with Countess Lidia Ivanovna, who had been carried away by it, he (Alexandrovitch) had never argued, but by silence had assiduously parried her (Ivanovna) attempts to provoke him (Alexandrovitch) into argument.

Alexey Alexandrovitch had disliked this new enthusiastic fervor. Now for the first time he (Alexandrovitch) heard her (Ivanovna) words with pleasure, and did not inwardly oppose them.

I am very, very grateful to you, both for your deeds and for your words,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, when she (Ivanovna) had finished praying.

Now I will enter upon my duties,'' she (Ivanovna) said with a smile after a pause, as she (Ivanovna) wiped away the traces of tears.

'' Countess Lidia Ivanovna once more pressed both her (Ivanovna) friend's hands. '' '' I am going to Seryozha. Only in the last extremity shall I apply to you.

Countess Lidia Ivanovna went into Seryozha's part of the house, and dropping tears on the scared child's cheeks, she (Ivanovna) told him (friend) that his (friend) father was a saint and his (friend) mother was dead.

'' And she (mother) got up and went out. Countess Lidia Ivanovna kept her (Ivanovna) promise. She (Ivanovna) did actually take upon herself the care of the organization and management of Alexey Alexandrovitch's household.

All her (Ivanovna) arrangements had to be modified because they could not be carried out, and they were modified by Korney, Alexey Alexandrovitch's valet, who, though no one was aware of the fact, now managed Karenin's household, and quietly and discreetly reported to his (Karenin) master while he (Karenin) was dressing all it was necessary for him (Karenin) to know.

But Lidia Ivanovna's help was none the less real; she (Ivanovna) gave Alexey Alexandrovitch moral support in the consciousness of her (Ivanovna) love and respect for him (Alexandrovitch), and still more, as it was soothing to her (Ivanovna) to believe, in that she (Ivanovna) almost turned him (Alexandrovitch) to Christianity--that is, from an indifferent and apathetic believer she (Ivanovna) turned him (Alexandrovitch) into an ardent and steadfast adherent of the new interpretation of Christian doctrine, which had been gaining ground of late in Petersburg.

But she (Ivanovna) had not overstated the case when saying that practical affairs were not her (Ivanovna) strong point. It was easy for Alexey Alexandrovitch to believe in this teaching.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, like Lidia Ivanovna indeed, and others who shared their views, was completely devoid of vividness of imagination, that spiritual faculty in virtue of which the conceptions evoked by the imagination become so vivid that they must needs be in harmony with other conceptions, and with actual fact.

He (Alexandrovitch) saw nothing impossible and inconceivable in the idea that death, though existing for unbelievers, did not exist for him (Alexandrovitch), and that, as he (Alexandrovitch) was possessed of the most perfect faith, of the measure of which he (Alexandrovitch) was himself the judge, therefore there was no sin in his (Alexandrovitch) soul, and he (Alexandrovitch) was experiencing complete salvation here on earth.

It is true that the erroneousness and shallowness of this conception of his (Alexandrovitch) faith was dimly perceptible to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and he (Alexandrovitch) knew that when, without the slightest idea that his (Alexandrovitch) forgiveness was the action of a higher power, he (Alexandrovitch) had surrendered directly to the feeling of forgiveness, he (Alexandrovitch) had felt more happiness than now when he (Alexandrovitch) was thinking every instant that Christ was in his (Christ) heart, and that in signing official papers he (Christ) was doing His (Christ) will.

But for Alexey Alexandrovitch it was a necessity to think in that way; it was such a necessity for him (Alexandrovitch) in his (Alexandrovitch) humiliation to have some elevated standpoint, however imaginary, from which, looked down upon by all, he (Alexandrovitch) could look down on others, that he (Alexandrovitch) clung, as to his (Alexandrovitch) one salvation, to his (Alexandrovitch) delusion of salvation.

The Countess Lidia Ivanovna had, as a very young and sentimental girl, been married to a wealthy man of high rank, an extremely good-natured, jovial, and extremely dissipated rake.

Two months after marriage her (Ivanovna) husband abandoned her (Ivanovna), and her (Ivanovna) impassioned protestations of affection he (husband) met with a sarcasm and even hostility that people knowing the count's good heart, and seeing no defects in the sentimental Lidia, were at a loss to explain.

Though they were divorced and lived apart, yet whenever the husband met the wife, he (husband) invariably behaved to her (wife) with the same malignant irony, the cause of which was incomprehensible.

Countess Lidia Ivanovna had long given up being in love with her (Ivanovna) husband, but from that time she (Ivanovna) had never given up being in love with someone.

She (Ivanovna) was in love with several people at once, both men and women; she (Ivanovna) had been in love with almost everyone who had been particularly distinguished in any way.

She (Ivanovna) was in love with all the new princes and princesses who married into the imperial family; she (Ivanovna) had been in love with a high dignitary of the Church, a vicar, and a parish priest; she (Ivanovna) had been in love with a journalist, three Slavophiles, with Komissarov, with a minister, a doctor, an English missionary and Karenin.

All these passions constantly waning or growing more ardent, did not prevent her (Ivanovna) from keeping up the most extended and complicated relations with the court and fashionable society.

But from the time that after Karenin's trouble she (Ivanovna) took him (Karenin) under her (Ivanovna) special protection, from the time that she (Ivanovna) set to work in Karenin's household looking after his (Karenin) welfare, she (Ivanovna) felt that all her (Ivanovna) other attachments were not the real thing, and that she (Ivanovna) was now genuinely in love, and with no one but Karenin.

Analyzing her (Ivanovna) feeling, and comparing it with former passions, she (Ivanovna) distinctly perceived that she (Ivanovna) would not have been in love with Komissarov if he (Karenin) had not saved the life of the Tsar, that she (Ivanovna) would not have been in love with Ristitch-Kudzhitsky if there had been no Slavonic question, but that she (Ivanovna) loved Karenin for himself, for his (Karenin) lofty, uncomprehended soul, for the sweet--to her (Ivanovna)--high notes of his (Karenin) voice, for his (Karenin) drawling intonation, his (Karenin) weary eyes, his (Karenin) character, and his (Karenin) soft white hands with their swollen veins.

She (Ivanovna) was not simply overjoyed at meeting him (Karenin), but she (Ivanovna) sought in his (Karenin) face signs of the impression she (Ivanovna) was making on him (Karenin).

Chapter 23 The feeling she (Ivanovna) now experienced for him (Karenin) seemed to her (Ivanovna) stronger than any of her (Ivanovna) former feelings. She (Ivanovna) tried to please him (Karenin), not by her (Ivanovna) words only, but in her (Ivanovna) whole person.

She (Ivanovna) caught herself in reveries on what might have been, if she (Ivanovna) had not been married and he (Karenin) had been free.

She (Ivanovna) blushed with emotion when he (Karenin) came into the room, she (Ivanovna) could not repress a smile of rapture when he (Karenin) said anything amiable to her (Ivanovna).

For his (Karenin) sake it was that she (Ivanovna) now lavished more care on her (Ivanovna) dress than before. For several days now Countess Lidia Ivanovna had been in a state of intense excitement.

Alexey Alexandrovitch must be saved from seeing her (Ivanovna), he (Alexandrovitch) must be saved even from the torturing knowledge that that awful woman was in the same town with him (Alexandrovitch), and that he (Alexandrovitch) might meet her (woman) any minute.

Lidia Ivanovna made inquiries through her (Ivanovna) friends as to what those infamous people , as she (Ivanovna) called Anna and Vronsky, intended doing, and she (Ivanovna) endeavored so to guide every movement of her (Ivanovna) friend during those days that he (friend) could not come across them.

The young adjutant, an acquaintance of Vronsky, through whom she (Ivanovna) obtained her (Ivanovna) information, and who hoped through Countess Lidia Ivanovna to obtain a concession, told her (Ivanovna) that they had finished their business and were going away next day.

Lidia Ivanovna had already begun to calm down, when the next morning a note was brought her (Ivanovna), the handwriting of which she (Ivanovna) recognized with horror.

The envelope was of paper as thick as bark; on the oblong yellow paper there was a huge monogram, and the letter smelt of agreeable scent.

She (Ivanovna) had learned that Anna and Vronsky were in Petersburg. It was the handwriting of Anna Karenina. '' Who brought it?''

'' A commissionaire from the hotel. '' It was some time before Countess Lidia Ivanovna could sit down to read the letter.

Her (Ivanovna) excitement brought on an attack of asthma, to which she (Ivanovna) was subject. When she (Ivanovna) had recovered her (Ivanovna) composure, she (Ivanovna) read the following letter in French:

``Madame la Comtesse, ``The Christian feelings with which your heart is filled give me the, I feel, unpardonable boldness to write to you.

I am miserable at being separated from my son. I entreat permission to see him (son) once before my departure. Forgive me for recalling myself to your memory.

I apply to you and not to Alexey Alexandrovitch, simply because I do not wish to cause that generous man to suffer in remembering me.

Could you send Seryozha to me, or should I come to the house at some fixed hour, or will you let me know when and where I could see him (man) away from home

Knowing your friendship for him (man), I know you will understand me. ? I do not anticipate a refusal, knowing the magnanimity of him (man) with whom it rests.

You cannot conceive the craving I have to see him (man), and so cannot conceive the gratitude your help will arouse in me.

Everything in this letter exasperated Countess Lidia Ivanovna: its contents and the allusion to magnanimity, and especially its free and easy--as she (Ivanovna) considered--tone.

``Say that there is no answer,'' (Countess)
said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, and immediately opening her (Ivanovna) blotting-book, she (Ivanovna) wrote to Alexey Alexandrovitch that she (Ivanovna) hoped to see him (Alexandrovitch) at one o'clock at the levee.

Anna'' '' I must talk with you of a grave and painful subject. There we will arrange where to meet. Best of all at my house, where I will order tea as you like it .

He (Alexandrovitch) lays the cross, but He (Alexandrovitch) gives the strength to bear it,'' she (Anna) added, so as to give him (Alexandrovitch) some slight preparation.

She (Anna) enjoyed that form of communication, which gave opportunity for a refinement and air of mystery not afforded by their personal interviews.

Urgent. Countess Lidia Ivanovna usually wrote some two or three letters a day to Alexey Alexandrovitch. Chapter 24 The levee was drawing to a close.

People met as they were going away, and gossiped of the latest news, of the newly bestowed honors and the changes in the positions of the higher functionaries.

If only Countess Marya Borissovna were Minister of War, and Princess Vatkovskaya were Commander-in-Chief,'' said a gray-headed, little old man in a gold-embroidered uniform, addressing a tall, handsome maid of honor who had questioned him (man) about the new appointments.

'' '' And me among the adjutants,'' said the maid of honor, smiling. '' You have an appointment already. You're over the ecclesiastical department.

And your assistant's Karenin. ''

``Good-day, prince!'' (the man)
said the little old man to a man who came up to him (man). ''

What were you saying of Karenin?'' said the prince. '' He (prince) and Putyatov have received the Alexander Nevsky.''

``I thought he (prince) had it already.

Just look at him (prince),'' (the man)

said the little old man, pointing with his (man) embroidered hat to Karenin in a court uniform with the new red ribbon across his (man) shoulders, standing in the doorway of the hall with an influential member of the Imperial Council.

Pleased and happy as a brass farthing,'' he (man) added, stopping to shake hands with a handsome gentleman of the bedchamber of colossal proportions.

'' '' No. '' '' No; he (man)'s looking older,'' said the gentleman of the bedchamber. '' From overwork. He (gentleman)'s always drawing up projects nowadays.

He (gentleman) won't let a poor devil go nowadays till he (devil)'s explained it all to him (devil) under heads.''

``Looking older, did you say?

Il fait des passions . I believe Countess Lidia Ivanovna's jealous now of his (devil) wife. '' (unknown)

``Oh, come now, please don't say any harm of Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

'' (unknown)

``Why, is there any harm in her (Ivanovna) being in love with Karenin?'' (Madame)
'' But is it true Madame Karenina's here?''

'' Well, not here in the palace, but in Petersburg. I met her (Ivanovna) yesterday with Alexey Vronsky, bras dessous, bras dessous , in the Morsky.''

'' the gentleman of the bedchamber was beginning, but he (gentleman) stopped to make room, bowing, for a member of the Imperial family to pass.

Thus people talked incessantly of Alexey Alexandrovitch, finding fault with him (Alexandrovitch) and laughing at him (Alexandrovitch), while he (Alexandrovitch), blocking up the way of the member of the Imperial Council he (Alexandrovitch) had captured, was explaining to him (Alexandrovitch) point by point his (Alexandrovitch) new financial project, never interrupting his (Alexandrovitch) discourse for an instant for fear he (Alexandrovitch) should escape.

Almost at the same time that his (Alexandrovitch) wife left Alexey Alexandrovitch there had come to him (Alexandrovitch) that bitterest moment in the life of an official--the moment when his (official) upward career comes to a full stop.

This full stop had arrived and everyone perceived it, but Alexey Alexandrovitch himself was not yet aware that his (Alexandrovitch) career was over.

Whether it was due to his (Alexandrovitch) feud with Stremov, or his (Alexandrovitch) misfortune with his (Alexandrovitch) wife, or simply that Alexey Alexandrovitch had reached his (Alexandrovitch) destined limits, it had become evident to everyone in the course of that year that his (Alexandrovitch) career was at an end.

He (Alexandrovitch) still filled a position of consequence, he (Alexandrovitch) sat on many commissions and committees, but he (Alexandrovitch) was a man whose day was over, and from whom nothing was expected.

Whatever he (Alexandrovitch) said, whatever he (Alexandrovitch) proposed, was heard as though it were something long familiar, and the very thing that was not needed.

But Alexey Alexandrovitch was not aware of this, and, on the contrary, being cut off from direct participation in governmental activity, he (Alexandrovitch) saw more clearly than ever the errors and defects in the action of others, and thought it his (Alexandrovitch) duty to point out means for their correction.

Shortly after his (Alexandrovitch) separation from his (Alexandrovitch) wife, he (Alexandrovitch) began writing his (Alexandrovitch) first note on the new judicial procedure, the first of the endless series of notes he (Alexandrovitch) was destined to write in the future.

Alexey Alexandrovitch did not merely fail to observe his (Alexandrovitch) hopeless position in the official world, he (Alexandrovitch) was not merely free from anxiety on this head, he (Alexandrovitch) was positively more satisfied than ever with his (Alexandrovitch) own activity.

'' C'est un homme qui n'a pas... '' He (Alexandrovitch) that is unmarried careth for the things that belong to the Lord, how he (Lord) may please the Lord:

But he (Lord) that is married careth for the things that are of the world, how he (Lord) may please his (Lord) wife,'' says the Apostle Paul, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, who was now guided in every action by Scripture, often recalled this text.

It seemed to him (Alexandrovitch) that ever since he (Alexandrovitch) had been left without a wife, he (Alexandrovitch) had in these very projects of reform been serving the Lord more zealously than before.

The unmistakable impatience of the member of the Council trying to get away from him (member) did not trouble Alexey Alexandrovitch; he (Alexandrovitch) gave up his (Alexandrovitch) exposition only when the member of the Council, seizing his (Alexandrovitch) chance when one of the Imperial family was passing, slipped away from him (Alexandrovitch).

Left alone, Alexey Alexandrovitch looked down, collecting his (Alexandrovitch) thoughts, then looked casually about him (Alexandrovitch) and walked towards the door, where he (Alexandrovitch) hoped to meet Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

how sound physically,'' thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, looking at the powerfully built gentleman of the bedchamber with his (Alexandrovitch) well-combed, perfumed whiskers, and at the red neck of the prince, pinched by his (Alexandrovitch) tight uniform.

Truly is it said that all the world is evil,'' he (Alexandrovitch) thought, with another sidelong glance at the calves of the gentleman of the bedchamber.

Moving forward deliberately, Alexey Alexandrovitch bowed with his (Alexandrovitch) customary air of weariness and dignity to the gentleman who had been talking about him (Alexandrovitch), and looking towards the door, his (Alexandrovitch) eyes sought Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

he (Alexandrovitch) was well aware, but he (Alexandrovitch) did not expect anything but hostility from them; he (Alexandrovitch) was used to that by now.

Catching sight of the yellow shoulders of Lidia Ivanovna jutting out above her (Ivanovna) corset, and her (Ivanovna) fine pensive eyes bidding him (Alexandrovitch) to her (Ivanovna), Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled, revealing untarnished white teeth, and went towards her (Ivanovna).

That they laughed at him (Alexandrovitch) Lidia Ivanovna's dress had cost her (Ivanovna) great pains, as indeed all her (Ivanovna) dresses had done of late.

Her (Ivanovna) aim in dress was now quite the reverse of that she (Ivanovna) had pursued thirty years before. Then her (Ivanovna) desire had been to adorn herself with something, and the more adorned the better.

Now, on the contrary, she (Ivanovna) was perforce decked out in a way so inconsistent with her (Ivanovna) age and her (Ivanovna) figure, that her (Ivanovna) one anxiety was to contrive that the contrast between these adornments and her (Ivanovna) own exterior should not be too appalling.

For him (herself) she (Ivanovna) was the one island not only of goodwill to him (herself), but of love in the midst of the sea of hostility and jeering that surrounded him (herself).

Passing through rows of ironical eyes, he (herself) was drawn as naturally to her (Ivanovna) loving glance as a plant to the sun.

And as far as Alexey Alexandrovitch was concerned she (Ivanovna) succeeded, and was in his (Alexandrovitch) eyes attractive. '' I congratulate you,'' she (Ivanovna) said to him (Alexandrovitch), her (Ivanovna) eyes on his (Alexandrovitch) ribbon.

Suppressing a smile of pleasure, he (Alexandrovitch) shrugged his (Alexandrovitch) shoulders, closing his (Alexandrovitch) eyes, as though to say that that could not be a source of joy to him (Alexandrovitch).

Countess Lidia Ivanovna was very well aware that it was one of his (Alexandrovitch) chief sources of satisfaction, though he (Alexandrovitch) never admitted it.

'' How is our angel?'' said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, meaning Seryozha. '' I can't say I was quite pleased with him (angel),'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, raising his (Alexandrovitch) eyebrows and opening his (Alexandrovitch) eyes.

'' And Sitnikov is not satisfied with him (Alexandrovitch). '' -LRB-Sitnikov was the tutor to whom Seryozha's secular education had been intrusted.-RRB-

As I have mentioned to you, there's a sort of coldness in him (Alexandrovitch) towards the most important questions which ought to touch the heart of every man and every child...

'' '' Alexey Alexandrovitch began expounding his (Alexandrovitch) views on the sole question that interested him (Alexandrovitch) besides the service--the education of his (Alexandrovitch) son.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch with Lidia Ivanovna's help had been brought back anew to life and activity, he (Alexandrovitch) felt it his (Alexandrovitch) duty to undertake the education of the son left on his (Alexandrovitch) hands.

Having never before taken any interest in educational questions, Alexey Alexandrovitch devoted some time to the theoretical study of the subject.

After reading several books on anthropology, education, and didactics, Alexey Alexandrovitch drew up a plan of education, and engaging the best tutor in Petersburg to superintend it, he (Alexandrovitch) set to work, and the subject continually absorbed him (Alexandrovitch).

I see in him (Alexandrovitch) his (Alexandrovitch) father's heart, and with such a heart a child cannot go far wrong,'' said Lidia Ivanovna with enthusiasm.

'' Yes, but the heart. '' Yes, perhaps.... As for me, I do my duty. It's all I can do. ''

You're coming to me,'' said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, after a pause;

``we have to speak of a subject painful for you.

'' (Lidia Ivanovna/Lidia)

I would give anything to have spared you certain memories, but others are not of the same mind. I have received a letter from her (Ivanovna) .

Alexey Alexandrovitch shuddered at the allusion to his (Alexandrovitch) wife, but immediately his (Alexandrovitch) face assumed the deathlike rigidity which expressed utter helplessness in the matter.

Countess Lidia Ivanovna looked at him (Alexandrovitch) ecstatically, and tears of rapture at the greatness of his (Alexandrovitch) soul came into her (Ivanovna) eyes.

When Alexey Alexandrovitch came into the Countess Lidia Ivanovna's snug little boudoir, decorated with old china and hung with portraits, the lady herself had not yet made her (lady) appearance.

A cloth was laid on a round table, and on it stood a china tea service and a silver spirit-lamp and tea kettle.

Alexey Alexandrovitch looked idly about at the endless familiar portraits which adorned the room, and sitting down to the table, he (Alexandrovitch) opened a New Testament lying upon it.

She (lady) is here in Petersburg. '' '' I was expecting it,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said. Chapter 25 She (lady) was changing her (lady) dress. The rustle of the countess's silk skirt drew his (Alexandrovitch) attention off.

Well now, we can sit quietly,'' said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, slipping hurriedly with an agitated smile between the table and the sofa,

``and talk over our tea.

After some words of preparation, Countess Lidia Ivanovna, breathing hard and flushing crimson, gave into Alexey Alexandrovitch's hands the letter she (Ivanovna) had received.

'' (Lidia Ivanovna/Lidia)

'' After reading the letter, he (Alexandrovitch) sat a long while in silence. '' I don't think I have the right to refuse her (Ivanovna),'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, timidly lifting his (Alexandrovitch) eyes.

But whether it is just...'' His (Alexandrovitch) face showed irresolution, and a seeking for counsel, support, and guidance in a matter he (Alexandrovitch) did not understand.

'' Dear friend, you never see evil in anyone!''

``On the contrary, I see that all is evil. '' (Countess)
No,'' Countess Lidia Ivanovna interrupted him (friend);
``there are limits to everything.

I can understand immorality,'' (him)

she (Ivanovna) said, not quite truthfully, since she (Ivanovna) never could understand that which leads women to immorality;
``but I don't understand cruelty: to whom? to you!

How can she (Ivanovna) stay in the town where you are? No, the longer one lives the more one learns. And I'm learning to understand your loftiness and her (Ivanovna) baseness.

I have forgiven all, and so I cannot deprive her (Ivanovna) of what is exacted by love in her (Ivanovna)--by her (Ivanovna) love for her (Ivanovna) son...'' (women)

''

``Who is to throw a stone?'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, unmistakably pleased with the part he (Alexandrovitch) had to play. '' ''

But is that love, my friend? Is it sincere? Admitting that you have forgiven--that you forgive-- have we the right to work on the feelings of that angel?

He (angel) looks on her (Ivanovna) as dead. He (angel) prays for her (Ivanovna), and beseeches God to have mercy on her (Ivanovna) sins. And it is better so.

But now what will he (angel) think?''

``I had not thought of that,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch, evidently agreeing. Countess Lidia Ivanovna hid her (Ivanovna) face in her (Ivanovna) hands and was silent.
