she (Ivanovna) was praying. '' (she)

Do you suppose I don't see how you are suffering, how this has torn open your wounds?

But supposing that, as always, you don't think of yourself, what can it lead to?--to fresh suffering for you, to torture for the child.

No, I have no hesitation in saying I advise not, and if you will intrust it to me, I will write to her (Ivanovna).

And Alexey Alexandrovitch consented, and Countess Lidia Ivanovna sent the following letter in French: ``Dear Madame,

``To be reminded of you might have results for your son in leading to questions on his (son) part which could not be answered without implanting in the child's soul a spirit of censure towards what should be for him (son) sacred, and therefore I beg you to interpret your husband's refusal in the spirit of Christian love.

If there were a trace of humanity left in her (Ivanovna), she (Ivanovna) ought not to wish for it herself. '' (Dear Madame)

I pray to Almighty God to have mercy on you.

Countess Lidia'' This letter attained the secret object which Countess Lidia Ivanovna had concealed from herself. It wounded Anna to the quick.

For his (God) part, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on returning home from Lidia Ivanovna's, could not all that day concentrate himself on his (Alexandrovitch) usual pursuits, and find that spiritual peace of one saved and believing which he (Alexandrovitch) had felt of late.

The thought of his (Alexandrovitch) wife, who had so greatly sinned against him (Alexandrovitch), and towards whom he (Alexandrovitch) had been so saintly, as Countess Lidia Ivanovna had so justly told him (Alexandrovitch), ought not to have troubled him (Alexandrovitch); but he (Alexandrovitch) was not easy; he (Alexandrovitch) could not understand the book he (Alexandrovitch) was reading; he (Alexandrovitch) could not drive away harassing recollections of his (Alexandrovitch) relations with her (Ivanovna), of the mistake which, as it now seemed, he (Alexandrovitch) had made in regard to her (Ivanovna).

The memory of how he (Alexandrovitch) had received her (Ivanovna) confession of infidelity on their way home from the races -LRB-especially that he (Alexandrovitch) had insisted only on the observance of external decorum, and had not sent a challenge-RRB- tortured him (Alexandrovitch) like a remorse.

He (Alexandrovitch) was tortured too by the thought of the letter he (Alexandrovitch) had written her (Ivanovna); and most of all, his (Alexandrovitch) forgiveness, which nobody wanted, and his (Alexandrovitch) care of the other man's child made his (Alexandrovitch) heart burn with shame and remorse.

And just the same feeling of shame and regret he (Alexandrovitch) felt now, as he (Alexandrovitch) reviewed all his (Alexandrovitch) past with her (Ivanovna), recalling the awkward words in which, after long wavering, he (Alexandrovitch) had made her (Ivanovna) an offer.

And this question always excited another question in him (Alexandrovitch)--whether they felt differently, did their loving and marrying differently, these Vronskys and Oblonskys...these gentlemen of the bedchamber, with their fine calves.

And there passed before his (Alexandrovitch) mind a whole series of these mettlesome, vigorous, self- confident men, who always and everywhere drew his (Alexandrovitch) inquisitive attention in spite of himself.

He (Alexandrovitch) tried to dispel these thoughts, he (Alexandrovitch) tried to persuade himself that he (Alexandrovitch) was not living for this transient life, but for the life of eternity, and that there was peace and love in his (Alexandrovitch) heart.

But the fact that he (Alexandrovitch) had in this transient, trivial life made, as it seemed to him (Alexandrovitch), a few trivial mistakes tortured him (Alexandrovitch) as though the eternal salvation in which he (Alexandrovitch) believed had no existence.

But this temptation did not last long, and soon there was reestablished once more in Alexey Alexandrovitch's soul the peace and the elevation by virtue of which he (Alexandrovitch) could forget what he (Alexandrovitch) did not want to remember.

Well, Kapitonitch?'' said Seryozha, coming back rosy and good- humored from his (Alexandrovitch) walk the day before his (Alexandrovitch) birthday, and giving his (Alexandrovitch) overcoat to the tall old hall porter, who smiled down at the little person from the height of his (Alexandrovitch) long figure.

'' But how have I been to blame? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself. Chapter 26 '' '' Well, has the bandaged clerk been here today?

Did papa see him (papa)?'' '' He (papa) saw him (papa). The minute the chief secretary came out, I announced him (secretary),'' said the hall porter with a good-humored wink.

'' Here, I'll take it off.''

``Seryozha! '' (the tutor)
said the tutor, stopping in the doorway leading to the inner rooms.
``Take it off yourself.'' (Seryozha)

But Seryozha, though he (porter) heard his (porter) tutor's feeble voice, did not pay attention to it. He (porter) stood keeping hold of the hall porter's belt, and gazing into his (porter) face.

The clerk with his (porter) face tied up, who had already been seven times to ask some favor of Alexey Alexandrovitch, interested both Seryozha and the hall porter.

Seryozha had come upon him (porter) in the hall, and had heard him (porter) plaintively beg the hall porter to announce him (porter), saying that he (porter) and his (porter) children had death staring them in the face.

'' Well, and did papa do what he (papa) wanted for him (papa)? '' The hall porter nodded his (porter) head affirmatively. Since then Seryozha, having met him (porter) a second time in the hall, took great interest in him (porter).

'' Well, was he (porter) very glad? '' he (porter) asked. '' Glad? I should think so! Almost dancing as he (porter) walked away.''

'' And has anything been left?'' asked Seryozha, after a pause.

``Come, sir,'' (the hall-porter)
said the hall-porter; then with a shake of his (porter) head he (porter) whispered,
``Something from the countess.

Seryozha understood at once that what the hall porter was speaking of was a present from Countess Lidia Ivanovna for his (porter) birthday.

Seryozha was too happy, everything was too delightful for him (porter) to be able to help sharing with his (porter) friend the porter the family good fortune of which he (porter) had heard during his (porter) walk in the public gardens from Lidia Ivanovna's niece.

This piece of good news seemed to him (porter) particularly important from its coming at the same time with the gladness of the bandaged clerk and his (porter) own gladness at toys having come for him (porter).

``Rather small, but a fine thing. '' (unknown)
``A book.'' (unknown)
'' No, a thing. '' It seemed to Seryozha that this was a day on which everyone ought to be glad and happy.

'' You know papa's received the Alexander Nevsky today?'' '' To be sure I do! People have been already to congratulate him (Nevsky).''

'' And is he (Nevsky) glad?''

``Glad at the Tsar's gracious favor! I should think so! It's a proof he (Tsar)'s deserved it,'' (the porter)
said the porter severely and seriously.

Seryozha fell to dreaming, gazing up at the face of the porter, which he (porter) had thoroughly studied in every detail, especially the chin that hung down between the gray whiskers, never seen by anyone but Seryozha, who saw him (porter) only from below.

'' Well, and has your daughter been to see you lately? '' The porter's daughter was a ballet dancer. '' When is she (daughter) to come on week-days?

On coming into the room, Seryozha, instead of sitting down to his (porter) lessons, told his (porter) tutor of his (porter) supposition that what had been brought him (porter) must be a machine.

They've their lessons to learn too. And you've your lesson, sir; run along. '' '' What do you think? '' he (porter) inquired.

But Vassily Lukitch was thinking of nothing but the necessity of learning the grammar lesson for the teacher, who was coming at two.

No, do just tell me, Vassily Lukitch,'' he (porter) asked suddenly, when he (porter) was seated at their work table with the book in his (porter) hands,

``what is greater than the Alexander Nevsky?

'' (he)

You know papa's received the Alexander Nevsky? '' Vassily Lukitch replied that the Vladimir was greater than the Alexander Nevsky.

'' And higher still?'' '' Well, highest of all is the Andrey Pervozvanny. ''

``And higher than the Andrey? '' (unknown)
``I don't know.

'' (unknown)

``What, you don't know?'' (Seryozha)
and Seryozha, leaning on his (Andrey) elbows, sank into deep meditation. His (Andrey) meditations were of the most complex and diverse character.

He (Andrey) imagined his (Andrey) father's having suddenly been presented with both the Vladimir and the Andrey today, and in consequence being much better tempered at his (Andrey) lesson, and dreamed how, when he (Andrey) was grown up, he (Andrey) would himself receive all the orders, and what they might invent higher than the Andrey.

Directly any higher order were invented, he (Andrey) would win it. They would make a higher one still, and he (Andrey) would immediately win that too.

The time passed in such meditations, and when the teacher came, the lesson about the adverbs of place and time and manner of action was not ready, and the teacher was not only displeased, but hurt.

He (Andrey) felt he (Andrey) was not to blame for not having learned the lesson; however much he (Andrey) tried, he (Andrey) was utterly unable to do that.

As long as the teacher was explaining to him (Andrey), he (Andrey) believed him (Andrey) and seemed to comprehend, but as soon as he (Andrey) was left alone, he (Andrey) was positively unable to recollect and to understand that the short and familiar word

``suddenly'' (he)
is an adverb of manner of action.

This touched Seryozha. Still he (Andrey) was sorry that he (Andrey) had disappointed the teacher. He (Andrey) chose a moment when the teacher was looking in silence at the book.

'' Mihail Ivanitch, when is your birthday? '' he (Andrey) asked all, of a sudden. '' You'd much better be thinking about your work.

Birthdays are of no importance to a rational being. It's a day like any other on which one has to do one's work.

Seryozha looked intently at the teacher, at his (Andrey) scanty beard, at his (Andrey) spectacles, which had slipped down below the ridge on his (Andrey) nose, and fell into so deep a reverie that he (Andrey) heard nothing of what the teacher was explaining to him (Andrey).

He (Andrey) knew that the teacher did not think what he (Andrey) said; he (Andrey) felt it from the tone in which it was said.

'' '' But why have they all agreed to speak just in the same manner always the dreariest and most useless stuff?

Why does he (Andrey) keep me off; why doesn't he (Andrey) love me? '' he (Andrey) asked himself mournfully, and could not think of an answer.

Chapter 27 After the lesson with the grammar teacher came his (Andrey) father's lesson. While waiting for his (Andrey) father, Seryozha sat at the table playing with a penknife, and fell to dreaming.

He (Andrey) did not believe in death generally, and in her (Andrey) death in particular, in spite of what Lidia Ivanovna had told him (Andrey) and his (Andrey) father had confirmed, and it was just because of that, and after he (Andrey) had been told she (Ivanovna) was dead, that he (Andrey) had begun looking for her (Ivanovna) when out for a walk.

Among Seryozha's favorite occupations was searching for his (Andrey) mother during his (Andrey) walks. Every woman of full, graceful figure with dark hair was his (Andrey) mother.

At the sight of such a woman such a feeling of tenderness was stirred within him (Andrey) that his (Andrey) breath failed him (Andrey), and tears came into his (Andrey) eyes.

All her (woman) face would be visible, she (woman) would smile, she (woman) would hug him (Andrey), he (Andrey) would sniff her (woman) fragrance, feel the softness of her (woman) arms, and cry with happiness, just as he (Andrey) had one evening lain on her (woman) lap while she (woman) tickled him (Andrey), and he (Andrey) laughed and bit her (woman) white, ring-covered fingers.

Later, when he (Andrey) accidentally learned from his (Andrey) old nurse that his (Andrey) mother was not dead, and his (Andrey) father and Lidia Ivanovna had explained to him (Andrey) that she (Ivanovna) was dead to him (Andrey) because she (Ivanovna) was wicked -LRB-which he (Andrey) could not possibly believe, because he (Andrey) loved her (Ivanovna)-RRB-, he (Andrey) went on seeking her (Ivanovna) and expecting her (Ivanovna) in the same way.

That day in the public gardens there had been a lady in a lilac veil, whom he (Andrey) had watched with a throbbing heart, believing it to be she (lady) as she (lady) came towards them along the path.

And he (Andrey) was on the tiptoe of expectation that she (lady) would come up to him (Andrey), would lift her (lady) veil. The lady had not come up to them, but had disappeared somewhere.

That day, more intensely than ever, Seryozha felt a rush of love for her (lady), and now, waiting for his (Andrey) father, he (Andrey) forgot everything, and cut all round the edge of the table with his (Andrey) penknife, staring straight before him (Andrey) with sparkling eyes and dreaming of her (lady).

Seryozha jumped up and went up to his (Andrey) father, and kissing his (Andrey) hand, looked at him (Andrey) intently, trying to discover signs of his (Andrey) joy at receiving the Alexander Nevsky.

Did you have a nice walk?'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, sitting down in his (Alexandrovitch) easy chair, pulling the volume of the Old Testament to him (Alexandrovitch) and opening it.

Although Alexey Alexandrovitch had more than once told Seryozha that every Christian ought to know Scripture history thoroughly, he (Alexandrovitch) often referred to the Bible himself during the lesson, and Seryozha observed this.

'' Here is your papa!'' said Vassily Lukitch, rousing him (papa). '' '' Yes, it was very nice indeed, papa,'' said Seryozha, sitting sideways on his (papa) chair and rocking it, which was forbidden.

'' I saw Nadinka '' -LRB-Nadinka was a niece of Lidia Ivanovna's who was being brought up in her (Ivanovna) house-RRB-. ''

She (Ivanovna) told me you'd been given a new star. Are you glad, papa?''

``First of all, don't rock your chair, please,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
said Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' And secondly, it's not the reward that's precious, but the work itself. And I could have wished you understood that.

If you now are going to work, to study in order to win a reward, then the work will seem hard to you; but when you work'' -LRB-Alexey Alexandrovitch, as he (Alexandrovitch) spoke, thought of how he (Alexandrovitch) had been sustained by a sense of duty through the wearisome labor of the morning, consisting of signing one hundred and eighty papers-RRB-,

``loving your work, you will find your reward in it.

This was the same long-familiar tone his (Alexandrovitch) father always took with him (Alexandrovitch), and Seryozha had learned by now to fall in with it.

His (Alexandrovitch) father always talked to him (Alexandrovitch)--so Seryozha felt--as though he (Alexandrovitch) were addressing some boy of his (Alexandrovitch) own imagination, one of those boys that exist in books, utterly unlike himself.

'' (he)

Seryozha's eyes, that had been shining with gaiety and tenderness, grew dull and dropped before his (Alexandrovitch) father's gaze. And Seryozha always tried with his (Alexandrovitch) father to act being the story-book boy.

'' You understand that, I hope? '' said his (Alexandrovitch) father. '' Yes, papa,'' answered Seryozha, acting the part of the imaginary boy.

The lesson consisted of learning by heart several verses out of the Gospel and the repetition of the beginning of the Old Testament.

The verses from the Gospel Seryozha knew fairly well, but at the moment when he (boy) was saying them he (boy) became so absorbed in watching the sharply protruding, bony knobbiness of his (boy) father's forehead, that he (boy) lost the thread, and he (boy) transposed the end of one verse and the beginning of another.

He (boy) frowned, and began explaining what Seryozha had heard many times before and never could remember, because he (boy) understood it too well, just as that

``suddenly'' (he)
is an adverb of manner of action.

Seryozha looked with scared eyes at his (boy) father, and could think of nothing but whether his (boy) father would make him (father) repeat what he (father) had said, as he (father) sometimes did.

So it was evident to Alexey Alexandrovitch that he (Alexandrovitch) did not understand what he (Alexandrovitch) was saying, and that irritated him (Alexandrovitch). And this thought so alarmed Seryozha that he (Alexandrovitch) now understood nothing.

Seryozha recounted the events themselves well enough, but when he (Alexandrovitch) had to answer questions as to what certain events prefigured, he (Alexandrovitch) knew nothing, though he (Alexandrovitch) had already been punished over this lesson.

The passage at which he (Alexandrovitch) was utterly unable to say anything, and began fidgeting and cutting the table and swinging his (Alexandrovitch) chair, was where he (Alexandrovitch) had to repeat the patriarchs before the Flood.

But his (Alexandrovitch) father did not make him (father) repeat it, and passed on to the lesson out of the Old Testament. He (father) did not know one of them, except Enoch, who had been taken up alive to heaven.

Last time he (Enoch) had remembered their names, but now he (Enoch) had forgotten them utterly, chiefly because Enoch was the personage he (Enoch) liked best in the whole of the Old Testament, and Enoch's translation to heaven was connected in his (Enoch) mind with a whole long train of thought, in which he (Enoch) became absorbed now while he (Enoch) gazed with fascinated eyes at his (Enoch) father's watch-chain and a half-unbuttoned button on his (Enoch) waistcoat.

In death, of which they talked to him (Enoch) so often, Seryozha disbelieved entirely. He (Enoch) did not believe that those he (Enoch) loved could die, above all that he (Enoch) himself would die.

But he (Enoch) had been told that all men die; he (Enoch) had asked people, indeed, whom he (Enoch) trusted, and they too, had confirmed it; his (Enoch) old nurse, too, said the same, though reluctantly.

That was to him (Enoch) something utterly inconceivable and impossible. But Enoch had not died, and so it followed that everyone did not die.

'' And why cannot anyone else so serve God and be taken alive to heaven?'' thought Seryozha. Bad people, that is those Seryozha did not like, they might die, but the good might all be like Enoch.

'' Well, what are the names of the patriarchs?''

``Enoch, Enos--'' (unknown)
'' But you have said that already. This is bad, Seryozha, very bad.

If you don't try to learn what is more necessary than anything for a Christian,'' said his (Christian) father, getting up,

``whatever can interest you?

I am displeased with you, and Piotr Ignatitch '' (father)

-LRB-this was the most important of his (Christian) teachers-RRB-
``is displeased with you....

I shall have to punish you. '' (teachers)

His (Christian) father and his (Christian) teacher were both displeased with Seryozha, and he (Christian) certainly did learn his (Christian) lessons very badly.

But still it could not be said he (Christian) was a stupid boy. On the contrary, he (Christian) was far cleverer than the boys his (Christian) teacher held up as examples to Seryozha.

In his (Christian) father's opinion, he (Christian) did not want to learn what he (Christian) was taught. In reality he (Christian) could not learn that.

He (Christian) could not, because the claims of his (Christian) own soul were more binding on him (Christian) than those claims his (Christian) father and his (Christian) teacher made upon him (Christian).

Those claims were in opposition, and he (Christian) was in direct conflict with his (Christian) education. He (Christian) was nine years old; he (Christian) was a child; but he (Christian) knew his (Christian) own soul

, it was precious to him (Christian), he (Christian) guarded it as the eyelid guards the eye, and without the key of love he (Christian) let no one into his (Christian) soul.

His (Christian) teachers complained that he (Christian) would not learn, while his (Christian) soul was brimming over with thirst for knowledge. And he (Christian) learned from Kapitonitch, from his (Christian) nurse, from Nadinka, from Vassily Lukitch, but not from his (Christian) teachers.

The spring his (Christian) father and his (Christian) teachers reckoned upon to turn their mill-wheels had long dried up at the source, but its waters did their work in another channel.

His (Christian) father punished Seryozha by not letting him (Christian) go to see Nadinka, Lidia Ivanovna's niece; but this punishment turned out happily for Seryozha.

The whole evening passed over this work and in dreaming how to make a windmill on which he (Christian) could turn himself--clutching at the sails or tying himself on and whirling round.

Of his (Christian) mother Seryozha did not think all the evening, but when he (Christian) had gone to bed, he (Christian) suddenly remembered her (mother), and prayed in his (Christian) own words that his (Christian) mother tomorrow for his (Christian) birthday might leave off hiding herself and come to him (Christian).

Vassily Lukitch was in a good humor, and showed him (Christian) how to make windmills. '' Vassily Lukitch, do you know what I prayed for tonight extra besides the regular things?''

``That you might learn your lessons better?'' (unknown)
'' No.''
``Toys?'' (unknown)
'' No. You'll never guess. A splendid thing; but it's a secret!

When it comes to pass I'll tell you. Can't you guess!'' '' No, I can't guess. You tell me,'' said Vassily Lukitch with a smile, which was rare with him (Christian).

``Come, lie down, I'm putting out the candle.'' (unknown)
``Without the candle I can see better what I see and what I prayed for.

There! I was almost telling the secret!'' (Seryozha)

said Seryozha, laughing gaily. When the candle was taken away, Seryozha heard and felt his (Christian) mother.

She (mother) stood over him (Christian), and with loving eyes caressed him (Christian). But then came windmills, a knife, everything began to be mixed up, and he (Christian) fell asleep.

On arriving in Petersburg, Vronsky and Anna stayed at one of the best hotels; Vronsky apart in a lower story, Anna above with her (Anna) child, its nurse, and her (Anna) maid, in a large suite of four rooms.

Chapter 28 On the day of his (Christian) arrival Vronsky went to his (Christian) brother's. There he (Christian) found his (Christian) mother, who had come from Moscow on business.

His (Christian) mother and sister-in-law greeted him (Christian) as usual: they asked him (Christian) about his (Christian) stay abroad, and talked of their common acquaintances, but did not let drop a single word in allusion to his (Christian) connection with Anna.

His (Christian) brother came the next morning to see Vronsky, and of his (Christian) own accord asked him (Christian) about her (Anna), and Alexey Vronsky told him (Vronsky) directly that he (Vronsky) looked upon his (Vronsky) connection with Madame Karenina as marriage; that he (Vronsky) hoped to arrange a divorce, and then to marry her (Anna), and until then he (Vronsky) considered her (Anna) as much a wife as any other wife, and he (Vronsky) begged him (Vronsky) to tell their mother and his (Vronsky) wife so.

``but if my relations want to be on terms of relationship with me, they will have to be on the same terms with my wife.

The elder brother, who had always a respect for his (brother) younger brother's judgment, could not well tell whether he (brother) was right or not till the world had decided the question; for his (brother) part he (brother) had nothing against it, and with Alexey he (Alexey) went up to see Anna.

Before his (Alexey) brother, as before everyone, Vronsky addressed Anna with a certain formality, treating her (Anna) as he (Vronsky) might a very intimate friend, but it was understood that his (friend) brother knew their real relations, and they talked about Anna's going to Vronsky's estate.

In spite of all his (Vronsky) social experience Vronsky was, in consequence of the new position in which he (Vronsky) was placed, laboring under a strange misapprehension.

One would have thought he (Vronsky) must have understood that society was closed for him (Vronsky) and Anna; but now some vague ideas had sprung up in his (Vronsky) brain that this was only the case in old-fashioned days, and that now with the rapidity of modern progress -LRB-he (Vronsky) had unconsciously become by now a partisan of every sort of progress-RRB- the views of society had changed, and that the question whether they would be received in society was not a foregone conclusion.

Of course,'' (he)

he (Vronsky) thought,
``she (Anna) would not be received at court, but intimate friends can and must look at it in the proper light.

One may sit for several hours at a stretch with one's legs crossed in the same position, if one knows that there's nothing to prevent one's changing one's position; but if a man knows that he (man) must remain sitting so with crossed legs, then cramps come on, the legs begin to twitch and to strain towards the spot to which one would like to draw them.

'' (he)

If the world disapproves, I don't care,'' said Vronsky; '' '' '' This was what Vronsky was experiencing in regard to the world.

Though at the bottom of his (Vronsky) heart he (Vronsky) knew that the world was shut on them, he (Vronsky) put it to the test whether the world had not changed by now and would not receive them.

Just as in the game of cat and mouse, the hands raised for him (Vronsky) were dropped to bar the way for Anna.

But he (Vronsky) very quickly perceived that though the world was open for him (Vronsky) personally, it was closed for Anna. One of the first ladies of Petersburg society whom Vronsky saw was his (Vronsky) cousin Betsy.

'' At last!'' she (Betsy) greeted him (Vronsky) joyfully. '' And Anna? How glad I am! Where are you stopping? I can fancy after your delightful travels you must find our poor Petersburg horrid.

I can fancy your honeymoon in Rome. How about the divorce? Is that all over? '' Vronsky noticed that Betsy's enthusiasm waned when she (Betsy) learned that no divorce had as yet taken place.

People will throw stones at me, I know,'' she (Betsy) said,

``but I shall come and see Anna; yes, I shall certainly come.

And she (Anna) did certainly come to see Anna the same day, but her (Anna) tone was not at all the same as in former days.

'' (she)

You won't be here long, I suppose? '' She (Anna) unmistakably prided herself on her (Anna) courage, and wished Anna to appreciate the fidelity of her (Anna) friendship.

She (Anna) only stayed ten minutes, talking of society gossip, and on leaving she (Anna) said:

``You've never told me when the divorce is to be?

I'm ready to fling my cap over the mill, other starchy people will give you the cold shoulder until you're married.

Supposing And that's so simple nowadays. √áa se fait . So you're going on Friday? Sorry we shan't see each other again.

From Betsy's tone Vronsky might have grasped what he (my) had to expect from the world; but he (my) made another effort in his (my) own family.

He (my) knew that his (my) mother, who had been so enthusiastic over Anna at their first acquaintance, would have no mercy on her (Anna) now for having ruined her (Anna) son's career.

He (son) fancied she (Anna) would not throw stones, and would go simply and directly to see Anna, and would receive her (Anna) in her (Anna) own house.

'' (she)

His (son) mother he (son) did not reckon upon. But he (son) had more hope of Varya, his (son) brother's wife. The day after his (son) arrival Vronsky went to her (Varya), and finding her (Varya) alone, expressed his (son) wishes directly.

You know, Alexey,'' she (Varya) said after hearing him (son),

``how fond I am of you, and how ready I am to do anything for you; but I have not spoken, because I knew I could be of no use to you and to Anna Arkadyevna,'' (him)
she (Arkadyevna) said, articulating the name
``Anna Arkadyevna'' (she)
with particular care.

'' '' Don't suppose, please, that I judge her (Arkadyevna). Never; perhaps in her (Arkadyevna) place I should have done the same. I don't and can't enter into that,'' she (Arkadyevna) said, glancing timidly at his (son) gloomy face.

You want me to go and see her (Arkadyevna), to ask her (Arkadyevna) here, and to rehabilitate her (Arkadyevna) in society; but do understand that I cannot do so.

'' But one must call things by their names. I have daughters growing up, and I must live in the world for my husband's sake.

Well, I'm ready to come and see Anna Arkadyevna: she (Arkadyevna) will understand that I can't ask her (Arkadyevna) here, or I should have to do so in such a way that she (Arkadyevna) would not meet people who look at things differently; that would offend her (Arkadyevna).

I can't raise her (Arkadyevna)... '' '' Oh, I don't regard her (Arkadyevna) as fallen more than hundreds of women you do receive!''

Vronsky interrupted her (Arkadyevna) still more gloomily, and he (husband) got up in silence, understanding that his (husband) sister-in-law's decision was not to be shaken.

'' Alexey! don't be angry with me. Please understand that I'm not to blame,'' began Varya, looking at him (Alexey) with a timid smile.

'' I'm not angry with you,'' he (Alexey) said still as gloomily;

``but I'm sorry in two ways. I'm sorry, too, that this means breaking up our friendship--if not breaking up, at least weakening it.

Vronsky knew that further efforts were useless, and that he (Alexey) had to spend these few days in Petersburg as though in a strange town, avoiding every sort of relation with his (Alexey) own old circle in order not to be exposed to the annoyances and humiliations which were so intolerable to him (Alexey).

One of the most unpleasant features of his (Alexey) position in Petersburg was that Alexey Alexandrovitch and his (Alexandrovitch) name seemed to meet him (Alexandrovitch) everywhere.

He (Alexandrovitch) could not begin to talk of anything without the conversation turning on Alexey Alexandrovitch; he (Alexandrovitch) could not go anywhere without risk of meeting him (Alexandrovitch).

So at least it seemed to Vronsky, just as it seems to a man with a sore finger that he (man) is continually, as though on purpose, grazing his (man) sore finger on everything.

Their stay in Petersburg was the more painful to Vronsky that he (man) perceived all the time a sort of new mood that he (man) could not understand in Anna.

You will understand that for me, too, it cannot be otherwise. '' (he)

And with that he (man) left her (Anna). At one time she (Anna) would seem in love with him (man), and then she (Anna) would become cold, irritable, and impenetrable.

She (Anna) was worrying over something, and keeping something back from him (man), and did not seem to notice the humiliations which poisoned his (man) existence, and for her (Anna), with her (Anna) delicate intuition, must have been still more unbearable.

Chapter 29 One of Anna's objects in coming back to Russia had been to see her (Anna) son. From the day she (Anna) left Italy the thought of it had never ceased to agitate her (Anna).

And as she (Anna) got nearer to Petersburg, the delight and importance of this meeting grew ever greater in her (Anna) imagination. She (Anna) did not even put to herself the question how to arrange it.

It seemed to her (Anna) natural and simple to see her (Anna) son when she (Anna) should be in the same town with him (son).

she (Anna) was suddenly made distinctly aware of her (Anna) present position in society, and she (Anna) grasped the fact that to arrange this meeting was no easy matter.

But on her (Anna) arrival in Petersburg She (Anna) had now been two days in Petersburg. The thought of her (Anna) son never left her (Anna) for a single instant, but she (Anna) had not yet seen him (son).

To go straight to the house, where she (Anna) might meet Alexey Alexandrovitch, that she (Anna) felt she (Anna) had no right to do.

To write and so enter into relations with her (Anna) husband--that it made her (Anna) miserable to think of doing; she (Anna) could only be at peace when she (Anna) did not think of her (Anna) husband.

To get a glimpse of her (Anna) son out walking, finding out where and when he (son) went out, was not enough for her (Anna)

; she (Anna) had so looked forward to this meeting, she (Anna) had so much she (Anna) must say to him (son), she (Anna) so longed to embrace him (son), to kiss him (son).

She (Anna) might be refused admittance and insulted. Seryozha's old nurse might be a help to her (nurse) and show her (nurse) what to do.

But the nurse was not now living in Alexey Alexandrovitch's house. In this uncertainty, and in efforts to find the nurse, two days had slipped by.

Hearing of the close intimacy between Alexey Alexandrovitch and Countess Lidia Ivanovna, Anna decided on the third day to write to her (Anna) a letter, which cost her (Anna) great pains, and in which she (Anna) intentionally said that permission to see her (Anna) son must depend on her (Anna) husband's generosity.

She (Anna) knew that if the letter were shown to her (Anna) husband, he (husband) would keep up his (husband) character of magnanimity, and would not refuse her (Anna) request.

The commissionaire who took the letter had brought her (Anna) back the most cruel and unexpected answer, that there was no answer.

She (Anna) had never felt so humiliated as at the moment when, sending for the commissionaire, she (Anna) heard from him (husband) the exact account of how he (husband) had waited, and how afterwards he (husband) had been told there was no answer.

Anna felt humiliated, insulted, but she (Anna) saw that from her (Anna) point of view Countess Lidia Ivanovna was right. Her (Anna) suffering was the more poignant that she (Anna) had to bear it in solitude.

She (Anna) knew that to him (husband), although he (husband) was the primary cause of her (Anna) distress, the question of her (Anna) seeing her (Anna) son would seem a matter of very little consequence.

She (Anna) knew that he (son) would never be capable of understanding all the depth of her (Anna) suffering, that for his (son) cool tone at any allusion to it she (Anna) would begin to hate him (son).

And she (Anna) dreaded that more than anything in the world, and so she (Anna) hid from him (son) everything that related to her (Anna) son.

Spending the whole day at home she (Anna) considered ways of seeing her (Anna) son, and had reached a decision to write to her (Anna) husband.

She (Anna) could not and would not share it with Vronsky. She (Anna) was just composing this letter when she (Anna) was handed the letter from Lidia Ivanovna.

The countess's silence had subdued and depressed her (Ivanovna), but the letter, all that she (Ivanovna) read between the lines in it, so exasperated her (Ivanovna), this malice was so revolting beside her (Ivanovna) passionate, legitimate tenderness for her (Ivanovna) son, that she (Ivanovna) turned against other people and left off blaming herself.

'' This coldness--this pretense of feeling! '' she (Ivanovna) said to herself. '' They must needs insult me and torture the child, and I am to submit to it!

And she (Ivanovna) decided on the spot that next day, Seryozha's birthday, she (Ivanovna) would go straight to her (Ivanovna) husband's house, bribe or deceive the servants, but at any cost see her (Ivanovna) son and overturn the hideous deception with which they were encompassing the unhappy child.

Not on any consideration! She (Ivanovna) is worse than I am. I don't lie, anyway. '' She (Ivanovna) went to a toy shop, bought toys and thought over a plan of action.

She (Ivanovna) would have money in her (Ivanovna) hand to give the hall porter and the footman, so that they should let her (Ivanovna) in, and not raising her (Ivanovna) veil, she (Ivanovna) would say that she (Ivanovna) had come from Seryozha's godfather to congratulate him (godfather), and that she (Ivanovna) had been charged to leave the toys at his (godfather) bedside.

She (Ivanovna) would go early in the morning at eight o'clock, when Alexey Alexandrovitch would be certain not to be up. She (Ivanovna) had prepared everything but the words she (Ivanovna) should say to her (Ivanovna) son.

The next day, at eight o'clock in the morning, Anna got out of a hired sledge and rang at the front entrance of her (Anna) former home.

Some lady,'' said Kapitonitch, who, not yet dressed, in his (son) overcoat and galoshes, had peeped out of the window and seen a lady in a veil standing close up to the door.

His (son) assistant, a lad Anna did not know, had no sooner opened the door to her (Anna) than she (Anna) came in, and pulling a three-rouble note out of her (Anna) muff put it hurriedly into his (son) hand.

Often as she (Anna) had dreamed of it, she (Anna) could never think of anything. '' Run and see what's wanted. '' Seryozha--Sergey Alexeitch,'' she (Anna) said, and was going on.

Scrutinizing the note, the porter's assistant stopped her (Anna) at the second glass door. '' Whom do you want? '' he (assistant) asked.

Noticing the embarrassment of the unknown lady, Kapitonitch went out to her (lady), opened the second door for her (lady), and asked her (lady) what she (lady) was pleased to want.

She (lady) did not hear his (assistant) words and made no answer. '' From Prince Skorodumov for Sergey Alexeitch,'' she (lady) said. '' His (Alexeitch) honor's not up yet,'' said the porter, looking at her (lady) attentively.

Anna had not anticipated that the absolutely unchanged hall of the house where she (Anna) had lived for nine years would so greatly affect her (Anna).

Memories sweet and painful rose one after another in her (Anna) heart, and for a moment she (Anna) forgot what she (Anna) was here for.

As he (Alexeitch) took off the cloak, Kapitonitch glanced at her (Anna) face, recognized her (Anna), and made her (Anna) a low bow in silence.

'' Would you kindly wait?'' said Kapitonitch, taking off her (Anna) fur cloak. '' Please walk in, your excellency,'' he (Alexeitch) said to her (Anna).

She (Anna) tried to say something, but her (Anna) voice refused to utter any sound; with a guilty and imploring glance at the old man she (Anna) went with light, swift steps up the stairs.

Bent double, and his (Bent) galoshes catching in the steps, Kapitonitch ran after her (Anna), trying to overtake her (Anna). '' The tutor's there; maybe he (Bent)'s not dressed.

I'll let him (Bent) know. '' Anna still mounted the familiar staircase, not understanding what the old man was saying. '' This way, to the left, if you please.

Excuse me, wait a little, your excellency; I'll just see,'' he (man) said, and overtaking her (Anna), he (man) opened the high door and disappeared behind it.

Excuse its not being tidy. His (man) honor's in the old parlor now,'' the hall porter said, panting. '' Anna stood still waiting.

'' He (porter)'s only just awake,'' said the hall porter, coming out. And at the very instant the porter said this, Anna caught the sound of a childish yawn.

From the sound of this yawn alone she (Anna) knew her (Anna) son and seemed to see him (son) living before her (Anna) eyes.

``Let me in; go away!

'' (she)

she (Anna) said, and went in through the high doorway. On the right of the door stood a bed, and sitting up in the bed was the boy.

The instant his (boy) lips came together they curved into a blissfully sleepy smile, and with that smile he (boy) slowly and deliciously rolled back again.

His (boy) little body bent forward with his (boy) nightshirt unbuttoned, he (boy) was stretching and still yawning.

``Seryozha! '' (she)
she (Anna) whispered, going noiselessly up to him (boy).

When she (Anna) was parted from him (boy), and all this latter time when she (Anna) had been feeling a fresh rush of love for him (boy), she (Anna) had pictured him (boy) as he (boy) was at four years old, when she (Anna) had loved him (boy) most of all.

Now he (boy) was not even the same as when she (Anna) had left him (boy); he (boy) was still further from the four-year-old baby, more grown and thinner.

How thin his (boy) face was, how short his (boy) hair was! What long hands! How he (boy) had changed since she (Anna) left him (boy)!

But it was he (boy) with his (boy) head, his (boy) lips, his (boy) soft neck and broad little shoulders.

``Seryozha! '' (she)
she (Anna) repeated just in the child's ear.

He (boy) raised himself again on his (boy) elbow, turned his (boy) tangled head from side to side as though looking for something, and opened his (boy) eyes.

all at once he (boy) smiled a blissful smile, and shutting his (boy) eyes, rolled not backwards but towards her (Anna) into her (Anna) arms.

Slowly and inquiringly he (boy) looked for several seconds at his (boy) mother standing motionless before him (boy), then

``Seryozha! my darling boy! '' (him)

she (Anna) said, breathing hard and putting her (Anna) arms round his (boy) plump little body. '' Mother!'' he (boy) said, wriggling about in her (Mother) arms so as to touch her (Mother) hands with different parts of him (boy).

Smiling sleepily still with closed eyes, he (boy) flung fat little arms round her (Mother) shoulders, rolled towards her (Mother), with the delicious sleepy warmth and fragrance that is only found in children, and began rubbing his (boy) face against her (Mother) neck and shoulders.

'' I know,'' he (boy) said, opening his (boy) eyes;

``it's my birthday today. I knew you'd come. I'll get up directly. '' (he)

And saying that he (boy) dropped asleep. Anna looked at him (boy) hungrily; she (Anna) saw how he (boy) had grown and changed in her (Anna) absence.

She (Anna) knew, and did not know, the bare legs so long now, that were thrust out below the quilt, those short-cropped curls on his (boy) neck in which she (Anna) had so often kissed him (boy).

She (Anna) touched all this and could say nothing; tears choked her (Anna). '' What are you crying for, mother? '' he (boy) said, waking completely up.

'' Mother, what are you crying for? '' he (boy) cried in a tearful voice. '' I won't cry... I'm crying for joy.

It's so long since I've seen you. I won't, I won't,'' she (Mother) said, gulping down her (Mother) tears and turning away. ''

Come, it's time for you to dress now,'' she (Mother) added, after a pause, and, never letting go his (boy) hands, she (Mother) sat down by his (boy) bedside on the chair, where his (boy) clothes were put ready for him (boy).

'' How do you dress without me? How... '' she (Mother) tried to begin talking simply and cheerfully, but she (Mother) could not, and again she (Mother) turned away.

'' I don't have a cold bath, papa didn't order it. And you've not seen Vassily Lukitch? He (papa)'ll come in soon.

Why, you're sitting on my clothes!'' And Seryozha went off into a peal of laughter. She (Mother) looked at him (papa) and smiled.

'' Mother, darling, sweet one!'' he (papa) shouted, flinging himself on her (Mother) again and hugging her (Mother). It was as though only now, on seeing her (Mother) smile, he (papa) fully grasped what had happened.

'' I don't want that on,'' he (papa) said, taking off her (Mother) hat. And as it were, seeing her (Mother) afresh without her (Mother) hat, he (papa) fell to kissing her (Mother) again.

'' But what did you think about me? You didn't think I was dead?''

``I never believed it.'' (unknown)
``You didn't believe it, my sweet?'' (he)

he (papa) repeated his (papa) favorite phrase, and snatching the hand that was stroking his (papa) hair, he (papa) pressed the open palm to his (papa) mouth and kissed it.

Chapter 30 Meanwhile Vassily Lukitch had not at first understood who this lady was, and had learned from their conversation that it was no other person than the mother who had left her (mother) husband, and whom he (husband) had not seen, as he (husband) had entered the house after her (mother) departure.

``I knew, I knew! '' (He)
He (husband) was in doubt whether to go in or not, or whether to communicate with Alexey Alexandrovitch.

Reflecting finally that his (Alexandrovitch) duty was to get Seryozha up at the hour fixed, and that it was therefore not his (Alexandrovitch) business to consider who was there, the mother or anyone else, but simply to do his (Alexandrovitch) duty, he (Alexandrovitch) finished dressing, went to the door and opened it.

But the embraces of the mother and child, the sound of their voices, and what they were saying, made him (Alexandrovitch) change his (Alexandrovitch) mind.

He (Alexandrovitch) shook his (Alexandrovitch) head, and with a sigh he (Alexandrovitch) closed the door. '' I'll wait another ten minutes,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said to himself, clearing his (Alexandrovitch) throat and wiping away tears.

All had heard that their mistress had come, and that Kapitonitch had let her (mistress) in, and that she (mistress) was even now in the nursery, and that their master always went in person to the nursery at nine o'clock, and every one fully comprehended that it was impossible for the husband and wife to meet, and that they must prevent it.

Korney, the valet, going down to the hall porter's room, asked who had let her (wife) in, and how it was he (porter) had done so, and ascertaining that Kapitonitch had admitted her (wife) and shown her (wife) up, he (porter) gave the old man a talking-to.

The hall porter was doggedly silent, but when Korney told him (porter) he (porter) ought to be sent away, Kapitonitch darted up to him (porter), and waving his (porter) hands in Korney's face, began:

``Oh yes, to be sure you'd not have let her (wife) in!

After ten years' service, and never a word but of kindness, and there you'd up and say, `Be off, go along, get away with you!'

Among the servants of the household there was intense excitement all this time. Oh yes, you're a shrewd one at politics, I dare say!

You don't need to be taught how to swindle the master, and to filch fur coats!'' (Korney)

``Soldier!'' (Korney)
said Korney contemptuously, and he (Soldier) turned to the nurse who was coming in.

'' Here, what do you think, Marya Efimovna: he (Soldier) let her (nurse) in without a word to anyone,'' Korney said addressing her (nurse).

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch will be down immediately--and go into the nursery!''

``A pretty business, a pretty business!'' (the nurse)
said the nurse. ''

You, Korney Vassilievitch, you'd best keep him (Alexandrovitch) some way or other, the master, while I'll run and get her (nurse) away somehow.

When the nurse went into the nursery, Seryozha was telling his (master) mother how he (master) and Nadinka had had a fall in sledging downhill, and had turned over three times.

She (mother) was listening to the sound of his (master) voice, watching his (master) face and the play of expression on it, touching his (master) hand, but she (mother) did not follow what he (master) was saying.

She (mother) heard the steps of Vassily Lukitch coming up to the door and coughing; she (mother) heard, too, the steps of the nurse as she (nurse) came near; but she (nurse) sat like one turned to stone, incapable of beginning to speak or to get up.

A pretty business! '' She (nurse) must go, she (nurse) must leave him (master),--this was the only thing she (nurse) was thinking and feeling. ''

Mistress, darling!'' began the nurse, going up to Anna and kissing her (Anna) hands and shoulders. '' God has brought joy indeed to our boy on his (God) birthday.

You aren't changed one bit.''

``Oh, nurse dear, I didn't know you were in the house,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, rousing herself for a moment.

'' I'm not living here, I'm living with my daughter. I came for the birthday, Anna Arkadyevna, darling! '' The nurse suddenly burst into tears, and began kissing her (nurse) hand again.

Seryozha, with radiant eyes and smiles, holding his (God) mother by one hand and his (God) nurse by the other, pattered on the rug with his (God) fat little bare feet.

The tenderness shown by his (God) beloved nurse to his (God) mother threw him (God) into an ecstasy. '' Mother! She (Mother) often comes to see me, and when she (Mother) comes...

'' he (God) was beginning, but he (God) stopped, noticing that the nurse was saying something in a whisper to his (God) mother, and that in his (God) mother's face there was a look of dread and something like shame, which was so strangely unbecoming to her (mother).

She (mother) went up to him (God). '' My sweet!'' she (mother) said. She (mother) could not say good-bye , but the expression on her (mother) face said it, and he (God) understood.

'' Darling, darling Kootik! '' she (mother) used the name by which she (mother) had called him (God) when he (God) was little,

``you won't forget me?

You... '' (he)

but she (mother) could not say more. How often afterwards she (mother) thought of words she (mother) might have said. But now she (mother) did not know how to say it, and could say nothing.

But Seryozha knew all she (mother) wanted to say to him (God). He (God) understood that she (mother) was unhappy and loved him (God). He (God) understood even what the nurse had whispered.

He (God) had caught the words

``always at nine o'clock,'' (He)
and he (God) knew that this was said of his (God) father, and that his (God) father and mother could not meet.

That he (God) understood, but one thing he (God) could not understand--why there should be a look of dread and shame in her (mother) face?...

He (God) would have liked to put a question that would have set at rest this doubt, but he (God) did not dare; he (God) saw that she (mother) was miserable, and he (God) felt for her (mother).

She (mother) was not in fault, but she (mother) was afraid of him (God) and ashamed of something. Silently he (God) pressed close to her (mother) and whispered,

``Don't go yet.

The mother held him (God) away from her (mother) to see what he (God) was thinking, what to say to him (God), and in his (God) frightened face she (mother) read not only that he (God) was speaking of his (God) father, but, as it were, asking her (mother) what he (God) ought to think about his (God) father.

he (God) cried in despair through his (God) tears, and, clutching her (mother) by the shoulders, he (God) began squeezing her (mother) with all his (God) force to him (God), his (God) arms trembling with the strain.

When you grow up you will judge. '' (she)

'' There's no one better than you!... '' '' My sweet, my little one!'' said Anna, and she (Anna) cried as weakly and childishly as he (God).

At the other door there was the sound of steps, and the nurse in a scared whisper said,

``He (God)'s coming,'' (the nurse)
and gave Anna her (Anna) hat.

At that moment the door opened. Vassily Lukitch came in. Seryozha sank onto the bed and sobbed, hiding his (God) face in his (God) hands.

Anna removed his (God) hands, once more kissed his (God) wet face, and with rapid steps went to the door. Alexey Alexandrovitch walked in, meeting her (Anna).

Although she (Anna) had just said he (Alexandrovitch) was better and kinder than she (Anna), in the rapid glance she (Anna) flung at him (Alexandrovitch), taking in his (Alexandrovitch) whole figure in all its details, feelings of repulsion and hatred for him (Alexandrovitch) and jealousy over her (Anna) son

Seeing her (Anna), he (Alexandrovitch) stopped short and bowed his (Alexandrovitch) head. took possession of her (Anna). With a swift gesture she (Anna) put down her (Anna) veil, and, quickening her (Anna) pace, almost ran out of the room.

She (Anna) had not time to undo, and so carried back with her (Anna), the parcel of toys she (Anna) had chosen the day before in a toy shop with such love and sorrow.

As intensely as Anna had longed to see her (Anna) son, and long as she (Anna) had been thinking of it and preparing herself for it, she (Anna) had not in the least expected that seeing him (son) would affect her (Anna) so deeply.

On getting back to her (Anna) lonely rooms in the hotel she (Anna) could not for a long while understand why she (Anna) was there.

Yes, it's all over, and I am again alone,'' she (Anna) said to herself, and without taking off her (Anna) hat she (Anna) sat down in a low chair by the hearth.

Chapter 31 '' Fixing her (Anna) eyes on a bronze clock standing on a table between the windows, she (Anna) tried to think.

The French maid brought from abroad came in to suggest she (maid) should dress. She (maid) gazed at her (maid) wonderingly and said,

``Presently.

The Italian nurse, after having taken the baby out in her (nurse) best, came in with her (nurse), and brought her (nurse) to Anna.

The plump, well-fed little baby, on seeing her (Anna) mother, as she (Anna) always did, held out her (Anna) fat little hands, and with a smile on her (Anna) toothless mouth, began, like a fish with a float, bobbing her (Anna) fingers up and down the starched folds of her (Anna) embroidered skirt, making them rustle.

It was impossible not to smile, not to kiss the baby, impossible not to hold out a finger for her (Anna) to clutch, crowing and prancing all over; impossible not to offer her (Anna) a lip which she (Anna) sucked into her (Anna) little mouth by way of a kiss.

And all this Anna did, and took her (Anna) in her (Anna) arms and made her (Anna) dance, and kissed her (Anna) fresh little cheek and bare little elbows; but at the sight of this child it was plainer than ever to her (Anna) that the feeling she (Anna) had for her (Anna) could not be called love in comparison with what she (Anna) felt for Seryozha.

'' (She)

A footman offered her (Anna) coffee. '' Later on,'' she (Anna) said. Everything in this baby was charming, but for some reason all this did not go deep to her (Anna) heart.

On her (Anna) first child, though the child of an unloved father, had been concentrated all the love that had never found satisfaction.

Her (Anna) baby girl had been born in the most painful circumstances and had not had a hundredth part of the care and thought which had been concentrated on her (Anna) first child.

Besides, in the little girl everything was still in the future, while Seryozha was by now almost a personality, and a personality dearly loved.

In him (father) there was a conflict of thought and feeling; he (father) understood her (Anna), he (father) loved her (Anna), he (father) judged her (Anna), she (Anna) thought, recalling his (father) words and his (father) eyes.

She (Anna) gave the baby back to the nurse, let her (Anna) go, and opened the locket in which there was Seryozha's portrait when he (father) was almost of the same age as the girl.

She (girl) got up, and, taking off her (girl) hat, took up from a little table an album in which there were photographs of her (girl) son at different ages.

And she (girl) was forever--not physically only but spiritually--divided from him (son), and it was impossible to set this right. She (girl) wanted to compare them, and began taking them out of the album.

She (girl) took them all out except one, the latest and best photograph. In it he (son) was in a white smock, sitting astride a chair, with frowning eyes and smiling lips.

With her (girl) little supple hands, her (girl) white, delicate fingers, that moved with a peculiar intensity today, she (girl) pulled at a corner of the photograph, but the photograph had caught somewhere, and she (girl) could not get it out.

There was no paper knife on the table, and so, pulling out the photograph that was next to her (girl) son's -LRB-it was a photograph of Vronsky taken at Rome in a round hat and with long hair-RRB-, she (girl) used it to push out her (girl) son's photograph.

she (girl) said, glancing at the portrait of Vronsky, and she (girl) suddenly recalled that he (son) was the cause of her (girl) present misery.

It was his (son) best, most characteristic expression. '' Oh, here is he (son)! '' She (girl) had not once thought of him (son) all the morning.

But now, coming all at once upon that manly, noble face, so familiar and so dear to her (girl), she (girl) felt a sudden rush of love for him (son).

she (girl) thought all at once with a feeling of reproach, forgetting she (girl) had herself kept from him (son) everything concerning her (girl) son.

She (girl) sent to ask him (son) to come to her (girl) immediately; with a throbbing heart she (girl) awaited him (son), rehearsing to herself the words in which she (girl) would tell him (son) all, and the expressions of love with which he (son) would console her (girl).

The messenger returned with the answer that he (son) had a visitor with him (son), but that he (son) would come immediately, and that he (son) asked whether she (girl) would let him (son) bring with him (son) Prince Yashvin, who had just arrived in Petersburg.

He (son)'s not coming alone, and since dinner yesterday he (son) has not seen me,'' she (girl) thought;

``he (son)'s not coming so that I could tell him (son) everything, but coming with Yashvin.

'' (she)

But where is he (Yashvin)? How is it he (Yashvin) leaves me alone in my misery? '' '' '' And all at once a strange idea came to her (girl): what if he (Yashvin) had ceased to love her (girl)?

And going over the events of the last few days, it seemed to her (girl) that she (girl) saw in everything a confirmation of this terrible idea.

The fact that he (Yashvin) had not dined at home yesterday, and the fact that he (Yashvin) had insisted on their taking separate sets of rooms in Petersburg, and that even now he (Yashvin) was not coming to her (girl) alone, as though he (Yashvin) were trying to avoid meeting her (girl) face to face.

If I knew it, then I know what I should do,'' she (girl) said to herself, utterly unable to picture to herself the position she (girl) would be in if she (girl) were convinced of his (Yashvin) not caring for her (girl).

'' But he (Yashvin) ought to tell me so. I must know that it is so. She (girl) thought he (Yashvin) had ceased to love her (girl), she (girl) felt close upon despair, and consequently she (girl) felt exceptionally alert.

As she (girl) dressed, she (girl) took more care over her (girl) appearance than she (girl) had done all those days, as though he (Yashvin) might, if he (Yashvin) had grown cold to her (girl), fall in love with her (girl) again because she (girl) had dressed and arranged her (girl) hair in the way most becoming to her (girl).

She (girl) rang for her (girl) maid and went to her (girl) dressing room. She (girl) heard the bell ring before she (girl) was ready. When she (girl) went into the drawing room it was not he (Yashvin), but Yashvin, who met her (girl) eyes.

Vronsky was looking through the photographs of her (girl) son, which she (girl) had forgotten on the table, and he (Vronsky) made no haste to look round at her (girl).

We have met already,'' she (girl) said, putting her (girl) little hand into the huge hand of Yashvin, whose bashfulness was so queerly out of keeping with his (Vronsky) immense frame and coarse face.

Give them to me,'' she (girl) said, with a rapid movement snatching from Vronsky the photographs of her (girl) son, and glancing significantly at him (son) with flashing eyes.

'' '' We met last year at the races.

``Were the races good this year? Instead of them I saw the races in the Corso in Rome.

But you don't care for life abroad,'' (she)

she (girl) said with a cordial smile. '' I know you and all your tastes, though I have seen so little of you.''

Having talked a little while, and noticing that Vronsky glanced at the clock, Yashvin asked her (girl) whether she (girl) would be staying much longer in Petersburg, and unbending his (Yashvin) huge figure reached after his (Yashvin) cap.

'' I'm awfully sorry for that, for my tastes are mostly bad,'' said Yashvin, gnawing at his (Yashvin) left mustache. '' Not long, I think,'' she (girl) said hesitatingly, glancing at Vronsky.

``Come and dine with me,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna resolutely, angry it seemed with herself for her (Anna) embarrassment, but flushing as she (Anna) always did when she (Anna) defined her (Anna) position before a fresh person.

'' So then we shan't meet again?'' '' The dinner here is not good, but at least you will see him (Yashvin).

There is no one of his (Yashvin) old friends in the regiment Alexey cares for as he (Alexey) does for you.''

``Delighted,'' (Yashvin/Prince Yashvin/Prince)
said Yashvin with a smile, from which Vronsky could see that he (Yashvin) liked Anna very much.

She (Anna) took him (Vronsky) by the hand, and without taking her (Anna) eyes off him (Vronsky), gazed at him (Vronsky) while she (Anna) ransacked her (Anna) mind for the words to say that would keep him (Vronsky).

``You did quite right,'' (he)
