Alexey, you have not changed to me? '' she (Anna) said, pressing his (Alexey) hand in both of hers. '' Alexey, I am miserable here.

You wouldn't believe how disagreeable our way of living here is to me too,'' he (Alexey) said, and he (Alexey) drew away his (Alexey) hand.

When are we going away?''

``Soon, soon. '' (unknown)
Well, go, go! '' she (Anna) said in a tone of offense, and she (Anna) walked quickly away from him (Alexey).

Soon after he (Alexey) had left, some lady, so they told him (Alexey), had come to see her (lady), and she (lady) had gone out with her (lady).

That she (lady) had gone out without leaving word where she (lady) was going, that she (lady) had not yet come back, and that all the morning she (lady) had been going about somewhere without a word to him (Alexey)--all this, together with the strange look of excitement in her (lady) face in the morning, and the recollection of the hostile tone with which she (lady) had before Yashvin almost snatched her (lady) son's photographs out of his (Yashvin) hands, made him (Yashvin) serious.

Chapter 32 When Vronsky returned home, Anna was not yet home. He (Vronsky) decided he (Vronsky) absolutely must speak openly with her (Anna). And he (Vronsky) waited for her (Anna) in her (Anna) drawing room.

But Anna did not return alone, but brought with her (Anna) her (Anna) old unmarried aunt, Princess Oblonskaya. This was the lady who had come in the morning, and with whom Anna had gone out shopping.

He (Vronsky) saw that there was something working within her (Anna); in her (Anna) flashing eyes, when they rested for a moment on him (Vronsky), there was an intense concentration, and in her (Anna) words and movements there was that nervous rapidity and grace which, during the early period of their intimacy, had so fascinated him (Vronsky), but which now so disturbed and alarmed him (Vronsky).

Anna appeared not to notice Vronsky's worried and inquiring expression, and began a lively account of her (Anna) morning's shopping. The dinner was laid for four.

All were gathered together and about to go into the little dining room when Tushkevitch made his (Vronsky) appearance with a message from Princess Betsy.

Princess Betsy begged her (Betsy) to excuse her (Betsy) not having come to say good-bye; she (Betsy) had been indisposed, but begged Anna to come to her (Anna) between half-past six and nine o'clock.

Vronsky glanced at Anna at the precise limit of time, so suggestive of steps having been taken that she (Anna) should meet no one; but Anna appeared not to notice it.

'' Very sorry that I can't come just between half-past six and nine,'' she (Anna) said with a faint smile. '' The princess will be very sorry.''

'' And so am I. '' '' You're going, no doubt, to hear Patti?'' said Tushkevitch. '' Patti? You suggest the idea to me.

I would go if it were possible to get a box. ''

``I can get one,'' (Tushkevitch)
Tushkevitch offered his (Tushkevitch) services. ''

I should be very, very grateful to you,'' said Anna. '' But won't you dine with us? '' Vronsky gave a hardly perceptible shrug.

He (Tushkevitch) was at a complete loss to understand what Anna was about. What had she (Anna) brought the old Princess Oblonskaya home for

, what had she (Anna) made Tushkevitch stay to dinner for, and, most amazing of all, why was she (Anna) sending him (Tushkevitch) for a box?

Could she (Anna) possibly think in her (Anna) position of going to Patti's benefit, where all the circle of her (Anna) acquaintances would be?

He (Tushkevitch) looked at her (Anna) with serious eyes, but she (Anna) responded with that defiant, half-mirthful, half-desperate look, the meaning of which he (Tushkevitch) could not comprehend.

When they got up from dinner and Tushkevitch had gone to get a box at the opera, Yashvin went to smoke, and Vronsky went down with him (Vronsky) to his (Vronsky) own rooms.

At dinner Anna was in aggressively high spirits--she (Anna) almost flirted both with Tushkevitch and with Yashvin. After sitting there for some time he (Yashvin) ran upstairs.

Anna was already dressed in a low-necked gown of light silk and velvet that she (Anna) had had made in Paris, and with costly white lace on her (Anna) head, framing her (Anna) face, and particularly becoming, showing up her (Anna) dazzling beauty.

'' Are you really going to the theater? '' he (Yashvin) said, trying not to look at her (Anna). '' Why do you ask with such alarm?

'' she (Anna) said, wounded again at his (Yashvin) not looking at her (Anna). '' Why shouldn't I go? '' She (Anna) appeared not to understand the motive of his (Yashvin) words.

That's just what I say,'' she (Anna) said, willfully refusing to see the irony of his (Yashvin) tone, and quietly turning back her (Anna) long, perfumed glove.

'' Oh, of course, there's no reason whatever,'' he (Yashvin) said, frowning. '' '' Anna, for God's sake! what is the matter with you?

'' he (God) said, appealing to her (Anna) exactly as once her (Anna) husband had done. '' I don't understand what you are asking.''

``You know that it's out of the question to go. '' (unknown)
``Why so? I'm not going alone. Princess Varvara has gone to dress, she (Princess) is going with me.

'' (He)

He (husband) shrugged his (husband) shoulders with an air of perplexity and despair. '' But do you mean to say you don't know?...

'' he (husband) began. '' But I don't care to know! '' she (Princess) almost shrieked. '' I don't care to. Do I regret what I have done?

No, no, no! If it were all to do again from the beginning, it would be the same. For us, for you and for me, there is only one thing that matters, whether we love each other.

Other people we need not consider. Why are we living here apart and not seeing each other? Why can't I go?

I love you, and I don't care for anything,'' she (people) said in Russian, glancing at him (Russian) with a peculiar gleam in her (people) eyes that he (Russian) could not understand.

'' If you have not changed to me, why don't you look at me?'' He (Russian) looked at her (people). He (Russian) saw all the beauty of her (people) face and full dress, always so becoming to her (people).

My feeling cannot change, you know, but I beg you, I entreat you,'' he (Russian) said again in French, with a note of tender supplication in his (Russian) voice, but with coldness in his (Russian) eyes.

But now her (people) beauty and elegance were just what irritated him (Russian). '' She (people) did not hear his (Russian) words, but she (people) saw the coldness of his (Russian) eyes, and answered with irritation:

``And I beg you to explain why I should not go. '' (she)
'' Because it might cause you... '' he (Russian) hesitated.

'' I don't understand. Yashvin n'est pas compromettant , and Princess Varvara is no worse than others. Oh, here she (Princess) is!''

Chapter 33 Vronsky for the first time experienced a feeling of anger against Anna, almost a hatred for her (Anna) willfully refusing to understand her (Anna) own position.

If he (Russian) had told her (Anna) directly what he (Russian) was thinking, he (Russian) would have said:

``In that dress, with a princess only too well known to everyone, to show yourself at the theater is equivalent not merely to acknowledging your position as a fallen woman, but is flinging down a challenge to society, that is to say, cutting yourself off from it forever.

This feeling was aggravated by his (Russian) being unable to tell her (woman) plainly the cause of his (Russian) anger. '' (he)

He (Russian) could not say that to her (woman).

'' But how can she (woman) fail to see it, and what is going on in her (woman)? '' he (Russian) said to himself.

He (Russian) felt at the same time that his (Russian) respect for her (woman) was diminished while his (Russian) sense of her (woman) beauty was intensified.

He (Russian) went back scowling to his (Russian) rooms, and sitting down beside Yashvin, who, with his (Yashvin) long legs stretched out on a chair, was drinking brandy and seltzer water, he (Yashvin) ordered a glass of the same for himself.

'' You were talking of Lankovsky's Powerful. That's a fine horse, and I would advise you to buy him (Yashvin),'' said Yashvin, glancing at his (Yashvin) comrade's gloomy face.

'' His (Yashvin) hind-quarters aren't quite first-rate, but the legs and head--one couldn't wish for anything better. ''

``I think I will take him (Yashvin),'' (Vronsky)
answered Vronsky.

Their conversation about horses interested him (Yashvin), but he (Yashvin) did not for an instant forget Anna, and could not help listening to the sound of steps in the corridor and looking at the clock on the chimney piece.

'' Anna Arkadyevna gave orders to announce that she (Arkadyevna) has gone to the theater. '' Yashvin, tipping another glass of brandy into the bubbling water, drank it and got up, buttoning his (Yashvin) coat.

Well, let's go,'' he (Yashvin) said, faintly smiling under his (Yashvin) mustache, and showing by this smile that he (Yashvin) knew the cause of Vronsky's gloominess, and did not attach any significance to it.

'' '' I'm not going,'' Vronsky answered gloomily. '' Well, I must, I promised to. Good-bye, then. If you do, come to the stalls; you can take Kruzin's stall,'' added Yashvin as he (Yashvin) went out.

``A wife is a care, but it's worse when she (wife)'s not a wife,'' (Yashvin/Prince Yashvin/Prince)
thought Yashvin, as he (Yashvin) walked out of the hotel.

'' No, I'm busy.'' Vronsky, left alone, got up from his (Yashvin) chair and began pacing up and down the room. ''

And what's today? The fourth night.... Yegor and his (Yashvin) wife are there, and my mother, most likely. Of course all Petersburg's there.

Now she (mother)'s gone in, taken off her (mother) cloak and come into the light. Tushkevitch, Yashvin, Princess Varvara,'' he (Yashvin) pictured them to himself...

'' What about me? Either that I'm frightened or have given up to Tushkevitch the right to protect her (Princess)? From every point of view--stupid, stupid!

With that gesture he (Yashvin) knocked against the table, on which there was standing the seltzer water and the decanter of brandy, and almost upset it.

... And why is she (Princess) putting me in such a position? '' he (Yashvin) said with a gesture of despair. He (Yashvin) tried to catch it, let it slip, and angrily kicked the table over and rang.

If you care to be in my service,'' he (Yashvin) said to the valet who came in,

``you had better remember your duties.

The valet, conscious of his (valet) own innocence, would have defended himself, but glancing at his (valet) master, he (valet) saw from his (valet) face that the only thing to do was to be silent, and hurriedly threading his (valet) way in and out, dropped down on the carpet and began gathering up the whole and broken glasses and bottles.

'' (the valet)

This shouldn't be here. You ought to have cleared away. '' '' That's not your duty; send the waiter to clear away, and get my dress coat out.

The little old box-keeper, recognizing Vronsky as he (Vronsky) helped him (Vronsky) off with his (Vronsky) fur coat, called him (Vronsky)

``Your Excellency,'' (him)
and suggested he (Vronsky) should not take a number but should simply call Fyodor.

In the brightly lighted corridor there was no one but the box-opener and two attendants with fur cloaks on their arms listening at the doors.

Through the closed doors came the sounds of the discreet staccato accompaniment of the orchestra, and a single female voice rendering distinctly a musical phrase.

'' Vronsky went into the theater at half-past eight. The performance was in full swing. The door opened to let the box-opener slip through, and the phrase drawing to the end reached Vronsky's hearing clearly.

But the doors were closed again at once, and Vronsky did not hear the end of the phrase and the cadence of the accompaniment, though he (Vronsky) knew from the thunder of applause that it was over.

On the stage the singer, bowing and smiling, with bare shoulders flashing with diamonds, was, with the help of the tenor who had given her (Vronsky) his (tenor) arm, gathering up the bouquets that were flying awkwardly over the footlights.

Then she (Vronsky) went up to a gentleman with glossy pomaded hair parted down the center, who was stretching across the footlights holding out something to her (Vronsky), and all the public in the stalls as well as in the boxes was in excitement, craning forward, shouting and clapping.

When he (gentleman) entered the hall, brilliantly lighted with chandeliers and gas jets, the noise was still going on. The conductor in his (conductor) high chair assisted in passing the offering, and straightened his (conductor) white tie.

That day less than ever was his (conductor) attention turned upon the familiar, habitual surroundings, the stage, the noise, all the familiar, uninteresting, particolored herd of spectators in the packed theater.

There were, as always, the same ladies of some sort with officers of some sort in the back of the boxes; the same gaily dressed women--God knows who--and uniforms and black coats; the same dirty crowd in the upper gallery; and among the crowd, in the boxes and in the front rows, were some forty of the real people.

Vronsky walked into the middle of the stalls, and, standing still, began looking about him (God). And to those oases Vronsky at once directed his (God) attention, and with them he (God) entered at once into relation.

The act was over when he (God) went in, and so he (God) did not go straight to his (God) brother's box, but going up to the first row of stalls stopped at the footlights with Serpuhovskoy, who, standing with one knee raised and his (God) heel on the footlights, caught sight of him (God) in the distance and beckoned to him (God), smiling.

Vronsky had not yet seen Anna. He (God) purposely avoided looking in her (Anna) direction. But he (God) knew by the direction of people's eyes where she (Anna) was.

He (God) looked round discreetly, but he (God) was not seeking her (Anna); expecting the worst, his (God) eyes sought for Alexey Alexandrovitch. To his (God) relief Alexey Alexandrovitch was not in the theater that evening.

'' How little of the military man there is left in you! '' Serpuhovskoy was saying to him (man). '' A diplomat, an artist, something of that sort, one would say.

``Yes, it was like going back home when I put on a black coat,'' (Vronsky)
answered Vronsky, smiling and slowly taking out his (artist) opera glass.

'' '' Well, I'll own I envy you there. When I come back from abroad and put on this,'' he (artist) touched his (artist) epaulets,

``I regret my freedom.

Serpuhovskoy had long given up all hope of Vronsky's career, but he (artist) liked him (artist) as before, and was now particularly cordial to him (artist).

'' (he)

'' What a pity you were not in time for the first act! '' Vronsky, listening with one ear, moved his (artist) opera glass from the stalls and scanned the boxes.

Near a lady in a turban and a bald old man, who seemed to wave angrily in the moving opera glass, Vronsky suddenly caught sight of Anna's head, proud, strikingly beautiful, and smiling in the frame of lace.

She (Anna) was in the fifth box, twenty paces from him (man). She (Anna) was sitting in front, and slightly turning, was saying something to Yashvin.

The setting of her (Anna) head on her (Anna) handsome, broad shoulders, and the restrained excitement and brilliance of her (Anna) eyes and her (Anna) whole face reminded him (Yashvin) of her (Anna) just as he (Yashvin) had seen her (Anna) at the ball in Moscow.

In his (Yashvin) feeling for her (Anna) now there was no element of mystery, and so her (Anna) beauty, though it attracted him (Yashvin) even more intensely than before, gave him (Yashvin) now a sense of injury.

But he (Yashvin) felt utterly different towards her (Anna) beauty now. She (Anna) was not looking in his (Yashvin) direction, but Vronsky felt that she (Anna) had seen him (Vronsky) already.

When Vronsky turned the opera glass again in that direction, he (Vronsky) noticed that Princess Varvara was particularly red, and kept laughing unnaturally and looking round at the next box.

Anna, folding her (Anna) fan and tapping it on the red velvet, was gazing away and did not see, and obviously did not wish to see, what was taking place in the next box.

Scowling, he (fan) sucked the left end of his (fan) mustache further and further into his (fan) mouth, and cast sidelong glances at the next box.

Yashvin's face wore the expression which was common when he (Yashvin) was losing at cards. In that box on the left were the Kartasovs.

Madame Kartasova, a thin little woman, was standing up in her (woman) box, and, her (woman) back turned upon Anna, she (woman) was putting on a mantle that her (woman) husband was holding for her (woman).

Vronsky knew them, and knew that Anna was acquainted with them. Her (Anna) face was pale and angry, and she (Anna) was talking excitedly.

When the wife had gone out, the husband lingered a long while, and tried to catch Anna's eye, obviously anxious to bow to her (Anna).

Kartasov, a fat, bald man, was continually looking round at Anna, while he (man) attempted to soothe his (man) wife. But Anna, with unmistakable intention, avoided noticing him (man), and talked to Yashvin, whose cropped head was bent down to her (Anna).

Vronsky could not understand exactly what had passed between the Kartasovs and Anna, but he (Yashvin) saw that something humiliating for Anna had happened.

He (Yashvin) knew this both from what he (Yashvin) had seen, and most of all from the face of Anna, who, he (Yashvin) could see, was taxing every nerve to carry through the part she (Anna) had taken up.

Kartasov went out without making his (Yashvin) salutation, and the box was left empty. And in maintaining this attitude of external composure she (Anna) was completely successful.

Anyone who did not know her (Anna) and her (Anna) circle, who had not heard all the utterances of the women expressive of commiseration, indignation, and amazement, that she (Anna) should show herself in society, and show herself so conspicuously with her (Anna) lace and her (Anna) beauty, would have admired the serenity and loveliness of this woman without a suspicion that she (Anna) was undergoing the sensations of a man in the stocks.

Knowing that something had happened, but not knowing precisely what, Vronsky felt a thrill of agonizing anxiety, and hoping to find out something, he (Vronsky) went towards his (Vronsky) brother's box.

Purposely choosing the way round furthest from Anna's box, he (Vronsky) jostled as he (Vronsky) came out against the colonel of his (Vronsky) old regiment talking to two acquaintances.

Vronsky heard the name of Madame Karenina, and noticed how the colonel hastened to address Vronsky loudly by name, with a meaning glance at his (colonel) companions.

'' Ah, Vronsky! When are you coming to the regiment? We can't let you off without a supper. You're one of the old set,'' said the colonel of his (colonel) regiment.

'' I can't stop, awfully sorry, another time,'' said Vronsky, and he (Vronsky) ran upstairs towards his (Vronsky) brother's box. The old countess, Vronsky's mother, with her (countess) steel-gray curls, was in his (Vronsky) brother's box.

Leaving the Princess Sorokina with her (Princess) mother, Varya held out her (Varya) hand to her (Varya) brother-in-law, and began immediately to speak of what interested him (brother-in-law).

Varya with the young Princess Sorokina met him (brother-in-law) in the corridor. She (Sorokina) was more excited than he (brother-in-law) had ever seen her (Sorokina).

'' I think it's mean and hateful, and Madame Kartasova had no right to do it. Madame Karenina... '' she (Sorokina) began.

'' But what is it? I don't know. ''

``What? you've not heard?'' (unknown)
``You know I should be the last person to hear of it.

'' (a creature)

'' There isn't a more spiteful creature than that Madame Kartasova!'' '' But what did she (Sorokina) do?'' '' My husband told me....

She (Sorokina) has insulted Madame Karenina. Her (Sorokina) husband began talking to her (Sorokina) across the box, and Madame Kartasova made a scene. She (Sorokina) said something aloud, he (husband) says, something insulting, and went away.''

``Count, your maman is asking for you,'' (Sorokina/Princess Sorokina)
said the young Princess Sorokina, peeping out of the door of the box. ''

'' Vronsky made no reply, and saying a few words to Princess Sorokina, he (son) went away. At the door he (son) met his (son) brother.

'' Ah, Alexey!'' said his (Alexey) brother. '' How disgusting! Idiot of a woman, nothing else.... I wanted to go straight to her (woman).

Let's go together. '' Vronsky did not hear him (Alexey). With rapid steps he (Alexey) went downstairs; he (Alexey) felt that he (Alexey) must do something, but he (Alexey) did not know what.

Anger with her (woman) for having put herself and him (Alexey) in such a false position, together with pity for her (woman) suffering, filled his (Alexey) heart.

He (Alexey) went down, and made straight for Anna's box. At her (Anna) box stood Stremov, talking to her (Anna). '' There are no more tenors.

You came in late, I think, and have missed the best song,'' Anna said to Vronsky, glancing ironically, he (Alexey) thought, at him (Alexey).

Anna was already at home. When Vronsky went up to her (Anna), she (Anna) was in the same dress as she (Anna) had worn at the theater.

She (Anna) was sitting in the first armchair against the wall, looking straight before her (Anna). She (Anna) looked at him (Vronsky), and at once resumed her (Anna) former position.

'' Anna,'' he (Vronsky) said. '' You, you are to blame for everything! '' she (Anna) cried, with tears of despair and hatred in her (Anna) voice, getting up.

``Unpleasant! '' (I)
she (Anna) cried--
``hideous! As long as I live I shall never forget it.

She (Anna) said it was a disgrace to sit beside me.'' (she)

``I hate your calm. You ought not to have brought me to this. If you had loved me... '' (unknown)
``Anna! How does the question of my love come in?'' (me)

'' Oh, if you loved me, as I love, if you were tortured as I am!... '' she (Anna) said, looking at him (Vronsky) with an expression of terror.

He (Vronsky) assured her (Anna) of his (Vronsky) love because he (Vronsky) saw that this was the only means of soothing her (Anna), and he (Vronsky) did not reproach her (Anna) in words, but in his (Vronsky) heart he (Vronsky) reproached her (Anna).

And the asseverations of his (Vronsky) love, which seemed to him (Vronsky) so vulgar that he (Vronsky) was ashamed to utter them, she (Anna) drank in eagerly, and gradually became calmer.

He (Vronsky) was sorry for her (Anna), and angry notwithstanding. The next day, completely reconciled, they left for the country. PART 6 Chapter 1 Darya Alexandrovna spent the summer with her (Anna) children at Pokrovskoe, at her (Anna) sister Kitty Levin's.

The house on her (Anna) own estate was quite in ruins, and Levin and his (Levin) wife had persuaded her (Anna) to spend the summer with them.

his (Levin) official duties prevented him (Levin) from spending the summer in the country with his (Levin) family, which would have been the greatest happiness for him (Levin); and remaining in Moscow, he (Levin) came down to the country from time to time for a day or two.

Besides the Oblonskys, with all their children and their governess, the old princess too came to stay that summer with the Levins, as she (princess) considered it her (princess) duty to watch over her (princess) inexperienced daughter in her (princess) interesting condition .

Moreover, Varenka, Kitty's friend abroad, kept her (Kitty) promise to come to Kitty when she (Kitty) was married, and stayed with her (Kitty) friend.

Stepan Arkadyevitch greatly approved of the arrangement. He (friend) said he (friend) was very sorry All of these were friends or relations of Levin's wife.

And though he (Levin) liked them all, he (Levin) rather regretted his (Levin) own Levin world and ways, which was smothered by this influx of the

``Shtcherbatsky element,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
as he (Levin) called it to himself.

Of his (Levin) own relations there stayed with him (Levin) only Sergey Ivanovitch, but he (Levin) too was a man of the Koznishev and not the Levin stamp, so that the Levin spirit was utterly obliterated.

In the Levins' house, so long deserted, there were now so many people that almost all the rooms were occupied, and almost every day it happened that the old princess, sitting down to table, counted them all over, and put the thirteenth grandson or granddaughter at a separate table.

And Kitty, with her (Kitty) careful housekeeping, had no little trouble to get all the chickens, turkeys, and geese, of which so many were needed to satisfy the summer appetites of the visitors and children.

The whole family were sitting at dinner. Dolly's children, with their governess and Varenka, were making plans for going to look for mushrooms.

Sergey Ivanovitch, who was looked up to by all the party for his (Ivanovitch) intellect and learning, with a respect that almost amounted to awe, surprised everyone by joining in the conversation about mushrooms.

``Take me with you. I am very fond of picking mushrooms,'' (he)
he (Ivanovitch) said, looking at Varenka;
``I think it's a very nice occupation.

The proposal of the learned and intellectual Sergey Ivanovitch to go looking for mushrooms with Varenka confirmed certain theories of Kitty's with which her (Kitty) mind had been very busy of late.

'' (Varenka)

'' Oh, we shall be delighted,'' answered Varenka, coloring a little. Kitty exchanged meaningful glances with Dolly. She (Dolly) made haste to address some remark to her (Dolly) mother, so that her (Dolly) look should not be noticed.

After dinner Sergey Ivanovitch sat with his (Ivanovitch) cup of coffee at the drawing-room window, and while he (Ivanovitch) took part in a conversation he (Ivanovitch) had begun with his (Ivanovitch) brother, he (Ivanovitch) watched the door through which the children would start on the mushroom-picking expedition.

Kitty stood beside her (Kitty) husband, evidently awaiting the end of a conversation that had no interest for her (Kitty), in order to tell him (husband) something.

You have changed in many respects since your marriage, and for the better,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling to Kitty, and obviously little interested in the conversation,

``but you have remained true to your passion for defending the most paradoxical theories.

Katya, it's not good for you to stand,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

her (Katya) husband said to her (Katya), putting a chair for her (Katya) and looking significantly at her (Katya).

Levin was sitting in the window near his (Levin) brother. '' '' '' '' Oh, and there's no time either,'' added Sergey Ivanovitch, seeing the children running out.

At the head of them all Tanya galloped sideways, in her (Tanya) tightly- drawn stockings, and waving a basket and Sergey Ivanovitch's hat, she (Tanya) ran straight up to him (Ivanovitch).

Boldly running up to Sergey Ivanovitch with shining eyes, so like her (Tanya) father's fine eyes, she (Tanya) handed him (Ivanovitch) his (Ivanovitch) hat and made as though she (Tanya) would put it on for him (Ivanovitch), softening her (Tanya) freedom by a shy and friendly smile.

'' Varenka's waiting,'' she (Tanya) said, carefully putting his (Ivanovitch) hat on, seeing from Sergey Ivanovitch's smile that she (Tanya) might do so. Varenka was standing at the door, dressed in a yellow print gown, with a white kerchief on her (Tanya) head.

I'm coming, I'm coming, Varvara Andreevna,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, finishing his (Ivanovitch) cup of coffee, and putting into their separate pockets his (Ivanovitch) handkerchief and cigar-case.

'' '' And how sweet my Varenka is! eh?'' said Kitty to her (Kitty) husband, as soon as Sergey Ivanovitch rose. She (Kitty) spoke so that Sergey Ivanovitch could hear, and it was clear that she (Kitty) meant him (Ivanovitch) to do so.

'' And how good-looking she (Kitty) is--such a refined beauty! Varenka! '' Kitty shouted. '' Shall you be in the mill copse?

We'll come out to you.''

``You certainly forget your condition, Kitty,'' (the princess)
said the old princess, hurriedly coming out at the door.

'' You mustn't shout like that. '' Varenka, hearing Kitty's voice and her (Kitty) mother's reprimand, went with light, rapid steps up to Kitty.

The rapidity of her (Kitty) movement, her (Kitty) flushed and eager face, everything betrayed that something out of the common was going on in her (Kitty).

She (Kitty) called Varenka at that moment merely in order mentally to give her (Kitty) a blessing for the important event which, as Kitty fancied, was bound to come to pass that day after dinner in the wood.

Kitty knew what this was, and had been watching her (Kitty) intently. '' Varenka, I should be very happy if a certain something were to happen,'' she (Kitty) whispered as she (Kitty) kissed her (Kitty).

'' And are you coming with us?'' Varenka said to Levin in confusion, pretending not to have heard what had been said.

'' I am coming, but only as far as the threshing-floor, and there I shall stop. ''

``Why, what do you want there?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
said Kitty.

I must go to have a look at the new wagons, and to check the invoice,'' said Levin;

``and where will you be?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

''

``On the terrace. '' (the ladies)
Chapter 2 On the terrace were assembled all the ladies of the party. They always liked sitting there after dinner, and that day they had work to do there too.

Besides the sewing and knitting of baby clothes, with which all of them were busy, that afternoon jam was being made on the terrace by a method new to Agafea Mihalovna, without the addition of water.

Agafea Mihalovna, to whom the task of jam-making had always been intrusted, considering that what had been done in the Levin household could not be amiss, had nevertheless put water with the strawberries, maintaining that the jam could not be made without it.

She (Levin) had been caught in the act, and was now making jam before everyone, and it was to be proved to her (Levin) conclusively that jam could be very well made without water.

Agafea Mihalovna, her (Levin) face heated and angry, her (Levin) hair untidy, and her (Levin) thin arms bare to the elbows, was turning the preserving-pan over the charcoal stove, looking darkly at the raspberries and devoutly hoping they would stick and not cook properly.

The princess, conscious that Agafea Mihalovna's wrath must be chiefly directed against her (princess), as the person responsible for the raspberry jam-making, tried to appear to be absorbed in other things and not interested in the jam, talked of other matters, but cast stealthy glances in the direction of the stove.

Kitty had introduced this new method, which had been in use in her (Kitty) home. '' I always buy my maids' dresses myself, of some cheap material,'' the princess said, continuing the previous conversation.

'' Isn't it time to skim it, my dear? '' she (princess) added, addressing Agafea Mihalovna. '' There's not the slightest need for you to do it, and it's hot for you,'' she (princess) said, stopping Kitty.

I'll do it,'' said Dolly, and getting up, she (Dolly) carefully passed the spoon over the frothing sugar, and from time to time shook off the clinging jam from the spoon by knocking it on a plate that was covered with yellow-red scum and blood-colored syrup.

'' she (Dolly) thought of her (Dolly) children, remembering how she (Dolly) herself as a child had wondered how it was the grown-up people did not eat what was best of all--the scum of the jam.

'' '' How they'll enjoy this at tea-time! '' Stiva says it's much better to give money. '' Dolly took up meanwhile the weighty subject under discussion, what presents should be made to servants.

'' But...''

``Money's out of the question! '' (the princess Kitty)
the princess and Kitty exclaimed with one voice. '' They appreciate a present...

Well, last year, for instance, I bought our Matrona Semyenovna, not a poplin, but something of that sort,'' said the princess.

'' '' '' I remember she (princess) was wearing it on your nameday.''

``A charming pattern--so simple and refined,--I should have liked it myself, if she (princess) hadn't had it.

Something like Varenka's. So pretty and inexpensive.'' (I)

'' Well, now I think it's done,'' said Dolly, dropping the syrup from the spoon.

'' When it sets as it drops, it's ready. Cook it a little longer, Agafea Mihalovna.''

``The flies!'' (Agafea Mihalovna)
said Agafea Mihalovna angrily.

Kitty said suddenly, looking at a sparrow that had settled on the step and was pecking at the center of a raspberry.

'' It'll be just the same,'' she (Kitty) added. '' Ah! how sweet it is! don't frighten it!'' '' Yes, but you keep a little further from the stove,'' said her (Kitty) mother.

√Ä propos de Varenka ,'' said Kitty, speaking in French, as they had been doing all the while, so that Agafea Mihalovna should not understand them,

``you know, mamma, I somehow expect things to be settled today.

'' (Agafea Mihalovna)

'' How carefully and cleverly she (Dolly) throws them together!... '' '' No; tell me, mamma, what do you think?''

``Why, what is one to think?

-LRB- he (French) meant Sergey Ivanovitch-RRB-
``might at any time have been a match for anyone in Russia; now, of course, he (Ivanovitch)'s not quite a young man, still I know ever so many girls would be glad to marry him (Ivanovitch) even now....

She (Dolly)'s a very nice girl, but he (Ivanovitch) might...'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

``Oh, no, mamma, do understand why, for him (Ivanovitch) and for her (Dolly) too, nothing better could be imagined.

said Kitty, crooking one of her (Kitty) fingers. '' He (Ivanovitch) thinks her (Kitty) very attractive, that's certain,'' assented Dolly.

'' All he (Ivanovitch) needs is a good, sweet wife--a restful one.'' '' Well, with her (wife) he (Ivanovitch) would certainly be restful,'' Dolly assented. ''

Thirdly, that she (Dolly) should love him (Ivanovitch). And so it is... that is, it would be so splendid!... I look forward to seeing them coming out of the forest--and everything settled.

I shall see at once by their eyes. I should be so delighted! What do you think, Dolly?'' '' But don't excite yourself.

It's not at all the thing for you to be excited,'' said her (Dolly) mother. '' Oh, I'm not excited, mamma. I fancy he (Ivanovitch) will make her (Dolly) an offer today.''

There is a sort of barrier, and all at once it's broken down,'' said Dolly, smiling pensively and recalling her (Dolly) past with Stepan Arkadyevitch.

``Ah, that's so strange, how and when a man makes an offer!... '' (papa)
Mamma, how did papa make you an offer?''

There was nothing out of the way, it was very simple,'' answered the princess, but her (princess) face beamed all over at the recollection.

Kitty felt a peculiar pleasure in being able now to talk to her (Kitty) mother on equal terms about those questions of such paramount interest in a woman's life.

Kitty asked suddenly. '' '' Oh, but how was it? You loved him (papa), anyway, before you were allowed to speak?'' ''

Of course I did; he (papa) had come to stay with us in the country.'' '' But how was it settled between you, mamma?''

'' You imagine, I dare say, that you invented something quite new? It's always just the same: it was settled by the eyes, by smiles...

'' she (Dolly) said. And the three women all fell to musing on the same thing. Kitty was the first to break the silence.

said Dolly. '' You judge by your own husband.

But I really don't know,'' the mother put in in defense of her (mother) motherly care of her (mother) daughter,

'' (daughter)

That Vronsky paid you attentions--that happens to every girl.'' '' Oh, yes, but we didn't mean that,'' Kitty said, flushing a little.

'' No, let me speak,'' her (Kitty) mother went on,

``why, you yourself would not let me have a talk to Vronsky.

Don't you remember?'' (mother)

'' Oh, mamma!'' said Kitty, with an expression of suffering. '' There's no keeping you young people in check nowadays....

Your friendship could not have gone beyond what was suitable. I should myself have called upon him (mother) to explain himself. But, my darling, it's not right for you to be agitated.

Please remember that, and calm yourself.'' '' I'm perfectly calm, maman.''

``How happy it was for Kitty that Anna came then,'' (Dolly)
said Dolly,

Now it is just the opposite. I often think of her (Kitty).'' '' A nice person to think about! Horrid, repulsive woman--no heart,'' said her (woman) mother, who could not forget that Kitty had married not Vronsky, but Levin.

'' What do you want to talk of it for?'' Kitty said with annoyance. '' I never think about it, and I don't want to think of it....

And I don't want to think of it,'' she (Kitty) said, catching the sound of her (Kitty) husband's well-known step on the steps of the terrace.

'' What's that you don't want to think about? '' inquired Levin, coming onto the terrace. But no one answered him (Levin), and he (Levin) did not repeat the question.

I'm sorry I've broken in on your feminine parliament,'' he (Levin) said, looking round on every one discontentedly, and perceiving that they had been talking of something which they would not talk about before him (Levin).

For a second he (Levin) felt that he (Levin) was sharing the feeling of Agafea Mihalovna, vexation at their making jam without water, and altogether at the outside Shtcherbatsky element.

'' He (Levin) smiled, however, and went up to Kitty. '' Well, how are you? '' he (Levin) asked her (Kitty), looking at her (Kitty) with the expression with which everyone looked at her (Kitty) now.

'' The wagons held three times as much as the old carts did.

Chapter 3 Kitty was particularly glad of a chance of being alone with her (Kitty) husband, for she (Kitty) had noticed the shade of mortification that had passed over his (husband) face--always so quick to reflect every feeling--at the moment when he (husband) had come onto the terrace and asked what they were talking of, and had got no answer.

When they had set off on foot ahead of the others, and had come out of sight of the house onto the beaten dusty road, marked with rusty wheels and sprinkled with grains of corn, she (Kitty) clung faster to his (husband) arm and pressed it closer to her (Kitty).

He (husband) had quite forgotten the momentary unpleasant impression, and alone with her (Kitty) he (husband) felt, now that the thought of her (Kitty) approaching motherhood was never for a moment absent from his (husband) mind, a new and delicious bliss, quite pure from all alloy of sense, in the being near to the woman he (husband) loved.

There was no need of speech, yet he (husband) longed to hear the sound of her (woman) voice, which like her (woman) eyes had changed since she (woman) had been with child.

In her (woman) voice, as in her (woman) eyes, there was that softness and gravity which is found in people continually concentrated on some cherished pursuit.

No, I'm so glad of a chance of being alone with you, and I must own, though I'm happy with them

'' I don't know what to think,'' Levin answered, smiling. '' Sergey seems very strange to me in that way. I told you, you know...''

'' Yes, that he (Sergey) was in love with that girl who died...''

``That was when I was a child; I know about it from hearsay and tradition.

But I've watched him (Sergey) since with women; he (Sergey) is friendly, some of them he (Sergey) likes, but one feels that to him (Sergey) they're simply people, not women.

I remember him (Sergey) then. He (Sergey) was wonderfully sweet. '' (girl)

``Yes, but now with Varenka... I fancy there's something...'' (unknown)
``Perhaps there is....

But one has to know him (Sergey).... He (Sergey)'s a peculiar, wonderful person. He (Sergey) lives a spiritual life only. He (Sergey)'s too pure, too exalted a nature.

No, but he (Sergey)'s so used to a spiritual life that he (Sergey) can't reconcile himself with actual fact, and Varenka is after all fact.

Levin had grown used by now to uttering his (Levin) thought boldly, without taking the trouble of clothing it in exact language.

He (Levin) knew that his (Levin) wife, in such moments of loving tenderness as now, would understand what he (Levin) meant to say from a hint, and she (wife) did understand him (Levin).

'' (unknown)

I can see that he (Levin) would never have cared for me. She (wife) is altogether spiritual.'' '' Oh, no, he (Levin) is so fond of you, and I am always so glad when my people like you...''

'' Why not speak of him (Levin)? '' he (Levin) added. '' I sometimes blame myself for not; it ends in one's forgetting.

Ah, how terrible and dear he (Levin) was! ... Yes, what were we talking about? '' Levin said, after a pause. ''

You think he (Levin) can't fall in love,'' said Kitty, translating into her (Kitty) own language. '' It's not so much that he (Levin) can't fall in love,'' Levin said, smiling,

I've always envied him (Levin), and even now, when I'm so happy, I still envy him (Levin).'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``I envy him (Levin) for being better than I,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin. '' He (Levin) does not live for himself. His (Levin) whole life is subordinated to his (Levin) duty.

She (Kitty) could never have explained the chain of thought that made her (Kitty) smile; but the last link in it was that her (Kitty) husband, in exalting his (husband) brother and abasing himself, was not quite sincere.

Kitty knew that this insincerity came from his (husband) love for his (husband) brother, from his (husband) sense of shame at being too happy, and above all from his (husband) unflagging craving to be better--she (Kitty) loved it in him (husband), and so she (Kitty) smiled.

And that's why he (husband) can be calm and contented.'' '' And you?'' Kitty asked, with an ironical and loving smile. ''

Her (Kitty) disbelief in his (husband) self-dissatisfaction delighted him (husband), and unconsciously he (husband) tried to draw her (Kitty) into giving utterance to the grounds of her (Kitty) disbelief.

And you? What are you dissatisfied with? '' she (Kitty) asked, with the same smile. '' I am happy, but dissatisfied with myself...'' he (husband) said.

'' Why, how can you be dissatisfied with yourself if you are happy?'' '' Well, how shall I say? ... In my heart I really care for nothing whatever but that you should not stumble--see?

'' he (husband) cried, breaking off to scold her (Kitty) for too agile a movement in stepping over a branch that lay in the path.

But when I think about myself, and compare myself with others, especially with my brother, I feel I'm a poor creature.''

Oh, but really you mustn't skip about like that! '' '' But in what way? '' Kitty pursued with the same smile.

'' Don't you too work for others? What about your co-operative settlement, and your work on the estate, and your book?...

'' '' Oh, but I feel, and particularly just now--it's your fault,'' he (brother) said, pressing her (Kitty) hand--

``that all that doesn't count.

I do it in a way halfheartedly. If I could care for all that as I care for you!... Instead of that, I do it in these days like a task that is set me.'' (he)

'' Well, what would you say about papa?'' asked Kitty. '' Is he (papa) a poor creature then, as he (papa) does nothing for the public good?

''

``He (papa)?--no! But then one must have the simplicity, the straightforwardness, the goodness of your father: and I haven't got that.

Before there was you--and this too,'' (he)

he (father) added with a glance towards her (Kitty) waist that she (Kitty) understood--
``I put all my energies into work; now I can't, and I'm ashamed; I do it just as though it were a task set me, I'm pretending....

I do nothing, and I fret about it. It's all your doing. '' (she)

'' Well, but would you like to change this minute with Sergey Ivanovitch?'' said Kitty.

Would you like to do this work for the general good, and to love the task set you, as he (Ivanovitch) does, and nothing else?''

''

said Levin. '' But I'm so happy that I don't understand anything. So you think he (Levin)'ll make her (Kitty) an offer today?

she (Kitty) said, giving him (Levin) the flower.

She (Kitty) had been watching his (Levin) fingers with interest. '' You picked off two.'' '' Oh, but see, this little one shan't count to make up,'' said Levin, tearing off a little half-grown petal.

'' Here's the wagonette overtaking us.''

called the princess. '' Not in the least.'' '' If you are you can get in, as the horses are quiet and walking.

'' But it was not worth while to get in, they were quite near the place, and all walked on together.

Chapter 4 Varenka, with her (Kitty) white kerchief on her (Kitty) black hair, surrounded by the children, gaily and good-humoredly looking after them, and at the same time visibly excited at the possibility of receiving a declaration from the man she (Kitty) cared for, was very attractive.

Looking at her (Kitty), he (man) recalled all the delightful things he (man) had heard from her (Kitty) lips, all the good he (man) knew about her (Kitty), and became more and more conscious that the feeling he (man) had for her (Kitty) was something special that he (man) had felt long, long ago, and only once, in his (man) early youth.

The feeling of happiness in being near her (Kitty) continually grew, and at last reached such a point that, as he (man) put a huge, slender-stalked agaric fungus in her (Kitty) basket, he (man) looked straight into her (Kitty) face, and noticing the flush of glad and alarmed excitement that overspread her (Kitty) face, he (man) was confused himself, and smiled to her (Kitty) in silence a smile that said too much.

If so,'' he (man) said to himself,

``I ought to think it over and make up my mind, and not give way like a boy to the impulse of a moment.'' (he)

I'm going to pick by myself apart from all the rest, or else my efforts will make no show,'' he (boy) said, and he (boy) left the edge of the forest where they were walking on low silky grass between old birch trees standing far apart, and went more into the heart of the wood, where between the white birch trunks there were gray trunks of aspen and dark bushes of hazel.

Walking some forty paces away, Sergey Ivanovitch, knowing he (Ivanovitch) was out of sight, stood still behind a bushy spindle-tree in full flower with its rosy red catkins.

Only overhead in the birches under which he (Ivanovitch) stood, the flies, like a swarm of bees, buzzed unceasingly, and from time to time the children's voices were floated across to him (Ivanovitch).

All at once he (Ivanovitch) heard, not far from the edge of the wood, the sound of Varenka's contralto voice, calling Grisha, and a smile of delight passed over Sergey Ivanovitch's face.

Conscious of this smile, he (Ivanovitch) shook his (Ivanovitch) head disapprovingly at his (Ivanovitch) own condition, and taking out a cigar, he (Ivanovitch) began lighting it.

Sergey Ivanovitch walked beside her (Ivanovitch), and never left off admiring her (Ivanovitch). '' '' It was perfectly still all round him (Ivanovitch). For a long while he (Ivanovitch) could not get a match to light against the trunk of a birch tree.

At last one of the matches burned, and the fragrant cigar smoke, hovering uncertainly in flat, wide coils, stretched away forwards and upwards over a bush under the overhanging branches of a birch tree.

The soft scales of the white bark rubbed off the phosphorus, and the light went out. Watching the streak of smoke, Sergey Ivanovitch walked gently on, deliberating on his (Ivanovitch) position.

If it were only a passing fancy or a passion, if it were only this attraction--this mutual attraction -LRB-I can call it a mutual attraction-RRB-, but if I felt that it was in contradiction with the whole bent of my life--if I felt that in giving way to this attraction I should be false to my vocation and my duty...

The only thing I can say against it is that, when I lost Marie, I said to myself that I would remain faithful to her (Marie) memory.

'' Why not? '' he (myself) thought. '' but it's not so. That's the only thing I can say against my feeling....

That's a great thing,'' Sergey Ivanovitch said to himself, feeling at the same time that this consideration had not the slightest importance for him (Ivanovitch) personally, but would only perhaps detract from his (Ivanovitch) romantic character in the eyes of others.

'' But apart from that, however much I searched, I should never find anything to say against my feeling. If I were choosing by considerations of suitability alone, I could not have found anything better.

However many women and girls he (Ivanovitch) thought of whom he (Ivanovitch) knew, he (Ivanovitch) could not think of a girl who united to such a degree all, positively all, the qualities he (Ivanovitch) would wish to see in his (Ivanovitch) wife.

She (wife) had all the charm and freshness of youth, but she (wife) was not a child; and if she (wife) loved him (Ivanovitch), she (wife) loved him (Ivanovitch) consciously as a woman ought to love; that was one thing.

Another point: she (wife) was not only far from being worldly, but had an unmistakable distaste for worldly society, and at the same time she (wife) knew the world, and had all the ways of a woman of the best society, which were absolutely essential to Sergey Ivanovitch's conception of the woman who was to share his (Ivanovitch) life.

Thirdly: she (woman) was religious, and not like a child, unconsciously religious and good, as Kitty, for example, was, but her (Kitty) life was founded on religious principles.

Even in trifling matters, Sergey Ivanovitch found in her (Kitty) all that he (Ivanovitch) wanted in his (Ivanovitch) wife: she (Kitty) was poor and alone in the world, so she (Kitty) would not bring with her (Kitty) a mass of relations and their influence into her (Kitty) husband's house, as he (husband) saw now in Kitty's case.

'' She (Kitty) would owe everything to her (Kitty) husband, which was what he (husband) had always desired too for his (husband) future family life.

And this girl, who united all these qualities, loved him (husband). He (husband) was a modest man, but he (husband) could not help seeing it.

But he (husband) came of a long-lived family, he (husband) had not a single gray hair, no one would have taken him (husband) for forty, and he (husband) remembered Varenka's saying that it was only in Russia that men of fifty thought themselves old, and

that in France a man of fifty considers himself dans la force de l'√¢ge , while a man of forty is un jeune homme .

But what did the mere reckoning of years matter when he (man) felt as young in heart as he (man) had been twenty years ago?

Was it not youth to feel as he (man) felt now, when coming from the other side to the edge of the wood he (man) saw in the glowing light of the slanting sunbeams the gracious figure of Varenka in her (themselves) yellow gown with her (themselves) basket, walking lightly by the trunk of an old birch tree, and when this impression of the sight of Varenka blended so harmoniously with the beauty of the view, of the yellow oatfield lying bathed in the slanting sunshine, and beyond it the distant ancient forest flecked with yellow and melting into the blue of the distance?

And he (man) loved her (themselves). There was one consideration against it--his (man) age. His (man) heart throbbed joyously. A softened feeling came over him (man).

He (man) felt that he (man) had made up his (man) mind. Varenka, who had just crouched down to pick a mushroom, rose with a supple movement and looked round.

Chapter 5

``Varvara Andreevna, when I was very young, I set before myself the ideal of the woman I loved and should be happy to call my wife.

Flinging away the cigar, Sergey Ivanovitch advanced with resolute steps towards her (wife). I have lived through a long life, and now for the first time I have met what I sought--in you.

I love you, and offer you my hand. '' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

Sergey Ivanovitch was saying this to himself while he (Ivanovitch) was ten paces from Varvara.

Kneeling down, with her (wife) hands over the mushrooms to guard them from Grisha, she (wife) was calling little Masha. '' Come here, little ones!

Seeing Sergey Ivanovitch approaching, she (wife) did not get up and did not change her (wife) position, but everything told him (Ivanovitch) that she (wife) felt his (Ivanovitch) presence and was glad of it.

There are so many! '' she (wife) was saying in her (wife) sweet, deep voice. '' Well, did you find some? '' she (wife) asked from under the white kerchief, turning her (wife) handsome, gently smiling face to him (Ivanovitch).

'' Not one,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch. '' Did you? '' She (wife) did not answer, busy with the children who thronged about her (wife). ''

That one too, near the twig,'' she (wife) pointed out to little Masha a little fungus, split in half across its rosy cap by the dry grass from under which it thrust itself.

Varenka got up while Masha picked the fungus, breaking it into two white halves. '' This brings back my childhood,'' she (Masha) added, moving apart from the children beside Sergey Ivanovitch.

They walked on for some steps in silence. Varenka saw that he (Ivanovitch) wanted to speak; she (Masha) guessed of what, and felt faint with joy and panic.

They had walked so far away that no one could hear them now, but still he (Ivanovitch) did not begin to speak.

After a silence it would have been easier for them to say what they wanted to say than after talking about mushrooms.

It would have been better for Varenka to be silent. But against her (Masha) own will, as it were accidentally, Varenka said:

``So you found nothing?

In the middle of the wood there are always fewer, though. '' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)

Sergey Ivanovitch sighed and made no answer. He (Ivanovitch) was annoyed that she (Masha) had spoken about the mushrooms.

He (Ivanovitch) wanted to bring her (Masha) back to the first words she (Masha) had uttered about her (Masha) childhood; but after a pause of some length, as though against his (Ivanovitch) own will, he (Ivanovitch) made an observation in response to her (Masha) last words.

I have heard that the white edible funguses are found principally at the edge of the wood, though I can't tell them apart.

Varenka's heart throbbed so that she (Masha) heard it beating, and felt that she (Masha) was turning red and pale and red again.

To be the wife of a man like Koznishev, after her (wife) position with Madame Stahl, was to her (wife) imagination the height of happiness.

'' '' Some minutes more passed, they moved still further away from the children, and were quite alone. Besides, she (wife) was almost certain that she (wife) was in love with him (Stahl).

And this moment it would have to be decided. She (wife) felt frightened. She (wife) dreaded both his (Stahl) speaking and his (Stahl) not speaking.

Now or never it must be said--that Sergey Ivanovitch felt too. Everything in the expression, the flushed cheeks and the downcast eyes of Varenka betrayed a painful suspense.

Sergey Ivanovitch saw it and felt sorry for her (wife). He (Ivanovitch) felt even that to say nothing now would be a slight to her (wife).

He (Ivanovitch) even said over to himself the words in which he (Ivanovitch) meant to put his (Ivanovitch) offer, but instead of those words, some utterly unexpected reflection that occurred to him (Ivanovitch) made him (Ivanovitch) ask: ``What is the difference between the `birch' mushroom and the `white' mushroom?

Varenka's lips quivered with emotion as she (wife) answered:

``In the top part there is scarcely any difference, it's in the stalk.

And as soon as these words were uttered, both he (Ivanovitch) and she (wife) felt that it was over, that what was to have been said would not be said; and their emotion, which had up to then been continually growing more intense, began to subside.

The birch mushroom's stalk suggests a dark man's chin after two days without shaving,'' (she)

said Sergey Ivanovitch, speaking quite calmly now.

Rapidly in his (Ivanovitch) own mind he (Ivanovitch) ran over all the arguments in support of his (Ivanovitch) decision. '' '' '' '' Yes, that's true,'' answered Varenka smiling, and unconsciously the direction of their walk changed.

They began to turn towards the children. Varenka felt both sore and ashamed; at the same time she (Ivanovitch) had a sense of relief.

When he (Ivanovitch) had got home again and went over the whole subject, Sergey Ivanovitch thought his (Ivanovitch) previous decision had been a mistaken one.

Levin shouted quite angrily to the children, standing before his (Levin) wife to protect her (wife) when the crowd of children flew with shrieks of delight to meet them.

He (Levin) could not be false to the memory of Marie. '' Gently, children, gently!'' Behind the children Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka walked out of the wood.

Kitty had no need to ask Varenka; she (Kitty) saw from the calm and somewhat crestfallen faces of both that her (Kitty) plans had not come off.

It doesn't bite,'' said Kitty, her (Kitty) smile and manner of speaking recalling her (Kitty) father, a likeness Levin often noticed with pleasure.

``I'll show you,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said, taking her (Kitty) husband's hand, lifting it to her (Kitty) mouth, and just faintly brushing it with closed lips.

'' Well?'' her (Kitty) husband questioned her (Kitty) as they were going home again. '' '' How doesn't bite?'' '' Like a kiss on a priest's hand.

''

``Which didn't it bite with? '' (he)
he (priest) said, laughing. '' Both. But it should have been like this...'' '' There are some peasants coming...''

Chapter 6 During the time of the children's tea the grown-up people sat in the balcony and talked as though nothing had happened, though they all, especially Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka, were very well aware that there had happened an event which, though negative, was of very great importance.

They both had the same feeling, rather like that of a schoolboy after an examination, which has left him (schoolboy) in the same class or shut him (schoolboy) out of the school forever.

'' Oh, they didn't see. '' Everyone present, feeling too that something had happened, talked eagerly about extraneous subjects. Levin and Kitty were particularly happy and conscious of their love that evening.

And their happiness in their love seemed to imply a disagreeable slur on those who would have liked to feel the same and could not--and they felt a prick of conscience.

That evening they were expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch to come down by train, and the old prince had written that possibly he (prince) might come too.

And I know why,'' the princess went on;

``he (prince) says that young people ought to be left alone for a while at first.

'' (the princess)

Mark my words, Alexander will not come,'' said the old princess. '' '' '' But papa has left us alone.

We've never seen him (papa),'' said Kitty. '' Besides, we're not young people!--we're old, married people by now. '' '' Only if he (papa) doesn't come, I shall say

good-bye to you children,'' said the princess, sighing mournfully. '' What nonsense, mamma! '' both the daughters fell upon her (princess) at once.

'' How do you suppose he (papa) is feeling? Why, now... '' And suddenly there was an unexpected quiver in the princess's voice.

Her (princess) daughters were silent, and looked at one another. '' Maman always finds something to be miserable about,'' they said in that glance.

They did not know that happy as the princess was in her (princess) daughter's house, and useful as she (princess) felt herself to be there, she (princess) had been extremely miserable, both on her (princess) own account and her (princess) husband's, ever since they had married their last and favorite daughter, and the old home had been left empty.

'' What is it, Agafea Mihalovna?'' Kitty asked suddenly of Agafea Mihalovna, who was standing with a mysterious air, and a face full of meaning.

Well, that's right,'' said Dolly;

``you go and arrange about it, and I'll go and hear Grisha repeat his (husband) lesson, or else he (husband) will have nothing done all day.

Grisha, who was by now at a high school, had to go over the lessons of the term in the summer holidays.

Darya Alexandrovna, who had been studying Latin with her (Dolly) son in Moscow before, had made it a rule on coming to the Levins' to go over with him (son), at least once a day, the most difficult lessons of Latin and arithmetic.

Levin had offered to take her (Dolly) place, but the mother, having once overheard Levin's lesson, and noticing that it was not given exactly as the teacher in Moscow had given it, said resolutely, though with much embarrassment and anxiety not to mortify Levin, that they must keep strictly to the book as the teacher had done, and that she (Dolly) had better undertake it again herself.

Levin was amazed both at Stepan Arkadyevitch, who, by neglecting his (Levin) duty, threw upon the mother the supervision of studies of which she (mother) had no comprehension, and at the teachers for teaching the children so badly.

'' (Dolly)

About supper.'' '' '' '' That's my lesson! No, Dolly, I'm going,'' said Levin, jumping up. But he (Levin) promised his (Levin) sister-in-law to give the lessons exactly as she (sister-in-law) wished.

And he (Levin) went on teaching Grisha, not in his (Levin) own way, but by the book, and so took little interest in it, and often forgot the hour of the lesson.

So it had been today. '' No, I'm going, Dolly, you sit still,'' he (Levin) said. '' We'll do it all properly, like the book.

Only when Stiva comes, and we go out shooting, then we shall have to miss it. '' And Levin went to Grisha.

Varenka was saying the same thing to Kitty. Even in the happy, well-ordered household of the Levins Varenka had succeeded in making herself useful.

'' I'll see to the supper, you sit still,'' she (Kitty) said, and got up to go to Agafea Mihalovna. '' Yes, yes, most likely they've not been able to get chickens.

If so, ours...''

``Agafea Mihalovna and I will see about it,'' (Varenka/Mademoiselle Varenka/Mademoiselle)
and Varenka vanished with her (Kitty). '' What a nice girl!'' said the princess.

'' Not nice, maman ; she (princess)'s an exquisite girl; there's no one else like her (princess).'' '' So you are expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch today?'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, evidently not disposed to pursue the conversation about Varenka.

One all movement, only living in society, like a fish in water; the other our Kostya, lively, alert, quick in everything, but as soon as he (Ivanovitch) is in society, he (Ivanovitch) either sinks into apathy, or struggles helplessly like a fish on land.''

'' It would be difficult to find two sons-in-law more unlike than yours,'' he (Ivanovitch) said with a subtle smile. ''

``Yes, he (Ivanovitch)'s very heedless,'' (the princess)
said the princess, addressing Sergey Ivanovitch.

I've been meaning, indeed, to ask you to tell him (Ivanovitch) that it's out of the question for her (princess)'' -LRB-she (princess) indicated Kitty-RRB-

``to stay here; that she (princess) positively must come to Moscow.

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

'' He (Ivanovitch) talks of getting a doctor down... In the middle of their conversation they heard the snorting of horses and the sound of wheels on the gravel.

Dolly had not time to get up to go and meet her (Dolly) husband, when from the window of the room below, where Grisha was having his (husband) lesson, Levin leaped out and helped Grisha out after him (Levin).

'' It's Stiva!'' Levin shouted from under the balcony. '' We've finished, Dolly, don't be afraid! '' he (Levin) added, and started running like a boy to meet the carriage.

'' Is ea id, ejus, ejus, ejus! '' shouted Grisha, skipping along the avenue. '' And some one else too! Papa, of course!

'' cried Levin, stopping at the entrance of the avenue. '' Kitty, don't come down the steep staircase, go round. ''

As he (Levin) got nearer to the carriage he (Levin) saw beside Stepan Arkadyevitch not the prince but a handsome, stout young man in a Scotch cap, with long ends of ribbon behind.

But Levin had been mistaken in taking the person sitting in the carriage for the old prince. This was Vassenka Veslovsky, a distant cousin of the Shtcherbatskys, a brilliant young gentleman in Petersburg and Moscow society.

Not a whit abashed by the disappointment caused by his (gentleman) having come in place of the old prince, Veslovsky greeted Levin gaily, claiming acquaintance with him (Levin) in the past, and snatching up Grisha into the carriage, lifted him (Levin) over the pointer that Stepan Arkadyevitch had brought with him (Levin).

'' A capital fellow, and a keen sportsman,'' as Stepan Arkadyevitch said, introducing him (fellow). Levin did not get into the carriage, but walked behind.

He (Levin) was rather vexed at the non-arrival of the old prince, whom he (prince) liked more and more the more he (prince) saw of him (prince), and also at the arrival of this Vassenka Veslovsky, a quite uncongenial and superfluous person.

He (prince) seemed to him (prince) still more uncongenial and superfluous when, on approaching the steps where the whole party, children and grown-up, were gathered together in much excitement, Levin saw Vassenka Veslovsky, with a particularly warm and gallant air, kissing Kitty's hand.

Your wife and I are cousins and very old friends,'' said Vassenka Veslovsky, once more shaking Levin's hand with great warmth.

'' '' Well, are there plenty of birds? '' Stepan Arkadyevitch said to Levin, hardly leaving time for everyone to utter their greetings.

'' We've come with the most savage intentions. Why, maman, they've not been in Moscow since! Look, Tanya, here's something for you!

How pretty you've grown, Dolly,'' he (Levin) said to his (Levin) wife, once more kissing her (Dolly) hand, holding it in one of his (Levin), and patting it with the other.

Levin, who a minute before had been in the happiest frame of mind, now looked darkly at everyone, and everything displeased him (Levin).

Get it, please, it's in the carriage, behind! '' he (Levin) talked in all directions. '' '' Who was it he (Levin) kissed yesterday with those lips?

'' he (Levin) thought, looking at Stepan Arkadyevitch's tender demonstrations to his (Levin) wife. He (Levin) looked at Dolly, and he (Levin) did not like her (Dolly) either.

He (Levin) looked at the princess, who had been so dear to him (Levin) a minute before, and he (Levin) did not like the manner in which she (Dolly) welcomed this Vassenka, with his (Levin) ribbons, just as though she (Dolly) were in her (Dolly) own house.

Even Sergey Ivanovitch, who had come out too onto the steps, seemed to him (Ivanovitch) unpleasant with the show of cordiality with which he (Ivanovitch) met Stepan Arkadyevitch, though Levin knew that his (Levin) brother neither liked nor respected Oblonsky.

And Varenka, even she (Dolly) seemed hateful, with her (Dolly) air sainte nitouche making the acquaintance of this gentleman, while all the while she (Dolly) was thinking of nothing but getting married.

And more hateful than anyone was Kitty for falling in with the tone of gaiety with which this gentleman regarded his (gentleman) visit in the country, as though it were a holiday for himself and everyone else.

'' She (Kitty) doesn't believe in his (gentleman) love. So what is she (Kitty) so pleased about? Revolting! '' thought Levin. And, above all, unpleasant was that particular smile with which she (Kitty) responded to his (Levin) smile.

Noisily talking, they all went into the house; but as soon as they were all seated, Levin turned and went out.

She (Kitty) tried to seize a moment to speak to him (Levin) alone, but he (Levin) made haste to get away from her (Kitty), saying he (Levin) was wanted at the counting-house.

Kitty saw something was wrong with her (Kitty) husband. It was long since his (Levin) own work on the estate had seemed to him (Levin) so important as at that moment.

It's all holiday for them,'' he (Levin) thought;

``but these are no holiday matters, they won't wait, and there's no living without them.

'' (he)

'' Chapter 7 Levin came back to the house only when they sent to summon him (Levin) to supper. On the stairs were standing Kitty and Agafea Mihalovna, consulting about wines for supper.

'' But why are you making all this fuss? Have what we usually do. '' '' No, Stiva doesn't drink... Kostya, stop, what's the matter?

Kitty began, hurrying after him (Kostya), but he (Kostya) strode ruthlessly away to the dining room without waiting for her (Kitty), and at once joined in the lively general conversation which was being maintained there by Vassenka Veslovsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Please, do let's go,'' said Veslovsky, moving to another chair, where he (Kostya) sat down sideways, with one fat leg crossed under him (Kostya).

'' '' Well, what do you say, are we going shooting tomorrow?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' '' I shall be delighted, we will go.

'' said Levin to Veslovsky, looking intently at his (Levin) leg, but speaking with that forced amiability that Kitty knew so well in him (Levin), and that was so out of keeping with him (Levin).

And have you had any shooting yet this year? '' I can't answer for our finding grouse, but there are plenty of snipe.

Only we ought to start early. You're not tired? Aren't you tired, Stiva?'' '' Me tired? I've never been tired yet.

Suppose we stay up all night. Let's go for a walk!''

``Yes, really, let's not go to bed at all! Capital!'' (people)

Oh, we all know you can do without sleep, and keep other people up too,'' Dolly said to her (Dolly) husband, with that faint note of irony in her (Dolly) voice which she (Dolly) almost always had now with her (Dolly) husband.

Veslovsky chimed in. '' '' But to my thinking, it's time for bed now.... I'm going, I don't want supper. ''

No, do stay a little, Dolly,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, going round to her (Dolly) side behind the table where they were having supper.

'' '' I've so much still to tell you.'' '' Nothing really, I suppose. ''

``Do you know Veslovsky has been at Anna's, and he (husband)'s going to them again?

You know they're hardly fifty miles from you, and I too must certainly go over there. Veslovsky, come here!'' (Veslovsky/Vassenka Veslovsky/Vassenka)

Vassenka crossed over to the ladies, and sat down beside Kitty.

Levin was left at the other end of the table, and though never pausing in his (Levin) conversation with the princess and Varenka, he (Levin) saw that there was an eager and mysterious conversation going on between Stepan Arkadyevitch, Dolly, Kitty, and Veslovsky.

'' Ah, do tell me, please; you have stayed with her (Kitty)? How was she (Kitty)?'' Darya Alexandrovna appealed to him (Levin). And that was not all.

He (Levin) saw on his (Levin) wife's face an expression of real feeling as she (wife) gazed with fixed eyes on the handsome face of Vassenka, who was telling them something with great animation.

I can't, of course, take it upon myself to judge, but in their house you feel the real feeling of home.''

'' It's exceedingly nice at their place,'' Veslovsky was telling them about Vronsky and Anna. '' '' What do they intend doing?''

``I believe they think of going to Moscow. '' (unknown)

When are you going there? '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
