She (Dolly)'s a splendid woman. I will go alone, when you go back, and then I shall be in no one's way.

And it will be better indeed without you. '' '' To be sure,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' And you, Kitty? ''

``I? Why should I go?'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Kitty said, flushing all over, and she (Kitty) glanced round at her (Kitty) husband. '' Do you know Anna Arkadyevna, then?''

Veslovsky asked her (Kitty). '' She (Kitty)'s a very fascinating woman. '' '' Yes,'' she (Kitty) answered Veslovsky, crimsoning still more. She (Kitty) got up and walked across to her (Kitty) husband.

His (husband) jealousy had in these few moments, especially at the flush that had overspread her (Kitty) cheeks while she (Kitty) was talking to Veslovsky, gone far indeed.

'' Are you going shooting, then, tomorrow? '' she (Kitty) said. Now as he (husband) heard her (Kitty) words, he (husband) construed them in his (husband) own fashion.

Strange as it was to him (husband) afterwards to recall it, it seemed to him (husband) at the moment clear that in asking whether he (husband) was going shooting, all she (Kitty) cared to know was whether he (husband) would give that pleasure to Vassenka Veslovsky, with whom, as he (husband) fancied, she (Kitty) was in love.

No, better spend the day here tomorrow, or Dolly won't see anything of her (Dolly) husband, and set off the day after,'' said Kitty.

'' Yes, I'm going,'' he (husband) answered her (Kitty) in an unnatural voice, disagreeable to himself. '' The motive of Kitty's words was interpreted by Levin thus:

``Don't separate me from him (Levin) . I don't care about your going, but do let me enjoy the society of this delightful young man.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Vassenka meanwhile, utterly unsuspecting the misery his (man) presence had occasioned, got up from the table after Kitty, and watching her (Kitty) with smiling and admiring eyes, he (man) followed her (Kitty).

'' Oh, if you wish, we'll stay here tomorrow,'' Levin answered, with peculiar amiability. Levin saw that look. He (Levin) turned white, and for a minute he (Levin) could hardly breathe.

'' How dare he (Levin) look at my wife like that! '' was the feeling that boiled within him (Levin). '' Tomorrow, then?

Do, please, let us go,'' said Vassenka, sitting down on a chair, and again crossing his (Levin) leg as his (Levin) habit was.

Already he (Levin) saw himself a deceived husband, looked upon by his (Levin) wife and her (wife) lover as simply necessary to provide them with the conveniences and pleasures of life....

But in spite of that he (Levin) made polite and hospitable inquiries of Vassenka about his (Levin) shooting, his (Levin) gun, and his (Levin) boots, and agreed to go shooting next day.

Happily for Levin, the old princess cut short his (Levin) agonies by getting up herself and advising Kitty to go to bed.

As he (Levin) said good-night to his (Levin) hostess, Vassenka would again have kissed her (hostess) hand, but Kitty, reddening, drew back her (Kitty) hand and said with a na√Øve bluntness, for which the old princess scolded her (princess) afterwards:

``We don't like that fashion.

In Levin's eyes she (princess) was to blame for having allowed such relations to arise, and still more to blame for showing so awkwardly that she (princess) did not like them.

Why, how can one want to go to bed!'' (the princess)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, who, after drinking several glasses of wine at supper, was now in his (Levin) most charming and sentimental humor.

Levin's jealousy went further still. But even at this point Levin could not escape another agony. '' '' '' Look, Kitty,'' he (Levin) said, pointing to the moon, which had just risen behind the lime trees --

``how exquisite!

Veslovsky, this is the time for a serenade. You know, he (Levin) has a splendid voice; we practiced songs together along the road.

When the party had broken up, Stepan Arkadyevitch walked a long while about the avenue with Veslovsky; their voices could be heard singing one of the new songs.

Levin hearing these voices sat scowling in an easy-chair in his (Levin) wife's bedroom, and maintained an obstinate silence when she (wife) asked him (Levin) what was wrong.

He (Levin) has brought some lovely songs with him (Levin), two new ones. Varvara Andreevna and he (Levin) must sing some duets. '' (he)

But when at last with a timid glance she (wife) hazarded the question:
``Was there perhaps something you disliked about Veslovsky?'' (she)
--it

all burst out, and he (Levin) told her (wife) all. He (Levin) was humiliated himself at what he (Levin) was saying, and that exasperated him (Levin) all the more.

He (Levin) stood facing her (wife) with his (Levin) eyes glittering menacingly under his (Levin) scowling brows, and he (Levin) squeezed his (Levin) strong arms across his (Levin) chest, as though he (Levin) were straining every nerve to hold himself in.

The expression of his (Levin) face would have been grim, and even cruel, if it had not at the same time had a look of suffering which touched her (wife).

His (Levin) jaws were twitching, and his (Levin) voice kept breaking. '' You must understand that I'm not jealous, that's a nasty word.

I'm not jealous, but I'm wounded, humiliated that anybody dare think, that anybody dare look at you with eyes like that.''

I can't be jealous, and believe that.... I can't say what I feel, but this is awful... '' Eyes like what?

'' said Kitty, trying as conscientiously as possible to recall every word and gesture of that evening and every shade implied in them.

At the very bottom of her (Kitty) heart she (Kitty) did think there had been something precisely at the moment when he (anybody) had crossed over after her (Kitty) to the other end of the table; but she (Kitty) dared not own it even to herself, and would have been even more unable to bring herself to say so to him (anybody), and so increase his (anybody) suffering.

'' And what can there possibly be attractive about me as I am now?...''

``Ah!'' (he)
he (anybody) cried, clutching at his (anybody) head,
``you shouldn't say that!...

If you had been attractive then...'' (he)

'' Oh, no, Kostya, oh, wait a minute, oh, do listen! '' she (Kitty) said, looking at him (Kostya) with an expression of pained commiseration.

'' Why, what can you be thinking about! When for me there's no one in the world, no one, no one!

For the first minute she (Kitty) had been offended at his (Kostya) jealousy; she (Kitty) was angry that the slightest amusement, even the most innocent, should be forbidden her (Kitty); but now she (Kitty) would readily have sacrificed, not merely such trifles, but everything, for his (Kostya) peace of mind, to save him (Kostya) from the agony he (Kostya) was suffering.

You must understand the horror and comedy of my position,'' he (Kostya) went on in a desperate whisper;

``that he (Kostya)'s in my house, that he (Kostya)'s done nothing improper positively except his (Kostya) free and easy airs and the way he (Kostya) sits on his (Kostya) legs.

... Would you like me never to see anyone? '' (he)

'' He (Kostya) thinks it's the best possible form, and so I'm obliged to be civil to him (Kostya).''

But, Kostya, you're exaggerating,'' said Kitty, at the bottom of her (Kitty) heart rejoicing at the depth of his (Kostya) love for her (Kitty), shown now in his (Kostya) jealousy.

The most awful part of it all is that you're just as you always are, and especially now when to me you're something sacred, and we're so happy, so particularly happy--and all of a sudden a little wretch...

'' '' He (Kostya)'s not a little wretch; why should I abuse him (Kostya)? I have nothing to do with him (Kostya). But why should my, and your, happiness...''

``Do you know, I understand now what it's all come from,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)
Kitty was beginning. '' Well, what? what?''
``I saw how you looked while we were talking at supper.

'' (unknown)

'' Well, well! '' Levin said in dismay. She (Kitty) told him (Levin) what they had been talking about. And as she (Kitty) told him (Levin), she (Kitty) was breathless with emotion.

Levin was silent for a space, then he (Levin) scanned her (Kitty) pale and distressed face, and suddenly he (Levin) clutched at his (Levin) head.

'' Katya, I've been worrying you! Darling, forgive me! It's madness! Katya, I'm a criminal. And how could you be so distressed at such idiocy?''

'' Oh, I was sorry for you.''

``For me? for me? How mad I am! ... But why make you miserable?

It's awful to think that any outsider can shatter our happiness.'' (unknown)

'' It's humiliating too, of course.'' '' Oh, then I'll keep him (outsider) here all the summer, and will overwhelm him (outsider) with civility,'' said Levin, kissing her (Katya) hands.

Next day, before the ladies were up, the wagonette and a trap for the shooting party were at the door, and Laska, aware since early morning that they were going shooting, after much whining and darting to and fro, had sat herself down in the wagonette beside the coachman, and, disapproving of the delay, was excitedly watching the door from which the sportsmen still did not come out.

The first to come out was Vassenka Veslovsky, in new high boots that reached half-way up his (Laska) thick thighs, in a green blouse, with a new Russian leather cartridge-belt, and in his (Laska) Scotch cap with ribbons, with a brand-new English gun without a sling.

Laska flew up to him (Laska), welcomed him (Laska), and jumping up, asked him (Laska) in her (Laska) own way whether the others were coming soon, but getting no answer from him (Laska)

, she (Laska) returned to her (Laska) post of observation and sank into repose again, her (Laska) head on one side, and one ear pricked up to listen.

At last the door opened with a creak, and Stepan Arkadyevitch's spot-and-tan pointer Krak flew out, running round and round and turning over in the air.

'' You shall see. Tomorrow.... Oh, yes, we are going tomorrow. '' Chapter 8 Stepan Arkadyevitch himself followed with a gun in his (Laska) hand and a cigar in his (Laska) mouth.

'' Good dog, good dog, Krak! '' he (Laska) cried encouragingly to the dog, who put his (Laska) paws up on his (Laska) chest, catching at his (Laska) game bag.

On his (Laska) head there was a wreck of a hat of indefinite form, but his (Laska) gun of a new patent was a perfect gem, and his (Laska) game bag and cartridge belt, though worn, were of the very best quality.

Vassenka Veslovsky had had no notion before that it was truly chic for a sportsman to be in tatters, but to have his (sportsman) shooting outfit of the best quality.

He (sportsman) saw it now as he (sportsman) looked at Stepan Arkadyevitch, radiant in his (sportsman) rags, graceful, well-fed, and joyous, a typical Russian nobleman.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was dressed in rough leggings and spats, in torn trousers and a short coat. And he (sportsman) made up his (sportsman) mind that next time he (sportsman) went shooting he (sportsman) would certainly adopt the same get-up.

'' Well, and what about our host? '' he (sportsman) asked. '' A young wife,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling. '' Yes, and such a charming one!''

Levin had run up again to his (Levin) wife to ask her (wife) once more if she (wife) forgave him (Levin) for his (Levin) idiocy yesterday, and, moreover, to beg her (wife) for Christ's sake to be more careful.

'' He (Christ) came down dressed. No doubt he (Christ)'s run up to her (wife) again. '' Stepan Arkadyevitch guessed right. The great thing was for her (wife) to keep away from the children

Then he (Christ) had once more to hear her (wife) declare that she (wife) was not angry with him (Christ) for going away for two days, and to beg her (wife) to be sure to send him (Christ) a note next morning by a servant on horseback, to write him (servant), if it were but two words only, to let him (servant) know that all was well with her (wife).

Kitty was distressed, as she (Kitty) always was, at parting for a couple of days from her (Kitty) husband, but when she (Kitty) saw his (husband) eager figure, looking big and strong in his (husband) shooting-boots and his (husband) white blouse, and a sort of sportsman elation and excitement incomprehensible to her (Kitty), she (Kitty) forgot her (Kitty) own chagrin for the sake of his (husband) pleasure, and said good-bye to him (husband) cheerfully.

--they might any minute push against her (Kitty). '' Pardon, gentlemen! '' he (husband) said, running out onto the steps. '' Have you put the lunch in?

``Put it with the herd of oxen,'' (he)
he (husband) said to the herdsman, who was waiting for him (husband) at the steps with some question.

Why is the chestnut on the right? Well, it doesn't matter. Laska, down; go and lie down!'' '' Excuse me, here comes another villain.

Levin jumped out of the wagonette, in which he (Levin) had already taken his (Levin) seat, to meet the carpenter, who came towards the steps with a rule in his (Levin) hand.

'' '' You didn't come to the counting house yesterday, and now you're detaining me. Well, what is it?''

``Would your honor let me make another turning?

It's only three steps to add. And we make it just fit at the same time. It will be much more convenient.

'' (unknown)

``You should have listened to me,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin answered with annoyance. '' I said: Put the lines and then fit in the steps.

The point was that in the lodge that was being built the carpenter had spoiled the staircase, fitting it together without calculating the space it was to fill, so that the steps were all sloping when it was put in place.

Now there's no setting it right. Do as I told you, and make a new staircase. '' Now the carpenter wanted, keeping the same staircase, to add three steps.

'' It will be much better.'' '' But where's your staircase coming out with its three steps? ''

``Why, upon my word, sir,'' (the carpenter)
the carpenter said with a contemptuous smile.

'' It comes out right at the very spot. It starts, so to speak,'' he (carpenter) said, with a persuasive gesture;

``it comes down, and comes down, and comes out.'' (he)

``Why, to be sure, it'll start from the bottom and go up and go up, and come out so,'' (the carpenter)
the carpenter said obstinately and convincingly.

'' But three steps will add to the length too... where is it to come out? '' '' It'll reach the ceiling and the wall.''

``Upon my word! Why, it'll go up, and up, and come out like this. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin took out a ramrod and began sketching him (Levin) the staircase in the dust.

'' There, do you see?''

``As your honor likes,'' (the carpenter)
said the carpenter, with a sudden gleam in his (carpenter) eyes, obviously understanding the thing at last.

'' It seems it'll be best to make a new one.'' '' Well, then, do it as you're told,'' Levin shouted, seating himself in the wagonette.

Levin felt now at leaving behind all his (Levin) family and household cares such an eager sense of joy in life and expectation that he (Levin) was not disposed to talk.

'' Down! Hold the dogs, Philip!'' Besides that, he (Philip) had that feeling of concentrated excitement that every sportsman experiences as he (sportsman) approaches the scene of action.

If he (sportsman) had anything on his (sportsman) mind at that moment, it was only the doubt whether they would start anything in the Kolpensky marsh, whether Laska would show to advantage in comparison with Krak, and whether he (Laska) would shoot well that day himself.

Not to disgrace himself before a new spectator--not to be outdone by Oblonsky--that too was a thought that crossed his (spectator) brain.

Oblonsky was feeling the same, and he (spectator) too was not talkative. Vassenka Veslovsky kept up alone a ceaseless flow of cheerful chatter.

As he (spectator) listened to him (spectator) now, Levin felt ashamed to think how unfair he (Levin) had been to him (Levin) the day before.

Vassenka was really a nice fellow, simple, good-hearted, and very good-humored. If Levin had met him (Levin) before he (Levin) was married, he (Levin) would have made friends with him (Levin).

It was as though he (Levin) assumed a high degree of importance in himself that could not be disputed, because he (Levin) had long nails and a stylish cap, and everything else to correspond; but this could be forgiven for the sake of his (Levin) good nature and good breeding.

Levin liked him (Levin) for his (Levin) good education, for speaking French and English with such an excellent accent, and for being a man of his (man) world.

Levin rather disliked his (Levin) holiday attitude to life and a sort of free and easy assumption of elegance. Vassenka was extremely delighted with the left horse, a horse of the Don Steppes.

He (Don) kept praising him (Don) enthusiastically. '' How fine it must be galloping over the steppes on a steppe horse! Eh? isn't it?

He (Don) had imagined riding on a steppe horse as something wild and romantic, and it turned out nothing of the sort.

But his (Don) simplicity, particularly in conjunction with his (Don) good looks, his (Don) amiable smile, and the grace of his (Don) movements, was very attractive.

Either because his (Don) nature was sympathetic to Levin, or because Levin was trying to atone for his (Levin) sins of the previous evening by seeing nothing

After they had driven over two miles from home, Veslovsky all at once felt for a cigar and his (Levin) pocketbook, and did not know whether he (Levin) had lost them or left them on the table.

'' he (Levin) said. but what was good in him (Levin), anyway he (Levin) liked his (Levin) society. In the pocketbook there were thirty-seven pounds, and so the matter could not be left in uncertainty.

'' Do you know what, Levin, I'll gallop home on that left trace-horse. That will be splendid. Eh? '' he (Levin) said, preparing to get out.

'' No, why should you?'' answered Levin, calculating that Vassenka could hardly weigh less than seventeen stone. '' I'll send the coachman.

'' The coachman rode back on the trace-horse, and Levin himself drove the remaining pair. Chapter 9 '' Well, now what's our plan of campaign?

In Gvozdyov there's a grouse marsh on this side, and beyond Gvozdyov come some magnificent snipe marshes where there are grouse too.

Tell us all about it,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Our plan is this. Now we're driving to Gvozdyov. It's hot now, and we'll get there

--it's fifteen miles or so--towards evening and have some evening shooting; we'll spend the night there and go on tomorrow to the bigger moors.''

'' And is there nothing on the way?'' '' Yes; but we'll reserve ourselves; besides it's hot. There are two nice little places, but I doubt there being anything to shoot.

Levin would himself have liked to go into these little places, but they were near home; he (Levin) could shoot them over any time, and they were only little places--there would hardly be room for three to shoot.

When they reached a little marsh Levin would have driven by, but Stepan Arkadyevitch, with the experienced eye of a sportsman, at once detected reeds visible from the road.

'' And so, with some insincerity, he (Levin) said that he (Levin) doubted there being anything to shoot. '' Shan't we try that?

'' he (Levin) said, pointing to the little marsh. '' Levin, do, please! how delightful!'' Vassenka Veslovsky began begging, and Levin could but consent.

Before they had time to stop, the dogs had flown one before the other into the marsh. '' Krak! Laska!... ''

I'll stay here,'' said Levin, hoping they would find nothing but peewits, who had been startled by the dogs, and turning over in their flight, were plaintively wailing over the marsh.

The dogs came back. '' There won't be room for three. '' No! Come along, Levin, let's go together!'' Veslovsky called.

'' Really, there's not room. Laska, back, Laska! You won't want another dog, will you?'' Levin remained with the wagonette, and looked enviously at the sportsmen.

They walked right across the marsh. Except little birds and peewits, of which Vassenka killed one, there was nothing in the marsh.

'' Come, you see now that it was not that I grudged the marsh,'' said Levin,

``only it's wasting time. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Did you see us?'' said Vassenka Veslovsky, clambering awkwardly into the wagonette with his (Levin) gun and his (Levin) peewit in his (Levin) hands.

'' Oh, no, it was jolly all the same. '' How splendidly I shot this bird! Didn't I? Well, shall we soon be getting to the real place?

The horses started off suddenly, Levin knocked his (Levin) head against the stock of someone's gun, and there was the report of a shot.

'' The gun did actually go off first, but that was how it seemed to Levin. It appeared that Vassenka Veslovsky had pulled only one trigger, and had left the other hammer still cocked.

The charge flew into the ground without doing harm to anyone. Stepan Arkadyevitch shook his (Levin) head and laughed reprovingly at Veslovsky.

In the first place, any reproach would have seemed to be called forth by the danger he (Levin) had incurred and the bump that had come up on Levin's forehead.

And besides, Veslovsky was at first so na√Øvely distressed, and then laughed so good-humoredly and infectiously at their general dismay, that one could not but laugh with him (Levin).

When they reached the second marsh, which was fairly large, and would inevitably take some time to shoot over, Levin tried to persuade them to pass it by.

But Levin had not the heart to reprove him (Levin). But Veslovsky again overpersuaded him (Levin). Again, as the marsh was narrow, Levin, like a good host, remained with the carriage.

Krak made straight for some clumps of sedge. Vassenka Veslovsky was the first to run after the dog. Before Stepan Arkadyevitch had time to come up, a grouse flew out.

Veslovsky missed it and it flew into an unmown meadow. This grouse was left for Veslovsky to follow up. Krak found it again and pointed, and Veslovsky shot it and went back to the carriage.

'' Now you go and I'll stay with the horses,'' he (Levin) said. Levin had begun to feel the pangs of a sportsman's envy.

Laska, who had been plaintively whining and fretting against the injustice of her (it) treatment, flew straight ahead to a hopeful place that Levin knew well, and that Krak had not yet come upon.

He (Levin) handed the reins to Veslovsky and walked into the marsh. '' Why don't you stop her (it)?'' shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch. ''

She (it) won't scare them,'' answered Levin, sympathizing with his (Levin) bitch's pleasure and hurrying after her (it). As she (it) came nearer and nearer to the familiar breeding places there was more and more earnestness in Laska's exploration.

She (it) made one circuit round the clump of reeds, was beginning a second, and suddenly quivered with excitement and became motionless.

'' shouted Levin, feeling his (Levin) heart beginning to beat more violently; and all of a sudden, as though some sort of shutter had been drawn back from his (Levin) straining ears, all sounds, confused but loud, began to beat on his (Levin) hearing, losing all sense of distance.

He (Levin) heard the steps of Stepan Arkadyevitch, mistaking them for the tramp of the horses in the distance; he (Levin) heard the brittle sound of the twigs on which he (Levin) had trodden, taking this sound for the flying of a grouse.

A little marsh bird did not divert her (Arkadyevitch) attention for more than an instant. ``Come, come, Stiva! He (Levin) heard too, not far behind him (Levin), a splashing in the water, which he (Levin) could not explain to himself.

Picking his (Levin) steps, he (Levin) moved up to the dog.

``Fetch it!'' (the dog)
Not a grouse but a snipe flew up from beside the dog.

Levin had lifted his (Levin) gun, but at the very instant when he (Levin) was taking aim, the sound of splashing grew louder, came closer, and was joined with the sound of Veslovsky's voice, shouting something with strange loudness.

When he (Levin) had made sure he (Levin) had missed, Levin looked round and saw the horses and the wagonette not on the road but in the marsh.

Levin saw he (Levin) had his (Levin) gun pointed behind the snipe, but still he (Levin) fired. Veslovsky, eager to see the shooting, had driven into the marsh, and got the horses stuck in the mud.

'' Damn the fellow!'' Levin said to himself, as he (Levin) went back to the carriage that had sunk in the mire.

'' What did you drive in for? '' he (Levin) said to him (Levin) dryly, and calling the coachman, he (Levin) began pulling the horses out.

Levin was vexed both at being hindered from shooting and at his (Levin) horses getting stuck in the mud, and still more at the fact that neither Stepan Arkadyevitch nor Veslovsky helped him (Levin) and the coachman to unharness the horses and get them out, since neither of them had the slightest notion of harnessing.

Without vouchsafing a syllable in reply to Vassenka's protestations that it had been quite dry there, Levin worked in silence with the coachman at extricating the horses.

But then, as he (Levin) got warm at the work and saw how assiduously Veslovsky was tugging at the wagonette by one of the mud-guards, so that he (Levin) broke it indeed, Levin blamed himself for having under the influence of yesterday's feelings been too cold to Veslovsky, and tried to be particularly genial so as to smooth over his (Levin) chilliness.

When everything had been put right, and the carriage had been brought back to the road, Levin had the lunch served.

Ce poulet va tomber jusqu'au fond de mes bottes ,'' Vassenka, who had recovered his (Levin) spirits, quoted the French saying as he (Levin) finished his (Levin) second chicken.

'' Bon app√©tit--bonne conscience! '' Well, now our troubles are over, now everything's going to go well. Only, to atone for my sins, I'm bound to sit on the box.

You shall see how I'll get you along,'' he (Levin) answered, not letting go the rein, when Levin begged him (Levin) to let the coachman drive.

That's so? eh? No, no! I'll be your Automedon. '' No, I must atone for my sins, and I'm very comfortable on the box.

Levin was a little afraid he (Levin) would exhaust the horses, especially the chestnut, whom he (Levin) did not know how to hold in; but unconsciously he (Levin) fell under the influence of his (Levin) gaiety and listened to the songs he (Levin) sang all the way on the box, or the descriptions and representations he (Levin) gave of driving in the English fashion, four-in-hand; and it was in the very best of spirits that after lunch they drove to the Gvozdyov marsh.

'' And he (Levin) drove. Chapter 10 Vassenka drove the horses so smartly that they reached the marsh too early, while it was still hot.

As they drew near this more important marsh, the chief aim of their expedition, Levin could not help considering how he (Levin) could get rid of Vassenka and be free in his (Levin) movements.

Stepan Arkadyevitch evidently had the same desire, and on his (Levin) face Levin saw the look of anxiety always present in a true sportsman when beginning shooting, together with a certain good-humored slyness peculiar to him (Levin).

It's a splendid marsh, I see, and there are hawks,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing to two great birds hovering over the reeds.

``Now, gentlemen,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, pulling up his (Levin) boots and examining the lock of his (Levin) gun with rather a gloomy expression,
``do you see those reeds?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

He (Levin) pointed to an oasis of blackish green in the huge half-mown wet meadow that stretched along the right bank of the river.

'' How shall we go? '' Where there are hawks, there is sure to be game.'' '' The marsh begins here, straight in front of us, do you see--where it is greener?

From here it runs to the right where the horses are; there are breeding places there, and grouse, and all round those reeds as far as that alder, and right up to the mill.

Over there, do you see, where the pools are? That's the best place. There I once shot seventeen snipe. We'll separate with the dogs and go in different directions, and then meet over there at the mill.

'' '' Well, which shall go to left and which to right?'' asked Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' It's wider to the right; you two go that way

and I'll take the left,'' he (you) said with apparent carelessness. '' Capital! we'll make the bigger bag! Yes, come along, come along!''

As soon as they entered the marsh, the two dogs began hunting about together and made towards the green, slime-covered pool.

Vassenka exclaimed. Levin could do nothing but agree, and they divided. Levin knew Laska's method, wary and indefinite; he (Levin) knew the place too and expected a whole covey of snipe.

'' Veslovsky, beside me, walk beside me! '' he (Levin) said in a faint voice to his (Levin) companion splashing in the water behind him (Levin).

Levin could not help feeling an interest in the direction his (Levin) gun was pointed, after that casual shot near the Kolpensky marsh.

'' Oh, I won't get in your way, don't trouble about me. '' But Levin could not help troubling, and recalled Kitty's words at parting:

``Mind you don't shoot one another.

The expectation of snipe was so intense that to Levin the squelching sound of his (Levin) own heel, as he (Levin) drew it up out of the mire, seemed to be the call of a snipe, and he (Levin) clutched and pressed the lock of his (Levin) gun.

'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

The dogs came nearer and nearer, passed each other, each pursuing its own scent. '' Bang! bang! '' sounded almost in his (Levin) ear.

Vassenka had fired at a flock of ducks which was hovering over the marsh and flying at that moment towards the sportsmen, far out of range.

Before Levin had time to look round, there was the whir of one snipe, another, a third, and some eight more rose one after another.

Stepan Arkadyevitch hit one at the very moment when it was beginning its zigzag movements, and the snipe fell in a heap into the mud.

Oblonsky aimed deliberately at another, still flying low in the reeds, and together with the report of the shot, that snipe too fell, and it could be seen fluttering out where the sedge had been cut, its unhurt wing showing white beneath.

Levin was not so lucky: he (Levin) aimed at his (Levin) first bird too low, and missed; he (Levin) aimed at it again, just as it was rising, but at that instant another snipe flew up at his (Levin) very feet, distracting him (Levin) so that he (Levin) missed again.

While they were loading their guns, another snipe rose, and Veslovsky, who had had time to load again, sent two charges of small-shot into the water.

Well, now let us separate,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and limping on his (Levin) left foot, holding his (Levin) gun in readiness and whistling to his (Levin) dog, he (Levin) walked off in one direction.

Stepan Arkadyevitch picked up his (Levin) snipe, and with sparkling eyes looked at Levin. '' Levin and Veslovsky walked in the other.

that when his (Levin) first shots were a failure he (Levin) got hot and out of temper, and shot badly the whole day.

They kept flying up from just under the dogs, from under the sportsmen's legs, and Levin might have retrieved his (Levin) ill luck.

But the more he (Levin) shot, the more he (Levin) felt disgraced in the eyes of Veslovsky, who kept popping away merrily and indiscriminately, killing nothing, and not in the slightest abashed by his (Levin) ill success.

Levin, in feverish haste, could not restrain himself, got more and more out of temper, and ended by shooting almost without a hope of hitting.

It always happened with Levin So it was that day. The snipe showed themselves in numbers. Laska, indeed, seemed to understand this.

She (Veslovsky) began looking more languidly, and gazed back at the sportsmen, as it were, with perplexity or reproach in her (Veslovsky) eyes.

The smoke of the powder hung about the sportsmen, while in the great roomy net of the game bag there were only three light little snipe.

Shots followed shots in rapid succession. And of these one had been killed by Veslovsky alone, and one by both of them together.

Meanwhile from the other side of the marsh came the sound of Stepan Arkadyevitch's shots, not frequent, but, as Levin fancied, well-directed, for almost after each they heard

``Krak, Krak, apporte !'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Their whirring wings close to the earth, and their harsh cries high in the air, could be heard on all sides; the snipe that had risen first and flown up into the air, settled again before the sportsmen.

This excited Levin still more. The snipe were floating continually in the air over the reeds. Instead of two hawks there were now dozens of them hovering with shrill cries over the marsh.

After walking through the larger half of the marsh, Levin and Veslovsky reached the place where the peasants' mowing-grass was divided into long strips reaching to the reeds, marked off in one place by the trampled grass, in another by a path mown through it.

Though there was not so much hope of finding birds in the uncut part as the cut part, Levin had promised Stepan Arkadyevitch to meet him (Levin), and so he (Levin) walked on with his (Levin) companion through the cut and uncut patches.

Half of these strips had already been mown. '' Hi, sportsmen! '' shouted one of a group of peasants, sitting on an unharnessed cart;

``come and have some lunch with us!

'' (peasants)

shouted a good-humored-looking bearded peasant with a red face, showing his (peasant) white teeth in a grin, and holding up a greenish bottle that flashed in the sunlight.

Have a drop of wine!'' Levin looked round. '' Come along, it's all right! '' Qu'est-ce qu'ils disent ? '' asked Veslovsky.

I should have some,'' said Levin, not without some guile, hoping Veslovsky would be tempted by the vodka, and would go away to them.

'' They invite you to have some vodka. Most likely they've been dividing the meadow into lots. '' Why do they offer it?''

'' Oh, they're merry-making. Really, you should join them. You would be interested.'' '' Allons, c'est curieux .''

``You go, you go, you'll find the way to the mill!

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

cried Levin, and looking round he (Levin) perceived with satisfaction that Veslovsky, bent and stumbling with weariness, holding his (Levin) gun out at arm's length, was making his (Levin) way out of the marsh towards the peasants.

'' You come too! '' the peasants shouted to Levin. '' Never fear! You taste our cake!'' Levin felt a strong inclination to drink a little vodka and to eat some bread.

He (Levin) was exhausted, and felt it a great effort to drag his (Levin) staggering legs out of the mire, and for a minute he (Levin) hesitated.

But Laska was setting. And immediately all his (Laska) weariness vanished, and he (Laska) walked lightly through the swamp towards the dog. A snipe flew up at his (Laska) feet; he (Laska) fired and killed it.

But it was an unlucky day for him (Laska); he (Laska) missed it, and when he (Laska) went to look for the one he (Laska) had shot, he (Laska) could not find that either.

He (Laska) wandered all about the reeds, but Laska did not believe he (Laska) had shot it, and when he (Laska) sent her (Levin) to find it, she (Levin) pretended to hunt for it, but did not really.

Laska still pointed.--

``Fetch it!'' (the dog)
Another bird flew up close to the dog. Levin fired. And in the absence of Vassenka, on whom Levin threw the blame of his (Levin) failure, things went no better.

The slanting rays of the sun were still hot; his (Levin) clothes, soaked through with perspiration, stuck to his (Levin) body; his (Levin) left boot full of water weighed heavily on his (Levin) leg and squeaked at every step; the sweat ran in drops down his (Levin) powder-grimed face, his (Levin) mouth was full of the bitter taste, his (Levin) nose of the smell of powder and stagnant water, his (Levin) ears were ringing with the incessant whir of the snipe; he (Levin) could not touch the stock of his (Levin) gun, it was so hot; his (Levin) heart beat with short, rapid throbs; his (Levin) hands shook with excitement, and his (Levin) weary legs stumbled and staggered over the hillocks and in the swamp, but still he (Levin) walked on and still he (Levin) shot.

There were plenty of snipe still, but Levin made one miss after another. At last, after a disgraceful miss, he (Levin) flung his (Levin) gun and his (Levin) hat on the ground.

'' No, I must control myself,'' he (Levin) said to himself. Picking up his (Levin) gun and his (Levin) hat, he (Levin) called Laska, and went out of the swamp.

When he (Laska) got on to dry ground he (Laska) sat down, pulled off his (Laska) boot and emptied it, then walked to the marsh, drank some stagnant-tasting water, moistened his (Laska) burning hot gun, and washed his (Laska) face and hands.

Feeling refreshed, he (Laska) went back to the spot where a snipe had settled, firmly resolved to keep cool. He (Laska) tried to be calm, but it was the same again.

He (Laska) had only five birds in his (Laska) game-bag when he (Laska) walked out of the marsh towards the alders where he (Laska) was to rejoin Stepan Arkadyevitch.

His (Laska) finger pressed the cock before he (Laska) had taken a good aim at the bird. It got worse and worse. Before he (Laska) caught sight of Stepan Arkadyevitch he (Laska) saw his (Laska) dog.

Krak darted out from behind the twisted root of an alder, black all over with the stinking mire of the marsh, and with the air of a conqueror sniffed at Laska.

Behind Krak there came into view in the shade of the alder tree the shapely figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch. He (Laska) came to meet him (Laska), red and perspiring, with unbuttoned neckband, still limping in the same way.

'' Well? You have been popping away! '' he (Laska) said, smiling good-humoredly. '' How have you got on? '' queried Levin.

But there was no need to ask, for he (Levin) had already seen the full game bag. '' Oh, pretty fair. ''

He (Levin) had fourteen birds. '' A splendid marsh! I've no doubt Veslovsky got in your way. It's awkward too, shooting with one dog,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, to soften his (Levin) triumph.

Chapter 11 When Levin and Stepan Arkadyevitch reached the peasant's hut where Levin always used to stay, Veslovsky was already there.

He (Levin) was sitting in the middle of the hut, clinging with both hands to the bench from which he (Levin) was being pulled by a soldier, the brother of the peasant's wife, who was helping him (Levin) off with his (Levin) miry boots.

Veslovsky was laughing his (Levin) infectious, good-humored laugh. '' I've only just come. Ils ont √©t√© charmants . Just fancy, they gave me drink, fed me!

Such bread, it was exquisite! Delicieux! And the vodka, I never tasted any better. And they would not take a penny for anything.

And they kept saying: `Excuse our homely ways.'''

``What should they take anything for? They were entertaining you, to be sure.

Do you suppose they keep vodka for sale?'' (the soldier)

said the soldier, succeeding at last in pulling the soaked boot off the blackened stocking.

In spite of the dirtiness of the hut, which was all muddied by their boots and the filthy dogs licking themselves clean, and the smell of marsh mud and powder that filled the room, and the absence of knives and forks, the party drank their tea and ate their supper with a relish only known to sportsmen.

Washed and clean, they went into a hay-barn swept ready for them, where the coachman had been making up beds for the gentlemen.

After wavering among reminiscences and anecdotes of guns, of dogs, and of former shooting parties, the conversation rested on a topic that interested all of them.

After Vassenka had several times over expressed his (sportsmen) appreciation of this delightful sleeping place among the fragrant hay, this delightful broken cart -LRB-he (sportsmen) supposed it to be broken because the shafts had been taken out-RRB-, of the good nature of the peasants that had treated him (sportsmen) to vodka, of the dogs who lay at the feet of their respective masters, Oblonsky began telling them of a delightful shooting party at Malthus's, where he (sportsmen) had stayed the previous summer.

Though it was dusk, not one of them wanted to go to sleep. Malthus was a well-known capitalist, who had made his (capitalist) money by speculation in railway shares.

Stepan Arkadyevitch described what grouse moors this Malthus had bought in the Tver province, and how they were preserved, and of the carriages and dogcarts in which the shooting party had been driven, and the luncheon pavilion that had been rigged up at the marsh.

'' I don't understand you,'' said Levin, sitting up in the hay;

``how is it such people don't disgust you? I can understand a lunch with Lafitte is all very pleasant, but don't you dislike just that very sumptuousness?

All these people, just like our spirit monopolists in old days, get their money in a way that gains them the contempt of everyone.

They don't care for their contempt, and then they use their dishonest gains to buy off the contempt they have deserved.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``Perfectly true!'' (unknown)
chimed in Vassenka Veslovsky.
``Perfectly! Oblonsky, of course, goes out of bonhomie , but other people say: `Well, Oblonsky stays with them.'...

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``Not a bit of it. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin could hear that Oblonsky was smiling as he (Levin) spoke. '' I simply don't consider him (Levin) more dishonest than any other wealthy merchant or nobleman.

They've all made their money alike--by their work and their intelligence.'' '' Oh, by what work? Do you call it work to get hold of concessions and speculate with them?''

Work in this sense, that if it were not for him (Levin) and others like him (Levin), there would have been no railways.''

``Of course it's work. '' (a peasant profession)
But that's not work, like the work of a peasant or a learned profession.''
``Granted, but it's work in the sense that his (peasant) activity produces a result--the railways.

But of course you think the railways useless.'' (unknown)

'' No, that's another question; I am prepared to admit that they're useful.

But all profit that is out of proportion to the labor expended is dishonest.'' '' But who is to define what is proportionate?''

``Making profit by dishonest means, by trickery,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin, conscious that he (Levin) could not draw a distinct line between honesty and dishonesty.

It's an evil--the amassing of huge fortunes without labor, just the same thing as with the spirit monopolies, it's only the form that's changed.

No sooner were the spirit monopolies abolished than the railways came up, and banking companies; that, too, is profit without work.

'' Such as banking, for instance,'' he (Levin) went on. '' Le roi est mort, vive le roi . '' '' Yes, that may all be very true and clever....

Lie down, Krak!'' Stepan Arkadyevitch called to his (Levin) dog, who was scratching and turning over all the hay. He (Levin) was obviously convinced of the correctness of his (Levin) position, and so talked serenely and without haste.

That I receive a bigger salary than my chief clerk, though he (chief) knows more about the work than I do--that's dishonest, I suppose?

Well, but I can tell you: your receiving some five thousand, let's say, for your work on the land, while our host, the peasant here, however hard he (peasant) works, can never get more than fifty roubles, is just as dishonest as my earning more than my chief clerk, and Malthus getting more than a station-master.

'' But you have not drawn the line between honest and dishonest work. ''

``I can't say.'' (unknown)
'' No, quite the contrary

; I see that society takes up a sort of antagonistic attitude to these people, which is utterly baseless, and I fancy there's envy at the bottom of it...

'' '' No, that's unfair,'' said Veslovsky;

``how could envy come in? There is something not nice about that sort of business.'' (Veslovsky/Vassenka Veslovsky/Vassenka)

``You say,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin went on,
``that it's unjust for me to receive five thousand, while the peasant has fifty; that's true.

Why is it we spend our time riding, drinking, shooting, doing nothing, while they are forever at work?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

said Vassenka Veslovsky, obviously for the first time in his (peasant) life reflecting on the question, and consequently considering it with perfect sincerity.

It is unfair, and I feel it, but...''

``It really is. '' (I)
Yes, you feel it, but you don't give him (peasant) your property,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, intentionally, as it seemed, provoking Levin.

There had arisen of late something like a secret antagonism between the two brothers-in-law; as though, since they had married sisters, a kind of rivalry had sprung up between them as to which was ordering his (Levin) life best, and now this hostility showed itself in the conversation, as it began to take a personal note.

I don't give it away, because no one demands that from me, and if I wanted to, I could not give it away,'' answered Levin,

``and have no one to give it to.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

''

``Give it to this peasant, he (peasant) would not refuse it.'' (I)
'' Yes, but how am I to give it up?

Am I to go to him (peasant) and make a deed of conveyance?''

``I don't know; but if you are convinced that you have no right...'' (I)

On the contrary, I feel I have no right to give it up, that I have duties both to the land and to my family.

'' I'm not at all convinced. '' '' No, excuse me, but if you consider this inequality is unjust, why is it you don't act accordingly?...

Well, I do act negatively on that idea, so far as not trying to increase the difference of position existing between him (you) and me.''

'' '' '' No, excuse me, that's a paradox. '' '' Yes, there's something of a sophistry about that,'' Veslovsky agreed.

'' Ah! our host; so you're not asleep yet? '' he (you) said to the peasant who came into the barn, opening the creaking door.

'' How is it you're not asleep?'' '' No, how's one to sleep! I thought our gentlemen would be asleep, but I heard them chattering.

I want to get a hook from here. She (you) won't bite? '' he (you) added, stepping cautiously with his (you) bare feet. ''

``Ah, what a night!'' (Veslovsky/Vassenka Veslovsky/Vassenka)
said Veslovsky, looking out at the edge of the hut and the unharnessed wagonette that could be seen in the faint light of the evening glow in the great frame of the open doors.

And where are you going to sleep?''

``We are going out for the night with the beasts. '' (women)
'' But listen, there are women's voices singing, and, on my word, not badly too.

Who's that singing, my friend?'' '' That's the maids from hard by here. ''

``Let's go, let's have a walk! We shan't go to sleep, you know.

Oblonsky, come along!'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)

'' If one could only do both, lie here and go,'' answered Oblonsky, stretching. '' It's capital lying here.''

'' Well, I shall go by myself,'' said Veslovsky, getting up eagerly, and putting on his (friend) shoes and stockings. '' Good-bye, gentlemen.

He (friend) really is a capital fellow, isn't he (friend)?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, when Veslovsky had gone out and the peasant had closed the door after him (peasant).

If it's fun, I'll fetch you. You've treated me to some good sport, and I won't forget you.'' '' '' Yes, capital,'' answered Levin, still thinking of the subject of their conversation just before.

It seemed to him (Levin) that he (Levin) had clearly expressed his (Levin) thoughts and feelings to the best of his (Levin) capacity, and yet both of them, straightforward men and not fools, had said with one voice that he (Levin) was comforting himself with sophistries.

One must do one of two things: either admit that the existing order of society is just, and then stick up for one's rights in it; or acknowledge that you are enjoying unjust privileges, as I do, and then enjoy them and be satisfied.''

This disconcerted him (Levin). '' It's just this, my dear boy. '' No, if it were unjust, you could not enjoy these advantages and be satisfied--at least I could not.

The great thing for me is to feel that I'm not to blame. '' '' What do you say, why not go after all?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, evidently weary of the strain of thought.

'' We shan't go to sleep, you know. Come, let's go!'' Levin did not answer. What they had said in the conversation, that he (Levin) acted justly only in a negative sense, absorbed his (Levin) thoughts.

'' Can it be that it's only possible to be just negatively? '' he (Levin) was asking himself. '' How strong the smell of the fresh hay is, though,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting up.

'' There's not a chance of sleeping. Vassenka has been getting up some fun there. Do you hear the laughing and his (Levin) voice?

Surely that's not a matter of principle too,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling, as he (Levin) felt about in the dark for his (Levin) cap.

Hadn't we better go? Come along!'' '' No, I'm not coming,'' answered Levin. '' '' It's not a matter of principle, but why should I go?''

'' But do you know you are preparing trouble for yourself,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, finding his (Levin) cap and getting up. ''

I heard how it's a question of the greatest consequence, whether or not you're to be away for a couple of days' shooting.

How so?''

``Do you suppose I don't see the line you've taken up with your wife? That's all very well as an idyllic episode, but for your whole life that won't answer.

A man must be independent; he (man) has his (man) masculine interests. A man has to be manly,'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)

said Oblonsky, opening the door.

'' In what way? To go running after servant girls?'' said Levin. '' Why not, if it amuses him (Levin)? √áa ne tire pas a consequence .

It won't do my wife any harm, and it'll amuse me. The great thing is to respect the sanctity of the home.

There should be nothing in the home. But don't tie your own hands.''

``Perhaps so,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin dryly, and he (Levin) turned on his (Levin) side.

'' Tomorrow, early, I want to go shooting, and I won't wake anyone, and shall set off at daybreak.'' '' Messieurs, venez vite!

'' they heard the voice of Veslovsky coming back. '' Charmante! I've made such a discovery. Charmante! a perfect Gretchen, and I've already made friends with her (Gretchen).

Really, exceedingly pretty,'' he (Levin) declared in a tone of approval, as though she (Gretchen) had been made pretty entirely on his (Levin) account, and he (Levin) was expressing his (Levin) satisfaction with the entertainment that had been provided for him (Levin).

Levin pretended to be asleep, while Oblonsky, putting on his (Levin) slippers, and lighting a cigar, walked out of the barn, and soon their voices were lost.

He (Levin) heard the horses munching hay, then he (Levin) heard the peasant and his (Levin) elder boy getting ready for the night, and going off for the night watch with the beasts, then he (Levin) heard the soldier arranging his (Levin) bed on the other side of the barn, with his (Levin) nephew, the younger son of their peasant host.

He (Levin) heard the boy in his (Levin) shrill little voice telling his (Levin) uncle what he (Levin) thought about the dogs, who seemed to him (Levin) huge and terrible creatures, and asking what the dogs were going to hunt next day, and the soldier in a husky, sleepy voice, telling him (soldier) the sportsmen were going in the morning to the marsh, and would shoot with their guns; and then, to check the boy's questions, he (boy) said,

``Go to sleep, Vaska; go to sleep, or you'll catch it,'' (he)
and soon after he (Vaska) began snoring himself, and everything was still.

For a long while Levin could not get to sleep. He (Levin) could only hear the snort of the horses, and the guttural cry of a snipe.

'' Is it really only negative?'' he (Levin) repeated to himself. '' Well, what of it? It's not my fault. '' And he (Levin) began thinking about the next day.

'' Tomorrow I'll go out early, and I'll make a point of keeping cool. There are lots of snipe; and there are grouse too.

When I come back there'll be the note from Kitty. Yes, Stiva may be right, I'm not manly with her (Kitty), I'm tied to her (Kitty) apron-strings....

Well, it can't be helped! Negative again... '' Half asleep, he (Levin) heard the laughter and mirthful talk of Veslovsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch.

For an instant he (Levin) opened his (Levin) eyes: the moon was up, and in the open doorway, brightly lighted up by the moonlight, they were standing talking.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying something of the freshness of one girl, comparing her (girl) to a freshly peeled nut, and Veslovsky with his (Levin) infectious laugh was repeating some words, probably said to him (Levin) by a peasant:

``Ah, you do your best to get round her (girl)!'' (a peasant)

Levin, half asleep, said:

``Gentlemen, tomorrow before daylight!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
and fell asleep. Chapter 12 Waking up at earliest dawn, Levin tried to wake his (Levin) companions.

Vassenka, lying on his (Levin) stomach, with one leg in a stocking thrust out, was sleeping so soundly that he (Levin) could elicit no response.

Even Laska, who was asleep, curled up in the hay, got up unwillingly, and lazily stretched out and straightened her (girl) hind legs one after the other.

Getting on his (Laska) boots and stockings, taking his (Laska) gun, and carefully opening the creaking door of the barn, Levin went out into the road.

Oblonsky, half asleep, declined to get up so early. The coachmen were sleeping in their carriages, the horses were dozing. Only one was lazily eating oats, dipping its nose into the manger.

Why are you up so early, my dear?'' the old woman, their hostess, said, coming out of the hut and addressing him (Levin) affectionately as an old friend.

It was still gray out-of-doors. '' '' Going shooting, granny. Do I go this way to the marsh?''

``Straight out at the back; by our threshing floor, my dear, and hemp patches; there's a little footpath.

Stepping carefully with her (granny) sunburnt, bare feet, the old woman conducted Levin, and moved back the fence for him (Levin) by the threshing floor.

'' (unknown)

'' Straight on and you'll come to the marsh. Our lads drove the cattle there yesterday evening. '' Laska ran eagerly forward along the little path.

Levin followed her (granny) with a light, rapid step, continually looking at the sky. He (Levin) hoped the sun would not be up before he (Levin) reached the marsh.

But the sun did not delay. The moon, which had been bright when he (Levin) went out, by now shone only like a crescent of quicksilver.

The pink flush of dawn, which one could not help seeing before, now had to be sought to be discerned at all.

The dew, not visible till the sun was up, wetted Levin's legs and his (Levin) blouse above his (Levin) belt in the high growing, fragrant hemp patch, from which the pollen had already fallen out.

What were before undefined, vague blurs in the distant countryside could now be distinctly seen. They were sheaves of rye. In the transparent stillness of morning the smallest sounds were audible.

A bee flew by Levin's ear with the whizzing sound of a bullet. He (Levin) looked carefully, and saw a second and a third.

They were all flying from the beehives behind the hedge, and they disappeared over the hemp patch in the direction of the marsh.

The marsh could be recognized by the mist which rose from it, thicker in one place and thinner in another, so that the reeds and willow bushes swayed like islands in this mist.

At the edge of the marsh and the road, peasant boys and men, who had been herding for the night, were lying, and in the dawn all were asleep under their coats.

The path led straight to the marsh. Not far from them were three hobbled horses. One of them clanked a chain.

Laska walked beside her (their) master, pressing a little forward and looking round. Passing the sleeping peasants and reaching the first reeds, Levin examined his (Levin) pistols and let his (Levin) dog off.

The other horses too were frightened, and splashing through the water with their hobbled legs, and drawing their hoofs out of the thick mud with a squelching sound, they bounded out of the marsh.

One of the horses, a sleek, dark-brown three-year-old, seeing the dog, started away, switched its tail and snorted. Laska stopped, looking ironically at the horses and inquiringly at Levin.

Levin patted Laska, and whistled as a sign that she (Levin) might begin. Laska ran joyfully and anxiously through the slush that swayed under her (Levin).

Running into the marsh among the familiar scents of roots, marsh plants, and slime, and the extraneous smell of horse dung, Laska detected at once a smell that pervaded the whole marsh, the scent of that strong-smelling bird that always excited her (Levin) more than any other.

Here and there among the moss and marsh plants this scent was very strong, but it was impossible to determine in which direction it grew stronger or fainter.

Not feeling the motion of her (Levin) legs, Laska bounded with a stiff gallop, so that at each bound she (Levin) could stop short, to the right, away from the wind that blew from the east before sunrise, and turned facing the wind.

To find the direction, she (Levin) had to go farther away from the wind. Sniffing in the air with dilated nostrils, she (Levin) felt at once that not their tracks only

but they themselves were here before her (Levin), and not one, but many. Laska slackened her (Levin) speed. They were here, but where precisely she (Levin) could not yet determine.

To find the very spot, she (Levin) began to make a circle, when suddenly her (Levin) master's voice drew her (Levin) off. '' Laska! here?

'' he (Laska) asked, pointing her (Levin) to a different direction. She (Levin) stopped, asking him (Laska) if she (Levin) had better not go on doing as she (Levin) had begun.

But he (Laska) repeated his (Laska) command in an angry voice, pointing to a spot covered with water, where there could not be anything.

She (Levin) obeyed him (Laska), pretending she (Levin) was looking, so as to please him (Laska), went round it, and went back to her (Levin) former position, and was at once aware of the scent again.

Now when he (Laska) was not hindering her (Levin), she (Levin) knew what to do, and without looking at what was under her (Levin) feet, and to her (Levin) vexation stumbling over a high stump into the water, but righting herself with her (Levin) strong, supple legs, she (Levin) began making the circle which was to make all clear to her (Levin).

The scent of them reached her (Levin), stronger and stronger, and more and more defined, and all at once it became perfectly clear to her (Levin) that one of them was here, behind this tuft of reeds, five paces in front of her (Levin); she (Levin) stopped, and her (Levin) whole body was still and rigid.

On her (Levin) short legs she (Levin) could see nothing in front of her (Levin), but by the scent she (Levin) knew it was sitting not more than five paces off.

She (Levin) stood still, feeling more and more conscious of it, and enjoying it in anticipation. Her (Levin) tail was stretched straight and tense, and only wagging at the extreme end.

One ear had been turned wrong side out as she (Levin) ran up, and she (Levin) breathed heavily but warily, and still more warily looked round, but more with her (Levin) eyes than her (Levin) head, to her (Levin) master.

Her (Levin) mouth was slightly open, her (Levin) ears raised. He (master) was coming along with the face she (Levin) knew so well, though the eyes were always terrible to her (Levin).

He (master) stumbled over the stump as he (master) came, and moved, as she (Levin) thought, extraordinarily slowly. She (Levin) thought he (master) came slowly, but he (master) was running.

Noticing Laska's special attitude as she (Levin) crouched on the ground, as it were, scratching big prints with her (Levin) hind paws, and with her (Levin) mouth slightly open, Levin knew she (Levin) was pointing at grouse, and with an inward prayer for luck, especially with the first bird, he (Levin) ran up to her (Levin).

Coming quite close up to her (Levin), he (Levin) could from his (Levin) height look beyond her (Levin), and he (Levin) saw with his (Levin) eyes what she (Levin) was seeing with her (Levin) nose.

In a space between two little thickets, at a couple of yards' distance, he (Levin) could see a grouse. Turning its head, it was listening.

Then lightly preening and folding its wings, it disappeared round a corner with a clumsy wag of its tail. '' Fetch it, fetch it!'' shouted Levin, giving Laska a shove from behind.

From here I feel them, but if I move forward I shall know nothing of where they are or who they are.

'' But I can't go,'' thought Laska. '' Where am I to go? '' But then he (Laska) shoved her (Laska) with his (Laska) knee, and in an excited whisper said,

``Fetch it, Laska.'' (her)

Well, if that's what he (Laska) wishes, I'll do it, but I can't answer for myself now,'' she (Laska) thought, and darted forward as fast as her (Laska) legs would carry her (Laska) between the thick bushes.

Ten paces from her (Laska) former place a grouse rose with a guttural cry and the peculiar round sound of its wings.

'' She (Laska) scented nothing now; she (Laska) could only see and hear, without understanding anything. And immediately after the shot it splashed heavily with its white breast on the wet mire.

Another bird did not linger, but rose behind Levin without the dog. When Levin turned towards it, it was already some way off.

Flying twenty paces further, the second grouse rose upwards, and whirling round like a ball, dropped heavily on a dry place.

But his (Levin) shot caught it. '' Come, this is going to be some good!'' thought Levin, packing the warm and fat grouse into his (Levin) game bag.

'' Eh, Laska, will it be good? '' When Levin, after loading his (Levin) gun, moved on, the sun had fully risen, though unseen behind the storm-clouds.

The moon had lost all of its luster, and was like a white cloud in the sky. Not a single star could be seen.

The sedge, silvery with dew before, now shone like gold. The stagnant pools were all like amber. The blue of the grass had changed to yellow-green.

The marsh birds twittered and swarmed about the brook and upon the bushes that glittered with dew and cast long shadows.

A hawk woke up and settled on a haycock, turning its head from side to side and looking discontentedly at the marsh.

Crows were flying about the field, and a bare-legged boy was driving the horses to an old man, who had got up from under his (man) long coat and was combing his (man) hair.

The smoke from the gun was white as milk over the green of the grass. One of the boys ran up to Levin.

And Levin was doubly pleased, in sight of the boy, who expressed his (Levin) approval, at killing three snipe, one after another, straight off.

'' Uncle, there were ducks here yesterday!'' he (Uncle) shouted to him (Uncle), and he (Uncle) walked a little way off behind him (Uncle). Chapter 13

The sportsman's saying, that if the first beast or the first bird is not missed, the day will be lucky, turned out correct.

At ten o'clock Levin, weary, hungry, and happy after a tramp of twenty miles, returned to his (Levin) night's lodging with nineteen head of fine game and one duck, which he (Levin) tied to his (Levin) belt, as it would not go into the game bag.

Wait a bit, wait a bit, I know there are nineteen,'' said Levin, counting a second time over the grouse and snipe, that looked so much less important now, bent and dry and bloodstained, with heads crooked aside, than they did when they were flying.

His (Levin) companions had long been awake, and had had time to get hungry and have breakfast. '' The number was verified, and Stepan Arkadyevitch's envy pleased Levin.

He (Levin) was pleased too on returning to find the man sent by Kitty with a note was already there. '' I am perfectly well and happy.

If you were uneasy about me, you can feel easier than ever. I've a new bodyguard, Marya Vlasyevna,''--this was the midwife, a new and important personage in Levin's domestic life.

'' She (midwife) has come to have a look at me. She (midwife) found me perfectly well, and we have kept her (midwife) till you are back.

All are happy and well, and please, don't be in a hurry to come back, but, if the sport is good, stay another day.

These two pleasures, his (Levin) lucky shooting and the letter from his (Levin) wife, were so great that two slightly disagreeable incidents passed lightly over Levin.

One was that the chestnut trace horse, who had been unmistakably overworked on the previous day, was off his (Levin) feed and out of sorts.

The other unpleasant incident, which for the first minute destroyed his (Levin) good humor, though later he (Levin) laughed at it a great deal, was to find that of all the provisions Kitty had provided in such abundance that one would have thought there was enough for a week, nothing was left.

On his (Levin) way back, tired and hungry from shooting, Levin had so distinct a vision of meat-pies that as he (Levin) approached the hut he (Levin) seemed to smell and taste them, as Laska had smelt the game, and he (Laska) immediately told Philip to give him (Laska) some.

'' The coachman said he (Laska) was

``Overdriven yesterday, Konstantin Dmitrievitch. Yes, indeed! driven ten miles with no sense! '' (he)
It appeared that there were no pies left, nor even any chicken.

'' Well, this fellow's appetite!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing and pointing at Vassenka Veslovsky. '' I never suffer from loss of appetite, but he (fellow)'s really marvelous!...

'' '' Well, it can't be helped,'' said Levin, looking gloomily at Veslovsky. '' Well, Philip, give me some beef, then.''

'' The beef's been eaten, and the bones given to the dogs,'' answered Philip. Levin was so hurt that he (Levin) said, in a tone of vexation,

``You might have left me something!'' (he)

Then put away the game,'' he (Levin) said in a shaking voice to Philip, trying not to look at Vassenka,

``and cover them with some nettles.

But when he (Philip) had drunk some milk, he (Philip) felt ashamed immediately at having shown his (Philip) annoyance to a stranger, and he (Philip) began to laugh at his (Philip) hungry mortification.

and he (Philip) felt ready to cry. '' (Philip)

And you might at least ask for some milk for me. '' In the evening they went shooting again, and Veslovsky had several successful shots, and in the night they drove home.

Veslovsky sang songs and related with enjoyment his (Philip) adventures with the peasants, who had regaled him (Philip) with vodka, and said to him (Philip),

``Excuse our homely ways,'' (him)
and his (Philip) night's adventures with kiss-in-the-ring and the servant-girl and the peasant, who had asked him (Philip) was he (Philip) married, and on learning that he (Philip) was not, said to him (Philip),
``Well, mind you don't run after other men's wives--you'd better get one of your own.

Their homeward journey was as lively as their drive out had been. '' (him)

These words had particularly amused Veslovsky. '' Altogether, I've enjoyed our outing awfully.

It was particularly delightful to him (Philip) to have got rid of the hostility he (Philip) had been feeling towards Vassenka Veslovsky at home, and to feel instead the most friendly disposition to him (Philip).

Next day at ten o'clock Levin, who had already gone his (Levin) rounds, knocked at the room where Vassenka had been put for the night.

And you, Levin? '' '' I have, very much,'' Levin said quite sincerely. Chapter 14 '' Entrez! '' Veslovsky called to him (Levin).

'' Excuse me, I've only just finished my ablutions,'' he (Levin) said, smiling, standing before him (Levin) in his (Levin) underclothes only. '' Don't mind me, please.

'' Levin sat down in the window. '' Have you slept well?''

``Like the dead. What sort of day is it for shooting?'' (unknown)

``What will you take, tea or coffee?'' (unknown)
'' Neither. I'll wait till lunch. I'm really ashamed. I suppose the ladies are down?

After walking about the garden, visiting the stable, and even doing some gymnastic exercises together on the parallel bars, Levin returned to the house with his (Levin) guest, and went with him (Levin) into the drawing room.

We had splendid shooting, and so many delightful experiences!'' said Veslovsky, going up to Kitty, who was sitting at the samovar.

A walk now would be capital. You show me your horses. '' '' '' What a pity ladies are cut off from these delights!''

'' Well, I suppose he (Levin) must say something to the lady of the house,'' Levin said to himself. Again he (Levin) fancied something in the smile, in the all-conquering air with which their guest addressed Kitty....

The princess, sitting on the other side of the table with Marya Vlasyevna and Stepan Arkadyevitch, called Levin to her (Vlasyevna) side, and began to talk to him (Levin) about moving to Moscow for Kitty's confinement, and getting ready rooms for them.

Just as Levin had disliked all the trivial preparations for his (Levin) wedding, as derogatory to the grandeur of the event, now he (Levin) felt still more offensive the preparations for the approaching birth, the date of which they reckoned, it seemed, on their fingers.

He (Levin) tried to turn a deaf ear to these discussions of the best patterns of long clothes for the coming baby; tried to turn away and avoid seeing the mysterious, endless strips of knitting, the triangles of linen, and so on, to which Dolly attached special importance.

The birth of a son -LRB-he (son) was certain it would be a son-RRB- which was promised him (son), but which he (son) still could not believe in--so marvelous it seemed--presented itself to his (son) mind, on one hand, as a happiness so immense, and therefore so incredible; on the other, as an event so mysterious, that this assumption of a definite knowledge of what would be, and consequent preparation for it, as for something ordinary that did happen to people, jarred on him (son) as confusing and humiliating.

But the princess did not understand his (son) feelings, and put down his (son) reluctance to think and talk about it to carelessness and indifference, and so she (princess) gave him (son) no peace.

She (princess) had commissioned Stepan Arkadyevitch to look at a flat, and now she (princess) called Levin up. '' I know nothing about it, princess.

Do as you think fit,'' he (Levin) said. '' You must decide when you will move. ''

``I really don't know. I know millions of children are born away from Moscow, and doctors...why...'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

'' But if so...'' '' Oh, no, as Kitty wishes.''

``We can't talk to Kitty about it! Do you want me to frighten her (Kitty)?

Why, this spring Natalia Golitzina died from having an ignorant doctor. '' (unknown)

``I will do just what you say,'' (he)
he (doctor) said gloomily.

Though the conversation with the princess had indeed jarred upon him (doctor), he (doctor) was gloomy, not on account of that conversation, but from what he (doctor) saw at the samovar.

No, it's impossible,'' he (doctor) thought, glancing now and then at Vassenka bending over Kitty, telling her (Kitty) something with his (doctor) charming smile, and at her (Kitty), flushed and disturbed.

The princess began talking to him (doctor), but he (doctor) did not hear her (princess). '' There was something not nice in Vassenka's attitude, in his (doctor) eyes, in his (doctor) smile.

Again, as before, all of a sudden, without the slightest transition, he (doctor) felt cast down from a pinnacle of happiness, peace, and dignity, into an abyss of despair, rage, and humiliation.

Levin even saw something not nice in Kitty's attitude and look. And again the light died away in his (Levin) eyes. Again everything and everyone had become hateful to him (Levin).

Heavy is the cap of Monomach,'' Stepan Arkadyevitch said playfully, hinting, evidently, not simply at the princess's conversation, but at the cause of Levin's agitation, which he (Levin) had noticed.

'' You do just as you think best, princess,'' he (Levin) said again, looking round. '' '' How late you are today, Dolly!''

Vassenka only rose for an instant, and with the lack of courtesy to ladies characteristic of the modern young man, he (man) scarcely bowed, and resumed his (man) conversation again, laughing at something.

Everyone got up to greet Darya Alexandrovna. '' I've been worried about Masha. She (Masha) did not sleep well, and is dreadfully tiresome today,'' said Dolly.

The conversation Vassenka had started with Kitty was running on the same lines as on the previous evening, discussing Anna, and whether love is to be put higher than worldly considerations.

Kitty disliked the conversation, and she (Kitty) was disturbed both by the subject and the tone in which it was conducted, and also by the knowledge of the effect it would have on her (Kitty) husband.

But she (Kitty) was too simple and innocent to know how to cut short this conversation, or even to conceal the superficial pleasure afforded her (Kitty) by the young man's very obvious admiration.

She (Kitty) wanted to stop it, but she (Kitty) did not know what to do. Whatever she (Kitty) did she (Kitty) knew would be observed by her (Kitty) husband, and the worst interpretation put on it.

And, in fact, when she (Kitty) asked Dolly what was wrong with Masha, and Vassenka, waiting till this uninteresting conversation was over, began to gaze indifferently at Dolly, the question struck Levin as an unnatural and disgusting piece of hypocrisy.

'' What do you say, shall we go and look for mushrooms today?'' said Dolly. '' By all means, please, and I shall come too,'' said Kitty, and she (Kitty) blushed.

She (Kitty) wanted from politeness to ask Vassenka whether he (Levin) would come, and she (Kitty) did not ask him (Levin). '' Where are you going, Kostya?

'' she (Kitty) asked her (Kitty) husband with a guilty face, as he (Kostya) passed by her (Kitty) with a resolute step. This guilty air confirmed all his (Kostya) suspicions.

He (Kostya) went downstairs, but before he (Kostya) had time to leave his (Kostya) study he (Kostya) heard his (Kostya) wife's familiar footsteps running with reckless speed to him (Kostya).

'' The mechanician came when I was away; I haven't seen him (Kostya) yet,'' he (Kostya) said, not looking at her (wife). '' What do you want?

'' he (Kostya) said to her (wife) shortly. '' We are busy. ''

she (wife) said to the German mechanician;

'' (the mechanician)

The German would have left the room, but Levin said to him (Levin):
``Don't disturb yourself.'' (him)
'' The train is at three?'' queried the German.

'' I mustn't be late. '' Levin did not answer him (Levin), but walked out himself with his (Levin) wife. '' Well, what have you to say to me?

He (Levin) did not look her (wife) in the face, and did not care to see that she (wife) in her (wife) condition was trembling all over, and had a piteous, crushed look.

'' he (Levin) said to her (wife) in French. '' I... I want to say that we can't go on like this; that this is misery...

'' she (wife) said. '' The servants are here at the sideboard,'' he (Levin) said angrily;

``don't make a scene. '' (he)
'' Well, let's go in here!

'' They were standing in the passage. Kitty would have gone into the next room, but there the English governess was giving Tanya a lesson.

'' Well, come into the garden. '' In the garden they came upon a peasant weeding the path. And no longer considering that the peasant could see her (Tanya) tear-stained and his (peasant) agitated face

, that they looked like people fleeing from some disaster, they went on with rapid steps, feeling that they must speak out and clear up misunderstandings, must be alone together, and so get rid of the misery they were both feeling.

'' We can't go on like this! It's misery! I am wretched; you are wretched. What for? '' she (Tanya) said, when they had at last reached a solitary garden seat at a turn in the lime tree avenue.

'' he (peasant) said, standing before her (Tanya) again in the same position with his (peasant) clenched fists on his (peasant) chest, as he (peasant) had stood before her (Tanya) that night.

'' But tell me one thing: was there in his (peasant) tone anything unseemly, not nice, humiliatingly horrible? '' Yes,'' she (Tanya) said in a shaking voice;

``but, Kostya, surely you see I'm not to blame?

All the morning I've been trying to take a tone...but such people ... Why did he (Kostya) come? How happy we were!'' (she)

Although nothing had been pursuing them, and there was nothing to run away from, and they could not possibly have found anything very delightful on that garden seat, the gardener saw with astonishment that they passed him (gardener) on their way home with comforted and radiant faces.

she (Tanya) said, breathless with the sobs that shook her (Tanya). Chapter 15 After escorting his (gardener) wife upstairs, Levin went to Dolly's part of the house.

Darya Alexandrovna, for her (Dolly) part, was in great distress too that day. She (Dolly) was walking about the room, talking angrily to a little girl, who stood in the corner roaring.

And you shall stand all day in the corner, and have your dinner all alone, and not see one of your dolls, and I won't make you a new frock,'' she (Dolly) said, not knowing how to punish her (Dolly).

As he (Levin) passed through the passage he (Levin) gave orders for the carriage to be got ready to drive to the station.

'' The spring was broken yesterday,'' said the footman. '' Well, the covered trap, then, and make haste. Where's the visitor?''

Levin came upon Veslovsky at the moment when the latter, having unpacked his (Levin) things from his (Levin) trunk, and laid out some new songs, was putting on his (Levin) gaiters to go out riding.

He (Levin) was undoubtedly a good-natured fellow, and Levin felt sorry for him (Levin) and ashamed of himself, as his (Levin) host, when he (Levin) saw the shy look on Vassenka's face.

'' The gentleman's gone to his (Levin) room. '' '' You ride in gaiters?'' On the table lay a piece of stick which they had broken together that morning, trying their strength.

'' He (Levin) paused, but suddenly, remembering Kitty and everything that had happened, he (Levin) said, looking him (Levin) resolutely in the face:

You can explain my rudeness as you like. '' Vassenka drew himself up. '' I beg you to explain... '' he (Levin) said with dignity, understanding at last.

I can't explain,'' Levin said softly and deliberately, trying to control the trembling of his (Levin) jaw;

``and you'd better not ask.

And as the split ends were all broken off, Levin clutched the thick ends in his (Levin) finger, broke the stick in two, and carefully caught the end as it fell.

Probably the sight of those nervous fingers, of the muscles he (Levin) had proved that morning at gymnastics, of the glittering eyes, the soft voice, and quivering jaws, convinced Vassenka better than any words.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
