When Anna found Dolly at home before her (Anna), she (Anna) looked intently in her (Anna) eyes, as though questioning her (Anna) about the talk she (Anna) had had with Vronsky, but she (Anna) made no inquiry in words.

They got up and walked to the house. Chapter 22 '' I believe it's dinner time,'' she (Anna) said. '' We've not seen each other at all yet.

I am reckoning on the evening. Now I want to go and dress. I expect you do too; we all got splashed at the buildings.

'' Dolly went to her (Dolly) room and she (Dolly) felt amused. To change her (Dolly) dress was impossible, for she (Dolly) had already put on her (Dolly) best dress.

But in order to signify in some way her (Dolly) preparation for dinner, she (Dolly) asked the maid to brush her (Dolly) dress, changed her (Dolly) cuffs and tie, and put some lace on her (Dolly) head.

This is all I can do,'' she (Dolly) said with a smile to Anna, who came in to her (Anna) in a third dress, again of extreme simplicity.

'' '' Yes, we are too formal here,'' she (Anna) said, as it were apologizing for her (Anna) magnificence. '' Alexey is delighted at your visit, as he (Alexey) rarely is at anything.

He (Alexey) has completely lost his (Alexey) heart to you,'' she (Anna) added. '' You're not tired? '' There was no time for talking about anything before dinner.

Going into the drawing room they found Princess Varvara already there, and the gentlemen of the party in black frock-coats. The architect wore a swallow-tail coat.

Vronsky presented the doctor and the steward to his (steward) guest. The architect he (steward) had already introduced to her (Princess) at the hospital.

A stout butler, resplendent with a smoothly shaven round chin and a starched white cravat, announced that dinner was ready, and the ladies got up.

Veslovsky was before Tushkevitch in offering his (butler) arm to Princess Varvara, so that Tushkevitch with the steward and the doctor walked in alone.

The dinner, the dining room, the service, the waiting at table, the wine, and the food, were not simply in keeping with the general tone of modern luxury throughout all the house, but seemed even more sumptuous and modern.

Darya Alexandrovna watched this luxury which was novel to her (Princess), and as a good housekeeper used to managing a household--although she (housekeeper) never dreamed of adapting anything she (housekeeper) saw to her (housekeeper) own household, as it was all in a style of luxury far above her (housekeeper) own manner of living--she (housekeeper) could not help scrutinizing every detail, and wondering how and by whom it was all done.

Vassenka Veslovsky, her (housekeeper) husband, and even Sviazhsky, and many other people she (housekeeper) knew, would never have considered this question, and would have readily believed what every well-bred host tries to make his (husband) guests feel, that is, that all that is well-ordered in his (husband) house has cost him (husband), the host, no trouble whatever, but comes of itself.

Darya Alexandrovna was well aware that even porridge for the children's breakfast does not come of itself, and that therefore, where so complicated and magnificent a style of luxury was maintained, someone must give earnest attention to its organization.

And from the glance with which Alexey Kirillovitch scanned the table, from the way he (Kirillovitch) nodded to the butler, and offered Darya Alexandrovna her (husband) choice between cold soup and hot soup

Vronsky asked Sviazhsky to take in Anna Arkadyevna, and himself offered his (Kirillovitch) arm to Dolly. , she (Dolly) saw that it was all organized and maintained by the care of the master of the house himself.

It was evident that it all rested no more upon Anna than upon Veslovsky. She (Anna), Sviazhsky, the princess, and Veslovsky, were equally guests, with light hearts enjoying what had been arranged for them.

The conversation was a difficult one for the lady of the house at a small table with persons present, like the steward and the architect, belonging to a completely different world, struggling not to be overawed by an elegance to which they were unaccustomed, and unable to sustain a large share in the general conversation.

But this difficult conversation Anna directed with her (Anna) usual tact and naturalness, and indeed she (Anna) did so with actual enjoyment, as Darya Alexandrovna observed.

The conversation began about the row Tushkevitch and Veslovsky had taken alone together in the boat, and Tushkevitch began describing the last boat races in Petersburg at the Yacht Club.

Anna was the hostess only in conducting the conversation. But Anna, seizing the first pause, at once turned to the architect to draw him (architect) out of his (architect) silence.

Nikolay Ivanitch was struck,'' she (Anna) said, meaning Sviazhsky,

``at the progress the new building had made since he (architect) was here last; but I am there every day, and every day I wonder at the rate at which it grows.

It's first-rate working with his (architect) excellency,'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)

said the architect with a smile -LRB-he (architect) was respectful and composed, though with a sense of his (architect) own dignity-RRB-.

Where one would have to write out sheaves of papers, here I call upon the count, and in three words we settle the business.

'' '' '' '' It's a very different matter to have to do with the district authorities. '' '' The American way of doing business,'' said Sviazhsky, with a smile.

The conversation passed to the misuse of political power in the United States, but Anna quickly brought it round to another topic, so as to draw the steward into talk.

'' Yes, there they build in a rational fashion... '' '' Have you ever seen a reaping machine? '' she (Anna) said, addressing Darya Alexandrovna.

'' We had just ridden over to look at one when we met. It's the first time I ever saw one.''

``How do they work?'' (Dolly)
asked Dolly. '' Exactly like little scissors. A plank and a lot of little scissors. Like this.

Anna took a knife and fork in her (Anna) beautiful white hands covered with rings, and began showing how the machine worked.

It was clear that she (Anna) saw nothing would be understood from her (Anna) explanation; but aware that her (Anna) talk was pleasant and her (Anna) hands beautiful

'' she (Anna) went on explaining. '' More like little penknives,'' Veslovsky said playfully, never taking his (Anna) eyes off her (Anna). Anna gave a just perceptible smile, but made no answer.

'' Isn't it true, Karl Fedoritch, that it's just like little scissors? '' she (Anna) said to the steward. '' Oh, ja, '' answered the German.

'' Es it ein ganz einfaches Ding,'' and he (Ding) began to explain the construction of the machine. '' It's a pity it doesn't bind too.

I saw one at the Vienna exhibition, which binds with a wire,'' said Sviazhsky. '' They would be more profitable in use.''

'' Es kommt drauf an.... Der Preis vom Draht muss ausgerechnet werden. '' And the German, roused from his (Ding) taciturnity, turned to Vronsky.

The German was just feeling in the pocket where were his (German) pencil and the dinner, and observing Vronsky's chilly glance, he (German) checked himself.

'' Das l√§sst sich ausrechnen, Erlaucht. '' '' Zu compliziert, macht zu viel Klopot,'' he (German) concluded. '' W√ºnscht man Dochots, so hat man auch Klopots,'' said Vassenka Veslovsky, mimicking the German.

We expected to find you in the fields, Vassily Semyonitch,'' she (man) said to the doctor, a sickly-looking man;

``have you been there?'' (a man)

'' J'adore l'allemand,'' he (man) addressed Anna again with the same smile.

``Cessez,'' (she)
she (Anna) said with playful severity. ''
``I went there, but I had taken flight,'' (the doctor)
the doctor answered with gloomy jocoseness.

'' Then you've taken a good constitutional?''

``Splendid!'' (the woman)
'' Well, and how was the old woman? I hope it's not typhus?''

``What a pity!'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, and having thus paid the dues of civility to her (Anna) domestic circle, she (Anna) turned to her (Anna) own friends.

'' Typhus it is not, but it's taking a bad turn. '' '' It would be a hard task, though, to construct a machine from your description, Anna Arkadyevna,'' Sviazhsky said jestingly.

Oh, no, why so?'' said Anna with a smile that betrayed that she (Anna) knew there was something charming in her (Anna) disquisitions upon the machine that had been noticed by Sviazhsky.

'' This new trait of girlish coquettishness made an unpleasant impression on Dolly. '' But Anna Arkadyevna's knowledge of architecture is marvelous,'' said Tushkevitch.

'' To be sure, I heard Anna Arkadyevna talking yesterday about plinths and damp-courses,'' said Veslovsky. '' Have I got it right?

'' '' There's nothing marvelous about it, when one sees and hears so much of it,'' said Anna. '' But, I dare say, you don't even know what houses are made of?

'' Darya Alexandrovna saw that Anna disliked the tone of raillery that existed between her (Anna) and Veslovsky, but fell in with it against her (Anna) will.

Vronsky acted in this matter quite differently from Levin. He (Levin) obviously attached no significance to Veslovsky's chattering; on the contrary, he (Levin) encouraged his (Levin) jests.

``Come now, tell us, Veslovsky, how are the stones held together?'' (unknown)
'' By cement, of course. ''
``Bravo! And what is cement?'' (the doctor)

The company at dinner, with the exception of the doctor, the architect, and the steward, who remained plunged in gloomy silence, kept up a conversation that never paused, glancing off one subject, fastening on another, and at times stinging one or the other to the quick.

Once Darya Alexandrovna felt wounded to the quick, and got so hot that she (Bravo) positively flushed and wondered afterwards whether she (Bravo) had said anything extreme or unpleasant.

'' Oh, some sort of paste...no, putty,'' said Veslovsky, raising a general laugh. Sviazhsky began talking of Levin, describing his (Levin) strange view that machinery is simply pernicious in its effects on Russian agriculture.

I have not the pleasure of knowing this M. Levin,'' Vronsky said, smiling,

``but most likely he (Levin) has never seen the machines he (Levin) condemns; or if he (Levin) has seen and tried any, it must have been after a queer fashion, some Russian imitation, not a machine from abroad.

'' (Vronsky)

What sort of views can anyone have on such a subject?''
``Turkish views, in general,'' (Veslovsky/Vassenka Veslovsky/Vassenka)
Veslovsky said, turning to Anna with a smile.

I can't defend his (Levin) opinions,'' Darya Alexandrovna said, firing up;

``but I can say that he (Levin)'s a highly cultivated man, and if he (Levin) were here he (Levin) would know very well how to answer you, though I am not capable of doing so.'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)

Mais pardon, il est un petit peu toqu√©; he (Levin) maintains, for instance, that district councils and arbitration boards are all of no use, and he (Levin) is unwilling to take part in anything.

It's our Russian apathy,'' said Vronsky, pouring water from an iced decanter into a delicate glass on a high stem; ``we've no sense of the duties our privileges impose upon us, and so we refuse to recognize these duties.

``I know no man more strict in the performance of his (man) duties,'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna, irritated by Vronsky's tone of superiority.

For my part,'' pursued Vronsky, who was evidently for some reason or other keenly affected by this conversation,

``such as I am, I am, on the contrary, extremely grateful for the honor they have done me, thanks to Nikolay Ivanitch'' (Vronsky)
-LRB-he (Vronsky) indicated Sviazhsky-RRB-,
``in electing me a justice of the peace.

I consider that for me the duty of being present at the session, of judging some peasants' quarrel about a horse, is as important as anything I can do.

'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)

``I like him (Vronsky) extremely, and we are great friends,'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
Sviazhsky said, smiling good-naturedly. '' '' '' '' '' And I shall regard it as an honor if they elect me for the district council.

It's only in that way I can pay for the advantages I enjoy as a landowner. Unluckily they don't understand the weight that the big landowners ought to have in the state.

'' It was strange to Darya Alexandrovna to hear how serenely confident he (landowner) was of being right at his (landowner) own table.

She (we) thought how Levin, who believed the opposite, was just as positive in his (Levin) opinions at his (Levin) own table. But she (we) loved Levin, and so she (we) was on his (Levin) side.

'' So we can reckon upon you, count, for the coming elections?'' said Sviazhsky. '' But you must come a little beforehand, so as to be on the spot by the eighth.

``I rather agree with your beau-fr√®re,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna,
``though not quite on the same ground as he (Levin),'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
she (Anna) added with a smile.

If you would do me the honor to stop with me.'' '' I'm afraid that we have too many of these public duties in these latter days.

Just as in old days there were so many government functionaries that one had to call in a functionary for every single thing, so now everyone's doing some sort of public duty.

Alexey has been here now six months, and he (Alexey)'s a member, I do believe, of five or six different public bodies.

Du train que cela va, the whole time will be wasted on it. And I'm afraid that with such a multiplicity of these bodies, they'll end in being a mere form.

How many are you a member of, Nikolay Ivanitch? '' she (you) turned to Sviazhsky--

``over twenty, I fancy. '' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
Anna spoke lightly, but irritation could be discerned in her (Anna) tone.

Darya Alexandrovna, watching Anna and Vronsky attentively, detected it instantly. She (Anna) noticed, too, that as she (Anna) spoke Vronsky's face had immediately taken a serious and obstinate expression.

Noticing this, and that Princess Varvara at once made haste to change the conversation by talking of Petersburg acquaintances, and remembering what Vronsky had without apparent connection said in the garden of his (acquaintances) work in the country, Dolly surmised that this question of public activity was connected with some deep private disagreement between Anna and Vronsky.

The dinner, the wine, the decoration of the table were all very good; but it was all like what Darya Alexandrovna had seen at formal dinners and balls which of late years had become quite unfamiliar to her (Anna); it all had the same impersonal and constrained character, and so on an ordinary day and in a little circle of friends it made a disagreeable impression on her (Anna).

The players, divided into two parties, stood on opposite sides of a tightly drawn net with gilt poles on the carefully leveled and rolled croquet-ground.

Darya Alexandrovna made an attempt to play, but it was a long time before she (Anna) could understand the game, and by the time she (Anna) did understand it, she (Anna) was so tired that she (Anna) sat down with Princess Varvara and simply looked on at the players.

After dinner they sat on the terrace, then they proceeded to play lawn tennis. Her (Anna) partner, Tushkevitch, gave up playing too, but the others kept the game up for a long time.

They kept a sharp lookout on the balls served to them, and without haste or getting in each other's way, they ran adroitly up to them, waited for the rebound, and neatly and accurately returned them over the net.

Sviazhsky and Vronsky both played very well and seriously. Veslovsky played worse than the others. He (they) was too eager, but he (they) kept the players lively with his (they) high spirits.

Like the other men of the party, with the ladies' permission, he (they) took off his (they) coat, and his (they) solid, comely figure in his (they) white shirt-sleeves, with his (they) red perspiring face and his (they) impulsive movements, made a picture that imprinted itself vividly on the memory.

When Darya Alexandrovna lay in bed that night, as soon as she (Vronsky) closed her (Vronsky) eyes, she (Vronsky) saw Vassenka Veslovsky flying about the croquet ground.

She (Vronsky) did not like the light tone of raillery that was kept up all the time between Vassenka Veslovsky and Anna, and the unnaturalness altogether of grown-up people, all alone without children, playing at a child's game.

But to avoid breaking up the party and to get through the time somehow, after a rest she (Anna) joined the game again, and pretended to be enjoying it.

All that day it seemed to her (Anna) as though she (Anna) were acting in a theater with actors cleverer than she (Anna), and that her (Anna) bad acting was spoiling the whole performance.

His (child) laughter and outcries never paused. During the game Darya Alexandrovna was not enjoying herself. She (Anna) had come with the intention of staying two days, if all went well.

The maternal cares and worries, which she (Anna) had so hated on the way, now, after a day spent without them, struck her (Anna) in quite another light, and tempted her (Anna) back to them.

When, after evening tea and a row by night in the boat, Darya Alexandrovna went alone to her (Anna) room, took off her (Anna) dress, and began arranging her (Anna) thin hair for the night, she (Anna) had a great sense of relief.

But in the evening, during the game, she (Anna) made up her (Anna) mind that she (Anna) would go home next day. It was positively disagreeable to her (Anna) to think that Anna was coming to see her (Anna) immediately.

She (Anna) longed to be alone with her (Anna) own thoughts. Chapter 23 Dolly was wanting to go to bed when Anna came in to see her (Anna), attired for the night.

In the course of the day Anna had several times begun to speak of matters near her (Anna) heart, and every time after a few words she (Anna) had stopped:

``Afterwards, by ourselves, we'll talk about everything.

I've got so much I want to tell you,'' (she)

she (Anna) said. Now they were by themselves, and Anna did not know what to talk about.

She (Anna) sat in the window looking at Dolly, and going over in her (Dolly) own mind all the stores of intimate talk which had seemed so inexhaustible beforehand, and she (Dolly) found nothing.

At that moment it seemed to her (Dolly) that everything had been said already. '' Well, what of Kitty? '' she (Kitty) said with a heavy sigh, looking penitently at Dolly.

``Tell me the truth, Dolly: isn't she (Dolly) angry with me?'' (unknown)
``Angry? Oh, no! '' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
said Darya Alexandrovna, smiling. '' But she (Dolly) hates me, despises me?''

'' Oh, no! But you know that sort of thing isn't forgiven.'' '' Yes, yes,'' said Anna, turning away and looking out of the open window.

'' But I was not to blame. And who is to blame? What's the meaning of being to blame? Could it have been otherwise?

What do you think? Could it possibly have happened that you didn't become the wife of Stiva?''

``Really, I don't know.

But this is what I want you to tell me...'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

'' Yes, yes, but we've not finished about Kitty. Is she (Kitty) happy?

He (me)'s a very nice man, they say. '' '' He (me)'s much more than very nice. I don't know a better man.''

``Ah, how glad I am! I'm so glad! Much more than very nice,'' (she)
she (Kitty) repeated. Dolly smiled. '' But tell me about yourself.

We've a great deal to talk about. And I've had a talk with... '' Dolly did not know what to call him (man).

She (Dolly) felt it awkward to call him (man) either the count or Alexey Kirillovitch. '' With Alexey,'' said Anna,

``I know what you talked about.

But I wanted to ask you directly what you think of me, of my life?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

``How am I to say like that straight off?

But you mustn't forget that you're seeing us in the summer, when you have come to us and we are not alone....

But we came here early in the spring, lived quite alone, and shall be alone again, and I desire nothing better.

I really don't know. '' (me)

'' No, tell me all the same.... You see my life. But imagine me living alone without him (I), alone, and that will be...

I see by everything that it will often be repeated, that he (I) will be half the time away from home,'' she (you) said, getting up and sitting down close by Dolly.

'' Of course,'' she (Dolly) interrupted Dolly, who would have answered,

``of course I won't try to keep him (I) by force. I don't keep him (I) indeed.

The races are just coming, his (I) horses are running, he (I) will go. I'm very glad. But think of me, fancy my position....

But what's the use of talking about it? '' (Dolly)

She (Dolly) smiled. '' Well, what did he (I) talk about with you?'' ''

He (I) spoke of what I want to speak about of myself, and it's easy for me to be his (I) advocate; of whether there is not a possibility ...

whether you could not... '' -LRB-Darya Alexandrovna hesitated-RRB-

``Divorce, you mean?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna. '' Do you know, the only woman who came to see me in Petersburg was Betsy Tverskaya?

You know her (Tverskaya), of course? Au fond, c'est la femme la plus deprave√© qui existe. She (Tverskaya) had an intrigue with Tushkevitch, deceiving her (Tverskaya) husband in the basest way.

And she (Tverskaya) told me that she (Tverskaya) did not care to know me so long as my position was irregular. Don't imagine I would compare...

I know you, darling. But I could not help remembering.... Well, so what did he (husband) say to you? '' she (Tverskaya) repeated.

'' He (husband) said that he (husband) was unhappy on your account and his (husband) own. Perhaps you will say that it's egoism, but what a legitimate and noble egoism.

He (husband) wants first of all to legitimize his (husband) daughter, and to be your husband, to have a legal right to you.''

``What wife, what slave can be so utterly a slave as I, in my position? '' (she)
she (wife) put in gloomily. ''

The chief thing he (slave) desires...he (slave) desires that you should not suffer. '' '' That's impossible. Well?'' '' Well, and the most legitimate desire--he (slave) wishes that your children should have a name.

''

``What children? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

'' He (slave) need not trouble on that score; I shall have no more children. ''

``How can you tell that you won't?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

And, in spite of all her (Annie) emotion, Anna smiled, as she (Anna) caught the na√Øve expression of curiosity, wonder, and horror on Dolly's face.

'' I shall not, because I don't wish it. '' '' The doctor told me after my illness... ''

``Impossible!'' (me)
said Dolly, opening her (Dolly) eyes wide.

For her (Dolly) this was one of those discoveries the consequences and deductions from which are so immense that all that one feels for the first instant

is that it is impossible to take it all in, and that one will have to reflect a great, great deal upon it.

This discovery, suddenly throwing light on all those families of one or two children, which had hitherto been so incomprehensible to her (Dolly), aroused so many ideas, reflections, and contradictory emotions, that she (Dolly) had nothing to say, and simply gazed with wide-open eyes of wonder at Anna.

This was the very thing she (Anna) had been dreaming of, but now learning that it was possible, she (Anna) was horrified. She (Anna) felt that it was too simple a solution of too complicated a problem.

Think, I have a choice between two alternatives: either to be with child, that is an invalid, or to be the friend and companion of my husband--practically my husband,'' Anna said in a tone intentionally superficial and frivolous.

Yes, yes,'' said Darya Alexandrovna, hearing the very arguments she (Anna) had used to herself, and not finding the same force in them as before.

For you, for other people,'' said Anna, as though divining her (Anna) thoughts,

``there may be reason to hesitate; but for me...

'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

N'est-ce pas immoral? '' was all she (Anna) said, after a brief pause. '' Why so? '' '' You must consider, I am not his (I) wife; he (I) loves me as long as he (I) loves me.

She (wife) moved her (wife) white hands in a curve before her (wife) waist with extraordinary rapidity, as happens during moments of excitement; ideas and memories rushed into Darya Alexandrovna's head.

I,'' she (wife) thought,

``did not keep my attraction for Stiva; he (I) left me for others, and the first woman for whom he (I) betrayed me did not keep him (I) by being always pretty and lively.

And how am I to keep his (I) love? Not like this!'' (she)

'' He (I) deserted her (woman) and took another. And can Anna attract and keep Count Vronsky in that way?

And however white and beautiful her (Anna) bare arms are, however beautiful her (Anna) full figure and her (Anna) eager face under her (Anna) black curls, he (I) will find something better still, just as my disgusting, pitiful, and charming husband does.

If that is what he (husband) looks for, he (husband) will find dresses and manners still more attractive and charming. '' Dolly made no answer, she (Dolly) merely sighed.

Anna noticed this sigh, indicating dissent, and she (Anna) went on. In her (Anna) armory she (Anna) had other arguments so strong that no answer could be made to them.

'' Do you say that it's not right? But you must consider,'' she (Anna) went on;

``you forget my position. How can I desire children?

I'm not speaking of the suffering, I'm not afraid of that. Think only, what are my children to be? Ill-fated children, who will have to bear a stranger's name.

For the very fact of their birth they will be forced to be ashamed of their mother, their father, their birth.'' (she)

'' But that is just why a divorce is necessary. '' But Anna did not hear her (Anna). She (Anna) longed to give utterance to all the arguments with which she (Anna) had so many times convinced herself.

What is reason given me for, if I am not to use it to avoid bringing unhappy beings into the world!''

She (Anna) looked at Dolly, but without waiting for a reply she (Anna) went on:

``I should always feel I had wronged these unhappy children,'' (she)
she (Anna) said.

If they are not, at any rate they are not unhappy; while if they are unhappy, I alone should be to blame for it.

'' '' '' These were the very arguments Darya Alexandrovna had used in her (Anna) own reflections; but she (Anna) heard them without understanding them.

And all at once the idea struck her (Anna): could it possibly, under any circumstances, have been better for her (Anna) favorite Grisha if he (Anna) had never existed?

And this seemed to her (Anna) so wild, so strange, that she (Anna) shook her (Anna) head to drive away this tangle of whirling, mad ideas.

'' How can one wrong creatures that don't exist? '' she (Anna) thought. '' No, I don't know; it's not right,'' was all she (Anna) said, with an expression of disgust on her (Anna) face.

And besides that,'' added Anna, in spite of the wealth of her (Anna) arguments and the poverty of Dolly's objections, seeming still to admit that it was not right,

``don't forget the chief point, that I am not now in the same position as you.

'' (Dolly)

Yes, but you mustn't forget that you and I.... For you the question is: do you desire not to have any more children; while for me it is:

do I desire to have them? And that's a great difference. You must see that I can't desire it in my position.

She (Anna) suddenly felt that she (Anna) had got far away from Anna; that there lay between them a barrier of questions on which they could never agree, and about which it was better not to speak.

'' Darya Alexandrovna made no reply. Chapter 24 '' Then there is all the more reason for you to legalize your position, if possible,'' said Dolly.

'' Yes, if possible,'' said Anna, speaking all at once in an utterly different tone, subdued and mournful. '' Surely you don't mean a divorce is impossible?

I was told your husband had consented to it.''

``Dolly, I don't want to talk about that.'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)
'' Oh, we won't then,'' Darya Alexandrovna hastened to say, noticing the expression of suffering on Anna's face.

'' All I see is that you take too gloomy a view of things.''

``I? Not at all! I'm always bright and happy.

You see, je fais des passions. Veslovsky...'' (I)

'' Yes, to tell the truth, I don't like Veslovsky's tone,'' said Darya Alexandrovna, anxious to change the subject.

'' Oh, that's nonsense! It amuses Alexey, and that's all; but he (Alexey)'s a boy, and quite under my control. You know, I turn him (Alexey) as I please.

It's just as it might be with your Grisha.... Dolly!''-- she (boy) suddenly changed the subject--

``you say I take too gloomy a view of things.

You can't understand. It's too awful! I try not to take any view of it at all.'' (she)

'' But I think you ought to.

You ought to do all you can.'' '' But what can I do? Nothing. You tell me to marry Alexey, and say I don't think about it.

I don't think about it! '' she (boy) repeated, and a flush rose into her (boy) face. She (boy) got up, straightening her (boy) chest, and sighed heavily.

With her (boy) light step she (boy) began pacing up and down the room, stopping now and then. '' I don't think of it?

Not a day, not an hour passes that I don't think of it, and blame myself for thinking of it...because thinking of that may drive me mad.

Drive me mad!'' she (boy) repeated. '' When I think of it, I can't sleep without morphine. But never mind. Let us talk quietly.

They tell me, divorce. In the first place, he (it) won't give me a divorce. He (it)'s under the influence of Countess Lidia Ivanovna now.

'' Darya Alexandrovna, sitting erect on a chair, turned her (Ivanovna) head, following Anna with a face of sympathetic suffering. '' You ought to make the attempt,'' she (Ivanovna) said softly.

'' Suppose I make the attempt. What does it mean? '' she (Ivanovna) said, evidently giving utterance to a thought, a thousand times thought over and learned by heart.

It means that I, hating him (it), but still recognizing that I have wronged him (it)--and I consider him (it) magnanimous--that I humiliate myself to write to him (it)...

'' Well, suppose I make the effort; I do it. Either I receive a humiliating refusal or consent.... Well, I have received his (it) consent, say...

'' Anna was at that moment at the furthest end of the room, and she (Anna) stopped there, doing something to the curtain at the window.

'' I receive his (it) consent, but my...my son? They won't give him (it) up to me. He (it) will grow up despising me, with his (it) father, whom I've abandoned.

She (Anna) came out into the middle of the room and stood facing Dolly, with her (Dolly) arms pressed tightly across her (Dolly) chest.

Do you see, I love... equally, I think, but both more than myself--two creatures, Seryozha and Alexey. '' In her (Dolly) white dressing gown her (Dolly) figure seemed more than usually grand and broad.

She (Dolly) bent her (Dolly) head, and with shining, wet eyes looked from under her (Dolly) brows at Dolly, a thin little pitiful figure in her (Dolly) patched dressing jacket and nightcap, shaking all over with emotion.

'' It is only those two creatures that I love, and one excludes the other. I can't have them together, and that's the only thing I want.

And since I can't have that, I don't care about the rest. I don't care about anything, anything. And it will end one way or another, and

so I can't, I don't like to talk of it. So don't blame me, don't judge me for anything. You can't with your pure heart understand all that I'm suffering.

'' She (I) went up, sat down beside Dolly, and with a guilty look, peeped into her (Dolly) face and took her (Dolly) hand.

'' What are you thinking? What are you thinking about me? Don't despise me. I don't deserve contempt. I'm simply unhappy.

If anyone is unhappy, I am,'' she (Dolly) articulated, and turning away, she (Dolly) burst into tears. Left alone, Darya Alexandrovna said her (Dolly) prayers and went to bed.

She (Dolly) had felt for Anna with all her (Dolly) heart while she (Dolly) was speaking to her (Dolly), but now she (Dolly) could not force herself to think of her (Dolly).

The memories of home and of her (Dolly) children rose up in her (Dolly) imagination with a peculiar charm quite new to her (Dolly), with a sort of new brilliance.

That world of her (Dolly) own seemed to her (Dolly) now so sweet and precious that she (Dolly) would not on any account spend an extra day outside it, and she (Dolly) made up her (Dolly) mind that she (Dolly) would certainly go back next day.

Anna meantime went back to her (Anna) boudoir, took a wine glass and dropped into it several drops of a medicine, of which the principal ingredient was morphine.

After drinking it off and sitting still a little while, she (Anna) went into her (Anna) bedroom in a soothed and more cheerful frame of mind.

He (it) was looking for traces of the conversation which he (it) knew that, staying so long in Dolly's room, she (Dolly) must have had with her (Dolly).

But in her (Dolly) expression of restrained excitement, and of a sort of reserve, he (it) could find nothing but the beauty that always bewitched him (it) afresh though he (it) was used to it, the consciousness of it, and the desire that it should affect him (it).

He (it) did not want to ask her (Dolly) what they had been talking of, but he (it) hoped that she (Dolly) would tell him (it) something of her (Dolly) own accord.

When she (Dolly) went into the bedroom, Vronsky looked intently at her (Dolly). But she (Dolly) only said:

``I am so glad you like Dolly.

You do, don't you?'' (she)

'' Oh, I've known her (Dolly) a long while, you know. She (Dolly)'s very good-hearted, I suppose, mais excessivement terre-√†-terre.

Still, I'm very glad to see her (Dolly). '' He (it) took Anna's hand and looked inquiringly into her (Anna) eyes. Misinterpreting the look, she (Anna) smiled to him (it).

Levin's coachman, in his (Levin) by no means new coat and shabby hat, with his (Levin) ill-matched horses and his (Levin) coach with the patched mud-guards, drove with gloomy determination into the covered gravel approach.

Next morning, in spite of the protests of her (Anna) hosts, Darya Alexandrovna prepared for her (Anna) homeward journey. Darya Alexandrovna disliked taking leave of Princess Varvara and the gentlemen of the party.

After a day spent together, both she (Princess) and her (Princess) hosts were distinctly aware that they did not get on together, and that it was better for them not to meet.

She (Princess) knew that now, from Dolly's departure, no one again would stir up within her (Dolly) soul the feelings that had been roused by their conversation.

It hurt her (Dolly) to stir up these feelings, but yet she (Dolly) knew that that was the best part of her (Dolly) soul, and that that part of her (Dolly) soul would quickly be smothered in the life she (Dolly) was leading.

As she (Dolly) drove out into the open country, Darya Alexandrovna had a delightful sense of relief, and she (Dolly) felt tempted to ask the two men how they had liked being at Vronsky's, when suddenly the coachman, Philip, expressed himself unasked:

``Rolling in wealth they may be, but three pots of oats was all they gave us.

Only Anna was sad. Everything cleared up till there wasn't a grain left by cockcrow. What are three pots? A mere mouthful!

And oats now down to forty-five kopecks. At our place, no fear, all comers may have as much as they can eat.'' (Philip)

``The master's a screw,'' (the house clerk)
put in the counting house clerk. '' Well, did you like their horses? '' asked Dolly. ''

The horses!--there's no two opinions about them. And the food was good. But it seemed to me sort of dreary there, Darya Alexandrovna.

I don't know what you thought,'' he (master) said, turning his (master) handsome, good-natured face to her (Dolly). '' I thought so too. Well, shall we get home by evening?''

On reaching home and finding everyone entirely satisfactory and particularly charming, Darya Alexandrovna began with great liveliness telling them how she (Dolly) had arrived, how warmly they had received her (Dolly), of the luxury and good taste in which the Vronskys lived, and of their recreations, and she (Dolly) would not allow a word to be said against them.

One has to know Anna and Vronsky--I have got to know him (master) better now--to see how nice they are, and how touching,'' she (Anna) said, speaking now with perfect sincerity, and forgetting the vague feeling of dissatisfaction and awkwardness she (Anna) had experienced there.

Chapter 25 Vronsky and Anna spent the whole summer and part of the winter in the country, living in just the same condition, and still taking no steps to obtain a divorce.

It was an understood thing between them that they should not go away anywhere; but both felt, the longer they lived alone, especially in the autumn, without guests in the house, that they could not stand this existence, and that they would have to alter it.

``Eh, we must!'' (unknown)
'' Their life was apparently such that nothing better could be desired. They had the fullest abundance of everything; they had a child, and both had occupation.

Anna devoted just as much care to her (Anna) appearance when they had no visitors, and she (Anna) did a great deal of reading, both of novels and of what serious literature was in fashion.

She (Anna) ordered all the books that were praised in the foreign papers and reviews she (Anna) received, and read them with that concentrated attention which is only given to what is read in seclusion.

Moreover, every subject that was of interest to Vronsky, she (Anna) studied in books and special journals, so that he (they) often went straight to her (Anna) with questions relating to agriculture or architecture, sometimes even with questions relating to horse-breeding or sport.

He (they) was amazed at her (Anna) knowledge, her (Anna) memory, and at first was disposed to doubt it, to ask for confirmation of her (Anna) facts; and she (Anna) would find what he (they) asked for in some book, and show it to him (they).

The building of the hospital, too, interested her (Anna). She (Anna) did not merely assist, but planned and suggested a great deal herself.

But her (Anna) chief thought was still of herself--how far she (Anna) was dear to Vronsky, how far she (Anna) could make up to him (Vronsky) for all he (Vronsky) had given up.

Vronsky appreciated this desire not only to please, but to serve him (Vronsky), which had become the sole aim of her (Anna) existence, but at the same time he (Vronsky) wearied of the loving snares in which she (Anna) tried to hold him (Vronsky) fast.

As time went on, and he (Vronsky) saw himself more and more often held fast in these snares, he (Vronsky) had an ever growing desire, not so much to escape from them, as to try whether they hindered his (Vronsky) freedom.

Had it not been for this growing desire to be free, not to have scenes every time he (Vronsky) wanted to go to the town to a meeting or a race, Vronsky would have been perfectly satisfied with his (Vronsky) life.

The r√¥le he (Vronsky) had taken up, the r√¥le of a wealthy landowner, one of that class which ought to be the very heart of the Russian aristocracy, was entirely to his (Vronsky) taste; and now, after spending six months in that character, he (Vronsky) derived even greater satisfaction from it.

In spite of the immense sums cost him (Vronsky) by the hospital, by machinery, by cows ordered from Switzerland, and many other things, he (Vronsky) was convinced that he (Vronsky) was not wasting, but increasing his (Vronsky) substance.

In all matters affecting income, the sales of timber, wheat, and wool, the letting of lands, Vronsky was hard as a rock, and knew well how to keep up prices.

In all operations on a large scale on this and his (Vronsky) other estates, he (Vronsky) kept to the simplest methods involving no risk, and in trifling details he (Vronsky) was careful and exacting to an extreme degree.

In spite of all the cunning and ingenuity of the German steward, who would try to tempt him (steward) into purchases by making his (steward) original estimate always far larger than really required, and then representing to Vronsky that he (steward) might get the thing cheaper, and so make a profit, Vronsky did not give in.

He (Vronsky) listened to his (Vronsky) steward, cross-examined him (Vronsky), and only agreed to his (Vronsky) suggestions when the implement to be ordered or constructed was the very newest, not yet known in Russia, and likely to excite wonder.

Apart from such exceptions, he (Vronsky) resolved upon an increased outlay only where there was a surplus, and in making such an outlay he (Vronsky) went into the minutest details, and insisted on getting the very best for his (Vronsky) money; so that by the method on which he (Vronsky) managed his (Vronsky) affairs, it was clear that he (Vronsky) was not wasting, but increasing his (Vronsky) substance.

In October there were the provincial elections in the Kashinsky province, where were the estates of Vronsky, Sviazhsky, Koznishev, Oblonsky, and a small part of Levin's land.

These elections were attracting public attention from several circumstances connected with them, and also from the people taking part in them.

And his (Levin) management of his (Levin) estate, which occupied and absorbed him (Levin) more and more, was most successful. There had been a great deal of talk about them, and great preparations were being made for them.

Persons who never attended the elections were coming from Moscow, from Petersburg, and from abroad to attend these. Vronsky had long before promised Sviazhsky to go to them.

Before the elections Sviazhsky, who often visited Vozdvizhenskoe, drove over to fetch Vronsky. On the day before there had been almost a quarrel between Vronsky and Anna over this proposed expedition.

It was the very dullest autumn weather, which is so dreary in the country, and so, preparing himself for a struggle, Vronsky, with a hard and cold expression, informed Anna of his (Vronsky) departure as he (Vronsky) had never spoken to her (Anna) before.

But, to his (Vronsky) surprise, Anna accepted the information with great composure, and merely asked when he (Vronsky) would be back. He (Vronsky) looked intently at her (Anna), at a loss to explain this composure.

He (Vronsky) knew that way she (Anna) had of withdrawing into herself, and knew that it only happened when she (Anna) had determined upon something without letting him (Vronsky) know her (Anna) plans.

He (Vronsky) was afraid of this; but he (Vronsky) was so anxious to avoid a scene that he (Vronsky) kept up appearances, and half sincerely believed in what he (Vronsky) longed to believe in--her (Anna) reasonableness.

She (Anna) smiled at his (Vronsky) look. '' I hope you won't be dull?''

``I hope not,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna. '' I got a box of books yesterday from Gautier's.

She (Anna)'s trying to take that tone, and so much the better,'' he (Vronsky) thought,

``or else it would be the same thing over and over again.

No, I shan't be dull. '' (he)

'' '' And he (Vronsky) set off for the elections without appealing to her (Anna) for a candid explanation.

It was the first time since the beginning of their intimacy that he (Vronsky) had parted from her (Anna) without a full explanation.

From one point of view this troubled him (Vronsky), but on the other side he (Vronsky) felt that it was better so. ''

At first there will be, as this time, something undefined kept back, and then she (Anna) will get used to it. In any case I can give up anything for her (Anna), but not my masculine independence,'' he (Vronsky) thought.

He (Vronsky) had spent a whole month in Moscow with nothing to do, when Sergey Ivanovitch, who had property in the Kashinsky province, and took great interest in the question of the approaching elections, made ready to set off to the elections.

Chapter 26 In September Levin moved to Moscow for Kitty's confinement. He (Levin) invited his (Levin) brother, who had a vote in the Seleznevsky district, to come with him (Levin).

Levin had, moreover, to transact in Kashin some extremely important business relating to the wardship of land and to the receiving of certain redemption money for his (Levin) sister, who was abroad.

Levin still hesitated, but Kitty, who saw that he (Levin) was bored in Moscow, and urged him (Levin) to go, on her (Kitty) own authority ordered him (Levin) the proper nobleman's uniform, costing seven pounds.

And that seven pounds paid for the uniform was the chief cause that finally decided Levin to go. He (Levin) went to Kashin....

Levin had been six days in Kashin, visiting the assembly each day, and busily engaged about his (Levin) sister's business, which still dragged on.

The district marshals of nobility were all occupied with the elections, and it was impossible to get the simplest thing done that depended upon the court of wardship.

After long negotiations over the legal details, the money was at last ready to be paid; but the notary, a most obliging person, could not hand over the order, because it must have the signature of the president, and the president, though he (president) had not given over his (president) duties to a deputy, was at the elections.

All these worrying negotiations, this endless going from place to place, and talking with pleasant and excellent people, who quite saw the unpleasantness of the petitioner's position, but were powerless to assist him (petitioner)--all these efforts that yielded no result, led to a feeling of misery in Levin akin to the mortifying helplessness

The other matter, the payment of the sums due, was met too by difficulties. one experiences in dreams when one tries to use physical force.

He (Levin) felt this frequently as he (Levin) talked to his (Levin) most good-natured solicitor. This solicitor did, it seemed, everything possible, and strained every nerve to get him (Levin) out of his (Levin) difficulties.

I tell you what you might try,'' he (Levin) said more than once;

``go to so-and-so and so-and-so,'' (he)
and the solicitor drew up a regular plan for getting round the fatal point that hindered everything.

'' But he (solicitor) would add immediately,

``It'll mean some delay, anyway, but you might try it. '' (he)
And Levin did try, and did go.

Everyone was kind and civil, but the point evaded seemed to crop up again in the end, and again to bar the way.

What was particularly trying, was that Levin could not make out with whom he (Levin) was struggling, to whose interest it was that his (Levin) business should not be done.

If Levin could have understood why, just as he (Levin) saw why one can only approach the booking office of a railway station in single file, it would not have been so vexatious and tiresome to him (Levin).

That no one seemed to know; the solicitor certainly did not know. But with the hindrances that confronted him (solicitor) in his (solicitor) business, no one could explain why they existed.

But Levin had changed a good deal since his (Levin) marriage; he (Levin) was patient, and if he (Levin) could not see why it was all arranged like this, he (Levin) told himself that he (Levin) could not judge without knowing all about it, and that most likely it must be so, and he (Levin) tried not to fret.

In attending the elections, too, and taking part in them, he (Levin) tried now not to judge, not to fall foul of them, but to comprehend as fully as he (Levin) could the question which was so earnestly and ardently absorbing honest and excellent men whom he (Levin) respected.

Since his (Levin) marriage there had been revealed to Levin so many new and serious aspects of life that had previously, through his (Levin) frivolous attitude to them, seemed of no importance, that in the question of the elections too he (Levin) assumed and tried to find some serious significance.

The marshal of the province in whose hands the law had placed the control of so many important public functions--the guardianship of wards -LRB-the very department which was giving Levin so much trouble just now-RRB-, the disposal of large sums subscribed by the nobility of the province, the high schools, female, male, and military, and popular instruction on the new model, and finally, the district council--the marshal of the province, Snetkov, was a nobleman of the old school,--dissipating an immense fortune, a good-hearted man, honest after his (man) own fashion, but utterly without any comprehension of the needs of modern days.

He (man) always took, in every question, the side of the nobility; he (man) was positively antagonistic to the spread of popular education, and he (man) succeeded in giving a purely party character to the district council which ought by rights to be of such an immense importance.

What was needed was to put in his (man) place a fresh, capable, perfectly modern man, of contemporary ideas, and to frame their policy so as from the rights conferred upon the nobles, not as the nobility, but as an element of the district council, to extract all the powers of self-government that could possibly be derived from them.

In the wealthy Kashinsky province, which always took the lead of other provinces in everything, there was now such a preponderance of forces that this policy, once carried through properly there, might serve as a model for other provinces for all Russia.

Sergey Ivanovitch explained to him (Ivanovitch) the meaning and object of the proposed revolution at the elections. And hence the whole question was of the greatest importance.

It was proposed to elect as marshal in place of Snetkov either Sviazhsky, or, better still, Nevyedovsky, a former university professor, a man of remarkable intelligence and a great friend of Sergey Ivanovitch.

The meeting was opened by the governor, who made a speech to the nobles, urging them to elect the public functionaries, not from regard for persons, but for the service and welfare of their fatherland, and hoping that the honorable nobility of the Kashinsky province would, as at all former elections, hold their duty as sacred, and vindicate the exalted confidence of the monarch.

When he (monarch) had finished with his (monarch) speech, the governor walked out of the hall, and the noblemen noisily and eagerly--some even enthusiastically--followed him (monarch) and thronged round him (monarch) while he (monarch) put on his (monarch) fur coat and conversed amicably with the marshal of the province.

Levin, anxious to see into everything and not to miss anything, stood there too in the crowd, and heard the governor say: ``Please tell Marya Ivanovna my wife is very sorry she (wife) couldn't come to the Home.

In the cathedral Levin, lifting his (Levin) hand like the rest and repeating the words of the archdeacon, swore with most terrible oaths to do all the governor had hoped they would do.

Church services always affected Levin, and as he (Levin) uttered the words

``I kiss the cross,'' (he)
and glanced round at the crowd of young and old men repeating the same, he (Levin) felt touched.

On the second and third days there was business relating to the finances of the nobility and the female high school, of no importance

'' And thereupon the nobles in high good-humor sorted out their fur coats and all drove off to the cathedral. whatever, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained, and Levin, busy seeing after his (Ivanovitch) own affairs, did not attend the meetings.

On the fourth day the auditing of the marshal's accounts took place at the high table of the marshal of the province.

And then there occurred the first skirmish between the new party and the old. The committee who had been deputed to verify the accounts reported to the meeting that all was in order.

The marshal of the province got up, thanked the nobility for their confidence, and shed tears. The nobles gave him (marshal) a loud welcome, and shook hands with him (marshal).

But at that instant a nobleman of Sergey Ivanovitch's party said that he (Ivanovitch) had heard that the committee had not verified the accounts, considering such a verification an insult to the marshal of the province.

Then a small gentleman, very young-looking but very malignant, began to say that it would probably be agreeable to the marshal of the province to give an account of his (marshal) expenditures of the public moneys, and that the misplaced delicacy of the members of the committee was depriving him (marshal) of this moral satisfaction.

Then the members of the committee tried to withdraw their admission, and Sergey Ivanovitch began to prove that they must logically admit either that they had verified the accounts or that they had not, and he (Ivanovitch) developed this dilemma in detail.

One of the members of the committee incautiously admitted this. Sergey Ivanovitch was answered by the spokesman of the opposite party.

Levin was surprised that they should dispute upon this subject so long, especially as, when he (Levin) asked Sergey Ivanovitch whether he (Ivanovitch) supposed that money had been misappropriated, Sergey Ivanovitch answered:

``Oh, no!

Then Sviazhsky spoke, and then the malignant gentleman again. The discussion lasted a long time and ended in nothing. He (Ivanovitch)'s an honest man.

But those old-fashioned methods of paternal family arrangements in the management of provincial affairs must be broken down. '' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

On the fifth day came the elections of the district marshals.

It was rather a stormy day in several districts. In the Seleznevsky district Sviazhsky was elected unanimously without a ballot, and he (Ivanovitch) gave a dinner that evening.

Chapter 27 The sixth day was fixed for the election of the marshal of the province. The rooms, large and small, were full of noblemen in all sorts of uniforms.

Men who had not seen each other for years, some from the Crimea, some from Petersburg, some from abroad, met in the rooms of the Hall of Nobility.

Many had come only for that day. There was much discussion around the governor's table under the portrait of the Tsar.

The nobles, both in the larger and the smaller rooms, grouped themselves in camps, and from their hostile and suspicious glances, from the silence that fell upon them when outsiders approached a group, and from the way that some, whispering together, retreated to the farther corridor, it was evident that each side had secrets from the other.

The old were for the most part either in old uniforms of the nobility, buttoned up closely, with spurs and hats, or in their own special naval, cavalry, infantry, or official uniforms.

The uniforms of the older men were embroidered in the old-fashioned way with epaulets on their shoulders; they were unmistakably tight and short in the waist, as though their wearers had grown out of them.

The younger men wore the uniform of the nobility with long waists and broad shoulders, unbuttoned over white waistcoats, or uniforms with black collars and with the embroidered badges of justices of the peace.

In appearance the noblemen were sharply divided into two classes: the old and the new. To the younger men belonged the court uniforms that here and there brightened up the crowd.

Some of the young men, as Levin observed, belonged to the old party; and some of the very oldest noblemen, on the contrary, were whispering with Sviazhsky, and were evidently ardent partisans of the new party.

Levin stood in the smaller room, where they were smoking and taking light refreshments, close to his (Levin) own friends, and listening to what they were saying, he (Levin) conscientiously exerted all his (Levin) intelligence trying to understand what was said.

But the division into young and old did not correspond with the division of parties. Sergey Ivanovitch was the center round which the others grouped themselves.

Hliustov would not agree to go with his (Ivanovitch) district to ask Snetkov to stand, while Sviazhsky was persuading him (Ivanovitch) to do so, and Sergey Ivanovitch was approving of the plan.

He (Ivanovitch) was listening at that moment to Sviazhsky and Hliustov, the marshal of another district, who belonged to their party. Levin could not make out why the opposition was to ask the marshal to stand whom they wanted to supersede.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just been drinking and taking some lunch, came up to them in his (Levin) uniform of a gentleman of the bedchamber, wiping his (Levin) lips with a perfumed handkerchief of bordered batiste.

'' We are placing our forces,'' he (Levin) said, pulling out his (Levin) whiskers,

``Sergey Ivanovitch!'' (he)
And listening to the conversation, he (Levin) supported Sviazhsky's contention.

'' One district's enough, and Sviazhsky's obviously of the opposition,'' he (Levin) said, words evidently intelligible to all except Levin. '' Why, Kostya, you here too!

Levin would have been glad indeed to be converted, but could not make out what the point was, and retreating a few steps from the speakers, he (Levin) explained to Stepan Arkadyevitch his (Levin) inability to understand why the marshal of the province should be asked to stand.

I suppose you're converted, eh?'' he (marshal) added, turning to Levin and drawing his (Levin) arm through his (Levin). '' O sancta simplicitas!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and briefly and clearly he (Levin) explained it to Levin.

If, as at previous elections, all the districts asked the marshal of the province to stand, then he (marshal) would be elected without a ballot.

Now eight districts had agreed to call upon him (marshal): if two refused to do so, Snetkov might decline to stand at all; and then the old party might choose another of their party, which would throw them completely out in their reckoning.

That must not be. But if only one district, Sviazhsky's, did not call upon him (marshal) to stand, Snetkov would let himself be balloted for.

They were even, some of them, going to vote for him (marshal), and purposely to let him (marshal) get a good many votes, so that the enemy might be thrown off the scent, and when a candidate of the other side was put up, they too might give him (candidate) some votes.

Levin understood to some extent, but not fully, and would have put a few more questions, when suddenly everyone began talking and making a noise and they moved towards the big room.

'' What is it? eh? whom?''

``No guarantee? whose? what?'' (him)
'' They won't pass him (Levin)?''
``No guarantee?'' (Flerov)
'' They won't let Flerov in?''

'' Eh, because of the charge against him (Levin)?''

``Why, at this rate, they won't admit anyone. It's a swindle!'' (unknown)
``The law!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Levin heard exclamations on all sides, and he (Levin) moved into the big room together with the others, all hurrying somewhere and afraid of missing something.

Squeezed by the crowding noblemen, he (Levin) drew near the high table where the marshal of the province, Sviazhsky, and the other leaders were hotly disputing about something.

A nobleman breathing heavily and hoarsely at his (nobleman) side, and another whose thick boots were creaking, prevented him (nobleman) from hearing distinctly.

He (nobleman) could only hear the soft voice of the marshal faintly, then the shrill voice of the malignant gentleman, and then the voice of Sviazhsky.

They were disputing, as far as he (gentleman) could make out, as to the interpretation to be put on the act and the exact meaning of the words:

``liable to be called up for trial.

Chapter 28 Levin was standing rather far off. '' (he)

The crowd parted to make way for Sergey Ivanovitch approaching the table.

Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till the malignant gentleman had finished speaking, said that he (Ivanovitch) thought the best solution would be to refer to the act itself, and asked the secretary to find the act.

Sergey Ivanovitch read the act and began to explain its meaning, but at that point a tall, stout, round-shouldered landowner, with dyed whiskers, in a tight uniform that cut the back of his (landowner) neck, interrupted him (landowner).

The act said that in case of difference of opinion, there must be a ballot. He (landowner) went up to the table, and striking it with his (landowner) finger ring, he (landowner) shouted loudly:

Then several voices began to talk all at once, and the tall nobleman with the ring, getting more and more exasperated, shouted more and more loudly.

``A ballot! Put it to the vote! No need for more talking!'' (he)
But it was impossible to make out what he (nobleman) said.

He (nobleman) was shouting for the very course Sergey Ivanovitch had proposed; but it was evident that he (Ivanovitch) hated him (Ivanovitch) and all his (Ivanovitch) party, and this feeling of hatred spread through the whole party and roused in opposition to it the same vindictiveness, though in a more seemly form, on the other side.

Shouts were raised, and for a moment all was confusion, so that the marshal of the province had to call for order.

'' A ballot! A ballot! Every nobleman sees it! We shed our blood for our country!... The confidence of the monarch....

No checking the accounts of the marshal; he (marshal)'s not a cashier.... But that's not the point.... Votes, please! Beastly!...'' shouted furious and violent voices on all sides.

Levin did not in the least understand what was the matter, and he (Levin) marveled at the passion with which it was disputed whether or not the decision about Flerov should be put to the vote.

He (Levin) forgot, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained to him (Ivanovitch) afterwards, this syllogism: that it was necessary for the public good to get rid of the marshal of the province; that to get rid of the marshal it was necessary to have a majority of votes; that to get a majority of votes it was necessary to secure Flerov's right to vote; that to secure the recognition of Flerov's right to vote they must decide on the interpretation to be put on the act.

And one vote may decide the whole question, and one must be serious and consecutive, if one wants to be of use in public life,'' concluded Sergey Ivanovitch.

But Levin forgot all that, and it was painful to him (Ivanovitch) to see all these excellent persons, for whom he (Ivanovitch) had a respect, in such an unpleasant and vicious state of excitement.

To escape from this painful feeling he (Ivanovitch) went away into the other room where there was nobody except the waiters at the refreshment bar.

Seeing the waiters busy over washing up the crockery and setting in order their plates and wine glasses, seeing their calm and cheerful faces, Levin felt an unexpected sense of relief as though he (Levin) had come out of a stuffy room into the fresh air.

Looks and faces were even more violent and furious than their words. They expressed the most implacable hatred. '' He (Levin) began walking up and down, looking with pleasure at the waiters.

one gray-whiskered waiter, who showed his (waiter) scorn for the other younger ones and was jeered at by them, was teaching them how to fold up napkins properly.

Levin was just about to enter into conversation with the old waiter, when the secretary of the court of wardship, a little old man whose specialty it was to know all the noblemen of the province by name and patronymic, drew him (man) away.

He (man) particularly liked the way '' Please come, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,'' he (Dmitrievitch) said, ``your brother's looking for you. They are voting on the legal point.

Levin walked into the room, received a white ball, and followed his (Levin) brother, Sergey Ivanovitch, to the table where Sviazhsky was standing with a significant and ironical face, holding his (Levin) beard in his (Levin) fist and sniffing at it.

Levin advanced, but utterly forgetting what he (Levin) was to do, and much embarrassed, he (Levin) turned to Sergey Ivanovitch with the question,

``Where am I to put it?'' (Sergey Ivanovitch/Koznishev/Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev)

He (Ivanovitch) asked this softly, at a moment when there was talking going on near, so that he (Ivanovitch) had hoped his (Ivanovitch) question would not be overheard.

'' Sergey Ivanovitch put his (Ivanovitch) hand into the box, put the ball somewhere, and making room for Levin, stopped. But the persons speaking paused, and his (Levin) improper question was overheard.

Levin crimsoned, hurriedly thrust his (Levin) hand under the cloth, and put the ball to the right as it was in his (Levin) right hand.

Having put it in, he (Levin) recollected that he (Levin) ought to have thrust his (Levin) left hand too, and so he (Levin) thrust it in though too late, and, still more overcome with confusion

Sergey Ivanovitch frowned. '' That is a matter for each man's own decision,'' he (Ivanovitch) said severely. Several people smiled. , he (Ivanovitch) beat a hasty retreat into the background.

'' A hundred and twenty-six for admission! Ninety-eight against!'' sang out the voice of the secretary, who could not pronounce the letter r .

Then there was a laugh; a button and two nuts were found in the box. The nobleman was allowed the right to vote, and the new party had conquered.

Levin heard that they were asking Snetkov to stand, and he (Levin) saw that a crowd of noblemen was surrounding the marshal, who was saying something.

In reply Snetkov spoke of the trust the noblemen of the province had placed in him (Levin), the affection they had shown him (Levin), which he (Levin) did not deserve, as his (Levin) only merit had been his (Levin) attachment to the nobility, to whom he (Levin) had devoted twelve years of service.

Several times he (Levin) repeated the words:

``I have served to the best of my powers with truth and good faith, I value your goodness and thank you,'' (he)
and suddenly he (Levin) stopped short from the tears that choked him (Levin), and went out of the room.

Whether these tears came from a sense of the injustice being done him (Levin), from his (Levin) love for the nobility, or from the strain of the position he (Levin) was placed in, feeling himself surrounded by enemies, his (Levin) emotion infected the assembly, the majority were touched, and Levin felt a tenderness for Snetkov.

But the old party did not consider themselves conquered. Levin went nearer. In the doorway the marshal of the province jostled against Levin.

'' Beg pardon, excuse me, please,'' he (Levin) said as to a stranger, but recognizing Levin, he (Levin) smiled timidly. It seemed to Levin that he (Levin) would have liked to say something, but could not speak for emotion.

His (Levin) face and his (Levin) whole figure in his (Levin) uniform with the crosses, and white trousers striped with braid, as he (Levin) moved hurriedly along, reminded Levin of some hunted beast who sees that he (Levin) is in evil case.

This expression in the marshal's face was particularly touching to Levin, because, only the day before, he (Levin) had been at his (Levin) house about his (Levin) trustee business and had seen him (Levin) in all his (Levin) grandeur, a kind-hearted, fatherly man.

The big house with the old family furniture; the rather dirty, far from stylish, but respectful footmen, unmistakably old house serfs who had stuck to their master; the stout, good-natured wife in a cap with lace and a Turkish shawl, petting her (wife) pretty grandchild, her (wife) daughter's daughter; the young son, a sixth form high school boy, coming home from school, and greeting his (boy) father, kissing his (boy) big hand; the genuine, cordial words and gestures of the old man--all this had the day before roused an instinctive feeling of respect and sympathy in Levin.

This old man was a touching and pathetic figure to Levin now, and he (Levin) longed to say something pleasant to him (Levin).

'' So you're sure to be our marshal again,'' he (marshal) said. '' It's not likely,'' said the marshal, looking round with a scared expression.

'' I'm worn out, I'm old. If there are men younger and more deserving than I, let them serve. '' And the marshal disappeared through a side door.

The most solemn moment was at hand. They were to proceed immediately to the election. The leaders of both parties were reckoning white and black on their fingers.

The discussion upon Flerov had given the new party not only Flerov's vote, but had also gained time for them, so that they could send to fetch three noblemen who had been rendered unable to take part in the elections by the wiles of the other party.

Two noble gentlemen, who had a weakness for strong drink, had been made drunk by the partisans of Snetkov, and a third had been robbed of his (Flerov) uniform.

On learning this, the new party had made haste, during the dispute about Flerov, to send some of their men in a sledge to clothe the stripped gentleman, and to bring along one of the intoxicated to the meeting.

'' I've brought one, drenched him (gentleman) with water,'' said the landowner, who had gone on this errand, to Sviazhsky. '' He (landowner)'s all right?

he (landowner)'ll do. ''

``Not too drunk, he (landowner) won't fall down?'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
said Sviazhsky, shaking his (landowner) head. '' No, he (landowner)'s first-rate. If only they don't give him (landowner) any more here....

I've told the waiter not to give him (waiter) anything on any account. '' Chapter 29 The narrow room, in which they were smoking and taking refreshments, was full of noblemen.

The excitement was specially keen for the leaders of each party, who knew every detail, and had reckoned up every vote.

The rest, like the rank and file before an engagement, though they were getting ready for the fight, sought for other distractions in the interval.

Some were lunching, standing at the bar, or sitting at the table; others were walking up and down the long room, smoking cigarettes, and talking with friends whom they had not seen for a long while.

Levin did not care to eat, and he (Levin) was not smoking; he (Levin) did not want to join his (Levin) own friends, that is Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch, Sviazhsky and the rest, because Vronsky in his (Ivanovitch) equerry's uniform was standing with them in eager conversation.

Levin had seen him (Levin) already at the meeting on the previous day, and he (Levin) had studiously avoided him (Levin), not caring to greet him (Levin).

The excitement grew more intense, and every face betrayed some uneasiness. They were the generals organizing the approaching battle. He (Levin) went to the window and sat down, scanning the groups, and listening to what was being said around him (Levin).

He (Levin) felt depressed, especially because everyone else was, as he (Levin) saw, eager, anxious, and interested, and he (Levin) alone, with an old, toothless little man with mumbling lips wearing a naval uniform, sitting beside him (man), had no interest in it and nothing to do.

'' He (man)'s such a blackguard! I have told him (man) so, but it makes no difference. Only think of it! He (man) couldn't collect it in three years!

he (man) heard vigorously uttered by a round-shouldered, short, country gentleman, who had pomaded hair hanging on his (man) embroidered collar, and new boots obviously put on for the occasion, with heels that tapped energetically as he (man) spoke.

'' Casting a displeased glance at Levin, this gentleman sharply turned his (gentleman) back. '' Yes, it's a dirty business, there's no denying,'' a small gentleman assented in a high voice.

Next, a whole crowd of country gentlemen, surrounding a stout general, hurriedly came near Levin. These persons were unmistakably seeking a place where they could talk without being overheard.

'' How dare he (Levin) say I had his (Levin) breeches stolen! Pawned them for drink, I expect. Damn the fellow, prince indeed!

He (prince)'d better not say it, the beast!'' '' But excuse me! They take their stand on the act,'' was being said in another group;

``the wife must be registered as noble.

'' (unknown)

'' Oh, damn your acts! I speak from my heart. We're all gentlemen, aren't we? Above suspicion. '' '' Shall we go on, your excellency, fine champagne?

Another group was following a nobleman, who was shouting something in a loud voice; it was one of the three intoxicated gentlemen.

I always advised Marya Semyonovna to let for a fair rent, for she (wife) can never save a profit,'' he (nobleman) heard a pleasant voice say.

'' '' The speaker was a country gentleman with gray whiskers, wearing the regimental uniform of an old general staff-officer. It was the very landowner Levin had met at Sviazhsky's.

He (Levin) knew him (Levin) at once. The landowner too stared at Levin, and they exchanged greetings. '' Very glad to see you!

To be sure! I remember you very well. Last year at our district marshal, Nikolay Ivanovitch's. '' '' Well, and how is your land doing?

Oh, still just the same, always at a loss,'' the landowner answered with a resigned smile, but with an expression of serenity and conviction that so it must be.

'' asked Levin. '' '' And how do you come to be in our province? '' he (Levin) asked.

``Come to take part in our coup d'etat?

'' (he)

he (Levin) said, confidently pronouncing the French words with a bad accent. '' All Russia's here--gentlemen of the bedchamber, and everything short of the ministry.

He (Levin) pointed to the imposing figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch in white trousers and his (Levin) court uniform, walking by with a general.

'' '' I ought to own that I don't very well understand the drift of the provincial elections,'' said Levin. The landowner looked at him (Levin).

'' Why, what is there to understand? There's no meaning in it at all. It's a decaying institution that goes on running only by the force of inertia.

Just look, the very uniforms tell you that it's an assembly of justices of the peace, permanent members of the court, and so on, but not of noblemen.''

'' Then why do you come?'' asked Levin. '' From habit, nothing else. Then, too, one must keep up connections. It's a moral obligation of a sort.

And then, to tell the truth, there's one's own interests. My son-in-law wants to stand as a permanent member; they're not rich people, and he (member) must be brought forward.

These gentlemen, now, what do they come for? '' he (member) said, pointing to the malignant gentleman, who was talking at the high table.

'' That's the new generation of nobility. '' '' New it may be, but nobility it isn't. They're proprietors of a sort, but we're the landowners.

As noblemen, they're cutting their own throats.'' '' But you say it's an institution that's served its time.''

``That it may be, but still it ought to be treated a little more respectfully.

If we're laying out a garden, planning one before the house, you know, and there you've a tree that's stood for centuries in the very spot....

Old and gnarled it may be, and yet you don't cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds, but lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree.

Snetkov, now... We may be of use, or we may not, but we're the growth of a thousand years. You won't grow him (fellow) again in a year,'' (he)

he (fellow) said cautiously, and he (fellow) immediately changed the conversation.

'' Well, and how is your land doing?'' '' Oh, not very well. I make five per cent. '' '' Yes, but you don't reckon your own work.

Aren't you worth something too? I'll tell you my own case. Before I took to seeing after the land, I had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service.

Now I do more work than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent. on the land, and thank God for that.

But one's work is thrown in for nothing.'' '' Then why do you do it, if it's a clear loss?'' ''

And what's more,'' the landowner went on, leaning his (landowner) elbows on the window and chatting on,

``my son, I must tell you, has no taste for it.

Oh, well, one does it! What would you have? It's habit, and one knows it's how it should be. There's no doubt he (son)'ll be a scientific man.

So there'll be no one to keep it up. And yet one does it. Here this year I've planted an orchard.

'' (the landowner)

'' Yes, yes,'' said Levin,
``that's perfectly true. I always feel there's no real balance of gain in my work on the land, and yet one does it....

It's a sort of duty one feels to the land.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

'' But I tell you what,'' the landowner pursued;
``a neighbor of mine, a merchant, was at my place.

We walked about the fields and the garden. ' No,' said he (merchant), `Stepan Vassilievitch, everything's well looked after, but your garden's neglected.'

But, as a fact, it's well kept up. ' To my thinking, I'd cut down that lime-tree. Here you've thousands of limes, and each would make two good bundles of bark.

And with what he (merchant) made he (merchant)'d increase his (merchant) stock, or buy some land for a trifle, and let it out in lots to the peasants,'' (the landowner neighbor)

Levin added, smiling.

And nowadays that bark's worth something. I'd cut down the lot.''' '' He (Levin) had evidently more than once come across those commercial calculations.

'' And he (Levin)'d make his (Levin) fortune. But you and I must thank God if we keep what we've got and leave it to our children.''

``You're married, I've heard?'' (the landowner)
said the landowner. '' Yes,'' Levin answered, with proud satisfaction. '' Yes, it's rather strange,'' he (Levin) went on.

'' So we live without making anything, as though we were ancient vestals set to keep in a fire. '' The landowner chuckled under his (landowner) white mustaches.

There are some among us, too, like our friend Nikolay Ivanovitch, or Count Vronsky, that's settled here lately, who try to carry on their husbandry as though it were a factory; but so far it leads to nothing but making away with capital on it.''

'' '' But why is it we don't do like the merchants? Why don't we cut down our parks for timber?

'' said Levin, returning to a thought that had struck him (Levin). '' Why, as you said, to keep the fire in.

Besides that's not work for a nobleman. And our work as noblemen isn't done here at the elections, but yonder, each in our corner.

There's a class instinct, too, of what one ought and oughtn't to do. There's the peasants, too, I wonder at them sometimes; any good peasant tries to take all the land he (peasant) can.

However bad the land is, he (peasant)'ll work it. Without a return too. At a simple loss. ''

``Just as we do,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin.

And here we've met for the first time since we met at your place,'' said the landowner to Sviazhsky,

``and we've had a good talk too.

'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)

Very, very glad to have met you,'' he (landowner) added, seeing Sviazhsky approaching him (landowner). '' ''
``Well, have you been attacking the new order of things?'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
said Sviazhsky with a smile.

'' That we're bound to do. ''

``You've relieved your feelings?'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
