Chapter 30 Sviazhsky took Levin's arm, and went with him (Levin) to his (Levin) own friends.

This time there was no avoiding Vronsky. He (Levin) was standing with Stepan Arkadyevitch and Sergey Ivanovitch, and looking straight at Levin as he (Levin) drew near.

Yes, I quite remember our meeting,'' said Levin, and blushing crimson, he (Levin) turned away immediately, and began talking to his (Levin) brother.

With a slight smile Vronsky went on talking to Sviazhsky, obviously without the slightest inclination to enter into conversation with Levin.

But Levin, as he (Levin) talked to his (Levin) brother, was continually looking round at Vronsky, trying to think of something to say to him (Levin) to gloss over his (Levin) rudeness.

'' Delighted! I believe I've had the pleasure of meeting you...at Princess Shtcherbatskaya's,'' he (Levin) said, giving Levin his (Levin) hand. '' ''

What are we waiting for now? '' asked Levin, looking at Sviazhsky and Vronsky.

``For Snetkov. He (Levin) has to refuse or to consent to stand,'' (Sviazhsky/Nikolay Ivanovitch/Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky)
answered Sviazhsky.

'' Well, and what has he (Levin) done, consented or not?'' '' That's the point, that he (Levin)'s done neither,'' said Vronsky. ''

And if he (Levin) refuses, who will stand then? '' asked Levin, looking at Vronsky. '' Whoever chooses to,'' said Sviazhsky. ''

Certainly not I,'' said Sviazhsky, looking confused, and turning an alarmed glance at the malignant gentleman, who was standing beside Sergey Ivanovitch.

Shall you? '' asked Levin. '' '' Who then? Nevyedovsky? '' said Levin, feeling he (Levin) was putting his (Levin) foot into it.

But this was worse still. Nevyedovsky and Sviazhsky were the two candidates. '' I certainly shall not, under any circumstances,'' answered the malignant gentleman.

This was Nevyedovsky himself. Sviazhsky introduced him (gentleman) to Levin. '' Well, you find it exciting too?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, winking at Vronsky.

'' It's something like a race. One might bet on it.''

``Yes, it is keenly exciting,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky. '' And once taking the thing up, one's eager to see it through.

It's a fight! '' he (Levin) said, scowling and setting his (Levin) powerful jaws. '' What a capable fellow Sviazhsky is! Sees it all so clearly.

A silence followed, during which Vronsky--since he (Levin) had to look at something--looked at Levin, at his (Levin) feet, at his (Levin) uniform, then at his (Levin) face, and noticing his (Levin) gloomy eyes fixed upon him (Levin), he (Levin) said, in order to say something:

``How is it that you, living constantly in the country, are not a justice of the peace?

'' (he)

'' Oh, yes!'' Vronsky assented indifferently. You are not in the uniform of one.'' '' It's because I consider that the justice of the peace is a silly institution,'' Levin answered gloomily.

He (Levin) had been all the time looking for an opportunity to enter into conversation with Vronsky, so as to smooth over his (Levin) rudeness at their first meeting.

'' I don't think so, quite the contrary,'' Vronsky said, with quiet surprise. '' It's a plaything,'' Levin cut him (Levin) short.

'' We don't want justices of the peace. I've never had a single thing to do with them during eight years.

And what I have had was decided wrongly by them. The justice of the peace is over thirty miles from me.

And he (Levin) related how a peasant had stolen some flour from the miller, and when the miller told him (miller) of it, had lodged a complaint for slander.

For some matter of two roubles I should have to send a lawyer, who costs me fifteen. '' All this was utterly uncalled for and stupid, and Levin felt it himself as he (Levin) said it.

'' Oh, this is such an original fellow!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch with his (fellow) most soothing, almond-oil smile. '' But come along; I think they're voting....

I can't understand,'' said Sergey Ivanovitch, who had observed his (Ivanovitch) brother's clumsiness,

``I can't understand how anyone can be so absolutely devoid of political tact.

The marshal of the province is our opponent, and with him (marshal) you're ami cochon , and you beg him (marshal) to stand.

I'm not making a friend of him (marshal); he (marshal)'s asked me to dinner, and I'm not going; but he (marshal)'s one of our side--why make an enemy of him (marshal)?

'' (brother)

And they separated. '' That's where we Russians are so deficient. Count Vronsky, now ... Then you ask Nevyedovsky if he (marshal)'s going to stand.

That's not a thing to do. '' '' Oh, I don't understand it at all! And it's all such nonsense,'' Levin answered gloomily.

You say it's all such nonsense, but as soon as you have anything to do with it, you make a muddle.

The marshal of the province, though he (marshal) was vaguely conscious in the air of some trap being prepared for him (marshal), and though he (marshal) had not been called upon by all to stand, had still made up his (marshal) mind to stand.

The secretary announced in a loud voice that the captain of the guards, Mihail Stepanovitch Snetkov, would now be balloted for as marshal of the province.

The district marshals walked carrying plates, on which were balls, from their tables to the high table, and the election began.

'' '' Levin did not answer, and they walked together into the big room. All was silence in the room. ''

Put it in the right side,'' whispered Stepan Arkadyevitch, as with his (Levin) brother Levin followed the marshal of his (Levin) district to the table.

But Levin had forgotten by now the calculations that had been explained to him (Levin), and was afraid Stepan Arkadyevitch might be mistaken in saying

``the right side.

As he (Levin) went up, he (Levin) held the ball in his (Levin) right hand, but thinking he (Levin) was wrong, just at the box he (Levin) changed to the left hand, and undoubtedly put the ball to the left.

An adept in the business, standing at the box and seeing by the mere action of the elbow where each put his (Levin) ball, scowled with annoyance.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Surely Snetkov was the enemy. It was no good for him (Levin) to use his (Levin) insight. Everything was still, and the counting of the balls was heard.

Then a single voice rose and proclaimed the numbers for and against. The marshal had been voted for by a considerable majority.

All was noise and eager movement towards the doors. Snetkov came in, and the nobles thronged round him (nobles), congratulating him (nobles). ''

Well, now is it over? '' Levin asked Sergey Ivanovitch. '' It's only just beginning,'' Sviazhsky said, replying for Sergey Ivanovitch with a smile.

Now he (Ivanovitch) could only remember that there was some sort of trickery in it, but he (Ivanovitch) was too bored to think what it was exactly.

'' Some other candidate may receive more votes than the marshal. '' Levin had quite forgotten about that. He (Levin) felt depressed, and longed to get out of the crowd.

As no one was paying any attention to him (Levin), and no one apparently needed him (Levin), he (Levin) quietly slipped away into the little room where the refreshments were, and again had a great sense of comfort when he (Levin) saw the waiters.

After eating a cutlet with beans and talking to the waiters of their former masters, Levin, not wishing to go back to the hall, where it was all so distasteful to him (Levin), proceeded to walk through the galleries.

The galleries were full of fashionably dressed ladies, leaning over the balustrade and trying not to lose a single word of what was being said below.

The little old waiter pressed him (waiter) to have something, and Levin agreed. With the ladies were sitting and standing smart lawyers, high school teachers in spectacles, and officers.

Everywhere they were talking of the election, and of how worried the marshal was, and how splendid the discussions had been.

In one group Levin heard his (Levin) brother's praises. One lady was telling a lawyer:

``How glad I am I heard Koznishev!

It's worth losing one's dinner. He (Koznishev)'s exquisite! So clear and distinct all of it! There's not one of you in the law courts that speaks like that.

The only one is Meidel, and he (Koznishev)'s not so eloquent by a long way. '' (a lawyer)

Finding a free place, Levin leaned over the balustrade and began looking and listening.

In the middle of the room stood a man in a uniform, who shouted in a loud, high voice:

``As a candidate for the marshalship of the nobility of the province we call upon staff-captain Yevgeney Ivanovitch Apuhtin!

All the noblemen were sitting railed off behind barriers according to their districts. '' (a man)

A dead silence followed, and then a weak old voice was heard:
``Declined!'' (councilor)

'' We call upon the privy councilor Pyotr Petrovitch Bol,'' the voice began again.

``Declined!'' (unknown)
a high boyish voice replied. Again it began, and again
``Declined.

At first he (councilor) wondered and wanted to know what it meant; then feeling sure that he (councilor) could not make it out he (councilor) began to be bored.

Then recalling all the excitement and vindictiveness he (councilor) had seen on all the faces, he (councilor) felt sad; he (councilor) made up his (councilor) mind to go, and went downstairs.

As he (councilor) passed through the entry to the galleries he (councilor) met a dejected high school boy walking up and down with tired-looking eyes.

'' (unknown)

And so it went on for about an hour. Levin, with his (Levin) elbows on the balustrade, looked and listened. On the stairs he (Levin) met a couple--a lady running quickly on her (lady) high heels and the jaunty deputy prosecutor.

I told you you weren't late,'' the deputy prosecutor was saying at the moment when Levin moved aside to let the lady pass.

Levin was on the stairs to the way out, and was just feeling in his (Levin) waistcoat pocket for the number of his (Levin) overcoat, when the secretary overtook him (Levin).

'' '' This way, please, Konstantin Dmitrievitch; they are voting. '' The candidate who was being voted on was Nevyedovsky, who had so stoutly denied all idea of standing.

Levin went up to the door of the room; it was locked. The secretary knocked, the door opened, and Levin was met by two red-faced gentlemen, who darted out.

'' I can't stand any more of it,'' said one red-faced gentleman. After them the face of the marshal of the province was poked out.

His (marshal) face was dreadful-looking from exhaustion and dismay. '' I told you not to let any one out! '' he (marshal) cried to the doorkeeper.

``Mercy on us!'' (the marshal)
and with a heavy sigh the marshal of the province walked with downcast head to the high table in the middle of the room, his (marshal) legs staggering in his (marshal) white trousers.

'' I let someone in, your excellency!'' Nevyedovsky had scored a higher majority, as they had planned, and he (marshal) was the new marshal of the province.

Many people were amused, many were pleased and happy, many were in ecstasies, many were disgusted and unhappy. The former marshal of the province was in a state of despair, which he (marshal) could not conceal.

When Nevyedovsky went out of the room, the crowd thronged round him (marshal) and followed him (marshal) enthusiastically, just as they had followed the governor who had opened the meetings, and just as they had followed Snetkov when he (governor) was elected.

Vronsky had come to the elections partly because he (governor) was bored in the country and wanted to show Anna his (governor) right to independence, and also to repay Sviazhsky by his (governor) support at the election for all the trouble he (governor) had taken for Vronsky at the district council election, but chiefly in order strictly to perform all those duties of a nobleman and landowner which he (landowner) had taken upon himself.

But he (landowner) had not in the least expected that the election would so interest him (landowner), so keenly excite him (landowner), and that he (landowner) would be so good at this kind of thing.

He (landowner) was quite a new man in the circle of the nobility of the province, but his (landowner) success was unmistakable, and he (landowner) was not wrong in supposing that he (landowner) had already obtained a certain influence.

This influence was due to his (landowner) wealth and reputation, the capital house in the town lent him (landowner) by his (landowner) old friend Shirkov, who had a post in the department of finances and was director of a flourishing bank in Kashin; the excellent cook Vronsky had brought from the country, and his (cook) friendship with the governor, who was a schoolfellow of Vronsky's--a schoolfellow he (cook) had patronized and protected indeed.

But what contributed more than all to his (cook) success was his (cook) direct, equable manner with everyone, which very quickly made the majority of the noblemen reverse the current opinion of his (cook) supposed haughtiness.

He (cook) was himself conscious that, except that whimsical gentleman married to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, who had √† propos de bottes poured out a stream of irrelevant absurdities with such spiteful fury, every nobleman with whom he (nobleman) had made acquaintance had become his (nobleman) adherent.

He (nobleman) saw clearly, and other people recognized it, too, that he (nobleman) had done a great deal to secure the success of Nevyedovsky.

And now at his (nobleman) own table, celebrating Nevyedovsky's election, he (nobleman) was experiencing an agreeable sense of triumph over the success of his (nobleman) candidate.

The election itself had so fascinated him (nobleman) that, if he (nobleman) could succeed in getting married during the next three years, he (nobleman) began to think of standing himself--much as after winning a race ridden by a jockey, he (jockey) had longed to ride a race himself.

Chapter 31 The newly elected marshal and many of the successful party dined that day with Vronsky. Today he (marshal) was celebrating the success of his (marshal) jockey.

Vronsky sat at the head of the table, on his (marshal) right hand sat the young governor, a general of high rank.

To all the rest he (marshal) was the chief man in the province, who had solemnly opened the elections with his (marshal) speech, and aroused a feeling of respect and even of awe in many people, as Vronsky saw; to Vronsky he (marshal) was little Katka Maslov--that had been his (marshal) nickname in the Pages' Corps--whom he (marshal) felt to be shy and tried to mettre √† son aise .

On the left hand sat Nevyedovsky with his (marshal) youthful, stubborn, and malignant face. With him (marshal) Vronsky was simple and deferential. Sviazhsky took his (Vronsky) failure very light-heartedly.

It was indeed no failure in his (Vronsky) eyes, as he (Vronsky) said himself, turning, glass in hand, to Nevyedovsky; they could not have found a better representative of the new movement, which the nobility ought to follow.

And so every honest person, as he (representative) said, was on the side of today's success and was rejoicing over it. Stepan Arkadyevitch was glad, too, that he (representative) was having a good time, and that everyone was pleased.

Sviazhsky comically imitated the tearful discourse of the marshal, and observed, addressing Nevyedovsky, that his (marshal) excellency would have to select another more complicated method of auditing the accounts than tears.

Another nobleman jocosely described how footmen in stockings had been ordered for the marshal's ball, and how now they would have to be sent back unless the new marshal would give a ball with footmen in stockings.

The episode of the elections served as a good occasion for a capital dinner. Continually during dinner they said of Nevyedovsky:

``our marshal,'' (Nevyedovsky)
and
``your excellency.

Nevyedovsky affected to be not merely indifferent but scornful of this appellation, but it was obvious that he (marshal) was highly delighted, and had to keep a curb on himself not to betray the triumph which was unsuitable to their new liberal tone.

'' (Nevyedovsky)

This was said with the same pleasure with which a bride is called
``Madame'' (a bride)
and her (bride) husband's name. After dinner several telegrams were sent to people interested in the result of the election.

And Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was in high good humor, sent Darya Alexandrovna a telegram:

``Nevyedovsky elected by twenty votes. Congratulations. Tell people.

Darya Alexandrovna, getting the message, simply sighed over the rouble wasted on it, and understood that it was an after-dinner affair.

'' (Darya Alexandrovna/Darya)

He (husband) dictated it aloud, saying:
``We must let them share our rejoicing. '' (He)
She (bride) knew Stiva had a weakness after dining for faire jouer le t√©l√©graphe.

Everything, together with the excellent dinner and the wine, not from Russian merchants, but imported direct from abroad, was extremely dignified, simple, and enjoyable.

The party--some twenty--had been selected by Sviazhsky from among the more active new liberals, all of the same way of thinking, who were at the same time clever and well bred.

They drank, also half in jest, to the health of the new marshal of the province, of the governor, of the bank director, and of

``our amiable host.

'' (the bank director)

Vronsky was satisfied. He (director) had never expected to find so pleasant a tone in the provinces. Towards the end of dinner it was still more lively.

The governor asked Vronsky to come to a concert for the benefit of the Servians which his (governor) wife, who was anxious to make his (governor) acquaintance, had been getting up.

'' There'll be a ball, and you'll see the belle of the province. Worth seeing, really. ''

``Not in my line,'' (Vronsky)
Vronsky answered.

Before they rose from the table, when all of them were smoking, Vronsky's valet went up to him (valet) with a letter on a tray.

He (valet) liked that English phrase. But he (valet) smiled, and promised to come. '' From Vozdvizhenskoe by special messenger,'' he (valet) said with a significant expression.

how like he (valet) is to the deputy prosecutor Sventitsky,'' said one of the guests in French of the valet, while Vronsky, frowning, read the letter.

'' Astonishing! The letter was from Anna. Before he (valet) read the letter, he (valet) knew its contents. Expecting the elections to be over in five days, he (valet) had promised to be back on Friday.

Today was Saturday, and he (valet) knew that the letter contained reproaches for not being back at the time fixed. The letter he (valet) had sent the previous evening had probably not reached her (Anna) yet.

The letter was what he (valet) had expected, but the form of it was unexpected, and particularly disagreeable to him (valet). '' Annie is very ill, the doctor says it may be inflammation.

I expected you the day before yesterday, and yesterday, and now I am sending to find out where you are and what you are doing.

I am losing my head all alone. Princess Varvara is no help, but a hindrance. I wanted to come myself, but thought better of it, knowing you would dislike it.

Send some answer, that I may know what to do. '' The child ill, yet she (Princess) had thought of coming herself.

The innocent festivities over the election, and this gloomy, burdensome love to which he (it) had to return struck Vronsky by their contrast.

Their daughter ill, and this hostile tone. But he (it) had to go, and by the first train that night he (it) set off home.

Before Vronsky's departure for the elections, Anna had reflected that the scenes constantly repeated between them each time he (it) left home, might only make him (it) cold to her (Anna) instead of attaching him (it) to her (Anna), and resolved to do all she (Anna) could to control herself so as to bear the parting with composure.

But the cold, severe glance with which he (it) had looked at her (Anna) when he (it) came to tell her (Anna) he (it) was going had wounded her (Anna), and before he (it) had started her (Anna) peace of mind was destroyed.

In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed his (it) right to freedom, she (Anna) came, as she (Anna) always did, to the same point--

Chapter 32 the sense of her (Anna) own humiliation. '' He (it) has the right to go away when and where he (it) chooses.

Not simply to go away, but to leave me. He (it) has every right, and I have none. But knowing that, he (it) ought not to do it.

Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it has never been so before, and that glance means a great deal,'' she (Anna) thought.

What has he (it) done, though?... He (it) looked at me with a cold, severe expression. '' That glance shows the beginning of indifference.

And though she (Anna) felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was nothing she (Anna) could do, she (Anna) could not in any way alter her (Anna) relations to him (it).

And so, just as before, only by occupation in the day, by morphine at night, could she (Anna) stifle the fearful thought of what would be if he (it) ceased to love her (Anna).

It is true there was still one means; not to keep him (it)--for that she (Anna) wanted nothing more than his (it) love--but to be nearer to him (it), to be in such a position that he (it) would not leave her (Anna).

And she (Anna) began to long for that, and made up her (Anna) mind to agree to it the first time he (it) or Stiva approached her (Anna) on the subject.

Absorbed in such thoughts, she (Anna) passed five days without him (it), the five days that he (it) was to be at the elections.

Walks, conversation with Princess Varvara, visits to the hospital, and, most of all, reading--reading of one book after another--filled up her (Princess) time.

But on the sixth day, when the coachman came back without him (it), she (Princess) felt that now she (Princess) was utterly incapable of stifling the thought of him (it) and of what he (it) was doing there, just at that time her (Princess) little girl was taken ill.

Anna began to look after her (Anna), but even that did not distract her (Anna) mind, especially as the illness was not serious.

'' Just as before, only by love and by charm could she (Anna) keep him (it). That means was divorce and marriage. However hard she (Anna) tried, she (Anna) could not love this little child, and to feign love was beyond her (Anna) powers.

Towards the evening of that day, still alone, Anna was in such a panic about him (it) that she (Anna) decided to start for the town, but on second thoughts wrote him (it) the contradictory letter that Vronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a special messenger.

She (Anna) dreaded a repetition of the severe look he (it) had flung at her (Anna) at parting, especially when he (it) knew that the baby was not dangerously ill.

The next morning she (Anna) received his (it) letter and regretted her (Anna) own. But still she (Anna) was glad she (Anna) had written to him (it).

At this moment Anna was positively admitting to herself that she (Anna) was a burden to him (it), that he (it) would relinquish his (it) freedom regretfully to return to her (Anna), and in spite of that she (Anna) was glad he (it) was coming.

Let him (it) weary of her (Anna), but he (it) would be here with her (Anna), so that she (Anna) would see him (it), would know of every action he (it) took.

She (Anna) was sitting in the drawing room near a lamp, with a new volume of Taine, and as she (Anna) read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and

every minute expecting the carriage to arrive. Several times she (Anna) had fancied she (Anna) heard the sound of wheels, but she (Anna) had been mistaken.

At last she (Anna) heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman's shout and the dull rumble in the covered entry.

Even Princess Varvara, playing patience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead of going down, as she (Anna) had done twice before, she (Anna) stood still.

She (Anna) suddenly felt ashamed of her (Anna) duplicity, but even more she (Anna) dreaded how he (Anna) might meet her (Anna). All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; she (Anna) was only afraid of the expression of his (Anna) displeasure.

She (Anna) remembered that her (Anna) child had been perfectly well again for the last two days. She (Anna) felt positively vexed with her (Anna) for getting better from the very moment her (Anna) letter was sent off.

Then she (Anna) thought of him (Anna), that he (Anna) was here, all of him (Anna), with his (Anna) hands, his (Anna) eyes. She (Anna) heard his (Anna) voice.

And forgetting everything, she (Anna) ran joyfully to meet him (Anna). '' Well, how is Annie? '' he (Anna) said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as she (Anna) ran down to him (Anna).

He (Anna) was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off his (footman) warm over-boot. '' Oh, she (Anna) is better.'' ''

And you? '' he (footman) said, shaking himself. She (Anna) took his (footman) hand in both of hers, and drew it to her (Anna) waist, never taking her (Anna) eyes off him (footman).

Well, I'm glad,'' he (footman) said, coldly scanning her (Anna), her (Anna) hair, her (Anna) dress, which he (footman) knew she (Anna) had put on for him (footman).

'' All was charming, but how many times it had charmed him (footman)! And the stern, stony expression that she (Anna) so dreaded settled upon his (footman) face.

'' Well, I'm glad. And are you well? '' he (footman) said, wiping his (footman) damp beard with his (footman) handkerchief and kissing her (Anna) hand.

Never mind,'' she (Anna) thought,

``only let him (footman) be here, and so long as he (footman)'s here he (footman) cannot, he (footman) dare not, cease to love me.

The evening was spent happily and gaily in the presence of Princess Varvara, who complained to him (footman) that Anna had been taking morphine in his (footman) absence.

'' (she)

'' '' What am I to do? I couldn't sleep.... My thoughts prevented me. When he (footman)'s here I never take it--hardly ever.

He (footman) told her (Anna) about the election, and Anna knew how by adroit questions to bring him (footman) to what gave him (footman) most pleasure--his (footman) own success.

She (Anna) told him (footman) of everything that interested him (footman) at home; and all that she (Anna) told him (footman) was of the most cheerful description.

But late in the evening, when they were alone, Anna, seeing that she (Anna) had regained complete possession of him (footman), wanted to erase the painful impression of the glance he (footman) had given her (Anna) for her (Anna) letter.

She (Anna) said:

``Tell me frankly, you were vexed at getting my letter, and you didn't believe me?'' (She)
As soon as she (Anna) had said it, she (Anna) felt that however warm his (footman) feelings were to her (Anna), he (footman) had not forgiven her (Anna) for that.

'' '' Yes,'' he (footman) said,

``the letter was so strange. First, Annie ill, and then you thought of coming yourself.'' (he)
``It was all the truth.'' (I)

'' Oh, I don't doubt it. '' '' Yes, you do doubt it. You are vexed, I see. ''

``Not for one moment.

I'm only vexed , that's true, that you seem somehow unwilling to admit that there are duties...'' (he)

'' The duty of going to a concert...''

'' But we won't talk about it,'' he (you) said. '' Why not talk about it? '' she (you) said. '' I only meant to say that matters of real importance may turn up.

Now, for instance, I shall have to go to Moscow to arrange about the house.... Oh, Anna, why are you so irritable?

Don't you know that I can't live without you?'' '' If so,'' said Anna, her (Anna) voice suddenly changing,

``it means that you are sick of this life....

Yes, you will come for a day and go away, as men do...'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

``Anna, that's cruel. I am ready to give up my whole life.

'' (she)

But she (Anna) did not hear him (my). '' If you go to Moscow, I will go too. I will not stay here.

Either we must separate or else live together. ''

``Why, you know, that's my one desire. But for that...'' (unknown)
``We must get a divorce.

I will write to him (my). I see I cannot go on like this.... But I will come with you to Moscow.

'' (unknown)

``You talk as if you were threatening me. But I desire nothing so much as never to be parted from you,'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, smiling.

But as he (my) said these words there gleamed in his (my) eyes not merely a cold look, but the vindictive look of a man persecuted and made cruel.

She (my) saw the look and correctly divined its meaning. '' If so, it's a calamity! '' that glance told her (my). It was a moment's impression, but she (my) never forgot it.

Anna wrote to her (Anna) husband asking him (husband) about a divorce, and towards the end of November, taking leave of Princess Varvara, who wanted to go to Petersburg, she (Princess) went with Vronsky to Moscow.

Expecting every day an answer from Alexey Alexandrovitch, and after that the divorce, they now established themselves together like married people.

The date had long passed on which, according to the most trustworthy calculations of people learned in such matters, Kitty should have been confined.

But she (Kitty) was still about, and there was nothing to show that her (Kitty) time was any nearer than two months ago.

The doctor, the monthly nurse, and Dolly and her (Dolly) mother, and most of all Levin, who could not think of the approaching event without terror, began to be impatient and uneasy.

PART 7 Chapter 1 The Levins had been three months in Moscow. Kitty was the only person who felt perfectly calm and happy.

She (Kitty) was distinctly conscious now of the birth of a new feeling of love for the future child, for her (Kitty) to some extent actually existing already, and she (Kitty) brooded blissfully over this feeling.

Often this separate being gave her (Kitty) pain, but at the same time she (Kitty) wanted to laugh with a strange new joy.

All the people she (Kitty) loved were with her (Kitty), and all were so good to her (Kitty), so attentively caring for her (Kitty), so entirely pleasant was everything presented to her (Kitty), that if she (Kitty) had not known and felt that it must all soon be over, she (Kitty) could not have wished for a better and pleasanter life.

The only thing that spoiled the charm of this manner of life was that her (Kitty) husband was not here as she (Kitty) loved him (husband) to be, and as he (husband) was in the country.

He (husband) was not by now altogether a part of herself, but sometimes lived his (husband) own life independently of her (Kitty). She (Kitty) liked his (husband) serene, friendly, and hospitable manner in the country.

In the town he (husband) seemed continually uneasy and on his (husband) guard, as though he (husband) were afraid someone would be rude to him (husband), and still more to her (Kitty).

At home in the country, knowing himself distinctly to be in his (husband) right place, he (husband) was never in haste to be off elsewhere.

Here in town he (husband) was in a continual hurry, as though afraid of missing something, and yet he (husband) had nothing to do.

He (husband) was never unoccupied. And she (Kitty) felt sorry for him (husband). To others, she (Kitty) knew, he (husband) did not appear an object of pity.

On the contrary, when Kitty looked at him (husband) in society, as one sometimes looks at those one loves, trying to see him (husband) as if he (husband) were a stranger, so as to catch the impression he (husband) must make on others, she (Kitty) saw with a panic even of jealous fear that he (husband) was far indeed from being a pitiable figure, that he (husband) was very attractive with his (husband) fine breeding, his (husband) rather old-fashioned, reserved courtesy with women, his (husband) powerful figure, and striking, as she (Kitty) thought, and expressive face.

But she (Kitty) saw him (husband) not from without, but from within; she (Kitty) saw that here he (husband) was not himself ; that was the only way she (Kitty) could define his (husband) condition to herself.

Sometimes she (Kitty) inwardly reproached him (husband) for his (husband) inability to live in the town; sometimes she (Kitty) recognized that it was really hard for him (husband) to order his (husband) life here so that he (husband) could be satisfied with it.

What had he (husband) to do, indeed? He (husband) did not care for cards; he (husband) did not go to a club. Spending the time with jovial gentlemen of Oblonsky's type--she (Kitty) knew now what that meant...

it meant drinking and going somewhere after drinking. She (Kitty) could not think without horror of where men went on such occasions.

But she (Kitty) knew he (husband) could only find satisfaction in that if he (husband) took pleasure in the society of young women, and that she (Kitty) could not wish for.

But much as she (Kitty) liked and enjoyed their conversations forever on the same subjects--

``Aline-Nadine,'' (the subjects)
as the old prince called the sisters' talks--she (Kitty) knew it must bore him (prince).

Was he (prince) to go into society? Should he (prince) stay at home with her (Kitty), her (Kitty) mother and her (Kitty) sisters? What was there left for him (prince) to do?

To go on writing at his (prince) book he (prince) had indeed attempted, and at first he (prince) used to go to the library and make extracts and look up references for his (prince) book.

And besides, he (prince) complained that he (prince) had talked too much about his (prince) book here, and that consequently all his (prince) ideas about it were muddled and had lost their interest for him (prince).

But, as he (prince) told her (Kitty), the more he (prince) did nothing, the less time he (prince) had to do anything. One advantage in this town life was that quarrels hardly ever happened between them here in town.

Whether it was that their conditions were different, or that they had both become more careful and sensible in that respect, they had no quarrels in Moscow from jealousy, which they had so dreaded when they moved from the country.

One event, an event of great importance to both from that point of view, did indeed happen--that was Kitty's meeting with Vronsky.

Kitty, though she (Kitty) did not go into society at all on account of her (Kitty) condition, went with her (Kitty) father to see the venerable old lady, and there met Vronsky.

The only thing Kitty could reproach herself for at this meeting was that at the instant when she (Kitty) recognized in his (father) civilian dress the features once so familiar to her (Kitty), her (Kitty) breath failed her (Kitty), the blood rushed to her (Kitty) heart, and a vivid blush--she (Kitty) felt it-- overspread her (Kitty) face.

The old Princess Marya Borissovna, Kitty's godmother, who had always been very fond of her (Borissovna), had insisted on seeing her (Borissovna). But this lasted only a few seconds.

Before her (Borissovna) father, who purposely began talking in a loud voice to Vronsky, had finished, she (Borissovna) was perfectly ready to look at Vronsky, to speak to him (father), if necessary, exactly as she (Borissovna) spoke to Princess Marya Borissovna, and more than that, to do so in such a way that everything to the faintest intonation and smile would have been approved by her (Borissovna) husband, whose unseen presence she (Borissovna) seemed to feel about her (Borissovna) at that instant.

She (Borissovna) said a few words to him (husband), even smiled serenely at his (husband) joke about the elections, which he (husband) called

``our parliament.

But she (Borissovna) turned away immediately to Princess Marya Borissovna, and did not once glance at him (husband) till he (husband) got up to go; then she (Borissovna) looked at him (husband), but evidently only because it would be uncivil not to look at a man when he (man) is saying good-bye.

She (Borissovna) was grateful to her (Borissovna) father for saying nothing to her (Borissovna) about their meeting Vronsky, but she (Borissovna) saw by his (father) special warmth to her (Borissovna) after the visit during their usual walk that he (father) was pleased with her (Borissovna).

She (Borissovna) had not expected she (Borissovna) would have had the power, while keeping somewhere in the bottom of her (Borissovna) heart all the memories of her (Borissovna) old feeling for Vronsky, not only to seem but to be perfectly indifferent and composed with him (father).

'' (he)

-LRB-She (Borissovna) had to smile to show she (Borissovna) saw the joke.-RRB- She (Borissovna) was pleased with herself. Levin flushed a great deal more than she (Borissovna) when she (Borissovna) told him (Levin) she (Borissovna) had met Vronsky at Princess Marya Borissovna's.

It was very hard for her (Borissovna) to tell him (Levin) this, but still harder to go on speaking of the details of the meeting, as he (Levin) did not question her (Borissovna), but simply gazed at her (Borissovna) with a frown.

'' I am very sorry you weren't there,'' she (Borissovna) said. '' Not that you weren't in the room... I couldn't have been so natural in your presence...

I am blushing now much more, much, much more,'' she (Borissovna) said, blushing till the tears came into her (Borissovna) eyes. '' But that you couldn't see through a crack.

The truthful eyes told Levin that she (Borissovna) was satisfied with herself, and in spite of her (Borissovna) blushing he (Levin) was quickly reassured and began questioning her (Borissovna), which was all she (Borissovna) wanted.

When he (Levin) had heard everything, even to the detail that for the first second she (Borissovna) could not help flushing, but that afterwards she (Borissovna) was just as direct and as much at her (Borissovna) ease as with any chance acquaintance, Levin was quite happy again and said he (Levin) was glad of it, and would not now behave as stupidly as he (Levin) had done at the election, but would try the first time he (Levin) met Vronsky to be as friendly as possible.

'' '' It's so wretched to feel that there's a man almost an enemy whom it's painful to meet,'' said Levin.

Chapter 2

``Go, please, go then and call on the Bols,'' (Kitty/Shtcherbatskaya/Kitty Shtcherbatskaya)

'' Well, anyway, I shall come home before dinner,'' he (Levin) said, looking at his (Levin) watch. '' Put on your frock coat, so that you can go straight to call on Countess Bola.''

'' But is it absolutely necessary?'' '' Oh, absolutely! He (Levin) has been to see us. Come, what is it? You go in, sit down, talk for five minutes of the weather, get up and go away.''

'' Oh, you wouldn't believe it! I've got so out of the way of all this that it makes me feel positively ashamed.

A complete outsider walks in, sits down, stays on with nothing to do, wastes their time and worries himself, and walks away!''

It's such a horrible thing to do! Kitty laughed. '' Why, I suppose you used to pay calls before you were married, didn't you?''

``Yes, I did, but I always felt ashamed, and now I'm so out of the way of it that, by Jove!

I'd sooner go two days running without my dinner than pay this call! One's so ashamed! I feel all the while that they're annoyed, that they're saying, `What has he (I) come for?''' (unknown)

'' No, they won't. I'll answer for that,'' said Kitty, looking into his (I) face with a laugh. She (Kitty) took his (I) hand.

'' Kostya, do you know I've only fifty roubles left?'' '' Oh, all right, I'll go to the bank and get some.

How much? '' he (Kostya) said, with the expression of dissatisfaction she (wife) knew so well. '' No, wait a minute. '' She (wife) held his (Kostya) hand.

``Let's talk about it, it worries me. I seem to spend nothing unnecessary, but money seems to fly away simply. We don't manage well, somehow.'' (he)

'' Oh, it's all right,'' he (Kostya) said with a little cough, looking at her (wife) from under his (Kostya) brows. That cough she (wife) knew well.

He (Kostya) certainly was displeased not at so much money being spent, but at being reminded of what he (Kostya), knowing something was unsatisfactory, wanted to forget.

It was a sign of intense dissatisfaction, not with her (wife), but with himself. '' I have told Sokolov to sell the wheat, and to borrow an advance on the mill.

We shall have money enough in any case. '' '' Yes, but I'm afraid that altogether...'' '' Oh, it's all right, all right,'' he (Sokolov) repeated.

As it is, I'm worrying you all, and we're wasting our money. ''

``Not at all, not at all. Not once since I've been married have I said that things could have been better than they are...'' (he)

But when he (Sokolov) glanced at her (it) and saw those sweet truthful eyes fastened questioningly on him (Sokolov), he (Sokolov) repeated it with his (Sokolov) whole heart.

she (it) said, looking into his (Sokolov) eyes. He (Sokolov) had said it without thinking, simply to console her (it). '' I was positively forgetting her (it),'' he (Sokolov) thought.

And he (Sokolov) remembered what was before them, so soon to come. '' Will it be soon? How do you feel? '' he (Sokolov) whispered, taking her (it) two hands.

'' I have so often thought so, that now I don't think about it or know anything about it.'' '' And you're not frightened?

'' She (it) smiled contemptuously. '' Not the least little bit,'' she (it) said. '' Well, if anything happens, I shall be at Katavasov's.''

'' No, nothing will happen, and don't think about it. I'm going for a walk on the boulevard with papa. We're going to see Dolly.

I shall expect you before dinner. Oh, yes! Do you know that Dolly's position is becoming utterly impossible? She (Dolly)'s in debt all round; she (Dolly) hasn't a penny.

said Levin.
