I'll go and see him (Levin). By the way, if I do go to the concert, I'll go with Natalia. Well, good-bye.

On the steps Levin was stopped by his (Levin) old servant Kouzma, who had been with him (Levin) before his (Levin) marriage, and now looked after their household in town.

'' '' Beauty'' -LRB-that was the left shaft-horse brought up from the country-RRB-

``has been badly shod and is quite lame,'' (he)
he (Levin) said.

'' What does your honor wish to be done? '' During the first part of their stay in Moscow, Levin had used his (Levin) own horses brought up from the country.

He (Levin) had tried to arrange this part of their expenses in the best and cheapest way possible; but it appeared that their own horses came dearer than hired horses, and they still hired too.

Levin was not by now struck as he (Levin) had been at first by the fact that to get from one end of Moscow to the other he (Levin) had to have two powerful horses put into a heavy carriage, to take the carriage three miles through the snowy slush and to keep it standing there four hours, paying five roubles every time.

``Send for the veterinary, there may be a bruise.'' (Katerina Alexandrovna)
'' And for Katerina Alexandrovna?'' asked Kouzma. Now it seemed quite natural.

And so, simply and easily, thanks to the facilities of town life, Levin settled a question which, in the country, would have called for so much personal trouble and exertion, and going out onto the steps, he (Levin) called a sledge, sat down, and drove to Nikitsky.

On the way he (Levin) thought no more of money, but mused on the introduction that awaited him (Levin) to the Petersburg savant, a writer on sociology, and what he (writer) would say to him (writer) about his (writer) book.

Only during the first days of his (writer) stay in Moscow Levin had been struck by the expenditure, strange to one living in the country, unproductive but inevitable, that was expected of him (Levin) on every side.

'' Hire a pair for our carriage from the jobmaster,'' said he (Levin). '' Yes, sir. '' But by now he (Levin) had grown used to it.

That had happened to him (Levin) in this matter which is said to happen to drunkards--the first glass sticks in the throat,

When Levin had changed his (Levin) first hundred-rouble note to pay for liveries for his (Levin) footmen and hall-porter he (Levin) could not help reflecting that these liveries were of no use to anyone--but they were indubitably necessary, to judge by the amazement of the princess and Kitty when he (Levin) suggested that they might do without liveries,--that these liveries would cost the wages of two laborers for the summer, that is, would pay for about three hundred working days from Easter to Ash Wednesday, and each a day of hard work from early morning to late evening--and that hundred-rouble note did stick in his (Levin) throat.

the second flies down like a hawk, but after the third they're like tiny little birds. But the next note, changed to pay for providing a dinner for their relations

, that cost twenty-eight roubles, though it did excite in Levin the reflection that twenty-eight roubles meant nine measures of oats, which men would with groans and sweat have reaped and bound and thrashed and winnowed and sifted and sown,--this

next one he (Levin) parted with more easily. And now the notes he (Levin) changed no longer aroused such reflections, and they flew off like little birds.

Whether the labor devoted to obtaining the money corresponded to the pleasure given by what was bought with it, was a consideration he (Levin) had long ago dismissed.

The rye, for the price of which he (Levin) had so long held out, had been sold for fifty kopecks a measure cheaper than it had been fetching a month ago.

Even the consideration that with such an expenditure he (Levin) could not go on living for a year without debt, that even had no force.

Only one thing was essential: to have money in the bank, without inquiring where it came from, so as to know that one had the wherewithal to buy meat for tomorrow.

His (Levin) business calculation that there was a certain price below which he (Levin) could not sell certain grain was forgotten too. And this condition had hitherto been fulfilled; he (Levin) had always had the money in the bank.

But now the money in the bank had gone, and he (Levin) could not quite tell where to get the next installment.

And this it was which, at the moment when Kitty had mentioned money, had disturbed him (Levin); but he (Levin) had no time to think about it.

Chapter 3 Levin had on this visit to town seen a great deal of his (Levin) old friend at the university, Professor Katavasov, whom he (Professor) had not seen since his (Professor) marriage.

He (Professor) drove off, thinking of Katavasov and the meeting with Metrov that was before him (Professor). He (Professor) liked in Katavasov the clearness and simplicity of his (Professor) conception of life.

Levin thought that the clearness of Katavasov's conception of life was due to the poverty of his (Levin) nature; Katavasov thought that the disconnectedness of Levin's ideas was due to his (Levin) lack of intellectual discipline; but Levin enjoyed Katavasov's clearness, and Katavasov enjoyed the abundance of Levin's untrained ideas, and they liked to meet and to discuss.

On the previous day Katavasov had met Levin at a public lecture and told him (Levin) that the celebrated Metrov, whose article Levin had so much liked, was in Moscow, that he (Levin) had been much interested by what Katavasov had told him (Levin) about Levin's work, and that he (Levin) was coming to see him (Levin) tomorrow at eleven, and would be very glad to make Levin's acquaintance.

Levin had read Katavasov some parts of his (Levin) book, and he (Levin) had liked them. '' You're positively a reformed character, I'm glad to see,'' said Katavasov, meeting Levin in the little drawing room.

'' I heard the bell and thought: Impossible that it can be he (Levin) at the exact time! ... Well, what do you say to the Montenegrins now?

Katavasov in a few words told him (Levin) the last piece of news from the war, and going into his (Levin) study, introduced Levin to a short, thick-set man of pleasant appearance.

The conversation touched for a brief space on politics and on how recent events were looked at in the higher spheres in Petersburg.

Metrov repeated a saying that had reached him (Levin) through a most trustworthy source, reported as having been uttered on this subject by the Tsar and one of the ministers.

They're a race of warriors. ''

``Why, what's happened?'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
asked Levin. This was Metrov. Katavasov had heard also on excellent authority that the Tsar had said something quite different.

Levin tried to imagine circumstances in which both sayings might have been uttered, and the conversation on that topic dropped. ''

Yes, here he (Levin)'s written almost a book on the natural conditions of the laborer in relation to the land,'' said Katavasov;

``I'm not a specialist, but I, as a natural science man, was pleased at his (man) not taking mankind as something outside biological laws; but, on the contrary, seeing his (man) dependence on his (man) surroundings, and in that dependence seeking the laws of his (man) development.'' (Katavasov)

What I began precisely was to write a book on agriculture; but studying the chief instrument of agriculture, the laborer,'' said Levin, reddening,

``I could not help coming to quite unexpected results.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

That's very interesting,'' said Metrov. '' '' And Levin began carefully, as it were, feeling his (Levin) ground, to expound his (Levin) views.

He (Levin) knew Metrov had written an article against the generally accepted theory of political economy, but to what extent he (Levin) could reckon on his (Levin) sympathy with his (Levin) own new views he (Levin) did not know and could not guess from the clever and serene face of the learned man.

But in what do you see the special characteristics of the Russian laborer?'' said Metrov;

``in his (laborer) biological characteristics, so to speak, or in the condition in which he (laborer) is placed?

But he (laborer) went on explaining his (laborer) own idea that the Russian laborer has a quite special view of the land, different from that of other people; and to support this proposition he (laborer) made haste to add that in his (laborer) opinion this attitude of the Russian peasant was due to the consciousness of his (laborer) vocation to people vast unoccupied expanses in the East.

One may easily be led into error in basing any conclusion on the general vocation of a people,'' (Metrov)

said Metrov, interrupting Levin.

'' '' Levin saw that there was an idea underlying this question with which he (Levin) did not agree. '' '' The condition of the laborer will always depend on his (laborer) relation to the land and to capital.

'' And without letting Levin finish explaining his (Levin) idea, Metrov began expounding to him (Levin) the special point of his (Levin) own theory.

In what the point of his (Levin) theory lay, Levin did not understand, because he (Levin) did not take the trouble to understand.

He (Levin) saw that Metrov, like other people, in spite of his (Levin) own article, in which he (Levin) had attacked the current theory of political economy, looked at the position of the Russian peasant simply from the point of view of capital, wages, and rent.

He (peasant) would indeed have been obliged to admit that in the eastern--much the larger--part of Russia rent was as yet nil, that for nine-tenths of the eighty millions of the Russian peasants wages took the form simply of food provided for themselves, and that capital does not so far exist except in the form of the most primitive tools.

Yet it was only from that point of view that he (peasant) considered every laborer, though in many points he (peasant) differed from the economists and had his (peasant) own theory of the wage-fund, which he (peasant) expounded to Levin.

He (Levin) would have liked to interrupt Metrov, to explain his (Levin) own thought, which in his (Levin) opinion would have rendered further exposition of Metrov's theories superfluous.

But later on, feeling convinced that they looked at the matter so differently, that they could never understand one another, he (Levin) did not even oppose his (Levin) statements, but simply listened.

Although what Metrov was saying was by now utterly devoid of interest for him (Levin), he (Levin) yet experienced a certain satisfaction in listening to him (Levin).

It flattered his (Levin) vanity that such a learned man should explain his (Levin) ideas to him (Levin) so eagerly, with such intensity and confidence in Levin's understanding of the subject, sometimes with a mere hint referring him (Levin) to a whole aspect of the subject.

He (Levin) put this down to his (Levin) own credit, unaware that Metrov, who had already discussed his (Levin) theory over and over again with all his (Levin) intimate friends, talked of it with special eagerness to every new person, and in general was eager to talk to anyone of any subject that interested him (Levin), even if still obscure to himself.

Levin listened reluctantly, and at first made objections. '' We are late though,'' said Katavasov, looking at his (Levin) watch directly Metrov had finished his (Levin) discourse.

Yes, there's a meeting of the Society of Amateurs today in commemoration of the jubilee of Svintitch,'' said Katavasov in answer to Levin's inquiry.

'' '' Pyotr Ivanovitch and I were going. I've promised to deliver an address on his (Levin) labors in zoology. Come along with us, it's very interesting.''

'' Yes, and indeed it's time to start,'' said Metrov.

``Come with us, and from there, if you care to, come to my place.

I should very much like to hear your work. '' (unknown)

'' Oh, no! It's no good yet , it's unfinished. But I shall be very glad to go to the meeting.

He (Levin) has handed in the separate report,'' Katavasov called from the other room, where he (Levin) was putting on his (Levin) frock coat.

'' ``I say, friends, have you heard? And a conversation sprang up upon the university question, which was a very important event that winter in Moscow.

Three old professors in the council had not accepted the opinion of the younger professors. The young ones had registered a separate resolution.

This, in the judgment of some people, was monstrous, in the judgment of others it was the simplest and most just thing to do, and the professors were split up into two parties.

One party, to which Katavasov belonged, saw in the opposite party a scoundrelly betrayal and treachery, while the opposite party saw in them childishness and lack of respect for the authorities.

Levin, though he (Levin) did not belong to the university, had several times already during his (Levin) stay in Moscow heard and talked about this matter, and had his (Levin) own opinion on the subject.

He (Levin) took part in the conversation that was continued in the street, as they all three walked to the buildings of the old university.

Round the cloth-covered table, at which Katavasov and Metrov seated themselves, there were some half-dozen persons, and one of these was bending close over a manuscript, reading something aloud.

Levin sat down in one of the empty chairs that were standing round the table, and in a whisper asked a student sitting near what was being read.

Though Levin was not interested in the biography, he (Levin) could not help listening, and learned some new and interesting facts about the life of the distinguished man of science.

The meeting had already begun. The student, eyeing Levin with displeasure, said:

``Biography.'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
When the reader had finished, the chairman thanked him (chairman) and read some verses of the poet

Then Katavasov in his (poet) loud, ringing voice read his (poet) address on the scientific labors of the man whose jubilee was being kept.

When Katavasov had finished, Levin looked at his (Levin) watch, saw it was past one, and thought that there would not be time before the concert to read Metrov his (Levin) book, and indeed, he (Levin) did not now care to do so.

Ment sent him (Levin) on the jubilee, and said a few words by way of thanks to the poet. During the reading he (poet) had thought over their conversation.

He (poet) saw distinctly now that though Metrov's ideas might perhaps have value, his (poet) own ideas had a value too, and their ideas could only be made clear and lead to something if each worked separately in his (poet) chosen path, and that nothing would be gained by putting their ideas together.

And having made up his (poet) mind to refuse Metrov's invitation, Levin went up to him (Levin) at the end of the meeting.

Metrov told the chairman what he (Levin) had already told Levin, and Levin made the same remarks on his (Levin) news that he (Levin) had already made that morning, but for the sake of variety he (Levin) expressed also a new opinion which had only just struck him (Levin).

Metrov introduced Levin to the chairman, with whom he (Levin) was talking of the political news. After that the conversation turned again on the university question.

As Levin had already heard it all, he (Levin) made haste to tell Metrov that he (Levin) was sorry he (Levin) could not take advantage of his (Levin) invitation, took leave, and drove to Lvov's.

Chapter 4 Lvov, the husband of Natalia, Kitty's sister, had spent all his (husband) life in foreign capitals, where he (husband) had been educated, and had been in the diplomatic service.

During the previous year he (husband) had left the diplomatic service, not owing to any

``unpleasantness'' (he)
-LRB-he (husband) never had any
``unpleasantness'' (he)
with anyone-RRB-, and was transferred to the department of the court of the palace in Moscow, in order to give his (husband) two boys the best education possible.

In spite of the striking contrast in their habits and views and the fact that Lvov was older than Levin, they had seen a great deal of one another that winter, and had taken a great liking to each other.

Lvov, in a house coat with a belt and in chamois leather shoes, was sitting in an armchair, and with a pince-nez with blue glasses he (Levin) was reading a book that stood on a reading desk, while in his (Levin) beautiful hand he (Levin) held a half-burned cigarette daintily away from him (Levin).

His (Levin) handsome, delicate, and still youthful-looking face, to which his (Levin) curly, glistening silvery hair gave a still more aristocratic air, lighted up with a smile when he (Levin) saw Levin.

Lvov was at home, and Levin went in to him (Levin) unannounced. '' Capital! I was meaning to send to you. How's Kitty?

Sit here, it's more comfortable. '' He (Levin) got up and pushed up a rocking chair. '' Have you read the last circular in the Journal de St. Petersbourg?

Levin told him (Levin) what he (Levin) had heard from Katavasov was being said in Petersburg, and after talking a little about politics, he (Levin) told him (Levin) of his (Levin) interview with Metrov, and the learned society's meeting.

I think it's excellent,'' he (Levin) said, with a slight French accent. To Lvov it was very interesting. '' That's what I envy you, that you are able to mix in these interesting scientific circles,'' he (Levin) said.

And as he (Levin) talked, he (Levin) passed as usual into French, which was easier to him (Levin). '' It's true I haven't the time for it.

My official work and the children leave me no time; and then I'm not ashamed to own that my education has been too defective.''

``That I don't believe,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin with a smile, feeling, as he (Levin) always did, touched at Lvov's low opinion of himself, which was not in the least put on from a desire to seem or to be modest, but was absolutely sincere.

'' Oh, yes, indeed! I feel now how badly educated I am. To educate my children I positively have to look up a great deal, and in fact simply to study myself.

For it's not enough to have teachers, there must be someone to look after them, just as on your land you want laborers and an overseer.

See what I'm reading''--he (overseer) pointed to Buslaev's Grammar on the desk--``it's expected of Misha, and it's so difficult.... Come, explain to me....

Levin tried to explain to him (Levin) that it couldn't be understood, but that it had to be taught; but Lvov would not agree with him (Levin).

``On the contrary, you can't imagine how, when I look at you, I'm always learning the task that lies before me, that is the education of one's children.'' (he)

Here he (Levin) says... '' '' Oh, you're laughing at it!'' '' Well, there's nothing for you to learn,'' said Lvov. ''

All I know,'' said Levin,

``is that I have never seen better brought-up children than yours, and I wouldn't wish for children better than yours.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

Lvov visibly tried to restrain the expression of his (Levin) delight, but he (Levin) was positively radiant with smiles. '' If only they're better than I!

That's all I desire. You don't know yet all the work,'' he (Levin) said,

``with boys who've been left like mine to run wild abroad.'' (he)

``You'll catch all that up. They're such clever children. The great thing is the education of character. That's what I learn when I look at your children.'' (unknown)

``You talk of the education of character. You can't imagine how difficult that is! You have hardly succeeded in combating one tendency when others crop up, and the struggle begins again.

If one had not a support in religion--you remember we talked about that--no father could bring children up relying on his (father) own strength alone without that help.

This subject, which always interested Levin, was cut short by the entrance of the beauty Natalia Alexandrovna, dressed to go out.

I didn't know you were here,'' (she)

she (Natalia) said, unmistakably feeling no regret, but a positive pleasure, in interrupting this conversation on a topic she (Natalia) had heard so much of that she (Natalia) was by now weary of it.

'' '' '' Well, how is Kitty? I am dining with you today. I tell you what, Arseny,'' she (Kitty) turned to her (Kitty) husband,

``you take the carriage.

As the husband had to drive to meet someone on official business, while the wife had to go to the concert and some public meeting of a committee on the Eastern Question, there was a great deal to consider and settle.

'' (husband)

And the husband and wife began to discuss their arrangements for the day. Levin had to take part in their plans as one of themselves.

It was settled that Levin should go with Natalia to the concert and the meeting, and that from there they should send the carriage to the office for Arseny, and he (Levin) should call for her (Natalia) and take her (Natalia) to Kitty's; or that, if he (Levin) had not finished his (Levin) work, he (Levin) should send the carriage back and Levin would go with her (Kitty).

He (Levin)'s spoiling me,'' Lvov said to his (Levin) wife;

``he (Levin) assures me that our children are splendid, when I know how much that's bad there is in them.'' (wife)

'' '' Arseny goes to extremes, I always say,'' said his (Levin) wife. '' If you look for perfection, you will never be satisfied.

when we were brought up there was one extreme--we were kept in the basement, while our parents lived in the best rooms; now it's just the other way--the parents are in the wash house, while the children are in the best rooms.

And it's true, as papa says,--that Parents now are not expected to live at all, but to exist altogether for their children.''

'' Well, what if they like it better? '' Lvov said, with his (papa) beautiful smile, touching her (Parents) hand. '' Anyone who didn't know you would think you were a stepmother, not a true mother.''

No, extremes are not good in anything,'' Natalia said serenely, putting his (papa) paper knife straight in its proper place on the table.

Well, come here, you perfect children,'' Lvov said to the two handsome boys who came in, and after bowing to Levin, went up to their father, obviously wishing to ask him (Levin) about something.

Levin would have liked to talk to them, to hear what they would say to their father, but Natalia began talking to him (Levin), and then Lvov's colleague in the service, Mahotin, walked in, wearing his (Levin) court uniform, to go with him (Levin) to meet someone, and a conversation was kept up without a break upon Herzegovina, Princess Korzinskaya, the town council, and the sudden death of Madame Apraksina.

'' '' Levin even forgot the commission intrusted to him (Levin). He (Levin) recollected it as he (Levin) was going into the hall. ''

Oh, Kitty told me to talk to you about Oblonsky,'' he (Levin) said, as Lvov was standing on the stairs, seeing his (Levin) wife and Levin off.

Well, then, I will attack him (Levin),'' said Madame Lvova, with a smile, standing in her (wife) white sheepskin cape, waiting till they had finished speaking.

'' Yes, yes, maman wants us, les beaux-fr√®res, to attack him (Levin),'' he (Levin) said, blushing. '' But why should I?'' ''

``Come, let us go.

'' (unknown)

Chapter 5 At the concert in the afternoon two very interesting things were performed. One was a fantasia, King Lear; the other was a quartette dedicated to the memory of Bach.

After escorting his (Bach) sister-in-law to her (sister-in-law) stall, he (Bach) stood against a column and tried to listen as attentively and conscientiously as possible.

He (Bach) tried not to let his (Bach) attention be distracted, and not to spoil his (Bach) impression by looking at the conductor in a white tie, waving his (Bach) arms, which always disturbed his (Bach) enjoyment of music so much, or the ladies in bonnets, with strings carefully tied over their ears, and all these people either thinking of nothing at all or thinking of all sorts of things except the music.

Both were new and in the new style, and Levin was eager to form an opinion of them. He (Levin) tried to avoid meeting musical connoisseurs or talkative acquaintances, and stood looking at the floor straight before him (Levin), listening.

But the more he (Levin) listened to the fantasia of King Lear the further he (King) felt from forming any definite opinion of it.

There was, as it were, a continual beginning, a preparation of the musical expression of some feeling, but it fell to pieces again directly, breaking into new musical motives, or simply nothing but the whims of the composer, exceedingly complex but disconnected sounds.

And these fragmentary musical expressions, though sometimes beautiful, were disagreeable, because they were utterly unexpected and not led up to by anything.

Gaiety and grief and despair and tenderness and triumph followed one another without any connection, like the emotions of a madman.

During the whole of the performance Levin felt like a deaf man watching people dancing, and was in a state of complete bewilderment when the fantasia was over, and felt a great weariness from the fruitless strain on his (Levin) attention.

And those emotions, like a madman's, sprang up quite unexpectedly. Loud applause resounded on all sides. Everyone got up, moved about, and began talking.

Anxious to throw some light on his (Levin) own perplexity from the impressions of others, Levin began to walk about, looking for connoisseurs, and was glad to see a well-known musical amateur in conversation with Pestsov, whom he (Levin) knew.

Particularly sculpturesque and plastic, so to say, and richly colored is that passage where you feel Cordelia's approach, where woman, das ewig Weibliche, enters into conflict with fate.

``Marvelous!'' (Pestsov)
Pestsov was saying in his (Levin) mellow bass. '' How are you, Konstantin Dmitrievitch? Isn't it?'' '' You mean...what has Cordelia to do with it?''

``Cordelia comes in...see here!'' (Pestsov)
said Pestsov, tapping his (Dmitrievitch) finger on the satiny surface of the program he (Dmitrievitch) held in his (Dmitrievitch) hand and passing it to Levin.

Only then Levin recollected the title of the fantasia, and made haste to read in the Russian translation the lines from Shakespeare that were printed on the back of the program.

You can't follow it without that,'' said Pestsov, addressing Levin, as the person he (Levin) had been speaking to had gone away, and he (Levin) had no one to talk to.

In the entr`acte Levin and Pestsov fell into an argument upon the merits and defects of music of the Wagner school.

Levin maintained that the mistake of Wagner and all his (Levin) followers lay in their trying to take music into the sphere of another art, just as poetry goes wrong when it tries to paint a face as the art of painting ought to do, and as an instance of this mistake he (Levin) cited the sculptor who carved in marble certain poetic phantasms flitting round the figure of the poet on the pedestal.

Levin asked timidly, forgetting that the fantasia was supposed to represent King Lear. '' '' These phantoms were so far from being phantoms that they were positively clinging on the ladder,'' said Levin.

The comparison pleased him (Levin), but he (Levin) could not remember whether he (Levin) had not used the same phrase before, and to Pestsov, too, and as he (Levin) said it he (Levin) felt confused.

Pestsov maintained that art is one, and that it can attain its highest manifestations only by conjunction with all kinds of art.

Pestsov, who was standing beside him (Levin), was talking to him (Levin) almost all the time, condemning the music for its excessive affected assumption of simplicity, and comparing it with the simplicity of the Pre-Raphaelites in painting.

As he (Levin) went out Levin met many more acquaintances, with whom he (Levin) talked of politics, of music, and of common acquaintances.

The second piece that was performed Levin could not hear. Among others he (Levin) met Count Bol, whom he (Levin) had utterly forgotten to call upon.

Well, go at once then,'' Madame Lvova said, when he (Levin) told her (Levin);

``perhaps they'll not be at home, and then you can come to the meeting to fetch me.

'' (her)

You'll find me still there. '' Chapter 6 '' Perhaps they're not at home? '' said Levin, as he (Levin) went into the hall of Countess Bola's house.

'' At home; please walk in,'' said the porter, resolutely removing his (porter) overcoat. '' How annoying! '' thought Levin with a sigh, taking off one glove and stroking his (Levin) hat.

As he (Levin) passed through the first drawing room Levin met in the doorway Countess Bola, giving some order to a servant with a care-worn and severe face.

'' What did I come for? What have I to say to them? '' On seeing Levin she (Countess) smiled, and asked him (Levin) to come into the little drawing room, where he (Levin) heard voices.

In this room there were sitting in armchairs the two daughters of the countess, and a Moscow colonel, whom Levin knew.

Levin went up, greeted them, and sat down beside the sofa with his (Levin) hat on his (Levin) knees. '' How is your wife?

Have you been at the concert? We couldn't go. Mamma had to be at the funeral service. ''

``Yes, I heard....

The countess came in, sat down on the sofa, and she (countess) too asked after his (Levin) wife and inquired about the concert.

What a sudden death!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

said Levin. Levin answered, and repeated an inquiry about Madame Apraksina's sudden death. '' But she (countess) was always in weak health.

``Yes, very good,'' (he)
he (Levin) said, and as it was utterly of no consequence to him (Levin) what they thought of him (Levin), he (Levin) began repeating what they had heard a hundred times about the characteristics of the singer's talent.

''

``Were you at the opera yesterday?'' (unknown)
``Yes, I was. '' (unknown)
'' Lucca was very good.'' Countess Bola pretended to be listening.

Then, when he (Levin) had said enough and paused, the colonel, who had been silent till then, began to talk. The colonel too talked of the opera, and about culture.

Levin too rose, but he (Levin) saw by the face of the countess that it was not yet time for him (Levin) to go.

At last, after speaking of the proposed folle journ√©e at Turin's, the colonel laughed, got up noisily, and went away. He (colonel) must stay two minutes longer.

But as he (colonel) was thinking all the while how stupid it was, he (colonel) could not find a subject for conversation, and sat silent.

He (colonel) sat down. '' You are not going to the public meeting? They say it will be very interesting,'' began the countess.

'' No, I promised my belle-soeur to fetch her (countess) from it,'' said Levin. A silence followed. The mother once more exchanged glances with a daughter.

'' Well, now I think the time has come,'' thought Levin, and he (Levin) got up. The ladies shook hands with him (Levin), and begged him (Levin) to say mille choses to his (Levin) wife for them.

The porter asked him (Levin), as he (Levin) gave him (Levin) his (Levin) coat,

``Where is your honor staying?'' (him)
and immediately wrote down his (Levin) address in a big handsomely bound book.

Of course I don't care, but still I feel ashamed and awfully stupid,'' thought Levin, consoling himself with the reflection that everyone does it.

'' He (Levin) drove to the public meeting, where he (Levin) was to find his (Levin) sister-in-law, so as to drive home with her (sister-in-law).

At the public meeting of the committee there were a great many people, and almost all the highest society. Levin was in time for the report which, as everyone said, was very interesting.

When the reading of the report was over, people moved about, and Levin met Sviazhsky, who invited him (Levin) very pressingly to come that evening to a meeting of the Society of Agriculture, where a celebrated lecture was to be delivered, and Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had only just come from the races, and many other acquaintances; and Levin heard and uttered various criticisms on the meeting, on the new fantasia, and on a public trial.

But, probably from the mental fatigue he (Levin) was beginning to feel, he (Levin) made a blunder in speaking of the trial, and this blunder he (Levin) recalled several times with vexation.

Speaking of the sentence upon a foreigner who had been condemned in Russia, and of how unfair it would be to punish him (foreigner) by exile abroad, Levin repeated what he (Levin) had heard the day before in conversation from an acquaintance.

I think sending him (Levin) abroad is much the same as punishing a carp by putting it into the water,'' said Levin.

Then he (Levin) recollected that this idea, which he (Levin) had heard from an acquaintance and uttered as his (Levin) own, came from a fable of Krilov's, and that the acquaintance had picked it up from a newspaper article.

'' After driving home with his (acquaintance) sister-in-law, and finding Kitty in good spirits and quite well, Levin drove to the club.

Levin had not been at the club for a very long while--not since he (Levin) lived in Moscow, when he (Levin) was leaving the university and going into society.

He (Levin) remembered the club, the external details of its arrangement, but he (Levin) had completely forgotten the impression it had made on him (Levin) in old days.

But as soon as, driving into the wide semicircular court and getting out of the sledge, he (Levin) mounted the steps, and the hall porter, adorned with a crossway scarf, noiselessly opened the door to him (porter) with a bow; as soon as he (porter) saw in the porter's room the cloaks and galoshes of members who thought it less trouble to take them off downstairs; as soon as he (porter) heard the mysterious ringing bell that preceded him (porter) as he (porter) ascended the easy, carpeted staircase, and saw the statue on the landing, and the third porter at the top doors, a familiar figure grown older, in the club livery, opening the door without haste or delay, and scanning the visitors as they passed in--Levin felt the old impression of the club come back in a rush, an impression of repose, comfort, and propriety.

Chapter 7 Levin reached the club just at the right time. Members and visitors were driving up as he (Levin) arrived. ''

Your hat, please,'' the porter said to Levin, who forgot the club rule to leave his (Levin) hat in the porter's room.

'' Long time since you've been. The prince put your name down yesterday. Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch is not here yet. ''

The porter did not only know Levin, but also all his (Levin) ties and relationships, and so immediately mentioned his (Levin) intimate friends.

Passing through the outer hall, divided up by screens, and the room partitioned on the right, where a man sits at the fruit buffet, Levin overtook an old man walking slowly in, and entered the dining room full of noise and people.

He (Levin) walked along the tables, almost all full, and looked at the visitors. He (Levin) saw people of all sorts, old and young; some he (Levin) knew a little, some intimate friends.

All seemed to have left their cares and anxieties in the porter's room with their hats, and were all deliberately getting ready to enjoy the material blessings of life.

There was not a single cross or worried-looking face. Sviazhsky was here and Shtcherbatsky, Nevyedovsky and the old prince, and Vronsky and Sergey Ivanovitch.

'' Ah! why are you late? '' the prince said smiling, and giving him (prince) his (prince) hand over his (prince) own shoulder. ''

How's Kitty? '' he (prince) added, smoothing out the napkin he (prince) had tucked in at his (prince) waistcoat buttons. '' All right; they are dining at home,

Go to that table, and make haste and take a seat,'' said the prince, and turning away he (prince) carefully took a plate of eel soup.

all the three of them.''

``Ah, `Aline-Nadine,' to be sure! There's no room with us. '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin, this way!'' a good-natured voice shouted a little farther on.

It was Turovtsin. He (Levin) was sitting with a young officer, and beside them were two chairs turned upside down. Levin gladly went up to them.

He (Levin) had always liked the good-hearted rake, Turovtsin--he (Levin) was associated in his (Levin) mind with memories of his (Levin) courtship--and at that moment, after the strain of intellectual conversation, the sight of Turovtsin's good-natured face was particularly welcome.

'' For you and Oblonsky. He (Levin)'ll be here directly. '' The young man, holding himself very erect, with eyes forever twinkling with enjoyment, was an officer from Petersburg, Gagin.

Turovtsin introduced them. '' Oblonsky's always late.''

``Ah, here he (officer) is!'' (unknown)
``Have you only just come?'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)
said Oblonsky, coming quickly towards them.

Levin got up and went with him (Levin) to the big table spread with spirits and appetizers of the most various kinds.

One would have thought that out of two dozen delicacies one might find something to one's taste, but Stepan Arkadyevitch asked for something special, and one of the liveried waiters standing by immediately brought what was required.

'' Good day. Had some vodka? Well, come along then. '' They drank a wine glassful and returned to their table.

At once, while they were still at the soup, Gagin was served with champagne, and told the waiter to fill four glasses.

He (waiter) was very hungry, and ate and drank with great enjoyment, and with still greater enjoyment took part in the lively and simple conversation of his (waiter) companions.

Gagin, dropping his (waiter) voice, told the last good story from Petersburg, and the story, though improper and stupid, was so ludicrous that Levin broke into roars of laughter so loud that those near looked round.

Levin did not refuse the wine, and asked for a second bottle. '' That's in the same style as, `that's a thing I can't endure!'

You know the story?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Ah, that's exquisite! Another bottle,'' he (Levin) said to the waiter, and he (Levin) began to relate his (Levin) good story.

Pyotr Illyitch Vinovsky invites you to drink with him (Levin),'' a little old waiter interrupted Stepan Arkadyevitch, bringing two delicate glasses of sparkling champagne, and addressing Stepan Arkadyevitch and Levin.

Stepan Arkadyevitch took the glass, and looking towards a bald man with red mustaches at the other end of the table, he (man) nodded to him (man), smiling.

'' '' Who's that?'' asked Levin. '' You met him (Levin) once at my place, don't you remember? A good-natured fellow. ''

Levin did the same as Stepan Arkadyevitch and took the glass. Stepan Arkadyevitch's anecdote too was very amusing. Levin told his (Levin) story, and that too was successful.

Then they talked of horses, of the races, of what they had been doing that day, and of how smartly Vronsky's Atlas had won the first prize.

Stepan Arkadyevitch said towards the end of dinner, leaning over the back of his (Levin) chair and holding out his (Levin) hand to Vronsky, who came up with a tall officer of the Guards.

Levin did not notice how the time passed at dinner. '' Ah! and here they are!'' Vronsky's face too beamed with the look of good-humored enjoyment that was general in the club.

He (Vronsky) propped his (Vronsky) elbow playfully on Stepan Arkadyevitch's shoulder, whispering something to him (Vronsky), and he (Vronsky) held out his (Vronsky) hand to Levin with the same good-humored smile.

'' Very glad to meet you,'' he (Levin) said. '' I looked out for you at the election, but I was told you had gone away.''

``Yes, I left the same day. We've just been talking of your horse. I congratulate you,'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
said Levin. '' It was very rapidly run.

'' '' Yes; you've race horses too, haven't you?'' '' No, my father had; but I remember and know something about it.''

``Where have you dined?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
asked Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' We were at the second table, behind the columns.'' '' We've been celebrating his (father) success,'' said the tall colonel.

'' It's his (father) second Imperial prize. I wish I might have the luck at cards he (father) has with horses. Well, why waste the precious time?

I'm going to the `infernal regions,''' added the colonel, and he (colonel) walked away. '' That's Yashvin,'' Vronsky said in answer to Turovtsin, and he (Vronsky) sat down in the vacated seat beside them.

Under the influence of the club atmosphere or the wine he (Vronsky) had drunk, Levin chatted away to Vronsky of the best breeds of cattle, and was very glad not to feel the slightest hostility to this man.

He (man) even told him (man), among other things, that he (man) had heard from his (man) wife that she (wife) had met him (man) at Princess Marya Borissovna's.

Ah, Princess Marya Borissovna, she (Borissovna)'s exquisite!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and he (man) told an anecdote about her (Borissovna) which set them all laughing.

He (man) drank the glass offered him (man), and ordered a bottle of wine. '' Vronsky particularly laughed with such simplehearted amusement that Levin felt quite reconciled to him (Levin).

Chapter 8 Getting up from the table, Levin walked with Gagin through the lofty room to the billiard room, feeling his (Levin) arms swing as he (Levin) walked with a peculiar lightness and ease.

'' Well, have we finished?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting up with a smile.

``Let us go. '' (he)
As he (Levin) crossed the big room, he (Levin) came upon his (Levin) father-in-law.

'' Well, how do you like our Temple of Indolence? '' said the prince, taking his (prince) arm. '' Come along, come along!''

``Yes, I wanted to walk about and look at everything. It's interesting.'' (unknown)
'' Yes, it's interesting for you. But its interest for me is quite different.

You look at those little old men now,'' he (prince) said, pointing to a club member with bent back and projecting lip, shuffling towards them in his (prince) soft boots,

``and imagine that they were shlupiks like that from their birth up.'' (lip shuffling)

``How shlupiks ?'' (unknown)
``I see you don't know that name. That's our club designation. You know the game of rolling eggs: when one's rolled a long while it becomes a shlupik .

So it is with us; one goes on coming and coming to the club, and ends by becoming a shlupik .

Ah, you laugh! but we look out, for fear of dropping into it ourselves. You know Prince Tchetchensky? '' (the prince)

inquired the prince; and Levin saw by his (Levin) face that he (Levin) was just going to relate something funny.

'' No, I don't know him (Levin). '' ``You don't say so! Well, Prince Tchetchensky is a well-known figure. No matter, though.

Only three years ago he (Tchetchensky) was not a shlupik and kept up his (Tchetchensky) spirits and even used to call other people shlupiks .

He (Tchetchensky)'s always playing billiards here. But one day he (Tchetchensky) turns up, and our porter...you know Vassily? Why, that fat one ; he (Tchetchensky)'s famous for his (Tchetchensky) bon mots .

And so Prince Tchetchensky asks him (Tchetchensky), `Come, Vassily, who's here? Any shlupiks here yet?' And he (Tchetchensky) says, `You're the third.' Yes, my dear boy, that he (boy) did!

Talking and greeting the friends they met, Levin and the prince walked through all the rooms: the great room where tables had already been set, and the usual partners were playing for small stakes; the divan room, where they were playing chess, and Sergey Ivanovitch was sitting talking to somebody; the billiard room, where, about a sofa in a recess, there was a lively party drinking champagne--

They peeped into the

``infernal regions,'' (party)
where a good many men were crowding round one table, at which Yashvin was sitting.

Trying not to make a noise, they walked into the dark reading room, where under the shaded lamps there sat a young man with a wrathful countenance, turning over one journal after another, and a bald general buried in a book.

They went, too, into what the prince called the intellectual room, where three gentlemen were engaged in a heated discussion of the latest political news.

Prince, please come, we're ready,'' said one of his (Prince) card party, who had come to look for him (Prince), and the prince went off.

Levin sat down and listened, but recalling all the conversation of the morning he (Levin) felt all of a sudden fearfully bored.

'' Gagin was one of them. '' He (Levin) got up hurriedly, and went to look for Oblonsky and Turovtsin, with whom it had been so pleasant.

Turovtsin was one of the circle drinking in the billiard room, and Stepan Arkadyevitch was talking with Vronsky near the door at the farther corner of the room.

It's not that she (Levin)'s dull; but this undefined, this unsettled position,'' Levin caught, and he (Levin) was hurrying away, but Stepan Arkadyevitch called to him (Levin).

Levin,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and Levin noticed that his (Levin) eyes were not full of tears exactly, but moist, which always happened when he (Levin) had been drinking, or when he (Levin) was touched.

Levin, don't go,'' he (Levin) said, and he (Levin) warmly squeezed his (Levin) arm above the elbow, obviously not at all wishing to let him (Levin) go.

'' '' Just now it was due to both causes. '' '' This is a true friend of mine--almost my greatest friend,'' he (friend) said to Vronsky.

'' You have become even closer and dearer to me. And I want you, and I know you ought, to be friends, and great friends, because you're both splendid fellows.

Well, there's nothing for us now but to kiss and be friends,'' Vronsky said, with good-natured playfulness, holding out his (Vronsky) hand.

'' '' Levin quickly took the offered hand, and pressed it warmly. '' I'm very, very glad,'' said Levin. '' Waiter, a bottle of champagne,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

But in spite of Stepan Arkadyevitch's desire, and their own desire, they had nothing to talk about, and both felt it.

'' And I'm very glad,'' said Vronsky. '' Do you know, he (Levin) has never met Anna? '' Stepan Arkadyevitch said to Vronsky.

'' And I want above everything to take him (Levin) to see her (Anna). Let us go, Levin!''

said Vronsky. '' She (Anna) will be very glad to see you.

'' (he)

``Why, is he (Yashvin) losing?'' (He)

It has been ready a long while,'' answered the marker, who had already set the balls in a triangle, and was knocking the red one about for his (Yashvin) own diversion.

Levin, will you play? Capital! '' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' Get the table ready,'' he (Levin) said to the marker. '' ''

After the game Vronsky and Levin sat down at Gagin's table, and at Stepan Arkadyevitch's suggestion Levin took a hand in the game.

Well, let us begin. '' Vronsky sat down at the table, surrounded by friends, who were incessantly coming up to him (Levin).

Every now and then he (Levin) went to the

``infernal'' (he)
to keep an eye on Yashvin. Levin was enjoying a delightful sense of repose after the mental fatigue of the morning.

He (Levin) was glad that all hostility was at an end with Vronsky, and the sense of peace, decorum, and comfort never left him (Levin).

When the game was over, Stepan Arkadyevitch took Levin's arm. '' Well, let us go to Anna's, then. At once? Eh?

She (Anna) is at home. I promised her (Anna) long ago to bring you. Where were you meaning to spend the evening?'' ''

Oh, nowhere specially. I promised Sviazhsky to go to the Society of Agriculture. By all means, let us go,'' said Levin.

Levin went up to the table, paid the forty roubles he (Levin) had lost; paid his (Levin) bill, the amount of which was in some mysterious way ascertained by the little old waiter who stood at the counter, and swinging his (waiter) arms he (waiter) walked through all the rooms to the way out.

'' Very good; come along. Find out if my carriage is here,'' Stepan Arkadyevitch said to the waiter. Chapter 9

``Oblonsky's carriage!

It was only for the first few moments, while the carriage was driving out of the clubhouse gates, that Levin was still under the influence of the club atmosphere of repose, comfort, and unimpeachable good form.

But as soon as the carriage drove out into the street, and he (Levin) felt it jolting over the uneven road, heard the angry shout of a sledge driver coming towards them, saw in the uncertain light the red blind of a tavern and the shops, this impression was dissipated, and he (driver) began to think over his (driver) actions, and to wonder whether he (driver) was doing right in going to see Anna.

'' (the porter)

the porter shouted in an angry bass. The carriage drove up and both got in. What would Kitty say? But Stepan Arkadyevitch gave him (porter) no time for reflection, and, as though divining his (porter) doubts, he (porter) scattered them.

'' How glad I am,'' he (porter) said,

``that you should know her (Kitty)! You know Dolly has long wished for it. And Lvov's been to see her (Dolly), and often goes.

Though she (Dolly) is my sister,'' (he)

Stepan Arkadyevitch pursued,
``I don't hesitate to say that she (Dolly)'s a remarkable woman. But you will see.

Her (Dolly) position is very painful, especially now. '' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

``Why especially now? '' (unknown)
``We are carrying on negotiations with her (Dolly) husband about a divorce.

And he (husband)'s agreed; but there are difficulties in regard to the son, and the business, which ought to have been arranged long ago, has been dragging on for three months past.

As soon as the divorce is over, she (Dolly) will marry Vronsky. How stupid these old ceremonies are, that no one believes in, and which only prevent people being comfortable!'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

Stepan Arkadyevitch put in. '' Well, then their position will be as regular as mine, as yours. '' '' What is the difficulty?'' said Levin.

But the point is she (Dolly) has been for three months in Moscow, where everyone knows her (Dolly), waiting for the divorce; she (Dolly) goes out nowhere, sees no woman except Dolly, because, do you understand,

'' Oh, it's a long and tedious story! The whole business is in such an anomalous position with us. she (Dolly) doesn't care to have people come as a favor.

That fool Princess Varvara, even she (Princess) has left her (Princess), considering this a breach of propriety. Well, you see, in such a position any other woman would not have found resources in herself.

But you'll see how she (woman) has arranged her (woman) life--how calm, how dignified she (woman) is. To the left, in the crescent opposite the church!'' shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch, leaning out of the window.

'' Phew! how hot it is!'' he (fool) said, in spite of twelve degrees of frost, flinging his (fool) open overcoat still wider open.

'' But she (woman) has a daughter: no doubt she (woman)'s busy looking after her (woman)?'' said Levin. '' I believe you picture every woman simply as a female, une couveuse, '' said Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' If she (female)'s occupied, it must be with her (female) children. No, she (female) brings her (female) up capitally, I believe, but one doesn't hear about her (female).

She (female)'s busy, in the first place, with what she (female) writes. I see you're smiling ironically, but you're wrong. She (female)'s writing a children's book, and doesn't talk about it to anyone, but she (female) read it to me

and I gave the manuscript to Vorkuev... you know the publisher... and he (female)'s an author himself too, I fancy. He (female) understands those things, and he (female) says it's a remarkable piece of work.

But are you fancying she (female)'s an authoress?--not a bit of it. She (female)'s a woman with a heart, before everything, but you'll see.

Now she (female) has a little English girl with her (female), and a whole family she (female)'s looking after. '' '' Oh, something in a philanthropic way?

''

``Why, you will look at everything in the worst light. It's not from philanthropy, it's from the heart. They--that is, Vronsky-- had a trainer, an Englishman, first-rate in his (Englishman) own line, but a drunkard.

She (female) saw them, helped them, got more and more interested in them, and now the whole family is on her (female) hands.

But not by way of patronage, you know, helping with money; she (female)'s herself preparing the boys in Russian for the high school, and she (female)'s taken the little girl to live with her (female).

He (Englishman)'s completely given up to drink--delirium tremens-- and the family were cast on the world. But you'll see her (female) for yourself.

And without asking the servant who opened the door whether the lady were at home, Stepan Arkadyevitch walked into the hall.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

The carriage drove into the courtyard, and Stepan Arkadyevitch rang loudly at the entrance where sledges were standing. Levin followed him (Levin), more and more doubtful whether he (Levin) was doing right or wrong.

Looking at himself in the glass, Levin noticed that he (Levin) was red in the face, but he (Levin) felt certain he (Levin) was not drunk, and he (Levin) followed Stepan Arkadyevitch up the carpeted stairs.

At the top Stepan Arkadyevitch inquired of the footman, who bowed to him (footman) as to an intimate friend, who was with Anna Arkadyevna, and received the answer that it was M. Vorkuev.

Passing through the dining room, a room not very large, with dark, paneled walls, Stepan Arkadyevitch and Levin walked over the soft carpet to the half-dark study, lighted up by a single lamp with a big dark shade.

Another lamp with a reflector was hanging on the wall, lighting up a big full-length portrait of a woman, which Levin could not help looking at.

While Stepan Arkadyevitch went behind the treillage , and the man's voice which had been speaking paused, Levin gazed at the portrait, which stood out from the frame in the brilliant light thrown on it, and he (Levin) could not tear himself away from it.

He (Levin) positively forgot where he (Levin) was, and not even hearing what was said, he (Levin) could not take his (Levin) eyes off the marvelous portrait.

'' Where are they?'' '' In the study. '' It was the portrait of Anna, painted in Italy by Mihailov. It was not a picture, but

a living, charming woman, with black curling hair, with bare arms and shoulders, with a pensive smile on the lips, covered with soft down; triumphantly and softly she (woman) looked at him (Levin) with eyes that baffled him (Levin).

He (Levin) heard suddenly near him (Levin) a voice, unmistakably addressing him (Levin), the voice of the very woman he (Levin) had been admiring in the portrait.

Anna had come from behind the treillage to meet him (Levin), and Levin saw in the dim light of the study the very woman of the portrait, in a dark blue shot gown, not in the same position nor with the same expression, but with the same perfection of beauty which the artist had caught in the portrait.

She (woman) was less dazzling in reality, but, on the other hand, there was something fresh and seductive in the living woman which was not in the portrait.

She (woman) was not living only because she (woman) was more beautiful than a living woman can be. '' I am delighted!'' Chapter 10

She (woman) had risen to meet him (artist), not concealing her (woman) pleasure at seeing him (artist); and in the quiet ease with which she (woman) held out her (woman) little vigorous hand, introduced him (artist) to Vorkuev and indicated a red-haired, pretty little girl who was sitting at work, calling her (girl) her (girl) pupil, Levin recognized and liked the manners of a woman of the great world, always self-possessed and natural.

'' I am delighted, delighted,'' she (woman) repeated, and on her (woman) lips these simple words took for Levin's ears a special significance.

I have known you and liked you for a long while, both from your friendship with Stiva and for your wife's sake....

I knew her (wife) for a very short time, but she (wife) left on me the impression of an exquisite flower, simply a flower.

She (wife) spoke easily and without haste, looking now and then from Levin to her (wife) brother, and Levin felt that the impression he (Levin) was making was good, and he (Levin) felt immediately at home, simple and happy with her (wife), as though he (Levin) had known her (wife) from childhood.

Ivan Petrovitch and I settled in Alexey's study,'' she (wife) said in answer to Stepan Arkadyevitch's question whether he (Alexey) might smoke,

``just so as to be able to smoke'' (he)
--and glancing at Levin, instead of asking whether he (Levin) would smoke, she (wife) pulled closer a tortoise-shell cigar-case and took a cigarette.

'' And to think she (wife) will soon be a mother! '' '' '' How are you feeling today? '' her (wife) brother asked her (wife).

'' Oh, nothing. Nerves, as usual. ''

``Yes, isn't it extraordinarily fine?'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch, noticing that Levin was scrutinizing the picture.

'' I have never seen a better portrait.'' '' And extraordinarily like, isn't it?'' said Vorkuev. Levin looked from the portrait to the original.

Levin flushed, and to cover his (Levin) confusion would have asked whether she (wife) had seen Darya Alexandrovna lately; but at that moment Anna spoke.

A peculiar brilliance lighted up Anna's face when she (Anna) felt his (Levin) eyes on her (Anna). '' We were just talking, Ivan Petrovitch and I, of Vashtchenkov's last pictures.

Have you seen them?'' '' Yes, I have seen them,'' answered Levin. '' But, I beg your pardon, I interrupted you...

you were saying?... '' Levin asked if she (Anna) had seen Dolly lately. '' She (Anna) was here yesterday. She (Anna) was very indignant with the high school people on Grisha's account.

The Latin teacher, it seems, had been unfair to him (Levin). '' '' Yes, I have seen his (Levin) pictures. I didn't care for them very much,'' Levin went back to the subject she (Anna) had started.

Levin talked now not at all with that purely businesslike attitude to the subject with which he (Levin) had been talking all the morning.

Every word in his (Levin) conversation with her (Anna) had a special significance. And talking to her (Anna) was pleasant; still pleasanter it was to listen to her (Anna).

Anna talked not merely naturally and cleverly, but cleverly and carelessly, attaching no value to her (Anna) own ideas and giving great weight to the ideas of the person she (Anna) was talking to.

The conversation turned on the new movement in art, on the new illustrations of the Bible by a French artist. Vorkuev attacked the artist for a realism carried to the point of coarseness.

Levin said that the French had carried conventionality further than anyone, and that consequently they see a great merit in the return to realism.

In the fact of not lying they see poetry. Never had anything clever said by Levin given him (Levin) so much pleasure as this remark.

Anna's face lighted up at once, as at once she (Anna) appreciated the thought. She (Anna) laughed. '' I laugh,'' she (Anna) said,

``as one laughs when one sees a very true portrait.

But perhaps it is always so, that men form their conceptions from fictitious, conventional types, and then--all the combinaisons made--they are tired of the fictitious figures and begin to invent more natural, true figures.

What you said so perfectly hits off French art now, painting and literature too, indeed--Zola, Daudet. '' (she)

'' That's perfectly true,'' said Vorknev.

Levin thought, forgetting himself and staring persistently at her (Anna) lovely, mobile face, which at that moment was all at once completely transformed.

Levin did not hear what she (Anna) was talking of as she (Anna) leaned over to her (Anna) brother, but he (Levin) was struck by the change of her (Anna) expression.

'' So you've been at the club? '' she (Anna) said to her (Anna) brother. '' Yes, yes, this is a woman!'' Her (Anna) face--so handsome a moment before in its repose--suddenly wore a look of strange curiosity, anger, and pride.

But this lasted only an instant. She (Anna) dropped her (Anna) eyelids, as though recollecting something. '' Oh, well, but that's of no interest to anyone,'' she (Anna) said, and she (Anna) turned to the English girl.

'' Please order the tea in the drawing room,'' she (Anna) said in English. The girl got up and went out. ''

Well, how did she (girl) get through her (girl) examination?'' asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.

``Splendidly! She (girl)'s a very gifted child and a sweet character.'' (unknown)

``It will end in your loving her (girl) more than your own.'' (a man)
'' There a man speaks. In love there's no more nor less.

``I was just telling Anna Arkadyevna,'' (Vorkuev)
said Vorkuev,
``that if she (Arkadyevna) were to put a hundredth part of the energy she (Arkadyevna) devotes to this English girl to the public question of the education of Russian children, she (Arkadyevna) would be doing a great and useful work.

I love my daughter with one love, and her (Arkadyevna) with another.'' (Vorkuev)

'' '' Yes, but I can't help it; I couldn't do it.

Count Alexey Kirillovitch urged me very much'' -LRB-as she (Arkadyevna) uttered the words Count Alexey Kirillovitch she (Arkadyevna) glanced with appealing timidity at Levin, and he (Levin) unconsciously responded with a respectful and reassuring look-RRB-;

``he (Levin) urged me to take up the school in the village.

I visited it several times. The children were very nice, but I could not feel drawn to the work. You speak of energy.

Energy rests upon love; and come as it will, there's no forcing it. I took to this child-- I could not myself say why.

'' (he)

And she (Arkadyevna) glanced again at Levin. And her (Arkadyevna) smile and her (Arkadyevna) glance-- all told him (Levin) that it was to him (Levin)

only she (Arkadyevna) was addressing her (Arkadyevna) words, valuing his (Levin) good opinion, and at the same time sure beforehand that they understood each other.

It's impossible to give one's heart to a school or such institutions in general, and I believe that's just why philanthropic institutions always give such poor results.

'' I quite understand that,'' Levin answered. '' '' She (Arkadyevna) was silent for a while, then she (Arkadyevna) smiled. '' Yes, yes,'' she (Arkadyevna) agreed;

``I never could.
