'' It's well worth taking up.'' '' Oh, no, it's all so sketchy. ''

``I told him (citizen) about it,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
Stepan Arkadyevitch said to his (citizen) sister, nodding at Levin.

My writing is something after the fashion of those little baskets and carving which Liza Mertsalova used to sell me from the prisons.

She (Liza) had the direction of the prison department in that society,'' she (Liza) turned to Levin;

``and they were miracles of patience, the work of those poor wretches.

'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

You shouldn't have. '' And Levin saw a new trait in this woman, who attracted him (Levin) so extraordinarily. Besides wit, grace, and beauty, she (woman) had truth.

As she (woman) said that she (woman) sighed, and her (woman) face suddenly taking a hard expression, looked as it were turned to stone.

With that expression on her (woman) face she (woman) was more beautiful than ever; but the expression was new; it was utterly unlike that expression, radiant with happiness and creating happiness, which had been caught by the painter in her (woman) portrait.

She (woman) had no wish to hide from him (painter) all the bitterness of her (woman) position. Levin looked more than once at the portrait and at her (woman) figure, as taking her (woman) brother's arm

she (woman) walked with him (Levin) to the high doors and he (Levin) felt for her (woman) a tenderness and pity at which he (Levin) wondered himself.

She (woman) asked Levin and Vorkuev to go into the drawing room, while she (woman) stayed behind to say a few words to her (woman) brother.

'' About her (woman) divorce, about Vronsky, and what he (brother)'s doing at the club, about me?'' wondered Levin. And he (Levin) was so keenly interested by the question of what she (woman) was saying to Stepan Arkadyevitch

, that he (Levin) scarcely heard what Vorkuev was telling him (Levin) of the qualities of the story for children Anna Arkadyevna had written.

There was not a single instant when a subject for conversation was to seek; on the contrary, it was felt that one had hardly time to say what one had to say, and eagerly held back to hear what the others were saying.

And all that was said, not only by her (Arkadyevna), but by Vorkuev and Stepan Arkadyevitch--all, so it seemed to Levin, gained peculiar significance from her (Arkadyevna) appreciation and her (Arkadyevna) criticism.

While he (Levin) followed this interesting conversation, Levin was all the time admiring her (Arkadyevna)-- her (Arkadyevna) beauty, her (Arkadyevna) intelligence, her (Arkadyevna) culture, and at the same time her (Arkadyevna) directness and genuine depth of feeling.

At tea the same pleasant sort of talk, full of interesting matter, continued. He (Levin) listened and talked, and all the while he (Levin) was thinking of her (Arkadyevna) inner life, trying to divine her (Arkadyevna) feelings.

And though he (Levin) had judged her (Arkadyevna) so severely hitherto, now by some strange chain of reasoning he (Levin) was justifying her (Arkadyevna) and was also sorry for her (Arkadyevna), and afraid that Vronsky did not fully understand her (Arkadyevna).

At eleven o'clock, when Stepan Arkadyevitch got up to go -LRB-Vorkuev had left earlier-RRB-, it seemed to Levin that he (Levin) had only just come.

Regretfully Levin too rose. '' Good-bye,'' she (Arkadyevna) said, holding his (Levin) hand and glancing into his (Levin) face with a winning look. ''

``Tell your wife that I love her (wife) as before, and that if she (wife) cannot pardon me my position, then my wish for her (wife) is that she (wife) may never pardon it.

I am very glad que la glace est rompue. '' (She)

She (wife) dropped his (Levin) hand, and half closed her (wife) eyes. To pardon it, one must go through what I have gone through, and may God spare her (wife) that.''

``Certainly, yes, I will tell her (wife)... '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
Levin said, blushing. Chapter 11
``What a marvelous, sweet and unhappy woman! '' (he)
he (Levin) was thinking, as he (Levin) stepped out into the frosty air with Stepan Arkadyevitch.

'' Well, didn't I tell you?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, seeing that Levin had been completely won over. '' Yes,'' said Levin dreamily,

``an extraordinary woman!

It's not her (woman) cleverness, but she (woman) has such wonderful depth of feeling. I'm awfully sorry for her (woman)!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

``Now, please God, everything will soon be settled.

Well, well, don't be hard on people in future,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, opening the carriage door. '' Good-bye ; we don't go the same way.

Still thinking of Anna, of everything, even the simplest phrase in their conversation with her (Anna), and recalling the minutest changes in her (Anna) expression, entering more and more into her (Anna) position, and feeling sympathy for her (Anna), Levin reached home.

At home Kouzma told Levin that Katerina Alexandrovna was quite well, and that her (Alexandrovna) sisters had not long been gone, and he (Levin) handed him (Levin) two letters.

'' Levin read them at once in the hall, that he (Levin) might not over look them later. One was from Sokolov, his (Sokolov) bailiff.

Sokolov wrote that the corn could not be sold, that it was fetching only five and a half roubles, and that more than that could not be got for it.

Well, we must sell it at five and a half if we can't get more,'' Levin decided the first question, which had always before seemed such a weighty one, with extraordinary facility on the spot.

The other letter was from his (Levin) sister. She (sister) scolded him (Levin) for her (sister) business being still unsettled. '' '' It's extraordinary how all one's time is taken up here,'' he (Levin) thought, considering the second letter.

He (Levin) felt himself to blame for not having got done what his (Levin) sister had asked him (Levin) to do for her (sister). ''

Today, again, I've not been to the court, but today I've certainly not had time. '' And resolving that he (Levin) would not fail to do it next day, he (Levin) went up to his (Levin) wife.

As he (Levin) went in, Levin rapidly ran through mentally the day he (Levin) had spent. All the events of the day were conversations, conversations he (Levin) had heard and taken part in.

All the conversations were upon subjects which, if he (Levin) had been alone at home, he (Levin) would never have taken up, but here they were very interesting.

One was what he (Levin) had said about the carp, the other was something not

``quite the thing'' (he)
in the tender sympathy he (Levin) was feeling for Anna.

And all these conversations were right enough, only in two places there was something not quite right. Levin found his (Levin) wife low-spirited and dull.

The dinner of the three sisters had gone off very well, but then they had waited and waited for him (Levin), all of them had felt dull, the sisters had departed, and she (wife) had been left alone.

'' Well, and what have you been doing? '' she (wife) asked him (Levin), looking straight into his (Levin) eyes, which shone with rather a suspicious brightness.

But that she (wife) might not prevent his (Levin) telling her (wife) everything, she (wife) concealed her (wife) close scrutiny of him (Levin), and with an approving smile listened to his (Levin) account of how he (Levin) had spent the evening.

You understand, I shall try not to see him (Levin), but I'm glad that this awkwardness is all over,'' he (Levin) said, and remembering that by way of trying not to see him (Levin), he (Levin) had immediately gone to call on Anna, he (Levin) blushed.

We talk about the peasants drinking; I don't know which drinks most, the peasantry or our own class; the peasants do on holidays, but...

'' Well, I'm very glad I met Vronsky. I felt quite at ease and natural with him (Levin). '' '' But Kitty took not the slightest interest in discussing the drinking habits of the peasants.

She (Kitty) saw that he (Levin) blushed, and she (Kitty) wanted to know why. '' Well, and then where did you go?''

``Stiva urged me awfully to go and see Anna Arkadyevna.

And as he (Levin) said this, Levin blushed even more, and his (Levin) doubts as to whether he (Levin) had done right in going to see Anna were settled once for all.

Kitty's eyes opened in a curious way and gleamed at Anna's name, but controlling herself with an effort, she (Anna) concealed her (Anna) emotion and deceived him (Levin).

'' (He)

He (Levin) knew now that he (Levin) ought not to have done so. '' Oh!'' was all she (Anna) said. '' I'm sure you won't be angry at my going.

Stiva begged me to, and Dolly wished it,'' Levin went on. '' Oh, no! '' she (Dolly) said, but he (Levin) saw in her (Dolly) eyes a constraint that boded him (Levin) no good.

She (Dolly) is a very sweet, very, very unhappy, good woman,'' he (Levin) said, telling her (Dolly) about Anna, her (Anna) occupations, and what she (Anna) had told him (Levin) to say to her (Anna).

'' '' Yes, of course, she (Anna) is very much to be pitied,'' said Kitty, when he (Levin) had finished. '' Whom was your letter from?

'' He (Levin) told her (Kitty), and believing in her (Kitty) calm tone, he (Levin) went to change his (Levin) coat. Coming back, he (Levin) found Kitty in the same easy chair.

When he (Levin) went up to her (Kitty), she (Kitty) glanced at him (Levin) and broke into sobs. '' What? what is it? '' he (Levin) asked, knowing beforehand what.

'' You're in love with that hateful woman; she (woman) has bewitched you! I saw it in your eyes. Yes, yes! What can it all lead to?

You were drinking at the club, drinking and gambling, and then you went...to her (woman) of all people! No, we must go away....

At last he (Levin) succeeded in calming her (woman), only by confessing that a feeling of pity, in conjunction with the wine he (Levin) had drunk, had been too much for him (Levin), that he (Levin) had succumbed to Anna's artful influence, and that he (Levin) would avoid her (Anna).

One thing he (Levin) did with more sincerity confess to was that living so long in Moscow, a life of nothing but conversation, eating and drinking, he (Levin) was degenerating.

I shall go away tomorrow. '' It was a long while before Levin could soothe his (Levin) wife. They talked till three o'clock in the morning.

Only at three o'clock were they sufficiently reconciled to be able to go to sleep. Chapter 12 After taking leave of her (wife) guests, Anna did not sit down, but began walking up and down the room.

She (Anna) had unconsciously the whole evening done her (Anna) utmost to arouse in Levin a feeling of love--as of late she (Anna) had fallen into doing with all young men--

and she (Anna) knew she (Anna) had attained her (Anna) aim, as far as was possible in one evening, with a married and conscientious man.

She (Anna) liked him (man) indeed extremely, and, in spite of the striking difference, from the masculine point of view, between Vronsky and Levin, as a woman she (woman) saw something they had in common, which had made Kitty able to love both.

Yet as soon as he (Levin) was out of the room, she (Kitty) ceased to think of him (Levin). One thought, and one only, pursued her (Kitty) in different forms, and refused to be shaken off.

'' If I have so much effect on others, on this man, who loves his (man) home and his (man) wife , why is it

he (man) is so cold to me? ...not cold exactly, he (man) loves me, I know that! But something new is drawing us apart now.

Why wasn't he (man) here all the evening? He (man) told Stiva to say he (man) could not leave Yashvin, and must watch over his (man) play.

Is Yashvin a child? But supposing it's true. He (man) never tells a lie. But there's something else in it if it's true.

He (man) is glad of an opportunity of showing me that he (man) has other duties; I know that, I submit to that.

But why prove that to me? He (man) wants to show me that his (man) love for me is not to interfere with his (man) freedom.

But I need no proofs, I need love. He (man) ought to understand all the bitterness of this life for me here in Moscow.

Is this life? I am not living, but waiting for an event, which is continually put off and put off. No answer again!

And Stiva says he (man) cannot go to Alexey Alexandrovitch. And I can't write again. I can do nothing, can begin nothing,

can alter nothing; I hold myself in, I wait, inventing amusements for myself--the English family, writing, reading--but it's all nothing but a sham

, it's all the same as morphine. He (Alexandrovitch) ought to feel for me,'' she (family) said, feeling tears of self-pity coming into her (family) eyes.

She (family) heard Vronsky's abrupt ring and hurriedly dried her (family) tears-- not only dried her (family) tears, but sat down by a lamp and opened a book, affecting composure.

She (family) wanted to show him (Alexandrovitch) that she (family) was displeased that he (Alexandrovitch) had not come home as he (Alexandrovitch) had promised-- displeased only, and not on any account to let him (Alexandrovitch) see her (family) distress, and least of all, her (family) self-pity.

She (family) did not want strife, she (family) blamed him (Alexandrovitch) for wanting to quarrel, but unconsciously put herself into an attitude of antagonism.

She (family) might pity herself, but he (Alexandrovitch) must not pity her (family). '' Well, you've not been dull? '' he (Alexandrovitch) said, eagerly and good-humoredly, going up to her (family).

'' What a terrible passion it is--gambling!'' '' No, I've not been dull; I've learned long ago not to be dull.

Stiva has been here and Levin. ''

``Yes, they meant to come and see you. Well, how did you like Levin?

'' (he)

he (Levin) said, sitting down beside her (family). '' Very much. They have not long been gone. What was Yashvin doing?'' ''

He (Yashvin) was winning--seventeen thousand. I got him (Yashvin) away. He (Yashvin) had really started home, but he (Yashvin) went back again, and now he (Yashvin)'s losing.''

``Then what did you stay for? '' (she)
she (family) asked, suddenly lifting her (family) eyes to him (Yashvin). The expression of her (family) face was cold and ungracious.

'' You told Stiva you were staying on to get Yashvin away. And you have left him (Yashvin) there. '' The same expression of cold readiness for the conflict appeared on his (Yashvin) face too.

'' In the first place, I did not ask him (Yashvin) to give you any message; and secondly, I never tell lies.

But what's the chief point, I wanted to stay, and I stayed,'' he (Yashvin) said, frowning. '' Anna, what is it for, why will you?

he (Yashvin) said after a moment's silence, bending over towards her (Anna), and he (Yashvin) opened his (Yashvin) hand, hoping she (Anna) would lay hers in it.

But some strange force of evil would not let her (Anna) give herself up to her (Anna) feelings, as though the rules of warfare would not permit her (Anna) to surrender.

'' She (Anna) was glad of this appeal for tenderness. '' Of course you wanted to stay, and you stayed. You do everything you want to.

But what do you tell me that for? With what object? '' she (Anna) said, getting more and more excited. '' Does anyone contest your rights?

But you want to be right, and you're welcome to be right. '' His (Anna) hand closed, he (Anna) turned away, and his (Anna) face wore a still more obstinate expression.

For you it's a matter of obstinacy,'' she (Anna) said, watching him (Anna) intently and suddenly finding the right word for that expression that irritated her (Anna),

``simply obstinacy.

'' (her)

For you it's a question of whether you keep the upper hand of me, while for me... '' Again she (Anna) felt sorry for herself, and she (Anna) almost burst into tears.

When I feel as I do now that you are hostile, yes, hostile to me, if you knew what this means for me!

'' If you knew what it is for me! If you knew how I feel on the brink of calamity at this instant, how afraid I am of myself!

'' And she (Anna) turned away, hiding her (Anna) sobs. '' But what are you talking about? '' he (me) said, horrified at her (Anna) expression of despair, and again bending over her (Anna), he (me) took her (Anna) hand and kissed it.

'' What is it for? Do I seek amusements outside our home? Don't I avoid the society of women?'' '' Well, yes!

I am ready to do anything to make you happy,'' he (me) said, touched by her (Anna) expression of despair;

``what wouldn't I do to save you from distress of any sort, as now, Anna!'' (he)
he (me) said.

If that were all!'' she (Anna) said.

``Come, tell me what I ought to do to give you peace of mind? '' (unknown)

It's nothing, nothing! '' she (Anna) said. '' I don't know myself whether it's the solitary life, my nerves.... Come, don't let us talk of it.

What about the race? You haven't told me! '' she (Anna) inquired, trying to conceal her (Anna) triumph at the victory, which had anyway been on her (Anna) side.

He (me) asked for supper, and began telling her (Anna) about the races; but in his (me) tone, in his (me) eyes, which became more and more cold, she (Anna) saw that he (me) did not forgive her (Anna) for her (Anna) victory, that the feeling of obstinacy with which she (Anna) had been struggling had asserted itself again in him (me).

And she (Anna), remembering the words that had given her (Anna) the victory,

``how I feel on the brink of calamity, how afraid I am of myself,'' (she)
saw that this weapon was a dangerous one, and that it could not be used a second time.

And she (Anna) felt that beside the love that bound them together there had grown up between them some evil spirit of strife, which she (Anna) could not exorcise from his (me), and still less from her (Anna) own heart.

There are no conditions to which a man cannot become used, especially if he (man) sees that all around him (man) are living in the same way.

Levin could not have believed three months before that he (Levin) could have gone quietly to sleep in the condition in which he (Levin) was that day, that leading an aimless, irrational life, living too beyond his (Levin) means, after drinking to excess -LRB-he (Levin) could not call what happened at the club anything else-RRB-, forming inappropriately friendly relations with a man with whom his (man) wife had once been in love, and a still more inappropriate call upon a woman who could only be called a lost woman, after being fascinated by that woman and causing his (man) wife distress--he (man) could still go quietly to sleep.

But under the influence of fatigue, a sleepless night, and the wine he (man) had drunk, his (man) sleep was sound and untroubled.

He (man) was colder to her (wife) than before, as though he (man) were regretting his (man) surrender. Chapter 13 At five o'clock the creak of a door opening waked him (man).

He (man) jumped up and looked round. Kitty was not in bed beside him (man). But there was a light moving behind the screen, and he (man) heard her (Kitty) steps.

'' What is it?... what is it? '' he (man) said, half-asleep.

``Kitty! What is it?'' (unknown)
``Nothing,'' (she)
she (Kitty) said, coming from behind the screen with a candle in her (Kitty) hand.

'' I felt unwell,'' she (Kitty) said, smiling a particularly sweet and meaning smile. '' What? has it begun? '' he (man) said in terror.

'' We ought to send...'' and hurriedly he (man) reached after his (man) clothes. '' No, no,'' she (Kitty) said, smiling and holding his (man) hand.

'' It's sure to be nothing. I was rather unwell, only a little. It's all over now. '' And getting into bed, she (Kitty) blew out the candle, lay down and was still.

Though he (man) thought her (Kitty) stillness suspicious, as though she (Kitty) were holding her (Kitty) breath, and still more suspicious the expression of peculiar tenderness and excitement with which, as she (Kitty) came from behind the screen, she (Kitty) said

``nothing,'' (she)
he (man) was so sleepy that he (man) fell asleep at once.

Only later he (man) remembered the stillness of her (Kitty) breathing, and understood all that must have been passing in her (Kitty) sweet, precious heart while she (Kitty) lay beside him (man), not stirring, in anticipation of the greatest event in a woman's life.

At seven o'clock he (man) was waked by the touch of her (woman) hand on his (man) shoulder, and a gentle whisper. She (woman) seemed struggling between regret at waking him (man), and the desire to talk to him (man).

'' Kostya, don't be frightened. It's all right. But I fancy.... We ought to send for Lizaveta Petrovna. '' The candle was lighted again.

She (woman) was sitting up in bed, holding some knitting, which she (woman) had been busy upon during the last few days. ''

I'm not a bit afraid,'' she (woman) said, seeing his (Kostya) scared face, and she (woman) pressed his (Kostya) hand to her (woman) bosom and then to her (woman) lips.

He (Kostya) hurriedly jumped up, hardly awake, and kept his (Kostya) eyes fixed on her (woman), as he (Kostya) put on his (Kostya) dressing gown; then he (Kostya) stopped, still looking at her (woman).

Please, don't be frightened, it's all right. He (Kostya) had to go, but he (Kostya) could not tear himself from her (woman) eyes. He (Kostya) thought he (Kostya) loved her (woman) face, knew her (woman) expression, her (woman) eyes, but never had he (Kostya) seen it like this.

How hateful and horrible he (Kostya) seemed to himself, thinking of the distress he (Kostya) had caused her (woman) yesterday. Her (woman) flushed face, fringed with soft curling hair under her (woman) night cap, was radiant with joy and courage.

Though there was so little that was complex or artificial in Kitty's character in general, Levin was struck by what was revealed now, when suddenly all disguises were thrown off and the very kernel of her (Kitty) soul shone in her (Kitty) eyes.

And in this simplicity and nakedness of her (Kitty) soul, she (Kitty), the very woman he (Levin) loved in her (Kitty), was more manifest than ever.

She (Kitty) looked at him (Levin), smiling; but all at once her (Kitty) brows twitched, she (Kitty) threw up her (Kitty) head, and going quickly up to him (Levin), clutched his (Levin) hand and pressed close up to him (Levin), breathing her (Kitty) hot breath upon him (Levin).

She (Kitty) was in pain and was, as it were, complaining to him (Levin) of her (Kitty) suffering. And for the first minute, from habit, it seemed to him (Levin) that he (Levin) was to blame.

But in her (Kitty) eyes there was a tenderness that told him (Levin) that she (Kitty) was far from reproaching him (Levin), that she (Kitty) loved him (Levin) for her (Kitty) sufferings.

'' If not I, who is to blame for it? '' he (Levin) thought unconsciously, seeking someone responsible for this suffering for him (Levin) to punish; but there was no one responsible.

She (Kitty) was suffering, complaining, and triumphing in her (Kitty) sufferings, and rejoicing in them, and loving them. He (Levin) saw that something sublime was being accomplished in her (Kitty) soul, but what?

He (Levin) could not make it out. It was beyond his (Levin) understanding. '' I have sent to mamma. You go quickly to fetch Lizaveta Petrovna ...Kostya!...

Nothing, it's over. '' She (Kitty) moved away from him (Kostya) and rang the bell. '' Well, go now; Pasha's coming. I am all right.

And Levin saw with astonishment that she (Kitty) had taken up the knitting she (Kitty) had brought in in the night and begun working at it again.

He (Levin) stood at the door and heard Kitty giving exact directions to the maid, and beginning to help her (Kitty) move the bedstead.

He (Levin) dressed, and while they were putting in his (Levin) horses, as a hired sledge was not to be seen yet, he (Levin) ran again up to the bedroom, not on tiptoe, it seemed to him (Levin), but on wings.

'' As Levin was going out of one door, he (Levin) heard the maid-servant come in at the other. Two maid-servants were carefully moving something in the bedroom.

Kitty was walking about knitting rapidly and giving directions. '' I'm going for the doctor. They have sent for Lizaveta Petrovna, but I'll go on there too.

Isn't there anything wanted? Yes, shall I go to Dolly's? '' She (Dolly) looked at him (doctor), obviously not hearing what he (doctor) was saying.

'' Yes, yes. Do go,'' she (Dolly) said quickly, frowning and waving her (Dolly) hand to him (doctor). He (doctor) had just gone into the drawing room, when suddenly a plaintive moan sounded from the bedroom, smothered instantly.

He (doctor) stood still, and for a long while he (doctor) could not understand. '' Yes, that is she (Dolly),'' he (doctor) said to himself, and clutching at his (doctor) head he (doctor) ran downstairs.

'' Lord have mercy on us! pardon us! aid us! '' he (Lord) repeated the words that for some reason came suddenly to his (Lord) lips.

At that instant he (Lord) knew that all his (Lord) doubts, even the impossibility of believing with his (Lord) reason, of which he (Lord) was aware in himself, did not in the least hinder his (Lord) turning to God.

And he (Lord), an unbeliever, repeated these words not with his (Lord) lips only. All of that now floated out of his (Lord) soul like dust.

To whom was he (Lord) to turn if not to Him (Lord) in whose hands he (Lord) felt himself, his (Lord) soul, and his (Lord) love?

The horse was not yet ready, but feeling a peculiar concentration of his (Lord) physical forces and his (Lord) intellect on what he (Lord) had to do, he (Lord) started off on foot without waiting for the horse, and told Kouzma to overtake him (Lord).

At the corner he (Lord) met a night cabman driving hurriedly. In the little sledge, wrapped in a velvet cloak, sat Lizaveta Petrovna with a kerchief round her (himself) head.

``Thank God! thank God!'' (he)
he (God) said, overjoyed to recognize her (himself) little fair face which wore a peculiarly serious, even stern expression.

Telling the driver not to stop, he (driver) ran along beside her (himself). '' For two hours, then? Not more? '' she (himself) inquired.

'' You should let Pyotr Dmitrievitch know, but don't hurry him (driver). And get some opium at the chemist's.'' '' So you think that it may go on well?

Lord have mercy on us and help us!'' Levin said, seeing his (Levin) own horse driving out of the gate. Jumping into the sledge beside Kouzma, he (Levin) told him (Levin) to drive to the doctor's.

The doctor was not yet up, and the footman said that

``he (footman) had been up late, and had given orders not to be waked, but would get up soon.

This concentration of the footman upon his (footman) lamps, and his (footman) indifference to what was passing in Levin, at first astounded him (Levin), but immediately on considering the question he (Levin) realized that no one knew or was bound to know his (Levin) feelings, and that it was all the more necessary to act calmly, sensibly, and resolutely to get through this wall of indifference and attain his (Levin) aim.

Don't be in a hurry or let anything slip,'' (the footman)

Levin said to himself, feeling a greater and greater flow of physical energy and attention to all that lay before him (Levin) to do.

Having ascertained that the doctor was not getting up, Levin considered various plans, and decided on the following one: that Kouzma should go for another doctor, while he (doctor) himself should go to the chemist's for opium, and if when he (doctor) came back the doctor had not yet begun to get up, he (doctor) would either by tipping the footman, or by force, wake the doctor at all hazards.

At the chemist's the lank shopman sealed up a packet of powders for a coachman who stood waiting, and refused him (chemist) opium with the same callousness with which the doctor's footman had cleaned his (footman) lamp chimneys.

Trying not to get flurried or out of temper, Levin mentioned the names of the doctor and midwife, and explaining what the opium was needed for, tried to persuade him (Levin).

The assistant inquired in German whether he (assistant) should give it, and receiving an affirmative reply from behind the partition, he (assistant) took out a bottle and a funnel, deliberately poured the opium from a bigger bottle into a little one, stuck on a label, sealed it up, in spite of Levin's request that he (Levin) would not do so, and was about to wrap it up too.

This was more than Levin could stand; he (Levin) took the bottle firmly out of his (Levin) hands, and ran to the big glass doors.

The doctor was not even now getting up, and the footman, busy now in putting down the rugs, refused to wake him (footman).

Levin deliberately took out a ten rouble note, and, careful to speak slowly, though losing no time over the business, he (Levin) handed him (Levin) the note, and explained that Pyotr Dmitrievitch -LRB-what a great and important personage he (Levin) seemed to Levin now, this Pyotr Dmitrievitch, who had been of so little consequence in his (Levin) eyes before!-RRB-

had promised to come at any time; that he (Levin) would certainly not be angry! and that he (Levin) must therefore wake him (Levin) at once.

Chapter 14 '' The footman was cleaning the lamp-chimneys, and seemed very busy about them. '' The footman agreed, and went upstairs, taking Levin into the waiting room.

Levin could hear through the door the doctor coughing, moving about, washing, and saying something. Three minutes passed; it seemed to Levin that more than an hour had gone by.

He (Levin) could not wait any longer. '' Pyotr Dmitrievitch, Pyotr Dmitrievitch!'' he (Levin) said in an imploring voice at the open door.

'' For God's sake, forgive me! See me as you are. It's been going on more than two hours already. ''

``In a minute; in a minute!'' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)
answered a voice, and to his (God) amazement Levin heard that the doctor was smiling as he (doctor) spoke.

Two minutes more passed while the doctor was putting on his (doctor) boots, and two minutes more while the doctor put on his (doctor) coat and combed his (doctor) hair. ''

'' For one instant.''

``In a minute. '' (Pyotr Dmitrievitch)
Pyotr Dmitrievitch!'' Levin was beginning again in a plaintive voice, just as the doctor came in dressed and ready.

'' These people have no conscience,'' thought Levin. '' Combing his (Levin) hair, while we're dying!''

``Good morning! '' (the doctor)
the doctor said to him (doctor), shaking hands, and, as it were, teasing him (doctor) with his (doctor) composure.

'' Trying to be as accurate as possible, Levin began to tell him (Levin) every unnecessary detail of his (Levin) wife's condition, interrupting his (Levin) account repeatedly with entreaties that the doctor would come with him (doctor) at once.

'' There's no hurry. Well now? '' Oh, you needn't be in any hurry. You don't understand, you know. I'm certain I'm not wanted, still I've promised, and if you like, I'll come.

Levin stared at him (Levin) with eyes that asked whether he (Levin) was laughing at him (Levin); but the doctor had no notion of making fun of him (doctor).

I know, I know,'' the doctor said, smiling;

``I'm a married man myself; and at these moments we husbands are very much to be pitied.

But there's no hurry. Please sit down; won't you have some coffee? '' (the doctor)

'' I've a patient whose husband always takes refuge in the stables on such occasions.''

'' But what do you think, Pyotr Dmitrievitch? Do you suppose it may go all right? ''

``Everything points to a favorable issue.'' (unknown)

'' So you'll come immediately?'' said Levin, looking wrathfully at the servant who was bringing in the coffee. '' In an hour's time.

''

``Oh, for mercy's sake!'' (me)
'' Well, let me drink my coffee, anyway. '' The doctor started upon his (doctor) coffee. Both were silent.

'' The Turks are really getting beaten, though. Did you read yesterday's telegrams?'' said the doctor, munching some roll. '' No, I can't stand it!'' said Levin, jumping up.

'' So you'll be with us in a quarter of an hour.''

``In half an hour. '' (unknown)
``On your honor? '' (Levin/Nikolay/Nikolay Levin)

When Levin got home, he (Levin) drove up at the same time as the princess, and they went up to the bedroom door together.

The princess had tears in her (princess) eyes, and her (princess) hands were shaking. Seeing Levin, she (princess) embraced him (Levin), and burst into tears.

'' Well, my dear Lizaveta Petrovna? '' she (princess) queried, clasping the hand of the midwife, who came out to meet them with a beaming and anxious face.

From the moment when he (Levin) had waked up and understood what was going on, Levin had prepared his (Levin) mind to bear resolutely what was before him (Levin), and without considering or anticipating anything, to avoid upsetting his (Levin) wife, and on the contrary to soothe her (wife) and keep up her (wife) courage.

Without allowing himself even to think of what was to come, of how it would end, judging from his (Levin) inquiries as to the usual duration of these ordeals, Levin had in his (Levin) imagination braced himself to bear up and to keep a tight rein on his (Levin) feelings for five hours, and it had seemed to him (Levin) he (Levin) could do this.

But when he (Levin) came back from the doctor's and saw her (wife) sufferings again, he (Levin) fell to repeating more and more frequently:

``Lord, have mercy on us, and succor us!'' (he)

He (Lord) sighed, and flung his (Lord) head up, and began to feel afraid he (Lord) could not bear it, that he (Lord) would burst into tears or run away.

'' She (wife)'s going on well,'' she (wife) said;

``persuade her (wife) to lie down. She (wife) will be easier so. '' (she)
Such agony it was to him (Lord).

But after that hour there passed another hour, two hours, three, the full five hours he (Lord) had fixed as the furthest limit of his (Lord) sufferings, and the position was still unchanged; and he (Lord) was still bearing it because there was nothing to be done but bear it;

every instant feeling that he (Lord) had reached the utmost limits of his (Lord) endurance, and that his (Lord) heart would break with sympathy and pain.

But still the minutes passed by and the hours, and still hours more, and his (Lord) misery and horror grew and were more and more intense.

All the ordinary conditions of life, without which one can form no conception of anything, had ceased to exist for Levin.

And only one hour had passed. He (Levin) lost all sense of time. Minutes--those minutes when she (Lord) sent for him (Levin) and he (Levin) held her (Lord) moist hand

, that would squeeze his (Levin) hand with extraordinary violence and then push it away--seemed to him (Levin) hours, and hours seemed to him (Levin) minutes.

He (Levin) was surprised when Lizaveta Petrovna asked him (Levin) to light a candle behind a screen, and he (Levin) found that it was five o'clock in the afternoon.

If he (Levin) had been told it was only ten o'clock in the morning, he (Levin) would not have been more surprised. Where he (Levin) was all this time, he (Levin) knew as little as the time of anything.

He (Levin) saw the old princess too, flushed and overwrought, with her (princess) gray curls in disorder, forcing herself to gulp down her (princess) tears, biting her (princess) lips; he (Levin) saw Dolly too and the doctor, smoking fat cigarettes, and Lizaveta Petrovna with a firm, resolute, reassuring face, and the old prince walking up and down the hall with a frowning face.

He (prince) saw her (princess) swollen face, sometimes bewildered and in agony, sometimes smiling and trying to reassure him (prince). But why they came in and went out, where they were, he (prince) did not know.

The princess was with the doctor in the bedroom, then in the study, where a table set for dinner suddenly appeared; then she (princess) was not there, but Dolly was.

Then Levin remembered he (Levin) had been sent somewhere. Once he (Levin) had been sent to move a table and sofa. He (Levin) had done this eagerly, thinking it had to be done for her (Dolly) sake, and

only later on he (Levin) found it was his (Levin) own bed he (Levin) had been getting ready. Then he (Levin) had been sent to the study to ask the doctor something.

Then he (Levin) had been sent to the bedroom to help the old princess to move the holy picture in its silver and gold setting, and with the princess's old waiting maid he (Levin) had clambered on a shelf to reach it and had broken the little lamp, and the old servant had tried to reassure him (servant) about the lamp and about his (servant) wife, and he (servant) carried the holy picture and set it at Kitty's head, carefully tucking it in behind the pillow.

The doctor had answered and then had said something about the irregularities in the municipal council. But where, when, and why all this had happened, he (doctor) could not tell.

He (doctor) did not understand why the old princess took his (doctor) hand, and looking compassionately at him (doctor), begged him (doctor) not to worry himself, and Dolly persuaded him (doctor) to eat something and led him (doctor) out of the room, and even the doctor looked seriously and with commiseration at him (doctor) and offered him (doctor) a drop of something.

All he (doctor) knew and felt was that what was happening was what had happened nearly a year before in the hotel of the country town at the deathbed of his (doctor) brother Nikolay.

Yet that grief and this joy were alike outside all the ordinary conditions of life; they were loop-holes, as it were, in that ordinary life through which there came glimpses of something sublime.

And in the contemplation of this sublime something the soul was exalted to inconceivable heights of which it had before had no conception, while reason lagged behind, unable to keep up with it.

'' he (doctor) repeated to himself incessantly, feeling, in spite of his (doctor) long and, as it seemed, complete alienation from religion, that he (doctor) turned to God just as trustfully and simply as he (doctor) had in his (doctor) childhood and first youth.

But that had been grief-- this was joy. '' Lord, have mercy on us, and succor us! All this time he (Lord) had two distinct spiritual conditions.

One was away from her (doctor), with the doctor, who kept smoking one fat cigarette after another and extinguishing them on the edge of a full ash tray, with Dolly, and with the old prince, where there was talk about dinner, about politics, about Marya Petrovna's illness, and where Levin suddenly forgot for a minute what was happening, and felt as though he (Levin) had waked up from sleep; the other was in her (Dolly) presence, at her (Dolly) pillow, where his (Levin) heart seemed breaking and still did not break from sympathetic suffering, and he (Levin) prayed to God without ceasing.

And every time he (Levin) was brought back from a moment of oblivion by a scream reaching him (Levin) from the bedroom, he (Levin) fell into the same strange terror that had come upon him (Levin) the first minute.

Every time he (Levin) heard a shriek, he (Levin) jumped up, ran to justify himself, remembered on the way that he (Levin) was not to blame, and he (Levin) longed to defend her (Dolly), to help her (Dolly).

But as he (Levin) looked at her (Dolly), he (Levin) saw again that help was impossible, and he (Levin) was filled with terror and prayed:

``Lord, have mercy on us, and help us!'' (he)

And as time went on, both these conditions became more intense; the calmer he (Lord) became away from her (Dolly), completely forgetting her (Dolly), the more agonizing became both her (Dolly) sufferings and his (Lord) feeling of helplessness before them.

Sometimes, when again and again she (Dolly) called upon him (Lord), he (Lord) blamed her (Dolly); but seeing her (Dolly) patient, smiling face, and hearing the words,

``I am worrying you,'' (patient)
he (Lord) threw the blame on God; but thinking of God, at once he (God) fell to beseeching God to forgive him (God) and have mercy.

He (God) jumped up, would have liked to run away, but ran to her (Dolly). Chapter 15 He (God) did not know whether it was late or early.

The candles had all burned out. Dolly had just been in the study and had suggested to the doctor that he (doctor) should lie down.

Levin sat listening to the doctor's stories of a quack mesmerizer and looking at the ashes of his (Levin) cigarette. There had been a period of repose, and he (Levin) had sunk into oblivion.

He (Levin) had completely forgotten what was going on now. He (Levin) heard the doctor's chat and understood it. Suddenly there came an unearthly shriek.

The shriek was so awful that Levin did not even jump up, but holding his (Levin) breath, gazed in terrified inquiry at the doctor.

The doctor put his (doctor) head on one side, listened, and smiled approvingly. Everything was so extraordinary that nothing could strike Levin as strange.

He (Levin) jumped up, ran on tiptoe to the bedroom, edged round Lizaveta Petrovna and the princess, and took up his (Levin) position at Kitty's pillow.

'' I suppose it must be so,'' he (Levin) thought, and still sat where he (Levin) was. Whose scream was this? The scream had subsided, but there was some change now.

What it was he (Levin) did not see and did not comprehend, and he (Levin) had no wish to see or comprehend. But he (Levin) saw it by the face of Lizaveta Petrovna.

Lizaveta Petrovna's face was stern and pale, and still as resolute, though her (Kitty) jaws were twitching, and her (Kitty) eyes were fixed intently on Kitty.

Kitty's swollen and agonized face, a tress of hair clinging to her (Kitty) moist brow, was turned to him (Levin) and sought his (Levin) eyes.

Her (Kitty) lifted hands asked for his (Levin) hands. Clutching his (Levin) chill hands in her (Kitty) moist ones, she (Kitty) began squeezing them to her (Kitty) face.

'' Don't go, don't go! I'm not afraid, I'm not afraid! '' she (Kitty) said rapidly. '' Mamma, take my earrings. They bother me.

You're not afraid? Quick, quick, Lizaveta Petrovna... '' She (Kitty) spoke quickly, very quickly, and tried to smile. But suddenly her (Kitty) face was drawn, she (Kitty) pushed him (Levin) away.

'' Oh, this is awful! I'm dying, I'm dying! Go away! '' she (Kitty) shrieked, and again he (Levin) heard that unearthly scream.

Levin clutched at his (Levin) head and ran out of the room. '' It's nothing, it's nothing, it's all right, '' Dolly called after him (Levin).

He (Levin) stood in the next room, his (Levin) head leaning against the door post, and heard shrieks, howls such as he (Levin) had never heard before, and he (Levin) knew that what had been Kitty was uttering these shrieks.

But they might say what they liked, he (Levin) knew now that all was over. He (Levin) had long ago ceased to wish for the child.

By now he (Levin) loathed this child. He (Levin) did not even wish for her (Kitty) life now, all he (Levin) longed for was the end of this awful anguish.

'' Doctor! What is it? What is it? By God! '' he (God) said, snatching at the doctor's hand as he (God) came up.

'' It's the end,'' said the doctor. And the doctor's face was so grave as he (doctor) said it that Levin took the end as meaning her (Kitty) death.

Beside himself, he (Levin) ran into the bedroom. The first thing he (Levin) saw was the face of Lizaveta Petrovna. It was even more frowning and stern.

In the place where it had been was something that was fearful in its strained distortion and in the sounds that came from it.

Kitty's face he (Levin) did not know. He (Levin) fell down with his (Levin) head on the wooden framework of the bed, feeling that his (Levin) heart was bursting.

The awful scream never paused, it became still more awful, and as though it had reached the utmost limit of terror, suddenly it ceased.

Levin could not believe his (Levin) ears, but there could be no doubt; the scream had ceased and he (Levin) heard a subdued stir and bustle, and hurried breathing, and her (Kitty) voice, gasping, alive, tender, and blissful, uttered softly,

``It's over!'' (he)

With her (Kitty) hands hanging exhausted on the quilt, looking extraordinarily lovely and serene, she (Kitty) looked at him (Levin) in silence and tried to smile, and could not.

And suddenly, from the mysterious and awful far-away world in which he (Levin) had been living for the last twenty-two hours, Levin felt himself all in an instant borne back to the old every-day world, glorified though now, by such a radiance of happiness that he (Levin) could not bear it.

The strained chords snapped, sobs and tears of joy which he (Levin) had never foreseen rose up with such violence that his (Levin) whole body shook, that for long they prevented him (Levin) from speaking.

Falling on his (Levin) knees before the bed, he (Levin) held his (Levin) wife's hand before his (Levin) lips and kissed it, and the hand, with a weak movement of the fingers, responded to his (Levin) kiss.

And meanwhile, there at the foot of the bed, in the deft hands of Lizaveta Petrovna, like a flickering light in a lamp, lay the life of a human creature, which had never existed before, and which would now with the same right, with the same importance to itself, live and create in its own image.

He (Levin) lifted his (Levin) head. '' Alive! alive! And a boy too! Set your mind at rest!'' Levin heard Lizaveta Petrovna saying, as she (Levin) slapped the baby's back with a shaking hand.

And in the midst of the silence there came in unmistakable reply to the mother's question, a voice quite unlike the subdued voices speaking in the room.

'' Mamma, is it true?'' said Kitty's voice. The princess's sobs were all the answers she (Kitty) could make. It was the bold, clamorous, self-assertive squall of the new human being, who had so incomprehensibly appeared.

If Levin had been told before that Kitty was dead, and that he (Levin) had died with her (Kitty), and that their children were angels, and that God was standing before him (God), he (God) would have been surprised at nothing.

But now, coming back to the world of reality, he (God) had to make great mental efforts to take in that she (Kitty) was alive and well, and that the creature squalling so desperately was his (God) son.

Kitty was alive, her (Kitty) agony was over. And he (God) was unutterably happy. That he (God) understood; he (God) was completely happy in it.

But the baby? Whence, why, who was he (God)?... He (God) could not get used to the idea. It seemed to him (God) something extraneous, superfluous, to which he (God) could not accustom himself.

Chapter 16 At ten o'clock the old prince, Sergey Ivanovitch, and Stepan Arkadyevitch were sitting at Levin's. Having inquired after Kitty, they had dropped into conversation upon other subjects.

Levin heard them, and unconsciously, as they talked, going over the past, over what had been up to that morning, he (Levin) thought of himself as he (Levin) had been yesterday till that point.

He (Levin) felt himself exalted to unattainable heights, from which he (Levin) studiously lowered himself so as not to wound the people he (Levin) was talking to.

He (Levin) talked, and was all the time thinking of his (Levin) wife, of her (wife) condition now, of his (Levin) son, in whose existence he (Levin) tried to school himself into believing.

The whole world of woman, which had taken for him (Levin) since his (Levin) marriage a new value he (Levin) had never suspected before, was now so exalted that he (Levin) could not take it in in his (Levin) imagination.

It was as though a hundred years had passed since then. He (Levin) heard them talk of yesterday's dinner at the club, and thought:

``What is happening with her (woman) now?

And in the middle of the conversation, in the middle of a sentence, he (Levin) jumped up and went out of the room.

Is she (woman) asleep? How is she (woman)? What is she (woman) thinking of? Is he (Levin) crying, my son Dmitri?'' (He)

``Send me word if I can see her (woman),'' (the prince)
said the prince.

'' Very well, in a minute,'' answered Levin, and without stopping, he (Levin) went to her (woman) room. She (woman) was not asleep, she (woman) was talking gently with her (woman) mother, making plans about the christening.

Carefully set to rights, with hair well-brushed, in a smart little cap with some blue in it, her (woman) arms out on the quilt, she (woman) was lying on her (woman) back.

Meeting his (Levin) eyes, her (woman) eyes drew him (Levin) to her (woman). Her (woman) face, bright before, brightened still more as he (Levin) drew near her (woman).

There was the same change in it from earthly to unearthly that is seen in the face of the dead. But then it means farewell, here it meant welcome.

Again a rush of emotion, such as he (Levin) had felt at the moment of the child's birth, flooded his (Levin) heart. She (woman) took his (Levin) hand and asked him (Levin) if he (Levin) had slept.

He (Levin) could not answer, and turned away, struggling with his (Levin) weakness. '' I have had a nap, Kostya! '' she (woman) said to him (Kostya);

``and I am so comfortable now.

'' (him)

She (woman) looked at him (Kostya), but suddenly her (woman) expression changed.
``Give him (Kostya) to me,'' (she)
she (woman) said, hearing the baby's cry.
``Give him (Kostya) to me, Lizaveta Petrovna, and he (Kostya) shall look at him (Kostya).

To be sure, his (Kostya) papa shall look at him (Kostya),'' (Lizaveta Petrovna)

said Lizaveta Petrovna, getting up and bringing something red, and queer, and wriggling.

Wait a minute, we'll make him (Kostya) tidy first,'' and Lizaveta Petrovna laid the red wobbling thing on the bed, began untrussing and trussing up the baby, lifting it up and turning it over with one finger and powdering it with something.

Levin, looking at the tiny, pitiful creature, made strenuous efforts to discover in his (Levin) heart some traces of fatherly feeling for it.

But when it was undressed and he (Levin) caught a glimpse of wee, wee, little hands, little feet, saffron-colored, with little toes, too, and positively with a little big toe different from the rest, and when he (Levin) saw Lizaveta Petrovna closing the wide-open little hands, as though they were soft springs, and putting them into linen garments, such pity for the little creature came upon him (Levin), and such terror that she (Levin) would hurt it, that he (Levin) held her (Levin) hand back.

'' '' '' He (Levin) felt nothing towards it but disgust. Lizaveta Petrovna laughed. '' Don't be frightened, don't be frightened! ''

When the baby had been put to rights and transformed into a firm doll, Lizaveta Petrovna dandled it as though proud of her (Levin) handiwork, and stood a little away so that Levin might see his (Levin) son in all his (Levin) glory.

Kitty looked sideways in the same direction, never taking her (Kitty) eyes off the baby.

``Give him (Levin) to me! give him (Levin) to me!

'' (she)

she (Kitty) said, and even made as though she (Kitty) would sit up. '' What are you thinking of, Katerina Alexandrovna, you mustn't move like that!

And Lizaveta Petrovna, with one hand supporting the wobbling head, lifted up on the other arm the strange, limp, red creature, whose head was lost in its swaddling clothes.

Wait a minute. I'll give him (Levin) to you. Here we're showing papa what a fine fellow we are!'' But it had a nose, too, and slanting eyes and smacking lips.

'' A splendid baby!'' said Lizaveta Petrovna. Levin sighed with mortification. This splendid baby excited in him (Levin) no feeling but disgust and compassion.

It was not at all the feeling he (Levin) had looked forward to. He (Levin) turned away while Lizaveta Petrovna put the baby to the unaccustomed breast.

Suddenly laughter made him (Levin) look round. The baby had taken the breast.

``Come, that's enough, that's enough!'' (Lizaveta Petrovna)
said Lizaveta Petrovna, but Kitty would not let the baby go.

He (Levin) fell asleep in her (Kitty) arms. '' Look, now,'' said Kitty, turning the baby so that he (Levin) could see it. The aged-looking little face suddenly puckered up still more and the baby sneezed.

Smiling, hardly able to restrain his (Levin) tears, Levin kissed his (Levin) wife and went out of the dark room. What he (Levin) felt towards this little creature was utterly unlike what he (Levin) had expected.

There was nothing cheerful and joyous in the feeling; on the contrary, it was a new torture of apprehension. It was the consciousness of a new sphere of liability to pain.

And this sense was so painful at first, the apprehension lest this helpless creature should suffer was so intense, that it prevented him (Levin) from noticing the strange thrill of senseless joy and even pride that he (Levin) had felt when the baby sneezed.

The money for two-thirds of the forest had all been spent already, and he (Levin) had borrowed from the merchant in advance at ten per cent discount, almost all the remaining third.

The merchant would not give more, especially as Darya Alexandrovna, for the first time that winter insisting on her (creature) right to her (creature) own property, had refused to sign the receipt for the payment of the last third of the forest.

Chapter 17 Stepan Arkadyevitch's affairs were in a very bad way. All his (merchant) salary went on household expenses and in payment of petty debts that could not be put off.

There was positively no money. This was unpleasant and awkward, and in Stepan Arkadyevitch's opinion things could not go on like this.

The explanation of the position was, in his (merchant) view, to be found in the fact that his (merchant) salary was too small.

Petrov, the bank director, had twelve thousand; Sventitsky, a company director, had seventeen thousand; Mitin, who had founded a bank, received fifty thousand.

The post he (director) filled had been unmistakably very good five years ago, but it was so no longer. '' Clearly I've been napping, and they've overlooked me,'' Stepan Arkadyevitch thought about himself.

And he (director) began keeping his (director) eyes and ears open, and towards the end of the winter he (director) had discovered a very good berth and had formed a plan of attack upon it, at first from Moscow through aunts, uncles, and friends, and then, when the matter was well advanced, in the spring, he (director) went himself to Petersburg.

It was one of those snug, lucrative berths of which there are so many more nowadays than there used to be, with incomes ranging from one thousand to fifty thousand roubles.

It was the post of secretary of the committee of the amalgamated agency of the southern railways, and of certain banking companies.

This position, like all such appointments, called for such immense energy and such varied qualifications, that it was difficult for them to be found united in any one man.

And since a man combining all the qualifications was not to be found, it was at least better that the post be filled by an honest than by a dishonest man.

And Stepan Arkadyevitch was not merely an honest man--unemphatically--in the common acceptation of the words, he (man) was an honest man--emphatically--in that special sense which the word has in Moscow, when they talk of an

``honest'' (an man writer newspaper institution tendency)
politician, an
``honest'' (an politician)
writer, an
``honest'' (an writer)
newspaper, an
``honest'' (an writer)
institution, an
``honest'' (an writer)
tendency, meaning not simply that the man or the institution is not dishonest, but that they are capable on occasion of taking a line of their own in opposition to the authorities.

Stepan Arkadyevitch moved in those circles in Moscow in which that expression had come into use, was regarded there as an honest man, and so had more right to this appointment than others.

The appointment yielded an income of from seven to ten thousand a year, and Oblonsky could fill it without giving up his (man) government position.

It was in the hands of two ministers, one lady, and two Jews, and all these people, though the way had been paved already with them, Stepan Arkadyevitch had to see in Petersburg.

Besides this business, Stepan Arkadyevitch had promised his (man) sister Anna to obtain from Karenin a definite answer on the question of divorce.

Stepan Arkadyevitch sat in Karenin's study listening to his (Karenin) report on the causes of the unsatisfactory position of Russian finance, and only waiting for the moment when he (Karenin) would finish to speak about his (Karenin) own business or about Anna.

Yes, that's very true,'' he (Karenin) said, when Alexey Alexandrovitch took off the pince-nez, without which he (Alexandrovitch) could not read now, and looked inquiringly at his (Alexandrovitch) former brother-in-law,

``that's very true in particular cases, but still the principle of our day is freedom.'' (brother-in-law)

Yes, but I lay down another principle, embracing the principle of freedom,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, with emphasis on the word

``embracing,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
and he (Alexandrovitch) put on his (Alexandrovitch) pince-nez again, so as to read the passage in which this statement was made.

And begging fifty roubles from Dolly, he (Alexandrovitch) set off for Petersburg. '' '' And turning over the beautifully written, wide-margined manuscript, Alexey Alexandrovitch read aloud over again the conclusive passage.

I don't advocate protection for the sake of private interests, but for the public weal, and for the lower and upper classes equally,'' he (Alexandrovitch) said, looking over his (Alexandrovitch) pince-nez at Oblonsky.

'' '' But they cannot grasp that, they are taken up now with personal interests, and carried away by phrases. ''

Stepan Arkadyevitch knew that when Karenin began to talk of what they were doing and thinking, the persons who would not accept his (Karenin) report and were the cause of everything wrong in Russia, that it was coming near the end.

And so now he (Karenin) eagerly abandoned the principle of free-trade, and fully agreed. Alexey Alexandrovitch paused, thoughtfully turning over the pages of his (Alexandrovitch) manuscript.

Oh, by the way,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, ``I wanted to ask you, some time when you see Pomorsky, to drop him (Alexandrovitch) a hint that I should be very glad to get that new appointment of secretary of the committee of the amalgamated agency of the southern railways and banking companies.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was familiar by now with the title of the post he (secretary) coveted, and he (secretary) brought it out rapidly without mistake.

He (secretary) was considering whether the new committee would not be acting in some way contrary to the views he (secretary) had been advocating.

But as the influence of the new committee was of a very complex nature, and his (secretary) views were of very wide application, he (secretary) could not decide this straight off, and taking off his (secretary) pince-nez, he (secretary) said:

``Of course, I can mention it to him (secretary); but what is your reason precisely for wishing to obtain the appointment?'' (he)

'' '' Alexey Alexandrovitch questioned him (Alexandrovitch) as to the duties of this new committee, and pondered. '' It's a good salary, rising to nine thousand, and my means...

The high figure of the salary made him (Alexandrovitch) reflect that on that side Stepan Arkadyevitch's proposed position ran counter to the main tendency of his (Alexandrovitch) own projects of reform, which always leaned towards economy.

I consider, and I have embodied my views in a note on the subject, that in our day these immense salaries are evidence of the unsound economic assiette of our finances.''

Suppose a bank director gets ten thousand--well, he (director)'s worth it; or an engineer gets twenty thousand--after all, it's a growing thing, you know!''

``I assume that a salary is the price paid for a commodity, and it ought to conform with the law of supply and demand.

If the salary is fixed without any regard for that law, as, for instance, when I see two engineers leaving college together, both equally well trained and efficient, and one getting forty thousand while the other is satisfied with two; or when I see lawyers and hussars, having no special qualifications, appointed directors of banking companies with immense salaries, I conclude that the salary is not fixed in accordance with the law of supply and demand, but simply through personal interest.

'' (unknown)

``Nine thousand!'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
repeated Alexey Alexandrovitch, and he (Alexandrovitch) frowned. '' '' But what's to be done?'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' And this is an abuse of great gravity in itself, and one that reacts injuriously on the government service.

I consider... '' Stepan Arkadyevitch made haste to interrupt his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law. '' Yes; but you must agree that it's a new institution of undoubted utility that's being started.

After all, you know, it's a growing thing! What they lay particular stress on is the thing being carried on honestly,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch with emphasis.

But the Moscow significance of the word

``honest'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

``by putting in a word to Pomorsky--just in the way of conversation...'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

'' '' But I fancy it's more in Volgarinov's hands,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' Volgarinov has fully assented, as far as he (Alexandrovitch)'s concerned,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, turning red.

Stepan Arkadyevitch reddened at the mention of that name, because he (Alexandrovitch) had been that morning at the Jew Volgarinov's, and the visit had left an unpleasant recollection.

Stepan Arkadyevitch believed most positively that the committee in which he (Alexandrovitch) was trying to get an appointment was a new, genuine, and honest public body, but that morning when Volgarinov had-- intentionally, beyond a doubt--kept him (Alexandrovitch) two hours waiting with other petitioners in his (Alexandrovitch) waiting room, he (Alexandrovitch) had suddenly felt uneasy.

Whether he (Alexandrovitch) was uncomfortable that he (Alexandrovitch), a descendant of Rurik, Prince Oblonsky, had been kept for two hours waiting to see a Jew, or that for the first time in his (Jew) life he (Jew) was not following the example of his (Jew) ancestors in serving the government, but was turning off into a new career, anyway he (Jew) was very uncomfortable.

During those two hours in Volgarinov's waiting room Stepan Arkadyevitch, stepping jauntily about the room, pulling his (Jew) whiskers, entering into conversation with the other petitioners, and inventing an epigram on his (Jew) position, assiduously concealed from others, and even from himself, the feeling he (Jew) was experiencing.

But all the time he (Jew) was uncomfortable and angry, he (Jew) could not have said why--whether because he (Jew) could not get his (Jew) epigram just right, or from some other reason.

When at last Volgarinov had received him (Jew) with exaggerated politeness and unmistakable triumph at his (Jew) humiliation, and had all but refused the favor asked of him (Jew), Stepan Arkadyevitch had made haste to forget it all as soon as possible.

And now, at the mere recollection, he (Jew) blushed. Chapter 18 '' Now there is something I want to talk about, and you know what it is.

``Oh, Alexey Alexandrovitch, for heaven's sake, don't let us indulge in recriminations! What is past is past, and you know what she (Arkadyevna) wants and is waiting for--divorce.'' (I)

'' But I believe Anna Arkadyevna refuses a divorce, if I make it a condition to leave me my son. I replied in that sense, and supposed that the matter was ended.

I consider it at an end,'' shrieked Alexey Alexandrovitch. '' But, for heaven's sake, don't get hot!'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, touching his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law's knee.

If you will allow me to recapitulate, it was like this: when you parted, you were as magnanimous as could possibly be; you were ready to give her (Arkadyevna) everything--freedom, divorce even.

She (Arkadyevna) did appreciate it--to such a degree that at the first moment, feeling how she (Arkadyevna) had wronged you, she (Arkadyevna) did not consider and could not consider everything.

'' The matter is not ended. She (Arkadyevna) appreciated that. No, don't think that. She (Arkadyevna) gave up everything. But experience, time, have shown that her (Arkadyevna) position is unbearable, impossible.''

'' The life of Anna Arkadyevna can have no interest for me,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch put in, lifting his (Alexandrovitch) eyebrows.

``Allow me to disbelieve that,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

She (Arkadyevna) knows that and asks you for nothing; she (Arkadyevna) says plainly that she (Arkadyevna) dare not ask you. But I, all of us, her (Arkadyevna) relatives, all who love her (Arkadyevna), beg you, entreat you.

Why should she (Arkadyevna) suffer? Who is any the better for it?'' '' Excuse me, you seem to put me in the position of the guilty party,'' observed Alexey Alexandrovitch.

please understand me,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, touching his (Alexandrovitch) hand again, as though feeling sure this physical contact would soften his (Alexandrovitch) brother-in-law.

She (Arkadyevna) does not ask for her (Arkadyevna) son now. Alexey Alexandrovitch, you are a good man. Put yourself in her (Arkadyevna) position for a minute.

The question of divorce for her (Arkadyevna) in her (Arkadyevna) position is a question of life and death. But you promised it, and she (Arkadyevna) wrote to you, and moved to Moscow.

Why, it's like keeping a condemned criminal for six months with the rope round his (criminal) neck, promising him (criminal) perhaps death, perhaps mercy.

Chapter 19 Stepan Arkadyevitch was about to go away when Korney came in to announce:

Yes, mon oncle ,'' he (boy) answered, glancing at his (boy) father, and again he (boy) looked downcast. His (boy) uncle called him (boy) to him (boy), and took his (boy) hand.

As soon as Stepan Arkadyevitch let go his (boy) hand, he (boy) glanced doubtfully at his (boy) father, and like a bird set free, he (boy) darted out of the room.

The boy, blushing and making no answer, cautiously drew his (boy) hand away. A year had passed since the last time Seryozha had seen his (boy) mother.

Since then he (boy) had heard nothing more of her (mother). And in the course of that year he (boy) had gone to school, and made friends among his (boy) schoolfellows.

The dreams and memories of his (boy) mother, which had made him (boy) ill after seeing her (mother), did not occupy his (boy) thoughts now.

When they came back to him (boy), he (boy) studiously drove them away, regarding them as shameful and girlish, below the dignity of a boy and a schoolboy.

He (boy) knew that his (boy) father and mother were separated by some quarrel, he (father) knew that he (father) had to remain with his (father) father, and he (father) tried to get used to that idea.

He (father) disliked it all the more as from some words he (father) had caught as he (father) waited at the study door, and still more from the faces of his (father) father and uncle, he (father) guessed that they must have been talking of his (father) mother.

And to avoid condemning the father with whom he (father) lived and on whom he (father) was dependent, and, above all, to avoid giving way to sentimentality, which he (father) considered so degrading, Seryozha tried not to look at his (father) uncle who had come to disturb his (father) peace of mind, and not to think of what he (father) recalled to him (father).

But when Stepan Arkadyevitch, going out after him (father), saw him (father) on the stairs, and calling to him (father), asked him (father) how he (father) spent his (father) playtime at school, Seryozha talked more freely to him (father) away from his (father) father's presence.

He (father) disliked seeing his (father) uncle, so like his (father) mother, for it called up those memories of which he (father) was ashamed. ''

We have a railway now,'' he (father) said in answer to his (father) uncle's question. '' It's like this, do you see: two sit on a bench--

And all are harnessed to it by their arms or by their belts, and they run through all the rooms--the doors are left open beforehand.

they're the passengers; and one stands up straight on the bench. Well, and it's pretty hard work being the conductor!'' ''

Yes, you want pluck for it, and cleverness too, especially when they stop all of a sudden, or someone falls down.''

Yes, that must be a serious matter,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, watching with mournful interest the eager eyes, like his (conductor) mother's; not childish now--no longer fully innocent.

That's the one that stands? '' Stepan Arkadyevitch inquired, smiling. '' '' And though he (conductor) had promised Alexey Alexandrovitch not to speak of Anna, he (conductor) could not restrain himself.

'' Do you remember your mother? '' he (conductor) asked suddenly. '' No, I don't,'' Seryozha said quickly. He (conductor) blushed crimson, and his (conductor) face clouded over.

His (conductor) tutor found his (conductor) pupil on the staircase half an hour later, and for a long while he (conductor) could not make out whether he (conductor) was ill-tempered or crying.

And his (conductor) uncle could get nothing more out of him (conductor). '' What is it? I expect you hurt yourself when you fell down?'' said the tutor.
