'' '' Well, what is it, then?''

``Leave me alone! If I remember, or if I don't remember?...what business is it of his (director)?

Why should I remember? Leave me in peace!'' (he)

he (director) said, addressing not his (director) tutor, but the whole world. Chapter 20 Stepan Arkadyevitch, as usual, did not waste his (director) time in Petersburg.

In Petersburg, besides business, his (director) sister's divorce, and his (director) coveted appointment, he (director) wanted, as he (director) always did, to freshen himself up, as he (director) said, after the mustiness of Moscow.

After living for some time in Moscow, especially in close relations with his (director) family, he (director) was conscious of a depression of spirits.

After being a long time in Moscow without a change, he (director) reached a point when he (director) positively began to be worrying himself over his (director) wife's ill-humor and reproaches, over his (director) children's health and education, and the petty details of his (director) official work; even the fact of being in debt worried him (director).

But he (director) had only to go and stay a little while in Petersburg, in the circle there in which he (director) moved, where people lived--really lived--instead of vegetating as in Moscow, and all such ideas vanished and melted away at once, like wax before the fire.

In spite of its caf√©s chantants and its omnibuses, Moscow was yet a stagnant bog. Stepan Arkadyevitch always felt it. His (director) wife?...

Only that day he (director) had been talking to Prince Tchetchensky. Prince Tchetchensky had a wife and family, grown-up pages in the corps,...and he (Tchetchensky) had another illegitimate family of children also.

Though the first family was very nice too, Prince Tchetchensky felt happier in his (Tchetchensky) second family; and he (Tchetchensky) used to take his (Tchetchensky) eldest son with him (Tchetchensky) to his (Tchetchensky) second family, and told Stepan Arkadyevitch that he (Tchetchensky) thought it good for his (Tchetchensky) son, enlarging his (Tchetchensky) ideas.

What would have been said to that in Moscow? His (Tchetchensky) children? In Petersburg children did not prevent their parents from enjoying life.

The children were brought up in schools, and there was no trace of the wild idea that prevailed in Moscow, in Lvov's household, for instance, that all the luxuries of life were for the children, while the parents have nothing but work and anxiety.

Here people understood that a man is in duty bound to live for himself, as every man of culture should live.

His (man) official duties? Official work here was not the stiff, hopeless drudgery that it was in Moscow. Here there was some interest in official life.

A chance meeting, a service rendered, a happy phrase, a knack of facetious mimicry, and a man's career might be made in a trice.

So it had been with Bryantsev, whom Stepan Arkadyevitch had met the previous day, and who was one of the highest functionaries in government now.

There was some interest in official work like that. The Petersburg attitude on pecuniary matters had an especially soothing effect on Stepan Arkadyevitch.

Bartnyansky, who must spend at least fifty thousand to judge by the style he (man) lived in, had made an interesting comment the day before on that subject.

As they were talking before dinner, Stepan Arkadyevitch said to Bartnyansky:

``You're friendly, I fancy, with Mordvinsky; you might do me a favor: say a word to him (man), please, for me.

There's an appointment I should like to get--secretary of the agency...'' (Bartnyansky)

'' Oh, I shan't remember all that, if you tell it to me....

But what possesses you to have to do with railways and Jews?... Take it as you will, it's a low business.

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch did not say to Bartnyansky that it was a

``growing thing'' (Bartnyansky)
--Bartnyansky would not have understood that. '' I want the money, I've nothing to live on.

''

``You're living, aren't you?'' (unknown)
'' Yes, but in debt.''
``Are you, though? Heavily?'' (Bartnyansky)
said Bartnyansky sympathetically. '' Very heavily: twenty thousand.

My debts mount up to a million and a half, and I've nothing, and still I can live, as you see!''

'' Bartnyansky broke into good-humored laughter. '' Oh, lucky fellow!'' said he (fellow). '' And Stepan Arkadyevitch saw the correctness of this view not in words only but in actual fact.

Zhivahov owed three hundred thousand, and hadn't a farthing to bless himself with, and he (fellow) lived, and in style too! Count Krivtsov was considered a hopeless case by everyone, and yet he (fellow) kept two mistresses.

Petrovsky had run through five millions, and still lived in just the same style, and was even a manager in the financial department with a salary of twenty thousand.

In Moscow he (manager) sometimes found a gray hair in his (manager) head, dropped asleep after dinner, stretched, walked slowly upstairs, breathing heavily, was bored by the society of young women, and did not dance at balls.

But besides this, Petersburg had physically an agreeable effect on Stepan Arkadyevitch. It made him (manager) younger. In Petersburg he (manager) always felt ten years younger.

His (manager) experience in Petersburg was exactly what had been described to him (manager) on the previous day by Prince Pyotr Oblonsky, a man of sixty, who had just come back from abroad:

``We don't know the way to live here,'' (a man)
said Pyotr Oblonsky.

'' I spent the summer in Baden, and you wouldn't believe it, I felt quite a young man. At a glimpse of a pretty woman, my thoughts....

I came home to Russia--had to see my wife, and, what's more, go to my country place; and there, you'd hardly believe it, in a fortnight I'd got into a dressing gown and given up dressing for dinner.

One dines and drinks a glass of wine, and feels strong and ready for anything. Needn't say I had no thoughts left for pretty women.

I became quite an old gentleman. There was nothing left for me but to think of my eternal salvation. I went off to Paris--I was as right as could be at once.

In Moscow he (gentleman) degenerated so much that if he (gentleman) had had to be there for long together, he (gentleman) might in good earnest have come to considering his (gentleman) salvation; in Petersburg he (gentleman) felt himself a man of the world again.

'' Stepan Arkadyevitch felt exactly the difference that Pyotr Oblonsky described. Between Princess Betsy Tverskaya and Stepan Arkadyevitch there had long existed rather curious relations.

Stepan Arkadyevitch always flirted with her (Tverskaya) in jest, and used to say to her (Tverskaya), also in jest, the most unseemly things, knowing that nothing delighted her (Tverskaya) so much.

The day after his (gentleman) conversation with Karenin, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to see her (Tverskaya), and felt so youthful that in this jesting flirtation and nonsense he (gentleman) recklessly went so far that he (gentleman) did not know how to extricate himself, as unluckily he (gentleman) was so far from being attracted by her (Tverskaya)

that he (gentleman) thought her (Tverskaya) positively disagreeable. What made it hard to change the conversation was the fact that he (gentleman) was very attractive to her (Tverskaya).

So that he (gentleman) was considerably relieved at the arrival of Princess Myakaya, which cut short their t√™te-√†-t√™te . '' Ah, so you're here!'' said she (Princess) when she (Princess) saw him (gentleman).

Ever since they've all turned against her (Princess), all those who're a thousand times worse than she (Princess), I've thought she (Princess) did a very fine thing.

'' Well, and what news of your poor sister? You needn't look at me like that,'' she (sister) added. '' I can't forgive Vronsky for not letting me know when she (sister) was in Petersburg.

I'd have gone to see her (sister) and gone about with her (sister) everywhere. Please give her (sister) my love. Come, tell me about her (sister).''

``Yes, her (sister) position is very difficult; she (sister)...'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
began Stepan Arkadyevitch, in the simplicity of his (sister) heart accepting as sterling coin Princess Myakaya's words
``tell me about her (Princess).

'' (Myakaya)

Princess Myakaya interrupted him (sister) immediately, as she (Princess) always did, and began talking herself. '' She (Princess)'s done what they all do, except me--only they hide it.

But she (Princess) wouldn't be deceitful, and she (Princess) did a fine thing. And she (Princess) did better still in throwing up that crazy brother-in-law of yours.

Everybody used to say he (brother-in-law) was so clever, so very clever; I was the only one that said he (brother-in-law) was a fool.

Now that he (brother-in-law)'s so thick with Lidia Ivanovna and Landau, they all say he (Landau)'s crazy, and I should prefer not to agree with everybody, but this time I can't help it.''

You must excuse me.

``Oh, do please explain,'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)
said Stepan Arkadyevitch;
``what does it mean? Yesterday I was seeing him (Landau) on my sister's behalf, and I asked him (Landau) to give me a final answer.

He (Landau) gave me no answer, and said he (Landau) would think it over. But this morning, instead of an answer, I received an invitation from Countess Lidia Ivanovna for this evening.

'' (Stepan Arkadyevitch)

'' Ah, so that's it, that's it!'' said Princess Myakaya gleefully,
``they're going to ask Landau what he (Landau)'s to say.

'' (Myakaya)

``Ask Landau? What for? Who or what's Landau? '' (unknown)
``What! you don't know Jules Landau, le fameux Jules Landau, le clairvoyant ?

He (Landau)'s crazy too, but on him (Landau) your sister's fate depends. See what comes of living in the provinces--you know nothing about anything.

Landau, do you see, was a commis in a shop in Paris, and he (Landau) went to a doctor's; and in the doctor's waiting room he (Landau) fell asleep, and in his (Landau) sleep he (Landau) began giving advice to all the patients.

And wonderful advice it was! Then the wife of Yury Meledinsky--you know, the invalid?--heard of this Landau, and had him (Landau) to see her (wife) husband.

And he (Landau) cured her (wife) husband, though I can't say that I see he (Landau) did him (Landau) much good, for he (Landau)'s just as feeble a creature as ever he (Landau) was, but they believed in him (Landau), and took him (Landau) along with them and brought him (Landau) to Russia.

Here there's been a general rush to him (Landau), and he (Landau)'s begun doctoring everyone. He (Landau) cured Countess Bezzubova, and she (Countess) took such a fancy to him (Landau) that she (Countess) adopted him (Landau).'' (unknown)

That's neither here nor there, though; but Lidia--I'm very fond of her (Lidia), but she (Lidia) has a screw loose somewhere--has lost her (Lidia) heart to this Landau now, and nothing is settled now in her (Lidia) house or Alexey Alexandrovitch's without him (Alexandrovitch), and so your sister's fate is now in the hands of Landau, alias Count Bezzubov.

Chapter 21 After a capital dinner and a great deal of cognac drunk at Bartnyansky's, Stepan Arkadyevitch, only a little later than the appointed time, went in to Countess Lidia Ivanovna's.

``Adopted him (Landau)?'' (son)
'' Yes, as her (Ivanovna) son. He (son)'s not Landau any more now, but Count Bezzubov. '' '' Who else is with the countess?--a Frenchman?''

Stepan Arkadyevitch asked the hall porter, as he (porter) glanced at the familiar overcoat of Alexey Alexandrovitch and a queer, rather artless-looking overcoat with clasps.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch Karenin and Count Bezzubov,'' the porter answered severely. '' Princess Myakaya guessed right,'' thought Stepan Arkadyevitch, as he (porter) went upstairs.

'' Curious! It would be quite as well, though, to get on friendly terms with her (Princess). She (Princess) has immense influence. If she (Princess) would say a word to Pomorsky, the thing would be a certainty.

It was still quite light out-of-doors, but in Countess Lidia Ivanovna's little drawing room the blinds were drawn and the lamps lighted.

A short, thinnish man, very pale and handsome, with feminine hips and knock-kneed legs, with fine brilliant eyes and long hair lying on the collar of his (man) coat, was standing at the end of the room gazing at the portraits on the wall.

After greeting the lady of the house and Alexey Alexandrovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch could not resist glancing once more at the unknown man.

'' At a round table under a lamp sat the countess and Alexey Alexandrovitch, talking softly.

``Monsieur Landau!'' (the countess)
the countess addressed him (Landau) with a softness and caution that impressed Oblonsky.

Landau looked round hurriedly, came up, and smiling, laid his (Landau) moist, lifeless hand in Stepan Arkadyevitch's outstretched hand and immediately walked away and fell to gazing at the portraits again.

I am very glad to see you, particularly today,'' said Countess Lidia Ivanovna, pointing Stepan Arkadyevitch to a seat beside Karenin.

``but he (Alexandrovitch) is really Count Bezzubov, as you're probably aware.

Ah, a voice!'' repeated Oblonsky, feeling that he (Alexandrovitch) must be as circumspect as he (Alexandrovitch) possibly could in this society, where something peculiar was going on, or was to go on, to which he (Alexandrovitch) had not the key.

A moment's silence followed, after which Countess Lidia Ivanovna, as though approaching the main topic of conversation, said with a fine smile to Oblonsky:

``I've known you for a long while, and am very glad to make a closer acquaintance with you.

But to be a true friend, one must enter into the spiritual state of one's friend, and I fear that you are not doing so in the case of Alexey Alexandrovitch.

'' (Oblonsky/Pyotr/Pyotr Oblonsky)

'' In part, countess, I understand the position of Alexey Alexandrovitch...'' said Oblonsky. Having no clear idea what they were talking about, he (Alexandrovitch) wanted to confine himself to generalities.

The change is not in his (Alexandrovitch) external position,'' Countess Lidia Ivanovna said sternly, following with eyes of love the figure of Alexey Alexandrovitch as he (Alexandrovitch) got up and crossed over to Landau;

``his (Landau) heart is changed, a new heart has been vouchsafed him (Landau), and I fear you don't fully apprehend the change that has taken place in him (Landau).'' (Landau/Jules Landau)

'' '' Oh, well, in general outlines I can conceive the change. '' But I am afraid you do not understand me.

'' and Stepan Arkadyevitch paused in confusion. He (Alexandrovitch) understood at last that they were talking of religion. '' Stepan Arkadyevitch looked round.

Landau was sitting at the window, leaning on his (Landau) elbow and the back of his (Landau) chair, his (Landau) head drooping. Noticing that all eyes were turned on him (Landau) he (Landau) raised his (Landau) head and smiled a smile of childlike artlessness.

'' she (Ivanovna) was beginning, when a footman came into the room with a letter. '' I have observed,'' she (Ivanovna) went on,

``that Moscow people, especially the men, are more indifferent to religion than anyone.'' (she)

'' Oh, no, countess, I thought Moscow people had the reputation of being the firmest in the faith,'' answered Stepan Arkadyevitch.

But as far as I can make out, you are unfortunately one of the indifferent ones,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch, turning to him (Alexandrovitch) with a weary smile.

I am not so much indifferent on that subject as I am waiting in suspense,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, with his (Alexandrovitch) most deprecating smile.

'' '' How anyone can be indifferent!'' said Lidia Ivanovna. '' '' I hardly think that the time for such questions has come yet for me.

'' Alexey Alexandrovitch and Lidia Ivanovna looked at each other. '' We can never tell whether the time has come for us or not,'' said Alexey Alexandrovitch severely.

God's grace is not guided by human considerations: sometimes it comes not to those that strive for it, and comes to those that are unprepared, like Saul.''

No, I believe it won't be just yet,'' said Lidia Ivanovna, who had been meanwhile watching the movements of the Frenchman.

'' We ought not to think whether we are ready or not ready. '' Landau got up and came to them.

'' Do you allow me to listen? '' he (Landau) asked. '' Oh, yes; I did not want to disturb you,'' said Lidia Ivanovna, gazing tenderly at him (Landau);

``sit here with us.'' (him)

Ah, if you knew the happiness we know, feeling His (Landau) presence ever in our hearts!'' said Countess Lidia Ivanovna with a rapturous smile.

But a man may feel himself unworthy sometimes to rise to that height,'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, conscious of hypocrisy in admitting this religious height, but at the same time unable to bring himself to acknowledge his (man) free-thinking views before a person who, by a single word to Pomorsky, might procure him (man) the coveted appointment.

'' One has only not to close one's eyes to shut out the light,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch went on. '' '' ''

That is, you mean that sin keeps him (Alexandrovitch) back?'' said Lidia Ivanovna. '' But that is a false idea. There is no sin for believers, their sin has been atoned for.

Yes, but faith without works is dead,'' (She)

said Stepan Arkadyevitch, recalling the phrase from the catechism, and only by his (footman) smile clinging to his (footman) independence.

''

she (Ivanovna) went on. '' '' It was unmistakably a subject they had discussed more than once before.

'' What harm has been done by the false interpretation of that passage! Nothing holds men back from belief like that misinterpretation. '

I have not works, so I cannot believe,' though all the while that is not said. But the very opposite is said.

'' Yet that is nowhere said. '' We are saved by Christ who suffered for us. We are saved by faith,'' Alexey Alexandrovitch chimed in, with a glance of approval at her (Ivanovna) words.

'' asked Lidia Ivanovna, and receiving a reply in the affirmative, she (Ivanovna) got up and began looking through a shelf of books.

In it is described the way by which faith can be reached, and the happiness, above all earthly bliss, with which it fills the soul.

And finding the book, and sitting down again in her (Ivanovna) place, she (Ivanovna) opened it. '' It's very short. The believer cannot be unhappy because he (Alexandrovitch) is not alone.

But you will see. '' She (Ivanovna) was just settling herself to read when the footman came in again. '' Madame Borozdina?

Yes,'' she (Ivanovna) said, putting her (Ivanovna) finger in the place in the book, and gazing before her (Ivanovna) with her (Ivanovna) fine pensive eyes,

``that is how true faith acts.

Tell her (Ivanovna), tomorrow at two o'clock. You know Marie Sanina? You know about her (Sanina) trouble? She (Sanina) lost her (Sanina) only child. She (Sanina) was in despair.

And what happened? She (Sanina) found this comforter, and she (Sanina) thanks God now for the death of her (Sanina) child. Such is the happiness faith brings!'' (she)

Oh, yes, that is most...'' said Stepan Arkadyevitch, glad they were going to read, and let him (God) have a chance to collect his (God) faculties.

''

Oh, I shall understand,'' said Landau, with the same smile, and he (Landau) closed his (Landau) eyes. Alexey Alexandrovitch and Lidia Ivanovna exchanged meaningful glances, and the reading began.

Chapter 22 Stepan Arkadyevitch felt completely nonplussed by the strange talk which he (Alexandrovitch) was hearing for the first time. The complexity of Petersburg, as a rule, had a stimulating effect on him (Alexandrovitch), rousing him (Alexandrovitch) out of his (Alexandrovitch) Moscow stagnation.

But he (Alexandrovitch) liked these complications, and understood them only in the circles he (Alexandrovitch) knew and was at home in. In these unfamiliar surroundings he (Alexandrovitch) was puzzled and disconcerted, and could not get his (Alexandrovitch) bearings.

As he (Alexandrovitch) listened to Countess Lidia Ivanovna, aware of the beautiful, artless--or perhaps artful, he (Alexandrovitch) could not decide which--eyes of Landau fixed upon him (Landau), Stepan Arkadyevitch began to be conscious of a peculiar heaviness in his (Landau) head.

The most incongruous ideas were in confusion in his (Landau) head. '' Marie Sanina is glad her (Sanina) child's dead.... How good a smoke would be now!...

To be saved, one need only believe, and the monks don't know how the thing's to be done, but Countess Lidia Ivanovna does know....

And why is my head so heavy? Is it the cognac, or all this being so queer? Anyway, I fancy I've done nothing unsuitable so far.

But anyway, it won't do to ask her (Ivanovna) now. They say they make one say one's prayers. I only hope they won't make me!

That'll be too imbecile. And what stuff it is she (Ivanovna)'s reading! but she (Ivanovna) has a good accent. Landau--Bezzubov-- what's he (Landau) Bezzubov for?

'' All at once Stepan Arkadyevitch became aware that his (Landau) lower jaw was uncontrollably forming a yawn. He (Landau) pulled his (Landau) whiskers to cover the yawn, and shook himself together.

But soon after he (Landau) became aware that he (Landau) was dropping asleep and on the very point of snoring. He (Landau) recovered himself at the very moment when the voice of Countess Lidia Ivanovna was saying

``he (Landau)'s asleep.

'' (Lidia Ivanovna/Lidia)

Stepan Arkadyevitch started with dismay, feeling guilty and caught. But he (Landau) was reassured at once by seeing that the words
``he (Landau)'s asleep'' (he)
referred not to him (Landau), but to Landau.

But Stepan Arkadyevitch's being asleep would have offended them, as he (Landau) thought -LRB-though even this, he (Landau) thought, might not be so, as everything seemed so queer-RRB-, while Landau's being asleep delighted them extremely, especially Countess Lidia Ivanovna.

Mon ami,'' said Lidia Ivanovna, carefully holding the folds of her (Ivanovna) silk gown so as not to rustle, and in her (Ivanovna) excitement calling Karenin not Alexey Alexandrovitch, but

``mon ami,'' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)
``donnez-lui la main.

The Frenchman was asleep as well as Stepan Arkadyevitch. '' (Alexey Alexandrovitch/Alexey/Karenin)

Vous voyez? Sh! '' she (Ivanovna) hissed at the footman as he (footman) came in again.

The Frenchman was asleep, or pretending to be asleep, with his (Frenchman) head on the back of his (Frenchman) chair, and his (Frenchman) moist hand, as it lay on his (Frenchman) knee, made faint movements, as though trying to catch something.

Alexey Alexandrovitch got up, tried to move carefully, but stumbled against the table, went up and laid his (Alexandrovitch) hand in the Frenchman's hand.

Stepan Arkadyevitch got up too, and opening his (Alexandrovitch) eyes wide, trying to wake himself up if he (Alexandrovitch) were asleep, he (Alexandrovitch) looked first at one and then at the other.

'' Not at home. '' It was all real. Stepan Arkadyevitch felt that his (Alexandrovitch) head was getting worse and worse. ''

Que la personne qui est arrivee la derniere, celle qui demande, qu'elle sorte! Qu'elle sorte!'' articulated the Frenchman, without opening his (Frenchman) eyes.

'' Vous m`excuserez, mais vous voyez.... Revenez vers dix heures, encore mieux demain.''

``Qu'elle sorte!'' (the Frenchman)
repeated the Frenchman impatiently. '' C'est moi, n'est-ce pas?''

And receiving an answer in the affirmative, Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgetting the favor he (Frenchman) had meant to ask of Lidia Ivanovna, and forgetting his (Frenchman) sister's affairs, caring for nothing, but filled with the sole desire to get away as soon as possible, went out on tiptoe and ran out into the street as though from a plague-stricken house.

At the French theater where he (Frenchman) arrived for the last act, and afterwards at the Tatar restaurant after his (Tatar) champagne, Stepan Arkadyevitch felt a little refreshed in the atmosphere he (Tatar) was used to.

For a long while he (Tatar) chatted and joked with his (Tatar) cab-driver, trying to recover his (Tatar) spirits. But still he (Tatar) felt quite unlike himself all that evening.

She (himself) wrote to him (Tatar) that she (himself) was very anxious to finish their interrupted conversation, and begged him (Tatar) to come next day.

He (Tatar) had scarcely read this note, and frowned at its contents, when he (Tatar) heard below the ponderous tramp of the servants, carrying something heavy.

On getting home to Pyotr Oblonsky's, where he (Tatar) was staying, Stepan Arkadyevitch found a note from Betsy. Stepan Arkadyevitch went out to look.

He (Tatar) was so drunk that he (Tatar) could not walk upstairs; but he (Tatar) told them to set him (Tatar) on his (Tatar) legs when he (Tatar) saw Stepan Arkadyevitch, and clinging to him (Tatar), walked with him (Tatar) into his (Tatar) room and there began telling him (Tatar) how he (Tatar) had spent the evening, and fell asleep doing so.

Stepan Arkadyevitch was in very low spirits, which happened rarely with him (Tatar), and for a long while he (Tatar) could not go to sleep.

Everything he (Tatar) could recall to his (Tatar) mind, everything was disgusting; but most disgusting of all, as if it were something shameful, was the memory of the evening he (Tatar) had spent at Countess Lidia Ivanovna's.

Next day he (Tatar) received from Alexey Alexandrovitch a final answer, refusing to grant Anna's divorce, and he (Tatar) understood that this decision was based on what the Frenchman had said in his (Frenchman) real or pretended trance.

In order to carry through any undertaking in family life, there must necessarily be either complete division between the husband and wife, or loving agreement.

When the relations of a couple are vacillating and neither one thing nor the other, no sort of enterprise can be undertaken.

Many families remain for years in the same place, though both husband and wife are sick of it, simply because there is neither complete division nor agreement between them.

Both Vronsky and Anna felt life in Moscow insupportable in the heat and dust, when the spring sunshine was followed by the glare of summer, and all the trees in the boulevards had long since been in full leaf, and the leaves were covered with dust.

But they did not go back to Vozdvizhenskoe, as they had arranged to do long before; they went on staying in Moscow, though they both loathed it, because of late there had been no agreement between them.

The irritability that kept them apart had no external cause, and all efforts to come to an understanding intensified it, instead of removing it.

It was an inner irritation, grounded in her (they) mind on the conviction that his (it) love had grown less; in his (it), on regret that he (it) had put himself for her (they) sake in a difficult position, which she (they), instead of lightening, made still more difficult.

Neither of them gave full utterance to their sense of grievance, but they considered each other in the wrong, and tried on every pretext to prove this to one another.

In her (they) eyes the whole of him (it), with all his (it) habits, ideas, desires, with all his (it) spiritual and physical temperament, was one thing--love for women, and that love, she (they) felt, ought to be entirely concentrated on her (they) alone.

That love was less; consequently, as she (they) reasoned, he (it) must have transferred part of his (it) love to other women or to another woman--and she (woman) was jealous.

It was the rejuvenated Pyotr Oblonsky. Chapter 23 She (woman) was jealous not of any particular woman but of the decrease of his (it) love.

Not having got an object for her (woman) jealousy, she (woman) was on the lookout for it. At the slightest hint she (woman) transferred her (woman) jealousy from one object to another.

At one time she (woman) was jealous of those low women with whom he (it) might so easily renew his (it) old bachelor ties; then she (woman) was jealous of the society women he (it) might meet; then she (woman) was jealous of the imaginary girl whom he (it) might want to marry, for whose sake he (it) would break with her (woman).

And this last form of jealousy tortured her (woman) most of all, especially as he (it) had unwarily told her (woman), in a moment of frankness, that his (it) mother knew him (it) so little that she (mother) had had the audacity to try and persuade him (it) to marry the young Princess Sorokina.

And being jealous of him (it), Anna was indignant against him (it) and found grounds for indignation in everything. For everything that was difficult in her (Anna) position she (Anna) blamed him (it).

The agonizing condition of suspense she (Anna) had passed in Moscow, the tardiness and indecision of Alexey Alexandrovitch, her (Anna) solitude --she (Anna) put it all down to him (Alexandrovitch).

If he (Alexandrovitch) had loved her (Anna) he (Alexandrovitch) would have seen all the bitterness of her (Anna) position, and would have rescued her (Anna) from it.

For her (Anna) being in Moscow and not in the country, he (Alexandrovitch) was to blame too. He (Alexandrovitch) could not live buried in the country as she (Anna) would have liked to do.

He (Alexandrovitch) must have society, and he (Alexandrovitch) had put her (Anna) in this awful position, the bitterness of which he (Alexandrovitch) would not see.

Even the rare moments of tenderness that came from time to time did not soothe her (Anna); in his (Alexandrovitch) tenderness now she (Anna) saw a shade of complacency, of self-confidence, which had not been of old, and which exasperated her (Anna).

And again, it was his (Alexandrovitch) fault that she (Anna) was forever separated from her (Anna) son. It was dusk. Anna was alone, and waiting for him (Alexandrovitch) to come back from a bachelor dinner.

She (Anna) walked up and down in his (Alexandrovitch) study -LRB-the room where the noise from the street was least heard-RRB-, and thought over every detail of their yesterday's quarrel.

Going back from the well-remembered, offensive words of the quarrel to what had been the ground of it, she (Anna) arrived at last at its origin.

For a long while she (Anna) could hardly believe that their dissension had arisen from a conversation so inoffensive, of so little moment to either.

But so it actually had been. It all arose from his (Alexandrovitch) laughing at the girls' high schools, declaring they were useless, while she (Anna) defended them.

He (Alexandrovitch) had spoken slightingly of women's education in general, and had said that Hannah, Anna's English proteg√©e, had not the slightest need to know anything of physics.

This irritated Anna. She (Anna) saw in this a contemptuous reference to her (Anna) occupations. And she (Anna) bethought her (Anna) of a phrase to pay him (Alexandrovitch) back for the pain he (Alexandrovitch) had given her (Anna).

I don't expect you to understand me, my feelings, as anyone who loved me might, but simple delicacy I did expect,'' she (Anna) said.

She (Anna) could not recall her (Anna) answer, but at that point, with an unmistakable desire to wound her (Anna) too, he (Alexandrovitch) had said:

``I feel no interest in your infatuation over this girl, that's true, because I see it's unnatural.

The cruelty with which he (Alexandrovitch) shattered the world she (girl) had built up for herself so laboriously to enable her (girl) to endure her (girl) hard life, the injustice with which he (Alexandrovitch) had accused her (girl) of affectation, of artificiality, aroused her (girl).

'' (he)

And he (Alexandrovitch) had actually flushed with vexation, and had said something unpleasant. '' '' I am very sorry that nothing

When he (Alexandrovitch) had come in to her (girl) yesterday evening, they had not referred to the quarrel, but both felt that the quarrel had been smoothed over, but was not at an end.

Today he (Alexandrovitch) had not been at home all day, and she (girl) felt so lonely and wretched in being on bad terms with him (Alexandrovitch) that she (girl) wanted to forget it all, to forgive him (Alexandrovitch), and be reconciled with him (Alexandrovitch); she (girl) wanted to throw the blame on herself and to justify him (Alexandrovitch).

but what's coarse and material is comprehensible and natural to you,'' she (girl) said and walked out of the room. '' I am myself to blame.

I'm irritable, I'm insanely jealous. I will make it up with him (Alexandrovitch), and we'll go away to the country ; there I shall be more at peace.''

She (girl) suddenly recalled the word that had stung her (girl) most of all, not so much the word itself as the intent to wound her (girl) with which it was said.

``Unnatural!'' (I)
'' I know what he (Alexandrovitch) meant; he (Alexandrovitch) meant-- unnatural, not loving my own daughter, to love another person's child. What does he (Alexandrovitch) know of love for children, of my love for Seryozha, whom I've sacrificed for him (Alexandrovitch)?

And perceiving that, while trying to regain her (daughter) peace of mind, she (daughter) had gone round the same circle that she (daughter) had been round so often before, and had come back to her (daughter) former state of exasperation, she (daughter) was horrified at herself.

But that wish to wound me! No, he (Alexandrovitch) loves another woman, it must be so. '' '' Can it be impossible?

Can it be beyond me to control myself? '' she (woman) said to herself, and began again from the beginning. '' He (Alexandrovitch)'s truthful, he (Alexandrovitch)'s honest, he (Alexandrovitch) loves me.

I love him (Alexandrovitch), and in a few days the divorce will come. What more do I want? I want peace of mind and trust, and I will take the blame on myself.

Yes, now when he (Alexandrovitch) comes in, I will tell him (Alexandrovitch) I was wrong, though I was not wrong, and we will go away tomorrow.

And to escape thinking any more, and being overcome by irritability, she (I) rang, and ordered the boxes to be brought up for packing their things for the country.

'' At ten o'clock Vronsky came in. Chapter 24

``Well, was it nice? '' (she)
she (I) asked, coming out to meet him (Alexandrovitch) with a penitent and meek expression.

He (Alexandrovitch) was used by now to these transitions, and he (Alexandrovitch) was particularly glad to see it today, as he (Alexandrovitch) was in a specially good humor himself.

'' Just as usual,'' he (Alexandrovitch) answered, seeing at a glance that she (I) was in one of her (I) good moods. '' What do I see?

Come, that's good! '' he (Alexandrovitch) said, pointing to the boxes in the passage. '' Yes, we must go. I went out for a drive, and it was so fine

I longed to be in the country. There's nothing to keep you, is there?'' '' It's the one thing I desire.

I'll be back directly, and we'll talk it over; I only want to change my coat. Order some tea. '' And he (Alexandrovitch) went into his (Alexandrovitch) room.

``Come, that's good,'' (a child)
as one says to a child when it leaves off being naughty, and still more mortifying was the contrast between her (I) penitent and his (Alexandrovitch) self-confident tone; and for one instant she (I) felt the lust of strife rising up in her (I) again, but making an effort she (I) conquered it, and met Vronsky as good-humoredly as before.

When he (Vronsky) came in she (I) told him (Vronsky), partly repeating phrases she (I) had prepared beforehand, how she (I) had spent the day, and her (I) plans for going away.

There was something mortifying in the way he (Vronsky) had said '' You know it came to me almost like an inspiration,'' she (I) said.

'' Why wait here for the divorce? Won't it be just the same in the country? I can't wait any longer!

I don't want to go on hoping, I don't want to hear anything about the divorce. I have made up my mind

it shall not have any more influence on my life. Do you agree?'' '' Oh, yes! '' he (Vronsky) said, glancing uneasily at her (I) excited face.

'' What did you do? Who was there? '' she (I) said, after a pause. Vronsky mentioned the names of the guests.

The dinner was first rate, and the boat race, and it was all pleasant enough, but in Moscow they can never do anything without something ridicule .

A lady of a sort appeared on the scene, teacher of swimming to the Queen of Sweden, and gave us an exhibition of her (Queen) skill.

'' ''

``How? did she (Queen) swim? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
asked Anna, frowning. '' In an absurd red costume de natation; she (Queen) was old and hideous too.

So when shall we go? ''

``What an absurd fancy! Why, did she (Queen) swim in some special way, then?'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
said Anna, not answering.

'' There was absolutely nothing in it. That's just what I say, it was awfully stupid. Well, then, when do you think of going?

'' Anna shook her (Anna) head as though trying to drive away some unpleasant idea. '' When? Why, the sooner the better!

The day after to-morrow's Sunday, I have to be at maman's,'' said Vronsky, embarrassed, because as soon as he (Queen) uttered his (Queen) mother's name he (Queen) was aware of her (mother) intent, suspicious eyes.

By tomorrow we shan't be ready. The day after tomorrow.'' '' Yes... oh, no, wait a minute! His (Queen) embarrassment confirmed her (mother) suspicion.

She (mother) flushed hotly and drew away from him (Queen). It was now not the Queen of Sweden's swimming-mistress who filled Anna's imagination, but the young Princess Sorokina.

She (Sorokina) was staying in a village near Moscow with Countess Vronskaya. '' Can't you go tomorrow? '' she (Countess) said. '' Well, no!

The deeds and the money for the business I'm going there for I can't get by tomorrow,'' he (Queen) answered. '' If so, we won't go at all.''

'' But why so?''

``I shall not go later. Monday or never! '' (unknown)
``What for?'' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, as though in amazement.

'' Why, there's no meaning in it!'' '' There's no meaning in it to you, because you care nothing for me.

You don't care to understand my life. The one thing that I cared for here was Hannah. You say it's affectation.

Why, you said yesterday that I don't love my daughter, that I love this English girl, that it's unnatural. I should like to know what life there is for me that could be natural!

For an instant she (girl) had a clear vision of what she (girl) was doing, and was horrified at how she (girl) had fallen away from her (girl) resolution.

But even though she (girl) knew it was her (girl) own ruin, she (girl) could not restrain herself, could not keep herself from proving to him (girl) that he (girl) was wrong, could not give way to him (girl).

'' '' I never said that; I said I did not sympathize with this sudden passion. ''

``How is it, though you boast of your straightforwardness, you don't tell the truth?'' (unknown)

``I never boast, and I never tell lies,'' (he)
he (girl) said slowly, restraining his (girl) rising anger. '' It's a great pity if you can't respect...

''

``Respect was invented to cover the empty place where love should be. And if you don't love me any more, it would be better and more honest to say so.'' (Vronsky)

'' cried Vronsky, getting up from his (girl) chair; and stopping short, facing her (it), he (girl) said, speaking deliberately:

``What do you try my patience for?

'' (he)

No, this is becoming unbearable! '' looking as though he (girl) might have said much more, but was restraining himself. ''

It has limits. '' '' What do you mean by that? '' she (it) cried, looking with terror at the undisguised hatred in his (girl) whole face, and especially in his (girl) cruel, menacing eyes.

'' I mean to say... '' he (girl) was beginning, but he (girl) checked himself. '' I must ask what it is you want of me?''

All I can want is that you should not desert me, as you think of doing,'' she (it) said, understanding all he (girl) had not uttered.

'' What can I want? '' But that I don't want; that's secondary. I want love, and there is none. So then all is over.

'' She (it) turned towards the door.

``Stop! sto-op! '' (Vronsky)
said Vronsky, with no change in the gloomy lines of his (girl) brows, though he (girl) held her (it) by the hand.

I said that we must put off going for three days, and on that you told me I was lying, that I was not an honorable man.''

Yes, and I repeat that the man who reproaches me with having sacrificed everything for me,'' she (it) said, recalling the words of a still earlier quarrel,

``that he (man)'s worse than a dishonorable

'' (she)

What is it all about? '' man-- he (man)'s a heartless man. '' '' Oh, there are limits to endurance! '' he (man) cried, and hastily let go her (it) hand.

He (man) hates me, that's clear,'' she (it) thought, and in silence, without looking round, she (it) walked with faltering steps out of the room.

'' '' He (man) loves another woman, that's even clearer,'' she (woman) said to herself as she (woman) went into her (woman) own room. ''

I want love, and there is none. So, then, all is over. '' She (woman) repeated the words she (woman) had said,

``and it must be ended.'' (she)

Thoughts of where she (woman) would go now, whether to the aunt who had brought her (woman) up, to Dolly, or simply alone abroad, and of what he (man) was doing now alone in his (man) study; whether this was the final quarrel, or whether reconciliation were still possible; and of what all her (woman) old friends at Petersburg would say of her (woman) now; and of how Alexey Alexandrovitch would look at it, and many other ideas of what would happen now after this rupture, came into her (woman) head; but she (woman) did not give herself up to them with all her (woman) heart.

At the bottom of her (woman) heart was some obscure idea that alone interested her (woman), but she (woman) could not get clear sight of it.

Thinking once more of Alexey Alexandrovitch, she (woman) recalled the time of her (woman) illness after her (woman) confinement, and the feeling which never left her (woman) at that time.

'' But how? '' she (woman) asked herself, and she (woman) sat down in a low chair before the looking glass. '' Why didn't I die?

'' and the words and the feeling of that time came back to her (woman). And all at once she (woman) knew what was in her (woman) soul.

And the shame and disgrace of Alexey Alexandrovitch and of Seryozha, and my awful shame, it will all be saved by death.

Yes, it was that idea which alone solved all. '' Yes, to die!... To die! and he (Alexandrovitch) will feel remorse; will be sorry; will love me; he (Alexandrovitch) will suffer on my account.

With the trace of a smile of commiseration for herself she (woman) sat down in the armchair, taking off and putting on the rings on her (woman) left hand, vividly picturing from different sides his (Alexandrovitch) feelings after her (woman) death.

'' Approaching footsteps--his (Alexandrovitch) steps--distracted her (woman) attention. As though absorbed in the arrangement of her (woman) rings, she (woman) did not even turn to him (Alexandrovitch).

He (Alexandrovitch) went up to her (woman), and taking her (woman) by the hand, said softly:

``Anna, we'll go the day after tomorrow, if you like.

I agree to everything. '' (her)

She (Anna) did not speak. '' What is it? '' he (Alexandrovitch) urged. '' You know,'' she (Anna) said, and at the same instant, unable to restrain herself any longer, she (Anna) burst into sobs.

``Cast me off!'' (she)
she (Anna) articulated between her (Anna) sobs. '' I'll go away tomorrow... I'll do more. What am I? An immoral woman!

A stone round your neck. I don't want to make you wretched, I don't want to! I'll set you free. You don't love me; you love someone else!''

Vronsky besought her (woman) to be calm, and declared that there was no trace of foundation for her (woman) jealousy; that he (your) had never ceased, and never would cease, to love her (woman); that he (your) loved her (woman) more than ever.

There was tenderness now in his (your) face, and she (woman) fancied she (woman) caught the sound of tears in his (your) voice, and she (woman) felt them wet on her (woman) hand.

'' Anna, why distress yourself and me so? '' he (your) said to her (woman), kissing her (woman) hands. And instantly Anna's despairing jealousy changed to a despairing passion of tenderness.

She (woman) put her (woman) arms round him (your), and covered with kisses his (your) head, his (your) neck, his (your) hands. Chapter 25 Feeling that the reconciliation was complete, Anna set eagerly to work in the morning preparing for their departure.

Though it was not settled whether they should go on Monday or Tuesday, as they had each given way to the other, Anna packed busily, feeling absolutely indifferent whether they went a day earlier or later.

She (Anna) was standing in her (Anna) room over an open box, taking things out of it, when he (your) came in to see her (Anna) earlier than usual, dressed to go out.

'' I'm going off at once to see maman; she (Anna) can send me the money by Yegorov. And I shall be ready to go tomorrow,'' he (your) said.

Though she (Anna) was in such a good mood, the thought of his (your) visit to his (your) mother's gave her (mother) a pang. ''

No, I shan't be ready by then myself,'' she (mother) said; and at once reflected,

``so then it was possible to arrange to do as I wished.'' (she)

It's only to turn out those things that aren't wanted,'' she (mother) said, putting something more on the heap of frippery that lay in Annushka's arms.

``No, do as you meant to do. Go into the dining room, I'm coming directly. Vronsky was eating his (Vronsky) beefsteak when she (mother) came into the dining- room.

'' (me)

You wouldn't believe how distasteful these rooms have become to me,'' she (mother) said, sitting down beside him (Vronsky) to her (mother) coffee.

'' There's nothing more awful than these chambres garnies . There's no individuality in them, no soul. These clocks, and curtains, and, worst of all, the wallpapers--they're a nightmare.

I think of Vozdvizhenskoe as the promised land. You're not sending the horses off yet?'' '' No, they will come after us.

Where are you going to?''

``I wanted to go to Wilson's to take some dresses to her (mother). So it's really to be tomorrow?

'' (she)

she (mother) said in a cheerful voice; but suddenly her (mother) face changed. Vronsky's valet came in to ask him (valet) to sign a receipt for a telegram from Petersburg.

There was nothing out of the way in Vronsky's getting a telegram, but he (valet) said, as though anxious to conceal something from her (mother), that the receipt was in his (valet) study, and he (valet) turned hurriedly to her (mother).

'' By tomorrow, without fail, I will finish it all.'' '' From whom is the telegram? '' she (mother) asked, not hearing him (valet). ''

From Stiva,'' he (valet) answered reluctantly. '' Why didn't you show it to me? What secret can there be between Stiva and me?

I didn't want to show it to you, because Stiva has such a passion for telegraphing: why telegraph when nothing is settled?''

'' Vronsky called the valet back, and told him (valet) to bring the telegram. ''

``About the divorce?'' (unknown)
'' Yes; but he (valet) says he (valet) has not been able to come at anything yet.

He (valet) has promised a decisive answer in a day or two. But here it is; read it. '' With trembling hands Anna took the telegram, and read what Vronsky had told her (Anna).

``I said yesterday that it's absolutely nothing to me when I get, or whether I never get, a divorce,'' (she)
she (Anna) said, flushing crimson.

'' There was not the slightest necessity to hide it from me.''

'' So he (Vronsky) may hide and does hide his (Vronsky) correspondence with women from me,'' she (Anna) thought. '' Yashvin meant to come this morning with Voytov,'' said Vronsky;

No,'' she (Anna) said, irritated by his (Yashvin) so obviously showing by this change of subject that he (Yashvin) was irritated, ``why did you suppose that this news would affect me so, that you must even try to hide it?

I said I don't want to consider it, and I should have liked you to care as little about it as I do.

``I believe he (Yashvin)'s won from Pyevtsov all and more than he (Yashvin) can pay, about sixty thousand.'' (unknown)
'' ''
``I care about it because I like definiteness,'' (he)
he (Yashvin) said.

Definiteness is not in the form but the love,'' she (Yashvin) said, more and more irritated, not by his (Yashvin) words, but by the tone of cool composure in which he (Yashvin) spoke.

'' '' What do you want it for?'' '' My God! love again,'' he (God) thought, frowning. '' Oh, you know what for; for your sake and your children's in the future.''

'' There won't be children in the future.'' '' That's a great pity,'' he (God) said. '' You want it for the children's sake, but you don't think of me?

'' she (you) said, quite forgetting or not having heard that he (God) had said, '' for your sake and the children's. ''

The question of the possibility of having children had long been a subject of dispute and irritation to her (you). His (God) desire to have children she (you) interpreted as a proof he (God) did not prize her (you) beauty.

Above all for your sake,'' he (God) repeated, frowning as though in pain,

``because I am certain that the greater part of your irritability comes from the indefiniteness of the position.'' (he)

Yes, now he (God) has laid aside all pretense, and all his (God) cold hatred for me is apparent,'' she (you) thought, not hearing his (God) words, but watching with terror the cold, cruel judge who looked mocking her (you) out of his (God) eyes.

The cause is not that,'' she (you) said,

``and, indeed, I don't see how the cause of my irritability, as you call it, can be that I am completely in your power.

'' (she)

he (God) interrupted, obstinately anxious to give utterance to his (God) thought.

'' Oh, I said: for your sake. '' '' What indefiniteness is there in the position? on the contrary... '' The indefiniteness consists in your imagining that I am free.''

``On that score you can set your mind quite at rest,'' (she)
she (you) said, and turning away from him (God), she (you) began drinking her (you) coffee.

After drinking a few sips she (you) glanced at him (God), and by his (God) expression, she (you) saw clearly that he (God) was repelled by her (you) hand, and her (you) gesture, and the sound made by her (you) lips.

I don't care in the least what your mother thinks, and what match she (you) wants to make for you,'' she (you) said, putting the cup down with a shaking hand.

She (you) lifted her (you) cup, with her (you) little finger held apart, and put it to her (you) lips. '' '' But we are not talking about that.''

And let me tell you that a heartless woman, whether she (woman)'s old or not old, your mother or anyone else, is of no consequence to me, and I would not consent to know her (woman).''

``Yes, that's just what we are talking about.

``Anna, I beg you not to speak disrespectfully of my mother.'' (A woman)
``A woman whose heart does not tell her (woman) where her (woman) son's happiness and honor lie has no heart.

``I repeat my request that you will not speak disrespectfully of my mother, whom I respect,'' (he)
he (son) said, raising his (son) voice and looking sternly at her (mother).

Looking intently at him (son), at his (son) face, his (son) hands, she (mother) recalled all the details of their reconciliation the previous day, and his (son) passionate caresses.

'' She (mother) did not answer. '' There, just such caresses he (son) has lavished, and will lavish, and longs to lavish on other women!

'' she (mother) thought. '' You don't love your mother. That's all talk, and talk, and talk! '' she (mother) said, looking at him (son) with hatred in her (mother) eyes.

``Must decide, and I have decided,'' (she)
she (mother) said, and she (mother) would have gone away, but at that moment Yashvin walked into the room.

Why, when there was a tempest in her (mother) soul, and she (mother) felt she (mother) was standing at a turning point in her (mother) life, which might have fearful consequences--why, at that minute, she (mother) had to keep up appearances before an outsider, who sooner or later must know it all--she (mother) did not know.

'' Even if so, you must...'' Anna greeted him (outsider) and remained. But at once quelling the storm within her (Anna), she (Anna) sat down and began talking to their guest.

'' Well, how are you getting on? Has your debt been paid you? '' she (Anna) asked Yashvin. '' Oh, pretty fair; I fancy I shan't get it all, but I shall get a good half.

And when are you off?'' said Yashvin, looking at Vronsky, and unmistakably guessing at a quarrel. '' The day after tomorrow, I think,'' said Vronsky.

But now it's quite decided,'' said Anna, looking Vronsky straight in the face with a look which told him (Yashvin) not to dream of the possibility of reconciliation.

'' You've been meaning to go so long, though.'' '' '' Don't you feel sorry for that unlucky Pyevtsov? '' she (Anna) went on, talking to Yashvin.

'' I've never asked myself the question, Anna Arkadyevna, whether I'm sorry for him (Yashvin) or not. You see, all my fortune's here''--he (Yashvin) touched his (Yashvin) breast pocket--

``and just now I'm a wealthy man.

You see, whoever sits down to play with me--he (Yashvin) wants to leave me without a shirt to my back, and so do I him (Yashvin).

But today I'm going to the club, and I may come out a beggar. And so we fight it out, and that's the pleasure of it.

'' (he)

'' Well, but suppose you were married,'' said Anna,
``how would it be for your wife? '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
Yashvin laughed. ''

That's why I'm not married, and never mean to be.''

``And Helsingfors?'' (Vronsky/Alexey Vronsky/Alexey)
said Vronsky, entering into the conversation and glancing at Anna's smiling face.

Meeting his (Vronsky) eyes, Anna's face instantly took a coldly severe expression as though she (Anna) were saying to him (Vronsky):

``It's not forgotten.

It's all the same.'' (him)

``Were you really in love? '' (she)
she (Anna) said to Yashvin. '' Oh heavens! ever so many times!

But you see, some men can play but only so that they can always lay down their cards when the hour of a rendezvous comes, while I can take up love, but only so as not to be late for my cards in the evening.

That's how I manage things.'' '' No, I didn't mean that, but the real thing. '' She (Anna) would have said Helsingfors , but would not repeat the word used by Vronsky.

Voytov, who was buying the horse, came in. Anna got up and went out of the room. Before leaving the house, Vronsky went into her (Anna) room.

She (Anna) would have pretended to be looking for something on the table, but ashamed of making a pretense, she (Anna) looked straight in his (I) face with cold eyes.

'' What do you want? '' she (Anna) asked in French. '' To get the guarantee for Gambetta, I've sold him (I),'' he (I) said, in a tone which said more clearly than words,

``I've no time for discussing things, and it would lead to nothing. '' (he)
'' I'm not to blame in any way,'' he (I) thought.

'' If she (Anna) will punish herself, tant pis pour elle. '' But as he (I) was going he (I) fancied that she (Anna) said something, and his (I) heart suddenly ached with pity for her (Anna).

'' Eh, Anna? '' he (I) queried. '' I said nothing,'' she (Anna) answered just as coldly and calmly. '' Oh, nothing, tant pis then,'' he (I) thought, feeling cold again, and he (I) turned and went out.

He (I) even wanted to stop and to say some comforting word to her (Anna), but his (I) legs carried him (I) out of the room before he (I) could think what to say.

The whole of that day he (I) spent away from home, and when he (I) came in late in the evening the maid told him (I) that Anna Arkadyevna had a headache and begged him (I) not to go in to her (Arkadyevna).

As he (I) was going out he (I) caught a glimpse in the looking glass of her (Arkadyevna) face, white, with quivering lips. Chapter 26

Never before had a day been passed in quarrel. Today was the first time. And this was not a quarrel. It was the open acknowledgment of complete coldness.

Was it possible to glance at her (Arkadyevna) as he (I) had glanced when he (I) came into the room for the guarantee?--to look at her (Arkadyevna), see her (Arkadyevna) heart was breaking with despair, and go out without a word with that face of callous composure?

And remembering all the cruel words he (I) had said, Anna supplied, too, the words that he (I) had unmistakably wished to say and could have said to her (Anna), and she (Anna) grew more and more exasperated.

He (I) was not merely cold to her (Anna), he (I) hated her (Anna) because he (I) loved another woman--that was clear. '' I won't prevent you,'' he (I) might say.

'' You can go where you like. You were unwilling to be divorced from your husband, no doubt so that you might go back to him (husband).

All the most cruel words that a brutal man could say, he (man) said to her (Anna) in her (Anna) imagination, and she (Anna) could not forgive him (man) for them, as though he (man) had actually said them.

Go back to him (man). If you want money, I'll give it to you. How many roubles do you want? '' ''

But didn't he (man) only yesterday swear he (man) loved me, he (man), a truthful and sincere man? Haven't I despaired for nothing many times already?

All that day, except for the visit to Wilson's, which occupied two hours, Anna spent in doubts whether everything were over or whether there were still hope of reconciliation, whether she (Anna) should go away at once or see him (Wilson) once more.

She (Anna) was expecting him (Wilson) the whole day, and in the evening, as she (Anna) went to her (Anna) own room, leaving a message for him (Wilson) that her (Anna) head ached, she (Anna) said to herself,

``If he (Wilson) comes in spite of what the maid says, it means that he (Wilson) loves me still.

'' (she)

she (maid) said to herself afterwards. If not, it means that all is over, and then I will decide what I'm to do!...

In the evening she (maid) heard the rumbling of his (Wilson) carriage stop at the entrance, his (Wilson) ring, his (Wilson) steps and his (Wilson) conversation with the servant; he (Wilson) believed what was told him (Wilson), did not care to find out more, and went to his (Wilson) own room.

And death rose clearly and vividly before her (maid) mind as the sole means of bringing back love for her (maid) in his (Wilson) heart, of punishing him (Wilson) and of gaining the victory in that strife which the evil spirit in possession of her (maid) heart was waging with him (Wilson).

Now nothing mattered: going or not going to Vozdvizhenskoe, getting or not getting a divorce from her (maid) husband--all that did not matter.

When she (maid) poured herself out her (maid) usual dose of opium, and thought that she (maid) had only to drink off the whole bottle to die, it seemed to her (maid) so simple and easy, that she (maid) began musing with enjoyment on how he (husband) would suffer, and repent and love her (maid) memory when it would be too late.

She (maid) lay in bed with open eyes, by the light of a single burned-down candle, gazing at the carved cornice of the ceiling and at the shadow of the screen that covered part of it, while she (maid) vividly pictured to herself how he (husband) would feel when she (maid) would be no more, when she (maid) would be only a memory to him (husband).

'' So then everything was over. The one thing that mattered was punishing him (husband). '' How could I say such cruel things to her (maid)?

'' he (husband) would say. '' How could I go out of the room without saying anything to her (maid)? But now she (maid) is no more.

'' Suddenly the shadow of the screen wavered, pounced on the whole cornice, the whole ceiling; other shadows from the other side swooped to meet it, for an instant the shadows flitted back, but then with fresh swiftness they darted forward, wavered, commingled, and all was darkness.

And such horror came upon her (maid) that for a long while she (maid) could not realize where she (maid) was, and for a long while her (maid) trembling hands could not find the matches and light another candle, instead of the one that had burned down and gone out.

She (maid) has gone away from us forever. She (maid) is...

``Death! '' (She)
she (maid) thought. '' No, anything--only to live! Why, I love him (maid)!

This has been before and will pass,'' she (maid) said, feeling that tears of joy at the return to life were trickling down her (maid) cheeks.

Why, he (maid) loves me! And to escape from her (maid) panic she (maid) went hurriedly to his (maid) room. He (maid) was asleep there, and sleeping soundly.

Now when he (maid) was asleep, she (maid) loved him (maid) so that at the sight of him (maid) she (maid) could not keep back tears of tenderness.

But she (maid) knew that if he (maid) waked up he (maid) would look at her (maid) with cold eyes, convinced that he (maid) was right, and that before telling him (maid) of her (maid) love, she (maid) would have to prove to him (maid) that he (maid) had been wrong in his (maid) treatment of her (maid).

Without waking him (maid), she (maid) went back, and after a second dose of opium she (maid) fell towards morning into a heavy, incomplete sleep, during which she (maid) never quite lost consciousness.

In the morning she (maid) was waked by a horrible nightmare, which had recurred several times in her (maid) dreams, even before her (maid) connection with Vronsky.

A little old man with unkempt beard was doing something bent down over some iron, muttering meaningless French words, and she (maid), as she (maid) always did in this nightmare -LRB-it was what made the horror of it-RRB-, felt that this peasant was taking no notice of her (maid), but was doing something horrible with the iron-- over her (maid).

She (maid) went up to him (peasant), and holding the light above his (peasant) face, she (maid) gazed a long while at him (peasant). And she (maid) waked up in a cold sweat.

When she (maid) got up, the previous day came back to her (maid) as though veiled in mist. '' There was a quarrel.

Just what has happened several times. I said I had a headache, and he (peasant) did not come in to see me.

Tomorrow we're going away; I must see him (peasant) and get ready for the journey,'' she (maid) said to herself. And learning that he (peasant) was in his (peasant) study, she (maid) went down to him (peasant).

As she (maid) passed through the drawing room she (maid) heard a carriage stop at the entrance, and looking out of the window she (maid) saw the carriage, from which a young girl in a lilac hat was leaning out giving some direction to the footman ringing the bell.

After a parley in the hall, someone came upstairs, and Vronsky's steps could be heard passing the drawing room. He (footman) went rapidly downstairs.

Anna went again to the window. She (Anna) saw him (footman) come out onto the steps without his (footman) hat and go up to the carriage.

The young girl in the lilac hat handed him (footman) a parcel. Vronsky, smiling, said something to her (girl). The carriage drove away, he (footman) ran rapidly upstairs again.

The mists that had shrouded everything in her (girl) soul parted suddenly. The feelings of yesterday pierced the sick heart with a fresh pang.

She (girl) could not understand now how she (girl) could have lowered herself by spending a whole day with him (footman) in his (footman) house.

She (girl) went into his (footman) room to announce her (girl) determination. '' That was Madame Sorokina and her (girl) daughter. They came and brought me the money and the deeds from maman.

I couldn't get them yesterday. How is your head, better? '' he (footman) said quietly, not wishing to see and to understand the gloomy and solemn expression of her (girl) face.

She (girl) looked silently, intently at him (footman), standing in the middle of the room. He (footman) glanced at her (girl), frowned for a moment, and went on reading a letter.

He (footman) still might have turned her (girl) back, but she (girl) had reached the door, he (footman) was still silent, and the only sound audible was the rustling of the note paper as he (footman) turned it.

Oh, by the way,'' he (footman) said at the very moment she (girl) was in the doorway,

``we're going tomorrow for certain, aren't we?'' (she)

She (girl) turned, and went deliberately out of the room. ''

``You, but not I,'' (she)
she (girl) said, turning round to him (footman). ''

Anna, we can't go on like this... ''

``You, but not I,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
she (Anna) repeated. '' This is getting unbearable!'' '' You...you will be sorry for this,'' she (Anna) said, and went out.

Frightened by the desperate expression with which these words were uttered, he (footman) jumped up and would have run after her (Anna), but on second thoughts he (footman) sat down and scowled, setting his (footman) teeth.

I've tried everything,'' he (footman) thought;

``the only thing left is not to pay attention,'' (he)
and he (footman) began to get ready to drive into town, and again to his (footman) mother's to get her (mother) signature to the deeds.

This vulgar--as he (footman) thought it --threat of something vague exasperated him (footman). '' She (mother) heard the sound of his (footman) steps about the study and the dining room.

But he (footman) did not turn in to see her (mother), he (footman) merely gave an order that the horse should be given to Voytov if he (footman) came while he (footman) was away.

At the drawing room he (footman) stood still. Then she (mother) heard the carriage brought round, the door opened, and he (footman) came out again.

But he (footman) went back into the porch again, and someone was running upstairs. It was the valet running up for his (footman) gloves that had been forgotten.

She (mother) went to the window and saw him (footman) take the gloves without looking, and touching the coachman on the back he (footman) said something to him (footman).

Then without looking up at the window he (footman) settled himself in his (footman) usual attitude in the carriage, with his (footman) legs crossed, and drawing on his (footman) gloves he (footman) vanished round the corner.

Anna said to herself, standing at the window; and in answer to this statement the impression of the darkness when the candle had flickered out, and of her (Anna) fearful dream mingling into one, filled her (Anna) heart with cold terror.

Chapter 27 '' He (footman) has gone! It is over!'' '' No, that cannot be! '' she (Anna) cried, and crossing the room she (Anna) rang the bell.

She (Anna) was so afraid now of being alone, that without waiting for the servant to come in, she (Anna) went out to meet him (servant).

'' Inquire where the count has gone,'' she (Anna) said. The servant answered that the count had gone to the stable. ''

His (servant) honor left word that if you cared to drive out, the carriage would be back immediately. ''

``Very good. Wait a minute.

I'll write a note at once. Send Mihail with the note to the stables. Make haste. '' (She)

She (Anna) sat down and wrote:
``I was wrong.

Come back home; I must explain. For God's sake come! I'm afraid. '' (She)

She (Anna) sealed it up and gave it to the servant.

She (Anna) was afraid of being left alone now; she (Anna) followed the servant out of the room, and went to the nursery.

'' was her (Anna) first thought when she (Anna) saw her (Anna) chubby, rosy little girl with her (Anna) black, curly hair instead of Seryozha, whom in the tangle of her (Anna) ideas she (Anna) had expected to see in the nursery.

The little girl sitting at the table was obstinately and violently battering on it with a cork, and staring aimlessly at her (Anna) mother with her (Anna) pitch-black eyes.

Answering the English nurse that she (Anna) was quite well, and that she (Anna) was going to the country tomorrow, Anna sat down by the little girl and began spinning the cork to show her (Anna).

But the child's loud, ringing laugh, and the motion of her (Anna) eyebrows, recalled Vronsky so vividly that she (Anna) got up hurriedly, restraining her (Anna) sobs, and went away.

'' Why, this isn't it, this isn't he (Anna)! Where are his (Anna) blue eyes, his (Anna) sweet, shy smile? '' Can it be all over?

No, it cannot be! '' she (Anna) thought. '' He (Anna) will come back. But how can he (Anna) explain that smile, that excitement after he (Anna) had been talking to her (Anna)?

But even if he (Anna) doesn't explain, I will believe. If I don't believe, there's only one thing left for me, and I can't.

'' She (Anna) looked at her (Anna) watch. Twenty minutes had passed. '' By now he (Anna) has received the note and is coming back.

Not long, ten minutes more.... But what if he (Anna) doesn't come? No, that cannot be. He (Anna) mustn't see me with tear-stained eyes.

I'll go and wash. Yes, yes; did I do my hair or not? '' she (Anna) asked herself. And she (Anna) could not remember.

She (Anna) felt her (Anna) head with her (Anna) hand. '' Yes, my hair has been done, but when I did it I can't in the least remember.

She (Anna) could not believe the evidence of her (Anna) hand, and went up to the pier glass to see whether she (Anna) really had done her (Anna) hair.

she (Anna) thought, looking in the looking glass at the swollen face with strangely glittering eyes, that looked in a scared way at her (Anna).

'' She (Anna) certainly had, but she (Anna) could not think when she (Anna) had done it. '' Who's that?'' '' Why, it's I!

she (Anna) suddenly understood, and looking round, she (Anna) seemed all at once to feel his (Anna) kisses on her (Anna), and twitched her (Anna) shoulders, shuddering.

'' Then she (Anna) lifted her (Anna) hand to her (Anna) lips and kissed it. '' What is it? Why, I'm going out of my mind!''

Annushka,'' she (Anna) said, coming to a standstill before her (Anna), and she (Anna) stared at the maid, not knowing what to say to her (Anna).

and she (Anna) went into her (Anna) bedroom, where Annushka was tidying the room. '' '' You meant to go and see Darya Alexandrovna,'' said the girl, as though she (girl) understood.

'' Darya Alexandrovna? Yes, I'll go. '' '' Fifteen minutes there, fifteen minutes back. He (I)'s coming, he (I)'ll be here soon. ''

She (girl) took out her (girl) watch and looked at it. '' But how could he (I) go away, leaving me in such a state?

How can he (I) live, without making it up with me? '' She (girl) went to the window and began looking into the street.

But her (girl) calculations might be wrong, and she (girl) began once more to recall when he (I) had started and to count the minutes.

At the moment when she (girl) had moved away to the big clock to compare it with her (girl) watch, someone drove up.

Judging by the time, he (I) might be back now. Glancing out of the window, she (girl) saw his (I) carriage. But no one came upstairs, and voices could be heard below.

It was the messenger who had come back in the carriage. She (girl) went down to him (I). '' We didn't catch the count.

The count had driven off on the lower city road. '' '' What do you say? What!... '' she (girl) said to the rosy, good-humored Mihail, as he (I) handed her (girl) back her (girl) note.

Go with this note to Countess Vronskaya's place, you know? and bring an answer back immediately,'' she (girl) said to the messenger.

'' Why, then, he (I) has never received it! '' she (girl) thought. '' '' And I, what am I going to do?

'' she (girl) thought. '' Yes, I'm going to Dolly's , that's true or else I shall go out of my mind.

Yes, and I can telegraph, too. '' And she (Dolly) wrote a telegram. '' I absolutely must talk to you; come at once.

'' After sending off the telegram, she (Dolly) went to dress. When she (Dolly) was dressed and in her (Dolly) hat, she (Dolly) glanced again into the eyes of the plump, comfortable-looking Annushka.

There was unmistakable sympathy in those good-natured little gray eyes. '' Annushka, dear, what am I to do?'' said Anna, sobbing and sinking helplessly into a chair.

'' Why fret yourself so, Anna Arkadyevna? Why, there's nothing out of the way. You drive out a little, and it'll cheer you up,'' said the maid.

'' Yes, I'm going,'' said Anna, rousing herself and getting up. '' And if there's a telegram while I'm away, send it on to Darya Alexandrovna's...

Yes, I mustn't think, I must do something, drive somewhere, and most of all, get out of this house,'' she (Anna) said, feeling with terror the strange turmoil going on in her (Anna) own heart, and she (Anna) made haste to go out and get into the carriage.

but no, I shall be back myself.'' '' '' Where to?'' asked Pyotr before getting onto the box. '' To Znamenka, the Oblonskys'.

'' Chapter 28 It was bright and sunny. A fine rain had been falling all the morning, and now it had not long cleared up.

The iron roofs, the flags of the roads, the flints of the pavements, the wheels and leather, the brass and the tinplate of the carriages--all glistened brightly in the May sunshine.

As she (It) sat in a corner of the comfortable carriage, that hardly swayed on its supple springs, while the grays trotted swiftly, in the midst of the unceasing rattle of wheels and the changing impressions in the pure air, Anna ran over the events of the last days, and she (Anna) saw her (Anna) position quite differently from how it had seemed at home.

Now the thought of death seemed no longer so terrible and so clear to her (Anna), and death itself no longer seemed so inevitable.

It was three o'clock, and the very liveliest time in the streets. Now she (Anna) blamed herself for the humiliation to which she (Anna) had lowered herself.

'' I entreat him (it) to forgive me. I have given in to him (it). I have owned myself in fault. What for?

Can't I live without him (it)? '' And leaving unanswered the question how she (Anna) was going to live without him (it), she (Anna) fell to reading the signs on the shops.

``Office and warehouse. Dental surgeon. Yes, I'll tell Dolly all about it. She (Dolly) doesn't like Vronsky. I shall be sick and ashamed, but I'll tell her (Dolly).

She (Dolly) loves me, and I'll follow her (Dolly) advice. I won't give in to him (surgeon); I won't let him (surgeon) train me as he (surgeon) pleases.

Filippov, bun shop. They say they send their dough to Petersburg. The Moscow water is so good for it. Ah, the springs at Mitishtchen, and the pancakes!

And she (Dolly) remembered how, long, long ago, when she (Dolly) was a girl of seventeen, she (Dolly) had gone with her (Dolly) aunt to Troitsa.

How much that seemed to me then splendid and out of reach has become worthless, while what I had then has gone out of my reach forever!

'' (unknown)

'' Riding, too. Was that really me, with red hands? Could I ever have believed then that I could come to such humiliation?

How conceited and self-satisfied he (girl) will be when he (girl) gets my note! But I will show him (girl).... How horrid that paint smells!

Why is it they're always painting and building? Modes et robes, '' she (my) read. A man bowed to her (my). It was Annushka's husband.

'' Our parasites''; she (my) remembered how Vronsky had said that. '' Our? Why our? What's so awful is that one can't tear up the past by its roots.

And then she (my) thought of her (my) past with Alexey Alexandrovitch, of how she (my) had blotted the memory of it out of her (my) life.

One can't tear it out, but one can hide one's memory of it. And I'll hide it. '' '' Dolly will think I'm leaving my second husband, and so I certainly must be in the wrong.

As if I cared to be right! I can't help it! '' she (Dolly) said, and she (Dolly) wanted to cry. But at once she (Dolly) fell to wondering what those two girls could be smiling about.

'' Love, most likely. They don't know how dreary it is, how low.... The boulevard and the children. Three boys running, playing at horses.

Seryozha! And I'm losing everything and not getting him (husband) back. Yes, I'm losing everything, if he (husband) doesn't return. Perhaps he (husband) was late for the train and has come back by now.

Longing for humiliation again! '' she (Dolly) said to herself. '' No, I'll go to Dolly, and say straight out to her (Dolly),

I'm unhappy , I deserve this, I'm to blame, but still I'm unhappy, help me. These horses, this carriage--how loathsome I am to myself in this carriage--all his (husband); but I won't see them again.

Thinking over the words in which she (Dolly) would tell Dolly, and mentally working her (Dolly) heart up to great bitterness, Anna went upstairs.

'' '' Is there anyone with her (Anna)? '' she (Anna) asked in the hall.

``Katerina Alexandrovna Levin,'' (the footman)
answered the footman. '' Kitty!

Kitty, whom Vronsky was in love with!'' thought Anna,

``the girl he (Vronsky) thinks of with love. He (Vronsky)'s sorry he (Vronsky) didn't marry her (girl).

But me he (Vronsky) thinks of with hatred, and is sorry he (Vronsky) had anything to do with me. '' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)

The sisters were having a consultation about nursing when Anna called.

Dolly went down alone to see the visitor who had interrupted their conversation. '' Well, so you've not gone away yet?

I meant to have come to you,'' she (Dolly) said;

``I had a letter from Stiva today.'' (she)
``We had a telegram too,'' (Anna/Anna Arkadyevna)
answered Anna, looking round for Kitty.

He (visitor) writes that he (visitor) can't make out quite what Alexey Alexandrovitch wants, but he (Alexandrovitch) won't go away without a decisive answer.''

''

``I thought you had someone with you. Can I see the letter?'' (unknown)
'' Yes; Kitty,'' said Dolly, embarrassed. '' She (Dolly) stayed in the nursery.

She (Dolly) has been very ill.'' '' So I heard. May I see the letter?''

``I'll get it directly. But he (Alexandrovitch) doesn't refuse; on the contrary, Stiva has hopes,'' (Dolly)
said Dolly, stopping in the doorway.

'' I haven't, and indeed I don't wish it,'' said Anna. '' What's this? Does Kitty consider it degrading to meet me?'' thought Anna when she (Anna) was alone.

'' Perhaps she (Anna)'s right, too. But it's not for her (Anna), the girl who was in love with Vronsky, it's not for her (Anna) to show me

that, even if it is true. I know that in my position I can't be received by any decent woman. I knew that from the first moment I sacrificed everything to him (I).

And this is my reward! Oh, how I hate him (I)! And what did I come here for? I'm worse here, more miserable.

'' She (woman) heard from the next room the sisters' voices in consultation. '' And what am I going to say to Dolly now?

Amuse Kitty by the sight of my wretchedness, submit to her (Kitty) patronizing? No; and besides, Dolly wouldn't understand. And it would be no good

It would only be interesting to see Kitty, to show her (Kitty) how I despise everyone and everything, how nothing matters to me now.

my telling her (Kitty). '' Dolly came in with the letter. Anna read it and handed it back in silence. '' I knew all that,'' she (Anna) said,

``and it doesn't interest me in the least.'' (she)

'' Oh, why so? On the contrary, I have hopes,'' said Dolly, looking inquisitively at Anna. She (Dolly) had never seen her (Dolly) in such a strangely irritable condition.
